                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                       AUGUST 3, 1999 Tuesday SF EDITION

PARTS OF PA., 5 OTHER STATES DECLARED DISASTER AREAS FARMERS WHO HAVE LOST AT
LEAST 30 PERCENT OF THEIR INCOME BECAUSE OF THE DROUGHT CAN RECEIVE LOW-INTEREST
LOANS.

BYLINE: Mark Jaffe and Gail Gibson, INQUIRER STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A03

LENGTH: 847 words


Prompted by withering crops and plummeting dairy production, the Clinton
administration yesterday declared parts of Pennsylvania and five other states
agricultural disaster areas.

The move will enable farmers who have lost at least 30 percent of their income,
as a result of the summer's searing drought, to draw up to $500,000 in
low-interest loans.

The disaster declaration covers 88 counties in parts of Pennsylvania, Ohio,
Kentucky, West Virginia, Virginia and Maryland.

Only four Western Pennsylvania counties are included: Fayette, Beaver, Green and
Washington.

But Robert Bunty, a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture,
said that "damage reports are being compiled from around the state . . . and
more counties will probably be added."

"Drought has affected everything from dairy farms to Christmas tree farms," said
Wilson Smeltz, a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Farm Bureau. "Everyone is
suffering."

In corn alone, the state's losses will add up to $100 million, according to Greg
Roth, a professor of agronomy at Pennsylvania State University.

The administration's response to what is being called the region's worst drought
since the 1930s comes as Congress is preparing its own national farm-aid
package.

But the congressional action is prompted not by farmers unable to grow enough,
but rather because most farms are growing too much.

While Eastern farmers are seeing their crops shrivel, Midwestern fields have
produced a glut of grain and soybeans that has driven down market prices.

The result is the most severe financial crisis on American farms since the
1980s, when farm failures rocked America and forced thousands of farmers off the
land.

Last week, farm-state Democrats proposed a $9.9 billion aid package to assist
farmers crippled by market prices and drought.

Senate Republican leaders are working on a measure of their own. But at least
one key Republican, Indiana Sen. Richard G. Lugar, said it was too soon to act.
Lugar, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, instead wants to hold three
days of hearings to better understand the problems.

He set the first hearing for today, with Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman
scheduled to testify one day after touring drought-stricken farms in West
Virginia and Maryland.

Both Democrats and Republicans in Congress say they are frustrated by the
President's failure to lay out his own detailed emergency-aid proposal. The
White House suggested last week that Congress try to fix the 1996 Freedom to
Farm Bill before deciding on emergency aid.

Clinton asserted in his radio address Saturday that the 1996 bill, which
provides only limited subsidy aid, "simply does not do enough to help our
farmers and ranchers cope in hard times."

The 1996 bill removed most controls on what farmers grow, allowing them to
switch crops in pursuit of profits. In return, the farmers agreed to receive
only limited subsidies. But bad weather and markets have prompted Congress to
offer emergency farm aid year after year. Last year, Congress provided a record
$5.9 billion in such aid.

Lugar said he hoped this week's Senate hearings would draw the White House into
crafting a bipartisan plan. But even if the Senate acts, no farm-aid vote is
scheduled in the House, and Clinton is unlikely to sign emergency-aid
legislation before the fall.

Compared with a decade ago, farm prices are incredibly low, said Steve Riggins,
a University of Kentucky grain marketing specialist.

Soybean prices, more than $7 per bushel as recently as two years ago, might be
less than $4 this fall - their lowest price since the early 1970s, Riggins said.
Corn prices reached record highs around $5 per bushel in 1996, but now they
could come in under $2. Nationally, the U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates
that net farm income for the major crops will be $7 billion below the average
income for 1993-97 period - a 29 percent drop. Farm exports are expected to be
down 19 percent from 1996 levels.

The low prices generally are attributed to abundant grain harvests that have
coincided with a depressed global demand for food after last year's financial
collapses in Russia and Southeast Asia.

Penn State's Roth said that Pennsylvania farmers laboring under both low market
prices and a drought were facing a double whammy. "Not only are the yields going
to be low, but so are the prices," he said. "It can't be much worse."

This year's federal farm-relief package would be unique because it is likely to
be tied primarily to price drops instead of to weather. That fact underscores
White House concerns that the 1996 Farm Bill just isn't working.

For many in Congress and on the farm, when this year's aid package is passed
matters almost as much as what is in it.

Kentucky Agriculture Commissioner Billy Ray Smith said farmers could not make
financial plans or adjustments until they knew specifically what federal aid
might come. A check that arrives in the mail months from now, Smith said, "would
be kind of after the fact."

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Modesto Bee (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 21, 2007 Sunday

Officials seek aid for farm damage: Stanislaus County estimates $3M in crops
lost to cold snap

BYLINE: Rosalio Ahumada, The Modesto Bee, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 590 words


Jan. 21--Stanislaus County and state officials declared a state of emergency to
give farmers and agriculture-related businesses a chance to recuperate after a
freezing week of low temperatures ruined crops across the state.

About $3 million in damage to citrus, broccoli and spinach crops in Stanislaus
County were left in the wake. Those are early estimates and county officials
said the complete extent of the damage has not been determined.

"Some of the damage won't be known for days or weeks," said Milton O'Haire,
assistant agriculture commissioner for Stanislaus County. "We expect to see more
damage."

Gov. Schwarzenegger on Saturday added Stanislaus to the list of counties under
the state of emergency.

The declaration allows the state, on behalf of farmers with crop damage, to
request assistance for federal aid from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and
the Small Business Administration.

Along with the federal funding, the declaration increases the opportunity for
farmers to get low-interest loans or grants to supplement their financial
losses, O'Haire said.

"It opens the doors, at least," he said. "But nothing is guaranteed."

Within the past week, the governor's office extended the emergency declaration
to 15 other counties: Merced, Madera, Fresno, Kern, Tulare, Kings, Imperial, San
Bernardino, San Diego, Santa Clara, Riverside, Monterey, San Luis Obispo, Santa
Barbara and Ventura. Additional counties could be added.

In Stanislaus County, spinach was hit the hardest when temperatures dipped into
the 20s.

According to the county Agriculture Commissioner's Office, the freeze caused an
estimated $1.32 million in damage to 1,720 acres of spinach grown in the county.

An estimated $908,700 in damage was inflicted on 1,070 acres of broccoli.

In the 352 acres of citrus grown in Stanislaus County, which includes lemons,
grapefruits and a variety of oranges, $859,100 in damage has been estimated.

"It's a little worse than we initially thought," O'Haire said. "We didn't know
how cold it was going to stay."

The forecast over the next few days calls for lows in the 30s.

O'Haire said the freeze damage could throw off planting cycles for some crops,
such as young alfalfa set for harvesting in the spring.

On Friday, county Chief Executive Officer Rick Robinson announced Stanislaus'
state of emergency declaration -- the first step in seeking state and federal
aid.

That was followed by the county Office of Emergency Services' request for aid,
said Gary Hinshaw, the county fire warden and assistant director of emergency
services.

"We don't know how much has been impacted," Hinshaw said. "We wanted to also
consider those agriculture industry-related businesses. We did a broad-brush
request."

Hinshaw said county officials are determining the initial damage estimates,
which could be completed by Tuesday.

Labor losses at produce packaging facilities and other agriculture-related
businesses could push those damage estimates higher, O'Haire said.

"There are already some harvesting crews laid-off, at least temporarily,"
O'Haire said. "We don't have any numbers yet on the labor losses. It all depends
on how bad the damage is to the crops."

Bee staff writer Rosalio Ahumada can be reached at 578-2394 or
rahumada@modbee.com.

Copyright (c) 2007, The Modesto Bee, Calif. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune
Business News. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call

                               The New York Times

                 August 1, 1998, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Big Aid Bill Likely for Farmers Hurt by Drought and Rain

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 482 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31


Though most highly productive farm regions seem to be on the way to bumper
crops, the drought in Texas and Oklahoma and the excess rain in the Upper
Midwest are now expected to require an emergency aid package topping $1 billion.

Earlier this month, the Senate approved $500 million in disaster aid, about half
of which would probably go to the Dakotas and Minnesota. With the drought
growing worse in Texas, Oklahoma and parts of the Southeast, Congress is
expected to increase the assistance before adjourning in October.

But on Thursday, Representative Larry Combest, Republican of Texas, said: "I
think we're talking about substantially more. We're looking at at least twice
that number and maybe more."

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman told the House Agriculture Committee that the
Agriculture Department would soon revise its estimate of the costs in the
affected areas. Mr. Glickman said revision would come after the release of the
Aug. 12 crop production figures, which rely on actual field surveys of crops to
be harvested in the fall.

A Texas A&M University study has estimated more than $1.4 billion in direct
losses to farmers because of the drought and $4.6 billion in overall economic
loss. In Oklahoma, officials say the disaster could cost $2 billion in total
losses.

That comes on top of repeated disasters in the Upper Midwest, where wet weather
has spawned a wheat disease that has destroyed crops for several years in a row.
In North Dakota, Mr. Glickman said farm income fell 92 percent in 1997 compared
with the year before.

The House is expected to vote next week on a measure to permit farmers to
receive on Oct. 1 all or part of $5.5 billion in transition payments. That
money, which was scheduled to be paid next year, is intended to wean farmers
from the subsidy system that was done away with in 1996 with passage of a farm
law backed by Republicans. The Senate is expected to follow suit, and Mr.
Glickman said the Administration supported the move.

Aside from the weather disasters, Mr. Glickman said the overall farm economy was
in a tailspin that would cut income by $7.5 billion this year. Prices for corn,
wheat, soybeans and other commodities are off sharply because exports have
decreased because of the Asian financial crisis and huge crops have been
produced worldwide.

Projected fall harvests here are again expected to be huge and farmers are
taking on more debt, he said.

He said many producers will withstand the downturn because of the strong markets
of the early 1990's and because production expenses actually dropped $1 billion
this year because of low inflation, low interest rates and low oil prices.

In addition, unless weather patterns change markedly over the next few weeks,
there will be big crops through the Corn Belt and other areas, bringing higher
yields per acre that will soften the blow of lower prices.

LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   July 14, 1994, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

FARMERS REAP 58 PERCENT OF U.S. DISASTER PAYOUTS

BYLINE: Kathleen Best Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: WAR PAGE; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 480 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


FARMING OPERATIONS collected nearly three-fifths of the $ 43.8 billion in
federal disaster assistance paid out over the last nine years - or 58 cents of
every federal disaster aid dollar, a new study shows.

And not all of that money was well or wisely spent, said the study conducted by
the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit environmental policy organization
based in Washington.

"In large measure, disaster policy has functioned as another crop subsidy
program that transferred large amounts of income from taxpayers to high-risk
farming regions, high-risk farmers, or both," the report concludes.

Researchers for the working group analyzed more than 5 million records from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture documenting disaster aid and crop insurance
payments from 1985 to 1993.

Among their conclusions:

Farmers - from family farmers to corporate farmers to partnerships - collected $
25.2 billion in USDA emergency aid between 1985 and 1993. Of that total, $ 10.7
billion was in emergency loan write-offs by the Farmers Home Administration; $
8.8 billion was in direct disaster aid payments from the Agricultural
Stabilization and Conservation Service; and $ 5.7 billion was in taxpayer
subsidies of federal crop insurance.

Generous disaster aid payments to farmers actually discourage farmers from
taking out federal crop insurance.

An analysis of disaster aid payments showed that 959 farmers got such payments
every year for seven years between 1987 and 1993. Those recipients, the study
showed, took in $ 56 million in disaster aid from the ASCS for an average
payment of $ 58,523 each.

An additional 73,359 farmers collected disaster aid in four of the seven years.
Those producers got checks totaling nearly $ 1.5 billion - or an average payment
of $ 20,101 each.

Farmers who collected disaster aid in just one of the seven years averaged $
2,995 each.

The crop insurance program ran up $ 5.7 billion in taxpayer losses from 1985 to
1993. The report calculated taxpayer losses by adding the government subsidy for
insurance premiums to claims paid in excess of premiums collected between 1985
and 1993.

Overall, the study said, the government spent nearly $ 10 billion on the crop
insurance program and paid out $ 2.04 in claims for every dollar in premiums
collected.

The top 10 states for crop insurance losses were Texas, North Dakota, Minnesota,
Montana, Iowa, Georgia, Kansas, Louisiana, Nebraska and South Dakota. Illinois
ranked 12th and Missouri 17th. Texas alone collected 15.6 percent of all
insurance payments.

The top 10 states for disaster assistance payments were Texas, North Dakota,
Minnesota, Kansas, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, South Dakota, Michigan and
Georgia. Missouri ranked 13th - a ranking that may be misleading because the
study did not count all of the disaster payments from last year's flooding.

LOAD-DATE: July 15, 1994

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: PHOTO; Photo by AP - A boat feels its way upstream on the Flint River
in Bainbridge, Ga., earlier this week where flooding has devastated much of the
southern part of the state. The flooding promises to escalate the nation's
mammoth disaster aid bills.

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                          September 27, 2006 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

REIN IN EXCESSIVE DISASTER RELIEF;
THE FEDERAL FARM DISASTER AID PROGRAM BENEFITS TEXAS AND THE PLAINS STATES AT
WISCONSIN'S EXPENSE.

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 417 words


There is something wrong with the federal disaster relief program for
agriculture when farmers are not so much planting crops as they are planting a
means to collect disaster payments.

The $6.5-billion request for farm disaster aid that Congress is considering this
week is a reminder of how much some farmers have come to depend upon disaster
aid -- at taxpayers' expense.

Moreover, the aid request reminds Wisconsin of how big a loser the state is in
the economics of farm disaster relief. Over the past 10 years, Wisconsin ranks a
lowly 30th among states in disaster aid payments to farmers.

The biggest beneficiaries of aid were Texas and the Great Plains states.

It's time for Congress to rein in farm disaster payments, and it's time for
Wisconsin's congressional delegation to help make it happen.

Disaster aid, an important safety net for farmers, is a good investment for
taxpayers because it helps to protect the nation's food suppliers from financial
ruin due to unusually harsh weather.

But the key word should be "unusually." To Congress' discredit, the unusual has
become the perpetual.

Congress has been dispensing so much farm disaster aid that farmers have been
encouraged to plant on marginal land, where drought and other disasters are
common. An analysis of U.S. Agriculture Department data by a Washington, D.C.,
advocacy organization called the Environmental Working Group, found that more
than 76,000 farmers nationwide were collecting disaster aid in more years than
they were not collecting aid.

Farmers so disaster-prone that they collect payments more than half the time
render the word "disaster" meaningless.

As a result of the largesse, disaster relief payments to farmers reached $2.9
billion in 2003, more than 10 times the average annual total of the mid-1990s.
The total fell to $548 million in 2004, the most recent year for which complete
data are available.

A disproportionate share of the aid, year after year, goes to farmers in Texas
and the Great Plains. In fact, from 1995 through 2004 about a third of all farm
disaster aid went to four states: Texas, North and South Dakota and Oklahoma.

Texas and Plains states would be the prime beneficiaries of the $6.5 billion aid
package now before Congress.

Wisconsin, in contrast, gets relatively little disaster aid -- just $4 million
in 2004, compared with $169 million for Florida and $44 million for Texas.

Congress should start now to reform how it distributes disaster aid to make it
fairer for all farmers, and for taxpayers.

LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               6 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 7, 1986, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

HOUSE APPROVES $530 MILLION FARMERS' AID PLAN

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 539 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6


The House today approved a package of drought relief measures designed to aid
farmers in the Southern and Middle Atlantic regions. The vote was 418 to 0.

The aid package, which was estimated to cost $530 million, was sent to the
Senate, which approved a similar proposal last week. Both Congressional
proposals are designed to complement a package of relief measures put into
effect last Friday by the Reagan Administration.

The Congressional measures, coupled with the Administration's assistance
program, would provide grain, feed, cash and other forms of aid to tens of
thousands of farmers in a 10-state region stretching from Alabama to southern
Pennsylvania, according to sponsors of the House bill. The region has suffered
for months because of high temperatures and a lack of rain.

Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House
Agriculture Committee, said: ''The additional assistance in our bill clearly can
not solve the entire drought problem, but it can help. In some cases, maybe we
can make the difference between survival and economic collapse for farm
families.''

The House legislation includes several provisions that are nearly identical with
those in the Reagan Administration's relief package. For instance, both programs
would enable farmers to split costs of feed with the Government. The cost of the
House feed program alone would total $300 million, the Congressional Budget
Office estimated Tuesday.

The Department of Agriculture said the Southern states affected by the drought
provided about $800 million in feed annually to their livestock. The House
program would give the farmers a supply of feed lasting approximately six
months, according to the House Agriculture Committee.

In addition, the House proposal would require the Agriculture Department to
monitor areas where livestock feed is scarce. The Secretary of Agriculture would
be required to transfer surplus stocks of Government grains to any region where
there was less than a three-day supply of feed. The feed would be donated to
farmers for the duration of the shortage.

The House relief measure also requires the Government to pay 80 percent of the
cost of transporting hay into areas where feed is in short supply if other
programs are not doing so.

The Congressional Budget Office estimated that monitoring feed and transporting
hay, coupled with several other programs, would cost $230 million.

The National Weather Service said today that the forecast through early next
week called for continued dry weather in most of the drought region. Earlier
this week three inches of rain fell in parts of Wayne County, a soybean and
sunflower growing region in eastern Georgia. This morning nearly an inch of rain
fell in Plains, Ga. But rain has not fallen in most of the west central and
southwestern areas of Georgia, which are the state's primary agricultural
regions.

Roger Getz, an agricultural meteorologist for the Weather Service in Auburn,
Ala., said: ''For the next five days we see about the same, just more dryness
and scattered afternoon and evening thundershowers. About the only positive
thing is that temperatures in the last few days have not been as hot as they had
been in July.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company

                          The Hazard Herald (Kentucky)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            December 6, 2016 Tuesday

Southeastern Kentucky farmers may be eligible for drought aid

BYLINE: The Hazard Herald, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 446 words


Dec. 06--FRANKFORT -- Farmers in 10 southeastern Kentucky counties may be
eligible for federal aid under an agricultural disaster declaration issued as a
result of the ongoing drought throughout the Commonwealth.

"The drought that has gripped Kentucky in recent months has been especially hard
on farmers," Agriculture Commissioner Ryan Quarles said. "Crops have been
affected, and livestock producers have been forced to feed hay earlier than
usual because their pastures are depleted. This aid will provide much-needed
resources for Kentucky farmers."

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack notified Gov. Matt Bevin by letter that
Vilsack has designated Bell, McCreary, and Whitley counties as agricultural
disaster areas. Farmers in counties contiguous to those counties also may be
eligible for aid; those counties are Clay, Harlan, Knox, Laurel, Leslie,
Pulaski, and Wayne, as well as Campbell, Claiborne, and Scott counties in
Tennessee and Lee County in Virginia.

A Secretarial disaster designation makes farm operators in the primary and
contiguous counties eligible to be considered for certain aid, including
emergency loans, from the U.S. Farm Service Agency (FSA). Farmers in eligible
counties have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for
emergency loans. For more information on available aid, contact your local FSA
office or go to fsa.usda.gov.

Commissioner Quarles said the Kentucky Department of Agriculture (KDA) is
working closely with federal and state agencies, agricultural organizations,
weather forecasters, and emergency management officials to monitor local
conditions. "We are grateful to Governor Bevin, Kentucky's congressional
delegation, and our agricultural leaders for helping make this disaster aid
available," Commissioner Quarles said. "The wildfires in eastern Kentucky have
been the primary concern, but our leaders also were mindful of the drought's
impact on agriculture, and we appreciate their consideration."

The KDA operates an online hay/forage sales directory where farmers who need to
buy forages can search by county. Entries contain information on the nutritional
and energy levels of the forages offered for sale. To search for available
forages for sale, go to kyagr.com/buyky/hay-search.aspx.

Commissioner Quarles also has activated the Hay Hotline for farmers who need to
find hay or who want to make hay available for sale. For more information about
the Hay Hotline, or to post hay for sale, go to
kyagr.com/marketing/hay-hotline.html or call (502) 782-4110.

___ (c)2016 The Hazard Herald (Hazard, Ky.) Visit The Hazard Herald (Hazard,
Ky.) at www.hazard-herald.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                                US Official News

                          September 21, 2013 Saturday

New York: Governor Cuomo Announces "Taste NY" Experience Coming to Farm Aid 2013
in Saratoga Springs on September 21

LENGTH: 741  words

DATELINE: Albany


Department of Agriculture & Markets, The State of New York has issued the
following news release:

Governor Andrew M. Cuomo today announced that concertgoers will be treated to a
"Taste NY" experience at the Farm Aid 2013 concert being held at the Saratoga
Performing Arts Center on September 21. Thirteen beer, wine and cider vendors
from across the state will be selling their products at the "Taste NY" tent as
part of the backdrop to this annual concert event in support of the tradition of
agriculture.

"There may be no better venue to showcase New York's wine, beer and cider than
at the Farm Aid 2013 concert as we celebrate the history and role of agriculture
in our state and country," Governor Cuomo. "Not only will there be great music
at the event, but also some of the best food and drink to enjoy here in New York
- so I encourage concertgoers to stop by the 'Taste NY' tent to sample these
local products and support our producers and farmers."

"Taste NY will add a local beverage experience for Farm Aid 2013 concertgoers.
We are proud to include New York's craft beers, wines, and cider at Farm Aid
2013," said Farm Aid Associate Director, Glenda Yoder. "Farm Aid values the New
York State programs that increase opportunities for the farmers who are growing
hops, grains, grapes and apples."

New York beer, wine and cider vendors taking part in the "Taste NY" experience
at Farm Aid 2013 include the New York State Brewers Association, Empire Brewing
Company (Syracuse), Brown's Brewing Co. (Troy), Saranac Brewery (Utica), Lake
Placid Brewery (Lake Placid), Captain Lawrence Brewing Company (Elmsford),
Brooklyn Brewery (Brooklyn), Davidson Brothers Brewing Company (Glens Falls),
Adirondack Brewery (Lake George), McKenzie's Hard Cider (Buffalo), Swedish Hill
Winery (Romulus), Hazlitt 1852 Vineyards (Hector) and Bedell Cellars
(Cutchogue). Sixteen ounce cups of beer and cider, and five ounce quantities of
wine will be available for purchase in the tent.

Paul Leone, Executive Director of the New York State Brewers Association said,
"Farm Aid insisted on having New York State craft beers at this event because we
are an important agricultural product. Some brewers selling their products at
this event will be farm brewers, showcasing materials made with ingredients
grown directly from local farmers. This will be an interactive 'Taste NY'
showcase that Farm Aid patrons will not soon forget."

Jim Trezise, President of the New York Wine and Grape Foundation said, "The Farm
Aid concert is the latest 'Taste NY' event to showcase New York wines before
thousands of consumers. We really appreciate this opportunity and the many ways
Governor Cuomo continues to support New York's wine industry."

In addition to the "Taste NY" tent, a FreshConnect Youth Market, co-sponsored by
the state Department of Agriculture and Markets in cooperation with GROW NYC,
will sell fresh fruits produced by New York State farmers at the concert.

Tom Strumolo, Director of Greenmarket Planning and Policy at GrowNYC said,
"We're so thrilled to partner each year with our friends at Farm Aid who do so
much to support family farms and strengthen local food systems. GrowNYC's
teen-run farm stands are one of the ways we increase food access where we work
in New York City - particularly in neighborhoods where finding even an apple is
a challenge. At the same time, we're 'grow'ing teenagers who are earning money
and becoming the next generation of advocates for the good food good health
movement. At this year's stand you'll find produce sourced from upstate New York
Farms. We'll see you at the stand!"

"Taste NY" was launched by Governor Cuomo to highlight New York's food and
beverage industry. Its goal is to make the wide variety of foods made and grown
in the state readily available and recognizable to New York residents, tourists
and the world. "Taste NY" is also a major component of the Governor's $60
million tourism campaign - the largest such campaign in decades. The program
publicizes New York-made food and beverage products via promotions such as
"Taste NY" tents and pavilions at food and wine events and "Taste NY" stores and
kiosks located at Thruway rest stops and soon at airports and other
transportation hubs. In 2013, "Taste NY" has already had a large presence at the
PGA Tournament in Rochester and the Great New York State Fair in Syracuse.

                               The New York Times

               October 27, 1987, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Cattle Virus Is Studied

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

SECTION: Section C; Page 8, Column 3; Science Desk

LENGTH: 440 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26


The Department of Agriculture and the National Institutes of the Health are
investigating a cattle virus similar to the virus that causes AIDS.

Researchers said there was no evidence that the cattle virus, bovine
immunodeficiency virus, causes AIDS or any other diseases in people. But they
said genetic similarities between the two viruses could help researchers develop
ways to use cattle to study how immune-suppressing viruses produce disease.

The project is a response to petitions filed with both agencies last summer by
Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington, a
group that is active in farm and health policy issues.

Theory Is Attacked

In his petition, Mr. Rifkin speculated that the AIDS virus might have evolved
from cattle viruses, or that the cattle virus might itself have played a role in
the development of AIDS. But researchers at the Federal Centers for Disease
Control today discounted the possibility that the cattle virus was related in
any way to acquired immune deficiency syndrome in humans.

''There are some zealots who have made the suggestion that animal viruses are
related to AIDS,'' said Dr. Peter Drotman, an epidemiologist in the AIDS Program
at the C.D.C. ''None of these have been supported by any scientific evidence.''

Some researchers have suggested that the cattle virus may have contaminated
human vaccines which are produced in part from serum taken from fetal calves.
Officials at the Canadian Department of National Health and Welfare today said
they were considering new rules to require United States and Canadian vaccine
manufacturers to test their products for the presence of the cattle virus before
selling them in Canada.

'A Thorough Investigation'

''I expect that if they are found there will be a thorough investigation because
that would mean we have a problem,'' said Dr. David Pope, assistant director of
the Bureau of Biologics in the Canadian Health Department. Dr. Pope and other
experts could not specify what sort of threat the cattle virus might pose if it
is found in human vaccines.

The BIV virus was isolated and identified 18 years ago by scientists at the
National Animal Disease Center in Ames, Iowa, a facility operated by the
Department of Agriculture.

Under the joint research project, Agriculture Department scientists are planning
to develop new diagnostic tests to see how widely BIV is found in the nation's
cattle herds. Scientists at Program Resources Incorporated, a private laboratory
in Frederick, Md., said today they were conducting studies on BIV under contract
to the National Institutes of Health.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1987 The New York Times Company

                           September 11, 2005 Sunday
                                  City Edition

New Legal Aid grants will provide assistance to low-income Nebraskans

BYLINE: Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: C; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 358 words

DATELINE: Lincoln, NE


Legal Aid of Nebraska, the law firm for one-eighth of the state's population,
recently received more than $469,000 in grants to help deliver its services to
low-income state residents.

Under terms of the grants, Legal Aid will help eligible clients with federal
government issues, provide education on family legal issues that ultimately will
help reduce domestic violence, and provide legal assistance to low-income
seniors, farmers, ranchers and Natives.

Legal Aid serves the entire state from offices in Omaha, Lincoln, Grand Island,
Norfolk, Scottsbluff, Bancroft and North Platte. In some rural areas, lawyers
from other firms are hired to assist.

The grants include:

* $50,000 from United Way of Lincoln-Lancaster County to help low-income county
residents to receive legal education, advice and brief legal help by phone or
actual representation. For more information, call Roberta Stick, Legal Aid's
director of advocacy, at (402) 435-2161, ext. 30.

* $29,000 from the Lincoln-Lancaster County Joint Budget Committee to provide
legal assistance to low-income domestic violence victims. For more information,
call Stick of Legal Aid.

* $100,000 per year for three years from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
Hispanic-Native America Farmer Program to help targeted Hispanic and Native
farmers and ranchers own, operate and retain their farms and ranches. For more
information, call Michelle Soll of Legal Aid at (402) 648-3457.

* $160,000 from the Nebraska Department of Agriculture for mediation and
financial counseling for low-income farmers. For more information, call Soll of
Legal Aid.

* $30,000 from Northeast Nebraska Area Agency on Aging for services to those
over age 60. The grant includes $6,000 for legal services to Native seniors. For
more information on the grant, call Lori Lee of Legal Aid at (402) 644-4761. For
more information on the Native funding, call Sherri Eveleth of Legal Aid at
(402) 648-3457.

* $100,000 from the Nebraska Lawyers Trust Account Foundation to assist indigent
Nebraskans in gaining access to the legal system via Legal Aid. For more
information, call Doug German of Legal Aid at (402) 348-1069, ext. 204.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      June 16, 1989, Friday, City Edition

2 widows feud over fortune

SOURCE: Compiled from Wire Reports

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; state digest; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 540 words

DATELINE: ANNISTON, Ala.; TALLAHASSEE; LANTANA



ANNISTON, Ala. - A 75-year-old widow is contesting a will allegedly    left by
her multimillionaire husband that gives his fortune to another    wife in
Florida. Ruth Davis of Anniston and Flossie Davis, 62, of    Tallahassee, claim
to have been married at the same time to Harry G.    Davis, 77, a real estate
developer and farmer in Alabama. Davis    "basically lived two lives," spending
weekends and holidays with    Flossie Davis and their children in Tallahassee
and weekdays on the    farm with Ruth Davis, said A. W. Bolt, a lawyer for Ruth
Davis. After    Davis died last year, Flossie Davis presented a will she said he
wrote    in 1969, giving her most of his $ 8-million estate. But a 1959 will
leaving the estate to Ruth Davis was found three weeks ago. Bolt said    that a
jury trial scheduled to begin Monday will decide which will is    valid.



 Agency director resigns

 TALLAHASSEE - Adis Vila, secretary of the state Department of
Administration, submitted her resignation to Gov. Bob Martinez on    Thursday.
Vila is expected to be appointed an assistant secretary of    the U.S.
Department of Agriculture by President Bush. Vila created a    controversy two
years ago by trying to change health insurance    companies for state employees.

 In her letter to Martinez, she said her    resignation will be effective June
30. She also recounted her    department's accomplishments, including changes in
the way the state    hires and trains employees.



 Tabloids to fire 47

 LANTANA - The new owners of the National Enquirer and Weekly World    News
supermarket tabloids announced layoffs of 47 employees and said    that for the
first time since 1971, the company won't provide the    town's Christmas tree
display free of charge. Michael Boylan, president    of Macfadden Holdings, said
20 of the 270 employees in editorial,    advertising and other departments at
the Lantana headquarters were laid    off immediately and 27 more would lose
their jobs in July. He also said    the company can't afford the Christmas tree
display, which reportedly    costs as much as $ 1-million. Boylan and Macfadden
chairman Peter    Callahan bought the Enquirer, which sells 4.3-million copies
weekly,    and the News, which sells about 1-million, in April for $
412.5-million.



 Farmers eligible for aid

 TALLAHASSEE - Farmers in 23 Florida counties who lost crops during a    winter
freeze can apply for federal aid now that the counties have been    designated
federal disaster areas, Gov. Bob Martinez said Thursday. In    late February,
nearly 3,500 farms covering more than 660,000 acres in    Charlotte, Flagler,
Hillsborough, Putnam and St. Johns counties were    hit hard by a three-day
freeze, according to reports to the governor.

 Farmers in 18 adjacent counties also can apply for the low-interest
emergency loans. The adjacent counties are Alachua, Bradford, Clay,    DeSoto,
Duval, Glades, Hardee, Hendry, Highlands, Lake, Lee, Manatee,    Marion, Pasco,
Pinellas, Polk, Sarasota and Volusia counties.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                 July 22, 1988, Friday, North Suncoast Edition

Lighter sentence suggested if woman seeks sterilization

SECTION: NATIONAL; NATIONAL DIGEST; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 756 words

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS; WASHINGTON; CHARLESTON, W. Va.; LOS ANGELES; NEW YORK;
NASHVILLE, Tenn.



INDIANAPOLIS - A woman convicted of criminal neglect in the death of    her
4-year-old son has been offered the possibility of a reduced    sentence if she
is sterilized. Melody S. Baldwin, 29, who faces a    possible 20-year sentence,
is seven months pregnant. At a hearing    Wednesday on Baldwin's medical status,
Marion Superior Court Judge Roy    F. Jones recommended that Baldwin undergo
sterilization and suggested    he might reduce her sentence if the procedure is
completed.

 Representatives of the Indiana Civil Liberties Union called Jones'    proposal
outrageous and an impermissible condition of sentencing.



 Rapid AIDS test developed

 WASHINGTON - Scientists have developed a rapid blood screening test    for the
AIDS virus that will make blood transfusions in developing    nations safer and
could save thousands of lives each year. Blood    transfusions are a major route
of transmission for AIDS in the Third    World, where there are few blood banks
and little money for the    sophisticated screening tests used in the United
States. "This is one    of the major advances in AIDS prevention," said Dr.
Thomas C. Quinn, a    leading AIDS researcher at the National Institutes of
Health and the    Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions who directed the study.
Quinn's    report appears in Friday's issue of The Journal of the American
Medical    Association.



 Pro-abortion nuns resign

 CHARLESTON, W.Va. - Two Roman Catholic nuns said Thursday they have    resigned
from their order, six weeks after winning a fight to remain    sisters despite
pro-abortion views. "We aren't nuns anymore,"    Patricia Hussey said after she
and Barbara Ferraro resigned from the    Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur. Both
women said they will remain in the    Roman Catholic church. "For us to stand
with women, we need to    renounce the differences, privileges and even
limitations that are part    of membership in a religious community in a
patriarchal church," they    said in a resignation letter.



 Two Medflies found in Calif.

 LOS ANGELES - Gov. George Deukmejian proclaimed a state of emergency    for Los
Angeles County on Thursday after the discovery of two female    Mediterranean
fruit flies in traps. County agricultural officials    sprayed the ground in
parts of the San Fernando Valley with a    protein-based bait and set an
additional 1,300 traps, said Bill    Edwards, chief deputy in the county
Department of Agriculture and    Weights and Measures. If the traps catch more
flies, the state    Department of Food and Agriculture may begin aerial spraying
as allowed    under the governor's proclamation, and county officials may
release    sterile flies to reduce the Medfly population, said Edwards. The
Medfly, one of the most destructive crop-destroying insects, is    considered a
severe threat to California's multibillion-dollar    agricultural industry.

 Meese called a 'sleaze'

 NEW YORK - A federal prosecutor in the racketeering trial of Rep.    Mario
Biaggi said on Thursday his boss, Attorney General Edwin Meese,    was "a
sleaze" for his role in the Wedtech bribery scandal. Assistant    U.S. Attorney
Edward Little, speaking during the the government's    summation at the
four-month racketeering trial of the Bronx    congressman, said he agreed with
the defense assessment of Meese.    "Meese is a sleaze, too - in addition to
these people (the    defendants)," Little said. Meese's lawyer, Nathan Lewin,
said that    Little's charge was "beneath contempt."

 Hall of Fame picks finalists

 NASHVILLE, Tenn. - Loretta Lynn, "the coal miner's daughter," and    Roy
Rogers, "the king of the cowboys," were among 10 finalists named    Thursday for
the Country Music Hall of Fame. Two people will be    selected from the
finalists and they will be named Oct. 10 during the    Country Music
Association's nationally televised awards show. The    inductees will bring the
hall of fame members' total to 48. Other    finalists are singers and humorists
Homer and Jethro, singers Bradley    Kincaid, Ray Price and Hank Thompson, Bill
Carlisle, the Louvin    Brothers, the Jordanaires and Cindy Walker. A panel of
200 music    industry representatives will pick two winners.

                       Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida)

                          November 16, 2005 Wednesday
                                SARASOTA EDITION

Lawmakers seek storm aid for Florida growers

BYLINE: By CORY REISS WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: B SECTION; Pg. BS5

LENGTH: 503 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Florida lawmakers asked Congress on Tuesday for $2.1 billion to aid
hurricane-stricken agriculture industries, saying their state's economy has
particularly suffered from devastating back-to-back storm seasons.

Whether the emergency aid bills that Sen. Mel Martinez, R-Fla., and Rep. Mario
Diaz-Balart, R-Miami, introduced can pass before the year ends is unclear.

Without the help, Martinez said, Florida growers would have trouble getting off
their knees.

"We're talking now about a second year in which these crops have been
devastated," he told reporters, "so I think the consequences would be very, very
dire."

The agriculture bills would apply to Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Alabama,
providing money for livestock, fisheries, fruits, vegetables, sugar and
ornamental plants.

Martinez said he hopes to attach the measure to any hurricane aid packages that
might arise, which so far have focused on recovery from Hurricane Katrina and
have not included agriculture.

The Congressional Budget Office estimated the bill would cost $2.1 billion
total. Martinez expected it to cover about 25 percent of the damage in Florida,
or $500 million to $600 million of the state's estimated $2.2 billion in
agriculture losses, mainly from hurricanes Katrina and Wilma.

The measure also includes $40 million to reimburse organizations housing
displaced farmworkers.

Martinez said he is optimistic about quick action. But Congress already is
wrestling with broad budget problems.

Martinez said the Senate has passed $35 billion in budget cuts partly to cover
emergency expenses like this. The House is having a tough time approving its own
version of that bill, however.

Sen. Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat, supports the measure, Martinez said.

Gov. Jeb Bush, touring a damaged nursery in Homestead last week, called for more
federal aid for the state's agriculture. He said Congress made $400 million
available after last year's four hurricanes.

The bills introduced Tuesday offer a long-term boost for one big industry. It
would make nurseries eligible for help under two permanent programs of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, which currently exclude ornamental plants.

The ornamental plant industry accounts for half of Florida's agriculture losses
this year, and Florida is second to California in plant production. The Florida
Nursery, Growers and Landscape Association said strikes by eight hurricanes in
15 months highlight the need for permanent changes to programs that reimburse
for debris removal and crop loss.

Ben Bolusky, executive vice president of the association, said hurricanes
Katrina and Wilma wrecked shade structures critical to ornamental plant growers,
causing an immense amount of debris and expense. Nurseries are excluded from a
program that helps other types of growers with debris, which the new bills would
change.

Ornamental plants also are not eligible for assistance under an existing
crop-loss program that covers fallen crops but not trees. The new bills would
expand the crop definition in that program.

                               The New York Times

                 July 18, 1986, Friday, Late City Final Edition

SOUTH SEEKS DROUGHT AID

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section A; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 240 words


Officials of parched Southern states turned to the Federal Government, Middle
Western farmers and neighbors yesterday for help in feeding livestock as the
record drought persisted. No relief was forecast in the heat wave, which spread
into the Middle West yesterday.

South Carolina's Agriculture Commissioner, D. Leslie Tindal, said the drought
was likely to cause at least $100 million in crop losses there. Offers of hay
and free transportation were coming in from as far away as Minnesota, he said.

South Carolina has had only eight and a half inches of rain this year, as
against nearly 16 inches by this time in 1933, the driest year on record, said
Wes Tyler, assistant state climatologist.

Senator Mack Mattingly, Republican of Georgia, announced that the United States
Department of Agriculture was putting together a group to tour Georgia, Alabama
and the Carolinas next week to develop recommendations for Government
assistance. The office of Gov. Joe Frank Harris of Georgia has asked the
Department of Agriculture to make livestock feed available to farmers.

In North Carolina, officials said 50 counties had applied for Federal disaster
aid through Gov. James G. Martin because cash crops are drying up.

Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia said he had requested Federal disaster
declarations for 17 counties where crop losses are estimated at nearly $61.5
million and said a dozen counties had asked to be included.

US MEAT GROUP TO AID

RUSSIAN PORK PROGRAM

DENVER - The U.S. Meat Export Federation said it will offer assistance to
Russian agencies in the distribution of U.S. pork as part of the upcoming food
aid package to the Russian Republic.

In a long-awaited move, the U.S. Department of Agriculture this week invited
U.S. suppliers to bid for $ 19 million in pork aid to Russia.

"We've been working in the Russian market for two years now to develop trade
contacts and to get a better understanding for the changing distribution
system," said Mark Gustafson, the USMEF's senior vice president.

"Meat supplies in Russia are expected to be tight this winter, so the pork aid
shipments in November and December will be very timely." 4,000 EVACUATED IN OHIO

AFTER CHEMICAL BLASTS ELYRIA, Ohio - Two chemical explosions at the Aztec
Catalyst Co. shortly after midnight Friday forced the evacuation of more than
4,000 people and sent 30 people to nearby hospitals overcome by fumes.

Several other plants in the industrial park did not open Friday morning because
of a chemical cloud that hung over the area in stagnant, humid air.

Lt. John McLean of the Elyria police department said at least one Aztec building
was destroyed and another was on fire Friday morning, and officials were
uncertain when it would be contained.

No officials from Aztec Catalyst could be reached for comment, and it was
uncertain if anyone had been in the building at the time of the blasts.

Mr. McLean said firefighters were unsure what chemicals exploded or what was
manufactured at the plant.  MILLS' USE OF COTTON

INCREASED LAST MONTH KANSAS CITY, Mo. - The National Cotton Council has detailed
its estimate that U.S. textile mills in July used cotton at a seasonally
adjusted annual rate of 10.42 million bales, up 0.72 percent from June's revised
10.34 million.

U.S. mills consumed cotton at a seasonally adjusted daily rate in July at 38,332
bales, up from 38,066 a month ago, U.S. Census Bureau figures said.

Total fiber use in July was 31.18 million bales, down 4.18 percent from June.
Cotton's share of total fiber use, at 33.4 percent, was up slightly from 31.8
percent in June.  WHEAT COUNCIL BOOSTS

PRODUCTION FORECAST LONDON - The International Wheat Council Thursday revised
its forecast of world 1993-94 (July-June) wheat production to 573 million metric
tons, up 11 million from its July previous forecast for 1993-94 of 562 million.

The IWC estimates world wheat production in 1992-93 at 562 million tons also.

The IWC now pegs world 1993-94 wheat consumption at 567 million tons, up 3
million from its previous forecast, and up 9 million from 558 million in
1992-93.

It forecasts world 1993-94 wheat trade at 96 million tons, down from its
previous forecast of 99 million, and down from 103 million for 1992-93.

It pegs end-season 1993-94 wheat stocks at 138 million tons, up 4 million from
its last forecast, and up from 128 million tons at the end of 1992-93.

                                US Official News

                           November 19, 2015 Thursday

Washington: Subcommittees of the Agriculture Committee and Transportation and
Infrastructure Committee examine Transportation Perspectives of U.S.
International Food Aid Programs

LENGTH: 708 words

DATELINE: Lahore



    Washington, DC: House Committee on Agriculture has issued the following
press release:



  Today, the House Agriculture Committee&rsquo;s Subcommittee on Livestock and
Foreign Agriculture and the House Transportation and Infrastructure
Committee&rsquo;s Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation held a
joint hearing to explore the intersection of food aid shipping and military
sealift capacity, particularly that provided by the Maritime Security Program
(MSP).





 Officials from the Department of Defense, the Maritime Administration, and
industry experts discussed how proposed changes to existing food aid programs
and cargo preference rules could affect the viability of the U.S. maritime
industry and the overall domestic support for international food aid.



 &ldquo;The agriculture and maritime communities have successfully partnered
with private voluntary organizations to lead the global effort to alleviate
hunger and malnutrition over the past 60 years. Today&rsquo;s hearing reaffirmed
the widely-held concern that disruptions to that historic partnership would have
devastating effects on both our international food aid programs and our military
readiness. Any effort to move away from in-kind donations in exchange for more
cash-based assistance is concerning, especially since USAID has attempted to
achieve these reforms by effectively driving a wedge between the maritime and
agriculture communities. I thank my colleagues on the Transportation and
Infrastructure Committee for joining me in highlighting this important
issue,&rdquo; said Rep. David Rouzer (R-NC), Chairman of the Agriculture
Committee&rsquo;s Subcommittee on Livestock and Foreign Agriculture.



 &ldquo;To remain a world power, with the ability to defend ourselves and our
allies, it is critical that we maintain a robust fleet of United States flag
commercial vessels to carry much needed supplies to the battlefield, food aid to
countries in need, a large cadre of skilled American mariners to man those
vessels, and a strong shipyard industrial base to ensure we have the capability
to build and replenish our naval forces in times of war," said Rep. Duncan
Hunter (R-CA), Chairman of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee's
Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation.



 &ldquo;The United States, as a steward of the world, provides assistance to
countries and regions that are less fortunate, and the farmers, ranchers, and
dairymen that I represent in California&rsquo;s Central Valley are proud that
many of the commodities we produce go to individuals throughout the world who
otherwise would go hungry and malnourished. Today&rsquo;s hearing is important
because it allows us to look at the challenges the maritime industry faces when
transporting food products to countries and regions in need. International food
aid programs are very beneficial for countries that do not have adequate
resources to provide the quality of food that we produce here in the United
States. From growing the fruits and vegetables to transporting them across the
world, international food aid programs support good-paying jobs throughout the
nation, especially in California and our Valley,&rdquo; said Rep. Jim Costa
(D-CA), Ranking Member of the Agriculture Committee&rsquo;s Subcommittee on
Livestock and Foreign Agriculture.



 &ldquo;The existing partnership between agriculture, the maritime industry, and
government-sponsored food aid providers has been very effective in delivering
aid where it&rsquo;s needed most, while also supporting our domestic industries
and our military readiness. A bag of American food delivered from an American
ship is the best way to say that America cares. Keeping this partnership strong
will also assist our troops in uniform: current sealift capacity is insufficient
to meet needs that could arise in times of crisis, and maintaining a robust
domestic fleet will help keep our military ready in an increasingly dangerous
world,&rdquo; said Rep. John Garamendi (D-CA), Ranking Member of the
Transportation and Infrastructure Committee's Subcommittee on Coast Guard and
Maritime Transportation.

                              The Washington Post

                    January 24, 1994, Monday, Final Edition

SHORT TAKES

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A15; THE FEDERAL PAGE

LENGTH: 448 words


Aid Cutoff to Trade-School Chain Is Reversed

An administrative judge has overturned the Education Department's cutoff of
student aid money to a Philadelphia-based chain of trade schools, calling the
department "extremely zealous" in its moves against the schools.

Ernest C. Canellos, an administrative law judge at the department, issued the
order Friday after three days of hearings involving PTC Career Institutes.

The department had taken emergency action Dec. 5 to cut off federal student aid
to the company, which has branches in Washington, Atlanta, Newark, Chicago and
Baltimore.

Education officials charged that the school's owners, Richard and Rimona
Friedberg, had drained cash from the schools through large salaries for
themselves and family members, and continued to be involved in running the
school despite an agreement that they not do so.

In his order setting aside the emergency action, Canellos said "some of [the
department's] actions could be described as extremely zealous and some of its
allegations [are] unsupported."

In a telephone interview, Rimona Friedberg blamed the government for the
company's financial difficulties.

"They've taken a vital company and shut it down," she said. "They didn't have
one piece of evidence to show that this emergency action was reasonable."

PTC, according to government documents, has received $ 133 million in federal
student aid over the past eight years. It trains nurses' aides, office computer
operators, data punchers and building maintenance and security personnel. It has
about 300 employees and 1,700 students.


Pork Sale to Ex-Soviet Republics Approved

The Agriculture Department has approved the subsidized sale this year of 20,000
metric tons of pork to seven former Soviet republics, the department said last
week.

The approval follows more than two years of efforts by the industry and members
of Congress from pork-producing states to win a share of those markets using the
Export Enhancement Program, or EEP.

Under the program, private export companies sell farm products to buyers in
other countries. The Agriculture Department pays the company the difference
between the price in that country and the higher U.S. price.

The program is designed to let U.S. agriculture compete with the subsidized
products sold by the European Union and other countries.

The pork sales will be made in Armenia, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Moldova,
Russia and Ukraine.

"By extending the Export Enhancement Program for this pork sale, the Clinton
administration sends a strong signal that we will continue to battle
head-to-head for foreign agricultural markets," said Sen. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa).

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                          September 8, 2001, Saturday

FISCHLER ATTACKS US FARM AID PACKAGE

BYLINE: David Mccoy

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 222 words

HIGHLIGHT: US President, George W Bush ... farm aid package


EUROPEAN Agriculture Commissioner, Franz Fischler, has again hit out at the
USA's farm relief aid package.

Mr Fischler said that the $ 5.5 billion package was evidence of "incoherence"
between the USA's own actions and its demand that other countries make their
agriculture policies market-oriented.

He said that the package - signed off by US President, George W Bush, was the
fourth year in succession that the American Government had provided
supplementary assistance to its farmers.

The total since 1998 had been $ 39 billion, the European Commission said.

The EU's denunciation of the US's farm relief aid has become almost as customary
as the annual aid packages.

Mr Fischler remains sensitive to charges that the EU, through its Common
Agricultural Policy, provides market-distorting aid to farmers.

He said that many US commentators, who continued to criticise the CAP, were
"disregarding" major reforms that had taken place in the last 10 years.

Mr Fischler reiterated the EU's intention to get the negotiations over
agriculture at the World Trade Organisation to close the loophole that allowed
such relief.

"On average, each US farmer has received $ 11,000 in direct payments each year
since 1998, or almost three times the level received by EU farmers," said a
Commission statement.

                               The New York Times

                 June 3, 1986, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Pigs, AIDS and Belle Glade

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 429 words


A double medical mystery, involving two deadly diseases, has briefly enveloped
the small Florida town of Belle Glade. A poor community of sugar cane farmers on
the south shore of Lake Okeechobee, it has 49 recorded cases of AIDS out of a
population of 15,000, a stunning per capita figure. And for a few days last week
there were fears that for the first time in America, African swine fever had
also been found there.

Caroline MacLeod and Mark Whiteside, the Miami physicians who first reported
Belle Glade's cluster of AIDS, seek a cause in overcrowded, unsanitary
conditions, or blood-biting insects. Two Boston researchers, Jane Teas and John
Beldekas, theorize that the virus of African swine fever may be related to AIDS
in humans, and have screened Belle Glade pigs for the fever.

All these conjectures challenge the prevailing view that AIDS virus is the cause
of AIDS, and that the virus is spread by sexual contact or needles, when
infected blood or sperm reaches another person's bloodstream. But Mr. Beldekas,
pursuing his theory, reported signs of the swine fever virus in a Belle Glade
pig. The Department of Agriculture at first confirmed the test result. African
swine fever is usually fatal, rapidly transmissible and, quite apart from any
connection with AIDS, would pose an urgent threat to the pork industry. But
having tested the town's pigs, the Department of Agriculture now says it is
''satisfied that African swine fever does not exist in Belle Glade.''

Presumably, Mr. Beldekas's diagnosis was a false positive; he now acknowledges
that he may have confused a standard positive test serum with his sample. The
heterodox hypotheses about how AIDS is transmitted may also be in error.

But in science, even unlikely ideas are often worth pursuing. The Federal
Centers for Disease Control has already begun an epidemiological study of Belle
Glade and results are expected in September. It doesn't really expect to find
much unusual. Though 19 of the Belle Glade AIDS cases did not belong to a known
risk group, many victims were not interviewed before their death. The incidence
of AIDS in Belle Glade is high, but so too are prostitution and intravenous drug
abuse, which are linked to the spread of the disease.

The Disease Centers study is designed to consider sexual practices, particularly
heterosexual transmission, but will also look at exposure to other viruses and
living conditions. Belle Glade may prove a false lead for AIDS as for African
swine fever. But dead ends are unavoidable in traversing the maze of this deadly
disease.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

               January 13, 2001, Saturday, 3 Early Tampa Edition

Bob Crawford wants crop disaster declaration

SOURCE: Compiled from Wire Reports

SECTION: TAMPA & STATE; AROUND THE STATE; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 432 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE; MIAMI; DAYTONA BEACH



(ran SS edition of Metro & State)

Florida should seek federal aid for crop damage totaling $ 179-million from
recent freezes and flooding, Agriculture Secretary Bob Crawford said Friday.

Crawford asked Gov. Jeb Bush to request an agriculture disaster declaration from
the U.S. Department of Agriculture for 18 Florida counties, including
Hillsborough and Polk counties.

The federal financial assistance would help replant crops.

Preliminary estimates show freeze and flooding losses of $ 121.3-million for
Florida's vegetable growers, $ 47.5-million for fern growers and $ 10.2-million
for the tropical fish industry. There also was freeze damage to citrus and sugar
cane crops, but an assessment of that isn't finished.

Earlier this month, Bush issued an executive order allowing increased weight
limits for trucks to allow freeze-damaged citrus fruit and sugar cane plants to
be taken to juice processing plants and sugar mills.

Forum set on dispute over

tree-cutting canker attack

MIAMI - Opponents will get a chance to challenge the disputed science behind the
state's tree-cutting attack on citrus canker at a town hall meeting Jan. 26, a
state Agriculture Department attorney told a judge Friday.

About 830,000 canker-infected and nearby trees have been cut, mostly in
residential areas of South Florida, to protect the state's $ 8.5-billion citrus
industry. The bacterial disease scars fruit and causes it to drop prematurely.

Circuit Judge Ronald Friedman, who is presiding over a lawsuit by homeowners in
Miami-Dade and Broward counties that seeks to end all cutting, refused to stop
the cutting of infected residential trees pending the meeting and said he is
inclined to dismiss the lawsuit. The state contends that any challenge to the
eradication program must be filed with a state appeals court.

Malfunction knocks out

Daytona Beach bridge

DAYTONA BEACH - A malfunctioning drawbridge has Volusia County officials
scrambling to make repairs before the start of Speed Weeks in early February.

The 50-year-old Memorial Bridge is stuck in the raised position to allow
nautical traffic on the Intracoastal Waterway to pass until at least Friday.

The bridge is the southernmost of four spanning Halifax River between Daytona
Beach and its strip of hotels and motel and the mainland, where the Daytona
International Speedway is located.

On Jan. 4, a power surge hit the electronic control panel that is the brain of
the bridge, disabling it. Workers could only raise it manually. It was decided
to leave it raised until new parts arrive.

- Wire reports

                              21 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 7, 1987, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

INQUIRY SOUGHT ON CATTLE VIRUS LINK TO AIDS

BYLINE: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 470 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6


Jeremy Rifkin, an outspoken critic of genetic engineering and other
biotechnologies, today asked three Federal agencies to determine whether cattle
viruses play a role in causing AIDS.

In a petition submitted to the Agriculture Department, the Federal Centers for
Disease Control and the National Institutes of Health, Mr. Rifkin called the
cattle viruses ''an extraordinary potential threat to public health''

Mr. Rifkin speculated in an interview that the AIDS virus might have evolved
from cattle viruses, or that the cattle viruses might themselves play a role in
the development of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in humans.

Correlation Is Seen

The petition cited scientific papers indicating a ''close correlation'' between
the HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, that causes AIDS in humans, and a
virus found in cattle called bovine visna-like virus or bovine
immunodeficiency-like virus. The petition warned that a range of viruses ''exist
in domestic animal herds in the U.S. and thus could pose a potential health
hazard.''

It also speculated that the cattle virus, BIV, might have infected cell cultures
used to make some human vaccines, perhaps thereby contributing to the global
spread of AIDS.

However, two of the scientists whose papers were cited by Mr. Rifkin expressed
doubt in interviews that the cattle viruses played any role in causing AIDS.

One of them, Dr. Matthew A. Gonda, a virus expert who has performed detailed
studies of the structural and genetic makeup of BIV as compared to the AIDS
virus, said that the two were close enough to be considered members of the same
family of viruses, called lentiviruses.

Not Considered Progenitor

In fact, Dr. Gonda and his colleagues at Program Resources, Inc., which conducts
research for the National Cancer Institute in Frederick, Md., have proposed that
the cattle virus be used as a model for studying the AIDS virus. But the cattle
virus is not close enough to be considered the progenitor of the AIDS virus or
the cause of AIDS, Dr. Gonda said.

''I don't think that BIV could cause AIDS in humans,'' he said. ''I don't want
people to say this is an AIDS virus. It's not something that somebody should be
afraid will jump into humans or that should make people fear cows.''

The second expert, Dr. Martin J. Van der Maaten, of the Agriculture Department's
National Animal Disease Laboratory in Ames, Iowa., who first isolated BIV from
cattle, said he believed there was ''very little chance of it infecting humans''
and that it was ''far-fetched'' to speculate that contaminated vaccines have
spread the virus to humans.

The petition filed today by Mr. Rifkin's organization, the Foundation on
Economic Trends, cited a 1977 Belgian study which found that the bovine virus
could infect human cells in the laboratory.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                  January 10, 2003 Friday Penn/Elkhart Edition

Area Briefs

BYLINE: Staff and Wire Reports

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D3

LENGTH: 408 words


State police issue tickets on bypass

 Troopers from the Indiana State Police Bremen Post conducted a traffic detail
to chart and ticket speeders Wednesday on the St. Joseph Valley Parkway (U.S. 20
bypass) near the Elkhart and St. Joseph County lines.

In one hour, they issued 11 speeding tickets. Four vehicles were clocked at 85
mph and two were cited at 76 mph. One vehicle was ticketed after hitting 106
mph.

The other vehicles were ticketed for these speeds: 80, 87, 90 and 94 mph.

Lt. Robert Rich, post commander, said, "Troopers patrol this road regularly and
will continue to hold specialized patrols."

WASHINGTON, D.C.

Chocola receives choice appointments

 Second District U.S. Rep. Chris Chocola, R-Bristol, received two of the
committee assignments he was hoping for Thursday.

Chocola was appointed to the House Committee on Transportation and
Infrastructure and to the House Committee on Agriculture. Prior to taking
office, the freshman congressman had sought and received the support of Speaker
Dennis Hastert in hopes of getting the transportation committee assignment.
Chocola hopes to use the position to push for an upgrade of U.S. 31, between
South Bend and Indianapolis, to interstate highway standards.

Earlier this week, Chocola had said his second committee choice was between
Agriculture and the House Financial Services Committee, which deals with
corporate and business responsibility.

"Improving our transportation infrastructure will help to strengthen our economy
and create jobs throughout Indiana. Improving U.S. 31 and the Hoosier Heartland
highway are a couple of projects that have considerable implications for our
communities," he said.

Regarding his appointment to the Agriculture committee, Chocola said he believes
agricultural issues are significant to all of those who make their living by
farming or working within agricultural-related industries.

"I have worked my entire life in the agriculture business and I feel that my
lifelong experience will be an asset to the committee and to the farmers in the
district," Chocola said.

SOUTH BEND

Financial aid night will be Tuesday

 Riley High School's financial aid night will be Tuesday in the school
auditorium. The program starts at 7 p.m.

Guy Fisher, financial aid officer at Bethel College, will explain and answer
questions about the financial aid process. High school seniors and their parents
are invited to attend.

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                               September 13, 2000

Attack on new cash aid for US farmers

BYLINE: By Joe Watson

SECTION: Agriculture: USA, Pg.18

LENGTH: 221 words


A SCOTTISH farming leader last night attacked another multi-billion -pound
bailout that seems likely to be paid to farmers in the United States ahead of
Congressional and Presidential elections in November.

Jim Walker, the Scottish NFU president, derided the cash aid that looks set to
be agreed before votes are cast in the US elections.

He said: "This is just typical of the United States. It is supposed to the
world's advocate of free trade, but here they are supporting their agricultural
industry again. They even have an eye on the elections.

"Meantime our Government does not to listen to the problems our industry has
here."

US Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman accepts the need for more cash for US
farmers, who since 1998 have had more than GBP 15billion in extra aid from their
government on top of the subsidies they already receive.

Mr Glickman told a news conference, held by National Farmers Union of the US in
Washington, that more money was needed by the nation's farmers.

He said the administration would work with Congress in assessing how much
additional disaster aid was needed in response to widespread droughts and other
weather -related crop failures across the States.

There are just 19 days left in the current US legislative session before
Congress breaks up for the elections.

                               The New York Times

               August 23, 1984, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT BY IOWA SEEKING ADDITIONAL FARM AID

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 354 words

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Aug. 22


A Federal district judge conceded today that Iowa farmers had financial
problems, but he dismissed a lawsuit seeking to force Agriculture Secretary John
R. Block to put additional farm aid programs into effect.

The judge, William C. Stuart, said he had no jurisdiction to force Mr. Block to
start programs that were subject to the Secretary's discretion, as the state had
requested.

Brent Appel, the Iowa Assistant Attorney General, said the state would appeal.

Attorney General Tom Miller filed the suit earlier this year, asserting that Mr.
Block had a variety of farm relief programs he could put into effect to help
farmers hurt by last summer's drought but that he had not done so.

The suit also asserted that many Iowa farmers were being denied aid they were
eligible for.

Judge Cites 'Complex' Factors


Judge Stuart said in his decision that he did not doubt the assistance programs
being used were insufficient for livestock farmers in southeastern Iowa who had
been affected by the drought.

''But it is not for the court to substitute its judgment for that of the
secretary under the circumstances presented here,'' he wrote.

The judge noted that any decision Mr. Block made on putting farm aid programs
into effect must be based on factors other than the precarious financial
condition of farmers in some Iowa counties.

He said the many factors to be considered, including the Federal budget, ''are
so far-reaching and complex that this determination is not a proper subject of
judicial review.''

Mr. Appel said state officials took some comfort in Judge Stuart's comment that
many farmers did not get enough aid, and said they would appeal to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

Judge Stuart said that Congress frequently sets up programs and then gives
administrative authority to an agency with a staff of experts. It would not be
right, he said, for a court to overrule the experts.

John Ochs, a press aide for Mr. Block, said lawyers for the Department of
Agriculture had not seen a copy of Judge Stuart's ruling and would have no
immediate comment.

                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             August 3, 2010 Tuesday
                                  ALL EDITION

Welcome to Wisconsin Farm Aid

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 354 words


Farm Aid, the quarter-century-old effort to raise money for family farms,
sustainable agriculture and rural communities, is coming to Wisconsin.

And all we can say is: What took you so long?

When Willie Nelson, Neil Young, John Mellencamp, Dave Matthews and their fellow
musicians headline Farm Aid's 25th Anniversary concert Oct. 2 at Milwaukee's
Miller Park, they will find themselves in a state that has a deep commitment to
its agricultural ancestry and to its farming future.

Like most states in the Upper Midwest, Wisconsin has been battered by farm
policies that tend to favor big agribusiness, and trade policies that undermine
working farmers and local food initiatives. But few states in the country have
worked harder than Wisconsin to embrace the Farm Aid vision that the future will
be all about "organic, humanely raised and family farm-identified food."

"People are much more interested in local, fresh, family farmed foods," says
Farm Aid Executive Director Carolyn Mugar. "The message is extremely important
to get people recognizing how important family farms are, that they can demand
food from family farms and get more transparency as far as where their food is
coming from."

Farm Aid will be celebrating groundbreaking regional initiatives, such as
Growing Power, Will Allen's urban farm, community food center and international
training effort in Milwaukee.

Allen, in turn, notes that Wisconsin is a leader in sustainable farming, and
reminds reporters of the many thriving small farms around Madison that have made
the Dane County Farmers' Market the largest producers-only market in the United
States.

All these connections matter. And they will be made Oct. 2 in Wisconsin by the
Farm Aid folks. That's something to celebrate -- along with all the great music.

Share your opinion on this topic by sending a letter to the editor to
tctvoice@madison.com Include your full name, hometown and phone number. Your
name and town will be published. The phone number is for verification purposes
only. Please keep your letter to 250 words or less.

Posted in Editorial on Tuesday, August 3, 2010 5:00 am Updated: 4:30 pm
