                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                            December 20, 2004 Monday
                                  ALL EDITION

REIN IN GROWTH IN FARM DISASTER AID;
A BOOM IN DISASTER AID FOR FARMERS IS BENEFITING GREAT PLAINS STATES AT
WISCONSIN'S EXPENSE.

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 583 words


Last year American farmers harvested a bumper crop of $2.9 billion worth of
disaster payments.

That record total should call attention to the bigger role disaster aid is
playing in farm policy and the farm economy.

Disaster aid, once a limited program to compensate farmers for weather-related
calamities, is becoming a regular source of income to farmers encouraged to
plant crops on marginal land and collect disaster payments year after year.

Wisconsin's congressional delegation ought to pay especially close attention
because as federal policy makes the collection of disaster payments an
ever-bigger agribusiness, Wisconsin farmers are at an ever-greater disadvantage.

Here are the dimensions of the problem:

* In 1995 disaster aid accounted for 9 percent of all farm subsidies. Last year,
disaster aid was 18 percent of farm subsidies.

* During the past five years disaster payments have averaged just over $2
billion a year. That is about nine times the annual average of $240 million
during the previous four years.

* The chief beneficiaries of the disaster largesse are farmers in the Great
Plains, where drought and other weather-related crop failures are common. From
1995 through 2003, about 40 percent of disaster aid went to five states --
Texas, North and South Dakota, Oklahoma and Kansas.

* Wisconsin, blessed with a favorable climate, receives a relatively tiny
benefit from disaster aid. Over the past nine years Wisconsin has received $119
million in disaster payments, compared with more than $2 billion for Texas.

* Recently, the increase in disaster aid has come at the expense of other farm
programs. This fall Congress approved $3 billion in disaster aid, but only by
cutting spending on the conservation program that was a hallmark of the 2002
farm bill.

* Wisconsin is among the chief losers in this spending shift. For the past nine
years Wisconsin ranked 13th among states in conservation payments, but the state
ranked only 27th in disaster aid.

Disaster aid , an important safety net for farmers, is also a good investment
for taxpayers because it helps to protect the nation's food suppliers from
financial ruin due to unusually harsh weather. But the key word is "unusually"
harsh weather.

Wisconsin offers a model for how the aid ought to work. Wisconsin farmers
received a record-high $72 million in disaster payments in 2003, a year marked
by drought. That was so unusual that it was $71 million more than Wisconsin
farmers collected the previous year.

But in other parts of the country, the liberal dispensing of disaster payments
has turned the unusual into the perpetual. More than 76,000 farmers nationwide
have collected disaster aid in five or more of the past nine years, according to
U.S. Agriculture Department data analyzed by the Environmental Working Group, a
Washington, D.C., advocacy organization.

A big share of those farmers plant crops on land in the Great Plains that simply
doesn't get enough rainfall. They are not so much planting crops as they are
planting a means to collect disaster payments.

A farmer so disaster-prone that he collects payments more than half the time has
rendered the word "disaster" meaningless.

Disaster aid ought to be reined in. Congress should start now to restructure how
it distributes disaster payments. Aid should be available when calamities
strike, but the program should not encourage farmers to "grow" disaster payments
on land that won't grow crops. Wisconsin's congressional delegation should lead
the campaign for reform.

LOAD-DATE: December 21, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              27 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  July 14, 1994, THURSDAY, THREE STAR Edition

FARMERS REAP 58 PCT. OF U.S. DISASTER AID

BYLINE: Kathleen Best Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 539 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Farming operations collected nearly three-fifths of the $ 43.8 billion in
federal disaster assistance paid out over the last nine years - or 58 cents of
every federal disaster aid dollar, a new study shows.

And not all of that money was well or wisely spent, said the study conducted by
the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit environmental policy organization
based in Washington.

"In large measure, disaster policy has functioned as another crop subsidy
program that transferred large amounts of income from taxpayers to high-risk
farming regions, high-risk farmers, or both," the report concludes.

"When federal policy perpetuates unsound farming practices year in and year out,
disaster payments and crop insurance benefits themselves become staple crops for
farmers and staple costs for taxpayers."

Researchers for the working group analyzed more than 5 million records from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture documenting disaster aid and crop insurance
payments from 1985 to 1993.

Among their conclusions:

Farmers - from family farmers to corporate farmers to partnerships - collected $
25.2 billion in USDA emergency aid between 1985 and 1993. Of that total, $ 10.7
billion was in emergency loan write-offs by the Farmers Home Administration; $
8.8 billion was in direct disaster aid payments from the Agricultural
Stabilization and Conservation Service; and $ 5.7 billion was in taxpayer
subsidies of federal crop insurance.

Generous disaster aid payments to farmers actually discourage farmers from
taking out federal crop insurance, which allows the federal government to recoup
some expenses in the form of premium payments for coverage.

An analysis of disaster aid payments showed that 959 farmers got such payments
every year for seven years between 1987 and 1993. Those recipients, the study
showed, took in $ 56 million in disaster aid from the ASCS for an average
payment of $ 58,523 each.

An additional 73,359 farmers collected disaster aid in four of the seven years.
Those producers got checks totaling nearly $ 1.5 billion - or an average payment
of $ 20,101 each.

Farmers who collected disaster aid in just one of the seven years averaged
payments of $ 2,995 each.

The crop insurance program ran up $ 5.7 billion in taxpayer losses from 1985 to
1993. The report calculated taxpayer losses by adding the government subsidy for
insurance premiums to claims paid in excess of premiums collected between 1985
and 1993.

Overall, the study said, the government spent nearly $ 10 billion on the crop
insurance program and paid out $ 2.04 in claims for every dollar in premiums
collected.

The top 10 states for crop insurance losses were Texas, North Dakota, Minnesota,
Montana, Iowa, Georgia, Kansas, Louisiana, Nebraska and South Dakota. Illinois
ranked 12th and Missouri 17th. Texas alone collected 15.6 percent of all
insurance payments between 1985 and 1993.

The top 10 states for disaster assistance payments were Texas, North Dakota,
Minnesota, Kansas, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, South Dakota, Michigan and
Georgia. Missouri ranked 13th - a ranking that may be misleading because the
study did not count all of the disaster payments from last year's catastrophic
flooding.

LANGUAGE: English

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                          August 25, 1999, Wednesday,

KING OPTIMISTIC FOR FARM AID;
 IF FEDERAL OFFICIALS GRANT THE RELIEF, MAINE FARMERS COULD GET LOW-INTEREST
LOANS FOR DROUGHT LOSSES.

BYLINE: PAUL CARRIER Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE, Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 644 words

DATELINE: AUGUSTA


Despite recent rains that have breathed new life into Maine's withering
greenery, Gov. Angus King and his agriculture commissioner say they remain
optimistic that the federal government will approve disaster relief for farmers
hard hit by a drought.

King and Agriculture Commissioner Robert Spear offered that assessment Tuesday
as they await the U.S. Department of Agriculture's decision on the state's
request for low-interest agricultural loans. The loans would help farmers
recover from what the state's application for federal aid calls "severe
extraordinary dry weather" in most of the state since early May.

In an Aug. 18 letter to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, King requested
"an emergency designation for crop production and physical losses" in 14 of the
state's 16 counties. "This request is intended to include not only actual losses
incurred to date but also continuing damages that may not be discovered in full
prior to harvest," King wrote.

Last week, Glickman declared Massachusetts and three other states disaster areas
because of the drought's impact on farming there. That raised to 15 the number
of states that have received such declarations so far. Others in the Northeast
include Connecticut, Rhode Island, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

If the federal government agrees that Maine farmers qualify for federal aid,
farmers who lost at least 30 percent of their crops will be able to borrow up to
$ 500,000 each to cover up to 80 percent of their loss. The current interest
rate is 3.75 percent, although that is always subject to change, according to
Deborah Dufour of the USDA.

King's application does not say how much money Maine farmers have lost as a
result of the drought, but it indicates that Aroostook and Piscataquis counties
are the only counties in the state that have been spared. Spear said Tuesday
that York, Cumberland, Androscoggin, Sagadahoc, Knox and Lincoln counties have
been the hardest hit.

Brent Mullis of the USDA, which surveyed losses and presented its findings to
King before he applied for federal loans, said the dollar value of those losses
will not become known until the harvest has been completed. Mullis listed major
losses of blueberries in Hancock and Waldo counties, hay and apples in southern
Maine and vegetable crops everywhere from Penobscot County south to the New
Hampshire border. By contrast, he said, potatoes "are at least normal, if not
better."

The state did get some much-needed rain over the past two weekends and more may
be in the offing this weekend.

Portland has received 1.37 inches of rain so far this month, according to the
National Weather Service in Gray, but the year-to-date total of 23.56 inches
still falls more than 3 inches short of normal levels.

"We still have a ways to go," said meteorologist Butch Roberts.

The sometimes heavy rain this month has been "too little too late," Spear said
Tuesday. In any case, King said, the state's request for federal aid is based on
already documented losses that will not be recovered this year, no matter how
much rain Maine gets from here on out.

"It really related to damages that have already occurred, and the recent rain
won't necessarily fix that," King said. The losses are "quantified and
quantifiable," he said, adding that he is optimistic the federal government will
come through with assistance. "I think the case is there," King said.

King is hoping his bid for low-interest loans fares better than the state's
recent application for federal permission to distribute hay from Aroostook
County to drought-stricken farmers elsewhere in the state. The federal
government pays the farmers who grew that hay not to sell or distribute it, and
the USDA recently refused to grant a waiver that would have allowed the National
Guard to truck the hay to other counties in Maine.

LOAD-DATE: August 26, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              July 1, 2011 Friday

Drought aid sought

BYLINE: Franklin Harris, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 476 words


July 01--Drought conditions in the southernmost part of Alabama have state
officials worried about crop yields, but conditions in North Alabama have
improved following recent rains.

State Department of Agriculture and Industries Commissioner John McMillan said
Thursday that he is requesting a review of drought conditions in the state in
order to begin the process of declaring a federal drought emergency, making
farmers eligible for federal aid.

"Right now, all counties in the southern tier of Alabama are suffering an
extreme drought. Other counties will follow suit if our current low rainfall
pattern persists. The next two weeks are critical," McMillan said.

Farmers in North Alabama, however, are seeing improvement.

"The rain that we've had has certainly helped out our situation in the northern
and central half of the state," said Dana Griffin, a meteorologist in the
National Weather Service's Huntsville office.

The Decatur area received 3.85 inches of rain in June, according to the weather
service.

"Normal is about 4 inches -- 4.08 inches. We're just a tick under right now,"
Griffin said.

According to the U.S. Drought Monitor report released Thursday, most of North
Alabama is either "abnormally dry," the least-severe drought designation, or not
experiencing drought. Most of the state from around Montgomery and south to the
Gulf Coast, however, is in a severe to exceptional drought, with the worst
conditions in Mobile and Baldwin counties.

McMillan also cited a crop acreage report released Thursday by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture stating that conditions for about one-third of
Alabama's leading crops range from poor to very poor. Only 27 percent are rated
good or excellent.

"Based on information from the U.S. Drought Monitor, crop acreage reports and
other sources, I am recommending to Gov. (Robert) Bentley that certain counties
be considered for a drought disaster declaration," McMillan said. The Farm
Services Agency, a division of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, will assess
the governor's request and take action, which in this case would include
providing emergency aid to farmers impacted by the drought, according to the
state Department of Agriculture. Meanwhile, conditions will remain hot and muggy
in North Alabama through the weekend, Griffin said.

"We're probably not looking at any significant rainfall coming into the picture
until maybe the Fourth of July, but really not until after that, maybe by
midweek of next week," he said.

A statewide no-burn order remains in effect.

To see more of The Decatur Daily, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.decaturdaily.com Copyright (c) 2011, The Decatur Daily, Ala.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                The Denver Post

                     September 20, 2002 Friday 1ST EDITION

Colo. cattlemen hope to corral drought aid Ranchers may get $ 18 million from
emergency funds

BYLINE: Steve Raabe , Denver Post Business Writer

SECTION: NEWS DESK; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 795 words


Colorado's drought-stricken ranchers stand to collect a portion of  a $ 752
million emergency aid package announced Thursday by the U.S.  Department of
Agriculture.

Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman said the funding is intended to  offer
immediate help for livestock producers.

In contrast, larger drought appropriations in Congress - as much as  $ 6 billion
- could take months to reach livestock producers, if  they survive a conference
committee and a possible veto by  President Bush. The bills in Congress would
assist livestock  producers and crop growers.

The federal emergency aid comes as Colorado and other parts of the  West suffer
the worst drought on record. Colorado has recorded  hundreds of millions of
dollars in livestock and crop losses.

Most Western states and many in other sections of the nation - 37  states in
total - are eligible for the financial help, including  Wyoming, Nebraska,
Kansas, Utah and New Mexico.

USDA officials could not say Thursday how much of the emergency aid  will go to
Colorado. The Colorado share could be about $ 18 million,  according to an
estimate from the office of U.S. Sen. Wayne Allard,  R-Colo.

Colorado agriculture officials said the funding will help preserve  remaining
herds of cattle producers. Ranchers have been forced to  prematurely sell
animals this summer because of scarce forage and  high feed costs.

'This will mean an awful lot for us,' said Bill Jack, a cattle  rancher in the
Wet Mountain Valley near Westcliffe. 'Without  knowing any details of the
program, I'd still say it'll be  important because the drought has been a near
disaster for many of  us.'

Jack said his hay pastures, which normally would produce 7,000  bales, this
summer yielded only 78 bales.

'This is a tremendous move,' said Terry Fankhauser, executive  vice president of
the Colorado Cattlemen's Association, which  represents 2,500 cattle producers
in Colorado. 'It'll be a  significant help in producers' ability to procure feed
and maintain  their base herds.'

The funding will go to most cattle, sheep and dairy farmers in  Colorado
counties that have been declared primary drought disaster  areas by the USDA.

All counties have received the disaster designation except  Broomfield, Clear
Creek, Denver, Gilpin and San Juan.

Payments under the USDA program range from $ 18 per head for beef  cattle to $
31.50 for dairy cows to $ 4.50 for sheep.

To be eligible, ranchers must have owned the livestock for 90 days.  Payments
are based on the number of animals owned as of June 1,  2002.

The program will be administered by local Farm Service Agency  offices in
Colorado and 36 other states affected by drought.  Livestock producers can begin
signing up Oct. 1.

'We're preparing to get a lot of calls real quick from people  wondering how
soon they'll get their checks,' said Ed Buck, an  agriculture program specialist
at the Farm Service Agency office in  Lakewood.

USDA officials said the payments will be made 'shortly' after a  producer signs
up for the program.

'This program will provide immediate assistance to producers who  need it the
most,' Veneman said in a conference call.

Funding for the $ 752 million aid package comes from the USDA's  Section 32
program, which uses duties collected on agricultural  imports to buy surplus
farm products as a price-support mechanism  for farmers.

The Section 32 funds also are used to pay for school lunch and  domestic
nutrition programs. Veneman said there will be no  reduction in lunch programs
because the drought aid package comes  from other Section 32 accounts.

A spokeswoman for Allard said Colorado's cattle population of 2  million head
earlier this year has been reduced to about 1 million  because of
drought-related sales.

Colorado ranchers would receive about $ 18 million based on payments  of $ 18 a
head for beef cattle, Allard's office said. That total  could increase based on
the number of dairy cows and sheep in the  state.

Under a $ 6 billion drought assistance bill pending in Congress,  Colorado would
receive about $ 80 million in crop disaster funds and  $ 20 million for
livestock assistance.

Veneman said she couldn't predict how the bill will fare in a  House-Senate
conference committee, nor whether Bush will sign the  bill.

U.S. Rep. Bob Schaffer, R-Colo., said he hopes to see a bill emerge  that won't
increase the federal deficit. He said funding for the  bill must originate from
cost savings in other programs instead of  new spending.

"Just spending more (for drought assistance) will not be a  realistic option,"
Schaffer said.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              Journal of Commerce

                            July 19, 1989, Wednesday

SENATE AT ODDS OVER SCOPE OF FARM DISASTER AID PLAN

BYLINE: PAUL S. TOSTO

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 865 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Moments after North Dakota Sen. Kent Conrad unveiled his broad farm disaster
relief plan last week, Minority Leader Robert Dole took the Senate floor. Sen.
Dole was not happy.

The Kansas Republican had wanted to move a narrow rescue bill quickly through
Congress, one that would rush relief to winter wheat farmers devastated by this
year's drought. But his Senate colleagues, Republicans included, wanted elief
for crops and disasters in their states, too.

With budget constraints tight, a big disaster bill would mean less money for
Sen. Dole's winter wheat farmers, who were suffering now. Sen. Conrad's bill
called for aid to crops that had yet to be planted. "Equity is not holding one
group hostage for 6, 7, 8 months until we take care of everybody else in the
country," Sen. Dole complained to Sen. Conrad, a Democrat.

"If we would have acted when the senator from Kansas was urging us to act, his
people would have been taken care of and my people would not have been take care
of . . . My people a re on the brink of facing a disaster every bit as serious .
. . ," Sen. Conrad said.

The Senate Agriculture Committee is supposed to begin crafting its disaster aid
package today, but congressional sources say that committee members have still
not finished drafting a bill.

So it goes. As the drought rolls mercilessly into 1989, the Senate finds itself
agonizing over which farmers to help and which to exclude. Despite Bush
administration warnings over the final cost of disaster aid, Senate Republicans
are divided on the scope of legislation, and the list of producers who may get
help is widening as the weeks tick by.

Congressional and industry sources agree it is no longer politically feasible
for Congress to pass a bill covering just winter wheat. The House has already
passed a massive crop disaster bill - essentially an extension of the 1988 law -
that may cost more than $ 1 billion. The Senate now appears headed down a
similar path.

Sen. Dole and U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter have
urged restraint, arguing that only winter wheat producers have been damaged so
far. But persistent dry weather in the Midwest and flooding down South have
forced new pressure on Sen. Dole and Mr. Yeutter to compromise.

''I think the cement has cracked around the (administration's) firm position
that (aid) was only going to winter wheat," said Rob Nooter, lobbyist with the
American Farm Bureau Federation. "The thing tends to snowball from this point
forward," he said.

Senators still hope to write a bill before early August, when Congress adjourns
for the summer. Senate Agriculture Committee members remain divided. But the
divisions are geographical, not political, with some Republicans asking for as
much aid for their farmers as Democrats.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, told reporters he favored extending the 1988
drought law, but for program crops only. Sen. Grassley is particularly worried
because in Iowa "his own corn crop is burning," said Caran Colbe McKee, his
press secretary. Sen. Grassley believes "Dole is mellowing" on his demand for a
drought bill targeted only at winter wheat farmers, Ms. McKee said.

In Mississippi, floods have put more than 200,000 crop acres under water.
Extension agents estimate damages to cotton and grains at roughly $ 400 million,
said an aide to Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss. In a meeting of Senate Republicans
last week, Sen. Cochran passed around photos of Mississippi drowning, apparently
convincing Mr. Yeutter that those farmers deserved help, too.

Montana Democratic Sen. Max Baucus, is worried about cherry producers in his
state, and Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., is concerned the blush may have left his
state's peach crop.

Like they did last year, lawmakers seeking aid for their farmers say it will not
cost the government a dime. Higher crop prices from the drought mean lower USDA
payments. That "savings" will be used to aid farmers hurt by weather disasters,
they say.

But savings from program commodities will likely need to be used to aid growers
of both program and non-program crops. That means, for example, that even if the
House bill were approved by Congress there may not be enough money to give
winter wheat producers the same aid spring wheat producers got last year - even
though the legislation is essentially the same.

Sen. Dole and Indiana Sen. Richard Lugar, ranking Republican on the Senate
Agriculture Committee, met with OMB Director Richard Darman on Tuesday to get a
better feel for possible budget savings from the drought and related weather
problems this year. The OMB's new spending estimates could be used as a
benchmark for new disaster aid.

At this point, however, Sen. Lugar and Sen. Dole will likely find it tough
persuading the full Senate committee to write a narrow disaster aid bill, no
matter what the numbers say.

''I think they've (Republicans) got a rebellion in their ranks," said one
agriculture staffer.

''Broadly speaking, there seems to be a consensus between Republicans and
Democrats, with the exception of Sen. Dole and Sen. Lugar, (that the bill should
cover) all crops and all disasters," he said.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

                                   USA TODAY

                     April 6, 1993, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Aid package includes $ 700M in symbolism

BYLINE: Lori Sharn

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 256 words


The new U.S. aid package for Russia includes $ 700 million in agricultural
credits - less than one-third of what the former Soviet Union used to purchase
from U.S. farmers.

But it is significant because all agricultural sales were suspended Dec. 1 when
Russia defaulted on payments guaranteed by the U.S. government.

"No, it's not a big package. It's big more for what it symbolizes," says Jack
King, of the American Farm Bureau Federation. "It bodes well for future sales."

Last year, 62% of U.S. exports to the former Soviet Union were agricultural.

Under the new aid package, revealed at last weekend's summit between President
Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin, the U.S. government will buy and
ship the agricultural products, and Russia will repay the USA. The products are
yet to be negotiated.

A big chunk of the $ 700 million will be spent on freight. The proposal calls
for sending 75% of the goods on U.S.-flagged ships, which can cost three times
as much as vessels registered in other nations.

Erick Erickson of the U.S. Feed Grains Council says the remaining money could
purchase more than 4 million tons of corn and wheat.

Wheat prices were up last week in anticipation of the aid announcement. But the
sale won't dent the U.S. corn surplus, which drove down prices after a bumper
crop last year, says Nebraska farmer Randy Cruise, president of the National
Corn Growers Association.

But he calls the aid plan "good news. . . . Nothing cuts off a democracy as fast
as people going hungry."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

WORKING WITH RUSSIA

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                             May 15, 1993, Saturday

SCIENCE DIGEST Musseling in on New Orleans territory

SECTION: SCIENCE; Section E; Page 1

LENGTH: 387 words


It was inevitable, but a new pest has made it all the way past New Orleans: a
freshwater mollusk that plays the dickens with drinking water systems, ports and
ships, according to the Louisiana State University Agricultural Center. The
mussels range in size from a dime to an adult's thumbnail, and, in huge numbers,
can clog water intake pipes and drainage culverts. They are native to the
drainage basins of the Black, Caspian and Aral seas of Europe and Asia. No one
knows how they reached North America. Experts suspect they were brought by
oceangoing ships traveling up the St. Lawrence Seaway to the Great Lakes around
1986.

A good fungus among us. A scientist with the U.S. Department of Agriculture says
a naturally occurring fungus can eliminate more than 90 percent of a common weed
that infests Southern crops. The fungus, dubbed COLTRU, can kill hemp sesbania,
a common weed that infests Southern soybean, cotton and rice fields. The fungus
was found on sick hemp sesbania seedlings near Stoneville, Miss. "COLTRU is
highly virulent, host-specific and will work in a wide range of environmental
conditions," said C. Douglas Boyette, a plant pathologist at the Jamie Whitten
Delta States Research Center in Stoneville.

New industrial robots taking shape. A new generation of scientific and
industrial robots is taking shape in a basement engineering laboratory at the
Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. "Shape" is a key word, as tentacle-like
trains of rods and motors twist and wind their way among obstacles and reach
into highly constrained areas. Descendants of these prototypes will be able to
perform such varied tasks as inspecting nuclear reactors, entering hostile
environments to clean up toxic materials or even exploring distant planets.

Nerve cells in damaged ear can regenerate. There's more good news for some
people with hearing loss. Researchers at Washington University in St. Louis have
evidence that nerve cells can regenerate in the damaged inner ear. "In areas of
the ears where there had been tremendous damage, we found new nerve fibers that
appeared to be seeking sensory cells to make new connections," says Dr. Barbara
Bohne, professor of otolaryngology. While a cochlear implant can help those with
profound hearing deficits, not everyone is a candidate for the device.

                               The Times (London)

                          September 10, 2005, Saturday

British aid is held up in US fiasco

BYLINE: Ben Hoyle

SECTION: Overseas news; 45

LENGTH: 576 words


MoD furious after ban on EU meat keeps ration packs sitting on runways after
urgent delivery by the RAF, Ben Hoyle reports

The United States held up British emergency rations worth £4 million for five
days because of fears about the safety of European meat.

As the refugee crisis that followed the floods in Louisiana grew during the
week, more than 400,000 military ration packs sat at two airfields in America.

Washington had requested them last weekend, but the meals fell foul of a United
States Department of Agriculture ban on the import of certain products from the
European Union.

But last night, five days after the first batches of aid arrived from Britain
and after negotiations with the British Government, the agency waived the ban,
paving the way for the food to be distributed to those who need it.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said: "The United States Department of Agriculture
has cleared ration packs for onward distribution. Meals from all EU member
states have been cleared."

However, British defence staff are furious that the delay prevented the rations
from reaching the refugees for whom they were intended until this weekend.

One member of the Ministry of Defence's Defence Logistics Organisation, which
helped to organise the airlift, said: "Can you imagine how this is going down at
our end? People were working their butts off on Sunday and Monday to make this
happen. This aid wasn't volunteered. The US asked for it.

"We moved heaven and earth to get this stuff out there. You don't send half a
million ration packs if you don't think they're going to be used."

The MoD estimates that the cost of supplying the meals was about £6 million.

A spokeswoman said: "The packs themselves cost £3 million to £4 million and the
airlift cost around $ 4 million (£2.2 million).

"We responded as quickly as possible to a request from the US authorities
following Hurricane Katrina -including specifically a request for emergency
ration packs. Some of these packs have arrived on US soil and the handling of
this is now a matter for the US authorities. It's a matter for them if and how
they distribute these packs."

The first batch of ration packs left RAF Brize Norton in two aircraft on Monday
morning. About half a million meals were assembled for transportation, of which
400,000 are at two airfields, one at Little Rock, Arkansas, the other in Texas.

Shipment of the remaining 100,000 packs had been suspended.

The packs sitting on the tarmac in Texas and Arakansas are standard issue
British military rations, designed to feed one soldier on operations for 24
hours.

Each one has 3,500 calories and can sustain a civilian in less-physically
demanding circumstances for two days. The packs include a boil-in-the-bag
breakfast, a main meal, a dessert, savoury snacks, biscuits, sweets, coffee and
tea and tissues.

Breakfast options are typically sausage or bacon served with beans. Lunch might
be a beef stew and dumplings, a chicken curry or a lamb hotpot. Desserts include
rice pudding and chocolate roll with chocolate sauce.

Vegetarian versions have also been sent.

Inside the cardboard pack there is a mini-stove and matches to heat up meals and
drinks, but they can be eaten cold if necessary.

Perhaps confusingly for their intended recipients, one of the chocolate bars
supplied in the packs is a Yorkie bar that bears the slogan "Not for civvies."

                 Republican & Herald (Pottsville, Pennsylvania)

                             June 2, 2010 Wednesday

Proposed state budget will cut funding for Schuylkill County Fair

BYLINE: Stephen J. Pytak AND Robert Swift, Republican and Herald, Pottsville,
Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 813 words


Jun. 2--The organizers of the Schuylkill County Fair aren't banking on the state
for much, if any, financial support this year.

State aid to county fairs is up in the air as lawmakers face tough decisions
while crafting a new budget.

"Every year, we kind of go through this. The current governor doesn't put us in
the budget, then state representatives and senators start getting together and
our people start to work the system and they find ways to get us funding," said
the Rev. Karl W. Jones, Orwigsburg, president of the Schuylkill County Fair
Association and the fair's parent organization, the Schuylkill County Foundation
for Agriculture and Resource Management.

Pennsylvania's 115 county fairs and shows are a summertime staple, providing a
showcase for the state's large agriculture industry. In flush economic times,
the fairs divvy up several million dollars in aid from Harrisburg to help pay
out prize money to contestants and underwrite improvements to buildings and
grounds.

But this year, assurances of aid haven't been forthcoming as the state budget
deficit hit $1.2 billion on Tuesday. The House and Senate return to session
Monday with fiscal issues taking center stage as the June 30 deadline looms for
approving the 2010-11 budget.

When Gov. Ed Rendell proposed an initial budget in February, he made no
allocation for the county fairs and that was when the deficit was pegged at a
smaller $500 million.

The fairs sustained an aid cut in the current budget, receiving $2 million,
compared with $3.6 million in fiscal 2008-09. Of that amount, $1.6 million went
to grants for the fairs, $300,000 to youth agriculture programs and $55,000 for
youth agricultural organizations, according to the state Agriculture Department.

In Schuylkill County in 2008, the state provided about $20,000 to the county
fair. In 2009, that was dropped to $15,000, said Robert Evanchalk, vice
president of the Schuylkill County Foundation for Agriculture and Resource
Management, the nonprofit organization that conducts the fair.

"The state funding we received was running around $20,000 for a few years. It
was really reduced last year, down about one-third. However, we were able to
cope with it. We're hoping to have something in the budget again this year but
we're certainly not counting on it," Evanchalk said Tuesday. "The $15,000 in
state funding was used to pay premium checks for our exhibitors."

If state aid isn't available this year, funding for premiums, which pay for
exhibitor prizes, will be taken from gate admissions, he said.

"We've all been living with budget cuts from the state to the county, so we have
to find other creative ways to do this. Our position has always been that we
want to keep the prices family friendly. So we lowered some of our prices while
keeping some the same. Some people think we get big money for doing this, but
all the members of the board, we're all volunteers. Nobody gets paid," Jones
said.

The Agriculture Department classifies fairs in five classes depending on days of
operation and fairground acreage to determine how much aid is given.

A complete loss of state aid wouldn't mean the shows won't go on, said Mark
O'Neill, spokesman for the Pennsylvania Farm Bureau. However, each fair board
would need to consider options such as increasing admission fees or reducing
prize amounts, he said.

"We're not saying a fair is not going to happen because of this," O'Neill said.
"The last thing they want to do is raise an admission fee."

At the Capitol, lawmakers are girding for fights on many appropriations that
have enjoyed considerable backing in the past.

"The line item for county fairs is one that has enjoyed strong bipartisan
support over the years, but restoring any of the governor's cuts this year will
be extraordinarily difficult," said Erik Arneson, spokesman for Senate Majority
Leader Dominic Pileggi, R-9, Chester.

"It (aid) can't be promised in any way, shape or form," said Kristin
Ebersole-Crawford, executive director of the Senate Agriculture and Rural
Affairs Committee.

The 27th annual Schuylkill County Fair will be held at the fairgrounds in Summit
Station from Aug. 2 through Aug. 7. Highlights of the 2010 Schuylkill County
Fair include Royalty Coronation on Aug. 2, and a live performance by the 1980s
rock group "Survivor," known for the hit "Eye of the Tiger," on Aug. 7.

For more information on this year's Schuylkill County Fair, log on to
www.schuylkillfair.com/index.html.

To see more of the Republican & Herald or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.republicanherald.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Republican and Herald,
Pottsville, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              The Washington Post

                      July 16, 1993, Friday, Final Edition

Area Prepares to Seek Disaster Aid;
Maryland, Virginia Survey Weather-Related Crop Damage

Richard Tapscott, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE B2

LENGTH: 452 words


Agriculture officials in Maryland and Virginia have begun systematic studies of
crop damage caused by the recent hot, dry weather as they prepare to seek
federal disaster relief.

After touring an Eastern Shore farm yesterday, Maryland Gov. William Donald
Schaefer said that preliminary surveys found scattered damage to corn and
soybean crops across the state.

"If we don't have rain in a week, it will become a disaster in some parts of the
state," Schaefer said as he returned to the State House in Annapolis.

State and federal agriculture officials were expected to complete a "flash"
survey today of county-by-county crop conditions. A more detailed study would be
needed before the state could ask President Clinton to declare disaster areas,
which would make farmers there eligible for low-interest loans.

Schaefer said he will ask the Maryland congressional delegation to seek
contingency funding for Maryland farmers as part of the $ 2.5 billion disaster
aid package that Clinton sent to Capitol Hill for the flood-ravaged Midwest.

In Virginia, King and Queen County officials mailed a request for a disaster
declaration to Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. A spokeswoman for state Agriculture
Commissioner Clifton V. Turner said two other counties, Middlesex and King
William, are expected to submit requests.

Fruit growers in the Virginia valleys have reported little loss as a result of
the heat wave, the spokeswoman said, but some vegetable farmers on the Virginia
Eastern Shore said they expect a yield of one-third less than last year.

Maryland Agriculture Secretary Robert L. Walker said yesterday that some
counties, such as Wicomico on the Eastern Shore, may see a 40 percent drop in
yields and could qualify for federal disaster aid. He cautioned, however, that
conditions for aid are spotty, since some areas have received recent rain.

Overall, the state's annual rainfall is about normal, Walker said, and subsoil
moisture remains good because of the dry, cool spring. But the hot and dry
weather in the last two weeks came at a critical time in corn pollination and
the growth of new soybean crops, experts said.

The irony, Walker said, is that feed-grain prices for Mid-Atlantic farmers could
be high this year because flooding in the Corn Belt along the Mississippi River
and drought in the South has reduced crop production.

Besides the effect on grains, the heat wave also has taken a toll on Eastern
Shore poultry growers and on the state's dairy industry. Walker said as many as
200,000 chickens have died as a result of the intense heat. Some dairy farmers
-- most clustered in Central and Western Maryland -- reported a nearly 15
percent drop in milk production, he said.

                                   USA TODAY

                            October 20, 2008 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Rules relaxed for 'food stamp' eligibility

BYLINE: Wendy Koch

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 423 words


As the economy weakens, states and the federal government are trying to help
more people qualify for "food stamps."

Since Oct. 1, new federal rules make it easier for households with income from
combat pay, retirement accounts or education savings to be eligible. The rules
are part of the 2008 Farm Bill, which changed the name of the food stamp program
to Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP).

"This is a nutrition program, not a welfare program," says Jean Daniel,
spokeswoman for the U.S. Department of Agriculture, noting that half the 29
million Americans who receive aid are children. SNAP serves one of every five of
the nation's kids, who are also eligible for free or reduced-price school meals.

Some states are going further to expand eligibility. Last month, California
enacted a bill that will allow low-income people to keep some savings and still
qualify for food aid. At least four other states -- Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania
and Vermont -- similarly eased the asset test this year.

"People won't have to sink to ground zero to get help," says Paul Fraunholtz, a
deputy director in Ohio's Department of Job and Family Services.

The U.S. government pays for the benefit, and states cover half the cost of
administering the program, which began in 1961.  States are allowed to adjust
eligibility rules, and more are doing so.  As of Oct. 1, Washington state
allowed people with slightly higher incomes, up to $42,400 for a family of four,
to qualify.  New York began giving energy aid to more low-income renters,
because receiving such aid increases their monthly food stamp benefit.

"States are looking for new ways to support working families," says Stacy Dean,
director of food assistance policy at the Center on Budget and Policy
Priorities, which studies policies that affect low- and moderate-income people.
She says more states, faced with tight budgets, are making changes this year to
increase federal food aid.

Dean says the changes will increase participation but job layoffs will do far
more to add people to the program. She says states and the USDA are encouraging
eligible people to seek benefits.  Currently, two-thirds of them do.

"This is not your father's food stamp program," says Heidi Tringe, policy
adviser to Vermont's Republican Gov. Jim Douglas. Recipients no longer get
vouchers; they get debit cards. She says many people are worried about food and
energy bills this winter, so expanding food aid is "the right thing to do."

To find out more about SNAP eligibility, go to: ww.fns.usda.gov/snap

LOAD-DATE: October 20, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Agriculture (Bar chart)

                              The Washington Post

                      July 12, 1992, Sunday, Final Edition

Frank R. Ellis, AID Official, Dies at Age 77

SECTION: METRO; PAGE B10; OBITUARIES

LENGTH: 386 words


Frank Ross Ellis, 77, a retired deputy coordinator of the Agency for
International Development's Food for Peace program who also had worked for the
Agriculture Department and on Capitol Hill, died of cancer July 10 at his home
in Bethesda.

He came to Washington and began his government career with USDA in 1935. He
transferred as a commodity specialist to the Economic Cooperation
Administration, the agency that administered the Marshall Plan, in 1948. He
later returned to Agriculture, where he was commodity programs branch chief in
the department's tobacco division from 1951 to 1959.

From 1959 to 1962, Mr. Ellis was an administrative assistant to Rep. Frank
Stubblefield (D-Ky.). He then joined AID as agricultural resources division
director in its material resources office. He worked for AID until retiring in
1972. During his years with AID, he participated in delegations to South Asia
and the Middle East and worked with United Nations groups.

He was a recipient of AID's highest award, the Distinguished Honor Award, and
the Agriculture Department's Superior Service Award.

Mr. Ellis, a Kentucky native, was a 1935 graduate of Murray State University. He
served with the Army in the Pacific during World War II, was recalled to active
duty during the Korean War, and rose to the rank of major in the Army Reserve in
the 1950s.

His first wife, Hazel Boyer Ellis, died in 1989. Survivors include his wife,
June Norris August Ellis of Bethesda; two sons from his first marriage, James
F., of Stuarts Draft, Va., and John R., of Los Angeles; three stepchildren,
James L. Norris Jr. of Lanham, Jon W. Norris of Bethesda and June Norris Carter
of Highland, Md.; a sister, Leila Erwin of Murray, Ky.; five grandchildren and
four stepgrandchildren.

FAYE M. WYLLY.

Chevy Chase Resident

Faye Merrell Wylly, 86, a Chevy Chase resident since moving to this area from
Florida in 1966, died of asthma and cardiac arrest July 10 at her home.

Mrs. Wylly, a Georgia native, had attended business school in Atlanta and was a
secretary and bookkeeper there before her 1930 marriage to Alexander Campbell
Wylly. She was active in his Florida acoustical insulation business before his
death in 1963.

Survivors include a son, Alexander Campbell Wylly, and a sister, Mildred
Merrell, both of Chevy Chase.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OBITUARY

                              39 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                 Republican & Herald (Pottsville, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 2, 2010 Wednesday

Proposed state budget will cut funding for Schuylkill County Fair funding

BYLINE: Stephen J. Pytak AND Robert Swift, Republican and Herald, Pottsville,
Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 822 words


Jun. 2--The organizers of the Schuylkill County Fair aren't banking on the state
for much, if any, financial support this year.

State aid to county fairs is up in the air as lawmakers face tough decisions
while crafting a new budget.

"Every year, we kind of go through this. The current governor doesn't put us in
the budget, then state representatives and senators start getting together and
our people start to work the system and they find ways to get us funding," said
the Rev. Karl W. Jones, Orwigsburg, president of the Schuylkill County Fair
Association and the fair's parent organization, the Schuylkill County Foundation
for Agriculture and Resource Management.

Pennsylvania's 115 county fairs and shows are a summertime staple, providing a
showcase for the state's large agriculture industry. In flush economic times,
the fairs divvy up several million dollars in aid from Harrisburg to help pay
out prize money to contestants and underwrite improvements to buildings and
grounds.

But this year, assurances of aid haven't been forthcoming as the state budget
deficit hit $1.2 billion on Tuesday. The House and Senate return to session
Monday with fiscal issues taking center stage as the June 30 deadline looms for
approving the 2010-11 budget.

When Gov. Ed Rendell proposed an initial budget in February, he made no
allocation for the county fairs and that was when the deficit was pegged at a
smaller $500 million.

The fairs sustained an aid cut in the current budget, receiving $2 million,
compared with $3.6 million in fiscal 2008-09. Of that amount, $1.6 million went
to grants for the fairs, $300,000 to youth agriculture programs and $55,000 for
youth agricultural organizations, according to the state Agriculture Department.

In Schuylkill County in 2008, the state provided about $20,000 to the county
fair. In 2009, that was dropped to $15,000, said Robert Evanchalk, vice
president of the Schuylkill County Foundation for Agriculture and Resource
Management, the nonprofit organization that conducts the fair.

"The state funding we received was running around $20,000 for a few years. It
was really reduced last year, down about one-third. However, we were able to
cope with it. We're hoping to have something in the budget again this year but
we're certainly not counting on it," Evanchalk said Tuesday. "The $15,000 in
state funding was used to pay premium checks for our exhibitors."

If state aid isn't available this year, funding for premiums, which pay for
exhibitor prizes, will be taken from gate admissions, he said.

"We've all been living with budget cuts from the state to the county, so we have
to find other creative ways to do this. Our position has always been that we
want to keep the prices family friendly. So we lowered some of our prices while
keeping some the same. Some people think we get big money for doing this, but
all the members of the board, we're all volunteers. Nobody gets paid," Jones
said.

The Agriculture Department classifies fairs in five classes depending on days of
operation and fairground acreage to determine how much aid is given.

A complete loss of state aid wouldn't mean the shows won't go on, said Mark
O'Neill, spokesman for the Pennsylvania Farm Bureau. However, each fair board
would need to consider options such as increasing admission fees or reducing
prize amounts, he said.

"We're not saying a fair is not going to happen because of this," O'Neill said.
"The last thing they want to do is raise an admission fee."

At the Capitol, lawmakers are girding for fights on many appropriations that
have enjoyed considerable backing in the past.

"The line item for county fairs is one that has enjoyed strong bipartisan
support over the years, but restoring any of the governor's cuts this year will
be extraordinarily difficult," said Erik Arneson, spokesman for Senate Majority
Leader Dominic Pileggi, R-9, Chester.

"It (aid) can't be promised in any way, shape or form," said Kristin
Ebersole-Crawford, executive director of the Senate Agriculture and Rural
Affairs Committee.

The 27th annual Schuylkill County Fair will be held at the fairgrounds in Summit
Station from Aug. 2 through Aug. 7. Highlights of the 2010 Schuylkill County
Fair include Royalty Coronation on Aug. 2, and a live performance by the 1980s
rock group "Survivor," known for the hit "Eye of the Tiger," on Aug. 7.

For more information on this year's Schuylkill County Fair, log on to
www.schuylkillfair.com/index.html.

Sign up for Text Alerts

                              The Washington Post

                              July 30, 2001 Monday
                                 Final Edition

'Eggplant Caucus' Cultivates Support

BYLINE: Dan Morgan, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A13

LENGTH: 637 words


The Senate's "eggplant caucus" racked up another victory last week.

The caucus, organized by Sen. Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.) and nicknamed for New
Jersey's eggplant farmers, has been fighting for more than a year to redress
what it considers years of discrimination against East Coast agricultural
interests in farm bills.

Only a third of farmers, most of them corn, wheat, soybean or cotton growers
with hefty political support, get any government support payments. Ten percent
of those who do, come away with about two-thirds of the money, according to
Washington's Environmental Working Group.

The short shrift given the East Coast is evident in the fact that Leahy is the
sole regional representative on the 21-member Senate Agriculture Committee.
(Rice producer Arkansas alone has two.) The House Agriculture Committee, with 51
members, has just two, representing Maine and Pennsylvania.

So the eggplant caucus, made up of senators from Virginia to Maine, came to be.

"Its immediate focus was to stress that Northeast and mid-Atlantic states whose
agriculture interests are different from those of the mass commodities of the
Midwest deserve a seat at table," said Leahy spokesman David Carle.

The caucus had its first success in last year's crop insurance legislation,
which traditionally has provided little help for growers of fruits, vegetables
and other specialty crops.

With the caucus behind him, Leahy was able to get money set aside in the bill
for government payment programs for which specialty farmers would be eligible,
such as conservation grants, environmental initiatives and assistance with the
transition to organic farming. The aid was limited to farmers in the 15 states
that get the least government farm aid.

Then last Thursday, Leahy and his eggplanters scored a further success with a $
7.4 billion "emergency supplemental" farm bill approved by the Senate
Agriculture Committee. The bill earmarked $ 100 million for additional
conservation programs in the same 15 states, and provided $ 25 million for the
army worm problem, which has devasted hay crops in Vermont, New Hampshire,
Missouri and other states.

The success of the eggplant coalition is part of an effort in Congress to
broaden the benefits of farm legislation that has long helped mainly the Midwest
and South.

The emergency measure approved Thursday also includes $ 220 million for
government purchases of specialty crops that experienced low prices in the 2000
and 2001 crop years -- another step outside traditional farm programs.

Apple growers, centered in such states as New York, Michigan, Washington, Oregon
and West Virginia, will be eligible for a $ 150 million government purchase
program to boost prices.

In a sign of changing times, Sen. Deborah Ann Stabenow (D-Mich.) criticized a
substitute measure offered by Sen. Richard G. Lugar (R-Ind.) for not aiding
apple growers.

The movement to diversify farm aid has its political perils for both parties,
however.

The traditional commodity states of the Midwest and Great Plains are an
important base for the Democratic Party in the Senate, starting with Senate
Majority Leader Thomas A. Daschle (D-S.D.). Senate Agriculture Committee
Chairman Tom Harkin (D-Iowa), who supports "balance" in farm bills, is up for
reelection next year.

The Week Ahead: The Senate will take up the $ 7.4 billion supplemental
agricultural authorization bill, reauthorization of export controls and
appropriations bills. The House is scheduled to complete work on a bill funding
the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Housing and Urban
Development. It will take up legislative branch appropriations, a ban on
cloning, the Jordan trade bill and an energy bill. Time permitting, the House
may consider the patients' bill of rights and "fast track" trade legislation.

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

New Nebraskan, Nebraska Legacy or Midwest Student Exchange Program scholarships
to attend the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

The North Dakota Grain Dealers Educational Foundation is taking applications for
financial aid for the 2006-07 school term. Ten awards of $500 per person are
planned. Students must be enrolled in one of the following curriculums:

Bismarck State College - Agribusiness Sales and Service, Agriculture Transfer.

Agriculture Sales and Service, Agribusiness Management, Agriculture Transfer.

Transfer.

Agriculture Transfer.

Service, Agriculture Transfer, Agriculture Systems Management (NDSU Transfer).

MSU­Bottineau - Agriculture Transfer.

College of Agriculture, Food Systems and Natural Resources, NDSU, Fargo -
Agribusiness: Agribusiness Finance, Agribusiness Management, Agribusiness
Marketing; Agricultural Economics: Farm Management, Agrifinance, Commodity
Marketing; Agricultural Systems Management: Agribusiness or Applied Technology
options; Crop and Weed Science: Biotech or Weed Science options; Plant
Protection; Soil Science; Food Science.

The scholarship application deadline is Sept. 30. Major emphasis will be placed
on students interested in careers in the grain marketing industry. Applications
can be obtained by writing the Foundation office at 118 Broadway N. Suite 606,
Fargo, N.D. 58102, or by calling 701-235-4184.

                               The New York Times

                  April 24, 1992, Friday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Wheat Up on Expectations Of Accelerated Russian Aid

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 14; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 423 words


Wheat futures prices rose sharply yesterday amid expectations for accelerated
Russian food aid and signs of further damage to the winter wheat crop.

Other grain and soybean futures also rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly
erasing Wednesday's losses.

Wheat for May delivery, which represents the last of the 1991 crop, rose 6 3/4
cents, to $3.80 3/4 a bushel, in Chicago. New-crop wheat rose as much as 8 1/4
cents a bushel.

May corn rose 3/4 cent, to $2.52 a bushel; May oats rose 2 1/4 cents, to $1.42
1/4 a bushel; May soybeans climbed 4 1/2 cents, to $5.81 1/2 a bushel.

Talk circulated in the pits that Russia had asked the Agriculture Department to
hasten the release of $600 million in agricultural export loan guarantees, which
are scheduled to be distributed in four monthly installments beginning next
month.

Traders expect the Russians to use a large chunk of the credits to buy wheat,
said Don Roose, grains analyst with U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines. That
has been the pattern with previous United States food aid.

Wheat futures also drew support from expectations that wet conditions in the
Great Plains and Midwest are fostering the spread of disease in the winter wheat
crop, said Gerald Zusel, a vice president with E.D.& F. Man International
Futures Inc. in Chicago.

"The wheat condition has not exactly been in the best of shape," he said.

The Agriculture Department reported Monday that 82 percent of the United States
winter wheat crop was in fair to good shape as of Sunday. Soft red winter wheat
in Indiana, Illinois and Missouri suffered severe frost damage last month.

Near-term wheat futures were also supported by reports of tight availability of
wheat for delivery against the May contract, which enters its delivery phase
next Thursday.

Soybean futures were increased by the Russian credit talk. Corn prices were
raised by a National Weather Service forecast for above-average rain in the
Midwest during the latter half of next week, which could cause further planting
delays, Mr. Roose said.

Crude oil ended unchanged on the New York Mercantile Exchange as OPEC oil
ministers gathered in Vienna for a meeting. The nations appeared likely to hold
oil production steady at the spring output ceiling of 22.98 million barrels a
day.

Light sweet crude oil was unchanged at $20.11 a barrel; May heating oil fell
0.37 cent, to 55.41 cents a gallon; May unleaded gasoline rose 0.05 cent, to
61.70 cents a gallon; May natural gas climbed 2.5 cents, to $1.596 for 1,000
cubic feet.

LOAD-DATE: April 24, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                   August 19, 1987, Wednesday, Final Edition

U.S. Aid May Be Scant Relief to Md. Farmers

BYLINE: Robert Barnes, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C3

LENGTH: 680 words

DATELINE: PRICE, Md., Aug.18, 1987


Hot, dry skies offered Maryland's drought-stricken farmers no relief today, and
federal agriculture officials were only slightly more promising.

While Assistant Secretary of Agriculture Wilmer D. Mizell told Eastern Shore
farmers it was likely the federal government would approve Gov. William Donald
Schaefer's request for disaster aid for 15 Maryland counties, state officials
questioned how much help that would provide.

Beginning this year, the federal government said that only farmers who had
federally subsidized crop insurance could become eligible for the low-interest
loans that are part of the federal disaster aid. State agriculture officials
said that as few as 570 of the state's 18,000 farmers had such insurance.

Mizell and other federal officials said it was not likely the government would
change those requirements, as some farmers had requested.

"The U.S. government and the USDA have said we're going to get out of the
disaster business," added James Richardson, the Maryland head of the
department's Agricultural, Stabilization and Conservation Service. The
government intends for the federally subsidized crop insurance program to cover
drought and other losses, he said.

Rep. Roy Dyson (D-Md.), whose 1st Congressional District covers much of the
state's agricultural land, invited federal officials to Queen Anne's County for
a firsthand look at the drought damage. As cameras recorded the scene, Mizell
and Dyson walked through cornfields that had turned the color of dried tobacco,
and were later shown soybeans that had failed to produce any seed pods.

"Welcome to the Eastern Shore, again," Dyson told Mizell, noting that Maryland
farmers for the second consecutive year are asking for federal disaster
assistance.

Although last year's drought was more severe, Dyson said this year could be
tougher for Maryland farmers politically.

Congress voted in 1986 to provide additional disaster aid, including direct
grants in some cases, Dyson said. But he added it would be much harder to get
such assistance this year. The cause was helped in 1986 because it was an
election year, Dyson said, and because 2,600 counties throughout the country
asked for aid. Only a few counties in about a half-dozen states are expected to
make requests this time.

It is a banner year for farmers in the Midwest, Dyson said, "and that's not
going to make it a good year for East Coast farmers" to receive special aid.

But that doesn't lessen the damage that has occurred here. In his letter asking
for assistance, Schaefer said that the record heat and lack of rainfall had cost
farmers in 15 counties more than $ 70 million in crops so far, about 18 percent
of the state's $ 400 million agriculture industry. Last year, the damage was
about $ 118 million.

This year's drought was much more spotty than last year's, state officials said,
and hardest hit were the Eastern Shore, Southern Maryland, and Anne Arundel and
Prince George's counties.

Pat Caulk, of the federal Farmers Home Administration, said his agency would be
recommending that the Agriculture Department grant Schaefer's request for
disaster aid, as well as extending the aid to three counties in Delaware.
Virginia officials have said it was likely that three counties in that state
would ask for aid.

But the requirement of crop insurance could mean that few farmers would receive
the low-interest loans the aid would make available. Paul Gunther, the
University of Maryland extension agency chief in Queen Anne's, said the
insurance plan was costly and it was difficult for farmers to enroll in it.

Maryland farmers trying to recover from last year's losses found that forgoing
the crop insurance was one way they could hold down their costs, Gunther said.

Mizell said that federal officials will work with the state, the farmers and
local banks to try to find other ways to help. "I know there's nothing more
disheartening to farmers than to plow and plant and then have nothing to
harvest," Mizell said, adding that his agency "is in the business of keeping
them on the farm."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, AT LEFT, WILMER MIZELL OF USDA AND REP. ROY DYSON, RIGHT,SURVEY
HAY FIELD WITH OWNER BILL KIMBLES, CENTER. AT RIGHT, DYSON, LEFT, AND MIZELL
CHECK CORN. LARRY MORRIS

TYPE: MARYLAND NEWS

                              The Washington Post

                    August 2, 1986, Saturday, Final Edition

Farmers to Get $1 Billion in Relief;
Agriculture Dept. Plan to Hike Subsidy Advances Gets Mixed Reception

BYLINE: By Jonathan Karp, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A3

LENGTH: 549 words


Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said yesterday that his department will
provide drought-stricken farmers in the Southeast with up to $1 billion in crop
relief "because many of these farmers need payments now."

Producers of wheat, feed grains, cotton and rice will be offered advance
deficiency payments -- subsidies to bridge the gap between a target price and a
lower market price -- of 10 percent more than they could receive in 1986, he
said. Growers until now have received between 30 percent and 40 percent in
advance payments, Lyng said.

Lyng also said the Agriculture Department will pay 50 percent of grain costs for
livestock owners, who have suffered a 40 percent loss of feed crops.

The drought, considered the worst in more than a century, has ruined crops from
southern Pennsylvania to northern Florida. The Agriculture Department has
designated 189 counties in Alabama, Delaware, Maryland, North Carolina, South
Carolina and Virginia for emergency aid. Lyng said he expects more states or
parts of states to be designated in the next few days.

Agriculture Department officials said it will be difficult to calculate losses
until the fall harvest, but several states estimate losses of hundreds of
millions of dollars.

The Senate approved by voice vote yesterday a drought-relief bill which its
sponsors said would provide $300 million in aid. The House Agriculture Committee
approved a similar measure Wednesday.

Members of Congress gave a lukewarm response to the Agriculture Department plan.
Sen. Jim Sasser (D-Tenn.), the sponsor of the Senate drought relief bill, and
cosponsor Sen. Albert Gore Jr. (D-Tenn.) called it "too little, too late."

In a prepared statement, Rep. E (Kika) de la Garza (D-Tex.) said he wished the
administration had "gone further."

De la Garza noted the proposal did not include House provisions for feed grain
donations, hay transportation assistance, disaster payments for soybean and
peanut growers, a delay in assessment payments for dairy farmers and
cost-sharing conservation incentives to prevent erosion.

" . . .  I think it will be necessary to continue work on our legislation," he
said.

The Agriculture Department announced several emergency aid programs July 24,
including discounts on loans to purchase feed grains and permission to allow
grazing and crop-planting on land set aside for conservation.

The additional measures introduced yesterday will enable livestock owners to
split with the government the cost of feed purchased for more than 5 cents per
pound.

Grain will be shipped from the Midwest to the affected regions, where farmers
with cattle, sheep, horses, mules, swine, goats and poultry will be able to use
certificates from the federal Commodity Credit Corp. to save 50 percent on grain
costs.

State agriculture officials had a mixed response to the plan. "We are thrilled
with it," said Cecil Davis, Alabama's assistant commissioner of agriculture. "I
personally think they're doing all they can," he added. Davis said Alabama could
lose $90 million to $360 million in cotton and peanut crops.

In Georgia, however, Agriculture Commissioner Tommy Irvin said the plan "still
falls far short of what Georgia farmers need." The state agriculture office
projects losses of more than $500 million.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, Agriculture Secretary Lyng: Advancing drought relief because
"farmers need payments now." BY ELLSWORTH J. DAVIS -- THE WASHINGTON POST

                       Copyright 1986 The Washington Post


                              45 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                December 29, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

FLORIDA GOVERNOR SEEKS DISASTER AID

BYLINE: By ALAN JUDD; New York Times Regional Newspapers

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 411 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 28


Gov. Bob Martinez sought Federal disaster aid today for Florida farmers whose
crops were damaged in the statewide freeze last weekend.

Mr. Martinez asked the Federal Agriculture Secretary, Clayton Yeutter, to
approve low-interest disaster-relief loans to Florida farmers, many of whom saw
crops wiped out as temperatures plunged.

Calling the freeze ''devastating'' to the state's agriculture interests, Mr.
Martinez said in a letter to Mr. Yeutter, ''Preliminary damage reports show that
the freezing temperatures caused extensive damage to the citrus, sugar cane and
vegetable producing regions, as well as heavy losses to ornamental crops,
nurseries and tropical fish breeders.''

Mr. Martinez, who did not give an estimate of total losses, also declared all 67
Florida counties to be disaster areas as a result of the freeze.

U.S. Survey of Losses

Federal agriculture officials will survey losses in each county before
determining whether Florida farmers qualify for disaster loans from the Farmers
Home Administration.

Mr. Martinez has not yet decided whether to ask President Bush to declare the
state a disaster area, said Jon Peck, the Governor's press secretary.

If the President takes that action, it would make low-interest loans available
to other Floridians who suffered losses, not just farmers, and would provide
emergency unemployment benefits to farm workers who were put out of work by the
freeze.

State officials need detailed, county-by-county damage reports before Mr.
Martinez could seek disaster aid from the President, Mr. Peck said, and the
Agriculture Department's survey will provide that information.

The two-day freeze severely damaged citrus and vegetable crops deep into South
Florida. Some citrus growers have estimated that they lost at least 40 percent
of their crops, and many vegetable crops were wiped out.

It will take agriculture officials three to four weeks to gather the information
Mr. Yeutter will use in deciding whether to grant disaster aid, said Wilbert
Campbell, director of the Farmers Home Administration's emergency designation
staff in Washington.

Disaster loans carry a 4.5 percent interest rate, and farmers may take as long
as 20 years to repay. Farmers could receive loans no greater than their actual
losses, as high as $500,000.

Today Mr. Martinez also extended an emergency order allowing trucks hauling
fruit and vegetables to processing plants to exceed weight limits on state
highways.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Gov. Bob Martinez (AP)

                 The Daily Record of Rochester (Rochester, NY)

                           September 6, 2007 Thursday

Rochester Business Briefs: September 6, 2007

BYLINE: Danielle Derringer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 529  words


Mayor On Hand For Farm Aid Caravan Tour

Rochester Mayor Robert J. Duffy joined FoodLink Executive Director Tom Ferraro
and Hank Herrera from the NorthEast Sustainable Agriculture Working Group this
week to welcome the Farm Aid Caravan Tour at the Rochester Public Market,
according to a release from the city.

The Farm Aid Caravan Tour is crossing the state to showcase the latest
innovations on family farms. The caravan will culminate with a benefit concert,
"Farm Aide 2007: A Homegrown Festival," at Randall's Island in New York City on
Sept. 9.

Farm Aid's mission is to build a family-farm centered system of agriculture in
America. Farm Aid works with family farmers and encourages people to choose
family-farmed food.

Since 1985, Farm Aid has raised more than $30 million to support programs that
help farmers.

Local Woman To Be Honored At Gala

The Greater Rochester Area Chapter of the Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Foundation has
announced that Joanne Schum, CF adult and author will be the honored guest at
the 6th annual Roses of Hope Gala, according to a recent release.

"The honoree is chosen based on perseverance, being a pioneer and leaving a
lasting legacy. Joanne exemplifies all of these characteristics and we are
pleased to be honoring her," said Mary Jane Taylor, chapter founder.

The gala will be held October 20 and will include a live and silent auction.
Reservations can be made by calling, (585) 697-0777.

Trillium Group Announces Liquidity Event

Trillium Group announced last week that Spectracom Corp., a Rochester-based time
and frequency company, has merged with the French firm Orolia, marking a key
liquidity event of Trillium Group's Monroe Fund.

Terms of the deal were undisclosed, according to a recent release.

"The announcement marks another milestone for the Monroe Fund and its
investors," said Kevin Phelps, Trillium General partner and Spectracom chairman.
"It also demonstrates the value of resident private equity in Monroe County,
driving the growth of companies that become attractive acquisition candidates. "

With a 95 percent market share, Spectracom is the U.S. leader for
synchronization systems for 911 emergency call centers. Orolia is a provider of
precision systems for the defense of aerospace, space and navigation and
broadcasting industries.

Best Milk In New York State Named

Stewart's Shops, of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. recently was named 2007's "Best Milk"
by Cornell University's New York State Milk Quality Improvement Program.

Stewart's scored a perfect 100 over a year of testing - the third perfect score
in the program's history, a release from Cornell states.

Awards were announced last week at the Great New York State Fair in Syracuse,
N.Y. The remaining top 10 dairies in the state were: Upstate Farms, Buffalo;
Cornell University Dairy, Ithica; Crowley Foods, Inc., Binghamton; Byrne Dairy,
Syracuse; Hillcrest Dairy, Moravia, Midland Farms Dairy, Menands; Mountainside
Dairy, Roxbury and Upstate Farms Cooperative of Rochester.

Judging criteria included butterfat content and post-pasteurization bacteria
counts within the milk's sell-by date. The most critical attributes tested were
product flavor and stability during shelf life.

                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             August 7, 2006 Monday
                                  ALL EDITION

GREEN CAN AID FARMERS

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 397 words


Supporters of Mark Green argue for handing him the governorship on the grounds
that the Republican congressman from Green Bay would be better positioned than
Democratic incumbent Jim Doyle to get his calls returned by the Bush White House
and, by extension, to get a better share of federal attention and resources for
Wisconsin.

Fair enough. Here's a test for Green: Twenty northern Wisconsin counties are
experiencing severe drought conditions, while others are suffering moderate
drought. Crops are dying in the fields and livestock producers are feeding
animals from reserves that had been put aside for the winter.

U.S. Rep. David Obey, D-Wausau, has asked U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike
Johanns to work with Gov. Jim Doyle and the state Department of Agriculture to
aid Wisconsin's drought-stricken farmers.

"I am encouraging Secretary Johanns to act as quickly as possible on the
governor's request for a federal disaster declaration," Obey said. "Wisconsin's
farmers are suffering and it's important that we act fast to get them what help
we can before it's too late."

With forecasters anticipating a steady worsening of conditions for farmers, the
urgency of Obey's call can't be underestimated.

The federal government has the networks and the resources to get aid to farmers
when and where they need it.

Quick intervention by the feds will make all the difference.

Obey wants the USDA to develop an improved version of the Livestock Compensation
Program, which operated in 2002 and 2003 and compensated farmers for the cost of
replacing failed feed crops.

So where does Mark Green fit in?

Here's what the congressman can and should do: Join Obey and Doyle in calling
for the Bush administration and its Department of Agriculture to take the
drought seriously. And if the president does not act immediately, Green can make
it clear that he puts Wisconsin first by telling the White House that he will
not accept campaign aid from Bush as long as his administration neglects the
state's farmers.

With the president expected to make several visits to Wisconsin in coming weeks
-- with the first being a visit to the candidate's hometown of Green Bay on
Thursday -- such a pronouncement would be sure to get the attention of the White
House. If that attention leads to action, Green will have delivered more for
Wisconsin farmers with one gutsy act than with his eight years in Congress.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
