                     The News-Examiner (Montpelier, Idaho)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                October 14, 2009

Farm Aid swings and misses

BYLINE: FRANK PRIESTLEY, President, Idaho Farm Bureau(r)

LENGTH: 765  words


A group of musicians including Dave Matthews, Neil Young, Willie Nelson and John
Mellencamp got together in St. Louis, Missouri recently and held a benefit
concert to raise money for small farmers.

This 24th anniversary of the Farm Aid concert/fundraiser broadcast to millions
on Direct TV sounds like a noble cause, but on closer inspection if s more of a
charade than anything. Good music indeed and Farm Aid deserves credit for
shining a light on some of American agriculture's problems. However, we disagree
with the amount of misinformation they are spreading to consumers and we think
if s poor judgment for farmers to attack other farmers when times get tough.

We commend Farm Aid for showing the plight of small farmers everywhere. And they
do a fine job of showing examples of small farmers using creative niche
marketing strategies.

But Farm Aid's public relations machine doesn't have a good grasp on the real
problems agriculture faces. For instance, they vilify corporate farms without
taking the time to understand that 98 percent of American farms are owned by
families. If s true that many of those farms are incorporated for tax purposes,
but are nonetheless still family owned.

In addition, Farm Aid attacks large farms and modern production methods much the
same as PETA and other animal rights groups. They argue America's remaining
small farms soon will be swallowed up and before consumers know it they won't
have a choice except to buy processed foods from giant agribusiness
corporations. These assertions are not even remotely accurate.

First, we all need a clear understanding of the fact that there are 300 million
Americans who need food every day. That food is currently produced by less than
2 percent of our population. If we were to take away large farms and modern
production methods, most of us would have to go back to living and working on
farms, much like our society was in the 1930's. Even if we had the land, water
and other resources available, how many Americans would quit their jobs, give up
their pensions and health insurance coverage, move to the country and assume the
risk and hardship that comes with running a farm?

Consumers today have more choices and more opportunities to buy fresh, local
food than they have in more than 20 years. The popularity of farmers markets and
community supported agriculture (CSA) ventures are off the charts. Plenty of
farmers across this nation are offeringthis nation are offering farm fresh eggs,
vegetables, meat and dairy products and consumers who want to know their farmer
are reaching out. The opportunity to buy farm fresh meat and produce has never
been greater.

Farm Aid also has its own unique interpretation of why the dairy industry is in
financial duress. It's not overproduction, they say, but big dairies, supported
by the government and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange are the real villains that
have driven milk prices to well below the cost of production. If Farm Aid were
to ask an agriculture economist or a dairy market analyst, they would soon
understand that the dairy industry is suffering from overproduction and lagging
demand, but at the same time dairy producers are taking steps to correct the
problem. Small dairies that sell milk to large corporate processing companies
are in direct competition with big dairies that can produce milk for less
because of economies of scale.

However much Farm Aid would like big dairies and other confined animal feeding
operations (CAFOs) to disappear, the reality is there are 300 million Americans
to feed. That simple fact dictates the need for large-scale, modern agriculture
methods. But there are lots of examples of small dairies and other small farms
producing value-added products and marketing them locally. Reed's Dairy in Idaho
Falls and Ballard Dairy in Gooding are excellent examples of dairy niche
marketing. They milk small herds by today's standards, rely on the quality and
freshness of their milk, and produce a wide variety of cheeses, ice cream, and
other dairy products. Many small dairies also provide delivery service as an
added convenience to their customers.

Farm Aid also misses the mark on agriculture trade, genetic modification of
crops, country of origin labeling and many other points we don't have space to
address here.

Farm Aid has the potential to do some good for American agriculture by helping
to educate the public about how food is produced, where it comes from and the
hardworking families who make their living on the land. But in our opinion, they
won't get there by placing blame at someone else's doorstep.

LOAD-DATE: January 17, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                           September 9, 2003 Tuesday

Farm aid down in Illinois last year  ;
 Higher crop prices cut payments more than two-thirds

BYLINE: DORI MEINERT COPLEY NEWS SERVICE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 720 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Illinois farmers received dramatically less in federal agricultural subsidies in
2002 than the previous year, largely because higher crop prices made less
federal aid necessary, according to data released Monday.

Federal farm aid coming into the state dropped to $615 million last year from
$1.9 billion in 2001, causing Illinois to fall to sixth in the national ranking
behind Texas, Iowa, Georgia, Arkansas and California, according to a database
created by the Environmental Working Group. The dip in funding to Illinois was
expected with higher crop prices last year, state farm group officials said.

"That's how the farm bill is designed to work - to provide income support when
income is down and to not provide that kind of support when the market is
providing it," said Rodney Weinzierl, executive director of the Illinois Corn
Growers Association.

Within Illinois, the counties that drew the most federal dollars last year
included: Iroquois, $16.7 million; LaSalle, $16.3 million; McLean, $15.5
million; Henry, $15.3 million; and Champaign, $14.9 million.

The top 2002 recipients in the state included: Pat Scates & Sons of Shawneetown,
which received $394,558; Rubenacker Farms of Dahlgren, $233,456; and the
University of Illinois at Urbana, $223,319. The university owns land that it
rents to farmers.

The figures come from the latest update by the same Washington-based
organization that caused an uproar among farmers in 2001 by releasing top
recipients in each state while Congress was debating the current farm law. The
Environmental Working Group obtained that data from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture after filing a Freedom of Information request.

Despite the one-year drop in federal aid to many Midwestern states, the latest
figures show a majority of federal funding is going to a few big farms at the
expense of smaller family farms, said the group's president, Ken Cook.

Nationally, from 1995 to 2002, the top 10 percent of the recipients collected 71
percent of the federal agriculture aid. The top 10 percent in Illinois received
62 percent over the same period. In 2002, the top 10 percent nationally
collected 65 percent of total subsidies compared to 62 percent in Illinois.

Cook's group has pushed to lower the caps on federal farm payments and to steer
more money into conservation programs, which it contends are a fairer way of
distributing the money with greater environmental impact.

"The conservation program broadens the participation. Taxpayers feel like
they're getting a good deal ... but we need to put money into it," Cook said.

The farm legislation signed into law by President Bush last year called for an
increase in conservation spending.

With money tight, Cook said he fears "there will be a temptation to cut
conservation funds in favor of commodity payments, and we'll fight that."

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, is planning another attempt to reduce the
per-farm cap on farm aid payments.

Farm groups, including those in Illinois, oppose such caps.

Government-funding trends follow trends in production and acreage, Weinzierl
said.

"As farms get larger, it doesn't mean the programs cause the farms to get
larger. You're going to get a higher concentration of payments among a smaller
group of farmers," he said.

Illinois Farm Bureau spokesman Dennis Vercler said the 2002 figures for Illinois
were predicted by farm groups.

"When Congress passed the new farm bill, the headlines said the farm program
costs would soar as much as 70 percent under this new law. Well, that didn't
happen, and we didn't think it would happen because there had been a strong
demand for commodities and we didn't think the prices would remain so low for
the 2002 crop year," Vercler said.

"Overall, farmers prefer to get their income from cash sales rather than
government payments."

In Illinois, the most significant drop came in commodity subsidies, which fell
from $1.7 billion in 2001 to $477.8 million in 2001. Disaster funds to the state
also decreased from $12 million in 2001 to $10 million in 2002.

But the state pulled in a slightly higher amount in agriculture conservation
funding, increasing from $110.4 million in 2001 to $127.2 million in 2002,
according to the group's database.

The farm subsidy data is available on the Environmental Working Group's Web
site, www.ewg.org.

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2007

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                   USA TODAY

                   November 12, 2002, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Ebbers linked to over $4M in farm subsidies

BYLINE: Andrew Backover

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 667 words

Former WorldCom CEO Bernie Ebbers, under increasing fire for the $ 408 million
in personal loans he got from the company, also harvested millions in farm
subsidies from U.S. taxpayers.

Three farms owned in part by Ebbers or linked to him got more than $ 4 million
in U.S. Department of Agriculture aid from at least 1998 through 2001, say USDA
records obtained by the Environmental Working Group (EWG).

Recipients, on average, got about $ 36,000 from 1996 through 2001, the
non-profit says.

The subsidies aren't illegal. They are guaranteed for certain crops, or are
spurred by price crashes or disasters -- no matter the wealth of the farm
owners. Media mogul Ted Turner, basketball star Scottie Pippen, Charles Schwab
and former Enron chief Kenneth Lay have received them.


"It's not illegal. It's outrageous," says EWG President Ken Cook.

Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., has pushed for limitations on payments to wealthy
individuals and large farms, but most of his efforts fell short this year.

Ebbers could not be reached. His attorney didn't respond to a request for
comment.

Although Ebbers was No. 174 on Forbes' list of the 400 richest Americans in
1999, his fortune has cratered. His WorldCom shares, valued at about $ 286
million in December, are nearly worthless now that WorldCom has filed for
Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

What's more, WorldCom is in the process of seizing some of his assets, many of
which were pledged as collateral for the loans. His farms include:

 * Angelina Plantation. The 21,000-acre property in Monterey, La., got about $
3.9 million in aid since 1998. Ebbers and his brother, John Ebbers, have owned
it since early 1998, according to Farm Service Agency records. It produces
wheat, rice, oats, corn, sorghum, cotton and soybeans.

In 2001, Angelina Plantation got almost $ 1.4 million in aid. That ranked No. 24
out of nearly 1.9 million recipients. USDA records show the farm has nearly 20
"other producers" on it, but it is unclear how much of a cut they get from
subsidies. Calls to Angelina Plantation were not returned.

 * Pine Ridge Farm. This Mississippi farm got nearly $ 220,000 in aid since
1996. Ebbers is shown as an official of the farm in a 1997 state filing. The
USDA aid was sent to the Brookhaven, Miss., address of Ebbers' brother, John,
who has a farming background.

Pine Ridge received funds for wheat, sorghum, cotton, corn and livestock. Calls
to Pine Ridge Farm were not returned.

 * Joshua Timber. It got $ 38,670 from 1996 through 2001, mostly in conservation
funds. It's unclear if Ebbers was the owner for all of those years.

Joshua Timber filed its articles of incorporation with the Mississippi Secretary
of State in 1996. Its Mississippi post office box -- on file with the USDA --
has been used in state filings by Bernie Ebbers and Joshua Holdings, which is
helping to secure his WorldCom loans.

Joshua Holdings is the parent of Joshua Timberlands, which paid $ 400 million in
1999 for 460,000 acres in Alabama, Tennessee and Mississippi. Joshua Timberlands
is cited in a shareholder lawsuit against Ebbers and others. Joshua Timber could
not be reached.

In July, WorldCom filed the biggest-ever bankruptcy case after disclosing
accounting misdeeds that have grown to $ 9 billion.

Ebbers faces scrutiny because he was CEO when the alleged fraud occurred and
because of questions about his loans.

A recent bankruptcy court report questioned whether all of the loans were
properly approved by the WorldCom board. Also, there are questions about how all
of the money was used.

The compensation committee that approved Ebbers' loans, at the time, said they
were in the best interests of shareholders. The premise for that was the concern
that, if Ebbers sold shares to cover other debts, the price of WorldCom's stock
would fall.

But more than $ 27 million was used by Ebbers for other personal reasons, the
report alleges.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

             February 15, 1997, Saturday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Farmers eligible for freeze aid

SECTION: CITY & STATE; AROUND THE STATE; Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 349 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE; BARTOW; ORLANDO



Florida farmers hurt by the mid-January freeze are now eligible for emergency
low-interest loans, thanks to a federal declaration of a disaster area in 16
counties.

The Jan. 18 and 19 freeze damaged an estimated $ 300-million in crops,  mainly
winter vegetables. The declaration by federal Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman lets farmers in 16 disaster counties and 12 "contiguous disaster
counties" apply for the emergency loans.

The counties declared disaster areas are Broward, Charlotte, Collier, Dade,  De
Soto, Glades, Hardy, Hendry, Highlands, Hillsborough, Lee, Manatee,  Okeechobee,
Orange, Palm Beach and Sarasota. The contiguous counties are  Brevard, Indian
River, Lake, Martin, Monroe, Osceola, Pasco, Pinellas, Polk,  St. Lucie,
Seminole and Volusia.  Jury recommends life

for ex-Zephyrhills man

    BARTOW - A jury recommended Friday that a former Zephyrhills man be
sentenced to life in prison for the 1993 murder of a Polk County man.

Jurors decided against recommending that Albert Leon Fletcher die in the
electric chair. His attorneys insisted that he did not fire the shot that
killed a Highland City man during a robbery attempt.

Subsequently, Fletcher escaped in 1995 while being transported to Pasco  County
to stand trial on armed burglary and grand theft charges. He spent more  than a
year on the lam.

Circuit Judge Dennis Maloney must consider the jury's recommendation when  he
sentences Fletcher, 26. Maloney said he will announce his decision  Wednesday.

Son is found guilty

of trying to bomb dad

   ORLANDO - A man was found guilty of trying to kill his millionaire father
with a pipe bomb he mailed from New York to Florida, authorities said Friday.

A jury returned the verdict against Douglas Dwight Lambert, 32, of  Calverton,
N.Y., after an eight day trial. Prosecutors said Lambert mailed the  bomb in
May, but the package was intercepted before it exploded.

- Information from the Associated Press, Times files and the Lakeland Ledger
was used in this report.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     June 5, 1993, Saturday, WEEKLY EDITION

Russia, U.S. seal US$700M aid deal

BYLINE: Reuter

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 226 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


U.S. and Russian officials Friday clinched a US$700- million package of
concessional agricultural credits and donations for Moscow, a deal Russian
officials several times threatened to reject.

The package, announced by President Bill Clinton at his April summit with
Russian President Boris Yeltsin, was nearly derailed several times by
disagreements over terms of shipping the food and by U.S. maritime industry
complaints that vessels were being held up and charged unexpected fees at
Russian ports.

''Russia has agreed to take steps to facilitate the rapid unloading of
commodities in Russian ports,'' Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said in a
ceremony with Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Zaveryukha to sign some
documents to the agreement.

Remaining parts of the agreement, a complex hybrid of the Agriculture
Department's commercial and aid programs, are to be signed next week by Russian
Prime Minister Viktor Chemomyrdin. Russia will get corn, soybean meal, wheat and
other products.

Russian officials earlier complained about the U.S. law that 75% of the
commodities shipped under such an aid package must go on U.S. flag carriers,
which generally have much higher rates than foreign carriers.

Russia and the U.S. finally agreed that the U.S. would pay the difference
between the U.S. and world freight rates.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: COLUMN

                              53 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                           September 23, 2012 Sunday
                                 CITY-D Edition

Celebrating the family farm;
30,000 showed up in Hershey for the annual concert to help struggling farmers.

BYLINE: By Amy Worden; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: PHILADELPHIA; P-com News Local; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 969 words


HERSHEY, Pa. - If you thought Farm Aid went the way of the Sony Walkman or the
Grateful Dead, you weren't in Chocolate Town USA on Saturday, when 30,000 people
turned HersheyPark Stadium into an organic oasis celebrating the family farm and
the healthy food movement - not to mention homegrown American music.

Now in its 27th year, the all-star benefit concert, started by country-music
legend Willie Nelson to help farmers survive the mid-1980s foreclosure crisis,
is still going strong.

No longer a one-day event, Farm Aid has evolved into a national organization
promoting the interests of family farmers.

The event returned to Pennsylvania, where agriculture remains the number-one
industry, for only the second time in its run.

In 2002, Farm Aid was held in Burgettstown, west of Pittsburgh. This time the
location was just a few miles from Lancaster County, which is about to make
national history when it hits the milestone of 100,000 acres of preserved
farmland. Lancaster boasts soil so rich it's known as the breadbasket of the
East.

The first-ever Farm Aid concert drew 54 bands and 78,000 to Champaign, Ill.;
Farm Aid is smaller now, with just under a dozen artists drawing 30,000.

Still, Farm Aid has brought in $40 million to benefit farmers and build
relationships between consumers and those who produce their food.

"It's a good event that hopefully will open people's eyes to the fact farmers
keep the country moving and they need help," said Teri Michelson of Linglestown.
She paused to talk during a tour of Homegrown Village, an area featuring booths
showcasing sustainable agriculture methods and environmental advocacy groups.

The healthy food movement has indeed grown (Pennsylvania has 600 certified
organic farms, the sixth highest in the nation), spawning a record number of
farm markets and encouraging industrywide shifts to organic farming methods. But
the problems facing small farmers - such as fluctuating milk prices, tighter
regulations, and access to distribution networks - are no less acute, organizers
say.

Every year a gamble "There is still danger for farmers," said Farm Aid
spokeswoman Jennifer Fahy, pointing to the drought that ravaged crops in
two-thirds of the United States this year. "They are gamblers every time they
put seed in ground."

The musicians - the lineup included the 79-year-old Nelson, Dave Matthews, Kenny
Chesney, Neil Young, John Mellencamp, and Jack Johnson - used the spotlight to
target agribusiness interests. They said corporate farming wields too much power
in Congress, where members last week failed to pass a comprehensive Farm Bill
before leaving town.

Before the festival opened, Nelson told hundreds of fans and reporters he was
"sorry to have to be here."

"This problem should have been solved years ago," he said.

Despite the problems, according to a 2007 survey, the number of farmers grew for
the first time in decades, attracting a more diverse cross section, many working
farms of just a few acres, Fahy said.

Farm Heads The atmosphere in the patchouli-scented Homegrown Village had an odd
time-warp quality: young people wearing T-shirts paying homage to past rock
stars like Janis Joplin, who died before they were born, mixing with the
in-your-face activism of the anti-gas drilling "fracktivists" - a term that
wasn't even in the lexicon when Farm Aid started.

Fahy said some people she called "Farm Heads" come every year, from all 50
states.

There was a booth dedicated to the "anti-sludge" cause - those who oppose
spreading municipal waste on farmland - and other booths where folks could learn
about genetically modified organisms (GMOs), rotational grazing, and biogas
energy.

Even the concession cups and plates were compostable. Those who put their eating
utensils in the wrong bin were swiftly corrected.

Bryan Snyder, executive director of the Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable
Agriculture, said the state has a strong farming tradition among the booming
Amish and Mennonite populations, which has helped give the next generation of
farmers an opportunity to work the land.

"We're ahead because we are behind," he said. "We still have the infrastructure.
You can drive 20 minutes from here and see what America used to look like."

Exhibitor Deb Brubaker, 30, of Mifflintown, is still working her family farm
northwest of Harrisburg, as her Mennonite ancestors did.

She and her family run Village Acres Farm, which supplies organic fruit and
vegetables to farm markets in Washington and to residents of the State College
area, who buy their farm products through a subscription.

Brubaker, who was demonstrating a bicycle-powered grain mill her father put
together for the festival, said she was pleased that such an event shines a
spotlight on a challenging way of life.

"It's great to see the general public and the entertainment community interested
in the plight of farmers," she said. "We'd like to see more of a market for
certified organic food in rural areas. We provide our food to people in D.C. and
Baltimore but much less so where we live."

Many exhibitors were concerned about the fate of the nearly $1 trillion federal
farm bill, set to expire next Sunday.

The lack of action on the bill won't affect the largest programs such as crop
subsidies and food stamps, they said, but could harm programs that most benefit
small farmers, such as conservation and initiatives to help beginning farmers
get started.

Neil Young, wearing a "Go Family Farms" T-shirt, pledged to continue to be a
voice for small farmers.

"We're up against something really big," Young said. "Some say we're not going
anywhere, and we're not going anywhere. We're going to stay right here; someone
has to stand up for small farmers."

Contact Amy Worden

at 717-783-2584 or aworden@phillynews.com or follow @inkyamy on Twitter.


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              54 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                            December 2, 2001 Sunday

FARM ILLINOIS

SECTION: MARKETPLACE; Pg. 53

LENGTH: 475 words


* From the field

Sharon Covert of Tiskilwa, member of the Illinois Soybean Checkoff Board, who
recently traveled to Botswana to set up a new initiative to deliver soy protein
to those with HIV/AIDS: "The soy checkoff board believes investing in this will
help develop new markets. We traveled to Africa to create partnership with soy
industry groups and the Botswana government to promote the development of a soy
foods manufacturing industry. While there, we did visit the new national food
and technology research center that has just been built. We hope to work with
the center for soy foods manufacturing.

"We want to create new local foods that are fortified with soy protein. Illinois
farmers want soy to be recognized as an excellent source of protein. We're also
working with Botswana officials to conduct feeding trials with those affected
with HIV/AIDS, and we're adopting an orphanage for feeding soy protein.

"While we know the food industry uses 70 percent of the soybeans grown, this new
use for the undernourished of the world would not be competing with that. The
population we're serving has little or no access to protein. The U.S. Department
of Agriculture says that 40 percent of current ag exports go to countries that
formerly received food aid assistance. Our program is designed to improve the
diet and nutrition in Botswana and at the same time make a commercial venture
out of adding more protein to their diets."

* Farming the Web

The state Agriculture Department's Web site (www.agr.

state.il.us/) has undergone a major overhaul and the result is a site with lots
of useful information. It offers an update on Ty-Walk facilities, information on
the next Illinois Products Expo, a program to cap unused wells and a new
quarantine for Asian longhorned beetles. Ag events are listed as well as soil
temperature maps.

* Coming up

* Illinois Farm Bureau members may get a close look at what form the next
federal farm bill will take when they attend their 87th annual meeting in St.
Louis today through Wednesday. U.S. Rep. Larry Combest, a Texas Republican and
chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, will speak at the annual meeting
along with Jack Block, former U.S. agriculture secretary; Adam's Mark Hotel, St.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                 February 8, 2005 Tuesday Penn/Elkhart Edition

More eligible for food stamps;
 Local storm, flooding victims now may qualify

BYLINE: Tribune Staff Report

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 191 words


Residents of local Indiana counties may qualify for food stamps if they suffered
losses because of the recent floods or winter storms.

Their home may have been damaged or lost. Or they may have lost food, money or
income. Or they may simply need food.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture is allowing the disaster aid to 24 extra
counties.

These include Elkhart, Marshall and St. Joseph counties.

Others are Adams, Allen, Dearborn, DeKalb, Fayette, Franklin, Fulton, Jasper,
Kosciusko, Lake, LaPorte, Newton, Noble, Porter, Pulaski, Ripley, Rush, Starke,
Union, Wayne and Whitley counties.

Residents who already receive food stamps have until Thursday to ask for
replacement food stamps and until Feb. 15 to seek the disaster aid.

Those who don't currently receive food stamps may apply for the disaster aid
until Feb. 15.

To apply, go to the county Office of Family and Children, which is part of the
state Family and Social Services Administration. Applicants should bring a
driver's license or other picture identification, Social Security numbers for
everyone in the household and a document that verifies the home address.


LOAD-DATE: February 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Finding disaster aid To find your county's Office of Family and
Children -- where victims of the recent storms and flooding may apply for food
stamps -- call (800) 622-4932 or go to the Web site www.IN.gov/fssa.  Those with
homes damaged by the recent storms and flooding also may qualify for aid from
the Federal Emergency Management Agency. For more information, call (800)
621-FEMA or go to the Web site www.fema.gov.

                              56 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           October 10, 1989, Tuesday

US LOADS FIRST SHIP WITH FOOD FOR POLAND

BYLINE: Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 297 words

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS


A U.S.-flag ship was to arrive in New Orleans at the weekend to be loaded with
the first shipment of U.S. food aid to Poland.

Maritime union officials, local shipping executives and elected officials
planned to attend a ceremony Saturday in the Riverwalk area of the city.
However, a battle could develop in Congress this week about how large a
roportion of future aid shipments must travel on U.S.-flag vessels.

The Spirit of Texas, operated by New York-based Falcon Shipping, will transport
11,500 metric tons of sorghum to Gdansk as part of the U.S. aid program to
Poland announced by President Bush earlier this year.

Falcon Shipping and two seagoing labor unions were to host the celebration. The
unions, which will supply licensed and unlicensed crewmembers for the voyage,
are District 2 - Marine Engineers Beneficial Association and the Seafarers
International Union.

Last week, Polish officials asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to seek a
waiver of the current requirement that U.S.-flag vessels carry 75 percent of
food aid shipments. However, a USDA official later told a House Foreign Affairs
subcommittee that the cargo preference waiver would not be sought. Christopher
Goldthwait, Foreign Agriculture Service assistant sales manager, told the panel:
"The administration is not seeking any change in maritime law."

In the next week or so, legislation will move through Congress to provide broad
economic aid and additional food shipments to Poland. Members are expected to
introduce amendments that would waive cargo preference so that more of the U.S.
funds could go for food instead of transportation costs.

Rep. Doug Bereuter, R-Neb., said about 40 percent of food aid to Poland is being
"eaten up" by higher U.S.-flag shipping costs.

                              57 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Moscow Times

                                 July 24, 1999

Premier to Push Food Aid on U.S. Visit

SECTION: No. 1757

LENGTH: 480 words


By Yevgenia Borisova Staff Writer Prime Minister Sergei Stepashin is headed for
Washington with plans to discuss new U.S. food aid and loans for tractors, while
his counterpart Vice President Al Gore wants to talk about further reductions in
nuclear weapons.

Stepashin is making his way to a Monday meeting with Gore and then with
President Bill Clinton via the Urals, Vladivostok, Seattle and then Washington -
in what Russian media are billing as his world tour.

It will be his first meeting with top U.S. officials, and the highest level
U.S.-Russian meeting since the NATO war in Yugoslavia soured relations between
Moscow and Washington.

Gore's foreign policy assistant, Leon Fuerth, was quoted by The Associated Press
as saying the one-day visit was unlikely to produce major agreements.

"We have to get warmed up with a brand-new government," he said.

Stepashin will meet Clinton on Tuesday after sessions with Gore on trade,
science, space and other topics that are the business of their joint commission.

The Americans will be putting new arms reductions on the agenda. But Interfax,
quoting a source in the Agriculture Ministry, said food aid shipments into 2000
would be on the Russian list.

The Americans confirmed that food aid is being considered. Carlos Pascual, who
heads the Russia desk at the National Security Council, said a U.S. delegation
would go to Russia later in the summer to evaluate the harvest and any needs for
food aid, AP reported Friday.

Reuters, however, quoted a U.S. Agriculture Department official as saying no
meetings have been scheduled to discuss additional food aid.

Interfax also reported that Stepashin would seek U.S. Export-Import Bank
guarantees for a $ 1 billion loan to buy Case and John Deere agriculture
machinery, and another $ 1 billion to finance the sales of engines and aviation
equipment by United Technologies Corp., Pratt & Whitney and other U.S.

suppliers to aircraft maker Ilyushin.

John Deere is poised to create its own assembly line on the basis of the
insolvent Rostselmash in Rostov to manufacture from 3,000 to 5,000 combines a
year. A decision on both the loan and the plant were expected in the spring but
have not yet officially come.

"The Russian agricultural sector needs more than 100,000 tractors and more than
100,000 combines, so whatever our critics are saying about getting foreign
equipment instead of Russian, there is enough room for all manufacturers," said
Andrei Cherepanov, an SBS-Agro spokesman.

was quoted by AP as saying Friday that Aigun Magomedov, deputy director of the
Agroprom center which leases farm equipment, said that Russia needs about
280,000 combines now.

The State Statistics Committee said that less than 100 combines are manufactured
each month in Russia. A decade ago, more than 82,000 combines were made every
year.

                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 17, 2011 Saturday

More aid available for crop losses

BYLINE: Nancy Glasscock, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 316 words


Dec. 17--Farmers in Morgan and Lawrence counties with crops damaged in April are
eligible for low-interest emergency loans, the U.S. Department of Agriculture
said.

Secretary of Agriculture Thomas Vilsack said Morgan, Lawrence, Blount, Madison,
Marion and Monroe counties were declared disaster areas because of crop losses
caused by excessive rain, flooding, flash flooding, hail, high winds and
tornadoes occurring throughout April.

USDA spokeswoman Vickie Lane said the declaration will "give producers in those
counties an opportunity to file for aid for their crops, if they had losses."

Statewide, 26 counties are eligible for agricultural assistance.

The six counties were declared natural disaster areas because they sustained 30
percent or greater crop loss, according to the declaration.

Farmers can contact USDA service centers for more information on eligibility
requirements and application procedures.

Sam Spruell, who grows grain, cotton and peanuts on about 5,000 acres in Mount
Hope and outside Lawrence County, said he didn't plan on applying for assistance
because of the red tape he encountered in seeking assistance in the past.

He had about $1 million in damages to buildings, machinery and wheat that was
nearly ready for harvest when the April tornadoes struck.

He said he's spent about $100 an acre on cleanup.

"There wasn't any coverage for that," he said. "We had a lot of cleanup to do,
and there wasn't any help from FEMA there. They came by and took the
information, and we tried to follow up but found out right quick that was a
wasted effort."

Spruell said he was pleased with his insurance company, Alfa, which covered 85
percent of his losses.

But creeks remain clogged with downed trees that pose a flooding threat, he
said.

Ala.) at www.decaturdaily.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                              59 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    October 13, 1996, Sunday, Final Edition

Willie Nelson Gets Farm Aid '96 Underway; Agriculture Secretary Says Exports
Will Set Record This Year

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A07

LENGTH: 297 words

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 12


Country and western singer and songwriter Willie Nelson today opened Farm Aid
'96, the ninth benefit concert designed to raise funds and public awareness of
the problems facing U.S. farmers and their families.

Since the first concert was held in 1985, Farm Aid has granted nearly $ 13
million in assistance to more than 100 farm organizations, churches and service
agencies in 44 states.

Before the concert, which attracted 45,000, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman
told a town meeting that while farmers still face problems, U.S. agricultural
exports will top the $ 60 billion mark this year. He said that is a record.

One of every three acres of production in the United States went to crops headed
for export, he said, adding that it was essential for small and medium-size
farmers to share in the growing export market.

In the last two years, farm assets increased faster than farm debt, and low
interest rates, low unemployment and low inflation rates were benefiting
farmers, Glickman said.

"While I don't like the structure problems of agriculture, when you've got more
and more larger producers, the fact is this year we will see net farming income
of $ 51.5 million," he said. "It's never been higher."

Farmers from across the nation at the town meeting expressed concern about the
growing concentration of large industrial-sized farms, which they said were
forcing small family farmers out of business.

Missouri farmer Rhonda Perry called on Glickman to block funding of a $ 25
million dollar swine research center in Iowa. "We don't want taxpayer-funded
research that subsidizes factory hog farms," she said.

Nelson, John Mellencamp, Neil Young, and Hootie and the Blowfish topped the bill
for the 12-hour concert at Williams-Brice Stadium.


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             July 23, 1994 Saturday

LENGTH: 174 words


Farm Aid comes to North Dakota Friday at the invitation of the North Dakota
State Fair in Minot. Farm Aid president and entertainer Willie Nelson will hold
a press conference before his grandstand performance with representatives from
farm and rural organizations around the state. The event is one of a series of
activities Farm Aid plans this summer to focus on the role family farmers play
in supporting the economy, food and environment. Commissioner of Agriculture
Sarah Vogel plans to attend along with representatives from the North Dakota
Farmers Union, Dakota Resource Council, North Dakota Conference of Churches and
Northern Plains Sustainable Agriculture Society. July 29 will be ""Farm Aid
Day'' at the fair. Farm Aid plans an exhibit in the All Seasons Arena that day
and will have information, giveaway items and sale merchandise available. Since
1985, Farm Aid has distributed $11.5 million to more than 100 farm
organizations, churches, hotlines and service agencies in 44 states. More than
$150,000 was distributed in North Dakota

                              61 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                       August 4, 2002 Sunday MO1 EDITION

Congress leaves farm aid package for September;
LAWMAKERS STALLED IN DECIDING AMOUNT

BYLINE: Alan Bjerga Knight Ridder

SECTION: A; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 349 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Senate Agriculture Committee didn't agree on a farm-aid bill after
discussions last week, leaving the business unfinished as the panel prepares to
take August off.

That means that a $2.9 billion aid package proposed by Sen. Pat Roberts, R-Kan.,
will remain one of several possible disaster-relief bills floating around
Washington this month while lawmakers work in their home areas. Though committee
members all agreed aid is necessary, they differ on what aid is best for farmers
and how much aid can make it through a Congress still skeptical about the size
of the $180 billion, 10-year farm bill passed in the spring.

"We should not vary from the practice of providing emergency assistance when
natural forces beyond the control of producers wreak havoc on farmers' and
ranchers' incomes," said Agriculture Committee chair Tom Harkin, D-Iowa.

Spreading drought is destroying crops across the central United States, and some
areas of the Great Plains are experiencing conditions not seen since the Dust
Bowl. Kansas' winter wheat crop is expected to lose $270 million this year.

In response, farm-state lawmakers are proposing disaster-aid packages that could
cost from $2 billion to $7 billion.

The aid would come in addition to the current farm bill, a bill widely derided
as pork-barrel spending on ineffective programs. But that bill is looking
slightly less expensive now. That's because drought pushes crop prices higher
and eases subsidy payments.

One bill introduced by Rep. Jerry Moran, R-Kan., and two other House members
exploits this by reimbursing farmers and ranchers for crop losses with money
taken from farm-bill savings.

But politically, swapping crop savings for disaster payments won't be so simple.
The farm bill's price tag raised eyebrows among lawmakers concerned about its
$80 billion jump in farm supports from the last farm bill.

Roberts' bill doesn't link aid to the current farm bill's cost. It does require
farmers to buy crop insurance, which allows farmers to hedge against disasters,
before they get any aid.

LOAD-DATE: August 4, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: news

                              62 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                      March 1, 1999, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Staggered delivery aims to check where food goes

BYLINE: Barbara Slavin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 355 words


When the aid agreement with Russia was reached before Christmas,
U.S. officials hoped that shipments would be on the high seas
in January. But the first installment -- 1,000 tons of pea seed
-- is arriving March 10 and the remainder of the promised 3.15
million tons of grain, meat and other commodities is to be dribbled
out in 60 to 70 shipments through June.

The main reason for the delay, and the staggered delivery, is
to try to check where the food actually goes. "We now have a
merchant-by-merchant, institution-by-institution breakdown for
almost all the commodities," says Chris Goldthwait, general sales
manager for the U.S. Department of Agriculture.


Most food is set for Moscow, St. Petersburg and other industrial
centers. Portions also are to go to the Far East and Siberia.
Critics say the best thing about the program is that it can be
canceled. "The most important change we were able to get into
the agreement was that if these commodities are not delivered
as planned, no further shipments will go," says Rep. Marcy Kaptur,
D-Ohio, ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Agriculture
Subcommittee.

She worries that the aid will hurt Russia's struggling private
sector because the wholesalers are former state-run conglomerates.

Some say the program is motivated largely by a desire to help
U.S. farmers hurt by sagging commodity prices. Thomas Graham,
a former U.S. diplomat in Moscow, says it also is meant to show
continued engagement in Russia at a time of increasing economic
and political instability -- and foreign reluctance to pump in
more cash aid. "Food aid is one of the few things you can do
that looks humanitarian without compromising your principles."

Goldthwait says the United States intends to spot check at least
20% of the tonnage by using four full-time monitors, plus agricultural
staff and junior consular officers. "If there is a significant
diversion of commodities and we don't see a way to control it,"
the program will be canceled, he says. Asked his definition of
"significant," he says: "We'll know it when we see it."



LOAD-DATE: March 01, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.


                              63 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                          February 12, 1992, Wednesday

SHIPLOAD OF FOOD AID TO LEAVE FOR ARMENIA

BYLINE: JANET PLUME; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 761 words

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS


The first waterborne shipment of $ 15 million in government-surplus food aid is
scheduled to departtoday for the hard-hit former Soviet republic of Armenia,
whose landlocked people have been extremely difficult to reach.

In an effort to expedite the shipments, the Department of Defense sent a
planeload of some 30 tons of butter to Armenia, which has been described as the
eediest of the new Commonwealth of Independent States.

The cargo is part of a $ 165 million in food aid announced Nov. 20 by President
Bush. Ared Bulbiljian, who is coordinating food shipments to Armenia for the
American Diocese of the Armenian Church, said efforts to get the food to hungry
townspeople in his homeland have been frustrated by logistical problems.

The Lyra, which arrived in New Orleans Monday, was expected to load 3,000
containerized tons of bulgur wheat on board before heading to Houston Monday
evening. In Houston, the vessel is scheduled to pick up 2,150 tons of powdered
milk and 1,150 tons of butter oil bound for Armenia.

The smallest of the former Soviet republics - with a population of 2.4 million -
Armenia suffered a devastating earthquake in 1988 and has since been engaged in
a conflict with Azerbaijan.

Last week the U.S. Department of Agriculture selected the non-profit
organization World Vision to administer another food relief program - this one
worth $ 7.5 million - to Armenia. The program includes $ 2.3 million to
transport, distribute and monitor $ 5.2 million worth of powdered milk, beans
and vegetable oil.

Armenian Church officials initially said their cargo had been held up nearly a
month by shortages of containers and available ships.

But Pete Kelly, vice president of freight forwarder Daniel F. Young Inc., agent
for the cargo, said Armenian officials didn't formally approve his firm's
appointment to handle the forwarding until Jan. 31.

Additionally, the Armenians changed their minds and wanted the cargo delivered
in containers rather than in breakbulk form.

Mr. Bulbiljian explained the containers were necessary to "ensure the integrity
of the cargo."

"It (the change) kind of put us back to square one," Mr. Kelly said.

Rather than delay the shipment by submitting another tender offer, Lykes Bros.
Steamship Co., which was awarded the bid for the breakbulk move, provided the
Lyra to carry the containers to Turkey earlier than the breakbulk shipment had
been scheduled, Mr. Kelly said.

Mr. Kelly denied a report published last week that alleged the cargo had been
sitting on docks in New Orleans and Houston for months because of shipping
delays. He said all the bulgur wheat didn't arrive in New Orleans until Jan. 27,
and the milk and butter oil didn't leave USDA warehouses for Houston until
Daniel F. Young's appointment became official at the end of January.

Once the 364 containers aboard the Lyra arrive at the Port of Mersin, Turkey, on
March 2, they will be loaded onto that country's single-track, 30- car railway
to Armenia.

The remainder of the cargo - 4,300 tons of frozen butter - is presenting
shippers with a logistical nightmare.

After tendering the initial order for the shipment of 68-pound boxes of butter,
the Armenians wanted to change the shipment to one-pound boxes to ease
distribution.

A second tender submitted last Friday was due Monday, but Mr. Kelly asked the
USDA for an extension until Tuesday to allow several shipping lines to work out
the logistics of trucking the frozen butter from warehouses spread between Texas
and Minnesota to a port for loading.

The problem of getting the frozen butter from Turkey to Armenia remains
unresolved.

While no vehicular traffic is allowed between Armenia and Turkey, it could
become available any day, Mr. Bulbiljian said.

But the condition of the roads, which haven't been used in 70 years, remains
questionable. One major bridge, for example, hasn't been crossed in so long that
its safety is dubious.

Mr. Bulbiljian said his organization has had no problem shipping construction
equipment across Turkey into Armenia by rail, but he acknowledges that the
frozen butter presents a new headache.

Even if trucks could make it across the border, it's uncertain whether they
could find diesel fuel. Since Azerbaijan cut off Armenia's oil pipeline, the
nation has been plagued by diesel shortages.

"But the USDA went so far as to offer to provide the diesel," Mr. Bulbiljian
said.

"The government has certainly done a Herculean job," Mr. Kelly said. ''they have
managed to overcome some major problems."

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1992 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              64 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                     December 13, 2000 Wednesday 2D EDITION

WESTERN EMPIRE

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-06

LENGTH: 720 words


EASTERN PLAINS

Owens seeks aid for counties

Colorado farmers are 'in dire need of relief and assistance'  because of bad
weather earlier this year, Gov. Bill Owens said  Tuesday, applying to add Las
Animas and Prowers counties to the  list of agricultural counties getting
federal disaster aid.

Owens wrote to Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, seeking to  make farmers and
ranchers in the southeastern Colorado counties  eligible for the U.S. Department
of Agriculture's emergency loans  and other aid programs.

He said freezing weather in late spring and a persistent  drought have affected
36 of the state's 63 counties. Federal  assistance has been granted to 29 of
them, and five more - Baca,  Bent, Mesa, Montrose and Ouray - were on the
waiting list before  the two recent additions.

FRONT RANGE

Trial ordered in fraud case

COLORADO SPRINGS - A man who once joined an all-girl high  school cheerleading
squad and poses as a female model has been  ordered to stand trial for theft,
fraud and other counts for  allegedly stealing money for plane tickets.

Storme Aerison, who legally changed his name from Charles  Daugherty, will be
arraigned Feb. 12. District Judge Edward Colt  ordered the arraignment after a
preliminary hearing Monday.

During the hearing, police Detective John Amundson said  Aerison stole about $
15,300 from Marjorie Hurd, whose teenage son  Joshua was promised a job working
with Aerison on a photo shoot in  Tahiti. He allegedly paid back Hurd with a
fake check.

At the time, Aerison was out of jail on $ 135,000 bond from an  earlier case in
which he is charged with felony theft. He also  will be arraigned in that case
on Feb. 12.

Aerison, 36, has also used the names Shannon Fox, Shannon  Ocastis Trump Ireland
and Shannon Ireland Trump. He has claimed to  be the sister of supermodel Kathy
Ireland and has posed in a  swimsuit on his own Web site.

Aerison is free on $ 165,000 bond in the latest case.

MOUNTAINS

Kids can trade food for fines

STEAMBOAT SPRINGS - Children with overdue library fines will  be able to settle
their debt with a donation of food under a  program modeled on similar programs
elsewhere.

Library-card holders under age 18 have until Dec. 31 to pay  up through the Food
for Fines program. Donations will go to  Lift-Up Food Bank, said Currie Meyer,
youth services librarian at  Bud Werner Memorial Library.

'It's a nice way to give back to the community and relieve  the stress of
overdue fines,' Meyer said.

Meyer will remove one dollar from fines for each can of food  donated.

'I want to be flexible with it,' Meyer said. 'If someone  brings in a huge jar
of peanut butter, that's worth a lot more  than a little can of peas.'

WESTERN SLOPE

Nuclear-waste route opposed

GATEWAY - Volunteer firefighters say hauling radioactive  waste to a Western
Slope dump will increase traffic accidents.

They are disputing a study that says Colorado 141 is a safe  route for trucking
shipments of radioactive waste from the  Shattuck Chemical Co. cleanup site in
south Denver to Uravan.

The site, already being used to store radioactive waste from  a former mine and
mill, is being proposed as a location for waste  collected elsewhere.

'I'd say the (Umetco Minerals Corp.) study looks at numbers.  I don't equate
numbers with human lives. The body count from  whatever disaster is out here,
whether it's Umetco or not, is  going to involve our own families and
neighbors,' said Dean  Rickman, chairman of the Gateway-Unaweep fire
department's board  of directors.

Rickman said the problem is that traffic would increase but  emergency
communications facilities would remain relatively  primitive. The narrow,
winding road is lined by steep canyons.

Hauling radioactive waste from Denver would generate 20 to 30  truck trips per
day on the two-lane canyon route, with a slight  increase in traffic accidents,
according to the traffic study  released by Umetco last week.

The fire department's pleas for improved communications, road  maintenance and
law enforcement have been largely unanswered since  April, Rickman said. Umetco
has not engaged the fire department in  addressing those problems, he said.

TYPE: BRIEFS

                               The New York Times

                December 29, 1995, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Drought Aid Expanded

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B;     Page 5;     Column 6;     Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 82 words

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 28


Farmers in six more counties have been deemed eligible for Federal disaster aid
because of losses caused by this year's drought.

Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman selected Cortland, Fulton, Lewis,
Montgomery, Ontario and Washington counties as eligible for drought aid. He also
designated Yates and Lewis counties as eligible for aid because of damage from
windstorms. In all, 31 New York counties have been designated as disaster areas
due to drought or windstorms this year.

                                US Official News

                           February 19, 2015 Thursday

New Jersey: Animal Emergency Working Group will hold its 17th Annual Symposium

LENGTH: 232  words

DATELINE: Trenton


Monmouth County, The State of New Jersey has issued the following news release:

The New Jersey Department of Agriculture Animal Emergency Working Group (AEWG)
will hold its 17th Annual Symposium at 9:15 a.m. on Monday, April 27 at the
Horse Park of New Jersey, 626 Route 524 in Allentown to train state and county
animal response teams in animal first aid.

During the daylong seminar, attendees will get hands-on experience in aiding
pets and small ruminants and will learn how to make a first aid kit. They also
will hear speakers about personal protective equipment and see how to tie knots
and make halters and leads.

The New Jersey Department of Agriculture, under the auspices of AEWG, develops
and coordinates plans to protect animals during emergency situations. It
oversees state and county animal response teams that work in the field during
disasters and emergencies. The AEWG operates under the New Jersey Department of
Agriculture's Division of Animal Health and the New Jersey State Police, Office
of Emergency Management.

Animal control officers, police and firefighters, county emergency planners,
animal response volunteers, veterinary-related personnel and others with an
interest in assisting animals during emergency situations will be in attendance
at the symposium

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                                US Official News

                           February 19, 2015 Thursday

New Jersey: Animal Emergency Working Group will hold its 17th Annual Symposium

LENGTH: 232  words

DATELINE: Trenton


Monmouth County, The State of New Jersey has issued the following news release:

The New Jersey Department of Agriculture Animal Emergency Working Group (AEWG)
will hold its 17th Annual Symposium at 9:15 a.m. on Monday, April 27 at the
Horse Park of New Jersey, 626 Route 524 in Allentown to train state and county
animal response teams in animal first aid.

During the daylong seminar, attendees will get hands-on experience in aiding
pets and small ruminants and will learn how to make a first aid kit. They also
will hear speakers about personal protective equipment and see how to tie knots
and make halters and leads.

The New Jersey Department of Agriculture, under the auspices of AEWG, develops
and coordinates plans to protect animals during emergency situations. It
oversees state and county animal response teams that work in the field during
disasters and emergencies. The AEWG operates under the New Jersey Department of
Agriculture's Division of Animal Health and the New Jersey State Police, Office
of Emergency Management.

Animal control officers, police and firefighters, county emergency planners,
animal response volunteers, veterinary-related personnel and others with an
interest in assisting animals during emergency situations will be in attendance
at the symposium

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

               October 2, 1999, Saturday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

USDA APPROVES DISASTER RELIEF FOR FARMERS IN ALL MISSOURI COUNTIES BECAUSE OF;
DROUGHT

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. 12

LENGTH: 166 words

DATELINE: JEFFERSON CITY


The U.S. Department of Agriculture on Friday announced that all of Missouri's
114 counties are eligible for disaster relief as a result of drought conditions
across the state.

Gov. Mel Carnahan requested the disaster aid earlier this month because Missouri
farmers had been hard hit by a lack of rain since July.

"From low commodity prices to severe heat and lack of rainfall, it's been a
tough year for Missouri farmers," Carnahan said in a statement.

USDA reports show that every county either had sustained significant losses or
had been indirectly affected by the drought.

Those reports showed at least a 50 percent crop loss in some areas and reduced
corn yield and severe damage to soybean crops.

The declaration will provide eligible farmers access to low-interest loans.
Those loans could be used to restore or replace property, cover some or all
production costs, help pay for essential family living expenses, or help
reorganize farming operations and refinance debt.

LANGUAGE: English

                              70 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                      March 1, 1999, Monday, FIRST EDITION

U.S. officials will stagger delivery to control where food shipments go

BYLINE: Barbara Slavin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 365 words


When the food aid agreement with Russia finally was hammered out
before Christmas, U.S. officials hoped that shipments would be
on the high seas in January. But the first installment -- 1,000
tons of pea seed -- is arriving March 10 and the remainder of
the promised 3.15 million tons of grain, meat and other commodities
is to be dribbled out in 60 to 70 shipments through June.

The main reason for the delay, and the staggered delivery, is
to try to check where the food actually goes. "We now have a
merchant-by-merchant, institution-by-institution breakdown for
almost all the commodities," says Chris Goldthwait, general sales
manager for the U.S. Department of Agriculture.


Most food is set for Moscow, St. Petersburg and other industrial
centers. And portions are to go to the Far East and Siberia.

Critics say the best thing about the program is that it can be
canceled.

"The most important change we were able to get into the agreement
was that if these commodities are not delivered as planned, no
further shipments will go," says Rep. Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio, ranking
Democrat on the House Appropriations Agriculture Subcommittee.
She worries that the aid will hurt Russia's struggling private
sector because the wholesalers are former state-run conglomerates.

Some see the program as motivated largely by a desire to help
U.S. farmers hurt by sagging commodity prices. Thomas Graham,
a former U.S. diplomat in Moscow, says it also is meant to show
continued U.S. engagement in Russia at a time of increasing economic
and political instability -- and foreign reluctance to pump in
more cash aid.

"Food aid is one of the few things you can do that looks humanitarian
without compromising your principles," he says.

Goldthwait says the United States intends to spot check at least
20% of the tonnage by using four full-time monitors, plus agricultural
staff and junior officers at the U.S. Embassy and consulates.
"If there is a significant diversion of commodities and we don't
see a way to control it," the program will be canceled, he says.
Asked his definition of "significant," he says: "We'll know
it when we see it."

LOAD-DATE: March 01, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1999 Gannett Company, Inc.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

             February 28, 1998, Saturday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Around state, El Nino hits like a hurricane

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: CITY & STATE; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 602 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE; ST. PETERSBURG; CLEARWATER



A series of El Nino-driven storms has left Floridians hip-deep in misery.

Across the state, people are fleeing rising rivers, building rings of  sandbags
around already-sodden houses and struggling to harvest flooded crops.

Consider the impact of El Nino so far:

+ More than 3,500 houses and businesses have been damaged or destroyed.  Total
damage: more than $ 350-million. About $ 100-million of that damage was  done
dramatically by powerful tornadoes that swept across Central Florida on  Monday,
killing 39 people and injuring 260 others.

+ Persistent floods in parts of Hillsborough, Citrus, Hernando and Duval
counties have driven 400 people out of their houses. Because the high water in
some areas has yet to recede, many have been homeless since late December.

+ Farmers are enduring more than $ 100-million in losses from swamped  vegetable
and strawberry crops. Landowners in Central Florida have been  shooting cattle
whose hooves have rotted from standing so long in flooded  pastures. About
40,000 chickens in North Florida have drowned, according to  the Department of
Agriculture and Consumer Affairs.

+ Few counties have escaped the wrath of severe wind damage or flooding.
Thirty-four of the state's 67 counties are eligible for federal disaster aid.

"When you add up all the damage caused by storm after storm after storm,  you
see an overall impact that's greater than we've seen with some  hurricanes,"
said Craig Fugate of the Florida Division of Emergency  Management.

Flooding along the Suwannee and Sante Fe rivers in North and Central  Florida
was the worst in a half-century. More than 300 houses were evacuated  along the
rivers last week.

In Central Florida, where the cleanup after Monday's tornadoes continued,  this
weekend's prediction of rain was on the forefront of people's minds.

"We're worried about the rain," said Martin Beck, who was going through  debris
in Kissimmee, trying to find his wedding photos. "We know rain and  pictures
don't go well together."

Volunteers descended on hundreds of damaged homes with hammers and pieces  of
wood and plastic tarps to safeguard against rain.

Applications for relief

accepted through April 6

   TALLAHASSEE - Residents of Florida counties whose homes were damaged in
Monday's tornadoes and floods have until April 6 to register with the Federal
Emergency Management Agency for disaster assistance.

Those who suffered losses in the storms may call (800) 462-9029.

Besides the Central Florida counties that were struck hardest, residents  and
business owners in Citrus, Hernando, Hillsborough, Pinellas, Manatee,  Pasco and
Polk counties also may apply.

Fund-raiser, blood drives

for victims set at Subway

  ST. PETERSBURG - A fund-raiser to benefit the Central Florida tornado  victims
and a blood drive to replenish the Tampa Bay area's supply will be  from 11 a.m.
to 3 p.m. today at the Lighthouse Crossing Subway, 3993 Tyrone  Blvd. N.

Scott Ledger of WTBT-FM 105.5 and a Salvation Army truck will be at Subway
collecting such items as money, canned food, blankets and clothes. Blood  drives
also will be at other Subways. Blood donor gifts include T-shirts, sub  coupons,
cholesterol screenings, drink coupons from Pick Kwik and two  round-trip tickets
to London.  City, Phillies pitch in

to help twister victims

   CLEARWATER - The city and the Philadelphia Phillies will collect donations
for victims of Monday's tornadoes at each spring training game at Jack Russell
Stadium.  S:

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           December 5, 1992, Saturday

GEORGIA IN BRIEF State faces fine in USDA program WASHINGTON: The U.S.
Department of Agriculture is asking Georgia and 23 other states to pay $ 300
million in penalties for mistakes and fraud in the food-stamp program.
Georgia's penalty is more than $ 26 million, but the USDA will settle for 35
cents on the dollar if states agree within 60 days to repay the money or invest
it in strengthening their program to minimize mistakes. A Georgia official said
caseworkers are bound to make mistakes when thousands of people are being added
to the rolls every month. "We do the best we can, [but] we're just not going to
let those children go hungry," said Peggy Peters, director of economic support
for the Georgia Department of Human Resources.  New York has the largest
penalty, $ 112 million. Ohio owes $ 29.2 million, and California owes more than
$ 26 million. The Virgin Islands owes the least, less than $ 7,000. DISASTER AID

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section C; Page 6

LENGTH: 300 words


ATLANTA: 9 more counties eligible for federal loans. Nine more counties have
been added to those eligible for federal disaster aid stemming from the
tornadoes that struck Georgia last month, officials said Friday. They are Dade,
Jones, Lincoln, Lumpkin, Monroe, Spalding, Talbot, Taliaferro and Wilkes
counties. Fourteen counties now are eligible for federal loans and grants. Also,
state Labor Commissioner David Poythress announced that workers who lost their
jobs as a direct result of the tornadoes may be entitled to federal Disaster
Unemployment Assistance. The federal program, in addition to providing benefits
to those who qualify, is open to workers who are ineligible for the state
unemployment insurance program. Applicants should contact a Labor Department
field services office or one of these centers: Cobb and Cherokee counties -
Kennesaw Elementary School's media building, 6997 Keene St., Kennesaw; Putnam
and Greene counties - National Guard Armory, Godfrey Road, Eatonton; Carroll
County - Carroll County Agricultural Cente r, 900 Newnan Road, Carrollton.

POLICE

TRENTON: Interstate closed by leaking truck. A tractor-trailer truck began
leaking hazardous chemicals after swerving off an interstate highway in
northwest Georgia Friday, and troopers closed the road, backing up traffic into
Tennessee. The truck, owned by Ricoh Chemical Corp., carried about 80 drums of
flammable resins that can irritate the eyes and respiratory system, said Dade
County Sheriff Phillip Street. The accident occurred about 2:30 p.m. on the
five-mile stretch of Interstate 24 that dips into Georgia. Dale McCreary, a
communications officer in the Dade County sheriff's office, said Friday evening
that it would be several hours before traffic would be moving again.

                              73 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           December 12, 2006 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Drought aid will help farmers, officials say ;
State's share of grants to total $6.5 million

BYLINE: Josh Rabe, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16A

LENGTH: 343 words


Cattle producers struggling with Oklahoma's ongoing drought could get a check
averaging about $500 per farm in the coming weeks.

The relief will come from a $50 million U.S. Department of Agriculture aid
program launched in September that is being divided among 20 states that were
hit hardest by drought this summer.

State agriculture officials said the grants won't bring farmers close to making
up for losses incurred this year but the amount each receives will be a little
more than anticipated.

Farmers who applied for the aid will get about $3.84 for each large grazing
animal they listed on a grant application, said Jack Carson, spokesman for the
state Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry.

"I have been saying all along this is a Band-Aid on a major wound," Carson said.

Agriculture officials feared livestock producers could get as little as 50 cents
per animal if it were divided among every cattle producer in the state but only
a small portion applied for the grants, Carson said.

The state's $6.5 million share of grant money is being divided among more than
12,000 farmers who applied for aid based on the number of animal units they had
this spring.

Large cows and bulls count as one unit, while smaller animals such as calves and
sheep only count as a fraction, Carson said.

Applicants listed an average of 124 units per farm, and would receive about $476
in aid.

Most Oklahoma farmers have between one to 499 cattle and could get anywhere from
a few dollars to nearly $2,000.

"That pales in comparison to the help that's still needed out there," said Scott
Dewald, executive vice president of the Oklahoma Cattlemen's Association. "It's
not going to offset anybody's loss but these are dollars that are going to
help."

Dewald said many farmers already have cut back herds to much smaller numbers so
they can survive until conditions improve, but the drought has forced others out
of the business.

Carson said the state Agriculture Department plans to get grant checks mailed by
the end of the year, or by early January at the latest.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                             April 5, 1992, Sunday

NATION IN BRIEF Bush spokesman denies allegation of job frustration

BYLINE: By Angela Duerson Tuck STAFF WRITERgeorge/bush; administration; policy;
assault; new/york; courts; executions; arizona; rulings; banking; aid; finances;
medicine; publications; ethics

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 4

LENGTH: 520 words


WASHINGTON, D.C.: President Bush's chief spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, denied
Saturday that he abruptly left on vacation in exasperation over turmoil in the
White House leadership. Mr. Fitzwater, in Bermuda, issued a statement through
White House aide Michael Busch, saying his vacation "has nothing to do with the
events described in The Washington Post article" about his frustration. The
article said Mr. Fitzwater had told associates that he was frustrated enough to
quit over White House inability to carry forward Mr. Bush's policies and themes.
"Marlin is not resigning and did not threaten to quit," Mr. Busch said.

NEW YORK: Shooting called mob attack. A reputed top-ranking member of the
Lucchese crime family was shot and critically wounded at a Westport restaurant
in what authorities termed a bungled mob attack. Aniello "Neil" Migliore, 59,
was in critical but stable condition Saturday at a hospital and was expected to
survive, said Nassau County police spokesman Officer Michael Aronsen.
Authorities say Mr. Migliore allegedly ran the family briefly during the 1980s
and is one of the most senior members of the Lucchese family.

ARIZONA: Court clears way for execution. The U.S. Supreme Court on Saturday
lifted a stay that had blocked the scheduled execution of a triple murderer. It
would be Arizona's first execution in 29 years. The Arizona Board of Pardons and
Paroles will hold a clemency hearing today for Donald Eugene Harding. The
hearing is the last step before he could be executed, said Assistant Attorney
General Jack Roberts.

WASHINGTON, D.C.: Delinquent borrowers got loans. The Farmers Home
Administration forgave multimillion-dollar loans to agribusiness borrowers who
misled the government about their finances, investigators say. The agency also
failed to verify or obtain complete information about assets, income and
collateral when large farm borrowers sought help restructuring their troubled
loans, according to government investigations. As a result, big borrowers reaped
millions of dollars in excess benefits, say investigators for the General
Accounting Office and the Agriculture Department's inspector general's office.
The inspector general's report was obtained by The Associated Press under the
Freedom of Information Act. Under the Agricultural Act of 1987, the FmHA has
provided about $ 2.8 billion in debt relief to delinquent farm borrowers.

MARYLAND: Doctor admonished for false AIDS report: A doctor has been reprimanded
by a state board for trying to get revenge on an ex- girlfriend by arranging for
her to be told falsely that she had tested positive for the AIDS virus. Dr.
Thomas DiGiovanna, 35, a former emergency room physician at Johns Hopkins
Hospital in Baltimore, put the name of his former girlfriend, a nurse at the
hospital, on a blood sample from a person with AIDS. The woman, whose name
wasn't disclosed, was told that her blood had tested positive for the virus but
didn't believe it because she hadn't submitted a sample for testing, Dr.
DiGiovanna's attorney, Patricia Fettman, said Friday. Dr. DiGiovanna didn't
contest the charges.

in Isla Vista, Calif., near Santa Barbara / The Associated Press

                              Journal of Commerce

                           April 4, 1990, Wednesday
                              Correction Appended

SHIPPING AGENTS FIGHT FOOD AID RULE REVISIONS

BYLINE: ALLEN R. WASTLER; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 526 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Shipping agents representing countries that receive U.S. foreign food aid
shipments are trying to thwart efforts on Capitol Hill to cut them out of the
program, government and industry sources said.

Ten foreign-country shipping agents and chartering brokers, all based in the
Washington area, are leading the attack on Capitol Hill. They have hired former
U.S. Senator John Melcher, a Nebraska Democrat, to lobby for them in Congress,
ccording to sources.

The agents are taking aim at legislation overhauling the U.S. foreign food aid
program. A provision in the legislation would require the Department of
Agriculture, instead of foreign country agents, to arrange the ocean
transportation of food aid shipments.

Government sources said the exact language of the provision eliminating
foreign-country agents is still being negotiated between Congress and the Bush
administration. The final language could allow the Department of Agriculture to
hire a shi pping agent itself to handle transportation arrangements.

A government source said the effort to get foreign-country shipping agents out
of the food-aid program was prompted by allegations of abuse in the industry and
by a series of Journal of Commerce articles outlining problems in the food-aid
shipping system.

In some cases, the agent arranging transportation for the country receiving food
aid also works as a broker for shipowners, said government and industry sources.
A provision in the legislation would eliminate this conflict of interest.

The legislation is the first to overhaul the federal foreign food aid program in
25 years. The program was put into place to provide impoverished nations with
the means to purchase U.S. agricultural goods.

Under present food aid regulations, three-quarters of U.S. food aid traffic has
to be moved on U.S.-flag carriers. These carriers are selected through an open
bidding process conducted by the Department of Agriculture.

The countries receiving the shipments select agents to arrange transportation
for the remaining traffic. The agents get a commission, usually 2.5 percent of
the freight charge, from the shipowner.

Agents claim that abuses of the present system are due to the Department of
Agriculture's failure to adequately enforce its own rules.

"There is a lot of stuff that needs to be policed," said one agent executive,
who asked not to be identified.

Agents maintain, however, that they should not be forced out of the market just
because the agency will not do its job.

"It's like a bank losing money, finding an embezzler on its staff, and to solve
the problem, closing the bank," said another agent executive.

According to an industry source the agents involved in the lobbying effort are:
Star Trading & Marine Inc.; Fettig & Donalty & Agarwal; Charrier, Gibson &
Associates Inc.; Potomac Marine Inc.; Pacific Cargoes Inc.; Panalpina Inc.;
EuroAmerican Shipping Inc.; International Navigation Corp.; Universal Marine
Corp. and Amex International Inc.

Sen. Melcher did not return phone calls. Some of the agent executives contacted
refused comment or denied knowledge of the lobbying effort.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: See related article: NEW EFFORTS PLANNED TO REVIVE GREAT LAKES
CARGO

CORRECTION-DATE: APRIL 6, 1990

CORRECTION:

A story appearing on the front page of the April 4 Journal of Commerce,
headlined "Shipping Agents Fight Food Aid Rule Revisions," identified the wrong
state as the home state of former U.S. Sen. John Melcher. Sen. Melcher
represented Montana during his tenure.

                  Copyright 1990 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              76 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            January 15, 1999 Friday
                                  City Edition

Nebraska hog farmers wait to hear about aid

SECTION: A; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 261 words


OMAHA (AP) -- Nebraska will learn in the coming months just what part of $50
million in federal aid will go to its hog farmers.

In North Carolina, officials said the state produces more hogs than any other
state except Iowa, but it will get next to nothing from the USDA.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture will not make any payments to farmers who
marketed more than 1,000 hogs during the last six months of 1998. In North
Carolina, less than 2 percent of the 18 million hogs grown there come from farms
with fewer than 1,000 pigs.

Much the federal aid appears to be headed to individual farmers in the Midwest,
North Carolina officials said.

"We don't have the small, individual hog farms in North Carolina like they still
have out in the Midwest," said Walter Cherry, executive director of the North
Carolina Pork Council. The USDA said eligible farmers will be paid $5 for each
pig marketed during the last half of 1998, up to a maximum of 500 animals. No
farmer will receive more than $2,500.

In Nebraska, about 6,000 farms produced almost 4 million hogs in 1998. Most of
the farms in the state are small, with individual farmers growing between 100
and 500 pigs.

Nebraska farmers won't know their cut for at least a month, state agricultural
officials said Thursday.

Doy Unzicker, a price support program specialist for the Nebraska Farm Services
Agency, said that as of Feb. 1, hog farmers can sign up at their local farm
services agencies to be eligible for the USDA payments. The amount Nebraska
receives will be based in part on how many farmers sign up, he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
