                              All Rights Reserved


                              77 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                             Corporate Legal Times

                                  August, 2005

SECTION: CIRCUIT ROUNDUP; Pg. 58

LENGTH: 1327 words

HIGHLIGHT: Exxon was in bad faith trying to make a "judicial train wreck" of the
claims administration process.
_District Judge Alan S. Gold


Debbi Mack

1st Circuit

Oracle Pays $ 8 Million To Settle Whistleblower Suit

Oracle Corp. has agreed to pay $ 8 million to settle civil claims over its
billing practices. The claims arose from a former employee's whistleblower
lawsuit. The U.S. Attorney's Office in Boston announced the settlement May 13.

Filed in Massachusetts federal court, the suit alleged that from 1997 through
2003 Oracle violated the False Claims Act by improperly billing the government
for computer training it was contracted to provide.

Oracle allegedly billed various agencies before providing the training and broke
federal travel regulations by billing the government for travel and expenses.

Robert J. Makheja, of McLean, Va., a former vice president of North American
sales for the company's Oracle University division, filed the whistleblower
action. He will get $ 1.58 million from the settlement.

The General Services Administration and U.S. Department of Agriculture, the
Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Defense Criminal Investigative Service and
the U.S. Postal Inspection Service were among the agencies investigating the
case.

3rd Circuit

Class Action Denied In Lipitor Suit

On May 3, a Pennsylvania state court refused to certify a class action lawsuit
against Rite Aid Inc. for allegedly selling counterfeit Lipitor, a
cholesterol-reduction drug.

Rite Aid started buying Lipitor from H.D. Smith Wholesale Drug Co. in March
2003. On May 23, 2003, H.D. Smith informed Rite Aid that some of the Lipitor it
bought could be counterfeit and suggested recalling Lipitor it had purchased
from April 22 to May 23, 2003. By that time, Rite Aid had sold the product to
330,000 customers. Most of it turned out to be genuine.

Christopher Crepeau, the named plaintiff, filed suit against Rite Aid and H.D.
Smith in September 2003, alleging breach of express warranty and unjust
enrichment.

The suit sought to represent all 330,000 Rite Aid customers as a class, even
though it was impossible to determine who had bought the counterfeit product and
how much each plaintiff purchased. Crepeau finished all the medication before he
got the recall notice and couldn't prove whether any of it was counterfeit.

The court found the case didn't meet most of the criteria for class
certification because the plaintiff wasn't able to "meaningfully define" the
class and the lead plaintiff couldn't prove he qualified at all.

"Plaintiff's class as defined is flawed because it necessarily includes all
those who purchased genuine Lipitor," Judge Mark I. Bernstein wrote. "Plaintiff
has created a class which is detrimentally over-inclusive. As a result neither
Plaintiff nor the Court can ever determine class identity or size."

6th Circuit

Class Action Suit Over Sex Products OK'd

The maker of pills that purportedly enlarge penis size and improve female sexual
response is appealing an Ohio state court decision to certify a class action
lawsuit that alleges the company misrepresented its products' capabilities.

The suit alleges Berkeley Premium Nutraceuticals Inc. made unsubstantiated
claims that its product, Enzyte, could increase penis size by one to three
inches and Avlimil could improve a woman's libido.

The plaintiffs allege the company had no evidence to back its claims for Enzyte
and the claims for Avlimil were based solely on a bogus clinical study.

Berkeley promoted the products by providing 30-day samples at the cost of
shipping and handling, which it charged to customers' credit cards. After
sending the samples, the company allegedly continued to ship the product to
customers every month and charge their credit cards.

The company allegedly trained its telephone sales representatives to withhold
information about this practice from customers and to deny refunds when
customers called to complain.

Berkeley argued that, because statements about the product and the company's
refund policy varied among different media, a class action was inappropriate
because common factual and legal questions didn't predominate.

The court disagreed. "Although varying statements regarding the efficacy of
Enzyte and Avlimil were made based upon the type of media, the Court finds that
rooted in each of those advertisements was Defendants' misrepresentation that
Enzyte would enlarge penis size and that Avlimil would increase female libido or
in some way manipulate female hormones." Judge John W. Kessler wrote.

11th Circuit

Exxon Sanctioned For Frivolous Defenses

On May 18, a Florida federal court took Exxon Mobil Corp. to task for dragging
its feet in paying a $ 500 million jury award to several thousand gas station
owners and trying to disrupt the claims-administration process by raising issues
already decided in the case.

The court struck down various defenses Exxon raised to paying the station owners
who won a class action lawsuit against Exxon in 2001 and awarded attorneys' fees
as a Rule 11 sanction against Exxon. The decision mentioned Robert Wallis,
Exxon's in-house counsel, by name, citing his active participation in the
lawsuit as a reason for sanctioning the company, rather than its outside
counsel.

"... [A]t the time the Court issued its warning, neither Plaintiffs' counsel or
the Court were aware of Exxon's now apparent intention to appeal every final
judgment in the claims process on practically every issue already resolved on
appeal, not just the issue of prejudgment interest," plaintiffs' counsel wrote
in its request for sanctions.

The case has been plodding through the courts since 1991, when a group of
dealers sued Exxon Corp. for allegedly overcharging them for gasoline. Exxon
unsuccessfully appealed the award up to the U.S. Supreme Court.

The district court resumed charge of the case to determine and pay the
individual claims. In the interim, the award has grown to more than $ 1.3
billion as interest accrued. The average claim is expected to be around $
130,000, according to Eugene Stearns, a partner with Stearns, Weaver, Miller,
Weissler, Alhadeff and Sitterson, who represented the gas station owners.

By challenging the claims based on arguments it previously lost on appeal,
District Judge Alan S. Gold said, "Exxon was in bad faith trying to make a
'judicial train wreck' of the claims administration process" and accused Exxon
of having "a cynical plan to prolong this litigation which has endured more than
13 years."

DC Circuit

Court Halts D.C. Hazardous Cargo Ban

The D.C. Circuit barred the Washington, D.C., government on May 3 from enforcing
an emergency ban on transporting hazardous materials near the U.S. Capitol
building.

The D.C. Council passed the Terrorism Prevention in Hazardous Materials
Transportation Emergency Act in February, prohibiting trains and trucks from
carrying explosives, flammable gases, poisonous gases and other hazardous
material within 2.2 miles of the Capitol.

The day after the act was signed, CSX Transportation Inc. sued the city and
mayor in federal court, seeking to invalidate the law and prevent its
enforcement.

CSX alleged the law would require re-routing hazardous materials to other rail
lines, increasing the total miles and time it would take to move them.

The district court found CSX wasn't likely to succeed on the merits of its claim
and, given the potential devastation of a terrorist attack close to the Capitol,
refused to strike down the law.

The D.C. Circuit reversed, finding CSX was likely to win on its argument that
the D.C. law was preempted by a federal rule requiring rail carriers to develop
and implement security plans for moving hazardous materials.

The court ruled the D.C. law addressed concerns already covered by the required
plans, which appeared to provide adequate protection.

The court also found the D.C. ordinance couldn't survive under an exception for
laws that address a local safety or security hazard and that it unreasonably
burdened interstate commerce.3

LOAD-DATE: July 22, 2005

LANGUAGE: English

                Copyright 2005 Corporate Legal Times Corporation


                              78 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 January 2, 1998, Friday, Late Edition - Final

After Storms, New Mexico Airlifts Hay To Livestock

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 376 words

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Jan. 1


With the announcement on Wednesday of $2 million in disaster aid for ranchers,
the New Mexico National Guard was airlifting hay to 181,000 head of livestock
stranded by snow.

The Farm Service Agency of the Federal Department of Agriculture estimated that
some 5,000 cattle had died because of a series of storms with high winds that
battered eastern New Mexico, blowing snow into drifts from 8 feet to 14 feet
high. The area usually receives little snow.

Five Air National Guard C-130 cargo planes dropped 96 tons of hay in the
southeastern part of the state, said Col. Barry Stout of the New Mexico National
Guard.

Three planes were to deliver 66 tons of hay today. Bob Redden of the state's
Office of Emergency Management said air drops would continue through Sunday.

"A tremendous amount of cattle and livestock in New Mexico were going to be lost
if these actions had not been taken," said Darren White, secretary of the State
Department of Public Safety.

Crusted snow kept livestock from grazing, and ice covered their water tanks.

Caren Cowan, executive secretary of the New Mexico Cattle Growers Association,
said: "These animals aren't prepared for this kind of cold."

The livestock industry -- cattle, dairy cows and sheep -- is a $1.1 billion
business in New Mexico. As of Jan. 1, 1997, there were nearly 1.5 million beef
cattle, 197,000 milk cows, and 235,000 sheep in the state, according to the New
Mexico Livestock Board.

Also on Wednesday, the Federal Agriculture Department announced emergency aid
that would reimburse ranchers for up to 30 percent of the cost of buying feed
for their cattle and sheep from Dec. 24 through Jan. 3. The agency will pay up
to $50 a ton for feed. Ranchers are paying about $90 a ton for the hay delivered
by the cargo planes, said Mr. White, of the Department of Public Safety.

Mr. White said the costs of rescue operations and snow removal across New Mexico
could reach $20 million.

New Mexico is seeking additional Federal aid to cover some of the relief
efforts.

So far, the state has spent about $10 million just to clear snow from roads and
highways. The National Guard is using its helicopters to rescue stranded
families and provide emergency medical treatment.



LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company


                              79 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                May 21, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

CHALLENGES PERIL A STATE RISE OF 15% IN WELFARE BENEFITS

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 658 words


As a result of conservative challenges now under study by the Reagan
Administration, New York welfare recipients might lose out on part of the full
15 percent increase recently approved in Albany.  Those challenges could lead to
a cut in food stamps that would offset nearly a third of the forthcoming
increase.

The challenges come from William T. Smith, Republican of Big Flats and deputy
majority leader of the State Senate, and Representative Gary A. Lee, Republican
of upstate Dryden. Mr. Lee contends the New York plan aims ''to get around the
intent'' of Federal food stamp rules. He has told President Reagan he would
sponsor an Administration bill to insure that the Federal Government is not
''duped.''

G. William Hoagland, the new food stamp administrator, said yesterday in
Washington that he was considering the challenges as well as documents offered
in defense of the New York plan by Barbara B. Blum, State Commissioner of Social
Services. About $50 million in Federal food stamp funds is involved, Mr.
Hoagland said.

The extra payment would be financed 50-50 by the Federal Government and the
state for families receiving Aid to Dependent Children funds, and borne entirely
by the state for recipients in the homerelief category. If the Administration
decided it was really a welfare increase - rather than energy aid - the state
share would be counted as income. For each $1 of increased income, Mr. Hoagland
said, the amount of food stamps received would be reduced by 30 cents.

Administration Decision Crucial

This would leave Aid to Dependent Children welfare families with a net increase
of about 12.75 percent and recipients of home relief with a net increase of 10.5
percent because of the loss of part of their food-stamp aid.

For a family of four, a maximum 15 percent increase would amount to $38.70 a
month above the present $258 basic welfare grant, which is separate from grants
to cover rents. Grants for rents vary by regions.

Mr. Hoagland, the director of the Agriculture Department's Food and Nutrition
Service, said the Reagan Administration sought legislation for the future to
count any state or local energy payments as income for food-stamp purposes. In
part, this would stop the Federal Government from having to decide whether such
payments were disguised welfare grants.

Mr. Hoagland wrote to Representative Lee on May 5, asserting that ''the
Administration has serious concerns'' about New York's plan to raise welfare
payments in the name of energy aid as possibly ''contrary to the spirit and
intent of the Food Stamp Act Amendments of 1980.''

The New York State Department of Social Services contended that any welfare
increase ''intended primarily to meet the increased cost of home energy'' was
not to be counted as income that would reduce the amount of food stamps
received.

Commissioner Blum said the nonrent welfare grant for a family of four had
allowed $14 for electricity and gas in 1974, but these costs had risen to $48 as
of last October. This, she said, would account for $34 of the new energy aid,
with other energy-related costs, such as transportation, accounting for the
rest.

A Reagan Administration proposal to count any state or local energy aid in the
future as income for food-stamp purposes has been approved by the Senate
Agriculture Committee but lost in the House Agriculture Committee.

State Senator Smith said the Federal Government had allocated $223 million to
New York in the current fiscal year for energy aid to lowincome households. He
contended that failure by Congress to approve the Reagan Administration
amendments would be ''a signal for every state to routinely label their general
welfare-grant increases as energy assistance payments.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company


                              80 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                            January 20, 2012 Friday

Utah floods bring most federal aid of any state

BYLINE: By Lee Davidson The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: POLITICS; News; State

LENGTH: 637 words


Utah may be a desert, but disastrous flooding here last year led it to receive
the most of any state in a big package of federal emergency agricultural
disaster aid announced on Wednesday.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture awarded Utah $60.3 million out of the $307.6
million given nationally -- about 20 percent of the national total. Utah's money
is for emergency watershed repair projects statewide.

That came after the wettest spring on record in northern Utah led to snowmelt
flooding along rivers including the Weber, Ogden, Blacksmith's Fork, Sevier,
Emigration Creek and Big and Little Cottonwood Creek. Flash flooding also
occurred in December 2010 in southern Utah. All that flooded, or even eroded
away, many farms and hurt irrigation and flood control systems.

"Landowners, individuals and communities have endured incredible hardships,"
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said as he announced the national
assistance. "This funding will help to rebuild communities.... This assistance
keeps farmers on the farm, ranchers on the ranch, and landowners on the land."

The U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service will funnel money to 13 local
governments in Utah to pay up to 75 percent for restoration or flood prevention
projects, while local governments must pay the rest through cash or in-kind
services. About $50.2 eventually will go to local governments, and the NRCS will
also use $10.1 million in the state for technical assistance.

Among amounts awarded so far are $13 million to Weber County, where high
snowmelt flooding damaged road, irrigation, structures, homes and bridges.
Washington County is receiving $6.59 million for damage from flash floods.

Salt Lake County is receiving $3.5 million. High stream flows in the most
populous county caused damage to property on Big and Little Cottonwood Creeks,
Mill Creek and the Jordan River.

Among some other initial amounts awarded are: Cache County, $6 million; Duchesne
County, $4 million; Sevier County, $3.5 million; Sanpete County, $2.5 million;
Piute County, $1.5 million; Green River Soil Conservation District, $1.5
million; Kane County, $600,000; Garfield County, $500,000; Spanish Fork,
$500,000; and the Northern Utah Water Conservancy District, $500,000.

"We look forward to working with the local sponsors to restore these critical
natural resource systems and help make these communities whole again," said Dave
Brown, state conservationist in the Utah NRCS office.

Ron Francis, NRCS Utah spokesman, said the agency figures that $57 million worth
of similar work after 2005 floods around St. George helped this year, when
similar flash flooding occurred. He said it helped avoid "damages exceeding $179
million, and protected 450 individual properties and 30 businesses.... It
worked. The stuff held and it didn't wipe out homes again."

The Utah Department of Agriculture and Food hailed the aid.

"Agriculture is hard enough without natural disasters making it even more
difficult," said department spokesman Larry Lewis. "It's very important that
farmers are able to put themselves back in business and undo what damage the
flood did. We're talking about tens of millions of dollars of losses" from
flooding last year.

Utah Deputy Agriculture Commissioner Kyle Stephens added, "As a result of
flooding around the state, it caused a lot of farmers and ranchers not to be
able to put their crops in" because of flooded or too-wet fields. He said even
where farmers may have been able to plant, "Irrigations systems were compromised
because of flooding, so they were not able to get water on fields." Alt Heads:

Utah floods bring most federal aid of any state Top five states in aid awards

Utah » $60.3 million

Missouri » $48.9 million

New York » $41.8 million

Alabama » $16.6 million

Pennsylvania » $13.9 million

Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Water floods an alfalfa field in the Taylor Ward west of Ogden in May
2011. The water will ruin summer crops. Director of Weber County Emergency
Management Lance Peterson estimates that 2,000 acres of alfalfa, pasture and
cattle range have already been flooded with water from the nearby Weber River.
Water floods an alfalfa field in the Taylor Ward west of Ogden in May 2011. The
water will ruin summer crops. Director of Weber County Emergency Management
Lance Peterson estimates that 2,000 acres of alfalfa, pasture and cattle range
have already been flooded with water from the nearby Weber River.
Water flooding out from the Weber River fills the front yard of a home on W.
1600 South outside of Ogden in May 2011.
Water floods the Wadeland dairy farm in the Taylor Ward west of Ogden Sunday in
May 2011. Director of Weber County Emergency Management Lance Peterson estimates
that 2,000 acres of alfalfa, pasture and cattle range have already been flooded
with water from the nearby Weber River.

                            January 20, 2012 Friday

Utah floods bring most federal aid of any state

BYLINE: By Lee Davidson The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: POLITICS; News; State

                              82 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      AUGUST 6, 1999 Friday CNORTH EDITION

PA. CROP REPORTS USED IN REQUEST FOR FEDERAL AID / A GROUP OF EXPERTS WILL
REVIEW THE LOSSES TODAY. BUCKS AND MONTGOMERY ARE THE HARDEST HIT.

BYLINE: Meredith Fischer and Mark Binker, INQUIRER SUBURBAN STAFF

SECTION: NEIGHBORS; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 487 words


Seeking to have Pennsylvania declared an agricultural disaster area, a team of
policy experts is scheduled to convene in Harrisburg today to review county
reports of drought-related crop loss.

The Natural Disaster Assessment Damage Reports, which detail withered crops and
lagging production statewide, will be sent to Washington to secure financial
help for farmers hit hardest this growing season, state officials said.

Topping the list of those in need will be farmers from Montgomery and Bucks
Counties.

"Bucks and Montgomery Counties are absolutely worse than any other part of the
state," said Michael Fournier, an agent for the Penn State Cooperative Extension
in Bucks County. "There is no field or farm in the area producing anywhere near
its annual average."

Darrell Tribue, a local director of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm
Service Agency, said both counties were looking at "a complete loss."

"The air is so dry that what showers do head our way evaporate and disband
before they can hit the ground," he said.

Hollis Baker, a representative with the Farm Service Agency, said officials from
Chester and Delaware Counties held meetings with farmers, and submitted their
reports to the state yesterday.

Today's session follows a decision earlier this week by the Clinton
administration to declare some parts of Pennsylvania and five other states
agricultural disaster areas.

The declaration will enable farmers who have lost at least 30 percent of their
income as a result of the summer's drought to draw up to $500,000 in
low-interest loans.

The disaster declaration covers 88 counties in parts of Pennsylvania, Ohio,
Kentucky, West Virginia, Virginia and Maryland. Only four Western Pennsylvania
counties are included: Fayette, Beaver, Green and Washington Counties.

Pennsylvania will be seeking direct aid rather than loans from Washington.

"We are hoping they will kick in another level of programs," said Jeff Schneck,
an agronomist based in Souderton, "and send a signal to Congress that they may
need to appropriate more money to the state."

According to county farmers, pastures are barren and milk production has dropped
by as much as 20 percent in some parts of the state.

Agriculture is Pennsylvania's leading industry, generating $4 billion a year,
according to state officials. Milk production - dairy is the state's largest
farm business - ranks fourth nationally, they added.

In Bucks County, the investment in this season's planting has been about $9
million, Tribue said.

In Montgomery County, farmers have invested $15 million in their 30,000 acres of
crops, said Lou Saporito, an agriculture agent with the Penn State Cooperative
Extension.

"Farmers will not harvest any corn or grain, and there is very little hope for
any bean harvest," he said.

* Inquirer staff writer Walter F. Naedele also contributed to this article.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              All Rights Reserved

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

              August 11, 1999, Wednesday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Black farmers' bias claims examined

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 1032 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON; BOSTON; HUNTSVILLE, Texas; LEXINGTON, Ky.; SACRAMENTO,
Calif.



The Agriculture Department is investigating complaints that black farmers were
denied disaster aid in Arkansas and Georgia this year, even as the department
was settling a civil rights lawsuit.

The complaints involve three of the Farm Service Agency's county offices in
Arkansas and two in Georgia. A team from the USDA's civil rights office was in
Georgia last week, officials said Tuesday.

Those cases were among several complaints of discrimination the department
received. Many of the complainants declined to cooperate with investigators.

Last April, a federal judge approved the settlement of a class-action lawsuit
alleging that USDA had regularly denied black farmers loans and other
assistance.

Some farmers have declined to participate in the settlement.

On Tuesday, about 120 people marched around the department's headquarters.
Later, 14 of the farmers met with Rosalind Gray, director of the civil rights
office.

Gray said some employees have been fired or disciplined.

John Boyd, president of the National Black Farmers Association, said he has
received complaints from producers who say they were told by department
officials that they didn't need disaster grants or loans because they were
benefiting from the settlement.

The agency distributed $ 2-billion in aid this summer for weather-related losses
that farmers had suffered in previous years.

Judge denies request to

end race-based busing

BOSTON - Quashing a bid by a group of white parents to end race-based student
assignment in Boston public schools by September, a federal judge ruled Tuesday
that racial formulas will still be used to send students to school next month.

The ruling, however, will not affect the Boston School Committee's recent vote
to rid the school district of race-based student assignment by the fall of 2000.

Saying that the "onerous" task of reassigning as many as 20,000 students within
five weeks would be too detrimental to parents, students and school staff, U.S.
District Judge Nancy Gertner denied the parents' request.

NASA revises cause

of launch short circuit

New findings Tuesday prompted NASA to change its mind about the cause of the
electrical short that occurred during last month's launch of the shuttle
Columbia.

The short that disrupted the computer-like controllers on two of the shuttle's
three rocket engines was likely caused by a blow to a wire beneath the payload
bay, said James Hartsfield, a NASA shuttle program spokesman.

NASA said Monday that engineers had determined the short occurred 5 seconds
after liftoff because insulation from the wire had been chafed away over time
against a screw head.

Experts, however, changed their mind Tuesday after reviewing the results of an
analysis with an electron microscope.

"From looking at it with the electron microscope the indentations in the wire
were a telltale sign that it was really an impact type of damage," Hartsfield
said. The short could have developed at any time since Columbia was
manufactured, he said, adding, "They really don't know when it could have
happened."

Texas executes man

in teller's slaying

HUNTSVILLE, Texas - A ninth-grade dropout who shot a bank teller to death the
day after she picked out her wedding dress was executed by injection on Tuesday.

Kenneth Dwayne Dunn, 39, was the third man executed in Texas in the last week
and the 19th this year. Three more are set to die in the next eight days.

On March 17, 1980, Dunn walked into a Houston-area bank where he had been seen
before as a customer. This time he was armed with a .357-caliber Magnum revolver
and demanded money from each teller.

Witnesses said 21-year-old Madeline Peters was on the phone and unaware of the
robbery. When Dunn reached her window and ordered her to put cash in a bag, she
responded, "What?"

He fired, killing her with one shot to her head. He fled with almost $ 12,000.

"Her wedding dress was in a box open behind her," prosecutor Joe Magliolo
recalled Tuesday.

Boy Scout recovering

from mauling by bear

A sleeping Boy Scout was dragged from his tent by a black bear at a northern
Wisconsin camp and severely mauled before campers scared the bear off.

Matthew Murphy, 14, of Ashland, Wis., was in serious condition with a dislocated
shoulder and bite wounds to his head and shoulder. He is expected to make a full
recovery.

The boy was sleeping about 6:30 a.m. Monday in a tent at Tomahawk Scout
Reservation camp when a bear grabbed the tent and hauled it and the boy about 80
feet.

Matthew's father threw a rock at the bear, which retreated. But it came toward
him, and he threw a log at the animal, forcing it to climb a tree. After the boy
was carried to safety, the bear began tearing up the tent again.

Suspect in railroad

killings indicted again

LEXINGTON, Ky. - Angel Maturino Resendiz, suspected of being the "railroad
killer," has been indicted in the 1997 killing of a University of Kentucky
student.

Fayette County prosecutors said they will seek the death penalty for Resendiz,
who was indicted Monday by a grand jury in the slaying of Christopher Maier, 21,
on railroad tracks near the Kentucky campus. He also was charged with the rape
and beating of Maier's girlfriend.

Authorities have linked Resendiz to nine slayings. He is charged with seven,
including two in Illinois and four in Texas.

Seat belt law proposed

for Calif. farm workers

SACRAMENTO, Calif. - In the aftermath of Monday's crash that killed 13 migrant
workers in the San Joaquin Valley, emergency legislative reforms were proposed
Tuesday that include a bill to require safety belts on farm labor vans.

"These accidents are almost as predictable as the harvests in the valley," said
Assemblyman Dean Florez, a Democrat from the valley.

Florez and Democratic Assemblywoman Sarah Reyes of Fresno proposed a package of
emergency bills to crack down on what they characterized as a worker transport
system desperately in need of tighter regulation.

 The two Latino freshmen legislators scrambled to draft the bills one day after
the tomato workers were killed when the long van they were riding in smashed
into a semitrailer truck on a country road in Fresno County.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           August 25, 1993, Wednesday

DEATHS ELSEWHERE Jeanne Yeutter, Ex-agriculture official's wife

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section C; Page 6

LENGTH: 186 words


McLean, Va. - Jeanne Yeutter, 62, wife of former U.S. Agriculture Secretary
Clayton Yeutter, died of an apparent heart attack Monday at her home here. Her
husband was agriculture secretary in the Bush administration.

William E. DeLoach, Congressional aide

Columbia, S.C. - William E. DeLoach, 46, a chief aide to U.S. Rep. James E.
Clyburn, died of AIDS-related pneumonia Monday at his home here. Mr. DeLoach is
a former consultant and lobbyist.

L. Charles Scorsese, Film director's father

New York City - L. Charles Scorsese, 80, a retired garment worker who became an
actor and appeared in films directed by his son, Martin Scorsese, died Monday at
New York University Hospital. The elder Mr. Scorsese had parts in his son's
movies "Goodfellas," "Raging Bull," "The King of Comedy," "The Color of Money"
and "Cape Fear."

Dinmukhamed Kunayev, Former Politburo member

Alma Ata, Kazakhstan - Dinmukhamed Kunayev, 81, a former member of the Soviet
Union's ruling Politburo, died here Sunday. A native of Kazakhstan, he was a
close associate of the late Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev.

                              85 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             August 2, 2015 Sunday

Farmers markets heralded as 'engines of growth'

BYLINE: Justin Horwath, The Santa Fe New Mexican

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 535 words


Aug. 02--State and federal agriculture officials declared this week National
Farmers Market Week at the Railyard on Saturday.

Anne Alonzo, who heads efforts at U.S. Department of Agriculture to help farmers
market crops, said that out of 8,500 farmers markets across the nation, the
federal agency chose to introduce the proclamation -- made by U.S Secretary of
Agriculture Tom Vilsack -- at the Santa Fe's Farmers Market because it's a
"thriving and a model market with over 5,000 customers a day."

"These are really engines of growth and they really produce a lot of foot
traffic," she said of farmers markets.

Alonzo said one of the agency's priorities is assisting local farming. Last
year, local food sales topped $11.6 billion across the country, she said.

In the past six years, the USDA has pumped $9.7 billion into various program in
New Mexico, Alonzo said, including $500,000 to eight projects in New Mexico last
year that went to groups such as the Santa Fe Farmers Market Institute, the
nonprofit that runs the market.

The New Mexico Department of Agriculture awarded the Santa Fe Farmers Market
Institute $400,000 to help farmers markets across the state administer the
Double-Up Food Bucks program. The program doubles benefits for food-aid
recipients up to a certain amount, if they spend the aid at a farmers market.

In 2009, food-benefit spending through Supplemental Nutrition Assistance
Program, formerly known as food stamps, at local farmers markets was $4 million,
Alonzo said. That number increased to $18 million last year, she said.

Jeff Witte, the secretary for the New Mexico Department of Agriculture, said
"money was tight" at the state Legislature during the last session, but the
$400,000 allocation aimed at helping markets administer the Double-Up Food Bucks
program made it through.

Witte, named secretary of the department by Republican Gov. Susana Martinez,
said in an interview after the event that he hasn't followed the Martinez
administration's proposal to impose more work-related requirements on food-aid
recipients.

"I think there's a lot of things that need to be evaluated," as Martinez's Human
Services Department creates the new rules, he said.

He told the crowd Saturday that the Santa Fe Farmers Markets is one of the
largest in the country -- with over $2 million worth of produce purchased
annually at it. He grew up on a ranch between Santa Fe and Las Vegas, N.M., he
said.

New Mexico has a $4 billion agricultural economy, Witte said.

"But when you add it all up and go to all the farmers markets," he said, "it
multiplies to over $10 billion worth of production in the [agricultural]
sector."

Director of the market Paolo Speirn said growers are facing a new challenge of
supplying food for the market's customers all four seasons.

"When people think of the desert they don't think of growing food" he said. "But
the intense climate has given us very elegant solutions to agricultural
problems. Things like the acequia system."

Justin Horwath can be reached at 986-3017 or jhorwath@sfnewmexican.com

                                   USA TODAY

                     August 3, 1993, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Agriculture chief seeks more aid for farmers

BYLINE: Sandra Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2A

LENGTH: 295 words


Disaster aid checks will be sent to flood-stricken Midwest farmers within two
weeks after Congress approves flood funding, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike
Espy said Monday.

Speaking at a Washington, D.C., farm conference, Espy said he'll push Congress
for more funding for farmers. Currently disaster payments are limited to 50% of
crop loss.

The formula has angered some farmers who say it does not figure in current
inflated prices, and actually would equate to 21 cents per dollar for what lost
crops now would bring at market.

Espy also pledged to lower future crop insurance costs.

A $ 4.7 billion flood aid bill is pending in the Senate.

Singer Willie Nelson, head of FARM AID, asked Espy "to change government
policies so that family farmers can once again make a decent living."

After the meeting, Nelson returned to his bus to find a $ 150 parking ticket.

Also Monday:

IN WASHINGTON: The House voted to ease federal banking regulations for flood
victims to pay back loans. The bill temporarily lifts banking regulations in the
flood area to encourage borrowing and prevent foreclosures. The bill, which also
allows victims to qualify for more credit, heads to the Senate.

BACK TO WORK: Missouri Gov. Mel Carnahan has ordered state workers in Jefferson
City to return to work today, although several roads and bridges remain closed.
Workers living north of the Missouri River had been on paid leave since Friday.

PLANT WORKING: The sewage plant in St. Joseph, Mo., resumed partial operation
for the first time in nearly three weeks. About 20 million gallons of raw sewage
had been dumped daily into the Missouri River since floodwaters forced the plant
to close July 14. Also, a boil order was lifted on drinking water for 85,000
residents.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 11, 2012 Friday

Food program aids seniors

BYLINE: Kate Giammarise, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 579 words


May 11--For 67-year-old Carl Smarage, who is living on a limited Social Security
income, every dollar counts.

So last year, the East Toledoan called Toledo Area Ministries seeking
information about food pantries where he could get assistance.

"The next thing you know, I'm eligible for food stamps and some medical
assistance for my medications," he said.

Mr. Smarage now receives $58 in food stamps monthly.

"That $58 allows me to buy some things I wouldn't normally buy," he said. On
Thursday, Mr. Smarage, a retiree, stocked up on such basics as noodles, eggs,
and margarine using his food assistance.

Toledo Area Ministries was one of six agencies nationally to receive a grant
from the U.S. Department of Agriculture in 2009 for a pilot program to increase
food-stamp outreach among senior citizens.

The agency hopes the techniques it is using can serve as a national model for
other groups.

RELATED ARTICLE: Farmers markets get U.S. aid to accept food-benefit cards

Nationally, just 34 percent of eligible individuals age 60 and older received
food-stamp benefits in federal fiscal year 2009, according to the Agriculture
Department, which administers the program.

"We saw an opportunity to really make an impact in Lucas County," said Jim
Brenizer, Toledo Area Ministries' director of meeting human need.

Seniors often don't have accurate information about the program, may be
concerned about the application process, or believe others, such as families
with young children, are more in need of assistance than themselves.

Toledo Area Ministries, which runs more than a dozen area food pantries, had
surveyed its pantry clients and found, in line with national trends, that many
seniors who were eligible for food stamps were not receiving them.

The organization's $500,000 grant is used to help screen potentially eligible
seniors and help the clients fill out applications. Other pilot programs funded
by the Ag Department targeted the elderly in Michigan and Pennsylvania.

"A lot of [seniors] ... are used to being very frugal and are not looking for
anything they see as a handout," said Justin Moor, vice president of planning
and program development at the Area Office on Aging, which is helping connect
some of the seniors it serves to Toledo Area Ministries.

Kathy Keller, a spokesman for AARP Ohio, said food stamps, now known as SNAP, or
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, can be a help to seniors on limited
incomes. "It can really be important in many ways," Ms. Keller said.

Education for these seniors is critical, she said, such as letting them know the
benefits are loaded onto an electronic card that looks similar to a debit card
and are not actually stamps.

In Lucas County, the number of people over age 60 receiving food assistance has
increased in recent years, as it has for all age groups. In 2009, 4,915 Lucas
County residents were using food assistance, and about 7,200 are using them now,
according to the county's Job and Family Services office.

Anna Bolden, another senior who has taken advantage of the program, said the $16
she receives each month is helpful.

"That's enough to buy a gallon of milk and a packet of meat," said the retiree.
"It has made a difference, it really has."

For more information, call Toledo Area Ministries at 419-242-7401.

Contact Kate Giammarise at: kgiammarise@theblade.com or 419-724-6091.

___ (c)2012 The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) Visit The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) at
www.toledoblade.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                                 The Oklahoman

                              May 16, 2006 Tuesday
                                Suburban Edition

Lucas pushes disaster relief for farmers

BYLINE: Chris Casteel, Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17A

LENGTH: 409 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON -- Fearing that agricultural aid will be cut out of an emergency
spending bill, Rep. Frank Lucas has authored disaster relief legislation that
will cover farmers and ranchers hurt by a variety of weather-related problems.

Lucas, R-Cheyenne, said his bill would cost an estimated $3.6 billion and cover
hurricane related damage in Southern states, as well as losses caused by
wildfires and the lack of rain for winter wheat production.

"It would address Mother Nature's disasters," said Lucas, whose sprawling
district covers many of the state's farming areas.

The Senate approved more than $4 billion in aid to farmers and ranchers as part
of an emergency spending bill covering war needs and hurricane relief. However,
the Senate bill is about $14 billion more than the White House requested, and
the president has vowed to veto any emergency spending legislation that tops his
request.

Fuel cost aid at risk

Lucas said the Senate aid for agriculture producers -- which includes a 30
percent boost in the annual marketing transition payments for qualifying farmers
-- is vulnerable because of the president's threat.

He said the Senate boost in the annual payments for farmers was intended to
offset rising fuel costs, but that it would likely be a tough sell to Congress
that one industry needs help with a problem facing many other large industries.

Sen. Conrad Burns, a Montana Republican who included the agriculture aid in the
Senate bill, said recently, "We can't ignore the impact this is having on
agriculture. Every time we go to the pumps these days, we see what happens when
America becomes dependent on foreign oil. I don't want to see a day when we have
ignored agriculture to the point that we are also dependent on foreign food."

Lucas, a high-ranking member of the House Agriculture Committee, said his
proposal would allow farmers to get aid for a 2005 or a 2006 disaster. In
Oklahoma, he said, there would be people who qualify for help because of
wildfire destruction but that the "biggest single loss" in the state has been to
the winter wheat crop.

"It just didn't rain enough at the right time," he said, adding that the crop
was a total loss for many farmers.

He acknowledged his legislation may be tough to push through in tightening
budget times.

"It's a lot of money," he said. "But when you look at the magnitude of winter
wheat crop losses, hurricane damage and drought, it's been a hard year for
production agriculture."

                              89 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            October 4, 1994, Tuesday

Feds to cull farmers who cheat Abused aid agency gets tougher after false
disaster claims

BYLINE: By Jingle Davis STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section C; Page 4

LENGTH: 494 words


Steps are being taken to weed out farmers who attempt to collect federal aid for
crop disasters that never occurred, according to the Mitchell County farmer who
chairs a statewide federal agriculture committee.

James Lee Adams, chairman of the Agriculture Conservation and Stabilization
Committee, said farmers will have to do more than fill in the blanks on forms in
order to receive federal disaster aid in the future.

"I think you will see a lot stronger enforcement of the existing regulations,
and farmers will have to document their losses better," he said. "There won't be
any more of this waiting six to 18 months to report crop losses."

Farmers also will be ordered to repay funds that were improperly received, he
added.

Investigators have uncovered widespread instances of fraud and mismanagement in
a federal farm aid program, according to new reports from the federal
Agriculture Department and a U.S. Senate committee. The program has provided
billions of dollars to farmers who suffered crop losses in disasters such as the
Midwest floods in 1993 and Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

Almost $ 2 million of the bogus aid claims came from a handful of South Georgia
farmers who grow squash and other vegetables in Colquitt, Mitchell, Sumter,
Thomas and Ware counties.

Employees fired in 2 counties

In at least two of the counties, the directors and other employees of ACSC
offices who assisted farmers in applying for the federal aid have been fired as
a result of the ongoing investigation.

Ron Lanier, former executive director of the Mitchell County ACSC office, said
he will appeal his dismissal, claiming he was "unfairly targeted" by federal
investigators.

Lanier claims he was directed by superiors to pay more than $ 1 million in
disaster aid claims for crops allegedly lost between 1988 and 1990.

A federal grand jury in Macon recently joined the investigation into aid paid to
Georgia growers, Adams said.

Some farmers "planted and planned" to defraud the government by deliberately
overstating crop losses, planting seeds they knew would not germinate or simply
allowing crops to rot in the fields when market prices dropped, according to
Adams.

"There were some farmers who made honest mistakes in reporting their losses, and
some cases where farmers facing financial ruin overreached," he said. "But there
were cases where well-off farmers got greedy and you can't justify that at all."

More crop disaster claims are expected from Georgia farmers this year because of
devastating flooding that struck the state in July. Drenching rains which swept
across South Georgia this weekend also drowned fields where cotton and other
crops were ready for harvesting.

Although results of the federal investigation recently have been made public,
Adams said he and other farmers have suspected for several years that a few
growers were claiming aid they did not deserve.

"In small agricultural towns, there are no secrets," he said.

                              Journal of Commerce

                           September 27, 1996, Friday

US CUTBACKS FOR AID PROGRAM GO AGAINST TEXAS PORTS' GRAIN

BYLINE: KEVIN G. HALL; JOURNAL OF COMMERCE STAFF

SECTION: TRANSPORTATION, Pg. 12B

LENGTH: 557 words

DATELINE: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas


Cuts in money available for humanitarian shipments of grain, whether due to
peace breaking out or Republican budget slashers in Congress, mean less business
for Texas ports.

Over the past two years, the U.S. Agriculture Department's Food for Peace
program has seen a sharp tumble, falling from a high over the last five years of
246,470 110-pound bags in 1994 to 97,740 bags projected for this fiscal year -
which ends Sept. 30.

PROGRAM'S TONNAGE OFF

Tonnage in the Food for Peace program - a program that provides important
revenue for private and public terminals along the Gulf of Mexico - also fell
this year. It went from a five-year high last year of 809,114 metric tons to
499,858 metric tons with a week to go in the current fiscal year.

The USDA's Kansas City, Mo., commodities office, responsible for humanitarian
relief exports, said that, while the Food for Peace program has declined, total
levels of grain aid have not fallen sharply. The Kansas City office this year
has arranged emergency aid shipments to Russia and North Korea, said Donna
Testerman, division chief of the export operations division.

But less Food for Peace aid is translating to less cargo on Texas docks.

''It's been cut back along with other cutbacks in federal programs so we're not
doing a lot of the humanitarian aid that we used to do,'' said John P. LaRue,
executive director of the Port of Corpus Christi.

BUSINESS NOT PROFITABLE

In Corpus Christi, Uncle Sam's increased frugality in grain donations has meant
that bulk grain shipments have dropped off from 300,000 metric tons of bagged
grain in 1994 to 120,000 tons last year to an expected 50,000 tons this year.

''Next year it will be 20,000, I guess. It's not a business we see our future
in,'' Mr. LaRue said. ''And the pricing on it got so ridiculously low. There
were so many people competing for a smaller and smaller market that some people
were bidding on it at almost no profit.''

In Texas, tough competition and union issues also have changed the playing
field. Pricing wars and labor problems contributed to the closure this year of a
private terminal in Galveston. It went bust in a roughly one-year period and its
equipment is now on the auction blocks. The Port of Houston's Jacinto Port
terminal has gobbled up the majority of government grain exports, partly because
of the lower costs as a nonunion operation.

'A PHILOSOPHICAL CHANGE'

With Galveston out of the running and Houston logging most of the grain bagging
operations, Corpus Christi has opted to focus more on bulk grain shipments in
general, Mr. LaRue said. Through August, grain tonnage was at 515,708 metric
tons - a healthy 17 percent increase over the same six months last year.

''We made a philosophical change and went back to more of a bulk export
operation, and we've been successful on that,'' Mr. LaRue said. ''Even though
the local crop was probably the worst in a long time, our elevator tonnage is
way up.''

The shifting away from bagging was a move that needed to be done immediately, he
said.

''We realized that if we kept going the way we were - trying to get bagging when
the market wasn't there - that just wasn't going to work,'' the port chief said.
''We were losing so much money we would have been out of the elevator business
by the end of this year.''

LOAD-DATE: December 13, 1996

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      OCTOBER 7, 1999 Thursday SF EDITION

2 SENATORS: REGION IS HURT ON FARM AID

BYLINE: Chris Mondics, INQUIRER WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A29

LENGTH: 553 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Sens. Rick Santorum (R., Pa.) and Robert G. Torricelli (D., N.J.) charged
yesterday that an $8 billion agriculture appropriations bill before Congress
badly shortchanges the mid-Atlantic region, providing too little assistance for
farmers hurt by the summer drought and Hurricane Floyd's flooding.

Santorum described the attitude of other regions' lawmakers as "oink, oink, we
want more for us."

He and Torricelli blamed lawmakers from the South and Midwest, who dominate the
agriculture committees of the House and the Senate, for targeting a
disproportionately higher share of agriculture aid to those regions.

"We are constantly fighting to have some sort of balance in this Congress, but
as long as I can remember, agriculture policy has been written primarily for the
Southeast and the Midwest," Santorum said at a Capitol Hill news conference with
Torricelli. "This bill is more pork for the Southeast and the Midwest but
provides only a bone for the mid-Atlantic and the Northeast. That's not
acceptable.

"We have a serious problem here and the response that we get is 'oink, oink, we
want more for us,' " Santorum added.

Torricelli and Santorum said they still hoped to persuade Senate leaders to
agree to amendments that would take care of the mid-Atlantic region. But they
threatened to try a filibuster if Senate leaders declined to send the bill back
to committee for amendments.

If the bill passes, they said, they would urge President Clinton to veto it. A
Senate vote on the farm aid measure is expected by next week.

Yesterday, Torricelli also released a letter he had written to Clinton
contending that many families could be forced off their farms without additional
federal aid.

"While most attention has been focused on the Midwest and Southeast regions of
our nation, farmers from the mid-Atlantic region and northeast states are facing
as dire a situation as their counterparts in the farm belt," Torricelli wrote.
"Rainfall across the region reached record lows, and data indicates that
millions of acres on thousands of farms sustained crop damage ranging from 30
percent to 100 percent."

The measure that the two senators criticized is a House-Senate conference bill
calling for $8 billion in aid to farmers nationwide, the bulk of it aimed at
price supports for farmers in the South and Midwest for peanut, sugar and
tobacco crops, among others.

A total of $1.2 billion is set aside for grants to farmers around the country
who suffered crop loss due to flooding, drought, or other natural disasters.
Torricelli contended that was far too little, noting that Secretary of
Agriculture Dan Glickman had estimated crop losses in the Northeast and
mid-Atlantic region alone at $2 billion.

"Natural disasters have inflicted as much damage to farms in the Northeast as
the drop in the commodities market has inflicted on Midwestern farms that are
getting the lion's share of the aid," Torricelli said. "New Jersey has always
been supportive of other states in need. We expect to receive the same
consideration in return."

Senate leaders had originally scheduled a vote on the bill for yesterday but
postponed action. Torricelli and Santorum said they wanted to try to persuade
the leaders to send the bill back to the conference committee for amendments.

Michigan: Departmental Analyst 9-P11 7901-14-AID-007

LENGTH: 269  words

DATELINE: Lansing


Department of Civil Services Commission, The State of Michigan has issued the
following job announcement:

7901-14-AID-007
Job Title:  Departmental Analyst 9-P11
Closing Date/Time:  Mon. 05/26/14 11:59 PM Eastern Time
Salary:  $17.98 - $29.26 hourly
Job Type:  Permanent Full Time
Bargaining Unit:  NON-EXCLUSIVE REPRESENTED EMPLOYEE (NERE)
Location:  Lansing, Michigan
Department:  Agriculture and Rural Development
The Animal Industry Division (AID) of the Michigan Department of Agriculture and
Rural Development is committed to protecting animal health in order to safeguard
animal agriculture, the food supply, public health, and animal well-being. The
purpose of this position is to be the professional resource for assessing,
planning, process improvement and implementing various division program projects
and services including but not limited to project management within the Business
Office in AID.  This position is responsible for assisting management in the
development and implementation of Division technology projects and providing
input on program planning and policy development in order to assist AID
management and representing the Division at meetings.

equivalent to the intermediate (10) level in state service

                              93 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD)

                           December 16, 2008 Tuesday

The Daily Record News Briefs: December 16, 2008

BYLINE: Daily Record Staff and Wire Reports

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1128  words


Celsion, Tokyo firm ink deal

Celsion Corp., of Columbia, a biotechnology company dedicated to the development
and commercialization of heat-activated treatment systems for cancer, announced
the execution of definitive agreements with Yakult Honsha Co. Ltd., of Tokyo, a
pharmaceutical, food, beverage and cosmetics company, involving
commercialization of Celsion's proprietary ThermoDox drug delivery platform to
the Japanese market. Under the agreements, Yakult will pay Celsion an immediate
$2.5 million, followed by an $18 million payment upon approval by Japanese
authorities of ThermoDox for the treatment of primary liver cancer. Additional
milestone payments are tied to the achievement of certain levels of sales and
other indications.

Mortgage rates reduced

The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development announced that the
interest rates for Maryland Mortgage Program products have been reduced by 0.75
percent. The rate reductions, covering both 30-year and 40-year amortizing
loans, are effective for loans reserved on or after Dec. 8, 2008. The program
helps first-time, low- and moderate-income home buyers access low-interest loans
from private lenders. The department said the rate reductions do not apply to
either the Lifeline Refinance Mortgage Program or the Homesaver Refinance
Mortgage Program, which the state created to help some homeowners with subprime
or other exotic mortgages avoid foreclosure.

AIDS program gets HUD grant

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development announced a nearly $1.37
million grant to AIDS Interfaith Residential Services Inc., a Baltimore program
that will provide permanent housing and critically needed support to persons
living with HIV/AIDS. AIDS Interfaith will use the grant to undertake its AIDS
Permanent Housing program in the Baltimore metropolitan area, which is designed
to target underserved populations. The program will provide tenant-based rental
assistance to approximately 26 households, in addition to a range of supportive
services focused on medical adherence, income stabilization and growth, and
family support.

Agriculture agency's agenda

The Maryland Department of Agriculture laid out its legislative agenda for the
upcoming General Assembly session. Departmental priorities include bills to
improve the effectiveness of the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation
Foundation; bring the Maryland Seed Law into uniformity with federal
requirements; give veterinary students more hands-on experience under the
supervision of a veterinarian; and repeal the Tobacco Authority, a program that
has not been operational since 2006.

Challenges facing consumers

Context-Based Research Group, a research firm specializing in ethnography - the
study of human cultures - and Carton Donofrio Partners Inc., a full-service
advertising and marketing communications firm, both of Baltimore, released a
report, "Grounding the American Dream: A Cultural Study on the Future of
Consumerism in a Changing Economy. " The study, based on research conducted in
October and November in New York City, Baltimore, Miami, San Antonio and
Lexington, Ky., identifies a five-step process that consumers undergo as they
struggle, cope and rebuild their lives amidst the faltering "American Dream. "
To download the study, go to www.groundedconsumer.com.

GXS' Swiss connection

GXS Inc., of Gaithersburg, which operates one of the world's largest
business-to-business e-commerce services, and Swiss Commercial Capital, of
Zurich, Switzerland, a provider of expertise in the structuring and execution of
cross-border trade finance programs, announced a strategic partnership. GXS
Trading Grid, GXS' global integration services platform, will provide electronic
integration of Swiss Commercial Capital's trade finance platform to facilitate
the exchange of purchase orders, invoices, transportation documents and cash
flow data.

ARINC's ammunition tracker

ARINC Inc., of Annapolis, a provider of communications and information
processing systems for the aviation and transportation industries, and Impeva
Labs Inc., of Mountain View, Calif., said they have been awarded a contract by
the U.S. Army Logistics Innovation Agency to install and demonstrate their
satellite-based Next Generation Wireless Communications tracking, security and
monitoring capability on containerized shipments of arms, ammunition and
explosives. The NGWC capability protects shipments by continuously monitoring
their locations and cargo conditions, and reporting as necessary over a
satellite network from any point on Earth.

RSV study I

The Johns Hopkins Children's Center announced that a research team led by its
scientists figured out why a respiratory syncytial virus vaccine used in 1966 to
inoculate children against the infection instead caused severe respiratory
disease and effectively stopped efforts to make a better one. RSV is the most
common cause of respiratory infections in infants and young children and is the
greatest cause of hospitalization in children less than 24 months of age. The
findings, published online Sunday in Nature Medicine, could restart work on
effective killed-virus vaccines not only for RSV but other respiratory viruses,
researchers said. To date, there is no vaccine against RSV.

RSV study II

Separately, MedImmune Inc., of Gaithersburg, a biotechnology company focused on
developing and manufacturing products to combat infectious disease, autoimmune
disease and cancer, and SDI Health LLC, of Plymouth Meeting, Mass., announced
the publication of a study on the variances of the RSV season among major U.S.
metropolitan areas. The study is published in the December issue of The
Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal.

Nutter takes on Del. work

A community planning firm in Salisbury is working with representatives of West
Rehoboth, Del., to revitalize the area. Nutter Associates will present proposals
for improvements to streets, neighborhoods and infrastructure in January. The
plan will be used to seek grant money. The West Side New Beginnings Coalition
paid Nutter $20,000 for the analysis. Coalition member Doc Roberts said the
community wants a coin-operated laundry, a general store and a restaurant. He
said some residents would love to see a bigger community center, a new
playground and new sidewalks.

Loan risk software unveiled

CMSI Group Inc., of Columbia, a developer of technology for automating credit
operations and mitigating credit risk, unveiled the first of two software
applications and services for assessing the underlying credit-loss risk of a
lender's loan portfolio. CMSI's credit underwriting software, eValuate, has been
tailored to provide lenders with the ability to re-evaluate each loan in their
portfolios based on an existing or updated set of credit policies.

LOAD-DATE: January 2, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                  The Analyst

                                 March 11, 2013

Church Aid Receives 100,000 Packets of Vegetable Seeds

LENGTH: 663 words


Church Aid Inc (CAI), the relief and development department of the New Water in
the Desert Apostolic Pentecostal Church, announced the arrival of a consignment
of 100,000 packets of vegetable seeds into Liberia with a retailed value of half
a Million United States Dollars. The seeds were purchased and shipped by Seeds
Program International based in Charlotte, North Carolina with the assistance of
collaborating partners and cleared with the assistance duty-free privilege from
the Office of the President of Liberia.

The seeds are in 14 varieties to include okra, pepper, collard, cucumber, onion,
eggplant, melon, lettuce, and mustard, amongst others and will be used to
support individual and community gardens to help rebuild personal economies and
boost food security.

With agriculture as the base to potentially resolve unemployment in the country,
Church Aid is calling on all Liberians "to sow seeds to fight hunger". With the
FAO of the United Nations predicting shortfalls in agriculture production due to
the 25% reduction in our production capacity, it behooves all Liberians to turn
to the soil and avert a future epoch of hunger in the country. The civil war
devastated the country and uprooted the farming population. Intermittent
attempts to salvage the agriculture sector are beginning to show some signs of
improvement but much is still desired. The following sub-programs will be
pursued in utilizing the seeds:

General Distribution (GD): To cover distribution to individual farmers and field
organizations through NGOs, Government, etc.

Special Distribution: To cover schools through churches, orphanages, communities
through community agriculture groups, etc. School Gardens: To support school
gardens involving both public and private schools with aim of exposing children
food security initiatives and complementing school feeding basket in schools
where such programs exist.

Seed Programs International has supplied approximately 1 million packets of
vegetable seeds for humanitarian gardening programs in Liberia since 1998.  More
than half a million packets of these seeds have been distributed by Church Aid
Inc.

All the vegetable seed shipped to Liberia is selected for its suitability for
the tropical growing conditions encountered there.  All selections must meet the
appropriate day-length requirements and, when possible, have appropriate heat
and disease tolerance for these growing conditions.  Selections are made by the
Ph.D. horticulturist on staff in consultation with several members of the SPI
Board of Directors who have extensive experience in the international vegetable
seed industry.  Our partners often choose the vegetables to be included in the
seed assortments based on local requirements and cultural preferences.  In the
fourteen years SPI has shipped seed to Liberia we have never received a report
of seed that failed to grow due to adaptation problems.

Church Aid and Seed Programs International seek to ship only seed that meets
commercial vegetable industry standards for germination and purity.  Germination
is tested at least annually by independent certified seed testing laboratories,
and only seed with germination above 80% (usually much higher) is shipped to our
partners.  Each major shipment of seed has undergone germination testing by the
Ministry of Agriculture upon arrival in Liberia, and only one seed lot was found
to fall below their standards in the last 14 years.  Seed packets are sealed in
plastic bags to prevent moisture intrusion, and instructions on seed storage and
handling are included with each shipment.

Church Aid partners do not accept or distribute any seed containing genetically
modified material.  Currently there is only one vegetable available in the
United States with genetically modified material (a summer squash with genes for
disease resistance).  Such seeds are produced only in limited quantities,
require advance orders, and are too expensive for donation for humanitarian
programs.

LOAD-DATE: March 11, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            August 31, 2004 Tuesday
                                  All Editions

Snowe, Collins seek aid for apple growers hurt by winter kill

BYLINE: SHARON KILEY MACK OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. A5

LENGTH: 450 words

DATELINE: PITTSFIELD


Maine's U.S. senators are pressing U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Ann
Veneman for aid for the state's apple growers, some of whom were hard hit by
losses due to winter kill - losses that are affecting this fall's harvest.

Even if aid is available, however, it is hardly going to help, Marilyn Meyerhans
of Fairfield, president of Maine's Pomological Society, said. "It would amount
to only $10 a tree," she said Monday.

The USDA's Farm Service Agency in Maine has estimated that apple growers in the
state could qualify for $400,000 in federal assistance unless the funding
already has been spent elsewhere.

"It appears that all of the funds appropriated for 2004 have already been
allocated to other specific disaster areas," Snowe and Collins said in a
statement. The senators' letter to Veneman asks her to distribute money to
Maine's apple growers if any funds are available.

To qualify for aid, a producer must sustain a 20 percent or higher loss.
Meyerhans said Maine producers are attempting to link with other states to pack
some increased punch into their aid request.

The orchard losses weren't evident until this spring, and although the damage
varied from orchard to orchard, it appears that some apple growers sustained
sizable ruin.

Most Maine orchards plant dwarf or semidwarf varieties, which grow quickly and
yield heavily, but also are susceptible to frigid winters such as the one just
experienced.

"It depended on which way the wind blew," Meyerhans said. Meyerhans and her
husband, Steven Meyerhans, operate orchards in Fairfield and Manchester.

"In one orchard, winter took an entire row while the row next to it was
untouched," she said. "Where the trees were not protected by snow, the cold was
deep and fast this winter."

With more than 3,500 acres under cultivation, apples bring more than $15 million
into the state annually.

Meyerhans said the results of this fall's harvest are just as capricious. "Some
orchards are loaded [with apples], while some have nothing," she noted.

When spring blossoms began falling off trees or when no blossoms appeared at
all, Maine's orchard operators began assessing the toll.

In some places, such as Auburn and Turner, the lack of snow and severe cold
decimated the orchards, while just a few miles north in Newport, Madison and
Etna, no damage was reported.

Peter Wallingford of Auburn estimated he lost 25 percent of his 4,000 apple
trees and 100 percent of his peach trees. Don Ricker of Ricker Orchards in
Turner said this spring that he was counting dead trees by the thousands.

Meyerhans recommends checking with individual orchards before heading out to
pick apples this fall. Pick-your-own operations are listed at
www.maineapples.org.

LOAD-DATE: August 31, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              96 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            October 4, 1994, Tuesday

Feds get tough on farmers after false disaster claims

BYLINE: By Jingle Davis STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section C; Page 3

LENGTH: 212 words


Steps are being taken to weed out farmers who attempt to collect federal aid for
crop disasters that never occurred, according to the Mitchell County farmer who
chairs a statewide federal agriculture committee.

James Lee Adams, chairman of the Agriculture Conservation and Stabilization
Committee, said farmers will have to do more than fill in the blanks on forms in
order to receive federal disaster aid.

"I think you will see a lot stronger enforcement of the existing regulations,
and farmers will have to document their losses better," he said. "There won't be
any more of this waiting six to 18 months to report crop losses."

Farmers also will be ordered to repay funds that were improperly received, he
added.

Investigators have uncovered widespread instances of fraud and mismanagement in
a federal farm aid program, according to new reports from the federal
Agriculture Department and a U.S. Senate committee. The program has provided
billions of dollars to farmers who suffered crop losses in disasters such as the
Midwest floods in 1993 and Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

Almost $ 2 million of the bogus aid claims came from a handful of South Georgia
farmers who grow squash and other vegetables in Colquitt, Mitchell, Sumter,
Thomas and Ware counties.

                              97 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           August 11, 1993, Wednesday

Georgia farmers ready to reap federal drought aid

BYLINE: By Jingle Davis STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section A; Page 3

LENGTH: 370 words


Southern farmers who watched their crops shrivel and die in the long drought
this summer welcomed Tuesday's announcement by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture that federal aid will be forthcoming.

"We're waiting to see what form it will take," said Judi Lewis, who runs a
Bulloch County farm south of Statesboro with her husband, Eddie, and son Brian.
"Even with low-interest loans, it's hard to borrow your way out of debt."

In Georgia, 154 of 159 counties were declared drought disaster areas by U.S.
Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. Only Atkinson, Brantley, Brooks, Clinch and
Ware counties in South Georgia were excluded. Rainfall there was adequate.

Also included in Mr. Espy's declaration were most of North Carolina and all of
South Carolina.

The declaration allows farmers to get reimbursement from the disaster aid bill
now awaiting President Clinton's signature. It includes more than $ 2 billion in
direct payments to cover about half of farmers' losses on each crop damaged by
the drought, Agriculture Department spokesman Steve Kinsella said.

In addition, the bill makes farmers eligible for Farmers Home Administration
loans with an interest rate of 4.5 percent.

However, many farmers say they are already in debt and are reluctant to borrow
more money, even at low interest rates.

Each county included in the disaster declaration lost at least 30 percent of one
crop, said Lisa Ray, spokeswoman for Georgia Agriculture Secretary Tommy Irvin.

"So the damage is really widespread," she said.

Spotty rains have brought some relief to some South Georgia areas in the past
week or so, Ms. Ray said.

Mr. Irvin estimated Georgia's overall losses could top $ 500 million, she said,
with Burke and Washington counties among the hardest hit. Officials estimate
statewide drought losses at $ 264 million in South Carolina and $ 161.5 million
in North Carolina.

Mrs. Lewis said it is too early to tell how large her family's losses will be.

"We know we've lost 60 percent of the corn, but we're still waiting to see if
the peanuts will put on a crop," she said. "We do know we're not going to be
able to pay back our loans this year without help."

The Associated Press contributed to this article.

                              98 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                     June 18, 2001 Monday Michigan Edition

Many apple growers accepting federal aid for first time

BYLINE: By SHANNON McCAFFREY; Associated Press Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. C8

LENGTH: 611 words


WASHINGTON -- Apple growers soon will be receiving something new in the mail:
checks from the federal government.

For decades, while many American farmers relied on federal aid, apple and other
fruit growers traditionally shunned such support. That is changing now, the
result of an increasingly competitive global apple market, stagnant demand and
destructive storms in parts of the country.

"I think it's a disgrace to take government money, but we can't survive any
other way, so I will," said Edwin Wittenbach, a grower in Belding, Mich.

The $100 million in checks that the Department of Agriculture began issuing last
week to apple growers across the nation is designed to compensate them for
market losses. While growers have received disaster aid in the past because of
severe storms or problems with pests, this year's aid is the first to help
compensate for low prices.

"Our industry has fought valiantly to stay away from these subsidies," said
grower George Lamont, of Albion, N.Y.

"But when you don't have money to pay last year's bills and you don't have money
to buy the spray and other things you need to get this year's season going, you
swallow your pride and cash the check."

About 7,500 growers applied for the aid, according to the U.S. Apple
Association. The maximum award for a grower is $31,000.

In the past three years, $14 billion in such market loss aid has gone to corn,
wheat and other grain growers, primarily in the Midwest.

Apple and potato growers are eligible for an additional $38 million to help
cover losses from problems such as last year's brutal storms in New York's
Hudson Valley that left apple crops too bruised for market.

Such apples typically would be sold for juice or for processing, but that market
has been flooded with concentrate imports from Chile, Mexico, South Africa, New
Zealand, Moldova and China. The imports have depressed prices so much that U.S.
growers say it sometimes does not pay for them to harvest their crop.

China, which only entered the apple market recently, has surpassed the United
States as the world's largest apple producer, churning out four times as many.

The Clinton administration last year accused China of dumping apple concentrate
in the United States at prices below production costs. U.S. growers recently
filed a complaint alleging that foreign competitors were skirting U.S. duties by
shipping through Canada.

Michigan annually vies with New York to be the second-ranking state in the
nation in apple production behind perennial leader Washington. The USDA
estimated that Michigan's 2000 harvest was about 19 million bushels, making it
the state's No. 1 fruit crop.

Whether apple growers should become virtually permanent recipients of federal
aid like grain farmers in the Midwest is still unresolved in Congress. Some
growers are uneasy about the federal checks becoming a rite of springtime.

"I'm hoping that this is a bridge to get us through some difficult times and
that's it," said Larry Olsen, a grower in Prosser, Wash.

Still, last week an additional $150 million in market loss aid for apples was
attached to an agriculture spending bill as it moved through the House
Appropriations Committee. In the Senate, $250 million is being sought.

Kraig Naasz, spokesman for the U.S. Apple Association, says more aid is needed
because the situation for growers has not improved.

"The growers have always wanted to keep Uncle Sam at arm's length, but these are
the worst economic times they've seen in years," Naasz said.

The aid now being distributed was approved last year -- a delay that has left
some growers frustrated.


LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
