                              99 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                   October 28, 1998, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

For farmers, food aid is mutual Their income boosted and hungry get relief

BYLINE: Barbara Slavin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 605 words


Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Tuesday that he has received
a request from Russia for "significant" aid because drought
there has caused the worst grain harvest since the drought after
the death of dictator Josef Stalin in 1953.

"It is in our interest to make sure Russians are fed through
this winter," Glickman said.

Fortunately for Russia and a string of hard-pressed countries
from Afghanistan to Yemen, bumper grain harvests in the USA, Australia,
Europe and elsewhere are more than sufficient to meet the need
-- if the food can be sent in time.


In fact, grain is so abundant that Jim Bishop, head of humanitarian
response for Interaction, a coalition of U.S. relief groups, said
he cannot think of a food emergency that cannot be met by current
supplies.

"It's a bright spot in a dark cloud," said Tom Buis of the National
Farmers Union, which represents 300,000 U.S. farmers and ranchers.

In a move motivated as much by a desire to boost sagging U.S.
farm income as by humanitarian concerns, the Agriculture Department
is buying 2.75 tons of surplus wheat to donate overseas.

Though Russia's needs are still undetermined, Russian officials
have expressed concern about food shortages this winter because
of a poor grain harvest and the slumping value of the ruble, which
makes imports more expensive.

Elsewhere, Indonesia, where nearly a third of the people live
on one meal a day, will receive more than half a million tons.
Bangladesh is getting 385,000. North Korea, where perhaps 1 million
have starved from a famine that began three years ago, will get
330,000.

The American generosity is not unprecedented. In the days of government
price supports for agriculture, U.S. silos were awash in grain,
much of it doled out abroad.

Before 1992, the U.S. was giving 2.2 million tons of grain a year
on top of the 6.6 million tons through the Food for Peace program
that began in 1954, said Ellen Levinson, a Washington lawyer and
consultant to aid groups.

Because tight budgets nearly cut that program in half, she said,
the latest infusion of grain merely returns aid to 1993 levels.

Congress has been tight-fisted with conventional foreign aid,
which has shrunk from nearly $ 20 billion a year to $ 12 billion.
But in this election year, it was sensitive to a measure helping
farmers.

The $ 500 billion budget bill Congress passed last week includes
$ 50 million for the Bill Emerson Humanitarian Trust, a revolving
food reserve named for a late Republican congressman from Missouri,
which will hold up to 4.4 million tons of grain.

Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of a Democratic task force on
hunger, said the reserve, which will expand the one created in
1996, will mean that "when we have a problem in the world, we
can react more quickly."

"Common sense tells us that it is time to bring together our
oversupply of domestic agricultural products and the growing international
need for food aid," Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., said earlier on the
Senate floor.

By the end of this fiscal year next September, the Agriculture
Department said, the world will have more than 330 million tons
of surplus grain. Fifty-five million tons will be American, including
26.4 million tons of wheat, twice the surplus the USA had two
years ago. The glut has halved the price of a bushel of wheat
to about $ 2.50.

"There is a mutuality of interest," Glickman said. "The United
States has historically had an interest in feeding hungry people.
I don't think the developed world has responded as aggressively
as it should."

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              100 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   February 28, 1996, Wednesday, ALL EDITIONS

Health Watch;
ON THE PULSE

BYLINE: Ann Hardie, Bill Hendrick

SECTION: HEALTH WATCH; Pg. 03E

LENGTH: 487 words


PREVENTING HIV: Doctors might be able to predict whether an HIV- infected
pregnant woman will pass the AIDS virus to her unborn baby by measuring the
level of an acid produced by the human immunodeficiency virus, according to a
study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA).

Those measurements could help doctors decide whether to prescribe the drug
zidovudine (AZT), shown to greatly reduce the chances of the virus being passed
from mother to baby.

Researchers from the UCLA School of Medicine studied 92 HIV-positive women and
their 97 infants. Forty-two mothers received AZT therapy while they were
pregnant, and during labor or delivery, or both. Eleven infants received AZT six
weeks after delivery.

Of the 20 babies infected with the virus in utero, the mothers were more likely
to have levels of ribonucleic acid (RNA) higher than 50,000 copies per
milliliter of plasma at delivery than mothers who didn't transmit the virus.

Transmission was unlikely at and below 20,000 HIV RNA copies per milliliter of
plasma.

The researchers say that AZT may reduce maternal HIV levels, inhibiting the
virus in blood and secretions during labor and delivery.

-IMPLANT RISKS LOW: Breast implants do not pose a huge risk for
connective-tissue diseases; however, they still pose a risk, according to a new
study in today's JAMA.

Women with implants are 24 percent more likely to report connective- tissue
disease than women who never had implants.

Connective-tissue diseases are associated with abnormal immune system function,
in which the body reacts against its own tissues and organs.

Researchers from Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital in
Boston analyzed questionnaires from 395,543 female health professionals: 10, 830
had breast implants; 11,805 had connective tissue disease between 1962 and 1991.

The researchers concluded that implants pose a "small but significant risk of
any connective tissue disease." An estimated 800,000 American women have breast
implants.

-TV AND AGGRESSION: People who are aggressive will react even more aggressively
after viewing violence on TV or in movies, a study in the American Psychological
Association's Journal of Personality and Social Psychology says.

Iowa State University researchers recruited 420 students, 210 men and 210 women,
who answered questionnaires to determine their aggression levels. People who
tested high in aggression were more likely to choose a violent film to watch
than individuals who scored low.

A second study found that aggressive subjects "felt more angry" after viewing a
violent videotape. And a third study required participants to view either a
violent or nonviolent videotape, after which they competed with an opponent on a
task. The loser received a blast of unpleasant noise; those who watched the
violent tapes gave their foes "significantly louder blasts of noise."

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Chart: Rich in vitamin C
 Worried about getting enough vitamin C, particularly with the season for
 colds in full blow? The recommended daily allowance for vitamin C is 60
 milligrams, but some studies suggest that vitamin C in higher amounts
 wards off or shortens the duration of colds and other viral illnesses.
 The top 10 foods for vitamin C:
 - 1/2 hot chile pepper - 182 milligrams
 -1/2 cantaloupe - 113 milligrams
 -1 cup cranberry juice - 108 milligrams
 -1 cup orange juice - 97 milligrams
 -1/2 cup sweet red pepper - 95 milligrams
-1 cup grapefruit juice - 83 milligrams
 -1 California orange - 80 milligrams
 -1 Florida orange - 68 milligrams
 -1 cup mixed vegetable juice - 67 milligrams
 -1 cup grape juice - 60 milligrams
 Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     August 6, 1988, Saturday, City Edition

Maryland, W. Virginia eligible for drought aid

SECTION: NATIONAL; UPDATE; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 485 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON; FERNANDINA BEACH; ALEXANDRIA, Va.; LOS ANGELES



WASHINGTON - Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng on Friday declared    Maryland
and West Virginia eligible for Farmers Home Administration    emergency loans
because of crop losses caused by drought damage. The    order applied to all 23
counties in Maryland and all 55 counties in    West Virginia if they meet
certain conditions, the Agriculture    Department said in a statement. Six other
states have been declared    eligible for the aid. They are: Alabama, Indiana,
Missouri, Ohio,    Wisconsin and Delaware.



 Judge orders beer can,    rat to UF laboratory

 FERNANDINA BEACH - A judge Friday ordered a Coors can and a    beer-sodden
rodent to a University of Florida laboratory. After    listening to arguments
from attorneys for Adolph Coors Co. and a    Jacksonville man who said he found
the rat in his beer can, Circuit    Judge Peter Dearing issued the order so
Coors officials can try to    learn more about when the rodent died and how it
might have got into    the can. Coors' attorneys and an expert witness assured
the judge that    evidence wouldn't be destroyed.



 8 plead innocent in Libyan    money diversion case

 ALEXANDRIA, Va. - Eight defendants pleaded innocent Friday at their
arraignment on federal charges they plotted to use Libyan government    money to
recruit dissident support in the United States. U.S. District    Judge Claude
Hilton set a trial date of Oct. 17. The defendants include    six Libyans and
two other Arabs named in a 40-count indictment last    week.



 Court says mom who hid      child must remain jailed

 WASHINGTON - A physician who hid her 5-year-old daughter nearly a year    ago
after alleging her ex-husband had sexually abused the child must    remain in
jail. A three-judge panel of the District of Columbia Court    of Appeals on
Friday affirmed Superior Court Judge Herbert B. Dixon's    decision to jail Dr.
Elizabeth Morgan on contempt of court charges for    failing to produce the
child last August. The appeals court also upheld    Dixon's decision allowing
her ex-husband, Dr. Eric Foretich, a two-week    visitation with his daughter,
Hilary. Morgan has been in the Washington    jail since Aug. 28, 1987.



 McDonnell Douglas starts    own procurement probe

 LOS ANGELES - McDonnell Douglas, under scrutiny in the ongoing    Pentagon
bribery probe, has begun an internal investigation of its use    of former
top-level Defense Department officials as procurement    consultants. Chairman
and Chief Executive John F. McDonnell said in a    letter to employees Thursday
the company is confident its policies are    sound, but named a task force to
see if more guidelines were needed.

                               The New York Times

              September 30, 1983, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Drought Aid

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 152 words

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 29


The State Department of Agriculture said today that it would recommend asking
the Federal Government to declare 12 New Jersey counties drought disaster areas.

Pat Quinn, a spokesman for the department, said a lack of rain this summer had
cost farmers $45 million in lost crops.

The spokesman said a final report on crop damage in New Jersey would be
submitted by Agriculture Secretary Arthur R. Brown Jr. ''within the next few
days'' to Governor Kean.

She said Mr. Brown would urge the Governor to send a formal request to the
United States Agriculture Secretary, John R. Block, that the 12 counties be
declared disaster areas.

If the declaration is made, farmers in the counties would be eligible for
long-term, low-interest Federal loans to cover their losses. The counties are
Atlantic, Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, Hunterdon,
Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Salem, Sommerset.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              103 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   October 2, 1991, Wednesday, Final Edition

President Speeds Up Farm Credit Guarantees;
Action Aimed at Soviet Food Shortages

Ann Devroy, Stuart Auerbach, Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A26

LENGTH: 862 words


President Bush accelerated $ 585 million in agricultural credit guarantees to
the Soviet Union yesterday as the administration worked on a larger package of
humanitarian aid that may include donations from government stockpiled food,
officials said.

The action on credit guarantees is the second move in a week by the Bush
administration to speed grain to the Soviet Union to forestall the possibility
of food shortages in Soviet cities this winter. Experts have said that foreign
grain shipments are needed to force Soviet farmers to bring to market crops they
have hoarded in hopes of getting higher prices.

Last week, the administration increased its loan guarantees to 100 percent after
American banks, worried about the creditworthiness of the Soviet Union, were
unwilling to make loans at the old guarantee level of 98 percent. The result was
immediate, Agriculture Department officials reported, as the Soviets were able
to get loans to buy $ 215 million worth of corn, wheat and soybeans in a week.

The new guarantees announced yesterday also will be covered in full, and
agricultural economists predicted they would quickly be picked up by American
banks.

But the amount of U.S. loan guarantees falls far short of what Soviet officials
say they need. Moscow first requested $ 7 billion in food aid, then doubled that
figure. Yesterday, European Community officials in Moscow said Soviet officials
inexplicably reduced their aid request by one-third, to $ 10.2 billion.

The $ 585 million in agricultural guarantees offered by Bush yesterday is the
final segment of a three-part package the president announced earlier this year
that has already brought more than $ 2 billion in loan guarantees to Moscow.
Under the program, the U.S. government underwrites the loans, guaranteeing that
U.S. taxpayers will repay it if Moscow defaults.

The guarantees were not scheduled to be available until February, but Bush
pushed them forward after the aborted coup attempt against Soviet President
Mikhail Gorbachev in August.

"This action will put more American grain and other food into the pipeline now
so that it will arrive at its destination in time to be of assistance during the
hard winter facing the Soviet people," Bush said in a statement.

Bush's announcement came hours before Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan left
Washington for the Soviet Union with a team of public and private sector
agriculture experts. During their eight-day trip, they are to make an assessment
of Soviet food needs and report back to the White House.

Agriculture Department sources said the Madigan mission will be looking at
distribution problems, which many consider the major impediment to making sure
all Soviet citizens have enough to eat, and the possibility of additional credit
lines in the future.

The assessment by the Madigan group is expected to become part of a broader
intergovernmental review being conducted out of the State Department on how much
immediate and long-term food aid and distribution help is actually needed and
what the U.S. contribution should be.

The U.S. aid package is to be coordinated with help from other industrialized
nations. Soviet Foreign Minister Boris Pankin announced at the United Nations
yesterday that a conference would be held Oct. 14 in Moscow to discuss economic
cooperation and assistance for his country.

Pankin said it would be attended by a "highly representative" mission sent by
the Group of Seven industrialized countries and the European Community. Pankin
said the mission would meet with the Inter-Republican Economic Committee headed
by Ivan Silayev.

A senior U.S. official said yesterday that there is no consensus at the State
Department yet on the U.S. role and no recommendations have been sent to Bush.
The official said, however, that a new package that would cost significant
taxpayer dollars is unlikely to emerge until early next year because of
budgetary reasons.

Robert Zoellich, State Department undersecretary for economic affairs, is
expected to testify before Congress today on what officials called "some broad
ideas on the direction" the administration might take. Zoellich has been
spearheading the administration's effort on the aid question.

While some Democrats have been pushing for greater direct aid to the Soviet
Union, Republicans from farm states have been vocal in attempting to persuade
the administration to "donate" stockpiled U.S. commodities and to provide new
funding to send large numbers of American agriculture experts to the Soviet
Union to help improve their system.

According to a senior administration official, the Soviets are expected to
present Madigan with a detailed request when he meets with Gorbachev and with
Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin.

U.S. officials expect to be asked for at least $ 2 billion, but an
administration official said yesterday the Soviet estimates of the country's
needs are exaggerated compared with the administration estimates, and they
anticipate a significant scaling back over the next several weeks "to meet
reality."

Special correspondent Trevor Rowe contributed to this report from the United
Nations.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, EDWARD MADIGAN.

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


                              104 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                   October 28, 1998, Wednesday, FIRST EDITION

For farmers, food aid is mutual Their income boosted and hungry get relief

BYLINE: Barbara Slavin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 613 words


Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Tuesday that he has received
a request for "significant" aid from Russia, where drought has
caused the worst grain harvest since the one it suffered after
the death of dictator Josef Stalin in 1953.

"It is in our interest to make sure Russians are fed through
this winter," Glickman said.

Fortunately for Russia and a string of hard-pressed countries
from Afghanistan to Yemen, bumper grain harvests in the USA, Australia,
Europe and elsewhere are more than sufficient to meet the need
-- if the food can be sent in time.

In fact, grain is so abundant that Jim Bishop, head of humanitarian
response for Interaction, a coalition of U.S. relief groups, says
he cannot think of a food emergency that cannot be met by current
supplies.


"It's a bright spot in a dark cloud," said Tom Buis of the National
Farmers Union, which represents 300,000 U.S. farmers and ranchers.

In a move motivated as much by a desire to boost sagging U.S.
farm income as by humanitarian concerns, the Agriculture Department
is buying 2.5 million metric tons of surplus wheat to donate overseas.

While Russia's needs are still undetermined, Russian officials
have expressed concern about food shortages this winter because
of a poor grain harvest and the slumping value of the ruble, which
makes imports more expensive.

Elsewhere, Indonesia, where nearly a third of the people live
on one meal a day, will receive more than half a million metric
tons. Bangladesh is getting 350,000. North Korea, where perhaps
1 million have starved from a famine that began three years ago,
will get 300,000.

The American generosity is not unprecedented. In the days of government
price supports for agriculture, U.S. silos were awash in grain,
much of it doled out abroad.

"Prior to 1992, we were giving 2 million metric tons of grain
a year, on top of 6 million metric tons" through the "Food for
Peace" program that began in 1954, said Ellen Levinson, a Washington
lawyer and consultant to aid groups.

Because tight budgets nearly cut that program in half, she said,
the latest infusion of grain merely returns aid to 1993 levels.

Congress has been tight-fisted with conventional foreign aid,
which has shrunk from nearly $ 20 billion a year to $ 12 billion.
But in this election year, it was sensitive to a measure helping
farmers.

The $ 500 billion mega-budget bill Congress passed last week includes
$ 50 million for the Bill Emerson Humanitarian Trust, a revolving
food reserve named for a late Republican congressman from Missouri,
which will hold up to 4 million metric tons of grain.

Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of a Democratic task force on
hunger, said the reserve, which will expand one created in 1996,
will mean that "when we have a problem in the world, we can react
more quickly."

"Common sense tells us that it is time to bring together our
oversupply of domestic agricultural products and the growing international
need for food aid," Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., said earlier on the
Senate floor.

By the end of this fiscal year next September, the Agriculture
Department says, the world will have more than 300 million metric
tons of surplus grain. Fifty million metric tons will be American,
including 24 million metric tons of wheat, twice the surplus the
USA had two years ago. The glut has halved the price of a bushel
of wheat to about $ 2.50.

"There is a mutuality of interest," Glickman said. "The United
States has historically had an interest in feeding hungry people.
I don't think the developed world has responded as aggressively
as it should."

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           Alaska Journal of Commerce

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             January 9, 2009 Friday

Demand for Alaska seafood increases in world's food aid programs

BYLINE: Margaret Bauman, Alaska Journal of Commerce, Anchorage

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 788 words


Jan. 9--An increasing hunger for nutritional foods in domestic and international
food aid programs bodes well for Alaska's fishing industry. Annual canned salmon
sales are roughly $6 million to $7 million, and canned herring has recently been
introduced.

"Everyone is looking for higher nutrition," said Bruce Schactler, a Kodiak
salmon and herring fisherman, who is also the food aid coordinator for the
Alaska Seafood Marketing Institute in Juneau. "It's not how much you feed them,
but what you feed them."

More people are looking for higher nutrition, and canned salmon is the only
animal protein on the grocery shelves in food aid programs associated with the
U.S. Department of Agriculture, he said.

In 2008, distribution of Alaska seafood into food aid programs was about equally
divided between domestic and foreign aid programs, he said.

To boost overall sales, Schactler and Kevin Adams, another commercial fisherman
who serves on the ASMI board, will give a demonstration in April at an
international food aid conference hosted by the Foreign Agriculture Service,
within the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

ASMI is also working with Global Food and Nutrition, a private Washington,
D.C.-based firm with global connections that provides networking to potential
buyers.

The demand for canned Alaska pink and chum salmon has the economic bonus of
keeping canned salmon prices up. Prices for Alaska canned salmon, like other
commodities, are affected by supply and demand.

For the past two years, processors of Alaska canned salmon have sold about 1,348
tons -- about 135,000 cases -- through the food aid programs, Schactler said.

That's significant, said Gunnar Knapp, a fisheries economist at the University
of Alaska Anchorage. "If the numbers are correct, this program is taking 5
percent to 10 percent of the pink and chum pack, enough to make a market
difference."

Without the food aid program, the processors would have had another 135,000 cans
of salmon to sell, and typically the only way to sell leftover inventory is to
lower the price. The food aid sales are a good thing for the industry, and
likely have an effect on the price to processors and potentially the fishermen
who harvest the salmon, Knapp said.

The new push for canned herring stands to boost the value of herring sales in
Alaska while helping AIDS victims in Uganda, Schactler said.

People facing critical health issues, like AIDS, react better to antiviral drugs
provided through health aid programs if they have better nutrition, he said.

A 20-ton container filled with canned chum and pink salmon and canned herring
soon will be shipped to Uganda, where medical and food aid workers will watch to
see how it affects the nutritional profile of those who eat it.

"The herring doesn't have quite as much protein as salmon, but it has over
double the omega 3s," Schactler said. "It will be very interesting project."

Fish for this program is a joint effort of ASMI, the state of Alaska, an
unidentified non-governmental organization and four major Alaska seafood
processors.

"Today's food aid clients are tomorrow's commercial clients," Schactler said.
"It is significant. You can look in many, many countries that are today
commercial markets. A few years ago they were food aid markets.

"It is a significant value to the industry, another market they can sell product
into, and you can't have too many markets or too many outlets. The amount of
support that the suppliers in the industry have as a whole for this program
shows that," he said.

Schactler hopes the demonstration projects on canned Alaska herring will prove
as successful as those of canned salmon.

"Canned herring and canned sardines have been used in the world food program for
several years, through donations from other countries." Schactler said. "In
Alaska we have a lot of herring, but the herring fishery in Alaska has been
primarily for the roe. The market for herring roe fell on its face some time ago
and has not recovered. We are going to give the herring fishery another try,
possibly next spring with maybe a larger demonstration program, with several
containers rather than a few thousand pounds. We will see how it grows, and if
there is a market for canned Alaska herring."

Margaret Bauman can be reached at margie.bauman@alaskajournal.com

To see more of the Alaska Journal of Commerce, or to subscribe to the newspaper,
go to http://www.alaskajournal.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Alaska Journal of
Commerce, Anchorage Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                August 18, 2010

Scholarships available for ag students

BYLINE: The Lake Metigoshe Mirror staff

LENGTH: 289  words


The North Dakota Grain Dealers Educational Foundation is taking applications for
financial aid for the 2010-2011 school term. Eight awards of $750 per person are
anticipated. Students must be enrolled in one of the following curriculums:

Bismarck State College: Agriculture Industry & Technology Agriculture Transfer

Dakota College of Bottineau: Agriculture Transfer

Dickinson State University: Agricultural Studies-Business/Marketing or Soil
Science Agriculture Sales and Service: Agribusiness Management or Technology in
Agriculture Agriculture Transfer

NDSU College of Agriculture, Food Systems and Natural Resources Agribusiness:
Management, Agribusiness Marketing or Agribusiness Financing specialization
Agricultural Economics Agricultural Systems Management: Business or Applied
Technology specialization Plant Science-Crop & Weed Science: Weed Science or
Biotechnology specialization Food Science Soil Science

Fort Berthold Community College, New Town: Agribusiness Sales & Service
Agriculture Transfer

North Dakota State College of Science, Wahpeton: Crop Production Sales and
Technology Agriculture Transfer Agriculture Systems Management (NDSU Transfer)

Williston State College: Ag Business Sales and Management Agriculture Transfer
Agronomy Technician

The Foundation was incorporated in 1981 by the North Dakota Grain Dealers
Association. Nearly $164,500 in scholarships and grants have been awarded by the
Foundation.

Major emphasis is on the students interested in careers in the grain marketing
industry.

Scholarship application deadline is September 30, 2010. Applications can be
downloaded from www.ndgda.org or requested by writing the Foundation office at
118 Broadway N, Ste 606, Fargo, ND 58102, or by calling 701-235-4184.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   November 14, 1991, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Grain, soybeans go higher

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 25, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 306 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg, Man.


Persistent ideas that a White House decision on export credits to the Soviet
Union could come soon generated the buying that took Chicago Board of Trade
grain and soybean futures higher yesterday.


The Chicago Tribune yesterday morning reported U.S. President George Bush would
announce US$1.5 billion (C$1.7 billion) in new export credits and US$500 million
in humanitarian aid at a scheduuled talk to the FFA Organization, formerly the
Future Farmers of America, in Kansas City after the close of trade.

A White House official later denied Bush would announce any aid package at the
talk, which in turn limited the advances. Bush in his actual speech also failed
to give specifics on any aid or export credits for the Soviet Union.

CBOT soybeans settled US4 1/4 cents to US10 cents a bushel higher, with featured
January closing at US$5.57 1/2, up US8 1/2 cents.

Corn values at the CBOT finished US1 3/4 cents to US3 1/4 cents higher with most
active March ending at US$2.55 3/4, up US3 cents.


Some support in corn also stemmed from Tuesday's U.S. Agriculture Department
corn crop estimate of 7.486 billion bushels, which was below the average trade
forecast.

CBOT wheat closed US4 3/4 cents to US5 3/4 cents a bushel higher, with featured
March ending at US$3.53 1/2, up US5 3/4 cents. Additional buying interest in the
wheat pit came from expectations China would soon be bidding for 1 million
tonnes tons of subsidized U.S. wheat.

The lack of farmer selling to the prairie elevator system combined with the
advances in CBOT soybeans to push canola futures at the Winnipeg Commodity
Exchange higher.

At the close, WCE canola ranged $2.10 to $3.00 a tonne higher with featured
January ending at $268.80, up $2.90. Strength in canola was also tied to steady
exporter and crusher demand.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            February 4, 2007 Sunday
                                 FIRST EDITION

California farmers to get freeze relief

BYLINE: By Michael Doyle McClatchy Newspapers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 235 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Federal aid is blossoming for California's freeze-damaged San Joaquin Valley
farmers.

The modest first wave accompanies Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns' new
designation of Tulare, Fresno, Kern and Madera counties as disaster areas. This
frees up low-interest farm loans.

The second and third waves could be more robust, coming from Congress and the
White House. It's all being tracked closely by farmers, who still don't know
exactly how much they've lost.

California lawmakers are poised to introduce this week a 16-page freeze relief
package in the House and Senate. As drafted, the bill would authorize more than
$1.3 billion in aid for citrus and other specialty crop farmers hurt in various
natural disasters over the past three years.

Also, dairy farmers in disaster areas could secure up to $230 million in
emergency aid under the draft bill. Ranchers could get up to $80 million, small
businesses could get grants and migrant farm workers could get mortgage
assistance and relief checks.

The money would not be limited to growers living in designated disaster areas.
Agriculture Department rules permit growers in adjacent counties to apply for
disaster aid.

The proposed disaster package also goes beyond the freeze because flooding in
2005, a heat wave in 2006 as well as this year's freeze have all taken their
agricultural toll. This year, state officials peg the statewide freeze damages
at $800 million.

                    Daily Journal of Commerce (Portland, OR)

                           September 24, 2001 Monday

Some prominent Oregonians receiving federal farm subsidies

BYLINE: Rich Riegel

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 879 words


Scottie Pippen's a basketball player, not a farmer, and a well paid one at that.
But he's been getting federal farm subsidies - more than $26,000 last year for
leaving fallow a plot of environmentally sensitive land he owns in Arkansas.

That's in addition to the $13.75 million the NBA star got last year from the
Portland Trail Blazers.

Pippen is among landowners in the United States who have been receiving farm
subsidies under the Conservation Reserve Program, a type of farm aid approved by
Congress and run by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Other prominent farm aid beneficiaries in Oregon include Sen. Gordon Smith, who
is a millionaire, and former Port of Portland director Mike Thorne.

"If it weren't for the farm program payments, there wouldn't be a wheat farm in
Umatilla County that would be able to make it today," said Thorne, who was
taking a break from working his own fields when reached by telephone by The
Associated Press.

In Oregon, 7,244 individuals and 2,085 corporations received aid in 2000,
according to a computer data base of USDA recipients reviewed by The AP. About
$165 million was disbursed.

More than half of that went to 10 percent of recipients, according to the USDA
figures. Nationally, federal subsidies accounted for about 62 percent of
farmers' net profits of about $46.1 billion in 2000.

Environmentalists praise the conservation program for helping improve the
quality of the nation's drinking water and providing habitat for wildlife.

Some criticize the farm aid on a number of counts, such as providing farm
subsidies to people who are wealthy from other sources, and to absentee
landlords.

"That's not the point of American farm policy," said Sarah Fienberg, spokeswoman
for the Environmental Working Group, a Washington, D.C.-based group that
analyzes farm policy.

Fienberg said current payment schemes "help the rich get richer and the big get
bigger and eliminate the family farm."

Nolin Farming Co. based in Pendleton in eastern Oregon was the state's largest
beneficiary, receiving $1.2 million in farm aid in 2000, according to the USDA
figures. Steven Corey, a partner in Nolin Farming, declined to comment on the
subsidies.

The Oregon Farm Bureau says the largest farming operations get most of the money
because they produce most of the food.

The USDA delivers checks under scores of programs, some designed to conserve
land, others to compensate farmers for disaster relief and losses due to
international treaties.

"Nobody wants to get into the business of farming to be on government
subsidies," said Dave Dillon at the state Farm Bureau.

The Depression-era system favors so-called program crops. These include corn,
wheat, oats, barley, cotton, sorghum, soybeans and cotton. Although Oregon's
largest agricultural product is nursery plants, farmers in this business
received almost no federal money.

Wheat - Oregon's seventh most valuable agriculture product, according to state
agricultural statistics - received hefty subsidies. Christmas trees, which are
in eighth place, received nothing.

On Pippen's farm, in rolling hill country about 15 miles south of the rural
community of Beebe in White County, Ark., stands of hardwood are growing
undisturbed under a conservation contract signed in 1991 by the property's
previous owners, according to USDA records.

Pippen bought the non-producing farm in 1993, according to USDA records. His
accountant Steven Lewis, of Wineberg & Lewis PC in Chicago, said it was
purchased as an investment property.

"The money just keeps coming," he said.

The Trail Blazers declined to forward a request for an interview to Pippen. He
could not be reached at listed phone numbers at U.S. residences. The agent who
brokered his most recent basketball contract, Jimmy Sexton, said he is no longer
working for Pippen.

Gordon Smith, the senator, was ranked by Roll Call Magazine last year as the
27th wealthiest member of the U.S Congress. He is the majority owner in Smith
Frozen Foods of Westen, Ore., worth between $5 million and $25 million,
according to financial disclosures. The company processes frozen vegetables and
invests in property.

Last year, Smith Frozen Foods got a boost from the taxpayers in farm aid,
according to USDA records.

Smith's press secretary, Joe Sheffo, said Smith Frozen Foods rents a 600-acre
property to a farmer who alternates between growing wheat, grass seeds and peas.

He said the tenant, and not Smith Frozen Foods, applied for a farm subsidy.

He said Smith Frozen Foods received $7,889 in 2000 from the USDA as the owner of
the property, and the tenant got a separate amount, which Sheffo did not
disclose.

"Smith Frozen Foods does not need these subsidies but it takes them so the
farmer, who does need them, can receive aid," he said.

Mike Thorne, the former director of the Port of Portland, received $185,266 in
farm subsidies for his M & T Thorne wheat farm in the Pendleton area in 2000,
according to the USDA figures. That money came on top of the $262,117 he earned
last year as Port director.

Thorne defended the aid, saying it was necessary to keep his wheat operation in
business because world commodity prices have dropped steeply in the past few
years.

LOAD-DATE: May 26, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Government activity

                                All Rights Reserved


                              110 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 22, 1997, Thursday

Battle against hunger

BYLINE: BY ALAN GERSTEN

SECTION: WORLD TRADE; Pg. 7B

LENGTH: 1123 words


About 800 million people in developing countries around the world suffer chronic
undernourishment, with the greatest unmet food needs in sub-Saharan Africa, the
U.S. Department of Agriculture said.

The reasons range from natural causes and wars in sub-Saharan Africa to
political considerations in the United States and Canada.

Budget cutbacks in North American governments have reduced the aid to this part
of the world and thus provided export opportunities for U.S. firms yet most
companies have limited investment plans for Africa.

About 125 million people, or half the population of the sub-Sahara, suffer from
""some sort of famine,'' said Jamie Wickens, regional food director in Africa
for the World Food Program, an arm of the United Nations.

Speaking by telephone from Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire, Mr. Wickens needed only four
words to explain the reasons for the area's hunger, ""Drought and civil
conflict.

Frequently, North American companies try to fill this export void, but a giant
grain company like Cargill Inc. of Minneapolis only has a $9 million investment
in Africa. Cargill handles coffee trading in Ethiopia, exporting tea in Kenya
and dealing in maize in Tanzania.

Archer Daniels Midland of Decatur, Ill., owns a one-third interest in the
largest cocoa producing company in Cote d'Ivoire, known as Unicao, and another
one-third interest in the country's largest cocoa trading company, known as
Cifca. While the company's investment is limited, the agricultural behemoth
recently added to its board Andrew Young, who has a keen interest in Africa.

In the interim, the region's needs remain unmet. Without enough food aid, the
drought and conflict create poverty, the root of hunger, according to another
U.N. agency, the Food and Agriculture Organization.

IMPROVE ECONOMIES

The answer is for these sub-Saharan countries to improve their economies and get
more foreign exchange, which they can use to import food and then develop their
own agricultural industry. This creates more commercial possibilities for U.S.
agriculture, which relies heavily on exports.

But, once again, many of these developing countries are too poor and
conflict-stricken to improve their economies or worry about anything except
survival.

FIVE-YEAR DROUGHT

Mr. Wickens said, as a continent, Africa has long been suffering from drought.
The last great drought was in 1980 to '85, and others date back to the start of
the 20th century.

To exacerbate the situation, civil conflict infects sub-Saharan Africa. Liberia
has suffered from a long civil war and that conflict also affects the
neighboring countries of Sierra Leone, Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire, which have to
absorb a large refugee population. In Mali, a rebellion affects that country as
well as the neighboring nations of Mauritania, Niger and Burkina Faso.

Angola has had civil conflict affecting 3 million people while other fighting in
the Congo, formally known as Zaire, and Rwanda leaves many dead or hungry.
Another civil war rages in Sudan, and ""Somalia is a total mess,'' Mr. Wickens
said.

To fix the problem, these sub-Saharan countries could increase their own
production, commercially import food or get food aid; otherwise, their per
capita consumption falls further.

Mr. Wickens' organization coordinates food programs from donors such as the
United States and the European Community. The group assesses food needs monthly,
appeals to the donors and distributes the food once it arrives.

But such food aid budgets are declining due to budget cutbacks, principally in
the United States, which supplies the majority of food shipments.

Public Law 480, the United States' main food program, has tumbled to a proposed
$967 million for fiscal 1998, down from $1.2 billion in fiscal 1995. The PL-480
program, which started in 1954, involves three parts - market development,
emergency needs and aid for the poorest countries.

GAO STUDY

After the Republicans took over Congress in 1994, they demanded a study by the
U.S. General Accounting Office about PL-480. In a June 1995 report, the GAO
concluded that the first part of PL-480, market development, was ineffective.

To develop markets, the United States sells food to developing countries at
below market interest rates, with long grace periods and up to 30 years for
repayment. The idea is to create a new market for U.S. agriculture.

None of GAO's studies could ""establish a link between Title I assistance and
the establishment of a long-term commercial market share for U.S. agricultural
products,'' the 1995 report said.

The report identified another problem as cargo preference, which mandates that
U.S.-flag vessels carry at least 75 percent of all U.S. food-aid shipments.

Some American-flag carriers disagreed with that assessment. ""This provides jobs
for Americans and is the basis of cargo preference,'' said Tom Madden, director
of market development for Farrell Lines Inc. in New York. Mr. Madden also said
cargo preference helps preserve the American fleet while providing on-time
container service for these shipments.

CUT FOOD AID

Nevertheless, Alice Rivlin, President Clinton's former budget director, cut
PL-480, taking the most from market development and the least from aid for the
poorest countries. The emergency food needs plan stayed the same. House
Democrats spoke out against the budget cuts, but they were maintained as part of
an overall budget reduction.

Critics of the food aid program contend that just giving food away depresses
local prices and discourages production, doing more harm than good, according to
officials at the USDA, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Whatever the reason, in 1996, food aid to sub-Saharan Africa was short 15
million tons of grain worldwide, and that shortfall is expected to go to 27
million tons of grain by the year 2005. The world's overall grain production is
now 1.7 billion tons.

In Canada, budget considerations also forced cutbacks in aid to sub-Saharan
Africa, said Don Boudria, minister of international cooperation. His agency is
responsible for foreign aid.

Food aid to sub-Saharan Africa now has fallen to C$67.9 million ($48.5 million),
down 34 percent from 1993. Overall, Mr. Boudria's budget dropped 28 percent
during the same time.

RESTRUCTURING FINANCES

""Canada has embarked on a large initiative of restructuring its o wn
finances,'' Mr. Boudria said. The plan is to balance the budget, which had a
C$42 million deficit in fiscal 1994, by fiscal 1998.

""We had to make immediate sacrifices to redress our own finances for the long
term of our country,'' Mr. Boudria said. If Canada can balance its budget, it
hopes to increase its aid to sub-Saharan Africa.

LOAD-DATE: May 22, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo - Rwandan Hutu refugees, weak from hunger and a long walk, sit in
a hospital 25 miles south of Kisangani, Congo. Fighting in Rwanda and Congo, the
area formerly known as Zaire, have contributed to massive hunger in sub- Saharan
Africa. (AFP Photo)

                              111 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               November 21, 1991, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

U.S. Planning $1.5 Billion in Food Aid To Soviet Peoples Through Moscow

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1272 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20


Amid rising concern about possible hunger and civil unrest in the Soviet Union
this winter, the Bush Administration announced today that it would send about
$1.5 billion worth of food aid, most of which would be channeled through the
central Government in Moscow.

The announcement, which followed weeks of delay, included the first large-scale
American shipments of free food to the Soviet Union in seven decades.

The action is part of a broadening Western effort to help the Soviet Union. The
United States has already given $2.5 billion worth of food credits in the last
11 months, almost all of which has been delivered. Japan, the European Community
and individual Western European countries have made separate pledges of aid in
recent months, but so far have delivered very little.

All of these aid efforts are driven by concerns of food shortages and the
possible collapse of new democratic institutions in the Soviet Union this
winter. But these efforts are complicated by weakening economies and growing
government budget deficits across much of the industrialized world, particularly
in the United States.

Farm States Back Aid

The aid package announced today is distinct from discussions in Congress over
whether to use $1 billion from the military budget to help the Soviet Union. The
announcement today is linked only indirectly to negotiations in Moscow
concerning ways to help the Soviet Union with its foreign debt, variously
estimated at $60 billion to $100 billion.

Congressional reaction today was divided on regional rather than party lines,
with legislators from farm states favoring more aid and other legislators
tending to worry that existing aid may already be excessive.

Representative David R. Nagle, an Iowa Democrat on the Agriculture Committee,
said in a telephone interview that the Administration's aid plan today was "too
little, too late" and added, "We haven't given them enough to get through a
couple weeks."

But Representative Charles E. Bennett, the Florida Democrat who is vice chairman
of the Armed Services Committee, criticized the deal for not requiring the
Soviet Union to barter or sell oil or other natural resources in exchange for
food. "The U.S. taxpayer shouldn't have to give a charitable gift if the
Russians have the wherewithal," to buy the grain, Mr. Bennett said in a
telephone interview.

Rationing in St. Petersburg

In another indication of Soviet food shortages, Anatoly Sobchak, the Mayor of
St. Petersburg, announced today that all types of food would be rationed
beginning on Dec. 15 because the city has been receiving only half the food it
needs, Reuters reported from Moscow, citing local journalists. Some American
officials have worried for weeks that urban areas will suffer first from hunger
this winter because farmers are refusing to sell their crops for rapidly
devaluing rubles.

Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan told reporters at the White House today
that the United States would guarantee $1.25 billion worth of commercial bank
loans for the purchase of American grain, and would provide $165 million worth
of free food, mainly through private voluntary organizations.

The Agriculture Department is negotiating with the United Way, CARE, World
Vision Relief and the Seventh-day Adventists to distribute the food, said a
department official who insisted on anonymity.

In addition, a much smaller but still undetermined amount of money will be used
to build a model farm in the St. Petersburg area, construct model wholesale food
markets near Moscow and Kiev, send American agricultural extension workers and
provide credit guarantees for loans to private Soviet-American ventures in
Soviet food processing and distribution, Mr. Madigan said.

Helping U.S. Farmers

The program will help American farmers and "is aimed at alleviating food
shortages and other dire humanitarian consequences in the Soviet Union this
winter," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. Only the food grants
and technical aid projects will result in direct outlays by the Federal
Government, he pointed out.

All of the credit guarantees will go to Vneshekonombank, the Soviet central bank
for foreign trade. But each of the 12 remaining Soviet republics has also
accepted responsibility for the debt's repayment if the central Government or
the other republics are unable to do so, Mr. Madigan said.

A detailed plan has been worked out for the amounts of food each republic will
actually receive, Mr. Madigan added. The plan was intended to reassure
conservatives who have warned that the central Government is not credit worthy
and will use the threat of withholding food as a lever to compel the obedience
from republics.

These arrangements did not initially satisfy some conservative critics.

"This appears to be a thinly disguised scheme to continue U.S. taxpayer loan
guarantees to a discredited Moscow center that is totally uncredit-worthy," said
Roger W. Robinson Jr., who was the National Security Council's senior director
for international economic affairs from 1982 to 1985.

Issue of Credit Worthiness

Federal law bars agricultural loan guarantees to countries that are not credit
worthy. Mr. Madigan said that this rule was met by the agreement by the Soviet
central Government, Vneshekonombank and the 12 republics to take responsibility
for repayment.

Some of the credit guarantees will only be available if the Soviet Union makes
payments falling due soon on previous loans already guaranteed, Mr. Madigan
said.

The program announced today by Mr. Madigan calls for $500 million in credit
guarantees to be made available immediately, followed by $250 million aid
packages in February, March and April.

A confidential Agriculture Department study has found that while the Soviet
transportation system may be clogged with deliveries of European food in January
and February, very little grain has been committed for delivery in December.

Grain Shipment Scheduled

The last grain from the most recent American assistance program, $1.5 billion in
credit guarantees granted in June, is scheduled for shipment at the beginning of
next month. If a new aid package had not been approved this week, some of this
transportation capacity might have been wasted.

Franklyn D. Holzman, professor emeritus of economics at Tufts University, said
the Soviet Union had paid a small percentage of the cost of the food it received
from the United States during World War II. The announcement today represents
the first time that the United States Government has given free food to the
Soviet Union since Herbert Hoover oversaw a $20 million program right after
World War I, Mr. Holzman said.

The bread lines and panic buying of food in the Soviet Union are the result of
both production and distribution problems there, American officials say.

Grain Production Drops

The Agriculture Secretary said for the first time in Congressional testimony on
Oct. 30 that while food distribution in the Soviet Union is a serious problem, a
decline in grain production this year has also become a crucial factor in a
substantial Soviet need for food imports this winter.

Nearly two weeks later, on Nov. 12, the Agriculture Department reduced its
estimate of this year's Soviet grain harvest to just 175 million metric tons.
Last month the department estimated a crop of 185 million metric tons, and in
August and September the prediction was 190 million metric tons.

Soviet crops in recent years have been close to 200 million metric tons, while
last year's near-record crop totaled 235 million metric tons.


LOAD-DATE: November 21, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              112 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                      May 11, 1993, Tuesday, Final Edition

Senator Puts Potato Aid on Front Burner at USDA

Al Kamen, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A8

LENGTH: 342 words


To some it may seem like small potatoes, but to Sen. William S. Cohen (R-Maine)
it's the big enchilada.

To Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, with not one confirmed deputy in the
110,000-employee department, it's the key stumbling block in his effort to end
his solitary status.

It is Washington at work: A senator bludgeoning the bureaucracy to get something
for his constituents.

In this case, Maine's potato farmers lost an estimated $ 75 million last year --
well over half of average annual sales -- because of bad weather. In northern
Maine, the loss amounted to 25 percent of the economy.

Cohen was concerned the department had not been forthcoming with aid from a crop
disaster assistance program. So he put a hold on the nominations of five senior
USDA officials after their confirmation hearings before the Senate Agriculture
Committee on April 28.

"The aid has been slow in coming," said Kathryn Gest, Cohen's press secretary,
so the holds were imposed "in order to make the point that this was necessary."

The move got attention from the department, which last week made some aid
available. It comes to "about $ 20 million," Gest said. "The question now is to
make sure they [farmers] are going to get the kinds of aid promised. Once he's
[Cohen's] satisfied, he will lift the hold."

That may not come immediately. "There's a lot of space between $ 20 million and
$ 75 million," Gest said.

The question for USDA officials is whether Maine farmers have been treated
fairly compared to other farmers who have had losses from natural disasters or
bad weather. With a new administration, this takes a while to determine.

"We are treating Maine producers the same as we would treat producers anywhere
else in America," said USDA press secretary Steve Kinsella. "We are continuing
to work on the issue of aid to Maine potato producers. In fact, around Easter, a
team of USDA disaster experts went to Maine to see the disaster first hand and
to make an assessment as to what type of assistance could be made available."

                           The Ledger (Lakeland, FL)

                          September 23, 2004, Thursday

BUSHES AGREE ON FLA. AG AID; WHITE HOUSE DID NOT SEEK EXTRA MONEY FOR
AGRICULTURE IN A STORM-RELIEF REQUEST.

BYLINE: CORY REISS Ledger Washington Bureau

SECTION: Business; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 536 words


WASHINGTON -- Florida Gov. Jeb Bush rounded Capitol Hill on Wednesday to press
Congress for more disaster relief from hurricanes Frances and Ivan, but he said
he was not worried about the ability of existing federal programs to aid
Florida's agricultural sectors.

Bush said he wasn't disappointed that the White House did not include extra
money for agriculture in a

$ 3.1 billion aid request after Frances. Agriculture also wasn't in an earlier

$ 2 billion package after Hurricane Charley. Bush backed up his brother, the
president.

"Our expectation is the federal response to that will come through the existing
programs," Bush told reporters after a meeting with Rep. Adam Putnam, R-Bartow,
and members of Florida's nursery industry.

Agricultural losses from hurricanes Charley and Frances have been estimated at $
2.1 billion and the figure has not been updated since Hurricane Ivan hit last
week. The damage has prompted calls from both sides of the aisle for emergency
funding.

President Bush is under pressure in an election year to respond generously to a
disaster, especially in a pivotal state like Florida. But he also is mindful of
mounting deficits and budget constraints. Bush has left agriculture aid to
current disaster programs in the U.S. Department of Agriculture, but some
lawmakers fear the agency doesn't have enough money to cope with the aftermath
of three hurricanes.

Some Republican lawmakers Wednesday seemed to back up the president's approach
while backing away from some earlier statements of dire need.

Rep. Clay Shaw, a Republican from Fort Lauderdale, was among 20 Florida House
members from both parties who wrote President Bush after Frances urging him to
ask for money specifically for agriculture in his emergency request. That $ 3.1
billion package, which has not yet been passed, followed an earlier $ 2 billion
bill that Congress approved after Hurricane Charley. A third measure is likely
in response to Ivan. So far, none has earmarked money for agriculture losses.

Sens. Bill Nelson and Bob Graham, both Florida Democrats, are fighting to ensure
Florida will get $ 1 billion in emergency funding dedicated to fruits,
vegetables and ornamental plant growers. Asked if he does not support that
effort, Gov. Bush said "I'm for anything that's reasonable."

In their letter, the House members expressed support for the efforts of Nelson
and Graham, although they didn't put a price tag on their own agriculture
request.

Asked Wednesday if he agreed with Gov. Bush that an aid package for Florida
growers is not necessary, Shaw said he didn't have enough information about the
status of the USDA program to say. "I certainly don't disagree with the
governor," he said.

The governor estimated that Florida's share in statewide disaster relief and
recovery could top $ 1 billion. He mentioned beach nourishment, housing and road
reconstruction as important areas needing federal attention.

Gov. Bush reiterated he was confident in the USDA program, especially with an
additional $ 300 million for Florida crops that recently was included in a $ 2.9
billion agriculture package aimed mainly at drought-stricken states that the
Senate has passed.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

                August 11, 1999, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

U.S. to Investigate A Complaint of Bias

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 178 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10


The Agriculture Department is investigating complaints by black farmers that
they were improperly denied disaster assistance in Arkansas and Georgia this
year, even as the department was settling a multimillion-dollar civil rights
lawsuit.

The complaints involve three county offices of the department's Farm Service
Agency, one in Arkansas and two in Georgia.

Rosalind Gray, director of the Agriculture Department's civil rights office,
said it would take appropriate action when the investigations were completed.

The cases in Arkansas and Georgia were among a number of complaints of racial
discrimination that the department received in distributing the disaster aid.
But many of those bringing the complaints declined to cooperate with
investigators, Ms. Gray said.

The agency distributed $2 billion in disaster aid this summer for
weather-related losses that farmers had suffered in 1998 and previous years.
Congress is likely to provide additional money for losses this year.

Ms. Gray provided no details about the cases in Arkansas and Georgia.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 11, 2012 Friday

Farmers markets get U.S. aid to accept food-benefit cards

BYLINE: Kate Giammarise, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 418 words


May 11--The U.S. Department of Agriculture is making available $4 million
nationwide -- $161,359 in Ohio -- to expand the number of farmers markets that
accept food-stamp benefits.

The United States has a total of about 7,100 farmers markets, according to the
U.S. Department of Agriculture; about 1,500 of them accept food stamps under the
federal program, the official name of which is SNAP, for Supplemental Nutrition
Assistance Program.

The $4 million could boost that number by about 4,000 markets, Kathleen
Merrigan. deputy secretary of agriculture, said.

More than 50 markets in Ohio accept the assistance, according to the Ohio
Department of Job and Family Services.

Among the obstacles markets face: the cost of installing and maintaining a
machine that accepts the electronic food-aid cards and the perception that such
markets are only for wealthy shoppers, Ms. Merrigan said.

In 2006, the Toledo Farmers' Market introduced a way for shoppers to use
electronic food stamps at the market.

The pilot program was hailed as a first in the state and a way to give
low-income shoppers access to fresh and inexpensive local produce.

The amount of money that food-stamp shoppers have spent at the Toledo Farmers
Market has climbed steadily, from about $1,500 in 2007 to more than $50,000 in
2011.

That includes additional incentive funds to encourage low-income shoppers.

The market offers a program to food-stamp consumers called "double-up bucks"
that doubles shoppers' purchasing power up to $20 per market visit for local
produce.

The program has been very successful, said Dan Madigan, the market's executive
director.

He estimated it brought in about 1,000 new food stamp customers last year; it
kicks off for this year in June.

In 2011, an average of 1.7 million people in Ohio received food assistance
monthly.

Of the 265 Ohio farmers markets that the Agriculture Department's Agricultural
Marketing Service has registered, 209 of them are not SNAP-authorized.

"We're looking to expand [the program] everywhere" to include both urban and
rural areas, said Ben Johnson, a spokesman for the state Department of Job and
Family Services.

He said the state would like to use the available funds to purchase wireless
devices that markets can use to scan food stamp cards.

A list of Ohio farmers markets that participate in SNAP is available at:
jfs.ohio.gov/ofam/pdf/2011FM- ContactList1.pdf.

___ (c)2012 The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) Visit The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) at
www.toledoblade.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

               September 16, 1998, Wednesday, THREE STAR EDITION

HOUSE VOTE SIGNALS PROMISE OF AID TO FARMERS;
SURPLUS WOULD BE TAPPED TO KEEP THOUSANDS AFLOAT

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A13

LENGTH: 471 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The House signaled strong bipartisan support Tuesday for rescuing farmers from
their worst financial crisis in at least a decade. President Bill Clinton,
meanwhile, warned that "thousands and thousands" of producers could go out of
business without government help.

In a nonbinding procedural move, the House voted 331-66 to use the budget
surplus for farm aid rather than requiring icuts in other government programs.
The administration has endorsed measures totaling $ 7 billion.

The House action ensures that "farmers' financial burdens will be eased by
disaster aid this fall," said Rep. Earl Pomeroy, D-N.D.

Farm income is expected to be down 15 percent nationwide and far more in some
states because of plunging grain prices, drought in the South and crop disease
in the Midwest. Wheat prices are down 30 percent from the average for the last
five years.

"The results are plain to see and painful to watch," Clinton told members of the
National Farmers Union. "Foreclosures and farm auctions are the order of the day
already in many communities."

Clinton defended his support for the 1996 farm law, which was meant to wean
producers from federal programs. But he said there must be a better government
"safety net for hard times."

How much aid Congress will provide this year and in what form are still being
debated. The Senate approved $ 500 million in July, but prices have continued to
fall and the Agriculture Department says that amount will be insufficient.

On Monday, the Senate rejected the administration's plan, the centerpiece of
which is a one-year increase in government loan rates that would trigger $ 5
billion in subsidies.

Republicans agree that the farm economy is in crisis, but they argue that the
Democratic measure could drive prices down further by stimulating excess
production. Several GOP senators are working on proposals for direct payments to
growers instead, and they are also pushing to pass more tax breaks to farmers
and give Clinton fast-track trade negotiating authority.

"What you saw in the Senate was less an objection to the dollar amount than it
was to the notion that we're turning our back on the 1996 farm bill," said Matt
Raymond, a spokesman for Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont.

Democrats said they would force another vote on the measure as early as today.

Farmers told a panel of Democratic lawmakers that the economic crunch was one of
the worst they have ever seen. "People are desperate," said John Kippley, a
farmer in Aberdeen, S.D., who also works as a financial counselor.

His phone rings from 7 a.m. to midnight, he said, and more than 60 producers
have told him that they will lose their farms.

"A whole lot of circumstances got us to this place," said Don Herzog, a hog
producer in Rapelje, Mont. "Not one single thing can change it."

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

             February 10, 2000, Thursday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Canker reaches Manatee; emergency status sought

SOURCE: Sarasota Herald-Tribune; Compiled from Wire Reports

SECTION: CITY & STATE; AROUND THE STATE; Pg. 7B

LENGTH: 666 words

DATELINE: BRADENTON; PORT ST. LUCIE; PALM BEACH



The same strain of citrus canker that has ravaged the South Florida lime
industry now has been found in Manatee County.

Meanwhile, Florida has moved to secure federal aid for lime growers in
Miami-Dade and surrounding counties.

State agricultural officials confirmed that inspectors on Friday found canker on
a grapefruit tree in the Albritton Groves in Duette in northern Manatee County.
The grove is in a 41-square-mile zone that already was under quarantine.

On Wednesday, Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford asked Gov. Jeb Bush to
declare an agricultural emergency in south Miami-Dade County. If endorsed by
federal officials, the declaration would help lime growers qualify for
low-interest loans and other aid authorized by Congress.

At least 1,000 of the 3,000 Miami-Dade acres now devoted to limes have been
affected. Thousands of trees are being bulldozed and burned in an attempt to
protect the rest of Florida's $ 8.5-billion citrus industry.

Blackthorne trial March 6

in alleged murder plot

Allen Blackthorne will stand trial March 6 in San Antonio, Texas, on federal
charges that he arranged the killing of his ex-wife in Sarasota, a judge ruled
Tuesday.

Blackthorne, 44, a wealthy businessman, was indicted in January by federal and
Texas grand juries.

Blackthorne, who is being held without bail, is accused of organizing a
murder-for-hire plot that led to the Nov. 7, 1997, shooting and stabbing death
of Sheila Bellush, a mother of six. Bellush was married to Blackthorne in the
mid-1980s.

U.S. District Judge Ed Prado will preside over the jury trial, which is expected
to last up to three weeks.

"He is looking forward to proving his innocence," David L. Botsford of Austin, a
Blackthorne attorney, said Wednesday.

The federal indictment alleges that Blackthorne crossed state lines to commit
murder for hire and domestic violence. Life in prison or the death penalty are
possible punishments; however, prosecutors have said they probably won't seek
the death penalty.

Two classmates are stuck

with syringe boy found

PORT ST. LUCIE - A sixth-grade boy who jabbed two classmates with a syringe
containing a yellowish-orange substance told authorities he did it for fun.

The 12-year-old has been charged with two counts of felony aggravated battery
and suspended from school pending an expulsion hearing.

The boy told authorities he found the syringe Monday in bushes on the grounds of
Southport Middle School. He put it in his bookbag, then stuck two boys sitting
next to him, St. Lucie County sheriff's spokesman Mark Weinberg said Wednesday.

"He takes the syringe inside and jabs a student in front of him and beside him
through their clothes. He didn't plunge the needle in," Weinberg said. "We asked
him why he did it. He indicated it was just for fun."

Another student grabbed the syringe out of the boy's bookbag and turned it over
to a teacher. It is being tested to determine what the substance was, Weinberg
said. The two boys who were stuck have undergone blood tests, he said.

The boy pleaded innocent at an arraignment in juvenile court, prosecutor
Michelle McMurtry said.

$ 19.2-million home sale

is a record for Palm Beach

PALM BEACH - The price for living in paradise reached a new high when an unnamed
European buyer paid $ 19.2-million for the former Ron Perelman estate.

The beachfront property, which includes a pool and two guest houses on this
island haven for the rich and famous is a "one-of-a-kind house," said Earl
Hollis of Earl A. Hollis Inc., who has participated in the home's sale three
times. It sold on Jan. 27.

Corporate raider Perelman, Revlon's boss, sold the Bermuda-style,
7,872-square-foot house with seven bedrooms and seven baths for $ 11-million to
a Florida corporation in 1995.

The previous record for a home sale in Palm Beach County was set in 1987 when a
couple paid $ 18-million for an estate, according to the county appraiser's
office.

- From Sarasota Herald-Tribune

and wire reports

                       Silver City Sun-News (New Mexico)

                             May 13, 2006 Saturday

Six NM counties will get drought relief aid

BYLINE: Sun-News report

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 280 words


With six New Mexico counties named as part of a disaster area, including Grant,
Catron and Hidalgo, U.S. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., said he expects the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to issue a broad drought disaster designation for most
of the state.

The USDA also included San Juan, McKinley and Cibola in western New Mexico. The
six contiguous counties are eligible for USDA assistance as part of a drought
disaster area designation for 14 of 15 counties in Arizona.

"I expect word soon from the USDA that virtually all agriculture and livestock
operations in New Mexico will fall under a federal drought disaster
designation," Domenici said. "The ramifications of virtually no snowpack and
little precipitation will ripple throughout our state economy. The official
designation I expect for New Mexico will open doors to federal aid that might
help our agriculture producers make it through the year."

Under the designation issued by the USDA, farmers will be eligible to apply for
Farm Service Agency low-interest emergency loans based on the extent of losses,
security available and repayment ability.

"I understand that there is a feeling that existing federal drought assistance
is wanting, but I hope producers will avail themselves of this aid if it can
help them continue operations," Domenici said.

Domenici noted that he will be part of the House-Senate negotiation team that
will debate whether the FY2006 Emergency Supplemental Bill will retain the
nearly $4 billion in agriculture and drought assistance included in the
Senate-passed bill.

The president has issued a veto threat against the supplemental package,
including the drought aid.

                              119 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                           September 10, 2001 Monday

BULK OF FARM AID WENT TO FRACTION OF RECIPIENTS BILLIONS IN SUBSIDIES DOLED TO
BIG FIRMS, RICH OWNERS

SECTION: Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 849 words


Almost two-thirds of the $27 billion in federal farm subsidies distributed last
year went to 10 percent of America's farm owners, including government agencies
and Fortune 500 corporations, a review of Agriculture Department records shows.

Farm-subsidy rules are based on farm acreage, rather than financial need. That
meant taxpayer money flowed to media mogul Ted Turner, pro-basketball star
Scottie Pippen and an heir to the Rockefeller fortune. Some of the wealthiest
members of Congress received aid from farm programs for which they voted.

At least 20 Fortune 500 companies and more than 1,200 universities and
government farms, including state prisons, received checks from federal programs
touted by politicians as a way to prop up needy farmers. Subsidies also went to
real-estate developers and absentee landowners who live in big cities such as
Chicago and New York.

Sen. Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat and chair of the Senate Agriculture Committee,
called such examples an "embarrassment, a black eye that can only undermine
public and taxpayer support for the programs."

A group of Sacramento Valley rice growers reaped the second-largest amount of
farm subsidies last year. But California farmers received $812 million of the
$27 billion doled out to U.S. farms last year, ranking the state 12th, despite
its place as the most productive agricultural state. Iowa, which produces less
than half the bounty of California, received $2.7 billion.

Government aid made up almost half of total farm income nationwide last year,
most of it parceled out through programs aimed at keeping farmers from
bankruptcy when the price they get for crops is not enough to pay their bills.
But recipients don't have to be cash-strapped farmers, or even farmers at all.
The subsidies flow to anyone with a stake in farmland.

An analysis of more than 22 million checks sent out by the Agriculture
Department in fiscal year 2000 shows that 63 percent of the money went to 10
percent of recipients.

In the past three years, with prices for corn, rice and other crops tumbling to
near-record lows, Congress passed a series of bailouts, sending billions of
dollars in extra aid to rescue farmers from mounting debt, foreclosure and
bankruptcy.

Of the 1.6 million farm-aid recipients last year, the average recipient got
about $16,000. About 57,500 recipients got more than $100,000, and at least 154
got more than $1 million. Because recipients can receive payments under several
different names, it is likely there are many more who passed the million-dollar
mark.

Mary Kay Thatcher, a lobbyist for the American Farm Bureau Federation, argues
against limits, saying big farms take bigger risks, log higher expenses and
produce more of the crop.

"It's not like these guys are getting rich from government payments," Thatcher
said. "They've had to have them in order to survive."

Yet among last year's recipients are wealthy people, companies and organizations
that could survive without government aid.

* Former Chase Manhattan Bank chairman David Rockefeller received $146,000 in
subsidies. Employees said the money goes into running the family's 3,000-acre
farm, not into Rockefeller's pocket.

* Agriculture Department records show checks sent to at least 20 Fortune 500
companies, including IBP, Chevron, Archer Daniels Midland and Caterpillar.

"The price-support program is to encourage production of the crops, and we are
just as much a part of that program as anyone else," said Ed Spaulding of
Chevron, which hires tenants to farm some of the oil-bearing land it owns in
central California.

* U.S. Rep. Doug Ose, R-Woodland, a developer ranked 22nd on Roll Call
magazine's list of the richest members of Congress with a net worth of $12.5
million, owns part of two companies that got about $149,000 in rice subsidies.

* Scottie Pippen, whose Portland Trail Blazers contract pays him about $14
million a year, received $26,000 for growing hardwood trees in Arkansas. When
Pippen bought the land in 1993, it already was enrolled in the conservation
program, according to USDA records.

* Ted Turner and his companies collected at least $190,000 in subsidies last
year for ranches he owns in Montana, South Dakota and Florida.

At least $17 million in crop subsidies went to government agencies including
airports, wildlife departments and prisons. Colleges and universities got $6.3
million.

The House Agriculture Committee already has endorsed a package that funnels more
money into the existing system and adds some new subsidies. Critics say it does
not curb payments to mega-farms or the rich. PHOTO: DAVID REICKS -- UNIVERSITY
OF ILLINOIS
The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, which receives more farm aid
than any other college, experiments on these fields.
PHOTO: TOM ROBERTS -- ASSOCIATED PRESS
Farmers gathered in August for a seminar on soybean aphid problems at the
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, which had received $710,000 in
federal farm subsidies in 2000.
