                              Journal of Commerce

                             March 6, 1992, Friday

COMMODITY BRIEFS

BYLINE: From Wire and Staff Reports

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 320 words


BALTICS TO GET US AID

WORTH $ 15 MILLION

WASHINGTON - The Baltic countries will get a total of $ 15 million in U.S. aid
to buy corn, wheat and soybeans, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said
in a statement Thursday.

The USDA said it will provide $ 5 million each in food aid to Lithuania, Latvia
and Estonia under PL480, the U.S. government's long-term low-interest loans
program.

The aid will be in addition to 100,000 metric tons in corn recently donated by
the USDA to each of the three Baltic states.

The aid will be used for "both food and animal feed," Mr. Madigan said in a
statement. However, he did not provide details.

COURT UPHOLDS RULING

STOPPING TIMBER SALES

SAN FRANCISCO - The Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a ruling halting
all future Bureau of Land Management timber sales in western Oregon that would
affect the northern spotted owl, unless the BLM complies with the Endangered
Species Act.

The court agreed Wednesday with a lower court that the BLM's land management
strategy associated with preserving owl habitat "was itself 'agency action'
requiring the BLM to submit the strategy for consultation with the U.S. Fish and
Wildlife Service before allowing any timber sales in those forests."

Environmental groups hailed the decision for the Lane County Audubon Society of
Eugene, Ore., which sued the BLM in 1990 after it adopted a timber management
plan without consulting the Fish and Wildlife Service, which listed the owl as a
threatened species.

MINING ACCIDENTS KILLED

600 S. AFRICANS IN '91

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - More than 600 miners died in South African mines
last year, said Mineral and Energy Affairs Minister George Bartlett.

Gold mine accidents claimed 461 miners, while 42 died in coal mines and the
remaining 101 in other mines, Mr. Bartlett said in response to a question tabled
in Parliament Wednesday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: COMMODITY BRIEFS

                  Copyright 1992 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              144 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    June 27, 1990, Wednesday, Final Edition

Agencies' Spat Blocks Plan for Reducing Coca Crops;
State Dept. Bid to Help Bolivians Grow Soybeans Could Hurt U.S. Farmers,
Agriculture Says

BYLINE: Guy Gugliotta, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A17; THE FEDERAL PAGE

LENGTH: 1073 words


A spat between the Agriculture and State departments has blocked a crop
assistance program that could help wean Bolivian farmers from growing coca, the
raw material used in making cocaine.

The Agriculture Department says the aid could harm the export competitiveness of
U.S. soybeans. The State Department says the program can encourage Bolivian
farmers to grow something besides coca.

The dispute could have important implications in the international drug war.
Bolivian farmers, plagued by a months-long slump in the price of coca leaf, for
the first time are abandoning the crop in large numbers and looking for
alternatives.

In an effort to investigate the matter, a House panel has scheduled hearings
today to discuss the $ 136.7 million U.S. aid program in Bolivia and the
relationship between Bolivian soybeans and the drug war.

"If we've had a calculated policy to prevent the shifting of crops away from
coca because of a few bushels of soybeans, we're making a big mistake," said
Rep. Dan Glickman (D-Kan.), chairman of the House Agriculture subcommittee on
wheat, soybeans and feed grains. "If what was alleged was true, it would be a
classic example of the government working at cross-purposes."

Glickman's office has documented two instances in which the Agriculture
Department and the State Department's Agency for International Development (AID)
clashed over the allotment of aid money destined for Bolivian economic
development.

In both cases, in 1988 and early this year, the Agriculture Department
successfully argued that under U.S. law the aid program could not be used to
encourage production of commodities that might potentially compete with U.S.
exports. Soybeans are an export crop both in the United States and Bolivia.

Controversy over these interchanges surged in early June after a report in the
Washington weekly law newspaper Legal Times said the Agriculture Department had
blocked the Bolivian soybean programs after succumbing to the lobbying efforts
of the 34,000-member American Soybean Association.

Agriculture Department sources said no one in the department hierarchy had
spoken directly about Bolivia with the soybean lobby at any time this year. In a
separate interview, soybean association officials also said they had not
discussed Bolivia with the department.

The Agriculture Department acknowledged, however, that it had opposed and
successfully blocked AID in consultations over two assistance programs to
Bolivia.

The sources noted that blocking such programs is an administrative action that
occurs almost automatically whenever the Agriculture Department judges that aid
might promote products that could compete with U.S. exports. The United States
is expected to export 16.6 million tons of soybeans in fiscal year 1990.

American Soybean Association President James Lee Adams, speaking in a telephone
interview from his Georgia farm, said that although no one in his organization
had directly lobbied the department about Bolivia this year, he and other
association officials had been "going in for quite a few years" to discuss
soybean development projects "not only in Bolivia but in other countries."

Adams said the association regards any soybean producer as a potential
competitor in "the long term." Bolivia, the poorest country in South America,
projects 52,000 tons of soybean exports this year.

"We deny categorically that we're in favor of drugs; that's not the question,"
Adams said. "But, frankly, we don't see how increased soybean production can
decrease coca production."

The State Department agrees that soybeans are not directly replacing coca
cultivation in Bolivia, for most Bolivian coca is grown in the hilly central
Chapare region, an area unsuited to soybeans. Soybeans are grown in sub-tropical
lowlands near the province of Santa Cruz several hundred miles away.

The department argues, however, that soybeans clearly represent an opportunity
for Bolivian farmers who would like to grow something besides coca. "It's true
you can't grow soybeans where you grow coca," U.S. Embassy spokesman Bruce
Wharton said in a telephone interview from La Paz, Bolivia's capital. "But it is
alternative development."

And, as such, soybean cultivation clearly comes under the umbrella "Andean
strategy" adopted by the Bush administration to promote the war against
international cocaine trafficking.

The United States formally endorsed the strategy in the Declaration of Cartagena
signed at a Feb. 15 "drug summit" by President Bush and the presidents of
Bolivia, Peru and Colombia, the three countries where nearly all the world's
coca and cocaine are produced.

The agreement specifically mentions the desirability of "alternative
development," "crop substitution," "broad-based rural development" and promotion
of "non-traditional exports" as alternatives to coca cultivation and processing.

Such plans lay moribund for years, however, because there was no crop or program
that farmers could grow that was as lucrative as coca. Bolivia, with an
estimated 165,000 acres planted with the shrub, is the world's second coca
producer after Peru. U.S. law enforcement officials estimate that the Bolivian
industry is worth $ 550 million to $ 600 million per year.

Since August, however, a crackdown on Colombia's cocaine bosses has put a
continent-wide damper on the business. Colombian entrepreneurs, who purchase
most of the coca leaf in South America, have been forced into hiding, leaving
growers in Bolivia and Peru without a buyer.

Prices of coca leaf in the Chapare began to tumble late last year, and by March
1990 had dropped to $ 7 per hundred pounds. Growers must sell at $ 30 per
hundred pounds to break even. For the first time, "alternative development"
began to look attactive.

The U.S. Embassy's Wharton said prices had come up since the beginning of June
to $ 20-$ 25 per hundred pounds, but growers were still rushing to take
advantage of a voluntary crop substitution program run by the Bolivian
government. Wharton said some 11,250 acres of coca had been plowed under so far
this year, nearly twice as much as in all of 1989.

Both Bolivia and the U.S. Embassy regard the recession in coca leaf sales as a
golden opportunity to put a significant dent in coca cultivation and get large
numbers of coca farmers out of the Chapare and into another line of work.

Soybeans and other forms of "alternative development" are the hook.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

GRAPHIC: ILLUSTRATION, TWP

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1990 The Washington Post


                              145 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             October 1, 2006 Sunday

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 563 words


SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (AP) - The Environmental Working Group, an advocacy group
based in Washington, says South Dakota farmers are "chronically dependent on
disaster aid."

The criticism comes while South Dakota and other Plains states are in the throes
of a drought - and before a possible congressional vote on more aid.

South Dakota ranks third, behind Texas and North Dakota, in total disaster aid
the past 21 years and second in the number of farmers who have gotten disaster
aid in at least 11 of those years, according to the Environmental Working Group.

Bryce Lindskov's family farm and ranch near Isabel has gotten disaster payments
16 of the past 21 years.

"If it weren't for disaster programs, there wouldn't be no towns out here, there
wouldn't be no schools out here, there wouldn't be nothing," he said.

The only alternative to disaster aid might be a faster exodus from rural South
Dakota, said Spencer farmer Calvin Heitzman.

South Dakota farmers have received disaster aid over many years because of
highly variable weather, said Lisa Richardson, executive director of South
Dakota Corn.

"We live where we have severe drought, severe floods, severe winters. You know,
Mother Nature, we have it all," she said.

Heitzman said variable moisture resulted in some 7-bushel-an-acre corn on his
place last year, while other fields yielded 70 bushels.

The Environmental Working Group said the federal government's system of payments
to farmers hit by drought is "dysfunctional."

The group studied U.S. Agriculture Department records on drought aid and other
natural disasters between 1985 and 2005.

Richardson said the Environmental Working Group's criticism actually is part of
a wider attack on the farm safety net. "They truly want to get rid of farm
policy overall," she said.

Environmental Working Group President Ken Cook said the group favors a safety
net and a $6.5 billion aid package now before Congress. But policy makers should
acknowledge the reality of farming on the edge of the Corn Belt instead of just
declaring an "emergency" whenever it's dry, he said.

Cook's group has opposed helping farmers and ranchers, said Russ Levsen,
spokesman for Rep. Stephanie Herseth, D-S.D.

"They don't understand South Dakota, and Stephanie will continue to fight for
our state's farmers and ranchers." Levsen said.

Sen. Tim Johnson, D-S.D., it should be no surprise that repeated droughts have
meant multiple disaster payments. "Nonetheless, I am always prepared to look at
ways to improve disaster aid implementation," he said.

Sen. John Thune said drought aid is needed, especially this year, but added that
he hopes the next farm bill addresses how disaster payments are made.

The farm bill will lay the foundation for farm payments, including disaster
programs.

The new farm legislation should try to help farmers find sources of income that
would wean them off disaster aid, according to Cook. Such aid should be based on
real losses, not on the size of a political constituency, he said.

"We have this ad hoc disaster system that requires building up political
momentum by waiting for disaster elsewhere," he said.

There are some problems with the current payment system, said farmer Mike
Goldammer, of Mitchell.

"You've got people farming 20,000 acres or whatever, and they abuse it.
Everybody knows that. But the middle-of-the-road guy is the one who's getting
his butt kicked," he said.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                            July 30, 1998, Thursday

Disaster aid available for farms hurt by weather

SECTION: HERNANDO TIMES; BRIEFLY; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 195 words



The U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency will offer federal
disaster assistance to eligible family farmers. Losses must have been caused  by
record high temperatures and drought conditions that occurred from May 1
through June 24 and beyond. Emergency loan applications are available at 30407
Commerce Drive, San Antonio, FL. For information, call 588-5211.

Enrichment centers offer

packet for medical data

   The Spring Hill Regional Hospital Enrichment Center, 1244 Mariner Blvd.,
Spring Hill, and the Brooksville Regional Hospital Enrichment Center, 711
Benton Ave., Brooksville, will act as a distribution point for "File of  Life"
packets. The packet lists a resident's medications, medical conditions,
allergies, emergency contacts and other information on a card that is kept in  a
person's wallet or purse. Another card is placed in a magnetic holder  displayed
on the front of the refrigerator door. The goal is to make available
information that might save a life in an emergency. The packets are free at  the
centers. For information, call Spring Hill at 686-4991 or Brooksville at
754-5120.

                              147 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 2, 1986, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. IS SENDING AID TO FARMERS HURT BY DROUGHT

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 923 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1


A multibillion-dollar Federal program to give financial relief to tens of
thousands of farmers in the drought-seared Southern and Middle Atlantic states
was put into action today, a week after the Administration said it could not
legally take such action.

The Agriculture Department announced a program that resembles a package of
relief measures that are quickly advancing in Congress.

Democrats in the Senate, which approved its package today, said they believed
the Administration responded to the farmers' plight only after Congress acted on
legislation of its own. They said the Administration's action would not stop the
Congressional efforts.

Legal Uncertainty Cited

But Agriculture Department officials said they did not act sooner because they
were not certain that the nation's farm law allowed them to do so.

The Government will move surplus stocks of grain from the Middle West to the
East and South, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said. Livestock producers
who have lost pastures and hay crops to the drought will be eligible to buy the
grain, and the Government will pay half the purchase price.

Aides to Mr. Lyng said the cost would run to hundreds of millions of dollars.

Support Payments Accelerated

The Agriculture Department also will make available now, rather than after
harvest, more than $1 billion in income support payments to farmers nationwide
who have signed up for the Government's farm programs. Farmers in the South and
Middle Atlantic regions are expected to receive half the payments, department
analysts said.

The package approved by the Senate today would give drought-afflicted farmers
surplus stocks of Government-owned feed grains, with the Government bearing all
the cost. The Government would also transport Government and donated hay to
livestock producers without charge. The House Agriculture Committee passed a
similar proposal earlier this week.

The flurry of activity over relief plans for stricken farmers came as the
Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist said the drought region had
expanded to 10 states, now including parts of Tennessee and Florida.

Moreover, crops in nearly a dozen other states are being damaged from withering
heat that struck the Mississippi Delta region and several Great Plains states
this week. Since July 1, heat has been blamed for the deaths of 85 people in 15
states.

Mr. Lyng said 189 counties in Alabama, Maryland, North Carolina, South Carolina
and Virginia have been designated agricultural disaster areas. Parts of northern
Florida, southern Pennsylvania and Georgia are also expected to be so
designated.

Mr. Lyng said that a large proportion of the South's peanut, tobacco and cotton
crops were covered under the Government's crop insurance program and that
thousands of farmers would receive financial aid under that program. In some
states, as much as 50 percent of some crops have been lost and insurance
payments could reach $300 million or more, according to Agriculture Department
economists.

'Every American Can Be Proud'

Mr. Lyng praised those who have helped by donating hay and grain. ''Every
American can be proud of how neighbors are assisting neighbors in need,'' Mr.
Lyng said. ''It's a remarkable achievement and one that should warm all of our
hearts.''

In Columbia, S.C., today about 100 people expressed their gratitude for hay and
corn donations at a rally put on by a relief group that is trying to raise money
to buy feed grains.

The Congressional drought-relief measures would provide farmers with surplus
stocks of grain at no cost to feed their cattle, while the Government will
charge farmers half price. Under the Congressional plan, growers of cotton,
peanut, corn and soybeans would also be eligible to receive disaster payments in
the form of surplus crops instead of cash.

The measure is designed to reduce record surpluses and save the Government
millions of dollars each month in storage costs. Reducing the surpluses would
also relieve the downward pressure on commodity prices that has afflicted
American farmers for more than five years.

Cost Estimates Vary

Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Budget
Committee, said on Thursday that the Senate relief program could cost as much as
$1.5 billion. But Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, who is a co-sponsor
of the relief measure, said today that the cost would be $300 million to $600
million.

All cost estimates, however, could soar if the weather does not improve in the
next few days, said Dr. Norton Strommen, the Department of Agriculture's chief
meteorologist. Improvement may be on the way, he said, citing a cold front in
the Plains that could move into the Southeast and bring showers and lower
temperatures. ''It could begin to stabilize or reduce the decline we've seen in
crop conditions over the last four weeks,'' he said.

Senator Sasser criticized the Administration as slow to respond to the farmers'
need. ''The Administration was giving farmers in my state and other states
nothing but rhetoric,'' he said. ''They had the tools to be of assistance to the
drought-stricken areas. Mr. Lyng did not want to use his discretionary authority
to act. Our legislation makes it mandatory that he act.''

Officials of the Agriculture Department said lawyers, program officers and other
specialists had been working on a drought-relief package for several days. ''We
finished yesterday, and we announced today,'' said one official. ''We moved as
fast as we could.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company


                              148 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                            December 17, 2006 Sunday

Editorial | Farm Aid;
Grow less, reap more

SECTION: CURRENTS; Pg. C06

LENGTH: 650 words


Every five years, Congress pays homage to the American farmer. Then it gives
away the farm.

The forum is the farm bill, due for renewal again in 2007. Legislators love the
bill's vote-getting ideals: securing family farms; bolstering rural economies;
ensuring safe food; preserving the land.

Those would be worthy goals - if fulfilled. But current farm policy fails.

What President Franklin Delano Roosevelt envisioned as a temporary boost to
insulate farmers from an occasional bad year has swelled into one of the
nation's budget-busting entitlements. It benefits a privileged few in selected
states.

In the last decade, the federal government paid out more than $172 billion in
farm aid. In 2005 alone, with agricultural profits at a near-record $72 billion,
government provided $25 billion in aid - almost 50 percent more than welfare
families received, according to a Washington Post investigation. In 16 of the
last 17 years, Congress added billions more in drought, flood and storm relief.

Congress guards farmers against low prices, even when prices are high. It
rescues them from disaster, even after subsidizing insurance against crop
failures. It rewards landowners for acres once farmed, regardless of how they're
used today.

Historically, farm bills have been wasteful, discriminatory and protectionist.
In 2007, Congress must do better.

Luckily, a growing coalition of taxpayer, environmental, consumer, rural and
international interest groups has lobbied tirelessly since the bloated 2002 bill
passed. A farm bill shouldn't be just about farmers. The bill should balance
their needs with issues such as food safety, nutrition, community markets,
America's energy future, water and land conservation, and international trade
rules.

Two hopeful signs emerged over the summer. The Bush administration and House of
Representatives defeated a Senate proposal for $4 billion in narrowly focused
farm disaster aid. And Congress rejected a yearlong extension of the 2002 bill,
which would have delayed a richer debate. Perhaps Congress can break habits.

Meanwhile, Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns, former governor of Nebraska, has
been on a nationwide listening tour. He's developing reasonable alternatives to
current policy, which boils down to subsidizing five crops in eight states.

It won't be easy to change America's ways. Farm aid is addictive and exclusive.

Between 2002 and 2005, 93 percent of government subsidies went to wheat, rice,
corn, soybean and cotton producers, according to the Department of Agriculture.
This policy concentrates half of all subsidies into 25 congressional districts,
an unfair national distribution. (None is in Pennsylvania or New Jersey.)

Further, it channels too much money to crops processed into unhealthful foods,
particularly artificial sweeteners and partially hydrogenated oils. Fruits and
vegetables, the largest growing segment of U.S. agriculture and the crops most
associated with disease prevention, receive almost no money.

It's not just the wrong crops, but the wrong farmers getting the most money.

Large commercial farms, which constitute less than one-fifth of the nation's 2.1
million farms, received more than half of all payouts. The chase for more aid
has led to farm consolidation and driven up rural land prices. Far from
preserving the family farm, current policy increases costs for small operators
and deters start-ups.

That's true not only in the United States but also abroad. Subsidies encourage
overproduction. The U.S. surplus is sold on the international market,
undercutting prices and hurting the livelihoods of many of the world's three
billion poor farmers.

U.S. farm policy has strayed far from its intent. No longer a safety net, it
props up big growers at the expense of smaller farms, here and abroad. It drives
up land prices, forces consolidation, degrades the environment, and distorts
prices worldwide. It's time for change.

LOAD-DATE: December 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

SRSO with collaboration of USA Aid distributes seeds and fertilizers

BYLINE:  Gr.Gorar & Abdul Ghaffar Khoso

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1754

LENGTH: 291  words


Sindh Rural Support Program (SRSO) with the collaboration of USA Aid launched a
Sindh Agriculture Recovery Project to provide free sunflower seeds, fertilizer
and cash money to flood affected farmers at the Old Gudh of taluka Bakrani on
Saturday.

Addressing on the occasion, former MNA, Hizbullah Bughio said that the
government has provided relief to flood affectees for past 5 months without any
discrimination.

He said that during the super flood hundred thousand acres of agriculture land
of Larkana district have been affected.

Project Chief, Dr. Haji Khan Kerio said that American people have donated 15
million dollars by USA Aid to facilitate the flood affected marooned people of
Sindh and provided opportunity to small growers and flood affected farmers to
rebuild their agriculture resources and improve economical conditions. He
informed that 2795 people will get benefit from this program while 101150 acre
agriculture land of Sindh will be utilized for cultivation of sunflower crop
including 7000 acre agriculture land of Larkana district.

He further told that SRSO with the collaboration of USA Aid have introduced this
project for 7 districts of Sindh including Larkana, Thatta, Qambar-Shahdadkot,
Sukkur and others in order to improve the economical conditions of flood
victims. Earlier, DPO SRSO Saeed Ahmed Buledi while expressing his views said
that the newly launched project will change the fate of people of flood affected
farmers and it will be beneficial for farming community. On the occasion, Deputy
Chief SARP Nisar Ahmed Pathan, Abdul Hamid Bulo, MPA Ghulam Sarwar Siyal,
District Program Manager, Saeed Ahmed Buledi, EDO Agriculture Tharo Mal, DO
Agriculture Abdul Latif Joyo, Zulfiqar Chajjro and others also addressed.

                               The New York Times

                  March 9, 1999, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Aid to Dairy Farmers May Be $5,000 Each

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 154 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8


Dairy farmers could get up to $5,000 each in Federal assistance under a one-time
program financed with money that Congress set aside in last year's farm bailout,
the Agriculture Department said today.

The department's benchmark price indicator for milk dropped $6 per hundred
pounds on Friday, the steepest monthly decline ever, because of surging
production.

Dairy-state lawmakers earmarked $200 million for milk producers in the $6
billion farm-relief bill that Congress passed last fall. At the time, milk
prices were at record levels, so the Agriculture Department waited for them to
drop before releasing the aid.

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman told the National Farmers Union in
Springfield, Ill., that the payment program would help many of the smaller dairy
farmers survive.

The payments, which will be directed to family-size operations, are limited to
the approximate production of a 150-cow herd.

                                   USA TODAY

                  December 23, 1998, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Distribution dispute tangles relief package for Russia U.S. wants to ensure $885
million worth of food gets to needy

BYLINE: Barbara Slavin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 504 words


An $ 885 million U.S. food aid package to Russia announced with
great fanfare by the Clinton administration Nov. 6 has not been
finalized because of disagreements about how it will be distributed
to the Russian people.

Mindful of problems with past food aid to Russia, officials at
the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Tuesday they are proceeding
cautiously to try to ensure that food gets to those in need and
does not wind up being resold by profiteers.

"This year we're trying to help Russians through a difficult
period but we want a higher level of accounting and accountability,"
said Ellen Levinson, a government relations adviser for the law
firm Cadwalader, Wickersham and Taft and a longtime adviser to
private relief agencies on food aid.


The package includes 1.5 million tons of donated surplus wheat
and another 1.5 million tons of other commodities including rice,
beef and pork. An additional 100,000 tons of food is to be distributed
by private agencies. The European Union last week approved a $ 500
million food aid package.

Russia, whose 1998 grain harvest of 47 million tons is its poorest
in 45 years, appealed for the aid earlier this year. A spiraling
economic crisis has depressed the value of the Russian currency,
the ruble, and increased the price of imports threefold.

But some in Russia have reacted with ambivalence to the foreign
offers. The Russian critics charge that the Western offers are
motivated less by the plight of Russians and more by the sagging
income of Western farmers at a time of record surpluses and to
show political support for the battered Russian government. They
argue that the nation's long-term need is for investment in Russia's
agricultural system.

There is also concern that food will not wind up in the areas
where it is most needed -- in Russia's frozen north and far east
and state-run institutions, such as orphanages, hospitals, prisons
and the military.

"The most insistent need for food is in the army and the prisons,"
said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a frequent visitor to Russia
who traveled there last month. "It's a mixed situation. There
will be some hungry people. Getting our food to those people is
going to be a stretch."

Chris Goldthwait, in charge of foreign sales for the U.S. Department
of Agriculture, said "at least two" staffers from the department's
Foreign Agricultural Service would be devoted to full-time monitoring
of distribution, and others would be added if needed.

Commercial Russian organizations are expected to handle sales
of much of the aid. The proceeds are supposed to be used for pensions
and other welfare needs.

Goldthwait said it will take about a month and a half for food
to arrive in Russia once a final agreement is reached.

Surpluses from previous Russian harvests are expected to tide
Russians over the winter. "Our analysis is that the worst needs
will be late in the spring" before the next harvest is in, Goldthwait
said.

                                US Official News

                            February 23, 2015 Monday

Arizona: Store Owner Sentenced to Prison and Forfeiture of Funds for Federal
Food Program Fraud

LENGTH: 590  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Justice has issued the following news release:


ANCHORAGE, AK--U.S. Attorney Karen L. Loeffler announced today that an Anchorage
store owner was sentenced by U.S. District Court Judge Timothy M. Burgess to 18
months' imprisonment, along with forfeiture of over $42,000 in criminal proceeds
in connection with a United States Department of Agriculture food aid program
fraud scheme which he operated out of his Anchorage store.

In late 2013, Africa and Middle East Market store owner Ayub Yusuf Eprahin, 45,
was charged by the federal grand jury with 15 counts of wire fraud and 11 counts
of U.S. Department of Agriculture Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
(SNAP) food aid fraud in connection with the illegal use of food aid debit
cards. Eprahin, who plead guilty in 2014, to two counts of wire fraud, contested
the overall loss amount of the scheme, claiming it amounted to only $42,000. In
day-long and contentious sentencing hearing, Judge Burgess found that Eprahin
had defrauded the United States Department of Agriculture of more than $335,000
over a period of 19 months. As part of that finding, Judge Burgess imposed a
sentence of 18 months' imprisonment, forfeited to the United States more than
$42,000 in funds seized from Eprahin, and imposed a term of three years of
supervised release.

According to Assistant U.S. Attorney Steve Skrocki, in November, 2012, Eprahin
was the owner of the Africa and Middle East Market and a participant in the
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), formerly known as the "Food
Stamp Program" administered by the United States Department of Agriculture's
Food and Nutritional Service. The program is designed to provide authorized
nutritional foods to low-income families. The federal government pays the full
cost of the SNAP benefits and also shares with the states some of the
administrative costs. Under the SNAP program, authorized recipients are issued a
certain amount of benefits each month, which they may use to purchase eligible
food items. SNAP recipients typically receive their benefits in the form of a
credit on their personal electronic benefit transfer card. The rules of the
program prohibit the purchase of items other than food, and the card benefits
cannot be redeemed for cash. As a participant in the program, Eprahin received
computer issued payments based on unauthorized purchases made by participants
from his store.

As part of the scheme Eprahin permitted non-food items and cash to be redeemed
from participants in the program on a large scale. In so doing, Eprahin
represented to the SNAP program that the benefits were being redeemed to
purchase eligible food items when they in fact were not. Instead, Judge Burgess
found that the cards were being used like ATM cards with amounts being debited
for cash instead of food items required by the program and with some of that
cash being wired overseas. Judge

Burgess noted that Eprahin's actions negatively impacted the community, other
small businesses and the integrity of a government program designed to help and
feed people in need, finding the offense, "very, very serious as hundreds of
thousands were misused by not being provided to those it was supposed to help."

Ms. Loeffler commends the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and United States
Department of Agriculture, Office of Inspector General, who administers the SNAP
program, for their investigation of this case.
In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                               The New York Times

                October 14, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Senate Approves $8.7 Billion for Emergency Aid to Farmers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 772 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13


Driven by low crop prices, bad weather in many parts of the country and arcane
farm-state politics, the Senate gave final legislative approval today to an $8.7
billion package of emergency aid to farmers.

This is the second straight year Congress has spent billions to bail farmers out
of financial trouble, raising doubt about the political practicality of applying
free-market principles to American farmers.

The emergency assistance is part of a $69 billion spending bill to finance
agriculture and food programs in the current fiscal year.

The Senate approved the final version by a vote of 74 to 26. The opponents were
almost all Easterners from both parties who opposed the way it dealt with milk
prices.

The House gave its final approval to the measure on Oct. 1. President Clinton is
expected to sign the measure quickly. The Agriculture Department said checks
should begin going out to farmers within two weeks.

The new fiscal year began on Oct. 1, but the agriculture bill is only the sixth
of 13 spending bills for the Federal departments and agencies to clear Congress.
The President vetoed one of those, the bill for the District of Columbia, so
only four have become law.

The Government has been running on stop-gap legislation that will expire on Oct.
21 and will almost certainly have to be extended to keep Federal offices open
while the politicians work out their differences.

More than half the money in the bill approved today will go for food stamps and
other nutrition programs. Much of the rest is earmarked for uncontested
agriculture and rural development programs.

To get the final version through Congress, several potentially controversial
items were left out by the conferees who reconciled the bills passed by the
House and Senate. One would have allowed food and medicine to be shipped to
Cuba. Another would have prohibited the Food and Drug Administration from
approving abortion drugs like RU-486.

But senators from the East balked when the conferees excluded provisions that
would have blocked a new milk-pricing system favored by the Clinton
Administration and would have allowed the continuation of a special arrangement
that keeps a floor on milk prices in New England. Several other Eastern states
hoped to join the New England compact.

On Tuesday the Senate voted, 79 to 20, to cut off a filibuster by the Easterners
and bring the bill to a vote.

The dairy question led to strange political bedfellows. Liberal Democrats like
Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey voted
alongside conservatives like Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, and
Robert C. Smith, the Republican-turned-independent from New Hampshire.

The emergency assistance itself had no opposition, though many senators argued
that $8.7 billion was inadequate in the face of Midwestern grain prices that are
the lowest in decades and the large crop losses from the drought this summer in
the East, floods in the South and crop disease in the upper Midwest.

Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat who voted for the bill, compared it to
"throwing a leaking life raft to a drowning person."

"It helps a little bit," he added, "but it's not a long-term solution to the
problem."

The consensus in Congress is that additional emergency assistance will be needed
when the farm losses in North Carolina from Hurricane Floyd are tallied.

Farm politics is guided much more by regional interests than partisan ones. But
Democrats used the bill today to renew their attack on the Freedom to Farm Act
of 1996.

The law was one of the central elements of Republican dogma that party leaders
got enacted after they won control of Congress in the 1994 elections. It
abolished most of the Government price-support programs, in place since the
1930's, on the theory that farmers would fare better in an unfettered
marketplace.

Farmers were happy in 1996 and 1997, when commodity prices were high and they
were still entitled to what were called transition payments from Washington. But
when grain prices began to plunge last year, farmers turned to the Government
for help. And the politicians who represent them, regardless of party, obliged.

"The transition turned out to be more difficult than we anticipated," said
Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, a leading Republican supporter of the
Freedom to Farm Act.

The problem, Mr. Grassley said, was not the principle of the law but the fact
that its authors did not anticipate such events as the devaluation of Brazilian
currency and the crash in Asian economies, which had a devastating effect on
American farm exports.

                            Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

                              July 13, 2012 Friday
                                 SOONER EDITION

FEDERAL AID WELCOMED BY DROUGHT-STRICKEN STATES

BYLINE: Alan Bjerga, Bloomberg News

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-9

LENGTH: 439 words


WASHINGTON -- State leaders welcomed a pledge of U.S. aid for the worst drought
in decades, even as the assistance paled in comparison to potential losses and a
forecaster said weather conditions may not improve in some areas until
September.

The Department of Agriculture on Wednesday named 1,016 counties in 26 states as
natural disaster areas, the agency's largest such declaration ever. Substantial
rains that would relieve the worst-hit areas may not arrive for months, said
Accuweather Inc. meteorologist Mike Pigott.

"When you are one of the biggest agricultural-producing states in the nation, a
monumental drought causes enormous losses," said Texas Department of Agriculture
spokesman Bryan Black. "The disaster relief assistance from USDA will help Texas
farmers and ranchers recover from devastating losses."

The federal action makes farmers and ranchers eligible for low-interest loans to
help weather the drought, wildfires and other disasters. The projected cost to
the federal government is about $4 million as loans are ultimately repaid,
according to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.

Still, with a budget-cutting farm policy bill going through Congress, and
prospects for other disaster aid slim, officials say the low-cost loans and
reduced penalties for grazing livestock on land set aside for conservation
announced Wednesday are better than nothing.

Moderate to extreme drought now covers about 53 percent of the Midwest, fueling
price gains that are the biggest this year among the 24 commodities tracked by
the Standard & Poor's GSCI Spot Index. The rallies are boosting costs for
companies from McDonald's and Coca-Cola to Archer Daniels Midland and Smithfield
Foods.

The area covered by the declaration includes most of the Southwest, which has
been affected by wildfires, as well as the Southeast and the southern and
eastern parts of the Corn Belt, mainly Illinois and Indiana. Iowa, the biggest
U.S. producer of the grain, is not included. Corn and soybeans are the two
largest U.S. crops.

The drought, which may be the worst since a 1988 dry spell that caused $78
billion in damages, is "beginning to have an impact on the corn crop in parts of
the Midwest," said Accuweather's Mr. Pigott, whose company is based in State
College, Pa. "The building heat and humidity could affect maturity and eventual
production."

Central Illinois, Indiana and Ohio are expected to remain under severe drought,
which may worsen as July continues. Some areas in the South are experiencing
multi-year droughts, including Texas, where all 254 counties are covered by the
declaration. Texas grows more cotton than any other state.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            May 26, 2010, Wednesday

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P2A

LENGTH: 643 words


Magic Johnson brings HIV testing push to W.Va.

MORGANTOWN - Basketball legend Earvin "Magic" Johnson is bringing his six-month,
48-state campaign to promote testing for HIV to Morgantown.

Free testing for the virus that causes AIDS will be done across from the
Monongalia County Courthouse in Morgantown from 1 to 5 p.m. Thursday. Caritas
House is co-sponsoring the event with the national AIDS Healthcare Foundation.

Johnson's "Testing America'' campaign is aimed at raising awareness of the
importance and ease of testing.

Although the Centers for Disease Control began recommending routine HIV testing
for everyone between 13 and 64 four years ago, it has not been widely
implemented.

The CDC estimates that 1,500 West Virginians are living with HIV or AIDS.

Johnson announced he was HIV-positive in 1991. His current tour ends June 27 in
New York City.

USDA team euthanizing feral ducks in Elkins

ELKINS - The U.S. Department of Agriculture is killing a colony of feral ducks
along the Tygart Valley River.

USDA spokeswoman Carol Bannerman says Elkins homeowners requested that the ducks
be removed, so her agency signed an agreement with them. Crews sedated dozens of
ducks Tuesday, removing them to be euthanized.

But Mayor Duke Talbott isn't happy. He says the city decided earlier this month
to form a citizens committee that would work on solutions. Before they had the
chance, the federal government stepped in.

Resident Missy Anello had long opposed killing the birds and called the
euthanizations a nightmare. She'd collected hundreds of signatures from people
opposed to killing the ducks. Others argued that they were potential heath and
ecological hazards.

DEP set to fine Weirton for raw sewage flow

WEIRTON - The Department of Environmental Protection is planning to fine Weirton
for letting 8 percent of the city's raw sewage flow directly into the Ohio
River.

The amount of the fines hasn't been decided, but attorney Dan Guida said the DEP
told Weirton last week to expect them in a consent order to address the problem.

City officials revealed in March that sewage has gushed from an outfall on the
former Weirton Steel Corp. property for about 50 years.

Luxembourg-based ArcelorMittal now owns the property and says it will cooperate
on a safe and timely solution.

Guida says the DEP told the city the problem is high on its priority list.

The city could face additional fines if it fails to meet DEP benchmarks for
progress laid out in the consent order.

Diocese starts funding push for St. Mary school

WHEELING - The Diocese of Wheeling-Charleston is starting a $1.2 million
fundraising campaign to rehabilitate the century-old St. Mary Central School in
Clarksburg.

Bishop Michael Bransfield says structural issues need to be addressed.

Bransfield says the school is important to the community, and he wants it to
remain open and viable for future generations seeking a Catholic education.

Two parishes have created a $400,000 matching grant fund to help.

Principal Nicole Folio says work will begin this summer, starting with the
replacement of loose bricks around the top of the building. A new roof, windows
and other improvements will follow as money becomes available.

Ex-prison guard pleads guilty to child porn

A former West Virginia corrections officer has pleaded guilty to possessing
child pornography. The U.S. Attorney's Office says Joseph Dwayne Valentine, 40,
faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced Sept. 22. Until then,
Valentine will be supervised under electronic monitoring.

Valentine, who entered his plea Wednesday, worked for the West Virginia Division
of Corrections before an investigation by the Bureau of Immigration and Customs
Enforcement led to his arrest. Authorities say they found hundreds of images of
child porn on Valentine's computer, as well as evidence he had purchased videos
from a website operated out of Latvia.

                              156 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The International Herald Tribune

                             April 23, 2007 Monday

Does U.S. have to grow its food aid in America?;
Amount sent falls as shipping costs rise

BYLINE: Celia W. Dugger - The New York Times Media Group

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 894 words

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Missouri


Waiters in white aprons maneuvered through a noisy cocktail party here, offering
heaping platters of jumbo shrimp, lamb chops and crab-stuffed mushrooms to a
crowd of people in town for an annual food-aid conference dedicated to ending
world hunger.

As shipping and agribusiness executives, charity workers, lobbyists and federal
employees mingled, Charles Worledge, who works for Sealift, a major shipper of
U.S. food to the hungry, offered an insight essential to understanding the
politics of food aid.

''I thought this was a charity,'' he explained during the party, for which
another shipping company played host. ''It's not. It's a business.''

It was here in Kansas City, at the 2005 food-aid conference, that the Bush
administration pushed for a fundamental change in food aid that would have
diminished profits to domestic agribusiness and shipping companies. It proposed
allowing a quarter of the Food for Peace budget to be used to buy food in poor
countries near hunger crises, rather than buying only U.S.-grown food that had
to be shipped across oceans.

Secretary of Agriculture Mike Johanns spoke at the conference Wednesday to again
make the administration's case for the same idea, contending that such a policy
would speed delivery, improve efficiency and save many lives.

The U.S. Congress in each of the past two years killed the proposal, which was
opposed by agribusiness and shipping interests who stood to lose business, even
as it won support from some liberal Democrat representatives.

But there are signs that the frozen politics of the issue are beginning to thaw,
especially as evidence grows of flaws in the current aid system.

A Government Accountability Office report released on the eve of this conference
describes in stark detail a system rife with inefficiencies: The amount of food
shipped during the past five years has fallen by half as shipping and other
logistical costs have soared.

Only a little more than a third of federal food-aid spending actually buys food.
The United States feeds about 70 million people a year now instead of the more
than 100 million it fed five years ago.

Experts worry that the food-aid budget will feed even fewer of the world's 850
million hungry people as soaring demand for corn to make ethanol drives up the
cost of that staple, a mainstay of food-aid programs.

This year, some farm state lawmakers are considering backing a pilot program to
test buying food overseas.

While an alliance of 15 nonprofit groups involved in food aid has endorsed only
a pilot program for local purchase, Catholic Relief Services, which has a
million donors and links with 13,000 parishes, has embraced the Bush
administration's proposal.

At perhaps no time since the U.S. food-aid program was created during the
Eisenhower administration more than 50 years ago has there been more ferment
about its future among scholars, politicians and advocates for the poor.

The curious mix of altruistic and self-interested motivations that animate U.S.
food aid spring from its origins. Public Law 480 and the Food for Peace program,
adopted in 1954, provided a way to dispose of surplus grain, which was costly to
store, and at the same time feed the world's hungry people. The law mandated
that food for the program be grown domestically.

In recent years, the United States has bought more than half the food for its
aid programs from just four agribusinesses and their subsidiaries: Archer
Daniels Midland, Cargill, Bunge and Cal Western Packaging, the Agriculture
Department said.

Some researchers and advocates said that it was time to rethink the U.S.
approach to fighting world hunger.

''Are we committed to eradicating hunger because it's feasible, not terribly
expensive and our moral obligation as the richest society in human history?''
asked Christopher Barrett, a Cornell University economist and the co-author of
''Food Aid After Fifty Years.'' ''Or are we just trying to placate a few
agribusiness, shipping and NGO constituencies with a handout?'' referring to
nongovernmental organizations.

But some in Congress, as well as lobbyists for interest groups that benefit from
food aid, warn that untying aid from requirements that the food be grown in the
United States and mostly shipped on U.S.-flagged vessels would shatter the
political coalition that has sustained the program for decades and made the
United States the world's largest food-aid donor.

Still, even at the food-aid conference organized by the Department of
Agriculture and the Agency for International Development, some participants were
talking about approaches that would sound heretical to old-line champions of
food aid.

Marv Baldwin, president of the Foods Resource Bank, a Christian nonprofit group
dedicated to fighting hunger, described how more than a thousand farmers have
turned U.S.-style food aid on its head.

They are raising farm animals and growing crops on about 7,000 acres, or 2,800
hectares, across the United States. They donate their land and labor and the use
of their equipment, while church groups help raise cash for fuel and fertilizer.

But instead of shipping the crops and animals to poor lands to feed the hungry,
the farmers sell them in the United States. The Foods Resource Bank then spends
the money from those sales in developing countries to buy seeds and other goods
that poor farmers need to grow food for their families.

LOAD-DATE: May 7, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2007 International Herald Tribune
                              All Rights Reserved


                              157 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           April 28, 1993, Wednesday

USDA STILL SEEKING FUNDS TO PAY FOR SHIPPING FOOD AID TO RUSSIANS

BYLINE: STEPHANIE NALL; & WILLIAM DiBENEDETTO

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 447 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Agriculture Department still is trying to find money it can shift around to
pay for the cost of shipping food aid to Russia so it can avoid asking Congress
for special legislation, a USDA official said Tuesday.

Charles O'Mara, acting undersecretary for international affairs and commodity
programs, told the Senate Appropriations Committee's agriculture subcommittee
that the department is "actively working with other parts of the administration
to implement" the subsidized $ 700 million loan "as quickly as ossible."

President Clinton promised the food loan package during his meeting with Russian
President Boris Yeltsin earlier this month in Vancouver, British Columbia. The
USDA has borrowing authority through its Commodity Credit Corp. to make the
loan, but a statutory limit of $ 30 million for fiscal 1993 transportation costs
has stalled it.

If the USDA or another agency can invoke emergency provisions in the law and
move existing funds, the shipments can proceed and be moved on U.S.-flag
carriers. Provisions of cargo preference requirements set aside 75 percent of
the cargo for U.S.-flag vessels.

Another option would be for Mr. Clinton to declare an emergency and waive the
cargo preference requirements, allowing the shipments to move on much-
lower-cost foreign-flag vessels.

Christopher Goldthwaite, the USDA's acting general sales manager, said later
that the Russians had not formally asked for different transportation
arrangements, and he refused to say if a waiver is being considered.

U.S.-flag vessels are charging three to four times as much a ton, which upsets
farm state lawmakers because higher shipping costs leave less money to be spent
on grain.

Rep. Bill Barrett, R-Neb., a member of the Agriculture Committee, last week
offered three measures attacking cargo preference. They would:

* Urge the president to use his authority to waive cargo preference
requirements.

* Amend the 1936 Merchant Marine Act to eliminate cargo preference requirements
on any food or other humanitarian aid provided in the Vancouver package.

* Eliminate cargo preference on only the humanitarian agriculture aid promised
at Vancouver.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, wrote to Mr. Clinton asking that he waive cargo
preference requirements on the Russian shipments. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D- Vt.,
last month suggested the same.

But that view is not universally held.

Sen. John Breaux, D-La., one of the maritime industry's biggest backers in
Congress, doesn't think the situation in Russia warrants an exception to U.S.
cargo preference laws.

"We should not sacrifice our interests for their interests," Sen. Breaux said
Tuesday.

LOAD-DATE: December 12, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1993 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              158 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              March 4, 2007 Sunday

Government officials rally to help counties: WINTER KILL

BYLINE: Margie Wood, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 449 words


Mar. 4--County, state and federal government agencies have been involved in
efforts to help rural counties in Southeastern Colorado buried by storms and
locked for weeks in bitter cold, but farmers in the area still face major
losses.

County governments, of course, were on the front line of efforts to open roads
so that ranchers could get to their snowbound cattle. The Federal Emergency
Management Agency says it will reimburse counties for 75 percent of their
extraordinary snow removal expenses.

But FEMA doesn't cover agricultural losses of individual producers. That is the
domain of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and USDA aid other than
low-interest loans has been denied -- to the dismay of state officials and
Colorado senators and congressmen. Cattle ranchers estimate they have lost
10,000 head and that more deaths may occur among cattle weakened by the bitter
winter.

FEMA was quick to authorize aid to counties trying to dig out of the storms,
getting a declaration of a snow emergency issued by President Bush on Jan. 7 to
cover storms that occurred Dec. 18-22 and a second storm Dec. 28-31. Counties
have been added until 24 counties in the state now are covered for one or both
storms.

Gov. Bill Ritter, who took office on Jan. 9 right in the middle of the emergency
efforts to save cattle, on Jan. 30 authorized $650,000 in state aid to eight
area counties -- Baca, Bent, Crowley, Huerfano, Kiowa, Las Animas, Otero and
Prowers -- to help with snow removal costs, which are expected to run into the
millions.

But as of last weekend, the farmers and ranchers in the hard-hit southern corner
of the state still were waiting for relief aid from the USDA. Representatives of
both Colorado's U.S. senators, Ken Salazar and Wayne Allard, met with ranchers
in Springfield, where they were told that state ag officials estimate losses
will reach $50 million to $100 million.

Allard, a Republican, has introduced a bill to require the USDA to cover some
livestock losses. Salazar has asked U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns to
consider livestock losses in addition to crop production losses, in order to
meet the threshold for USDA disaster aid.

Last week, U.S. Rep. John Salazar, D-Colo., announced that House Democrats will
attempt to attach $4 billion in agricultural disaster aid to the supplemental
defense budget bill expected to be moving through the House this month.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 July 27, 1998, Monday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

U.S. DECLARES 66 PARCHED OKLAHOMA COUNTIES AS DISASTER AREAS

BYLINE: From News Services

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A4

LENGTH: 413 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman declared most of Oklahoma a disaster area
Sunday because of devastating drought and excessive heat that has parched the
state.

Glickman said 66 of Oklahoma's 77 counties received the disaster designation.
Only the northeast corner of the state, near Missouri, has escaped serious
agricultural losses.

Texas, Florida and Georgia have already been declared disaster zones.

Glickman said April, May and June had been the driest in history for Texas, New
Mexico, Louisiana and Florida. He also estimated that 10 to 20 percent of all
farmers in North Dakota might be out of business because of "pre-existing
disaster problems."

"I mean, you're talking big numbers. And if the Texas situation continues, it
will particularly affect cotton and livestock producers, cattle producers. So
these are monumental issues and we will do our best to try to take care of
them," he said.

Under the disaster designation, the U.S. Department of Agriculture makes
low-interest loans available to farmers in the designated counties and
contiguous counties. To be eligible, farmers must have suffered a loss of 30
percent or more on any single crop.

The scorching weather continued Sunday in Texas. Dallas had the 21st day in a
row with the temperature above 100. Morning lows have not been below 80 for 24
days.

High demand and heat stress on pipes ruptured water mains in neighboring Fort
Worth on Saturday, the second day in a row, shutting off water to two hospitals
and the city's popular downtown tourist attractions.

Service had been restored throughout the city by Sunday, but all outdoor
watering was banned.

City officials will discuss on Monday when and how to lift the ban, water
department spokeswoman Mary Gugliuzza said.

"If everyone goes out and turns their sprinkler system on at the same time, that
could put quite a stress on the system again," she said.

Nationwide, the heat had been blamed for 141 deaths, including at least 93 in
Texas.

The heat is blamed for $ 1.5 billion in agricultural damage and more than 6,765
wildfires in Texas.

Meteorologists forecast little if any chance of cooling rain in the coming week
because of a large area of high pressure covering the South.

"The high pressure is pressing down on the earth, and suppressing the formation
of clouds that could perhaps develop into thunderstorms," said Michael Mach, a
meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Fort Worth.

LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1998

LANGUAGE: English

                              160 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                             May 13, 2006 Saturday

Congress, Bush at odds on farm aid  ;
 20 House districts would get most of $1.6 billion

BYLINE: DORI MEINERT Copley News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 777 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Congress and the Bush administration are at odds over $1.6 billion in emergency
aid to farmers that senators included last week in a $109 billion funding bill
for the war in Iraq and hurricane victims.

While Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., and other farm-state lawmakers say the aid is
critical for farmers struggling from last year's drought and rising fuel costs,
President Bush has threatened to veto the bill because it's $14 billion more
than he requested.

In addition, Agriculture Department officials and several watchdog groups
complain that the emergency funding would be paid out only to a favored few.

More than half the $1.6 billion would go to farmers in 20 congressional
districts, including those of Illinois Reps. Tim Johnson, R-Urbana, John
Shimkus, R-Collinsville, and Ray LaHood, R-Peoria, according to the
Environmental Working Group.

That's because the emergency aid would be handed out to last year's farm payment
recipients - amounting to about 30 percent of what each received in 2005 -
perpetuating what critics see as an unfair distribution system. The money would
be in addition to annual subsidies.

"Even in the congressional districts where you have a substantial amount of the
money going in ... it's still not going to go to all of the farmers by any
means," said Ken Cook, president of the Environmental Working Group. "An average
of 38 percent of the farms in those top 20 districts will be left out. So even
within that there are serious inequities."

But Illinois Farm Bureau officials say the funding would go where it's needed
the most.

The Midwest, where farmers grow many of the crops favored under the current
system, was dramatically affected by increases in fuel prices, low crop yields
due to last year's drought and shipment disruptions because of Hurricane
Katrina, said Chuck Spencer, the bureau's director of national legislation.

"So I don't know that there's any surprise about it being the largest target for
relief," he said.

The $1.6 billion is part of a  $4 billion farm aid package included in the
emergency funding bill, which the Senate passed last week. It now goes to a
House-Senate conference committee.

While the House version didn't include the farm aid, House Agriculture Chairman
Bob Goodlatte, R-Va., has said he favors some emergency aid for farmers.

Durbin met with Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns in late April in an attempt
to persuade him to support the extra aid.

Illinois farmers suffered $433 million in losses as a direct result of the
drought, Durbin said. He also noted that an average, 1,000-acre farm, costs
$24,000 more to operate than in 2001, an increase he attributed to higher fuel,
fertilizer and pesticide costs.

Local House members offered more cautious support.

LaHood said that last year he supported emergency help for farmers that wasn't
included in the House bill. Relief money included by the Senate was rejected by
House leaders in conference.

"While I still believe our farmers need assistance to help recover from drought
damage, I believe we must find a way to pay for it and not just heap it on the
national debt," LaHood said in a statement issued by his office.

Shimkus noted that farmers can't pass on the increased costs of fuel and
fertilizer.

The arguments provide a glimpse of the upcoming battle over renewing the current
farm law.

The Environmental Working Group and Environmental Defense have joined with the
conservative Heritage Foundation and the libertarian Cato Institute to push for
major reforms in the system and to fight efforts to extend the current farm
program beyond its scheduled expiration in 2007.

"Even though we're told that farm subsidies are to help small, struggling family
farmers, the reality is that farm subsidies are America's largest corporate
welfare program," said Brian Riedl, a senior policy analyst for the Heritage
Foundation.

The reformers argue that the current farm program is unfair to farmers, consumer
and taxpayers. Most of the federal crop subsidies now go to those who grow just
a few crops, such as corn, wheat, rice and cotton.

The Environmental Working Group also argues that large commercial farm
operations receive a disproportionate share. In Illinois about 58 percent of the
federal dollars in 2004 went to just 10 percent of the recipients, according to
the group's database.

This week, two former agriculture secretaries - Republican Clayton Yeutter and
Democrat Dan Glickman - endorsed recommendations by the American Farmland Trust
to refocus the farm program so that it helps more farmers and livestock
producers, creates incentives for protecting the environment and avoids
challenges from trading partners.

whose constituents have the most to gain from the aid plan.

                        Watertown Daily Times (New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 3, 2007 Tuesday

Dairy farmers to receive $30 million in state aid

BYLINE: Chris Garifo, Watertown Daily Times, N.Y.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 525 words


Apr. 3--ALBANY -- North country dairy farmers will be able to share in $30
million in financial support included in the 2007-08 enacted state budget, half
of what had been proposed by the state Senate.

"The original proposal was $60 million, but I'm pleased we were able to achieve
$30 million," said state Sen. James W. Wright, R-Watertown. "In general, the
governor and the Assembly were not supportive of it, so we had to negotiate on
it."

The aid was provided to help upstate dairy farmers deal with last year's
historically low milk prices, coupled with increased expenses for such crucial
items as fuel and animal feed.

The state Senate last month included the funding, to be disbursed through a
program administered by the state Department of Agriculture, in its budget
proposal. The plan was modeled on a similar aid program in Vermont.

Despite the support of Assemblyman Darrel J. Aubertine, D-Cape Vincent, a
longtime north country dairy farmer, the Assembly did not include the aid in its
budget proposal. However, Mr. Aubertine last month did introduce legislation
creating the dairy assistance program, including the full $60 million proposed
by the Senate.

"Obviously, it's less than we had hoped for," Mr. Aubertine said about the
compromise. "We had hoped for $60 million, but it's certainly going to be
important to our dairy farmers to help with crop expenses this spring."

Though the amount of money to be provided has been agreed upon, negotiators
still have to work out just how the money will be disbursed, Mr. Aubertine said.

"I hope it will be based on full year's production," he said.

Among the recommendations being considered are to cap the amount of milk
produced to be used in the disbursement formula at 4 million to 5 million
gallons, Mr. Aubertine said.

"But those are very preliminary numbers," he said.

Farmers can expect to get about 331/3 cents per hundredweight of milk, Mr.
Aubertine said. A hundredweight is 100 pounds, or 11.6 gallons, of milk.

A farmer with 50 milking cows produces about 1 million pounds of milk a year.
So, based on the 331/3 cents per hundredweight, that farmer would get slightly
more than $3,300 in aid.

"It's going to treat the small farms differently than the bigger farms," Mr.
Aubertine said. "If we had got the full $60 million, it would have been 50
cents, regardless of how big you were. We had planned on paying 50 cents per
hunderdredweight regardless of how many cows a farmer has."

The program is economic development aid using agriculture as a driver, Mr.
Aubertine said.

"Nobody's going to argue that this money isn't going to go back into the economy
of upstate New York," he said. "Farmers are going to spend every penny of this
locally getting their feed crops in the ground."

to http://www.wdt.net. Copyright (c) 2007, Watertown Daily Times, N.Y.

                              The Washington Post

                  September 14, 1991, Saturday, Final Edition

Fuel Aid Unrelated To Food Stamps, Md. Judge Rules

From news services and staff reports

SECTION: METRO; PAGE B5; AROUND THE REGION

LENGTH: 189 words


A federal judge ruled yesterday that energy assistance grants made to low-income
people cannot be cited by the Agriculture Department as the basis for reducing
eligibility for food stamps.

The ruling, by U.S. District Judge Herbert F. Murray in Baltimore, affects about
202,000 Maryland welfare clients who receive both energy assistance and food
stamps. The lawsuit was filed six years ago by the state and the Maryland Legal
Aid Bureau after the federal government began requiring Maryland officials to
reduce food stamp allotments to people who received increases in their heating
assistance grants, which were counted as income.

"If the federal policy had not been challenged successfully, poor people in
Maryland would have to choose between having food or having heat during the
winter months, and we couldn't allow that," said Carolyn W. Colvin, Maryland
Department of Human Resources secretary.

Maryland Attorney General J. Joseph Curran Jr. (D) said Congress never intended
for the low-income people who receive help meeting their fuel bills to pay for
that assistance with cuts in their food stamp allotments.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

                              163 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 18, 2011 Friday

Redistricting here could aid agriculture interests

BYLINE: Erinn Connor, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 412 words


Nov. 18--With Pennsylvania's ongoing redistricting effort looking like it could
significantly reshuffle Berks County's legislative districts, some people who
live in the county's rural areas wonder if it will give them a stronger voice.

It won't hurt, judging by remarks that state Sen. David G. Argall made at the
Berks Agricultural Resource Network, or BARN, meeting Thursday during a speech
on redistricting's effect on those in agriculture.

The meeting was held at the Berks County Agricultural Center in Bern Township.

One of the more notable changes in the proposed map is a new House district.

The district would comprise a large swath of the county, wrapping around the
Reading area from Ruscombmanor and Alsace townships to Bethel and Upper
Tulpehocken townships.

"While it won't be a complete rural representation, it'll at least be a good
mix," said Argall, a Schuylkill County Republican who also represents part of
Berks.

The proposed redistricting plan he was talking about was prompted by population
shifts noted in the last census and would take effect in 2012.

Berks would still have all or parts of four state Senate and nine state House
districts, but they wouldn't be the same as they are now.

The new House district, the 5th, would be picked up from the Erie area.

Meanwhile, Berks would lose its part of the House's 125th District, which is
mostly in Schuylkill County.

BARN member Joseph Griffin asked Argall if there were any efforts being made so
rural areas could get more equal representation with urban areas in the
Legislature.

Argall said legislators have been introducing bills to do just that for 40 or 50
years, but he did not hold out much hope that any would ever pass.

He also defended the ongoing redistricting effort.

"It's a challenge for them," Argall said of those working on the plan. "Because
the districts are determined by population, it's hard to do much about it."

As for the agricultural community's political clout, Argall said it is not
always vocal about every issue but is passionate when it comes to hot-button
issues.

"This year, Sunday hunting has been a big issue," he said. "We've certainly
heard from a lot of people on all sides about that.

"When there's an issue that's important to the rural community, we'll hear about
it."

Contact Erinn Connor: 610-371-5042 or econnor@readingeagle.com
