                              164 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   August 28, 1994, SUNDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

ABUSES PLAGUING CROP-AID PROGRAM; STUDY FINDS LAX CONTROLS ON BILLIONS PAID TO
FARMERS

BYLINE: Louis J. Rose Of the Post-Dispatch Staff 1994, St. Louis Post-Dispatch

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1315 words


The federal government has paid farmers billions of dollars in disaster aid for
crop losses under a program riddled with weak internal controls that left it
vulnerable to abuse and fraud, a federal investigation concludes.

The previously confidential report finds major defects at virtually every stage,
from the time farmers apply for help to when they get federal disaster-aid
checks from their county agricultural offices.

The investigators said safeguards were absent or so weak that they jeopardized
the integrity of the program. Some failings were human, others technical. For
example, local agricultural officials frequently handed out checks without
requiring farmers to prove the size of crop they lost, and computer programs
often were unreliable in monitoring claims, the report says.

A unit of the U.S. Department of Agriculture conducted the study. It focused on
the crop years 1990 and 1991 during which farmers got more than $ 1 billion in
disaster payments for crops lost to floods, drought or other weather-related
conditions.

But some federal officials say the problems uncovered in the study may have
spanned the period from 1988 - when Congress greatly expanded the program -
through last year's Great Flood.

Over the six years, the nation's farmers collected about $ 8.8 billion in
disaster aid. Missouri farmers got $ 265.8 million; Illinois farmers got $ 501.8
million.

In their review, Department of Agriculture investigators sampled 560
transactions in 30 county offices operated by the department's Agricultural
Stabilization and Conservation Service. They focused on 1990-91 records but also
examined some from 1992.

The sampling covered 18 states and included three Missouri counties - Lincoln,
New Madrid and Scotland - and four Illinois counties - Calhoun, Champaign,
Livingston and Wayne.

The report did not identify shortcomings in specific counties. Nor did
investigators set out to search for fraud or to calculate how much money the
government might have lost. Instead, they concentrated on evaluating internal
controls and suggesting changes to protect the system.

County offices and their three-member farmer committees have had a major role in
crop-disaster programs. Besides processing claims, they also issue checks.

The Post-Dispatch obtained the internal report earlier this month under a
Freedom of Information Act request. But the findings of a confidential interim
report had suggested some changes last September, even as the first claims were
being made from the Great Flood of '93.

"We immediately began making changes," said Grant Buntrock, who administers
disaster assistance as head of the stabilization and conservation agency. By
that time, many flood crop damage claims had been paid, but Buntrock ordered a
review using the new controls.

That review turned up instances where farmers got money they were not entitled
to, Buntrock said. He said some farmers had cheated to get more money, while in
other cases county employees had erred in making payments.

Buntrock has ordered local agricultural offices to collect the overpayments from
the farmers, he said. Big Volume, Big Rush

The Kansas City staff of the Financial Management Office, part of the
Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, conducted the review. Among
the findings:

- Many county offices were unable to effectively handle disaster assistance
because they lacked time to train employees to handle the heavy volume of
applications.

- Computer data used in processing applications proved vulnerable to being
altered, either by accident or design. At risk were entries recording producer
shares, crop yields and insurance information.

For example, the report said one county improperly increased by 72 percent the
per-acre yield figure that should have been used in calculating soybean crop
losses.

- Agriculture employees often failed to get farmers to document production
claims and acreage involved in crop losses. Often, they accepted reports of
production and yield without examining supporting documents.

- Farmers collectively got about $ 957,000 more than they were entitled to
despite the system's limit then of $ 50,400 a year.

- County agriculture employees failed to make required spot checks on disaster
payments, intended to detect "error and fraud."

During the two-year period, Illinois farmers got $ 42.6 million in disaster aid,
the fifth highest state total. Missouri farmers wound up 12th, with $ 25.2
million. A Bumper Crop of Disaster Aid

Until six years ago, county agriculture officials dealt exclusively with crops
such as wheat, corn and cotton - so-called program crops - that had a
well-established history of production, yields and acreage data.

They expanded their horizons in 1988 when Congress made about 480 nonprogram or
specialty crops eligible for crop aid. Those are fruits, vegetables and other
crops that did not have federal price support.

Those crops frequently lacked production data by which employees could judge
claims. Some county offices ended up taking farmers at their word without
documenting loss claims.

The impact of making specialty crops eligible for disaster aid was dramatic -
and swift. By the end of 1989, producers of nonprogram crops had taken in $ 1.3
billion in disaster aid. Since then, disaster aid to farmers who have lost crops
has become almost an annual ritual.

The rapid increase in disaster spending caught the attention of federal and
congressional investigators. They say they have uncovered patterns of abuse and
fraud in disaster or crop insurance claims in several states, involving both
specialty and program crops.

Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Commiittee, has
been a leader in the drive to curb farm fraud.

"My committee's oversight activities have established that generous programs
designed to help farmers cope with serious disasters have too often been used by
farmers to help themselves to funds from the federal treasury," Leahy said
Friday.

"Neither honest farmers nor honest taxpayers should accept this type of fraud
and abuse. Those who defraud the program should be prosecuted as the criminals
they are."

In their 30-county review, federal investigators found about one in five claims
for disaster aid were not sufficiently documented to prove the extent of the
loss. Most of the deficiencies involved specialty crops.oapr

In some cases, farmers got aid after crops had been plowed under or without
evidence that they'd ever planted a crop.

The list of specialty crops covered by disaster aid has expanded to more than
1,200 crops. They include 120 kinds of flowers, four kinds of clover, oysters,
tropical fish, oregano, peppermint and ginseng.

While congressional and Agriculture Department officials have encouraged farmers
to buy crop insurance in recent years, most farmers have balked. Then whenf
disasters struck, Congress coughed up aid.

Donald F. Lloyd, an agriculture official in Washington, said the agency was
"exploring anything we can to maintain and increase the integrity of the
disaster-aid program. The problem is basically with our nonprogram crops. We
have a pretty good handle on the program crops because we get acreage reports
from the farmers in a timely manner."

Last week, the Senate took steps to reform the federal crop insurance program
and make it harder to provide federal bailouts for growers who do not buy crop
insurance. It passed a bill late Thursday that will have to be reconciled with a
version the House passed earlier.

Congress is considering a separate bill appropriating disaster aid for this
year.

"We got the flood in the Southeast in Georgia and Alabama," Lloyd said. "At this
point it's not that extensive, but we know we have something." Farmers in
Florida also are expected to file flood-damage claims.

LOAD-DATE: August 31, 1994

LANGUAGE: English

                              165 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                 NEW YORK TIMES

                             March 5, 1974, Tuesday

BYLINE: BY DAVID BINDER

SECTION: Page 1, Column 6

LENGTH: 195 words

Carnegie Endowment for Internatl Peace study, conducted by Roger Morris and Hal
Sheets, on relief efforts by US Govt and internatl agencies for '73 sub-Sahara
drought victims charges that gross neglect and outright failures contributed to
deaths of more than 100,000 people.  Asserts that AID officials and other relief
orgns had known that long-term drought was developing in region, but no
contigency plans were drawn.  Holds that 'pattern of neglect and inertia' by AID
and FAO caused emergency food and med supplies to reach nomads too late.  AID,
responding to charges, acknowledges that there had been no emergency plan for
region and that US relief effort in area, totaling $129-million, was not 'model
operation'.  Rejects charges of neglect and inertia.  Carnegie study makes
strongest charges on basis of '73 US PHS survey that found thousands of
inadequately fed nomadic children facing imminent death from measles, for which
vaccine was lacking.  Asserts that health findings, prepared by Center for
Disease Control, Atlanta, made clear acute malnutrition and rampant measles
epidemics were inevitable many mos before relief supplies were sent.  Map (M).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

JOURNAL-CODE:  NYT

TYPE: 64-74

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                             July 2, 2016 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

SOUTH CAROLINA FARMERS CAN BEGIN APPLYING FOR $40 MILLION IN AID

BYLINE:  JEFFREY COLLINS  ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B03

LENGTH: 460 words

DATELINE: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C.


When extension agent Charles Davis visits farms, he gets one question over and
over again - when will South Carolina farmers start getting aid for crops
damaged in last year's floods?

Finally, Davis and his fellow agents have the paperwork. The state on Friday
began taking applications for

$40 million in aid approved by lawmakers in May over Gov. Nikki Haley's veto.

The aid supplements crop insurance. It only covers

20 percent of losses from October's floods and subsequent months of waterlogged
fields and no farmer can get more than $100,000. But that extra money will be
vital to farmers who have tapped out their credit with months to go before
getting paid for this year's crops.

"We lost a heck of a lot of money in a short period of time," said Davis, the
Clemson University extension agent for Calhoun and Richland counties.

Up to

24 inches of rain fell over two days in parts of South Carolina. Much of the
state's cotton and peanut crop had not been harvested and simply rotted in the
stagnant water. Repeated heavy rains in the weeks after the floods kept fields
too wet to plant winter crops, taking another revenue stream from farmers and
eventually causing nearly $400 million in damage, state Agriculture Commissioner
Hugh Weathers said.

The application for state aid is available on the Department of Agriculture's
website. Farmers must have documented proof of their losses, show they plan on
farming again and sign a sworn statement.

Claims will be accepted through Aug.

15. If farmers request more than $40 million, the awards will be prorated,
Weathers said.

Officials are fanning out across the state to help farmers fill out their
applications. They will meet at community centers, farm sheds, restaurants and
extension offices from Dillon to St. George to Blackville throughout July.

South Carolina farmers saw more than just flooding disasters in

2015. The summer was hot and dry enough to wipe out another round of crops that
aren't included in the farm aid awards, Weathers said.

The farm aid bill turned into one of the biggest political battles of

2016. Dozens of farmers packed the Statehouse after Haley vetoed the bill, and
just five of 156 House members and senators voted to sustain the veto.

Weathers only briefly mentioned the political fight Thursday. "It is simply
designed to give them a lifeline," Weathers said. "This is not a bailout."

Haley said Thursday she still thinks farmers should not have been treated
differently and given aid not available to other small businesses that lost
everything. But she said she still wishes the state's farmers the best.

"It's not that I don't want the farmers to be successful. I do. But I am still
driving down the street and seeing businesses that have never opened back up
again," Haley said.

LOAD-DATE: August 10, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              167 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            February 23, 2015 Monday

Arizona: Store Owner Sentenced to Prison and Forfeiture of Funds for Federal
Food Program Fraud

LENGTH: 590  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Justice has issued the following news release:


ANCHORAGE, AK--U.S. Attorney Karen L. Loeffler announced today that an Anchorage
store owner was sentenced by U.S. District Court Judge Timothy M. Burgess to 18
months' imprisonment, along with forfeiture of over $42,000 in criminal proceeds
in connection with a United States Department of Agriculture food aid program
fraud scheme which he operated out of his Anchorage store.

In late 2013, Africa and Middle East Market store owner Ayub Yusuf Eprahin, 45,
was charged by the federal grand jury with 15 counts of wire fraud and 11 counts
of U.S. Department of Agriculture Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
(SNAP) food aid fraud in connection with the illegal use of food aid debit
cards. Eprahin, who plead guilty in 2014, to two counts of wire fraud, contested
the overall loss amount of the scheme, claiming it amounted to only $42,000. In
day-long and contentious sentencing hearing, Judge Burgess found that Eprahin
had defrauded the United States Department of Agriculture of more than $335,000
over a period of 19 months. As part of that finding, Judge Burgess imposed a
sentence of 18 months' imprisonment, forfeited to the United States more than
$42,000 in funds seized from Eprahin, and imposed a term of three years of
supervised release.

According to Assistant U.S. Attorney Steve Skrocki, in November, 2012, Eprahin
was the owner of the Africa and Middle East Market and a participant in the
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), formerly known as the "Food
Stamp Program" administered by the United States Department of Agriculture's
Food and Nutritional Service. The program is designed to provide authorized
nutritional foods to low-income families. The federal government pays the full
cost of the SNAP benefits and also shares with the states some of the
administrative costs. Under the SNAP program, authorized recipients are issued a
certain amount of benefits each month, which they may use to purchase eligible
food items. SNAP recipients typically receive their benefits in the form of a
credit on their personal electronic benefit transfer card. The rules of the
program prohibit the purchase of items other than food, and the card benefits
cannot be redeemed for cash. As a participant in the program, Eprahin received
computer issued payments based on unauthorized purchases made by participants
from his store.

As part of the scheme Eprahin permitted non-food items and cash to be redeemed
from participants in the program on a large scale. In so doing, Eprahin
represented to the SNAP program that the benefits were being redeemed to
purchase eligible food items when they in fact were not. Instead, Judge Burgess
found that the cards were being used like ATM cards with amounts being debited
for cash instead of food items required by the program and with some of that
cash being wired overseas. Judge

Burgess noted that Eprahin's actions negatively impacted the community, other
small businesses and the integrity of a government program designed to help and
feed people in need, finding the offense, "very, very serious as hundreds of
thousands were misused by not being provided to those it was supposed to help."

Ms. Loeffler commends the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and United States
Department of Agriculture, Office of Inspector General, who administers the SNAP
program, for their investigation of this case.
In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: May 5, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              168 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                          October 30, 1991, Wednesday

MADIGAN: BUSH TO UNVEIL SOVIET FOOD AID SOON

BYLINE: RICHARD LAWRENCE; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 566 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


President Bush will announce in the "very, very near future" a multipronged food
aid program to help the Soviet Union through the winter, Agriculture Secretary
Edward Madigan said Tuesday.

The announcement, he indicated, will be made jointly with Soviet President
ikhail Gorbachev, suggesting that it could be as early as today.

The two presidents met Tuesday in Madrid. Mr. Bush is scheduled to leave Spain
today to return directly to Washington.

Both President Bush at a Madrid press conference Tuesday and Mr. Madigan, in
remarks here, declined to disclose the magnitude of the food aid program.

But three congressional leaders separately indicated that Mr. Bush may scale
down Mr. Gorbachev's reported request of $ 3.5 billion in new U.S. agricultural
credit guarantees plus $ 1 billion in food donations and other emergency
humanitarian aid.

Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, the House Agriculture Committee chairman, said
his "guess" is that if Mr. Gorbachev asked for $ 3.6 billion in credit
guarantees, the administration would probably offer $ 1.5 billion.

Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., raised the question of Soviet
''creditworthiness." The United States, he noted, has already extended $ 2.5
billion in farm credit guarantees to the Soviets in the last 10 months.

The Soviets already are "deep in debt," their economy "flat on its back," he
said. American taxpayers, he added, "don't want to be left holding the bag on
billions of dollars of credit."

Sen. Richard Lugar, Ind., the Senate Agriculture Committee's ranking Republican,
said whatever aid the United States provides will be a sort of ''rifle-shot"
approach, keyed to some big cities and "remote" areas.

Posing a further complication, Sen. Dole suggested that Mr. Bush's food aid
program will "have to be approved by the Congress," which is due to adjourn
shortly before Thanksgiving.

President Bush, he said, is "sensitive" to charges by Democrats that "if you are
not an American, President Bush will take care of you."

If Mr. Bush puts his food aid proposal to Congress, said Sen. Dole, ''Democrats
will have to either stop giving that speech or stop giving aid to the Soviets."

The question of Soviet creditworthiness, Mr. Madigan indicated, is a key factor
in the Bush administration's granting further credit guarantees to the Soviets.

The administration, he told a National Press Club luncheon, is still checking
whether the U.S. aid would meet "statutory" requirements. Last year, Congress
enacted a law generally setting strict creditworthiness criteria for U.S. farm
credit guarantees.

Earlier this year, the Senate and the House Agriculture Committee signaled that
they would not oppose $ 1.5 billion in credit guarantees that President Bush had
then proposed for the Soviets.

Whether Congress will do the same for any new Soviet food aid package is ''very
problematic," Sen. Dole said.

But, he added, "I think that we should look at the Gorbachev request
sympathetically."

President Bush said Tuesday that he and Mr. Gorbachev were trying to ''figure
out the best package we can that will come as close to meeting (Soviet)
requirements as possible for economic aid."

The food aid package, Mr. Madigan indicated, would include the offer of
technical assistance, ranging from the creation of "model farms" in the Soviet
Union to help in distributing produce.

LOAD-DATE: December 17, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            March 10, 2016 Thursday

Head Line: US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri) Issues
Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 276 words

DATELINE: Lahore


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAG-S-16-0032

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: March 9, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-16-0032 (2000003927) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after March 9, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near March 16, 2016.



Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Janet Cleveland, Grain Marketing Specialist
janet.cleveland@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 816-926-2540

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    October 6, 1994, Thursday, City Edition

Smith is denied state aid for race

BYLINE: BILL MOSS

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 844 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE



Jim Smith, who withdrew from the governor's race to run for agriculture
commissioner, faces a major financial hurdle in his new campaign.

A circuit judge Wednesday barred him from taking matching state money for  the
Cabinet race.

Judge Philip J. Padovano ruled that Smith's run for governor gave him the
advantage of heavy television exposure and boosted his name recognition.

"Jim Smith has been authorized to run for commissioner of agriculture, but  he
has not been allowed to obtain an unfair advantage by the expenditure of  public
funds he received in his previous race for governor," Padovano said.

Smith spent $ 2.2-million running for the Republican nomination for governor
and received $ 880,047 in public matching money.

Padovano's order gave incumbent Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford a  series
of victories on the campaign finance issues:

   Smith can't take public financing in this race because he spent  $ 2,219,859
in the gubernatorial campaign. The limit in the governor's race for  candidates
taking matching money is $ 5-million. The limit in Cabinet races is  $
2-million, which Smith already exceeded.

   Crawford is entitled to $ 219,859 in matching money, the amount Smith  spent
over the $ 2-million Cabinet cap.

   Smith must calculate how much of the $ 219,859 was public matching money  and
return that to the state treasury.

   If Smith got donations as a gubernatorial candidate from industries
regulated by the agriculture commissioner, he must give back the amount over  $
100. State law bars candidates for that job from taking donations of more  than
$ 100 from those regulated industries.

  "These contributions were not illegal when they were made in the race  for
governor, but they have become illegal now that Jim Smith has decided to  run
for commissioner of agriculture," Padovano said.

  Smith got into the race after the withdrawal of the GOP's original  nominee,
Frank Darden. Padovano said in court Friday that he was disturbed to  learn that
Republican Party chairman Tom Slade had talked about replacing  Darden with one
of the losing gubernatorial candidates on Aug. 6, two weeks  after the
qualifying period. Slade had testified in an earlier court  appearance that he
had not discussed the candidate swap until Sept. 8.

  Smith's attorney vowed to file an immediate appeal and said he will ask  the
judge to stay the order until the 1st District Court of Appeal resolves  the
case.

   The judge "granted Crawford everything he asked for, so obviously I am  not
happy with the result," said attorney Barry Richard.

   Smith said that if he doesn't win on appeal, "I think we have to fold  it up"

 in terms of raising money. The alternative, he said, is spending money  that
automatically accrues, to his opponent's benefit. Smith has only $ 16,000  on
hand now, including a $ 10,000 personal loan to his campaign.

  "I am absolutely stunned," he said of the ruling. "I've practiced a  lot of
law as attorney general for eight years, and this is the most  incredible ruling
I've ever seen. Obviously, he is incensed at Tom Slade, and  I am being
thoroughly thrashed, I think, because he's so upset with Tom."

  Slade was unrepentant. He questioned the political motivation of  Padovano.

  "The guy is a Democrat, his wife works for Lawton Chiles and we got a  bunch
of home cooking out of his courtroom," Slade said. "We got a political  decision
out of a political judge trying to judicially mandate Bob Crawford's
re-election."

  Padovano is married to Janet Ferris, a high-ranking official in the  Chiles
administration. Padovano could not be reached for comment Wednesday  night.

  "This thing is a slam dunk," said Lynda Russell, executive director of  the
Democratic Party. "The judge has made sure campaign finance will do what  it was
intended to do, not serve as golden parachute for failed politicians."

  Smith's candidacy has raised issues never tested before in court because  the
public financing law was enacted in 1991.

  Padovano referred in his ruling to the testimony of a surprise witness,  who
told the court on Friday that Slade had talked about a candidate swap two  weeks
after the qualifying period.

  "He explained that he put this word out only as a part of a campaign of
"disinformation' to confuse the Democrats and "mess with Crawford's head,' "
Padovano wrote. "This change in facts together with the new explanation came
about primarily as a result of the presence of Mr. Tom Clements," the man who
testified about his Aug. 6 conversation with Slade.

   Padovano said that while the law is unclear, its plain purpose was to  even
up campaign financing between candidates and allowing Smith to start  fresh
would defeat the law's purpose.

"To allow Jim Smith to start fresh at the beginning of a new campaign  spending
limit when he already has a $ 2.2-million head start in media exposure  would
defeat the purpose of the law," he said.

LOAD-DATE: October 6, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; TAMPA TODAY

GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO; Jim Smith

                            Times Publishing Company


                              173 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                            June 30, 1998, Tuesday,

GOV. KING IS SEEKING FEDERAL AID TO HELP SODDEN FARMS RECOVER;
 THE $ 5.2 MILLION IN DISASTER RELIEF WOULD PROVIDE LOANS - NOT DIRECT AID - TO
FARMERS.

BYLINE: Clarke Canfield Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 693 words


June's heavy rains have destroyed as much as a third of the crops in southern
and western Maine, devastating scores of farmers and prompting the state to ask
for federal disaster aid.

The rains have flooded fields, left crops rotting, washed away fertilizers and
chemical sprays and otherwise wreaked havoc. More rain is forecast for today.

Doug Albert, owner of the 300-acre Albert Farm in Fryeburg, will lose most of
his potato crop on 150 acres. The rains turned his fields into lakes, and at
times the flooded Saco River put his potatoes 5 feet under water.

''We've lost about 80 percent of our potatoes,'' said Albert, who has been
farming for 34 years. ''I just had a guy in here from Presque Isle who said he's
been all over the country but never seen damage this bad.''

Gov. Angus King has asked Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman for $ 5.2
million in disaster aid for 11 of Maine's 16 counties. To meet the requirements
for aid, the rains must have destroyed at least 35 percent of the crops in those
counties, on average.

Albert Roach, state director for the Farm Service Agency, a part of the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, said the disaster relief, if approved, will mean
little direct aid for farmers. Instead, it will provide primarily low-interest
loans to help farmers rebuild.

The 1996 federal Farm Bill, Roach said, changed the way disaster relief is
administered. Farmers now have to buy private crop insurance to protect
themselves. Many farmers - Albert included - are not covered.

''I feel very bad that there are some farmers who don't have crop insurance and
will be hurt very, very bad,'' Roach said. ''We're finding quite a few people
are falling through the cracks.''

The season got off to a promising start this spring, as mild weather allowed
farmers to plant early. The rains changed all that.

Heavy rains have fallen for weeks in the western and southern parts of the
state, flooding rivers and lakes and fields. The worst-hit areas have been along
the Saco River in York and Oxford counties and along the Sandy River in Franklin
County.

Farm agents have reported that entire fields in low-lying areas have been
submerged. When that happens, potato crops are destroyed, hay quality drops,
corn withers, strawberries rot.

Gary Raymond, the Farm Service Agency director for Franklin County, said some
farmers have replanted their beans and corn. But crop work for the most part has
come to a standstill, and entire strawberry fields have been abandoned.

In one instance, a field full of plastic-wrapped bales of hay flooded, causing
the bales to float into woodlands and down the Sandy River. One bale was found
10 miles away, stuck under a bridge in the town of New Sharon.

''To see the damage is enough to make you sick to your stomach,'' Raymond wrote
in his weekly farm report.

The losses go beyond the cost of crops, Raymond explained. Even for farmers who
can replant or salvage some of their crops, the rains washed away the expensive
fertilizers and pesticides they applied on their fields.

The loss of silage corn and hay will result in higher feed prices for dairy
farmers, who are already barely making a profit. Roach said he didn't know how
the losses would affect consumer prices, because the rest of the country has had
good harvests so far.

King, in a letter dated June 25, asked the government to declare as disaster
areas the counties of Androscoggin, Cumberland, Franklin, Kennebec, Knox,
Lincoln, Oxford, Sagadahoc, Somerset, Waldo and York.

Roach said it usually takes three to seven days for the department to respond to
a disaster request.

The National Weather Service predicts more rain today. The forecast then calls
for three consecutive days of fair weather, before rain possibly returns for the
weekend.

In northern and eastern Maine, meanwhile, the crops are doing exceptionally
well, Roach said.

He said weather conditions are ideal for potatoes, broccoli, blueberries and
other crops in Aroostook and Washington counties.

''The crops look as good as I've seen in 40 years,'' Roach said by car phone
while traveling through Aroostook County.

LOAD-DATE: July 1, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: color;

Staff photo by Doug Jones Doug Albert stands beside a potato fiel;

 on his farm in Fryeburg on Monday, as his son aerates the field on a tractor.
Albert, who has no private crop insurance, says he has lost about 80 percent of
his potato crop due to flooding.

                              174 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             June 9, 2016 Thursday

State expands program urging food stamp users to buy produce

BYLINE: Justin Horwath, The Santa Fe New Mexican

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 335 words


June 09--New Mexico is expanding a welfare program meant to encourage food aid
recipients to spend benefits on fruits and vegetables.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced Wednesday it will grant $16.8
million nationally to encourage those on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance
Program, formerly known as food stamps, to spend benefits on healthy food. Just
over $2 million of that money will go to the New Mexico Farmers' Marketing
Association.

The money is also intended to benefit regional food producers in local
economies. Last year, the U.S. Department of Agriculture granted $99,999 to the
New Mexico Farmers' Marketing Association for the Double Up Food Bucks program.
State lawmakers allocated $128,000 to the program last year.

The program began in New Mexico in 2010 with 17 participating farmers markets,
Denise Miller, executive director of the New Mexico Farmers' Marketing
Association, said in a news release. She said the association expanded the
program last year to 34 farmers markets, allowing for participation in rural
communities.

Food assistance enrollees receive double the food stamp benefits if they spend
them at participating farmers markets in the state.

State lawmakers allocated $390,300 in state funding for the Double Up Food Bucks
program in the budget bill signed into law in February by Gov. Susana Martinez.
Miller said the funds will be used to expand the program to nearly 90 sites
across the state, including farmers markets, grocery stores, farm stands, mobile
markets and Community Supported Agriculture outlets.

The New Mexico Farmers' Marketing Association expects up to 25,000 food aid
recipients will use the program this year, for $1.2 million in local food sales
that will help support 800 small farms across the state.

Contact Justin Horwath at 505-986-3017 or jhorwath@sfnewmexican.com

Mexican (Santa Fe, N.M.) at www.santafenewmexican.com Distributed by Tribune
Content Agency, LLC.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            March 17, 2001, Saturday

USDA pays farmers for drought loss; 'Pressure': No state totals are released;
officials estimate the amount of aid could go as high as $2 billion

BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Pg. a2

LENGTH: 290 words


WASHINGTON (AP) - The government began making $ 1.1 billion in payments Friday
to 160,000 farmers who lost crops to drought and other weather-related disasters
last year.

The totals could go higher, as the Agriculture Department said it will continue
taking applications from farmers who want aid. The department has been under
pressure from Congress to start sending checks to producers who already have
been approved for the assistance.

Congress put no limit on the total amount of aid, and some officials have
estimated it could reach $ 2 billion. USDA made $ 1.2 billion in disaster
payments for 1999 crop losses.

"American farmers are still feeling the pressure of low prices, and in many
cases the effects of natural disasters. These payments will assist farmers in
this difficult time," said Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman.

Texas, North Dakota, Nebraska and Kansas are among the states with the greatest
demand for the money, officials said. No state totals were released.

The payments cover a portion of the farmers' losses. Growers who lost their
entire crops would receive 42 cents for every dollar of their projected
production.

To be eligible for the program, farmers must have lost at least 35 percent of
their production.

No deadline for applications for the assistance has been set.

Many farmers need the government checks to start planting this year's crops,
said Rep. Larry Combest, R-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee.

"The producer's ability to complete financial arrangements is important to
moving forward with field preparations so that loans are secured, seed and input
costs are paid, and rural communities can begin the cycle of a new growing
season," Combest said.

LOAD-DATE: March 20, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Copyright 2001, Telegraph-Herald


                              176 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                June 24, 2001, Sunday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Farmers: USDA slow to stop wheat disease

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 851 words

DATELINE: ANTHONY, Kan.; WASHINGTON



Bureaucratic bungling by the U.S. Department of Agriculture has allowed the
spread of a plant disease that could prove as devastating to wheat exports as
foot-and-mouth disease has been to livestock, farm groups said.

Wheat growers in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas say the USDA responded too slowly to
an outbreak of Karnal bunt at the southernmost edge of the nation's wheat belt
just as harvest was getting under way.

Karnal bunt is a fungus that is harmless to people but sours the taste and smell
of flour made from infected kernels. It also slightly cuts production in
infected fields.

The disease's main effect is economic: 80 countries ban imports of wheat grown
in infected regions.

That could be as crippling for American growers, who last year produced nearly $
6-billion of wheat, as would be the discovery of foot-and-mouth disease in U.S.
livestock, said Brett Myers, executive vice president for the Kansas Wheat
Growers Association.

The suspected Karnal bunt contamination was reported to the USDA on May 25, said
Michael Bryant, co-owner of the elevator in Olney, Texas, that found it.

But it took seven days before the USDA's Animal and Plant Inspection Service
confirmed the finding, and 15 days before it quarantined the first affected
counties.

Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Okla., has been pursuing the issue after a request from
growers for a Congressional investigation into the USDA's handling.

Rep. Condit meets

with police again

WASHINGTON - Police interviewed Rep. Gary Condit, D-Calif., a second time
Saturday in their search for a missing California woman he has described as a
"good friend."

The hourlong meeting took place mid afternoon at an undisclosed location, said
Terrance Gainer, Washington's executive assistant chief of police.

"The congressman was responsive to our inquiries," Gainer said.

But Gainer said police did not learn anything dramatic to help them in their
search for Chandra Levy, 24, of Modesto, Calif.

Gainer repeated Saturday night that Condit is not a suspect in Levy's
disappearance. But police wanted to talk to him again for any information he
might hold about Levy's habits or state of mind in the days before she
disappeared.

Levy was last seen April 30, in a Washington gym, a few days after she finished
an internship with the federal Bureau of Prisons.

Also . . .

CALIF. LOTTO HITS $ 140-MILLION: With time running out before the drawing,
people were lining up Saturday to buy what they hoped would be a winning ticket
for the biggest single-state lottery jackpot in U.S. history. Booming ticket
sales pushed the prize to $ 140-million. Early Saturday, 54,000 tickets were
being sold every minute.

AID FOR ALLISON VICTIMS: President Bush will make $ 500-million available to aid
victims of Tropical Storm Allison in five states, the White House said Saturday.
The money, to be released Monday, will be used by the Federal Emergency
Management Agency to aid people affected by the storm in Texas, Louisiana,
Florida, Mississippi and Pennsylvania.

UNIVERSITY CUTS NAZI CLASS: School officials worried that a course titled "The
Culture of Nazi Germany" would give Kennesaw State University an anti-Semitic
image have pulled the class from their fall catalog. The Georgia university has
been sued at least five times in the past decade by former professors claiming
anti-Semitism, said Ed Rugg, chief academic officer. Officials said the course
might be reintroduced for a later semester after a lengthy review.

DRUG COMPANY LOSES SUIT: One of the world's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers
lost a defamation lawsuit for misusing a woman's photo in a brochure for an AIDS
drug, prosecutors say. The woman sued Merck & Company and its New York
advertising agency, Harrison & Star, for improperly using her photograph in a
brochure for Crixivan, a drug to fight AIDS. The brochure described the woman as
a 19-year-old with two children and suggested she had contracted AIDS and herpes
through sexual promiscuity. The woman, a suburban housewife and mother in her
mid 30s, did not have herpes and contracted HIV from her husband.

9 HURT AT AMUSEMENT PARK: A ride at a New York amusement park toppled Saturday
evening, injuring nine people, police said. None of the injuries was considered
life-threatening, said Suffolk County police spokesman Mark Ryan. The ride's top
- a large disk to which swings are attached by chains - crashed to the ground
after the central column supporting the disk toppled over at Bullwinkles Family
Fun Center in Medford, about 50 miles from Manhattan. The cause of the accident
was under investigation.


EMERGENCY LANDING: A flight from Columbus, Ohio, to Hartford, Conn., made an
emergency landing in Pittston, Pa., Saturday because of smoke in the cockpit.
America West Express Flight 6583 landed at Wilkes-Barre/Scranton International
Airport about 10:30 a.m. The cause of the smoke was not immediately known, said
Benet Wilson, a spokeswoman for Mesa Airlines, which operates the flight for
America West. The Canadair CL-600-2B19 regional jet has room for 50 passengers.
No one was hurt.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: DIGEST

                    Copyright 2001 Times Publishing Company


                              177 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

               November 7, 1998, Saturday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

MORNING BRIEFING

BYLINE: From Staff And Wires Reports

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. 33, MORNING BRIEFING COLUMN

LENGTH: 364 words



Fedex pilots put off strike vote

The pilots union at Federal Express, the world's largest air express package
carrier, has delayed mailing strike ballots to 3,200 members until Monday in a
bid to restart stalled contract negotiations.

This is the second time the Fedex Pilots Association has delayed sending the
ballots. Union leaders first said they would mail ballots in October.

A union spokesman said Friday that faster electronic counting methods give the
union more flexibility in mailing. It is asking members to authorize a strike
during the peak holiday shipping season.

Pay and scheduling are the major issues in the union's bid to get a first
contract at Fedex, a unit of Memphis, Tenn.-based FDX Corp.

Illinois farmers get aid

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has begun payments worth $ 236.8 million to
Illinois farmers to help offset losses from low commodity prices. A total of $
2.8 billion is being provided to farmers across the country. The USDA plans to
announce in a few weeks other provisions of this financial aid, including
disaster-relief payments.

Consumers borrow more

Borrowing by U.S. consumers rose at a faster-than-expected pace in September as
credit-card debt and personal loans accelerated, Federal Reserve figures showed.

Borrowing rose by $ 8.4 billion to $ 1.282 trillion after rising $ 4.4 billion
during August. Before Friday's report, analysts had expected an increase of $
4.7 billion for September.

Credit statistics are a gauge of changes in consumer spending, which accounts
for two-thirds of the U.S. gross domestic product.

Emerson will raise money

Emerson Electric Co. reserved the right Friday to raise up to $ 675 million over
the next two years through the sale of debt securities. The company filed its
intention with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Emerson wouldn't specify uses for the money. But an analyst said this week that
the company was poised to pick up its acquisition pace.

The company has $ 325 million left to raise from an earlier "shelf filing." Such
filings let a company register securities in advance and sell them as needed
over a two-year period.

LOAD-DATE: November 8, 1998

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1998 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              178 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                              June 5, 1989, Monday

NINE SHIPOWNERS BID FOR FOOD RELIEF CARGO

BYLINE: MARIE PRAT; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 521 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Nine vessel owners made offers Friday in the first U.S. government public bid
opening on freight rates for food-aid cargoes.

The bid opening at the Tunisian Embassy was observed by about 16 people,
including U.S. Department of Agriculture officials and ocean carrier
representatives. The Tunisian government sought bids on transportation of about
0,000 tons of bulk wheat.

The open tender for U.S.-flag shipping lines comes after years of government and
industry criticism regarding potential conflict of interest among shipping
agents.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture unveiled the change in a final rule published
in the Federal Register April 10. The rule went into effect May 25. It requires
that all freight bids financed by the U.S. government be opened in public with
"no negotiations, clarification or submission of additional information."

In the past, bids submitted to a destination country's agents or embassy were
opened behind closed doors with negotiations on freight rates allowed. Under the
new system, the destination government and the USDA will review the freight bids
coupled with bids on the commodity to determine the lowest cost.

"It's nothing unusual," said Rene Cohen of Bingham-Bigotte & Co., a New
York-based ship broker who watched the bid opening Friday. "The only thing is
there are not going to be any c ounter-offers."

The carriers offering bids were Gulfcoast Transit Co., Tampa, Fla.; Liberty
Maritime Corp. of New York City; Marine Transport Lines of Secaucus, N.J.;
Coastal Barge Corp. of Annapolis, Md.; Lykes Bros. Steamship Co. of New Orleans;
First Attransco Tankers Co. of New York; Trans Bulk Carriers Inc. of New York;
Crest Tankers of St. Louis; and Sea Hawk Management Inc. of Houston.

The bids listed both the possible loading ports and ports of destination. In
most cases, the load ports were either U.S. Gulf Coast or East Coast. One bid
included the St. Lawrence River west of Montreal.

Observers declined to comment on the host of rates offered in the bids,
preferring to take time to analyze them.

The bids varied widely with some companies making offers on only part of the
40,000 tons available for shipment.

Each bid gave a range of rates depending on coastal range, volume and other
factors. For instance, Lykes offered a basic bid of $ 69 a gross metric ton for
2,000 tons to 3,999 tons; $ 67 for 4,000 tons to 6,999 tons; and $ 65 for 7,000
tons to 9,000 tons. The Lykes bid listed U.S. Gulf ports for loading and the
full range of Tunisian ports for discharging the cargo.

Lykes also specified that the vessel, the Genevieve Lykes, must be able to load
and discharge at other ports en route.

Glenn D. Whiteman, deputy assistant administrator for export credits in the
USDA, said the freight bids will be matched up with commodity bids to be opened
today. By Tuesday, he said, the Tunisian government will suggest a carrier.

Mr. Whiteman said the open bidding was "deemed significant by some people.
Frankly, we didn't think it was that significant."

Mr. Cohen said it could ensure that the lowest bid will get the contract.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                          November 30, 2016 Wednesday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S.
International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 277  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: 12-1NAG-17-S-0006

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: November 30, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation 12-1NAG-17-S-0006 (2000004438) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after November 29, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near December 7, 2016.



Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Janet Cleveland, Grain Marketing Specialist
janet.cleveland@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 8169262540

                              187 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           August 17, 2016 Wednesday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S.
International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 277  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INFG-S-16-0058

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: August 17, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INFG-S-16-0058 (2000004265) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after August 16, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near Ausust 24, 2016.

Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after January 5, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a

                              206 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                Birmingham Post

                            June 22, 2000, Thursday

FARM POST: POUNDS 4.7BN AID ATTACKED BY EU;
 COMMISSIONER ANGERED BY US PROMISE

BYLINE: John Duckers Business Editor

SECTION: Pg. 30

LENGTH: 540 words


European Union Farm Commissioner Mr Franz Fischler yesterday attacked a US
decision to give pounds 4.7 billion in aid to farmers, saying it conflicted with
American calls for a global cutback in farm support.

President Bill Clinton approved the aid to shield farmers from persistently low
prices.

The money was added on to legislation restructuring the crop insurance programme
at a cost to the US government of pounds 5.3 billion over six years.

'Providing supplementary support to US farmers severely undermines the
credibility of the frequent US statements on the need for a global reduction in
agricultural support,' said Mr Fischler.

He said US direct support to agriculture had increased by about 700 per cent
since 1996.

Mr Fischler's strongly-worded statement could be an opening shot in skirmishes
expected in Geneva, where World Trade Organisation talks on removing remaining
obstacles to open farm trade began in March.

'Time and again the US denounces other countries, in particular the EU, for
providing support to their farmers while at the same time, year after year, it
provides special financial packages for its own farmers,' Mr Fischler added.

By contrast, he said, the EU had passed a second major agricultural policy
reform in a decade, including a freeze on spending until 2006.

EU governments agreed last year on Agenda 2000 reforms which eroded internal
price supports for arable, beef and dairy products and compensated farmers with
higher direct-aid payments.

Mr Fischler said the EU would carefully monitor developments in US policy to
ensure it respected commitments made under the 1986-93 Uruguay Round of global
trade liberalisation talks. The EU would oppose any attempt by the United States
to circumvent its WTO spending limit by 'misclassifying' farm payments, he said.

The farm support issue has long been a sore point in the EU's relations with the
United States and the Australian-led Cairns group of major agricultural
exporting countries.

Washington regularly attacks the EU's Common Agricultural Policy, with its
annual pounds 25.6 billion budget.

Disputes over agricultural subsidies helped to sink attempts to launch a new
round of global trade liberalisation talks in Seattle last December.

Narrower WTO talks on farm trade did get under way in Geneva in March. The
United States and the Cairns group want those talks, which have no set
timeframe, to lead to the elimination of farm export subsidies, reductions in
trade-distorting domestic supports and lower agricultural import barriers.

The European Commission said the latest US aid package, together with those
approved in 1998 and 1999, amounted to more than pounds 20 billion in
supplementary aid to US farmers.

'Estimates for direct payments to US farmers this fiscal year suggest a payout
by the federal government of more than $ 32 billion (pounds 21 billion) or $
16,000 (pounds 10,660) per farmer - more than three times the average level paid
to EU farmers,' the commission said.

These payments represented only about one third of the total budget of the US
Department of Agriculture, and much of the rest was used for the direct or
hidden benefit of US agriculture, it said.

LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

               Copyright 2000 Midland Independent Newspapers plc


                              207 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                    November 17, 1994 Thursday FINAL EDITION

SACRED COW WILL THE GOP'S BUDGET SCYTHE PASS OVER FARM AID?

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A22

LENGTH: 363 words


If Newt Gingrich and his allies really want to dismantle Big Government, one
obvious step is to end federal subsidies of Big Agriculture.

Federal support for agriculture will cost about $10 billion in 1995. That's a
lot of money, and it's spread very unevenly. Wheat, rice and tobacco farmers get
aid, for example, while folks who produce beef and many vegetables don't.

The new Republican majority includes a natural leader of a push for free- market
economics in agriculture. Rep. Dick Armey of Texas, a former economics
professor, has long crusaded against "the staggering waste and inefficiency" of
"America's Soviet-style farm policy."

Mr. Armey, whose fresh thinking on budget matters has earned him influence with
his colleagues, neatly summed up the inanity of U.S. farm policy five years ago:
"While a sound economy should produce an abundance of goods that can then be
sold at a low price, our farm programs are designed to create a scarcity of
goods that can then be sold at a high price."

Alas, now that he's on the verge of real power as House majority leader, the
outspoken Mr. Armey is losing his voice on the topic of farm folly.

He announced this week that he would defer on agricultural issues - which are up
for a five-year review next year - to the new chairman of the Agriculture
Committee: Pat Roberts of Kansas, a state that produces more than a little in
the way of federally subsidized grains.

The Senate agriculture panel is as loaded down with farm-state lovers of the
status quo as the House one is.

What a letdown.

Here we were, all set to sit back and watch the revolution begin. Then, before
it even starts, the special interests win a big one.

Not perhaps what all those angry voters had in mind last week.

In their post-election rants against wasteful government spending, Mr. Gingrich
and his allies have aimed a lot of fire against welfare - by which they mean Aid
to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps and so on.

If they really want to attack waste, they also need to go after welfare for
non-needy parties, such as agribusiness.

Otherwise, they'll just be treating the voters as a bunch of rubes.

LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: EDITORIAL

                  Copyright 1994 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved

                              210 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                        The Legal Ledger (St. Paul, MN)

                               May 6, 2002 Monday

Farm bill could be cash cow for Minnesota farmers

BYLINE: David Knutson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 733 words


Congress is poised to pass a farm bill that includes $73.5 million in new
spending and covers everything from trade policy to conservation measures,
nutrition programs and aid to farmers when commodity prices are down.

A conference committee last week reached agreement on the legislation, which is
expected to be passed by both the House and Senate and signed by President Bush.

The bill is a departure from the past farm bill -- the Freedom to Farm Act --
which relied more heavily on markets and included little federal aid to
producers. Poor commodity prices in recent years have forced Congress to
appropriate billions of dollars annually in emergency aid to producers.

The new law would include counter-cyclical payments -- when prices are low,
producers receive higher payments; when they are high, lower payments are given.

"I would say it's not heaven on earth, but it's real good for Minnesota," said
U.S. Sen. Paul Wellstone, during a teleconference call with state media last
week.

U.S. Sen. Mark Dayton, who sits with Wellstone on the Senate Agriculture
Committee, agreed, calling the new bill "a huge improvement over current law."

The two senators noted that the Northeast Dairy Compact -- a longtime agreement
that critics say boosted milk prices for producers in the Northeast at the
expense of those in the Midwest -- has been changed to include a national
price-support program.

"We've been admitted into the Northeast Dairy Compact along with the rest of the
country," Dayton said.

He estimated the new program could mean as much as $12,000 more income for the
average milk producer in Minnesota, he said.

"It's the best thing that's happened to dairy farmers for a long time," Dayton
said.

The bill also includes increased spending for conservation programs such as the
Conservation Reserve Program and wetlands restoration.

For rural Minnesota, the bill should mean a significant infusion of dollars,
Dayton said.

"This is the economic stimulus bill for greater Minnesota and for the heartland
of America," he said.

For the average consumer, evidence of the new legislation will be seen on
produce they buy in the form of country-of-origin labeling. Wellstone pushed for
the labeling to be included in the final bill.

"Consumers have every right to know what they are eating and where it was
produced," he said, noting that the use of pesticides and other factors vary
greatly in crop production around the world.

Al Christopherson, president of the Minnesota Farm Bureau, said a key element in
the legislation gives producers some ability to plan.

"It gives us a little degree of certainty as to what is going to transpire next
year," Christopherson said. "Lenders are always interested in that certainty."

Much of the debate in recent months over the farm bill involved regional
differences, he noted.

The dairy compact is an example, he said, of sections of the country wanting to
protect or do away with the status quo.

"We have felt for a long time that the dairy compact really favored the
Northeast and to some extent the South and was a disadvantage to us,"
Christopherson said. "The long and the short of it was that dairy policy needed
to be overhauled."

Other differences also came into play, he said.

Generally, southern farm operations tend to be much larger than those in the
Midwest, Christopherson said. As a result, there was some effort to limit their
eligibility for federal payments.

"(But) in the Midwest we were concerned that if indeed you had limits in the
South, you force them out of cotton and rice and into corn and soybean and then
into competition with us," he said.

Kristin Weeks-Duncanson, vice president of the Minnesota Soybean Growers
Association, said the farm bill is only part of the good news out of Washington
recently.

The energy bill recently passed by the Senate would require American refiners to
triple their use of ethanol by 2012. Minnesota soybean farmers rotate their
crops with corn.

But Christopherson -- who grows corn and soybeans and raises hogs on his farm
northwest of Willmar -- tempered his enthusiasm for the pending legislation.

"I've farmed for 30 years," he said. "I don't know that there has ever been a
farm bill deemed successful while we've been a part of it. It seems like the
success of a farm bill rises or falls depending on how the next farm bill treats
you."

LOAD-DATE: March 27, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Government activity

                      Copyright 2002 Dolan Media Newswires
                                All Rights Reserved


                              211 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     August 3, 1999, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Farmers get emergency drought aid

BYLINE: Gary Fields

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 347 words

DATELINE: CHARLES TOWN, W. Va.


CHARLES TOWN, W. Va. -- Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman declared
88 counties in six mid-Atlantic states federal disaster areas
Monday, making farmers enduring the worst drought since the 1930s
eligible for low-cost loans.

The emergency declaration includes all 55 counties in West Virginia
and 33 counties in Kentucky, Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania and
Virginia.


Rainfall in those states has been about 14 inches below normal
for the past year, leaving fields dry and crops stunted. Adding
to the problems is a heat wave in parts of the Midwest and Northeast
that has been blamed for at least 218 deaths since July 19.

The disaster declaration makes farmers in the 88 counties eligible
for low-interest loans that would cover up to 80% of their losses.

Agriculture Department officials said other counties in those
states could be added to the list, along with parts of Connecticut,
New Jersey, Indiana, Massachusetts, Tennessee, New York and Delaware.

Glickman said low prices along with the drought are creating a
"double whammy" for farmers. He said the Clinton administration
and Congress would work to develop a long-term plan to give farmers
"a safety net" that includes more crop insurance and price relief.

West Virginia Agriculture Commissioner Gus Douglass estimated
that the state's 21,000 farmers have lost $ 100 million because
of the drought. He said 10% of them would go out of business as
a result.

Joe Hottel, who raises corn, wheat, soybeans and hay on his 8,500
acres in Burkittsville, Md., said the answer is not more loans
from the federal government. "We need higher prices or something
to get us through these times," he said.

Hottel said corn sold for $ 2.95 a bushel in 1974, and the price
now is $ 2.10. During the same period the cost of a combine has
increased from $ 35,000 to $ 210,000.

"I'm 57 and I've got some land, and now I'm borrowing against
the equity in my land to pay my farm loans," he said.

"I've got some major decisions to make in the next year. Do I
want to keep going?"

LOAD-DATE: August 03, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, Color, Roberto Borea, AP; Withered: Drought-stunted corn in
Frederick, Md.

                              212 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

              December 16, 1993, Thursday, North Suncoast Edition

Trial postponed for teens in rest-stop tourist killing

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; STATE DIGEST; THE STATE; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 476 words

DATELINE: MONTICELLO; PENSACOLA; JACKSONVILLE; MIAMI; PLANTATION



A circuit judge Wednesday postponed to March the trial of four teenagers
accused of killing a British tourist at an interstate highway rest stop. The
trial, scheduled for Jan. 29, was pushed back to March 29. The defense lawyer
predicted even that date would not hold up.

County to let students leave school for religious training

PENSACOLA - Escambia will become the second county in Florida to give high
school students the option of leaving campus an hour daily for religious
instruction. Brevard was first. The hour will come out of non-academic time
under a policy the School Board adopted Tuesday. Classes will be conducted by
churches or other religious groups on their own property.

Gun buyback program to

try statewide expansion

JACKSONVILLE - A gun buyback program is going statewide on Dr. Martin Luther
King Jr.'s birthday next month. Bob Ingram, a leader in the Black Issues  Forum,
said Wednesday that the Jacksonville organization has been asked by the  Florida
General Baptist Convention to help set up a statewide program. In  Jacksonville,
individuals who turn in workable guns are paid $ 25, no questions  asked. The
guns are then turned over to the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office.  Since June,
about 1,000 guns have come in.

Computers used for AIDS network are stolen, erased

MIAMI - Two hospital security guards have been arrested in the in-house theft
of desktop computers bearing the records of 7,000 people who receive  AIDS
-related services. One of the stolen computers was sold to an unsuspecting
buyer; another was being used in the home of one of those arrested, police
said. Both hard drives, which carried the AIDS program information, had been
erased. AIDS activists feared the confidential information could be used
against the patients served by the South Florida AIDS Network. However, both
suspects, Edgardo Chacon-Diaz and Robert Gonzalez, denied they knew what was  in
the computers.

Gas cheat checks

Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford fills a gasoline can Wednesday in
Tallahassee as he announces the state will seek fines from three South Florida
stations that have been cheating customers. Crawford advised consumers to call
(800) 435-7352 to report suspected fraud.

One person killed, two wounded at car dealership

PLANTATION - Three men opened fire in a used car dealership Wednesday night,
killing one employee and wounding two other people, police said. The finance
manager of City Auto Repo Sales was killed and his wife wounded in the attack.
She was apparently at the business to pick up her husband after work. The
firm's sales manager also was wounded. Police did not release the names of the
victims. The suspects may have planned to rob the dealership, police said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE

Crawford fills a gasoline can Wednesday in Tallahassee

TYPE: DIGEST

                            Times Publishing Company


                              213 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             March 15, 1999, Monday

Farmers won't get relief aid until June

BYLINE: BY JANELLE CARTER

SECTION: COMMODITIES/CHEMICALS/ENERGY; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 480 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Farmers counting on $2 billion in congressionally approved disaster aid will
have to wait until June to get it, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said.

In a letter sent last week to Senate Agriculture Chairman Richard Lugar and
House Agriculture Chairman Larry Combest, Mr. Glickman said administering the
aid is ""far more complex than past natural disaster assistance programs.''

And he said the agency is inundated with aid disbursements during this
tumultuous farm year, including assistance packages of $50 million for hog
farmers and $200 million for dairy farmers.

""Getting these payments out as expeditiously and as fairly as possible is a top
personal priority for me,'' Mr. Glickman wrote Mr. Combest, R-Texas, fired back
that the delay was ""unacceptable.''

""There are now billions of dollars that should already be in the hands of
farmers and ranchers,'' Mr. Combest said, noting that farmers need the money as
they go into the planting season.

Many in Congress have complained that USDA is moving too slow in administering
aid to farmers. Congress approved the money as part of a $6 billion emergency
package late last year amid free-falling commodity prices. Prices have done
little to rebound since then - making some members of Congress angry at the slow
dispersal process.

Rep. Bill Barrett, R-Neb., has accused the agency of ""foot-dragging.''

""To see delay after delay stack up while our producers are in need of
assistance is unacceptable,'' Mr. Barrett said early this month.

Mr. Glickman said one of the things complicating the disbursement is that it
covers farmers who have suffered crop losses over several years before 1998 or
who had losses only in 1998.

""USDA must go through one additional step of determining which will pay the
applicant more before issuing final payments,'' he said.

Lawmakers on both sides of the Capitol, meanwhile, spent Wednesday looking at
ways to overhaul a crop insurance program for farmers, even while acknowledging
an uphill battle for money.

The USDA unveiled details for between $2 billion to $2.5 billion worth of
reforms, including raising coverage, making higher-level coverage more
affordable and covering multiyear disasters as well as livestock. Several
lawmakers have introduced proposals as well.

""Our proposal is specific and it is designed to fill the most glaring crop
insurance voids,'' Mr. Glickman said in a statement. ""It will make crop
insurance more affordable and worth buying.''

But it won't be easy as Congress faces pressure to use budget surpluses for
Social Security and Medicare. ""I've got to figure out what the tide will
bear,'' Mr. Lugar, R-Ind., said of attempts to get money.

About 79 GOP lawmakers sent a letter to House Budget Committee Chairman John
Kasich last week urging him to address crop insurance in his committee's budget
resolution.

LOAD-DATE: March 15, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1999 Journal of Commerce, Inc.

                         Morris Daily Herald (Illinois)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            March 24, 2016 Thursday

State Rep. Anthony talks about agriculture education funding cuts

BYLINE: Heidi Litchfield, Morris Daily Herald, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 390 words


March 24--MORRIS -- The proposed Illinois budget for fiscal 2017 that Gov. Bruce
Rauner put forward showed the funding for agricultural education zeroed out,
upsetting many in the agriculture education industry.

According to a news release sent by Jess Smithers, state coordinator of
Facilitating Coordination in Agricultural Education, 25 percent of all jobs in
Illinois are directly or indirectly related to agriculture.

"This proposed cut comes just as the demand for agricultural teachers is
exceeding the supply from out state universities by over 32 a year," the release
stated.

Andrew Bowman, chairman of the Illinois Leadership Council for Agricultural
Education, said in the release that the organization acknowledges the need for
drastic action on the part of the state government, but it strongly is opposed
to the agricultural education cut.

State Rep. John Anthony, R-Joliet, a member of the House Agriculture Committee,
said he supports agriculture education.

"I support ag education in the classroom 100 percent and I have personally
donated thousands of dollars to support local FFA chapters in my district,"
Anthony said.

He said he reached out to the governor's office after hearing concerns from
residents and said the governor is not eliminating funding for agriculture
education -- he instead is proposing giving the power back to each school
district to decide which specialized education is important.

"The governor hasn't eliminated funding for ag education," Anthony said.
"Instead, he's giving power back to our communities by taking all specialized
funding, including ag education, and pooling it into General State Aid."

General State Aid has not been paid 100 percent to school districts since 2009.
According to data from Illinois State Board of Education, pre-oration has paid
GSA to schools between 87 percent and 99 percent for fiscal 2010 through 2015.

Anthony said the governor's plan would fund General State Aid at 100 percent,
increasing local control.

"It's also worth noting that the governor's proposal includes a funding increase
for the cooperative extension, which support our 4-H program and other ag
education initiatives," Anthony said.

___ (c)2016 the Morris Daily Herald (Morris, Ill.) Visit the Morris Daily Herald
(Morris, Ill.) at www.morrisdailyherald.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.
