                               The New York Times

                July 17, 1986, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. TO TEST FOR TIE BETWEEN AIDS AND SWINE FEVER

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 5, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 540 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16


Federal medical researchers said today that they were preparing to test the
blood of AIDS patients for the presence of African swine fever in an effort to
prove or disprove a disputed theory that the lethal disease in humans is somehow
related to the swine virus.

They said they were also preparing to test blood serum collected from pigs in
Belle Glade, Fla., for the presence of the human AIDS virus as a result of a
disputed report that antibodies to the African swine disease were found in a
single pig there.

''The question of whether these two viruses are somehow related has come up
repeatedly for several years,'' said Dr. Harold Jaffe, chief of the epidemiology
branch in the AIDS program at the Federal Centers for Disease Control in
Atlanta. ''We feel the work that has been done does not support either African
swine fever playing a role in human AIDS or that the human AIDS virus can infect
swine. But it was our feeling that we should try to do some experiment that
would be definitive.''

Dr. Jaffe said a test for diagnosing swine fever in pigs would be adapted to
humans, and a test for diagnosing acquired immune deficiency syndrome in humans
would be adapted to pigs. He said the testing could begin before the end of the
month and the results should be ready several weeks later.

Theory Raises Controversy

Since 1983 a controversial theory about the cause of AIDS, based largely on
visual evidence, has been advanced by Dr. Jane Teas, a pathobiologist who was
formerly at the Harvard School of Public Health. In a letter to the British
medical journal Lancet, Dr. Teas suggested that African swine fever be
investigated as the possible cause of AIDS because the symptoms of human AIDS
patients closely resembled those of pigs infected with chronic African swine
fever.

Though the vast majority of AIDS researchers insist that the theory has no
scientific basis, it continues to attract attention among a small group of
scientists and homosexuals, who along with intravenous drug abusers are the
major group affected by AIDS in the United States.

Last year, Dr. John Beldekas, a biochemist at the Boston University School of
Medicine, tested the blood of AIDS patients and found evidence of the swine
fever virus in half the samples. Last September, the New York State Department
of Health tested blood from healthy donors and found that 4.5 percent of the
samples contained antibodies to the swine fever, indicating that the people
could have been exposed to the disease.

African swine fever, one of the world's most devastating livestock diseases, has
never been found in North America, according to the Department of Agriculture.
Last May, Dr. Beldekas reported finding antibodies to the virus in the blood of
a single pig from a farm in Belle Glade. After testing the blood from more than
150 animals on two farms near Belle Glade, the Agriculture Department concluded
that there was no swine fever in Florida.

Dr. Teas said today that she was worried that scientists from the Federal center
were pursuing the research with a predetermined conclusion. ''I worry that
people in Atlanta know absolutely nothing about pigs and that they are being
forced to do this for political reasons,'' she said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo of Dr. Harold Jaffe (AP)

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company


                              216 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 23, 1991, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grain Prices Surge on Hope Of Further Aid for Soviets

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 18; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 394 words


Grain and soybean futures prices rose strongly yesterday after President Bush
raised hopes for new food aid to the Soviet Union by declaring "nobody is going
to starve" there this winter.

Wheat for December delivery rose 5 3/4 cents on the Chicago Board of Trade to
settle at $3.60 3/4 a bushel, a 17-month high. December corn ended 3 3/4 cents
higher at $2.54 1/4 a bushel; December oats rose 3/4 cent, to $1.34 1/4 a
bushel, and November soybeans climbed 8 cents, to $5.55 1/2 a bushel.

Mr. Bush received a Soviet request for emergency food aid yesterday from
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan, who recently visited the Soviet Union.

The President said he had not decided how much help he would approve but added
that the United States was open to humanitarian aid.

"Nobody is going to starve, and people are not going to be adversely affected in
their health for lack of medicine," Mr. Bush said.

The remark bolstered perceptions among grain traders that more United States
grain would soon be headed for the Soviet Union.

"It was taken as meaning we're going to feed them no matter what they need,"
said John Frazier, director of agricultural commodities trading with Gerald Inc.
in Chicago.

Mr. Bush also said, however, that he wanted to consult with United States allies
before offering aid to the Soviets.

Energy Prices Off

Energy futures dropped on the New York Mercantile Exchange, making traders
wonder whether a monthlong rally had run its course.

A sharp drop in November crude oil deliveries may have been exaggerated,
however, by the contract's expiration. Oil to be delivered later fell more
modestly.

November crude dropped 56 cents, to $23.48 a barrel; November home heating oil
fell 0.72 cent, to 69.46 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline slipped 0.21
cent, to 65.23 cents a gallon, and November natural gas tumbled 10.3 cents, to
$1.910 for 1,000 cubic feet.

Livestock and meat futures finished mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in
advance of two Agriculture Department reports.

The quarterly cattle-on-feed report showed a 6 percent decline in the number of
cattle being fattened for slaughter on feedlots on Oct. 1 compared with a year
ago. It was the largest third-quarter decline on record, and live cattle futures
prices were expected to react by rising as much as 1/2 cent a pound today.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                       May 22, 2003 Thursday CITY EDITION

BUSH SAYS EUROPE HINDERS AID EFFORTS
FAMINE, AIDS ARE NEGLECTED, PRESIDENT SAYS

BYLINE: RON HUTCHESON,Washington Bureau

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 475 words


NEW LONDON, Conn. -- President Bush took the offensive against America's
prickliest allies Wednesday, accusing European nations of hindering the fight
against famine and not doing enough to combat AIDS.

The tough talk, a week before Bush meets with European leaders in France for a
summit of the world's leading economic powers, signaled he isn't ready to soothe
hard feelings over his handling of the war in Iraq. Relations with France and
Germany are in a tailspin, and polls indicate that anti-American sentiment is
sweeping Europe.

Without mentioning any specific countries, Bush challenged European leaders to
follow his lead in spending more to fight AIDS in Africa. The House of
Representatives gave final approval Wednesday to Bush's $15 billion, five-year
plan for AIDS research and treatment in Africa and the Caribbean.

In a commencement speech at the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, Bush said he intended
to remind European leaders next week that "the clock is ticking" on AIDS and
urge them to "match their good intentions with real resources." The annual Group
of Eight summit of select industrialized democracies brings together leaders
from the United States, Canada, France, Germany, Britain, Italy, Russia and
Japan.

In Washington, one European Union official, who asked not to be identified
because he wasn't authorized to quarrel publicly with the U.S. president,
nonetheless expressed dismay.

"We've been involved in development in Africa for a long time, and I think we
are probably the major donor of all forms of aid to Africa," the E.U. official
said.

Bush used harsher language in criticizing European agriculture policies,
asserting that European opposition to genetically engineered crops could prolong
famine in Africa.

The European Union has banned the importation of genetically altered crops --
soybeans, corn and other plants that have been altered to thwart pests and
disease -- because of health and environmental concerns that Washington contends
are groundless.

U.S. agriculture companies have taken the lead in biotechnology, and the United
States filed papers last week asking the World Trade Organization to declare the
ban illegal. Advocates of genetic engineering say it can help end famine by
increasing crop yields, but many developing nations are reluctant to try it for
fear that they would be unable to export their agricultural products.

"We have the ability to confront this suffering. ... Yet our partners in Europe
are hindering this effort," Bush said. "European governments should join -- not
hinder -- the great cause of ending hunger in Africa."

He said Europe's concerns about genetically altered crops stemmed from
"unfounded, unscientific fears."

The E.U. official said European governments didn't counsel African nations about
importing genetically modified food.

LOAD-DATE: July 28, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Copyright 2003 St. Paul Pioneer Press
                              All Rights Reserved

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

               June 24, 2000, Saturday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Agriculture official says Florida is a disaster area

SOURCE: From wire reports

SECTION: CITY & STATE; AROUND THE STATE; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 142 words



Farmers in 59 of Florida's 67 counties, including every county in the Tampa Bay
area, are eligible for emergency, low-cost federal loans after agricultural
disaster areas were declared Friday in parts of four states by U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Dan Glickman.

Glickman announced the federal action in Florida, Alabama, Nebraska and New
Mexico.

In Florida, Glickman declared 41 counties agricultural disaster areas, then
listed 18 adjoining counties as equally eligible for benefits offered under the
federal disaster declaration program.

Farmers and ranchers have eight months to apply for the loans to help cover part
of their losses.

Included in the disaster areas were Citrus, Hernando, Hillsborough, Manatee and
Sarasota counties. Pinellas County was one of the 18 adjoining counties also
eligible for benefits.

                              219 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                Birmingham Post

                          September 30, 1999, Thursday

EU MINISTERS ADOPT AGGRESSIVE APPROACH TO WORLD TRADE TALKS

SECTION: Pg. 28

LENGTH: 397 words


European Union Agriculture Ministers will go on the offensive to defend the
bloc's farm policy in the forthcoming round of global trade negotiations.

Finland, which holds the EU presidency, drew up a six-page document on the EU's
agriculture position to be passed on to EU Foreign Ministers when they meet on
October 11.

"The fact we have reached agreement with unanimity will be very important ahead
of Seattle," said European Farm Commissioner Mr Franz Fischler.

The next World Trade Organisation round, the Millennium Round, will begin in
Seattle in November.

The United States and the Cairns Group of farm exporters, which includes
Australia and New Zealand, have pledged to make agriculture a main focus and
attack the Common Agricultural Policy, which they view as a trade-distorting
anachronism.

EU Ministers have already mapped out a two-pronged strategy for the talks -
defending already agreed farm reforms and attacking what it perceives as
weaknesses in other countries' policies.

The EU has said it will hit back at US use of export credits and the existence
of commodity monopoly agencies, such as the Australian Wheat Board, among Cairns
Group members.

"The Council sees a need to take an offensive line within the forthcoming WTO
negotiations. It is imperative to introduce discipline on the use of export
credits," said the document drawn up by Finland.

It also said appropriate solutions must be found to other less transparent forms
of export support - including state trading and the provision of food aid.

US and Cairns Group criticism of the CAP is likely to centre on the EU's use of
export subsidies to compensate farmers for the difference between high internal
prices and lower world market levels, and its use of direct aid payments to
farmers.

The policy paper said it was essential the EU be allowed to continue its direct
aids, which were expanded under the recently-agreed Agenda 2000 reforms.

Any further reductions in its export subsidies would have to be matched by other
parties giving ground elsewhere.

Despite a public show of unity among EU Farm Ministers, some countries -
including Britain, Sweden and Denmark - are more disposed towards free trade and
wanted to keep the EU's negotiating stance as flexible as possible. France had
pressed for a more robust declaration to defend farm policies.

LOAD-DATE: October 1, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

               Copyright 1999 Midland Independent Newspapers plc


                              220 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           August 1, 1990, Wednesday

FOOD AID COST IS UNDER FIRE FEE-HANDLING SEEN AS ISSUE

BYLINE: ROSE A. HOROWITZ; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 532 words


Critics of the system for shipping U.S. government-financed food aid cargoes
point outthat competing loyalties among the small community of agents and
brokers that represent recipient countries can drive up the cost of the program.

More money spent for ocean freight financing can mean less money for buying ood,
U.S. officials said.

Two years ago, the U.S. Department of Agriculture asked the U.S. attorney for
Washington, D.C., to investigate an alleged conflict of interest on the part of
Star Trading & Marine Inc., the biggest agent in the Food for Peace program.
That case, which is still under investigation, and other cases involving country
agents raise similar concerns, said David Dickson, director of the
investigations division at the USDA.

"The basic issue with this case and with several others over the years is, are
fees being mishandled? . . . and conflict of interest," he said in an interview.

Including three current cases, the USDA inspector general's office has conducted
about nine investigations concerning conflict of interest, commission payments
and other problems in the Food for Peace program since 1976, the office said.

One government official questioned why the USDA hadn't suspended or barred Star
Trading because of concerns about particular transactions, even though there
have been no criminal indictments yet.

"We were instructed by the IG (inspector general) to take no action until
(there's) a verdict," said Glenn Whiteman, deputy assistant administrator for
export credits at the USDA. He also said the USDA general counsel advised the
administrators that an agent in the program can't be barred without evidence of
guilt.

Country agents in the Food for Peace program often harbor competing loyalties.
Many agents in the program not only represent foreign countries and shipping
companies, but also may perform or help arrange discharging services, bagging
and stevedoring services.

They often collect money through a chain of services starting from the time a
ship leaves a U.S. port to its arrival and discharging of its food cargoes at a
foreign port, shipping executives and government officials said.

"When they arrange transportation, which hat are they wearing?" Mr. Dickson
asked.

Investigators also have examined commissions received by country agents that are
channeled back to an arm or agency of the foreign government, Mr. Dickson said.
The agents are appointed by a foreign country, subject to approval by the
Foreign Agricultural Service, an arm of the USDA.

"Is the 2.5 percent being used as a kickback?" M r. Dickson asked. The 2.5
percent figure is the maximum commission allowable under USDA regulations for
U.S.-flag ships.

On the Star Trading case, the Justice Department "asked for a number of
additional steps, which we're currently working on," said Mr. Dickson. "It's not
over by any means," said another key government official.

The criminal investigation of Star Trading grew from an earlier two-year study
by the USDA, following complaints from Star's competitors that the company had a
conflict of interest and should be suspended from acting as agent. Star has
denied the allegations.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: FOOD FOR PEACE? FOOD FOR PROFIT? United States of America.

on Saturday at its Destination Wellness health resource center, the Galleria at
Pittsburgh Mills, 590 Pittsburgh Mills Circle, Frazer. Part one runs from 9 a.m.

child and infant CPR, choking relief and automated external defibrillator AED
usage, running from 1 to 4 p.m. Cost: $35 per person for each part, $50 for
both. To register, call 724-274-5202.

disabilities. Call 412-221-3302 ext. 124.

                            Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

                                 SOONER EDITION

HEALTH HAPPENINGS

BYLINE: Rick Nowlin / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

SECTION: MAGAZINE; Pg. D-2

                              223 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      July 15, 1988, Friday, City Edition

Reagan urges speedy drought aid // President consoles farmers

SOURCE: New York Times; Washington Post

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 636 words

DATELINE: DAVENPORT, Iowa



DAVENPORT, Iowa - After touring corn and soybean fields stunted by    weeks of
searing heat, President Reagan urged Congress on Thursday to    swiftly pass
drought relief legislation.

     Reagan said any new bill should provide disaster relief to all    farmers
affected by the drought, including those who grow such crops as    soybeans,
fruit and vegetables that normally do not qualify for federal    subsidies.

     "I'm calling today for Congress to act quickly on comprehensive    drought
relief, disaster relief for all farmers, for all crops,"    Reagan said here at
a local Chamber of Commerce luncheon.

     The president also announced that he had directed Agriculture    Secretary
Richard Lyng to visit 10 parched states next week to look at      farms, rivers,
and forests.

     "From Montana to Texas, from California to Georgia and right here    in
Illinois, farms face the worst national disaster since the Dust Bowl    of the
1930s," Reagan said on Thursday in Du Quoin, Ill. before    traveling to
Davenport. "The heartland of America desperately needs    more rain. We can't
make it rain but we can help to ease the pain."

     This trip was important for Reagan not only for its political    signal to
Farm Belt voters, whose support will be critical to a    Republican victory in
the fall, but also for its personal significance    to him.

     Later, he returned to station WOC here and recalled how he was    hired to
broadcast college football games, at $ 5 a game plus bus fare    from his home
75 miles east in Dixon, Ill.        In a speech to a Chamber of Commerce group
here, Reagan noted that    WOC's motto was "Where the West Begins and the Corn
Grows Tall." But    he said had seen that the crops were not growing this year
and appealed    to Congress not to clutter a relief measure with unnecessary
amendments.

     Reagan traveled by helicopter from the Williamson County Airport in
Marion, Ill. to the Herman Krone farm in Du Quoin, about 100 miles    southeast
of St. Louis, and had an aerial view of crop damage as well    as a walk through
corn and soybean fields.

     "Having been born and raised in this part of the country, in the    state
of Illinois, I know how these fields would usually be at this    time of year,"
he said, standing in a field of stunted corn as the    2 mid-morning temperature
hovered near 100 degrees.

     The president made his remarks as the Senate panel gave its    tentative
approval to a $ 6-billion drought relief bill. The House    Agriculture
Committee tentatively passed a similar, $ 4-billion measure.

 Both panels planned to take another look at the legislation when    Congress
returns July 26.

     "This is a very significant safety net on which our farmers can    count at
this time," Richard Lugar of Indiana, the senior Republican    on the Senate
Agriculture Committee, said of his panel's bill. "On    average, farmers will
receive about 50 percent of the value that would    have been expected from
their crops."

     Lugar estimated that the Senate measure would cost $ 6.5-billion to    $
7-billion, but Senate Agriculture Committee aides said the cost could    run as
high as $ 8-billion.

     The House Agriculture Committee said its plan would cost about    $
2-billion less than the Senate version. Cost figures in both cases are    only
estimates because lawmakers do not have all the crop information    that must be
taken into account in working out the payment formulas.

 - Information from the Washington Post was used in this report.

son, Rick, show President Reagan stricken corn in their farm field

                              224 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

               June 21, 2000, Wednesday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Clinton okays aid for farmers

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: NATIONAL; IN BRIEF; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 529 words



President Clinton released a flood of money to farmers Tuesday, signing a $
15-billion package of cash payments and insurance subsidies that represents the
third big bailout of the agricultural economy in as many years.

The legislation ignored his administration's proposals to overhaul the
market-oriented farm program enacted by the Republican-controlled Congress in
1996.

The bill includes $ 8.2-billion to expand and cut the cost of federal crop
insurance over the next five years and $ 5.5-billion for payments to grain and
cotton growers this fall. An additional $ 1.6-billion is earmarked for other
farmers and lawmakers' special projects.

Largest state dinner

honors Moroccan King

Drum rolls and trumpet fanfare greeted King Mohammed VI of Morocco to the White
House on Tuesday. The king ended the day at the largest state dinner of the
Clinton administration.

Former Indianapolis 500 winner Bobby Rahal made the guest list of 425. Others
include: Rachel and Sharon Robinson, the widow and daughter of baseball great
Jackie Robinson; Washington Redskins owner Daniel Snyder; actor Ted Danson; sex
therapist and talk show host Ruth Westheimer; singer and dancer Paula Abdul;
actors Carol Alt and Teri Garr; and Alma Brown, the widow of former Commerce
Secretary Ron Brown.

The dinner ended with an orange sherbet dessert called "A Moroccan Oasis." The
sherbet was scooped from a circular band of white chocolate painted to resemble
a building with Moroccan architecture.

Also . . .

NO CUBA COMMISSION: The Senate on Tuesday thwarted an attempt by several
lawmakers to create a commission to re-evaluate U.S. policy toward Cuba with an
eye toward normalizing relations.

The commission proposal, an amendment to a defense authorization bill, was
rejected 59-41. Florida Sens. Bob Graham, D, and Connie Mack, R, both opposed
the 12-member commission.

 Mack and Graham were among many lawmakers who said that it was the wrong time
to create a commission with a presidential election looming on the horizon. The
commission's recommendations, they argued, could restrict the decisions of the
next president.

TOBACCO SUIT FUNDS RESTORED: Reversing a vote lawmakers took just one day
earlier, the House decided Tuesday not to block a significant source of funding
for the Justice Department's lawsuit against the tobacco industry. The House
accepted by voice vote an amendment to allow the Department of Veterans Affairs
to spend $ 4-million from general administration accounts.

MISSILE SHIELD TEST SET: The Pentagon set a July 7 target date for a $
100-million test of an anti-missile shield, while leaving open the possibility
that Defense Secretary William Cohen could recommend proceeding with deployment
of the controversial system by 2005 even if the July test fails.

MEDICARE PAYMENTS: President Clinton on Tuesday proposed increasing Medicare
payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, as
evidence grew that cuts made in 1997 had harmed the quality of care around the
country. Clinton asked Congress to increase payments to providers by $
21-billion in the next five years and by $ 40-billion over 10 years.

                               The New York Times

                 June 10, 1999, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

William Hess, 82, Microbiologist and Expert on African Swine Fever

BYLINE: By ERIC NAGOURNEY

SECTION: Section B; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 360 words


William R. Hess, a microbiologist and a leading expert in African swine fever,
died on May 29 at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. He was
82, and lived in Tuftonboro, N.H.

Dr. Hess spent his life researching how to prevent and control the kinds of
diseases that, if unleashed, can quickly ravage populations of domesticated
animals.

He was often abroad; but when he was not, he worked at the Animal Disease
Center, a top-security facility run by the United States Department of
Agriculture on Plum Island, off the North Fork of Long Island.

For years, recalled his son Brian, Dr. Hess would drive from his home in East
Marion, on the North Fork, to Orient Point, for the nearly two-mile commute by
boat to the island.

Plum Island is home to a collection of some of the most infectious animal
diseases in the world, and the Government goes to great lengths to insure that
they are not inadvertently carried to the mainland. Employees there work in
"negative pressure" laboratories designed to stop pathogens from escaping and
are required to disinfect themselves at the start and end of their work day.

Dr. Hess's speciality, African swine fever, is a rapidly spreading, usually
deadly disease found in pigs. Its presence has never been confirmed in North
America.

Dr. Hess worked on Plum Island from 1953 to 1988. In the mid-1980's he was part
of a team of scientists called upon to investigate a theory that the disease
might have a connection with AIDS. Some scientists said they had seen a
correlation between swine fever outbreaks and incidents of AIDS in Africa and
Haiti. But the theory was ruled out.

"We agreed that there was no connection between these two viruses," Dr. Hess
said in 1986.

Dr. Hess, who was born in St. Paul, received his doctorate from the University
of Minnesota. He traveled extensively in South America, Africa and Asia, and,
with his family, lived in Kenya for three years starting in 1960.

In addition to his son Brian, of New York, he is survived by his wife, Caroline;
another son, Robert, of Sag Harbor, N.Y.; two brothers, Lewis and Joseph, and
four grandchildren.



http://www.nytimes.com

NAME: William R. Hess

                              226 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     June 23, 1988, Thursday, Final Edition

Farm Drought Aid Plan Drafted;
Task Force, White House Agree on Package for Distressed Farmers

BYLINE: Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21

LENGTH: 534 words


A bipartisan congressional task force and the administration agreed yesterday on
outlines of a plan to provide federal aid to farmers affected by the drought
that is spreading across the Farm Belt.

Most of the package entailed disaster assistance that Agriculture Secretary
Richard E. Lyng is authorized by law to provide. The plan stressed that the
government should protect farm and ranch incomes "in an efficient and equitable
manner" and that consumers should be assured of a continued adequate food
supply.

Rep. E (Kika) de la Garza (D-Tex.) and Sen. Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.), chairmen
of the House and Senate agriculture committees, indicated that the outline would
be amended to deal with drought problems as they develop.

Much of the wheat crop in Montana, North Dakota and Minnesota is in poor shape.
Crop and pasture damage extends from the northern Plains states through the
Midwest and parts of the South.

Lyng and the Agriculture Department's chief weatherman, Norton D. Strommen, gave
the task force little hope that the dry, searing weather would break soon.
Strommen said he could foresee little relief from the intense heat and dryness
parching the Midwest as the corn crop enters a crucial period.

"Corn will be approaching the critical stage in the early part of July. The next
two weeks will be critical, and on through July," he said. "There is a longer
window for soybeans. Soybeans can be planted after wheat is harvested, but they
need two inches of rain to establish themselves."

Lyng added, "This could be, if this weather continues, such a catastrophic thing
that rural communities could suffer severe [economic] damage."

Leahy, sharply criticizing food processors and retailers against using the
drought as a pretext to raise prices, warned that Congress would watch the
situation.

Leahy noted that in recent days both beef prices and pork prices have been
declining. "Food retailers need to be aware that we are watching," Leahy said.

Leahy said that food prices eventually will rise as the drought reduces farm
output. But he called it "selfish, unreasonable, dishonest, misleading" for food
merchants to seek "windfall profits" from the disaster.

Task force members, noting that livestock producers have been hit hardest and
earliest by the drought, urged Lyng to use his authority to provide
government-owned grain at reduced rates and to expand another cost-sharing feed
purchase program.

Lyng earlier took other steps to allow haying and grazing on land removed from
production to reduce surpluses or to enhance soil conservation.

Sen. Richard G. Lugar (R-Ind.) urged the secretary to use special care in
determining which farmers may eventually be designated for financial aid. "There
are certain sections of all of our states that have been favored with rain," he
said. "I hope we can fashion equitable income protection and not an overlay of
money for everybody."

Lyng said such steps were taken to compensate drought victims in 1986 in the
Southeast. He also gave assurances that any administration aid plan would
include "nonprogram" farmers, such as dry bean and vegetable growers, whose
crops receive no federal price support protection.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

STUNTED CROP NEARS A CRUCIAL PERIOD IN EARLY JULY. UPI

                              The Washington Post

                    November 29, 1991, Friday, Final Edition

H.M. Gabbert Dies at 85;
AID Official

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C7; OBITUARIES

LENGTH: 598 words


Howard Markland Gabbert, 85, a retired official of the Agency for International
Development, died of complications following stomach surgery at a hospital in
Tucson. A Washington resident from 1956 to 1989, he lived in Green Valley, Ariz.

Mr. Gabbert retired in 1969 as associate coordinator of the Food for Peace
program. He was with AID for eight years. Before that, he was director of the
State Department's food resources division and a private consultant in
California.

He began his career in 1931 as a soil scientist with the U.S. Department of
Agriculture in California and Oregon. He continued that work with the State
Department, for which he worked until 1954 on development projects in Paraguay
and El Salvador and as director of U.S. operations in Costa Rica.

He then worked as a private consultant until joining the Foreign Operations
Administration, a predecessor to AID. He joined the latter agency when it was
organized in 1961.

Mr. Gabbert was a native of Ventura, Calif., and a graduate of Stanford
University. As a young man, he was the leader of a jazz orchestra that toured on
the cruise ships of the old Dollar Steamship lines in the Far East.

His first wife, Marjorie Gosnell Gabbert, died in 1988.

He is survived by his wife, Marie Hampton Gabbert of Green Valley; three sons
from his first marriage, Howard M. Gabbert II of Tucson, James J. Gabbert of San
Francisco and J. Stephen Gabbert of Alexandria; and six grandchildren.

SID L. SCHWARTZ

Filmmaker

Sid L. Schwartz, 79, a retired filmmaker with the Department of Agriculture, the
Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Energy, died of a heart attack
Nov. 18 at the Ramses Hilton Hotel in Cairo. A resident of Silver Spring, he was
on vacation when he was stricken.

Mr. Schwartz was born in New York City. He attended St. John's College. He was a
publicist and broadcaster in New York until World War II, when he served in the
Army Air Forces as a photographer and filmmaker.

After the war, he worked for an Air Force filmmaking unit in New York. In 1949,
he joined the Department of Agriculture and moved to the Washington area. He was
a scriptwriter and director at Agriculture until 1965, when he transferred to
the Atomic Energy Commission as deputy chief of the audiovisual branch.

After the commission was abolished in 1974, he worked for the Energy Research
and Development Administration and then the Department of Energy. He retired in
1979.

Mr. Schwartz was a member of Temple Israel in Silver Spring, the Anti-Defamation
League of B'nai B'rith and the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.

Survivors include his wife of 55 years, Sylvia Schwartz of Silver Spring; a
daughter, Ellen C. Schwartz of Ann Arbor, Mich.; a brother, Noel Schwartz of
Nesconset, N.Y.; and two grandchildren.

BRIDGET MARY JONES CASEY

Hairstylist

Bridget Mary Jones Casey, 93, a retired hairstylist and a member of the parish
of St. Ann's Catholic Church in Washington, died of heart and lung ailments Nov.
8 at the Sacred Heart Home in Hyattsville.

Mrs. Casey was born in County Tipperary, Ireland. She came to the United States
in 1923 and settled in Washington.

She joined the staff of Emile's Beauty Salon in Washington when she arrived. She
became the chief hairstylist, and she was known professionally as "Miss
Beatrice." Her clients included Evelyn Walsh McLean, owner of the Hope Diamond.
She retired in 1977.

Her husband, Raymond Paul Casey, whom she married in 1929, died in 1957.

Survivors include a daughter, Noreen Casey Emerson of Bethesda; and 11
grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: OBITUARY

                              228 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               July 16, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

SENATORS SAY ADMINISTRATION DEEPENS CRISIS IN AGRICULTURE

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 375 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15


Farm-state senators from both parties said today that the Reagan Administration
was sending American agriculture into a deeper economic depression by failing to
activate provisions in the new farm law designed to increase agricultural
exports.

''This committee passed a bill out of here last year that was keyed to
increasing our exports,'' said Senator Mark Andrews, Republican of North Dakota.
''Unfortunately, this has not happened yet, and we want to know why. Without
those exports, this law is not going to work.''

The criticism indicated the growing uneasiness on Capitol Hill over the gloomy
prospects for reducing the nation's huge grain surplus, which depresses prices.
The comments came at a hearing of a Senate agriculture subcommittee on
international food aid programs and world hunger.

Daniel G. Amstutz, Under Secretary of Agriculture for International Affairs and
Commodity Programs, one of four Administration trade officials who testified,
said putting the new export trade provisions into place was far more complex
than simply shipping food to hungry nations.

The Administration, he said, seeks to use food exports as an economic stimulus
in developing countries. The farm law, he said, allows developing nations to
sell part of the food aid in their own currencies, with the proceeds used to
improve food production and distribution.

Export Subsidies in Law

Mr. Amstutz said such policies were preferred by many developing nations over
direct grants of food. ''These countries are afraid of the problems sudden
supplies of food aid can have on their own economies,'' he said.

The farm program that became law last year contained the most aggressive
strategy for increasing grain exports in United States history. The law sharply
lowered the prices the Government guarantees for wheat, corn, soybeans, rice,
cotton and other crops in order to make American grain more competitive in
international markets.

The law also provided the Department of Agriculture and the State Department
with financing plans and subsidies to develop new markets in developing
countries and to persuade cash customers like Japan to buy more American food.

But in May the nation had its first monthly deficit in farm trade in 15 years.

                      The Easley Progress (South Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            July 27, 2016 Wednesday

Farmers urged to apply for grants

BYLINE: The Easley Progress, S.C.

SECTION: ENTERTAINMENT NEWS

LENGTH: 478 words


July 27--PICKENS COUNTY -- Farmers in Cherokee, Pickens and Oconee counties can
apply for South Carolina Farm Aid grants through Sept. 6 to help offset losses
due to the October 2015 flooding.

On July 20, the federal Farm Service Agency informed the S.C. Department of
Agriculture that the three counties qualify along with the previously announced
42 counties.

"When we heard this news, we immediately went to work to make farmers in these
counties aware of their eligibility," said Hugh Weathers, S.C. Department of
Agriculture. "Our goal is to help as many farmers as possible recover from the
devastation we saw in October."

The application and more information is available at http://agriculture
.sc.gov/SC-farm-aid/.

"Agriculture is very important to Pickens County. During last October's
excessive rain and flood events, the farmers of South Carolina experienced one
of the worst disasters seen in their industry," said Rep. David Hiott, chairman
of the S.C. House of Representatives Agriculture, Natural Resources &
Environmental Affairs Committee. "However, because of the SC Farm Aid program,
qualified farmers will have an opportunity to seek relief, and I highly
encourage farmers from Pickens and Oconee Counties to submit an application to
help recover uninsured crop losses."

The S.C. General Assembly approved $40 million in state aid to help farms in
flood-ravaged communities. Farmers can receive grants covering 20 percent of
their crop loss up to $100,000.

"While this won't make our farmers whole, we hope through this relief funding,
they can begin to recover," Weathers said.

To be eligible for the grant, farmers must have experienced a verifiable loss of
affected agricultural commodities of at least 40 percent as a result of the
October 2015 flooding; have a farm located in a USDA disaster declared South
Carolina county; and have a U.S. Department of Agriculture-Farm Service Agency
issued farm number.

Applicants will also be required to sign an affidavit, under penalty of perjury,
certifying that loss information is accurate.

Producers who have already submitted an application, but have additional farms
in Cherokee, Pickens, or Oconee counties, should contact SCDA.

To help farmers apply for assistance, the Clemson University Cooperative
Extension Service and SCDA will conduct regional educational workshops in
Cherokee, Pickens and Oconee counties. For workshop details and registration
information, visit agriculture.sc.gov/sc-farm-aid/educational-sessions/.

For complete application instructions and to access the application PDF form,
visit agriculture.sc.gov/SC-farm-aid/.

For more information about Farm Aid or to be put in contact with Farm Aid staff,
call Megan Heidkamp with SCDA at 803-734-2210.

___ (c)2016 The Easley Progress, S.C. Visit The Easley Progress, S.C. at
www.theeasleyprogress.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                               The New York Times

                          September 24, 2003 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

U.N. Official Plans to Urge U.S. to Reconsider Its Food Policies

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 468 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23


Jacques Diouf, the director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture
Organization, dedicated to helping solve the world's hunger problems, knows he
has a hard sell on Capitol Hill.

Mr. Diouf is here on a visit from his Rome headquarters, trying to keep alive
the issues that stalled trade talks in Cancun, Mexico, last week. Like many at
the talks, he wants Congress and the administration to reconsider the nation's
annual $22 billion in farm subsidies, which make it hard for farmers in poorer
countries to compete.

But he also wants to make a separate, difficult point: that the United States'
generosity with food aid sometimes undermines countries' abilities to feed
themselves.

The United States provides 41 percent of the food aid distributed by the United
Nations. But in an interview at his agency's Washington offices, Mr. Diouf said
hunger could be better fought if money were spent to help poor farmers dig wells
and canals for irrigation and lay better roads to bring crops to market.

"Giving money to farmers before a crisis is better than giving food after the
crisis hits," he said.

In the last 15 years, as rich countries increased their subsidies to their
farmers and slashed aid to the world's poorest farmers, poor countries have gone
from net exporters of food to net importers. With 70 percent of poor countries'
populations dependent on agriculture for their livelihoods, the change has
helped fuel a rise in malnutrition. In places like sub-Saharan Africa, one out
of three people suffer chronic hunger.

Mr. Diouf will meet with officials including Senator Richard G. Lugar,
Republican of Indiana, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee; Andrew S.
Natsios, administrator of the United States Agency for International
Development; and Ann M. Veneman, secretary of agriculture.

But there is no immediate legislation before Congress, and both Republican and
Democratic politicians are publicly rejecting much of the criticism leveled at
the United States by the developing nations at Cancun. With the 2004 election on
their minds, many lawmakers said they were disinclined to question the
subsidies.

Mr. Diouf, an agricultural economist, said he would remind the lawmakers of the
cold war era, when presidents like Ronald Reagan spent as much as $1.3 billion
every year to help farmers around the world. Today, the United States gives some
$400 million to that effort.

But the resistance to his various messages may be high. At a Congressional
hearing today, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said he saw a bigger
problem in tariffs imposed on imports by some poor countries, which make the
exports of other poor countries less affordable.

"The vast bulk of market access barriers faced by farmers in developing
countries are imposed by other developing countries," he said.

                              231 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                           October 20, 1994, Thursday

Around the South Delta pinning hopes on massive U.S. aid Area along Mississippi
is nation's poorest

BYLINE: By Jim Yardley STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 3

LENGTH: 668 words


Lake Providence, La. - Hope is a fragile brick to build on here. The blighted
stretch of boarded-up stores and shattered windows comes to a dead end at the
Mississippi River. The few open shops - a bakery, a discount store - survive
like dandelions sprouting from a cracked sidewalk.

This town - where seven of 10 children grow up poor, where grandmothers leave at
daybreak to dig potatoes for minimum wage - is the archetype of intractable
rural poverty. The Census Bureau ranks it one of the poorest spots in America.

Yet these days, that may be good news. "If they're looking for people in
poverty," said retiree Carl Bonner, "they can't overlook us."

"They" are the U.S. Department of Agriculture, which as early as Nov. 8 will
designate three communities as "rural empowerment zones." The three winners will
each bask in $ 40 million of federal aid and benefit from tax breaks targeted to
attract new industry.

Thirty other applicants will receive "enterprise community" status, which brings
just under $ 3 million each in benefits. The application process, emphasizing
local initiative and control, has drawn comparisons with foreign aid programs
for Third World countries.

"It's geared to the regions of the country that have been and currently are
economically disadvantaged," said Jim Brownlee of USDA.

Nationally, of the 221 communities or agencies that applied for the grants,
nearly two-thirds (143) are from the South, including the Alabama Black Belt,
South Georgia's lower Chattahoochee region and eastern Kentucky's hardscrabble
Appalachian counties.

"The bottom line is jobs and business development," said USDA Undersecretary Bob
Nash. "[Rural America] has been off the radar screen, out of sight and out of
mind. The television crews don't go there unless somebody kills somebody or
there's a catastrophe."

Perched on the western edge of the Mississippi Delta, Lake Providence is in the
heart of the poorest region in the country. Louisiana recently surpassed
Mississippi as the poorest state in the nation with more than 26 percent of all
families living below the poverty line. The rate in East Carroll Parish, which
includes Lake Providence, is nearly twice the state average.

The city's application is in conjunction with nearby Eudora, Ark., and
Greenville, Miss., which, not coincidentally, are the home states of President
Clinton and USDA Secretary Mike Espy, who will select the winners before
resigning in December. Locals hope some "home cooking" will help their cause.

Politics aside, Robbie Gibson said the application process has helped restore a
measure of hope in Lake Providence. Gibson, the city's coordinator for the
proposal, said "quality of life leaders" went door-to- door asking residents
about problems and solutions. To energize the effort, organizers will sponsor a
"Rally Against Poverty" tonight in Greenville and a Saturday march culminating
in Lake Providence.

If chosen, organizers plan to pump resources into education, health care,
housing, transportation and business development. Two outside manufacturing
companies, anticipating tax breaks, are considering building plants in East
Carroll. Money also would go to widening La. 65 to four lanes and building a
bridge over the Mississippi River.

Many residents support the grant application, but they blame the government for
lingering problems, particularly a welfare system they say discourages marriage
and work. "We've got to develop a new work ethic and show there's a better way
of life than drawing a welfare check," said Bonner, who believes new industry is
the answer.

Jeralene Evans, 53, earns $ 4.25 an hour bagging potatoes in Arkansas, not
including the $ 5 she pays for her round-trip ride. The seasonal work swells the
arthritis in her knees, but without it she could not survive on her $ 112
monthly food stamp allotment. She hopes Lake Providence catches a break.

"We work to keep the lights on," she said. "There's no economy or nothing here.
This town is dead."

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              June 19, 1987 Friday

Nelson plans Farm Aid concert

BYLINE: GREG McCUNE; REUT

LENGTH: 517 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


BY  GREG McCUNE
 Reuter
  WASHINGTON
 WILLIE NELSON , wearing customary faded jeans, sneakers, and hair in a
ponytail, told Congress yesterday he plans another Farm Aid concert this
fall to raise money for farmers because the situation in rural America is
still deplorable.

Appearing with rock star John Cougar Mellencamp at a Senate Agriculture
subcommittee hearing, Nelson said farmers tell him the rural crisis is
deepening and politicians should do something about it.

Nelson, who raised $8-million (U.S.) for farmers at two previous Farm
Aid concerts, said he hopes to hold a third Sept. 19 in Lincoln, Neb.

'We've still got a crisis on our hands. We're still losing hundreds of  family
farms a day. Rural businesses are closing. Schools and hospitals in  rural areas
are shutting down. A record number of agricultural banks are  in financial
trouble,' the entertainer said.

But the two musicians' claim that the farm situation is worsening runs
counter to new government forecasts which predict net farm income will
rise slightly this year, thanks mostly to massive government subsidies,
and agricultural exports are starting to recover after a five-year slump.

To the contrary, Nelson said the rural crisis centres, telephone
hotlines and other social services funded in 40 states by the proceeds
from Farm Aid are still flooded with appeals for help.

But Nelson and Mellencamp, who in the past have been accused of siding
with farm populists such as Iowa Democratic Senator Tom Harkin against the
Reagan administration, tried yesterday to stay out of the heated partisan
political battle over the direction of U.S. farm policy.

'I'm not here to get behind any one farm proposal,' Nelson told the  hearing.

But politicians knew a good photo opportunity when they saw it.
Senators Harkin and John Melcher, a Montana Democrat, unabashedly posed,
smiling with Nelson and Mellencamp for television cameras.

And the Democratic senators endorsed Nelson's call for a 'fair price'
for farmers.

Not to be outdone, Republican Senator Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota tried
a little free market economics on Nelson.

'The marketplace in your industry, music, has been good to you,' he  told the
highly successful Nelson. 'And I think the marketplace will work  in agriculture
.'     Nelson and Mellencamp said they don't claim to be politicians, but have
seen evidence of the deterioration in rural America.

'The country used to be the place to go if you wanted to live a quiet,  stable
life. Today, that stability is gone for many rural Americans. It  has been
replaced by fear and heartbreak,' Nelson said.

Mellencamp, who is living this summer in South Carolina, added that in
the south the condition of black farmers is deplorable.

'It's shocking. It's this nation's embarrassment. These black farmers  don't
have a chance,' he told the hearing.

Mellencamp said some people turn to him for help because they are
desperate to save failing farms.

'I've got people calling me up wanting me to loan them money,'  Mellencamp said.

'It's like . . . what is this? You (the senators) are supposed to be  the
experts.'

                      Bladen Journal, Elizabethtown, N.C.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            September 5, 2014 Friday

Farm Aid T-shirt highlights Carolina cotton

BYLINE: Bladen Journal, Elizabethtown, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 377 words


Sept. 05--RALEIGH -- Showcasing the need to find more sustainable, soil-friendly
cotton sources, Farm Aid has announced a partnership with Cotton of the
Carolinas to bring concertgoers a special edition organic Farm Aid T-shirt that
is grown, made and sold in the Carolinas.

Farm Aid brings attention to the challenges farmers face in bringing us good
food and fiber.

Farm Aid 2014, which takes place at Walnut Creek Amphitheatre on Sept. 13, will
feature performances by Farm Aid President and Founder Willie Nelson and board
members John Mellencamp, Neil Young and Dave Matthews with Tim Reynolds, as well
as Jack White, Gary Clark Jr., Jamey Johnson, Preservation Hall Jazz Band, North
Carolina's own Delta Rae, Lukas Nelson & Promise of the Real, Carlene Carter,
Todd Snider, Insects vs. Robots, Raelyn Nelson Band and Jesse Lenat.

By tracing and telling the story of the entire supply chain, Farm Aid seeks
transparency from farm to table and from dirt to shirt. To learn more about the
process and pre-order a shirt, visit: www.farmaid.org/NCShirt.

Farm Aid also is working to highlight stories of family farmers as they seek to
produce the best product while protecting natural resources. The creation of
this shirt supports more than 500 jobs in a little less than 750 miles. In
addition to the special edition T-shirt, Farm Aid highlights other stories
through demonstrations and products at the HOMEGROWN Village and HOMEGROWN
Concessions®.

Farm Aid's mission is to build a vibrant, family farm-centered system of
agriculture in America. Farm Aid artists and board members Willie Nelson, Neil
Young, John Mellencamp and Dave Matthews host an annual concert to raise funds
to support Farm Aid's work with family farmers and to inspire people to choose
family farm food.

Since 1985, Farm Aid, with the support of the artists who contribute their
performances each year, has raised more than $45 million to support programs
that help farmers thrive, expand the reach of the Good Food Movement, take
action to change the dominant system of industrial agriculture and promote food
from family farms.

(Elizabethtown, N.C.) at www.bladenjournal.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                          September 17, 1992, Thursday

COBB AT WORK Name: Laura Mauldin

BYLINE: Dana Dratchprofiles; personalities; food; aid

SECTION: EXTRA; Section G; Page 9

LENGTH: 293 words


Age: 65

Home: Marietta:

Occupation: Case manager and U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) food
coordinator for the Cobb County Emergency Aid Association Inc.

Nature of the job: "I coordinate food drives and go to the food bank to buy
food. I also do case management - working one-on-one with families, trying to
prevent homelessness."

Background: A former Sunday school teacher and regional distribution manager for
Scott Graphics, she was unemployed after her company relocated to Texas six
years ago. So she answered a newspaper ad to volunteer to work in a program that
became the first Cobb County USDA food distribution. Later, when the food
coordinator was leaving, she got the job. "The corporate world works totally
differently from the non- profit world. The pay is about a third or less. And
this job a lot more emotional."

Worst part of the job: "The restrictions. We can only operate within the
guidelines, which I respect. But with the limitations that we have with money
and resources, we depend on the community for support. We have been cut again by
Cobb County - that's going to hurt. Any time we lose resources, it cuts what we
can do for our clients."

Best part of the job: "Seeing the light come back into a person's face when the
hope comes back. To see a family become self-sufficient. And the excitement on a
child's face when they get a box of Cheerios, and you know they've been looking
for those Cheerios for a long time. I love this job and all facets of it. It's
like everything I've done all my life has brought me to this job."

Quote: "One of the neatest things about this line of work is the people you get
to know. People involved with meeting the needs of people are sensitive and are
great to work with."

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH922660288

left) food coordinator Laura Mauldin, Stephanie Johnson and Emily Myers, prepare
a food package for a needy family./ JOE McTYRE / Staff

                              235 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 12, 1986, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

REAGAN TO OFFER AID FOR FARMERS

BYLINE: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 855 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11


On a trip to Illinois Tuesday to garner farm state support for Republican
candidates, President Reagan will announce plans to increase fees paid to
farmers for storing surplus grain, Administration sources said today.

The measure, increasing the fees by almost 20 percent, would raise the incomes
of thousands of farmers in the Middle West and elsewhere who are anticipating
near record harvests of wheat, corn and other grains.

It would add from $200 million to $300 million to the costs of the Federal farm
program, which is anticipated to exceed $30 billion this fiscal year, according
to an estimate by the House Agriculture Committee. It was unclear immediately if
new Federal funds would be provided or if the money would come from existing
programs.

In addition, Mr. Reagan will announce that he is instructing the Agriculture
Department to provide adequate and immediate assistance to farmers in 10
Southern and Middle Atlantic states hard pressed by drought.

The Administration, under Congressional pressure, announced relief measures Aug.
1 that provide farmers with cash and other assistance. But Democrats in Congress
criticized the package because much of the aid was to go to regions not stricken
by drought.

The measures are the latest attempts by the Reagan Administration to ease
political and other concerns about the depression in American agriculture.

White House political officials acknowledge that they are concerned about
election prospects in the farm states, which they have said are crucial to
Republican hopes for maintaining control of the Senate. Mr. Reagan plans to make
at least 14 trips on behalf of Republican hopefuls from now to November,
including several to farm areas.

Senator James Abdnor, Republican of South Dakota, informed tonight of Mr.
Reagan's expected announcement, said it was ''clearly a step in the right
direction, but it is not going to solve the biggest problem we have, and that is
finding some space for all of the crops that we're harvesting.''

Asked if the announcement would help Republicans in farm states, Mr. Abdnor, who
is in a tight re-election campaign against Representative Thomas A. Daschle,
said: ''It certainly shows someone is being sympathetic. But I don't think it's
enough to win an election.''

Speech at State Fair

The initiatives are contained in a speech that Mr. Reagan will deliver Tuesday
at the Illinois State Fair in Springfield on a visit to raise money for Gov.
James R. Thompson, a Republican who is running for re-election.

Two weeks ago, Mr. Reagan authorized the sale of subsidized wheat to the Soviet
Union under a proposal in which American grain traders could receive subsidies
totaling $52 million. The program was designed to increase American wheat
exports and to help alleviate surplus conditions that have kept wheat prices
low.

Economists say a principal reason for the farm crisis has been plummeting
exports. The Administration's farm law, signed last December, was designed to
reverse the slide in export sales, but has had little effect.

Meanwhile, farmers have harvested a huge wheat crop, and are about to harvest a
near-record corn crop, which will be piled into grain elevators and other
storage areas where most of last year's crop remains.

The latest program would also involve an effort to address the grain surplus
problem, but would take a different tack. Many of Mr. Reagan's senior aides,
including Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W.
Weinberger, criticized the decision to subsidize the Soviet wheat sale, which
also drew an outcry from some American allies like Canada and Australia.

Mr. Reagan's new proposal, which had been advocated by legislators from farm
states, would try to reduce the financial burden for farmers who must store
large grain surpluses.

Currently, the Federal Government pays 26.5 cents for every bushel of grain
stored on farms. Mr. Reagan's new proposal would raise the storage fee to 31
cents a bushel, Administration officials said.

The Agriculture Department has estimated that the cost of storing more than 2
billion bushels of wheat and 5 billion bushels of corn, along with millions of
bushels of other commodities, could total $1.5 billion this year. The increase
in Government fees could raise storage costs substantially above that level.

Mr. Reagan has also been considering other relief proposals, including one
measure that provides grain farmers with income support payments months in
advance for crops to be harvested in late 1987.

Other Grain Sales Considered

In addition, Mr. Reagan has been considering directing the Agriculture
Department to pursue more aggressively the sale of grain overseas by making use
of several export-enhancing provisions of the 1985 Farm Act.

White House officials said that Mr. Reagan's assurances to provide drought
assistance do not reflect a new initiative, but underscore his concern and his
willingness to provide whatever Federal aid is needed.

''He will say that we will make every effort to try to speed up and better
coordinate what we are doing,'' one official said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company


                              236 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                           January 20, 2007 Saturday

County added to state list for freeze aid

BYLINE: Truong Phuoc Khánh, Mercury News

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 300 words


Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Friday added Santa Clara to the list of counties
declared to be in a ``state of emergency'' because of this week's sub-freezing
weather.

The proclamation allows the state, on behalf of farmers with crop damage, to
request expedited assistance for federal aid from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture and the Small Business Administration.

The governor had earlier declared a state of emergency in 10 counties: Fresno,
Kern, Kings, Madera, Merced, Monterey, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Tulare
and Ventura. On Friday, Imperial, San Bernardino, San Diego, Santa Clara,
Riverside and Yuba were added, bringing the list to 16.

Santa Clara County agriculture commissioners had sent the governor's office
information to document the extent of crop damage, but said they did not yet
have a dollar amount.

``We are gathering the reports of damage as they come in,'' said Kevin O'Day,
deputy agriculture commissioner for the county. ``What is difficult at this time
is much of the damage is not visible or apparent.''

Freeze damage to row crops like lettuce and broccoli, O'Day said, won't appear
for a couple of more weeks. An Arctic mass of cold air brought four consecutive
days of record low temperatures to the Bay Area earlier this week. Among the
state's record lows: 17 degrees in King City on Jan. 13; 27 degrees at Moffett
Field in Mountain View on Monday morning; and 25 degrees below zero Sunday
morning at Bodie State Park, northeast of Yosemite.

The state estimates that farmers will sustain more than $1 billion in damage to
crops. However, the freeze may benefit others: Deciduous trees, like cherry and
apricot, O'Day said, need ``chilling hours'' below 45 degrees in order to bloom
in the spring.

Contact Truong Phuoc Khánh at tkhanh@mercurynews.com or (650) 688-7505.

LOAD-DATE: January 20, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              238 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     March 4, 1993, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Gephardt shifts on campaign reform

BYLINE: Leslie Phillips; Marilyn Greene

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 652 words


House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt appears to be softening his position on a
key, but volatile, element of Democratic campaign finance reform: the public
financing of congressional campaigns.

Gephardt, D-Mo., said in an interview that public funding was never the central
issue of reform, unlike reducing spending limits and political action committee
contributions. Public financing is the best inducement to bring adherence to
voluntary spending limits, Gephardt said, but "there are other ways" to
encourage compliance.

Reduced rates for mailing and TV advertising were "the main inducements to get
the limits accepted," he said.

The idea of public financing has House and Senate members balking. When
President Clinton is calling for shared sacrifice, no one wants to inform the
public it must also pay for campaigns. "The case has never been well made to the
public," said Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., a key player in campaign reform. "What's
in it for them?" _ Leslie Phillips

RUSSIAN AID: Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., who has a tighter grip on the nation's
aid purse strings than almost any other lawmaker, today will warn Senate
colleagues that the U.S. faces a return to the Cold War unless it beefs up
assistance to Russia. "I think it's certainly the most crucial area in the use
of foreign aid," Leahy says. "And
when you consider the stakes, it's the most neglected."    Clinton

has proposed increasing current U.S. aid to Russia from $ 410 million
to $ 700 million.    The current aid program for Russia "has not been

a success," says Leahy, who heads both the Senate Agriculture Committee _ which
dispenses agricultural credits, and the Appropriations subcommittee on foreign
operations, which administers
foreign aid.    Russia is in default $ 415 million to the United

States, which co-signed for $ 4 billion in loans. The United States could, Leahy
says, "end up paying far more aid than we ever agreed
to; and we end up with a destabilized country."    He wants the

United States to redistribute and possibly reduce its $ 15 billion aid budget,
focusing more on Russia and less on traditional big recipients _ including
Israel and Egypt. His plan may fall on deaf ears, says Leahy, but not for long:
"You may be able to push through one more foreign aid bill on the basis of
inertia. But you won't get through more than that." _ Marilyn Greene

HEALTH-CARE BILLS: Liberal lawmakers introduced a bill to scrap private health
insurance and have the government pay all medical bills, a system like Canada's
that President Clinton's health task force reportedly has rejected. The plan
wouldn't touch veterans benefits and the Indian Health Service. It would be
financed by higher payroll taxes and income taxes.

Also, three members of Congress said they'll introduce a bill to raise the
24-cent federal tax on cigarettes to $ 1 a pack and use the money for health
care.

And Hillary Rodham Clinton, who heads her husband's health reform task force,
said in Little Rock that it's too early to outline what Clinton will propose by
his self-imposed May deadline.

She added, "The problem is so complex with so many different facets to it that I
can understand why other people have looked at it and thrown up their hands in
despair and walked away from it."

BRIEFLY: The Senate approved a $ 5.7 billion bill to extend unemployment
benefits to the long-term jobless, adding a freeze on congressional pay. The
House, which passed a bill without the pay freeze, will take up the measure
today. . . . The House voted to soften Hatch Act restrictions on political
activities of nearly 3 million federal workers. Under the bill, federal workers
could participate in campaigns and run for local offices in off-duty hours. A
Senate filibuster is expected over the proposed legislation.

                           Star News (Wilmington, NC)

                          September 14, 2006 Thursday

Damage figures not high enough for federal aid, officials report

BYLINE: Mark Schreiner

SECTION: LOCAL/STATE; Pg. 1b

LENGTH: 517 words


Raleigh | Tropical Storm Ernesto's bill is running about $80 million and is
expected to grow.

But the combined value of damage to homes, businesses, farms and governments
doesn't approach the thresholds that would trigger federal aid for the affected
region, state and local officials said.

Preliminary figures pegged damage from the late August storm to homes at $2.2
million and business losses at $1.3 million. Only Duplin County, where damage to
homes exceeds $315,000, appears to be potentially eligible for federal loans.

Initial reports put Ernesto's cost to the local and county governments at
$565,000. It's unlikely the figure will rise to more than $9 million, which is
what's needed to bring in federal aid to city halls and county government
buildings.

On Wednesday, state agricultural officials raised their estimate of farm damage
from Ernesto to $76 million from $58 million. It appeared that while extensive,
the damage is likely not severe enough to bring emergency aid from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.

Figures so far are incomplete, said Bryan Beatty, head of the state's public
safety department.

"Until this week, the water was still too high, in some places, to do the
assessments," Beatty said. "But still, it appears we will be under the
threshold."

There is no complete estimate yet on what Ernesto cost the state government. On
Wednesday, the N.C. Department of Transportation said it was still compiling
what it will cost to repair the damage floodwaters did to roads and bridges.

Once figures are complete, Gov. Mike Easley will have decisions to make. If
damage doesn't reach federal thresholds, he may declare a state disaster in the
affected counties. If that happens, the state government will pay 75 percent of
repair and reimbursement costs. The money would likely come from the state
government's contingency account, known commonly as the "Rainy Day Fund."

Eligible residents could apply for aid at recovery centers that would be set up
in the affected counties.

Ernesto was no Fran or Floyd. Fran, which hit the state 10 years ago this month,
left $5.2 billion in damage in North Carolina. Hurricane Ophelia, a Category 1
storm from 2005, did about $70 million in damage.

Ernesto damaged crops and livestock most.

The storm killed at least 44,000 chickens and turkeys, stripped tobacco leaves
that were ready for cutting and drowned corn that was to be harvested soon. The
true extent of the damage may not be seen for some time.

"You won't know until we get a harvest in," said Warren Hepler, the U.S. Farm
Service Agency agent for Southeastern North Carolina. "Peanuts and sweet
potatoes are underground, and you don't know they're damaged until you pull them
up."

Damage found in Hyde and Sampson counties, as well as additional damage to
vegetable and tobacco crops in Duplin County, accounted for the change.

Meanwhile, damage assessment crews were out Wednesday in Pender and Duplin
counties, taking another look at how Ernesto affected homes and businesses.
Revised figures are expected later this week.

Mark Schreiner: (919) 835-1434

mark.schreiner@starnewsonline.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
