                              240 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 4, 1988, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Drought-Stricken Farmers Applying for Aid

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 742 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3


Farmers began signing up for payments today under a $3.9 billion benefits
package to aid victims of the summer drought.

''The telephones have been real busy all morning with calls from people asking
for appointments,'' said James Anderson, director of the Agricultural
Stabilization and Conservation Service office in Brown County, S.D.

The Agriculture Department agency is in charge of parceling out aid under the
program President Reagan signed into law on Aug. 11 to offset losses among
farmers from a drought that reduced the nation's harvest by an estimated 31
percent.

Brisk business was reported at the agency's offices in the northern Plains
states, where the drought wrecked the spring wheat crop. In most places, though,
there was no stampede on the first day of a long sign-up period scheduled to
last until March.

'A Production-Loss Program'

Across the Middle West, many farmers were still in their fields harvesting what
was left of their crops after the drought. Only after they are finished will
they know the full extent of their losses - prerequisite for receiving benefits
under the program.

''It's a production-loss program,'' said Dale Hertlein, executive director of
the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service office in Fayette
County, Ohio. ''To know exactly what the guy has lost, he will have to finish
harvesting first.''

Terence G. Harman, the agency's state executive director in Texas, said quiet
prevailed at most of the agency's 239 county offices.

''We're in harvest in a lot of the crops down here, so we're involved in a lot
of other things rather than standing in line,'' he said, adding that he thought
there would be ''a gradual trickle'' of farmers applying for the benefits in the
months ahead.

Cost Remains Uncertain

The agency has county offices nationwide, and in some cases farmers who have
finished their harvest can do much of the ''paperwork'' of applying for benefits
on computer terminals in those offices. Sometimes, farmers can obtain a check on
the day they apply for the aid. In other cases, the length of the wait varies.

The cost of the assistance remains uncertain, although officials say it could
exceed the $3.9 billion price estimated when the measure won Congressional
approval.

Among the highlights for eligible producers are these:

LIVESTOCK AID - Livestock producers with an annual gross revenue of less than
$2.5 million can get either half of their feed costs from the Government or
surplus grain owned by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation
at discounted prices.

Those eligible are producers of cattle, sheep, goats, swine, poultry, horses,
mules and donkeys used for food or in the production of food, and fish used for
commercial food production.

CROP AID - Crop producers with a gross annual revenue of less than $2 million
can receive payments for losses exceeding 35 percent of normal production. They
are eligible for aid equal to 90 percent of losses in excess of 75 percent of
normal production.

Producers are also eligible for assistance equal to 65 percent of losses from 35
percent of normal production to 75 percent. These losses are calculated on the
basis of ''payment rates'' set by the Agriculture Department and which vary from
one crop to another.

This is how some of the payment rates will be set:

* For crops participating in farm programs, such as wheat, feed grains, cotton
and rice, the payment rate will be the target price, a figure set by Congress,
adjusted by the Secretary of Agriculture and normally used to calculated
''deficiency,'' or income support, payments for farmers.

* For nonparticipating program crops, the rate will be the county rate for
price-support loans.

* For tobacco, the rate will be the national average price-support loan rate for
the type of tobacco involved.

* For sugar beets and sugar cane, the rate will be ''a level determined by the
Secretary to be fair and reasonable'' in relation to 1988-crop price supports
for beets and cane.

* For soybeans and nonprogram crops, the rate will be the average commodity
price received in the state for the previous five years, not counting the high
and low years.

Among other provisions, an owner of 1,000 or fewer acres of trees planted for
commercial purposes will be eligible for 65 percent Federal assistance if losses
of the 1987 or 1988 tree seedlings are greater than 35 percent, adjusted for
normal mortality.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company


                              241 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   February 22, 2001 Thursday, Final Edition

NATION IN BRIEF

SOURCE: From our news services

SECTION: News; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 580 words


Dad watched suspect flee, police say The father of one of two teenage suspects
in the stabbing deaths of two Dartmouth College professors waited about eight
hours before notifying police that his son had fled, according to court
documents. John Parker watched his 16-year-old son drive away from their
Chelsea, Vt., home in his mother's car about 3 a.m. Friday, then followed the
boy to the home of Robert Tulloch, 17, according to an arrest warrant affidavit
released Wednesday.

The affidavit, signed by New Hampshire State Police Sgt. Robert Bruno, says the
father then returned home and found a note from his son asking him not to alert
police.

Parker placed a call to the New Hampshire State Police about 11 a.m., according
to the affidavit, triggering a manhunt for the teens, who were arrested Monday
at a New Castle, Ind., truck stop.

James Parker remained jailed Wednesday in Indiana. Tulloch, meanwhile, was
arraigned in Lebanon District Court on two counts of first-degree murder in the
Jan. 27 slayings and was ordered held without bail. He is expected to enter a
plea at a hearing next week.

Half Zantop, 62, taught earth sciences at Dartmouth; his wife, Susanne Zantop,
55, was chairwoman of the German studies department.

New HIV vaccine being tried on humans Pharmaceutical manufacturer Merck & Co.
has begun a small-scale human trial of a new experimental HIV vaccine, The Wall
Street Journal reported today. The vaccine has been able to prevent laboratory
monkeys exposed to an extremely virulent strain of the disease from contracting
it, the newspaper quoted sources as saying. The company would not discuss
details of the laboratory trials, but said it began testing the vaccine in
healthy, uninfected volunteers last week. At least a dozen companies are
experimenting with possible HIV vaccines. Merck officials said they plan to
present their findings at a scientific forum in April. They already presented
data to a closed-door session with the National Institutes of Health advisory
committee on AIDS vaccine and another session with AIDS activists, the newspaper
said.

Forestry officials fear wildfire danger Devastating winter ice storms that
pummeled three states and left thousands of mangled trees littered across the
region could be the source of yet another disaster: wildfires. Forestry
officials in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Texas fear a potential summertime inferno on
hundreds of thousands of acres where trees were snapped and shredded by the
storm. "I don't think it's a question of if. That fuel's on the ground. We'll
have a hot, dry summer, if not this year, the next," said Pat McDowell,
assistant director of the forestry division at the Oklahoma Department of
Agriculture. Texas estimates 80,000 acres of damaged pine forests have increased
risk for wildfires. Arkansas has timber on more than 200,000 acres that was
damaged. Wildfires blackened about 7 million acres in the United States last
year, with the majority of damage occurring in the West.

Porn fan charged after using store's VCR Police in York County, Penn., said a
man walked into a Wal-Mart electronics department, popped a porn tape into a VCR
and started watching. An employee at the store said the suspect had two other
porn tapes with him. The store worker held the man until police arrived. Robert
Nelson was charged with displaying explicit sexual material and could get five
years in prison if convicted. Store officials had no comment.

LOAD-DATE: February 23, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Brief

                    Copyright 2001 The Atlanta Constitution


                              242 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                          September 14, 2006 Thursday

BYLINE: CRYSTALR. REID Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 591 words


Floods, frost damage, torrential rainfall, hail and severe drought put North
Dakota on a federal natural disaster list Wednesday.

The secretarial natural disaster designation was issued for the entire state of
North Dakota on Wednesday afternoon, officials announced, after the state's
congressional delegation last week urged the secretary of agriculture to clear
the way for emergency loan programs.

Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns stated in a letter to Gov. John Hoeven that
losses due to the combined effects of extreme weather warranted the natural
disaster designation.

The designation allows producers in all North Dakota counties to be eligible for
low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency.

Hoeven, who has been in Washington all week pushing for a federal disaster aid
package, said the designation was expected, but that farmers need more.

"We're pleased to get it,"Hoeven said in a Wednesday phone interview with the
Tribune. "It will help. But we still need a federal disaster aid package for
farmers and ranchers."

Hoeven has estimated that North Dakota alone will need between $250 million and
$300 million in emergency disaster aid for producers affected by severe weather
in 2005 and 2006. He's been working with more then 20 governors across the
nation to secure an agricultural disaster aid package.

And Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., introduced legislation, co-sponsored by Sen. Byron
Dorgan, D-N.D., and Montana Republican Sen. Conrad Burns, that calls for $6.5
billion in emergency disaster aid for the more than 20 states suffering from ag
losses due to severe weather.

"(The designation) confirms in a very clear way that what we've been saying has
been true,"Conrad said. "We have been badly hurt. Our farmers and ranchers are
at risk."

Conrad introduced the legislation last week, and Nebraska Sen. Ben Nelson sought
yesterday to attach the legislation to a port security bill.

Dorgan, Conrad and Hoeven all agreed that the designation was due, but it's
still not enough.

"It has forced the USDAto recognize that there is in fact a bona fide
disaster,"Dorgan said. "But offering loans is not a substitute for the kind of
help that we need. Loading farmers up with additional debt ... that's not going
to be a solution."

In a news conference Wednesday morning, both Hoeven and Gov. Mike Rounds, of
South Dakota, detailed their efforts for farm aid, calling on Congress to do
something before the November elections.

But Rounds remained "cautiously optimistic" about a disaster aid package,and
Hoeven said he doubted the $6.5 billion in aid will pass.

Last month, Johanns visited South Dakota to assess drought damage, then pledged
$79 million in relief funds.

House Republicans and the White House have opposed several versions of drought
relief legislation, saying the bills are too expensive and would not be
distributed fairly.

Hoeven and Rounds countered that by saying aid would be distributed based on
need: Rounds said it could be for producers in D2 and D3 areas -moderate and
severe drought, respectively-and Hoeven said producers with 30 percent loss or
more should be eligible.

In Conrad's legislation, farmers who suffer 35 percent or more in losses would
receive aid.

"As is all disaster legislation, (it's) targeted to those who have the biggest
losses,"Conrad said. "This has been very carefully designed, and is based on
what has been successful in the past."

(The Associated Press contributed to this report. Reach reporter Crystal Reid at
250-8261 or at crystal.reid@bismarcktribune.com.)

N.D. makes disaster list

LOAD-DATE: September 14, 2006

                              Journal of Commerce

                             June 21, 1993, Monday

FARM LAWMAKERS WANT TO REPLACE US PREFERENCE RULES FOR FOOD AID

BYLINE: Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 616 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Farm state lawmakers Thursday urged the federal government to stop using its
food aid programs to "subsidize" U.S.-flag shipping companies and instead to
establish a direct budget line to aid the maritime industry.

Their proposal, which would replace U.S. cargo preference laws with a direct
maritime subsidy, has been received well by the U.S. Department of Agriculture
but is strongly opposed by shipping interests and the U.S. Maritime
dministration.

"If our objective is to provide U.S.-flag (vessels) with a reasonable subsidy,
it should be an above-board direct subsidy," Sen. Charles Grass- ley, R-Iowa,
told the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Foreign Agriculture and Hunger.

He called cargo preference a "hidden, back-door subsidy that latches like a
parasite onto the lifeblood of other federal programs."

Joan Yim, acting maritime administrator, said a review of maritime program
reforms was under way "at the highest levels of the Clinton administration" but
opposed the idea of eliminating cargo preference and setting up a direct subsidy
program for the fleet.

Meanwhile, Rep. Helen Delich Bentley, R-Md., a key advocate of cargo preference,
called on members of the House farm panel to live up to a 1985 compromise that
increased the amount of U.S. food aid moving on U.S.-flag vessels to 75 percent
from 50 percent.

That agreement specifically kept cargo preference out of USDA commercial export
credit guarantee programs.

Cargo preference laws require that 100 percent of Department of Defense cargo,
75 percent of food aid cargo and at least 50 percent of other government-owned
or financed cargo be shipped on U.S.-flag vessels.

Supporters say cargo preference is necessary to maintain an active U.S. merchant
fleet that can be called on during times of war and national emergency. But
critics such as Sen. Grassley contend the provisions establish a legal monopoly
that allows U.S.-flag vessels to charge exorbitant rates.

U.S.-flag ships employ higher-cost American citizens, are subject to stricter
safety regulations and are allowed a slower depreciation rate than ships in
other countries. All of these factors make their costs - and freight rates -
higher than their foreign-flag competitors, American shipowners say.

U.S.-flag freight charges will absorb $ 200 million of the $ 700 million U.S.
food aid package for Russia that will begin flowing later this summer. Those
charges angered many farm state lawmakers and caused an emotional and angry
debate between U.S. maritime and agriculture interests.

In her comments to the committee, Rep. Bentley said "a mere 4 percent" of U.S.
agricultural shipments are subject to the cargo preference requirements.
Meanwhile, American farmers are about to receive $ 17 billion in direct
government subsidies this year, she said.

Christopher Goldthwait, acting USDA general sales manager, told the committee
the USDA has no "formal position" on whether the United States should eliminate
the cargo-preference requirement of food aid programs and create a direct
subsidy program for the merchant marine. But "we believe that we should
certainly consider" that option, he said.

However, USDA sources have said they promoted the idea of a direct subsidy in
the inter-agency discussions on maritime reform this spring.

Mr. Goldthwait said there are a number of costs associated with cargo preference
other than higher rates for U.S.-flag ships. "Many U.S.-flag vessels, such as
tankers, are not designed to load bulk grain and are slower to load and
discharge than conventional bulk carriers," he said. Also, the grain is more
likely to be damaged in tankers, than in bulk carriers, he said.

                               The New York Times

                            August 1, 2001 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Senate Rejects G.O.P. Effort To Limit Emergency Farm Aid

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 568 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31


Risking a presidential veto, the Senate today rejected a Republican proposal to
limit emergency farm aid to $5.5 billion, pushing ahead with a Democratic
measure worth $2 billion more.

The White House warned last week that the Democratic bill was unacceptable and
that senior advisers would recommend that President Bush veto it. The
administration urged that the Senate instead approve the Republican bill, which
was passed by the House last month.

But Democrats, led by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, argued that the larger amount
was necessary to finance programs for smaller farmers who are ineligible for the
special subsidies for row crops -- corn, wheat, soybeans, rice and cotton --
that make up most of the bill.

Mr. Harkin, chairman of the Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry
Committee, maintained that the needs of these smaller farmers could not wait
another year.

"Without these programs," he said, "thousands of farmers could go out of
business. We need to help all the family farmers all over America, not just
those in the big farm states."

The committee's ranking Republican, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, agrees
that subsidies tend to help large commercial farmers and not the struggling
smaller farmers. But Mr. Lugar said this emergency bill, providing supplemental
aid before the current fiscal year ends on Sept. 30, was not the way to reorder
farm policy.

It was his measure that failed today, on a vote of 52 to 48, largely along party
lines.

At issue is legislation that, though designated emergency, has become an annual
routine to make up for payments that many farmers have lost since Congress
enacted a farm subsidy overhaul five years ago.

In adopting its version of the emergency bill last month, the House abided by
the Congressional budget resolution, which had set a $5.5 billion ceiling for
the measure.

With the Senate taking up its bill, the White House argued this week that
improvements in agricultural markets, with better livestock and crop prices,
meant that there was less need for emergency payments.

Senator Lugar concurred, and cited Agriculture Department figures showing that
the net worth of the nation's farms was up 3.2 percent in the last five years.

After the Lugar alternative was defeated today, the Senate majority leader, Tom
Daschle of South Dakota, whose state is among the top recipients of agricultural
aid, said he wanted the $7.5 billion Democratic bill passed, reconciled with the
House version and then sent to President Bush by the end of the week.

Most of the additional $2 billion in the Democratic bill would go to
conservation programs and to growers of specialty crops, particularly apple
growers.

The Senate vote is expected on Wednesday, although several senators today
offered an amendment, action on which was delayed, that would extend a dairy
compact authorizing a system of milk price controls in New England.

The compact, scheduled to expire with the fiscal year on Sept. 30, is strongly
opposed by lawmakers from the Midwest, who view it as a cartel intended to keep
milk from their states' dairies out of New England.

Democrats said they would make conservation a major push in the far broader
coming farm bill that will chart agricultural policy over the next decade.

At the same time, they are reluctant to cut back subsidies to the large farmers
who make up an important voting bloc in next year's Congressional elections.

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                    August 02, 2000 Wednesday, ALL EDITIONS

Biotech park to get new tenant;
 BioDynamics signs lease agreement

BYLINE: Lisa Eckelbecker; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 769 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER



- BioDynamics Inc. yesterday signed a lease for space in the city's
biotechnology park, cementing the Chinese-American venture's plans to study a
horse vaccine that may provide clues to fighting AIDS.

Zhongsheng Ou, chairman of BioDynamics, compared the company's research in the
Massachusetts Biotechnology Research Park to a seed.

Today we set up a research base, and compared to the park it is tiny,'' Mr. Ou
said, speaking through an interpreter. But like a seed, we (will) grow up into a
tree.''

In a ceremony held before city and biotech officials, BioDynamics agreed to
sublease 4,000 square feet of office and laboratory space for three years in
Five Biotech, the newest building in the biotech park.

The space is empty now, but BioDynamics officials want to begin filling it with
activity soon. The company will seek to file applications this month for state
and federal permits that would allow BioDynamics to retrieve biological
materials sent from China and held at a U.S. Department of Agriculture center,
said Dr. Robert J. Tashjian, a West Boylston veterinarian and BioDynamics chief
executive.

The company's plan is to use the samples to study a vaccine long used in China
to inoculate horses against Equine Infectious Anemia.

The EIA virus bears similarities to HIV, the virus that causes AIDS in humans,
so the EIA vaccine may shed light on how to fight AIDS or other human diseases,
Dr. Tashjian said.

We have to get to the mechanism, the molecular biology and the immunology that's
involved,'' said Dr. Tashjian, who has been working since the early 1980s to
bring research on the vaccine to the United States. Establishing the workings of
the vaccine can be an enormously important discovery that can lead to many other
vaccine technologies.''

BioDynamics is 60 percent owned by China Animal Husbandry Industrial Co. Ltd.,
or CAHIC, a Beijing animal health and husbandry company that controls the EIA
vaccine. CAHIC, which trades on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, is largely owned by
the China Animal Husbandry Group.

CAHIC is investing $500,000 to start BioDynamics, which may hire about 10
people. A goal in backing the U.S. venture is to develop technologies for the
Chinese market of 1.2 billion people, said Mr. Ou, who is also chief executive
of China Animal Husbandry Group.

At the back of this small laboratory is a huge market,'' he said.

The remaining 40 percent of BioDynamics is owned by American Chinese Medical
Frontiers Inc. of West Boylston, a nonprofit entity led by Dr. Tashjian.

In the past, American Chinese Veterinary Medical Frontiers has received grants
from the National Institutes of Health and a private foundation to support early
studies on the EIA vaccine.

Vaccines work by priming the body's immune system to fight off invading
organisms. Some vaccines use killed viruses to raise the body's defenses. Some
use living but weakened viruses.

The most famous case of an animal virus leading to a human vaccine may be the
smallpox vaccine. In the 18th century, English doctor Edward Jenner used the
cowpox virus to inoculate a boy against smallpox. A modern vaccine similar to
the cowpox virus has helped eradicate the disease.

CAHIC's vaccine against EIA is a live, attenuated vaccine. It appears to protect
horses against illness, but BioDynamics needs to establish how it works and
whether that mechanism could be applied against HIV, said Nelson Yuan-Sheng
Kiang, a professor at Harvard Medical School and the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology.

Once you understand how it works, what part of the virus serves as the essential
component for the vaccine?'' said Mr. Kiang, who attended yesterday's ceremony.
If that part is also contained in the (human) virus, then the chance that this
might be another cowpox-smallpox becomes very alive.''

For the biotech park, the arrival of BioDynamics helps fill a portion of Five
Biotech.

BioDynamics is subleasing its space from AstraZeneca plc, a pharmaceutical
company that holds a lease on about 49,000 square feet of the 93,000-square-foot
building. AstraZeneca, which leases space in another building in the park, does
not plan to move in to Five Biotech because it is consolidating research in
Delaware.

The only other tenant in Five Biotech is Q-One Biotech Ltd., a Glasgow-based
company that is leasing about 14,000 square feet.

Yet AstraZeneca continues to pursue tenants for its space, and the park's
management is also marketing the building, said Thomas J. Andrews, executive
director of the biotech park. The building could be filled, he said, in early
2001.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     June 6, 1992, Saturday, Tampa Edition

Delta passenger fears AIDS

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; STATE DIGEST; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 289 words

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE; MIAMI



A Delta Air Lines passenger who reached into his seat pocket for a magazine
charged that he was jabbed with a bloody syringe and now fears he may have
caught the AIDS virus. Retiree Maurice Albert of Lauderhill is seeking $
1-million in damages in a negligence lawsuit filed this week in Broward Circuit
Court over the incident. Albert said he was jabbed on a flight from Las Vegas to
Fort Lauderdale March 17. He wants the name of the passenger sitting in the seat
before him, but Delta has refused.
 Black Miamians
 angry about visit
 MIAMI A luncheon intended to bring together South African Zulu leader
Mangosuthu Buthelezi and 40 civic leaders was canceled after the fund-raising
trip sparked discord in the city's black community. Black residents, still
smarting from the cold shoulder given by city officials when Nelson Mandela
visited two years ago, were disturbed that the Miami Herald would sponsor an
event with his political rival. Johnnie McMillian, president of the Miami branch
of the NAACP, was encouraged by Thursday's cancellation of the luncheon, which
Buthelezi's supporters said would raise money for South African education. "It
wouldn't have done anything for race relations," she said. "We're already at the
cusp of a blowup."
 Ocean World
 fined $ 20,000
 FORT LAUDERDALE Ocean World was fined $ 20,000 and its license suspended for
two weeks over allegations of animal mistreatment under an agreement Friday with
the U.S.  Department of Agriculture. The accusations against Ocean World
included a diver wrestling with a dolphin in its underwater cage and the keeping
of 15 dolphins in overchlorinated water until their skin peeled. Under the
agreement, Ocean World admits no wrongdoing.

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              March 2, 2007 Friday

House to put blizzard aid in Pentagon bill

BYLINE: Peter Roper, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 257 words


Mar. 2--House Democratic leaders have decided to attach $4 billion in disaster
assistance to a $93 billion defense budget bill coming through the House this
month, including money to help Eastern Plains ranchers hurt by the recent
blizzards.

Rep. John Salazar, D-Colo., said he was assured by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on
Thursday and Rep. Collin Peterson, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee,
that disaster aid will be attached to the Pentagon supplemental bill.

"Chairman Peterson (D-Minn.) assured me that among that $4 billion in disaster
aid there will be blizzard assistance money for Colorado ranchers and farmers,"
Salazar said. "How much is still to be determined but the situation is better
than we thought."

Salazar is a member of the House agriculture panel. Earlier this week, he said
that lawmakers from western states hurt by the blizzards were hoping to get $50
million dedicated for blizzard relief.

The $4 billion in disaster funds would be in addition to the $93 billion the
White House has requested to continue funding for the war in Iraq. Last year,
efforts to include drought and disaster aid in supplemental budget bills were
blocked by the Republican leadership and also opposed by the Bush
administration.

                              249 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                           October 20, 2007 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

World Bank Report Puts Agriculture at Core of Antipoverty Effort

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1030 words


For the first time in a quarter century, the World Bank's flagship annual report
on development puts agriculture and the productivity of small farmers at the
heart of a global agenda to reduce poverty. Three-quarters of the world's poor
still live in the countryside.

The World Development Report, released yesterday, is the first on agriculture
since 1982. Just a week ago, an internal evaluation unit chided the bank for its
neglect of agriculture in Africa and its plummeting financial support for that
sector over the past 15 years -- support that did not begin to grow
significantly until last year.

More broadly, the report crystallizes an emerging consensus among wealthy
countries, philanthropists and African governments: Increased public investment
in scientific research, rural roads, irrigation, credit, fertilizer and seeds --
the basics of an agricultural economy -- is crucial to helping Africa's poor
farmers grow more sorghum, corn, millet, cassava and rice on their miniature
plots.

Foreign aid for agriculture has plunged as support for global health and primary
education has surged. The fight against AIDS and other diseases is keeping
millions of people alive, and rising elementary school attendance is lifting
literacy rates. But most poor Africans make their living in agriculture and need
to grow more to feed themselves and earn their way out of destitution, many
analysts say.

''We're not saying health and education aren't important,'' said Alain de
Janvry, one of two authors of the report, ''Agriculture for Development,'' who
has taught agricultural economics at the University of California, Berkeley, for
40 years. ''But if you look at Africa, there's no alternative to agriculture as
a source of growth.''

The World Bank is not the first to reach this conclusion. African governments,
at a 2003 African Union summit, promised to more than double their own very low
public spending on agriculture. In 2005, the United Nations Millennium Project,
led by the Columbia University economist Jeffrey D. Sachs, advocated major
investments to increase the productivity of poor farmers in Africa.

Last year, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation joined the Rockefeller
Foundation to help bring a green revolution to Africa. The Gates Foundation,
known for its work on global health, was motivated in part by an awareness that
extreme poverty and malnutrition were underlying causes of much of the sickness
and premature death plaguing Africa.

But the bank, the world's leading development institution and financier of
antipoverty programs, plays a unique  role in advising poor countries, and its
return to agriculture is likely to influence practical policies across
sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, where hundreds of millions of farmers and
landless laborers are still mired in poverty.

The 365-page report was conceived before the arrival of the bank's new
president, Robert B. Zoellick, but he embraced its themes yesterday in
Washington, while acknowledging the recent critical evaluation of the bank's own
performance.

''To make this successful, we're going to need to increase investment,'' he said
at a forum that was shown live on the Web.

Robert S. McNamara, an earlier World Bank president, initiated the last period
of ambitious investment in African agriculture, in the 1970s. Internal
evaluations found that many of those projects and subsequent ones failed for a
variety of reasons. Often, they were complex, devised and run by professionals
from outside the countries being helped and not adopted wholeheartedly by poor
countries that had little capacity to carry them out independently and,
sometimes, little commitment to poor farmers.

In the 1980s, in the era of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, the World Bank
increasingly withdrew its support from agriculture and expected private markets
to spur growth through competition. Bank officials even thought profit-seeking
companies would build toll roads in remote parts of Africa.

But, as the recent internal evaluation found, private markets often failed to
deliver a range of goods and services farmers needed, including improved seeds,
fertilizer and credit.

In India's green revolution, which began in the 1960s with the introduction of
new high-yielding varieties of rice and wheat, the World Bank, the United States
and the Rockefeller Foundation encouraged the Indian government to play a
pivotal role in the provision of seeds, fertilizer and credit, said Uma Lele, an
agricultural economist who worked at the bank for 35 years and evaluated many of
its agricultural programs before retiring. The Indian state also set floor
prices for wheat and rice to ensure farmers a return on their investments.

In the effort to bring an agrarian revolution to Africa, much of the debate from
now on will focus on the role that African governments should play in spurring
farm productivity. Economists who have read the World Development Report said
there was clearly still a great deal of ferment and disagreement within the bank
about many of the particulars. For example, should African governments give
farmers subsidies to buy fertilizer, and under what conditions?

The report notes that agricultural subsidies have a way of becoming deeply
entrenched politically long after their original purpose has been served.

The report found, for example, that if European countries, the United States and
other wealthy nations removed all tariffs and subsidies for cotton, soybeans and
other oilseeds -- practices that reduce the world price of those commodities and
make it harder for unsubsidized farmers in poor countries to compete --
developing countries' share of world trade in cotton and oilseeds would be more
than 80 percent in 2015 instead of only about half.

Derek Byerlee, an agricultural economist with the bank who wrote the report with
Professor de Janvry, said at a panel discussion yesterday that the United
States' subsidies to cotton growers were ''directly and negatively impacting
African farmers.''

Professor de Janvry said the report was not meant to settle the complicated and
difficult policy questions, but ''to change the conversation.''

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2007 The New York Times Company


                              250 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 May 26, 1986, Monday, Late City Final Edition

FLORIDA PIG FARM POSES AIDS RIDDLE

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1376 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 25


Following a hunch, two medical researchers looking for clues to the riddle of
why a small Florida migrant center has so many cases of AIDS went deep inside a
sugar cane field outside the town. What they found there earlier this month is
now a matter of dispute.

They say they found a backwoods swine farm with more than 150 domestic and wild
pigs showing the ravages of a deadly disease, perhaps an unknown variant of
African swine fever, as well as evidence of the virus believed to cause AIDS in
humans. The farm is near Belle Glade, the poverty-stricken migrant town on the
south shore of Lake Okeechobee where 50 cases of AIDS, or acquired immune
deficiency syndrome, have been reported.

A special team of veterinarians from the Department of Agriculture went to the
farm to take blood and tissue samples from the pigs. They said that tests of the
samples at the Plum Island Animal Diagnostic Center at Greenport, L.I., found no
evidence of African swine fever, and that the Belle Glade pigs were merely
undernourished, a condition fairly common among swine raised for local
consumption near there. They plan further studies of the researchers findings.
No Record of Fever in U.S.  African swine fever, a usually deadly and rapidly
transmitted disease of pigs, has never been officially recorded in the United
States, Agriculture officials say. Evidence of it in this country, even in such
a remote setting, would be perceived as a potential threat to the $9
billion-a-year national pork industry.

But even if evidence of African swine fever were to be found in the herd, a
spokesman for the Agriculture Department said, ''AIDS is a human disease problem
and we have no basis for assuming yet that it is related to African swine fever
virus.''

The medical researchers, Jane Teas, a pathobiologist formerly with the Harvard
School of Public Health, and John C. Beldekas, a chemical immunologist with the
microbiology department of Boston University's School of Medicine, came across
the pigs while searching for evidence that might identify environmental causes
for the high incidence of AIDS in Belle Glade, a town of about 15,000 people.

Preliminary studies have failed to establish a link between the AIDS victims
there and the major groups known to be at highest risk of getting the disease:
male homosexuals, intravenous drug abusers and hemophiliacs who received
contaminated blood products.

Ken Castro, an epidemiologist who heads a Federal Centers for Disease Control
team investigating AIDS in Belle Glade, said results of blood samples and
questionnaires from 1,200 residents should be available in September. Most of
the questions dealt with sexual practices, he said, and the main hypothesis
being tested deals with heterosexual transmission.

Common Characteristics Seen

Miss Teas and Mr. Beldekas concede that they are not veterinarians and are not
qualified to diagnose exotic infectious animal diseases like African swine
fever. They are, however, leading advocates of a theory that the African swine
fever virus may be linked to the transmission of AIDS.

AIDS victims and pigs stricken with chronic African swine fever have common
characteristics, Mr. Beldekas said, including fever, abnormally large lymph
nodes, skin lesions, immune-related pneumonia, and a reduction of white blood
cells. Both diseases can be spread through exposure to infected blood, blood
products and semen, Mr. Beldekas said, but the animal virus can also be
transmitted by infected ticks.

Accordingly, they say, the animal virus may somehow be a factor in the
transmission of AIDS, which could have spread from infected pigs to humans
through tick bites, and then from human to human through sexual contact or
direct infection of blood.

Results of Researchers' Tests

This theory runs counter to generally accepted scientific research that
pinpoints the causative agent of AIDS as a virus called HTLV-III or LAV, which
is believed to be transmitted through direct infection of the blood, primarily
through homosexual contact or contaminated needles and blood products.

The researchers suggest that HTLV-III may simply be present in AIDS victims as a
product of a body's reaction to the presence of the swine fever virus.

Miss Teas first suggested a possible link between AIDS and the African swine
fever virus two years ago in the British medical journal The Lancet. Two months
ago she and Mr. Beldekas collaborated on a letter published by The Lancet
asserting that 9 of 21 American AIDS patients they tested had evidence of the
swine fever virus in their blood, although none had a known history of exposure
to infected pigs. The swine virus is very difficult to detect and identify, Mr.
Beldekas said last week in suggesting a possible explanation for the apparent
absence of the virus in the 12 other AIDS victims.

Mr. Beldekas said studies of blood and organs taken from the pigs by Dr. Mark
Whiteside, a tropical disease specialist working with them in Belle Glade,
''gave me positive Western blot for HTLV-III.'' The Western blot test is
considered a usually reliable indicator of the presence of antibodies to the
HTLV-III virus, a signal of infection by the virus.

Mr. Beldekas said additional pig blood and organ specimens were carried to
England this month by Miss Teas for tests by the Pirbright Animal Virus Research
Institute in Surrey.

Mr. Beldekas and Miss Teas were partly financed, they said, by private sources
among homosexual groups in New York and California. The disease has infected
hundreds of thousands of homosexual men and has killed thousands of them since
it was first identified in 1981.

AIDS Records Not Precise

Of the 50 confirmed cases of AIDS reported in Belle Glade, nearly all of them
have been black residents of two central slum districts. It is suspected that
the actual toll may be significantly higher, researchers say, but owing to the
transient nature of the migrants and the poor quality of their medical care, it
is difficult to keep track of the cases. AIDS victims could possibly die
elsewhere, without autopsies, and their deaths could be attributed to other
causes, like pneumonia, Dr. Whiteside said.

The Boston researchers and Dr. Whiteside described one theory, based on accounts
provided by local inhabitants, that illegal immigrants from Haiti brought with
them pigs infected with chronic, low-grade swine fever. After the Haitians found
migrant work in the farmland around Belle Glade, the theory goes, their pigs
integrated with wild hogs that abound in the dense sugar cane fields.

''Perhaps the pigs, infected with a chronic, low-virulent strain of African
swine fever, are a reservoir'' for AIDS in the environment, Mr. Baldekas said.

''Look around the world,'' he continued, ''and where you find AIDS you will
always find African swine fever and pigs,'' notably in Haiti and Africa.

Insects Seen as Carriers

Miss Teas said pigs from the farm outside Belle Glade were sold to migrant
workers in one of the slum areas. Although the African swine fever virus has
been known to survive cooking, she said its transmission to humans would more
likely be through an insect carrier, like the ticks present in the Belle Glade
fields.

The Agriculture Department field check of the pigs uncovered no evidence of
African swine fever, according to Dr. Gerald Fichtner, associate deputy
administrator of veterinary services for the Federal Animal and Plant Inspection
Service.

''If we were concerned about an acute virus disease like African swine fever
we'd be looking for severe symptons like hemorrhaging, acute dehydration and
high fever,'' Dr. Fichtner said. ''If diarrhea was present we'd be more
concerned, but no diarrhea was found.''

The department's chief veterinarian in Florida, Dr. William Grene, in a separate
telephone interview, said diarrhea was indeed found in some of the pigs,
however. He nonetheless discounted the importance of that finding, saying it was
consistent with mismanagement of a pig herd that had inadequate water and food
supplies, and was probably attributable to internal parasites.

Agriculture Department specialists last week visited Mr. Beldekas's laboratory
in Boston to get samples for comparison studies at Plum Island.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                           October 22, 2008 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

DISASTER AID FOR CROPS AVAILABLE

BYLINE: The Capital Times

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 343 words


Farmers and growers suffering losses during the floods and cold weather earlier
this year will be eligible for low-cost loans and other assistance from the
federal government.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture approved three disaster declarations asked
for by Gov. Jim Doyle, making aid available in 55 counties, including 39 for
damages due to flooding and 16 for damages due to frost, freeze, winterkill and
extreme cold.

The approvals came from the USDA Oct. 15. No dollar estimates were attached to
the declarations.

"Agriculture has remained a strong segment of the Wisconsin economy despite
severe weather in our state this past year," Doyle said. "These declarations can
help eligible farmers prepare for future financial needs."

Wisconsin farmers and growers suffered tens of millions of dollars in losses
this year with most of the damage coming in the June floods.

Twenty-four primary and 15 contiguous counties were in the flooding disaster
declaration. The primary counties include Adams, Columbia, Crawford, Dane,
Dodge, Grant, Green Lake, Jefferson, Juneau, Kenosha, Lafayette, Manitowoc,
Marquette, Milwaukee, Monroe, Racine, Richland, Rock, Sauk, Sheboygan, Vernon,
Walworth, Waukesha and Winnebago counties, while the contiguous counties in the
declaration include Brown, Calumet, Fond du Lac, Green, Iowa, Jackson, Kewaunee,
La Crosse, Outagamie, Ozaukee, Portage, Washington, Waupaca, Waushara and Wood
counties.

Four primary and 10 contiguous counties were in the winterkill, freezing rain
and extreme cold declaration, including Barron, Lafayette, Polk and St. Croix
counties as primary and Burnett, Chippewa, Dunn, Grant, Green, Iowa, Pierce,
Rusk, Sawyer and Washburn counties as contiguous.

Two counties, Door as primary and Kewaunee as contiguous, were in the drought,
freeze and frost disaster declaration, with 98 percent of the cherry crop in
Door County lost this year.

Landowners in the counties included in the declarations should contact the USDA
Wisconsin State Farm Service Agency at 608-662-4422 for more information.

                               The New York Times

                August 23, 1985, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Block Warns of Farm Trouble

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section D; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 204 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 22


Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today it may be necessary for some
farmers to lose their businesses so the entire troubled farm industry can be
freed from ''heavy-handed'' Government policy.

''Whatever farm policy we adopt, we are going to lose some farmers,'' Mr. Block
said. ''The credit crunch is not over. We're going to have a tough winter. We
must reduce subsidies that encourage production.''

Mr. Block, speaking at the Agriculture Department's food safety and nutrition
editor's conference, predicted there would be more foreclosures against
Midwestern farmers, but said it was necessary.

''For the past 50 years government has been trying to protect farmers into
prosperity and profitability,'' he said. ''What do we have to show for all this
help? We have a weakened agricultural sector that lurches from crisis to crisis,
from Band-Aid to Band-Aid.''

Deregulation is likely to hurt farmers, decrease food supplies and increase
prices, but Mr. Block said these are ''small prices to pay'' for saving the
troubled farm industry.

He said the belt-tightening must begin immediately, starting with the new
agricultural bill, and that President Reagan will take an active role in forming
the bill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                            August 25, 2016 Thursday

Governor Terry E. Branstad Iowa State Fair Scholarship Recipients Announced

LENGTH: 352  words

DATELINE: New York



 Des Moines: Iowa College Student Aid Commission has issued the following news
release:



   Iowa College Aid has announced Kethryn Eyheralde of Centerville and Kaitlyn
Boyer of Weldon as recipients of the 2016 Governor Terry E. Branstad Iowa State
Fair Scholarship. This scholarship recognizes outstanding Iowa high school
seniors who have actively participated in the Iowa State Fair and plan to attend
an Iowa college or university.





 Both Eyheralde and Boyer will use the $2,000 scholarship to help pay for
studies at Iowa State University, where Eyheralde will major in Animal Ecology
with an emphasis in Pre-Veterinary Studies and Boyer will study Animal Science
with a focus on Beef Production.



 "Kethryn and Kaitlyn reflect the spirit of the Iowa State Fair scholarship, as
both have had their lives shaped by their experiences volunteering at the fair,"
said Karen Misjak, executive director of Iowa College Aid, the state agency
charged with administering the scholarship. "Their dedication to a future in
agriculture is great for Iowa."



 "Being chosen as a recipient means that my hard work and effort that led to my
4-H project at the state fair have even greater influence on my future and
education than just taking home a ribbon," Eyheralde said.



 "I am honored to receive this scholarship as it will help me pursue my passion
for the beef industry and agriculture at Iowa State University," Boyer said.



 Eyheralde and Boyer will receive their awards during the Iowa State Fair. Each
will be presented a certificate of recognition by Governor Branstad on Saturday,
August 20, at 10 a.m. on the Anne & Bill Riley Stage.



 Iowa College Aid will also exhibit in the Varied Industries Building at the
fair. Free publications about financial aid will be available, and prizes will
be given to fairgoers who complete a "College Passport." Iowa College Aid staff
will be on hand to answer questions about preparing and applying for college,
obtaining financial aid and succeeding in college.

 (c)  Certification renewal.--The department shall require

 proprietors of food establishments to provide for the renewal of

 food service employees' emergency first aid certification. The

 following shall apply:

 (1)  Renewal of first aid certification may be provided

 by the local health authority or a certification

 Section 4.  Duties of department.

 appropriate to carry out the provisions of this act.

 health authorities to develop guidelines in accordance with

 paragraph (1).

 (3)  Coordinate with local health authorities to develop

 uniform standards for emergency first aid training and

 certification, including procedures for verifying emergency

 first aid training.

                     The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)

                              July 9, 2012 Monday

Farm Aid 2012 chooses Hershey

BYLINE: Lebanon Daily News staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 341 words


Farm Aid announced Monday that the 2012 edition of its annual benefit concert
will take place on Saturday, Sept. 22, at Hersheypark Stadium.

"We've built a strong family farm movement to grow our economy, ensure our
health and protect our environment. Farm Aid brings these Main Street values to
transform the Wall Street-controlled farm and food system," said Farm Aid
President Willie Nelson in a news release. "The Farm Aid concert is our chance
to shine a spotlight on the independent family farmers who are essential to the
well-being of our country."

Farm Aid 2012 will feature Nelson and fellow board members John Mellencamp, Neil
Young and Dave Matthews - with Tim Reynolds - as well as Jack Johnson, ALO, Pegi
Young & The Survivors, and Lukas Nelson & Promise of the Real.

Farm Aid has a rich history in Pennsylvania. Farm Aid has long collaborated with
and supported organizations and organizers in the state who are growing the Good
Food Movement, including innovators at the forefront of the organic and the Buy
Fresh Buy Local movements.

Tickets for Farm Aid 2012 will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. and will be
available atLive Nation ,Ticketmaster , Ticketmaster outlets, the Giant Center
Box Office, or by phone at 800-745-3000. Ticket prices range from $35.75 to
$99.75.

Farm Aid will offer advance sale tickets to Farm Aid members beginning July 10.
To become a member of Farm Aid, visitwww.farmaid.org.

Farm Aid welcomes the participation of the local business community and offers
corporate sponsorship opportunities. For more information, contact Glenda Yoder
at Farmaid.org/concert.

Farm Aid's mission is to build a vibrant, family farm-centered system of
agriculture in America, according to the news release. Since 1985, Farm Aid,
with the support of the artists who contribute their performances each year, has
raised more than $40 million to support programs that help farmers thrive,
expand the reach of the Good Food Movement, take action to change the dominant
system of industrial agriculture and promote food from family farms.

LOAD-DATE: July 11, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: FILE - In this Oct. 2, 2010, file photo, Dave Matthews performs during
the 25th anniversary Farm Aid concert in Milwaukee. The annual Farm Aid benefit
concert is coming to Hershey, Pa., in September 2012 as the country s small and
medium-size farms face a shifting economic landscape, but board member Dave
Matthews sees some hopeful signs in the uncertainty. Matthews, who will perform
at the Hersheypark show on Sept. 22 with longtime collaborator Tim Reynolds,
sees demand growing for the types of farm products produced by smaller
operations. (AP Photo/Jeffrey Phelps, File)

                              257 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           January 6, 2016 Wednesday

The Economic Welfare and Trade Relations Implications of the 2014 Farm Bill
edited by Vincent H. Smith

LENGTH: 972  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: American Enterprise Institute has issued the following news
release:



 In "The Economic Welfare and Trade Relations Implications of the 2014 Farm
Bill" (Emerald Group Publishing, January 2016), a collection of studies on
various key aspects of the Farm Bill, editor and AEI agricultural economist
Vincent H. Smith joins other experts to assess the impact of the 2014 Farm Bill.
Throughout the 12 chapters, college professors and agricultural experts examine
the different sections of the 2014 Farm Bill and find that the programs appear
to focus on transferring income -- at the expense of US consumers and taxpayers
-- to relatively wealthy farmers and to nonfarm entities, such as the US
merchant marine and private insurance and reinsurance companies. These transfers
have negative effects on the long-term productivity of the agricultural sector
and on how well international food aid programs can meet humanitarian needs. In
addition, the 2014 Farm Bill does too little to efficiently address conservation
issues and will likely make it harder for US trade negotiators to secure
beneficial trade agreements.





 A summary of the chapters follows:



 Chapter 1 by Barry K. Goodwin (North Carolina State University) and Vincent H.
Smith (Montana State University): An introduction of current farm policy and how
farm subsidies have distorted the market.



 Chapter 2 by David Orden (International Food Policy Research Institute) and
Carl Zulauf (Ohio State University): A look at the evolution of modern US
agricultural policy since the 1990s, including the continued support for
programs that transfer resources from taxpayers to consumers, though transfers
to farmers are no longer needed to mitigate rural poverty.



 Chapter 3 by Bruce Babcock (Iowa State University): Examines the Price Loss
Coverage and Agricultural Risk Coverage programs, which are really price and
income support programs for specific commodities under the guise of providing
farm income safety net programs.



 Chapter 4 by Erik Lichtenberg (University of Maryland): Examines the economic
rationale and efficiencies of the conservation programs authorized under Title
II of the Farm Bill.



 Chapter 5 by Christopher B. Barrett (Cornell University) and Erin C. Lentz
(University of Texas at Austin): Examines the problems associated with
international emergency food aid, including the requirement that aid be
transported on US flagged ships; the requirement that the US be the source of
food aid, instead of using conveniently located local food sources; and the
monetization of food aid, where nongovernment agencies sell food aid and use the
funds for other forms of assistance. They conclude that millions of lives are
not saved because of all these requirements.



 Chapter 6 by Colin A. Carter (University of California, Davis): Examines the
trade policy implications of the 2014 Farm Bill including the new dairy margin
protection program and the livestock-related Country of Origin Labeling, which
violates US WTO trade obligations.



 Chapter 7 by Dr. Joseph Glauber (International Food Policy Research Institute)
and Patrick Westhoff (University of Missouri): Discusses how the 2014 Farm Bill
could cause the US to violate its current WTO obligations because of the various
subsidies included in the program.



 Chapter 8 by Brian Davern Wright (University of California, Berkeley): Examines
the economic benefits and costs of the federal agricultural insurance program
and finds that the program accounts for about 30 percent of all farm-subsidy
spending, which amounts to an estimated $8 billion a year or more, according to
the Congressional Budget Office. Wright finds that the insurance program
increases riskier behavior while transferring income to the wealthier farm
operations and transferring the financial risks to taxpayers.



 Chapter 9 by Daniel A. Sumner (University of California, Davis), Joseph V.
Balagtas (Purdue University), and Jisang Yu (University of California, Davis):
Studies dairy programs and finds that the Dairy Margin Protection Program has
the potential to exceed all previous government outlays on dairy subsidies and
makes it more difficult for US dairy food processors to be competitive in export
markets.



 Chapter 10 by Gary W. Brester (Montana State University): Assesses the US sugar
program and finds that restrictions of imports, restriction of acreage where
sugar beets and sugar canes are planted, and a long-standing "loan rate" price
support result in US domestic sugar prices being much higher than world prices.



 Chapter 11 by Philip G. Pardey (University of Minnesota), Steven T. Buccola
(Oregon State University), and Jason M. Beddow (University of Minnesota):
Explores the impact of the 2014 Farm Bill on public research and development
(R&D) programs and finds a modest increase in R&D funding, though an
insufficient one to reverse the decline in the US share of global food and
agricultural R&D spending -- with adverse consequences for the future
competitiveness of US agriculture.



 Chapter 12 by Dr. Mary Clare Ahearn (United States Department of Agriculture
Economic Research Service, retired): Examines rural development policy reflected
by successive farm bills between 1950 and 2014. She assesses the effectiveness
of the various rural credit programs targeted to new and socially disadvantaged
farmers and finds that they are in fact trivial (less than 0.04 percent of the
spending on all other farm and rural programs).



 As the first comprehensive account to address contemporary US agricultural
policy as defined by the 2014 Farm Bill, this primer provides a careful analysis
of US agricultural policy that is accessible to students, graduates, interest
groups, and policymakers.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolution.com

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              258 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            August 13, 1996, Tuesday

FOOD FOR N. KOREA SENT VIA TACOMA, SACRAMENTO

BYLINE: WILLIAM DiBENEDETTO; JOURNAL OF COMMERCE STAFF

SECTION: TRANSPORTATION, Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 431 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


With waivers in hand from three federal agencies, a U.S. carrier recently sent a
shipment of food to North Korea through the ports of Tacoma, Wash., and
Sacramento, Calif.

It was a first for the ports, and U.S. shipments of anything to North Korea are
extremely rare.

An Afram vessel hauled about 13,100 metric tons of cornmeal, milled rice and
corn/soy blend to Nampo in July and early August. The shipment was arranged
under the PL-480 food aid program. Afram is a U.S.-flag carrier based in Port
Arthur, Texas, that specializes in U.S. military and foreign aid cargoes.

Trade between the United States and North Korea, including U.S-flag vessel
calls, has been restricted since the early 1950s, when the Korean War spilt the
Korean Peninsula.

South Korea has prospered since the end of the conflict and is a major U.S.
trading partner. But communist North Korea does virtually no business with the
United States.

With the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, North Korea lost its main
benefactor and has experienced economic hard times. The death in 1994 of Kim Il
Sung and severe flooding in 1994-95 that damaged crops added to the country's
woes.

The United Nations called for emergency food aid for North Korea. The country
historically is a food importer, said Jeffrey Goldstein, a specialist in North
Korean affairs at the State Department.

''They've had a couple of bad harvests in a row, so the UN's World Food Program
issued an appeal for food aid,'' he said.

South Korea and Japan also are sending food to North Korea.

About half of the U.S. food aid went through Tacoma and the rest moved through
Sacramento.

PL-480 sends surplus farm commodities overseas as foreign aid on U.S.-flag
vessels. But that latter requirement ran up against the U.S. restrictions on
U.S. ship movements to North Korea, imposed during the Korean War. That's why
the departments of Commerce, Transportation and Treasury had to issue special
waivers for the transaction.

A similar grain relief effort to North Korea moved through the Port of Seattle
last year.

James Firth, chief of export operations for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
Farm Service Agency, said the food aid was shipped through ports that don't
normally handle PL-480 commodities. The Clinton administration placed a high
priority on the shipment, so for the sake of speed, only West Coast ports were
considered, he said.

Among West Coast ports, Tacoma offered the best price structure for the cornmeal
and corn/soy blend, which were valued at a total of $ 2.7 million, Mr. Firth
said.

LOAD-DATE: December 13, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1996 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              259 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   February 5, 1992, Wednesday, Final Edition

U.S. Food Aid Waits on the Dock;
After Months of Delays, None Has Reached Ex-Soviet Republics

David Hoffman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21

LENGTH: 908 words


The White House announced last Nov. 20 that President Bush had approved a new
program of $ 165 million in food aid to help "hard-hit" former Soviet republics
get through the winter using what press secretary Marlin Fitzwater called
"America's abundance."

But more than two months after the announcement, as winter drags on and food
supplies dwindle, none of the food has reached the shores of the former Soviet
republics. Thousands of tons of nonfat dry milk and bulgur wheat are awaiting
shipment at ports in New Orleans and Houston, held up by a transportation
bottleneck in the shipping industry.

Some of the food may be finally loaded onto ships this week, and next week an
airlift organized by the State Department and Pentagon will ferry bulk food left
from the Persian Gulf War to the republics in a largely symbolic display of
concern. But the slow start to the program Bush announced in November is
illustrative of the delays and frustrations that the administration and private
groups have encountered in trying to launch emergency relief efforts to the
republics.

"I'm not happy. You have a volatile situation, people need food, and every
passing day is a problem," said Ared Bulbuljian, who is coordinating food
shipments to Armenia for the American Diocese of the Armenian Church.

The church was the first private organization to get a contract from the
Agriculture Department to deliver food from the program Bush announced in
November, and its $ 15 million in commodities is stuck in warehouses or on docks
in the United States. Church officials said they have been frustrated by an
apparent shortage of shipping containers and available ships.

After leaving Washington last week, Russian President Boris Yeltsin expressed
frustration to a Canadian audience that urgent needs of his republic have been
met with a lot of rhetoric in the United States but not much action.

There are multiple reasons behind the delays Yeltsin lamented. First, critics
say, the Bush administration and Congress, worried about political campaigns and
dissatisfaction at home, have been slow to commit sizable resources to the
effort, especially in comparison to the billions of dollars that were devoted to
fighting communism.

Second, it has been time-consuming for the government and private groups to get
organized to spend money already approved. And third, both the government and
private groups continue to struggle with nightmarish logistical difficulties in
transportation and distribution of relief supplies.

"It's been an awful slow start," said Tom Gettman, director of government
relations for World Vision, an international relief organization that has been
sending private aid to families, hospitals and orphanages in the republics and
is now preparing to send some of the U.S. food. "These people have to have
encouragement to hang on. Otherwise, the democratization process will go down a
dark hole."

The 54 U.S. Air Force flights were announced by Secretary of State James A.
Baker III after an international conference here to coordinate assistance. At
the time, Bush pledged the administration would seek $ 645 million this year and
next in additional aid.

But administration officials have not detailed plans for this money and are only
slowly beginning to use what Congress has already approved. The airlift involves
only $ 3 million to $ 5 million of the $ 100 million that Congress last fall
diverted from the defense budget for transporting humanitarian relief. The
administration also is holding talks with Russia and other republics on how to
spend another $ 400 million to help dismantle nuclear warheads.

The bulk of the aid over the last year has been U.S.-backed credit guarantees
allowing the republics to borrow money from U.S. banks to buy surplus American
agricultural commodities.

Baker is expected to face questions on the pace and scope of the relief effort
today when he testifies before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Some
Democrats, including Chairman Claiborne Pell (R.I.) and Joseph R. Biden Jr.
(Del.), are impatient with the U.S. relief program; others, however, have been
reluctant to speak out, concerned about voter backlash in an election year.

"We have a fundamental problem on the ground" that both the administration and
Congress recognize, said a State Department official. "There are no good
answers" to the complex logistical hurdles that have confronted the relief
effort, the official added, short of dropping the food out of airplanes in a
rescue mission like that undertaken for Kurdish refugees last spring.

After Bush announced the $ 165 million in food aid, the Agriculture Department
said the food would be sent and distributed by private groups. The Armenian
Church proposal was attractive because the church already had an establishment
on the ground that could help with distribution, Bulbuljian said. The department
made an "extraordinary effort" to come up with the food in a short period, he
said, including 4,300 metric tons of butter, 1,150 tons of butter oil, 2,150
tons of nonfat dry milk and 3,000 tons of bulgur wheat. The group signed a
contract with the department Dec. 20.

Then it ran into shipping delays.

Meanwhile, the Agriculture Department has announced one other contract out of
the $ 165 million allotted -- this one worth $ 1 million in dried milk for St.
Petersburg schools. Several other efforts are expected to get underway soon.

                              260 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

               October 2, 1999, Saturday, EARLY AND CITY EDITIONS

Uncertainty centers around farm-relief bill

BYLINE: TOBY ECKERT COPLEY NEWS SERVICE

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. 1

LENGTH: 738 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Struggling central Illinois farmers would get a $ 366 million lifeline from the
federal government under legislation moving through Congress.

The House approved the bailout, which totals $ 8.7 billion nationwide, on a
240-175 vote Friday.  The Senate may take up the bill next week, but its
ultimate fate is uncertain.

A top White House official called the aid inadequate, and said some of it may go
to farmers who have not suffered losses.  But it is unclear whether President
Clinton would veto the bill.

Most of the money, $ 7.5 billion, would go to farmers who have seen their
incomes plummet because of low commodity prices, sagging exports and competition
from growers abroad.  The payments would start flowing within two weeks of the
bill becoming law.

According to figures provided by the House Agriculture Committee, the emergency
aid would total more than $ 90 million in Rep. Ray LaHood's district, $ 79.3
million in Rep. John Shimkus' district and $ 87.6 million in Rep. David Phelps'
district.

Figures for other Illinois congressional districts were not immediately
available.

Farm groups said they were happy with the aid but sorely disappointed by other
elements of the bill, including its failure to lift a ban on food sales to Cuba
and other nations that are under U.S.-only embargoes.

"This is a short-term package that farmers have said they need," said Illinois
Farm Bureau President Ron Warfield.  "It does not address many of the long-term
issues we need to address.  Obviously, we're very disappointed about the loss of
the embargo language."

Farm advocates lobbied lawmakers to lift the embargoes, which deprive U.S.
growers of potentially valuable markets. Other nations freely sell grain and
livestock to the targeted countries.

The Senate approved the embargo-lifting provision in August.  But House Speaker
Dennis Hastert, R-Yorkville, and other GOP leaders blocked it because it would
have allowed food sales to Cuba.

Cuban-Americans are an important Republican voting bloc in Florida and other key
states.  Many of them oppose any official dealings with the communist nation.

The embargo dispute derailed negotiations between the House and Senate on the
bill earlier this week.  Republican leaders took over the process and crafted
the bill to their liking.

Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., one of the original negotiators, refused to sign off
on the legislation in protest.

"They asked me to sign a conference report and I've not even seen it," said
Durbin.  "Unless they've cleaned it up, I think it's going to be vetoed
quickly."

Numerous House members, Republican and Democrat, also objected to the
leadership's tactics.  But many of them voted for the bill anyway because of the
turmoil in American agriculture.

"There is a real economic threat in farm country, a threat that could wipe out
many family farmers," said LaHood, R-Peoria.  "Hopefully, this relief plan will
help farmers weather this crisis."

"For this process to work, compromise has to be involved," said Shimkus,
R-Collinsville.  "As important as lifting the embargoes is, getting cash
assistance to the farmers is equally important."

The bailout would come on top of a $ 6 billion emergency farm aid package
approved by Congress last year.  The continuing crisis has raised questions
about the 1996 Freedom to Farm law, which was supposed to gradually end
Depression-era federal agriculture subsidies and production controls.

Some farm groups that were once supportive of the law are calling for a careful
review.  The House Agriculture Committee is expected to examine the issue early
next year.

Illinois farmers were hit hard last year.  Average net farm income there plunged
to $ 11,074 in 1998, from $ 51,048 in 1997, according to an estimate by
University of Illinois researchers.  The outlook is just as bleak this year.

The emergency aid was included in a $ 69 billion agriculture spending bill for
fiscal year 2000, which started Friday.  Other highlights of the aid package
include:

o $ 400 million to reduce the cost of crop insurance, keeping rates at 1999
levels;

o $ 325 million in direct assistance to livestock and dairy farmers;

o Doubling maximum loan deficiency payments, to $ 150,000;

o Requiring meat packers to report prices they pay for cattle and hogs, seen as
a step toward greater price transparency in the increasingly consolidated
industry.

                               The New York Times

               November 20, 1991, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

2 Senators Seek to Revive Plan to Divert Pentagon Funds to Soviets

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 770 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19


In an effort to break a political impasse, two senior Senators said today that
they had agreed to urge bipartisan revival of a plan to use up to $1 billion
from the defense budget to aid the Soviet Union.

"Let's take the pledge" to avoid injecting the issue into the 1992 campaign,
David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat and a senior member of the Senate
Agriculture Committee, said in outlining the initiative. "It matters too much
for any of us to take cheap shots and make it a campaign issue."

Mr. Boren's main partner in this new effort for a truce that would clear the way
for Soviet aid is Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the committee's ranking
Republican.

The earlier effort, sponsored by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representative
Les Aspin of Wisconsin, died a week ago after the White House failed to endorse
it amid mounting charges that it was being overly attentive to foreign affairs.
There was particularly strenuous opposition to a provision that would have
helped retrain Soviet officers at a time when the American economy is struggling
to shake off recession.

Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin are both Democrats.

The Senators did not provide any details today of how a new plan would differ
from the old one; it was understood that they would meet over breakfast on
Wednesday with Mr. Nunn, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Senator John W. Warner and
others to plot further strategy. Mr. Biden is a Democrat from Delaware, Mr.
Warner a Republican from Virginia.

A White House representative may also attend. A Senate official said he
understood that Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, had expressed
willingness to take part in the effort if a political truce could be arranged.

Democratic leaders had said of the earlier proposal that without a public
expression of support by the White House they would drop it rather than suffer
political repercussions alone.

The original plan, advanced within days of the failed August coup attempt,
called for transferring as much as $1 billion of the military budget into
humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union. A primary aim was to help insure stability
as central authority was eclipsed in the country, which has more than 30,000
nuclear weapons.

As part of the plan, Air Force planes would transport food and medical supplies
this winter, American companies would be given incentives to invest in converted
Soviet military enterprises and there would be a joint effort by the two
countries to destroy Soviet nuclear and chemical weapons.

In a related development, Marlin Fitzwater, the chief White House spokesman,
said today that the Administration would act within days on a much-delayed plan
to send about $1.5 billion worth of food to the Soviet Union.

The White House has repeatedly delayed offering such a package since Agriculture
Secretary Edward Madigan promised in late October that one would be drawn up
within two weeks. This, too, has been a sensitive political subject, drawing,
among other fire, the accusation by some farm state Democrats that the
Administration has misrepresented the true size of an aid request made last
month by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

Envoy Expresses Concern

The White House announcement may have been hastened by concern expressed on
Monday by Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador in Moscow, about mounting
opposition in this country to aiding the Soviet Union. Mr. Strauss, a longtime
friend and an appointee of President Bush, is a Democrat; he may have provided
some impetus to the revival of the Nunn-Aspin proposal as well as to fashioning
the current aid package.

The main element of the food aid package is some $1.25 billion in guarantees of
bank loans that the Soviets would use to buy American grain. The United States
previously gave the Soviet Union $1 billion worth of loan guarantees last
December and $1.5 billion of guarantees in June; the last of this grain is to be
shipped at the end of this month.

Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee,
promptly assailed the Administration plan to use credit guarantees for long-term
food aid.

"By giving piecemeal foreign aid to the Soviets under the guise of agricultural
credit guarantees, the Administration is playing a deceptive game with American
taxpayers," who bear the ultimate risk of default, Mr. Leahy said. He called for
greater coordination with Europe and Japan, with these countries paying
"substantially more."

As for the Boren-Lugar initiative, the Senators' hope is to have President Bush
convene a Congressional group to produce a deal by early next week.
