                               The New York Times

              September 23, 1986, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

NO SWINE FEVER LINK TO AIDS SEEN

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

SECTION: Section C; Page 12, Column 5; Science Desk

LENGTH: 734 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22


Scientists at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta today said that a
series of blood tests conducted in July and August indicated that a deadly
disease in swine was not related to the spread of AIDS in humans.

In making their findings public, the scientists said they hoped to put to rest a
theory advanced by a small group of researchers in Boston and Florida that the
animal disease, African swine fever, somehow contributed to the transmission of
acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

''We tested the blood from AIDS patients. We tested blood serum from pigs,''
said Dr. Paul Feorino, chief of the Virology Laboratory at the centers, and the
principal investigator. ''The results were absolutely negative for everything.
As far as I'm concerned, there is no evidence to suggest that African swine
fever is involved in AIDS.''

On September 11, eight researchers from the Centers for Disease Control, the
Department of Agriculture, and several other agencies met in Cold Spring Harbor
on Long Island to discuss Dr. Feorino's research. According to Dr. William Hess,
an African swine fever specialist with the Department of Agriculture who
attended the meeting, the group unanimously supported Dr. Feorino's conclusions.
''We agreed that there was no connection between these two viruses,'' said Dr.
Hess. ''Nobody was being dogmatic about it. But this alleged connection has been
causing some problems with people who have been working on AIDS. They felt the
theory has distracted them from the things they should be doing.''

African swine fever, a usually lethal and rapidly transmitted disease in pigs,
has never been found in North America, according to the Department of
Agriculture. Three years ago, Dr. Jane Teas, a disease and population specialist
formerly with the Harvard School of Public Health, wrote a letter to The Lancet,
the British medical journal, suggesting that the swine disease could be related
to the spread of AIDS. In Africa and Haiti, where pigs had been infected with
African swine fever, people soon became sick with AIDS, she said. Moreover, the
symptoms of AIDS in humans closely resembled those of pigs infected by swine
fever.

Last March, Dr. Teas and Dr. John Beldekas, a microbiologist formerly with the
Boston University School of Medicine, collaborated on another letter to The
Lancet asserting that 9 of 21 American AIDS patients they tested had evidence of
the swine fever virus in their blood.

The two researchers traveled to Florida where they tested the blood of domestic
and wild pigs found on a farm near Belle Glade, a poor migrant town where 50
cases of AIDS had been reported.

After a series of laboratory tests, Dr. Beldekas said he had found evidence that
the pigs were infected with swine fever.

In May, the Department of Agriculture dispatched inspectors to two farms in the
area to take blood samples from roughly 150 animals. They concluded that that
while the animals were sick, none had African swine fever.

In mid-July, in an effort to prove or disprove the dispute theory, the C.D.C.
began testing blood from AIDS patients and the blood serum drawn from the pigs
in Belle Glade. The tests were completed in the last week of August, said Dr.
Feorino, and the results will be published in The Lancet within a few months.

Dr. Teas and Dr. Beldekas said today they would like to study Dr. Feorino's
testing procedures. ''I'm continuing my work, said Dr. Beldekas, now an AIDS
researcher with the Massachusetts Health Research Institute in Boston. ''It is
not a dead issue as far as I'm concerned.''

THOUSANDS CALL AIDS HOTLINE

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -Since disclosure of the first drug to help AIDS
sufferers, thousands of people have called a Federal hotline to get more
information, health officials said today. Federal authorities announced Friday
that an experimental drug found to extend the lives of some AIDS patients would
be made available to certain categories of AIDS patients. They stressed,
however, that the drug was not a cure, and that it could have serious side
effects.

The National Institutes of Health said a special telephone hotline established
to answer questions about the drug, azidothymidine or AZT, had received more
than 3,500 calls from patients and physicians between Friday and Monday. The
Federal hotline number is (800) 843-9388. It operates daily from 8 A.M. until
midnight, Eastern time.

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                  March 27, 2003 Thursday, RT. 9 WEST EDITION

Garage plans are still in gear;
 Warren voters to decide on borrowing

BYLINE: J.P. Ellery; CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 779 words

DATELINE: WARREN



- Town officials plan to ask voters to spend $900,000 to build a highway garage
despite the possibility of sizable reductions in state aid.

Warren has been trying for nearly 15 years to move its Highway Department from
leased quarters off Albany Street in West Warren, facilities that have been
described as inadequate and antiquated.

In November, voters agreed to spend $110,000 to purchase a 7.25-acre tract off
Route 19, near Pine Grove Cemetery. An ad hoc committee is moving forward with
plans to construct a metal building there to serve as a highway garage. Those
plans include a request at the May annual town meeting to borrow the $900,000.

Selectmen Michael A. Smith and Donald G. Nickerson said yesterday that the plan
is to borrow the $900,000 for the highway garage from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture at a low interest rate for 40 years. They said the debt will have a
minimal effect on the town's overall annual operating budget.

At their meeting Tuesday, selectmen said the town could be in its worst
financial situation in recent memory if state lawmakers fail to increase local
aid to cities and towns.

''I think we're going to ride out the storm until we get the final (aid) figures
from the state,'' Mr. Smith said yesterday.

The state has serious fiscal problems. Gov. Mitt Romney and state lawmakers have
talked about various ways to deal with a $3 billion state budget shortfall.

Selectmen are concerned about a projected loss of roughly $700,000 in state
lottery funds, Mr. Smith said. Another plan being discussed by legislative
leaders, he said, would mean a potential reduction of 15 percent to 20 percent
in other state aid programs for fiscal 2004 compared with the amount received
for fiscal 2003.

Selectmen also learned Monday that the town's assessment as a member town in the
Quaboag Regional School District has increased by more than $250,000 because of
a cut in state aid to education.

If the town has to live with a 15 percent to 20 percent cut in local aid, Mr.
Smith said, the Quaboag Regional School District also will feel that reduction
on top of the loss in funds earmarked for education.

''The schools are going to have to take that cut, too,'' he said. ''They're
going to have to eat the 15 to 20 percent. We're (municipal government) not
going to be the only ones doing this.''

The Quaboag Regional School District budget of just over $12 million for fiscal
2004 calls for the layoff of 21 school personnel, including 17 teachers.

The town may have to look at laying off police, fire, highway and administrative
personnel if the fiscal situation fails to improve, Mr. Smith said.

An increase in the local property tax rate is also in the mix of possibilities,
he said.

Mr. Nickerson said it is still early in the state budgetary process, but he is
pessimistic. ''It is very doubtful that anything is going to be changed,'' he
said. ''If anything, we may even see more of a cut.''

Selectmen are considering moving the date of the annual town meeting to coincide
with the annual town meeting in neighboring West Brookfield, which is the other
town in the Quaboag Regional School District.

West Brookfield is scheduled to hold its annual town meeting on May 13 and
Warren is set to meet on May 14.

Mr. Smith said he would like to have Warren's annual town meeting moved up to
May 13 so West Brookfield's vote on the Quaboag Regional School budget will not
influence the vote in Warren.

West Brookfield selectmen are dealing with a shortfall of $230,000 as the town
prepares its fiscal 2004 operating budget.

West Brookfield Selectman Thomas H. Long said a meeting will be set up next week
with the town's Advisory Board in an effort to cut funds from various town
departments.

Warren selectmen also announced Tuesday that Richard Hamelin and Garine
Arakelian, his wife, have resigned from the Community Center Restoration
Committee.

The committee is trying to convince the town that purchasing and renovating the
former Community Center on Main Street in West Warren would be a smart move.

The two resignations were prompted by a difference of opinion among committee
members, Mr. Hamelin said. He declined to specify what those differing views
were, but said he and his wife still supported the work of the committee and
would continue to assist in seeing the project become a reality.

The restoration committee has proposed that the town purchase the vacant
community center building for $125,000 to $140,000 and spend as much as $1
million to renovate it into a combination police station, library, senior center
annex and community center.

                              264 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     January 9, 1990, Tuesday, City Edition

Farmers praised, Congress criticized as Bush visits Florida

BYLINE: CHRIS LAVIN

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 849 words

DATELINE: ORLANDO



ORLANDO - President Bush visited here Monday bringing a political    boost for a
friendly governor, words of comfort for farmers and a few    words of criticism
for Congress.

     Bush was accompanied by Florida Gov. Bob Martinez on the flight    from
Washington and throughout the three-hour visit.

     Bush also toured Epcot Center while punctuating his visit with    short
discussions with Martinez about pressing federal issues in    Florida.

     In a news conference after the president's departure, Martinez said    Bush
pledged his administration's help for Florida farmers hurt by the    Christmas
freeze and had directed Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter    to personally
oversee the effort. But Martinez said specifics on the    federal aid would have
to await documentation of the damage.

     Martinez said he again told Bush that Florida opposes off-shore oil
drilling along the state's coastline and is concerned the state's    citrus
industry could be hurt if U.S. citrus import tariffs are    eliminated before
foreign governments take a similar step.

     Bush didn't tip his hand on the off-shore oil or tariff issues,    Martinez
said.

     "I didn't get any guarantees," he said. "But we feel optimistic    because
he knew what I had to say and he was willing to meet to discuss    it."

     Martinez acknowledged that the president's visit could give him a
political boost this election year and he said he expects another boost    when
Bush visits Miami on Jan. 19 for a Martinez fund-raiser.

     "That's why we Republicans work real hard to get a Republican
president," Martinez said.

     Bush was among friends again as he addressed the 7,000 farmers at    the
American Farm Bureau Federation's gathering. He got long and loud    applause
for his positions on a wide variety of farm issues and for his    decision to
send troops into Panama.

     Bush pledged to protect farmers by working to keep interest rates    low,
foreign markets open to U.S. goods and by pushing again for a cut    in the
capital gains tax - a move he said would greatly benefit farmers    who have so
much invested in land and machinery.

     Capital gains are the profits from the sale of assets or    investments,
primarily stocks and bonds, but his proposed capital gains    cut also would
apply to the sale of farmland.

     Bush abandoned his kinder, gentler tone when he shifted his focus    to the
upcoming congressional session. Bush clearly was blaming    Congress for
dragging its feet on farm issues, his capital gains    proposal and other crime
and clean air proposals.

     "Getting a good farm bill through Congress is like milking a    bull," Bush
said to much laughter from his agrarian audience.

     "A year has passed and it is past time for Congress to tend to    some
unfinished business," Bush said.

     Bush also got loud applause when he called on Congress to pass his    Crime
Control Act "that has been sitting on Capitol Hill for months."

     Though Bush told the farmers the fight for the cut in capital gains    tax
"isn't over yet," many supporters of his proposal in Washington    were more
optimistic.

     The New York Times reported Monday that congressional leaders are
conceding they don't have the votes to block the capital gains cut this    year
and that debate now seems to center on how big the cut would be    and what form
it would take.

     That would come as good news to many of the small farmers - like    Cecile
and Marcel LaRoche of northern Vermont - who after a decade of    turmoil on
America's farms, had come to the Farm Bureau meeting this    year with a short
but critical list of problems.

     Farm prices were stabilizing and seemed adequate, the LaRoches    said, but
small farmers are now facing another crisis as they age.

     The LaRoches would like to sell their farm to their son and retire    on
the proceeds. But they say in recent years the price of farmland has
skyrocketed beyond their son's means.

     "Even if he could borrow the money, with interest rates today he
couldn't make a go of it," Cecile LaRoche said.

      "And if we sell it to some corporation, the capital gains tax    could
take our retirement money," said Marcel LaRoche.

     So hearing of a possible capital gains tax cut was some comfort to    the
aging farmers here, but many said they wished Bush had spoken more    directly
to this threat to the future of the small family farm.

     "For once I would like to hear someone talk about us," Mrs.    LaRoche
said. "We have to find a way to pass our farms on. The farm
 crisis isn't over for us or our children."

 - Information from the Los Angeles Times was used in this report.

gathering of 7,000 during an appearance Monday at the American Farm Bureau
Federation convention in Orlando.

                            Times Publishing Company


                              265 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      AUGUST 11, 1999 Wednesday SF EDITION

N.J. IS DECLARED A FARM DISASTER AREA FARMERS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR LOW-INTEREST
FEDERAL LOANS. PA. SEEKS SUCH RELIEF

BYLINE: Suzette Parmley, INQUIRER TRENTON BUREAU

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1138 words

DATELINE: TRENTON


With crop losses spiraling upward and a growing sense of urgency throughout the
region, the U.S. Department of Agriculture yesterday declared New Jersey a farm
disaster area. Farmers in 10 Pennsylvania counties also became eligible for
federal low-interest loans.

The declaration came one week after Gov. Whitman and members of the New Jersey
congressional delegation appealed to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman for
a statewide disaster designation.

On Monday, Gov. Ridge asked Glickman for the same designation for Pennsylvania.
The state's two Republican senators and the state agriculture secretary met with
farmers near Hershey yesterday, and said they were confident the state would
qualify for federal relief.

"The question is what form is that assistance going to take, and that's really
what the battle is ahead of us," said U.S. Sen. Rick Santorum, who met with the
farmers along with U.S. Sen. Arlen Specter, Pennsylvania Agriculture Secretary
Samuel Hayes Jr., and U.S. Rep. George Gekas (R., Pa.).

Connecticut, Maryland, Ohio and Virginia also are seeking farm-disaster
designations.

While Delaware has not requested the designation, Gov. Thomas Carper declared a
drought emergency Thursday in the northern part of the state, which means
mandatory water-use restrictions are in effect. The southern portion is under a
drought warning, and residents there are being asked to conserve water
voluntarily.

With the growing number of states enduring drought conditions, President Clinton
last week announced the formation of a task force to help coordinate efforts
nationally to tackle the crisis.

"This has been a devastating year for farmers all over the Northeast," Glickman
said while touring a family farm in Romulus, N.Y., where he made yesterday's
declaration. "They've been hit with a double whammy - a horrible drought on top
of record-low farm prices."

Glickman also declared 34 counties in New York agricultural disaster areas
yesterday. The decree also allows farmers in counties bordering on the region to
obtain the emergency low-interest loans. As a result, farmers in 10 Pennsylvania
border counties qualified for drought-relief loans yesterday. The counties on
the list were Bucks, Delaware, Monroe, Northampton, Philadelphia, Pike,
Bradford, Potter, Susquehanna and Tioga.

Last week, Glickman issued a similar declaration for West Virginia, which also
allowed four counties in southwest Pennsylvania - Beaver, Fayette, Greene and
Washington - to qualify.

With the disaster designation, farmers in New Jersey are eligible for assistance
programs under the USDA's Farm Service Agency. They have eight months to apply
for emergency, low-interest loans of up to $500,000 to help cover some of their
production and labor losses.

To be eligible for the loans, farmers must have suffered at least a 30 percent
loss in production in a single crop, be able to repay the loan and any other
loans, be unable to obtain credit elsewhere, and have adequate security.

Of New Jersey's 21 counties, 19 had sufficient production losses to warrant the
designation, according to state officials. Farmers in the two adjoining counties
- Hudson and Union - also are eligible for the loans.

A preliminary assessment by the state Agriculture Department last week estimated
that nearly 406,000 acres on more than 7,000 farms throughout New Jersey had
sustained crop losses of between 30 percent and 100 percent, at a cost exceeding
$80 million.

Assembly Speaker Jack Collins (R., Salem) and Assemblyman Jack Gibson (R.,
Atlantic) said last week that they would introduce legislation in the fall to
provide $15 million in loans and grants to aid New Jersey farmers.

New Jersey's secretary of agriculture, Arthur Brown, said farmers would need
more from the federal government than loans.

"Certainly, I am very happy with the turnaround time to get this request through
because it's extremely important for the agriculture community," Brown said
yesterday. "The loan program is certainly nice and can be utilized by farmers to
a certain extent to restructure their debt. But some are already so heavily in
debt because of two back-to-back drought seasons. For this group, additional
debt is not the answer."

Mike Maccarone, 38, a Swedesboro vegetable farmer, echoed Brown's concerns. The
drought, he said, has nearly wiped him out financially.

Loan assistance "is just not going to do it for a lot of people," Maccarone
said. "It is something, but it is still a loan. You still have to pay it back,
and in years like this, there is no profit to pay it back with."

Maccarone, who farms tomatoes, pickles, peppers, squash and cucumbers on 300
acres, said he had turned a small profit on tomatoes, which came in early - but
that was about it.

"If it wasn't for that, we wouldn't be able to pay our bills," he said. "Squash
and cucumbers didn't sell for anything this year. You can barely give the stuff
away. We've never seen a drought like this - ever."

Whitman yesterday sought help from Congress to include emergency-aid grants for
crop losses in the $7.4 billion Agriculture Department appropriations bill,
which passed the Senate and will be taken up by the House in the fall. The bill
is geared to aid farmers in several mid-Atlantic states but does not include
financial relief for farmers in New Jersey.

"Unfortunately, this traditional disaster assistance cannot adequately respond
to this year's unexpected economic impact on New Jersey's farm families and
agricultural industry," Whitman wrote to House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert (R.,
Ill.).

Democratic Sens. Frank Lautenberg and Robert Torricelli are also appealing to
colleagues in Washington to provide emergency grants for New Jersey in the
federal bill.

Late yesterday, Santorum visited a 600-acre farm in Nockamixon Township, Upper
Bucks County, with State Sen. Joseph Conti (R., Bucks) to make a pitch for
grants and direct cash payments to Pennsylvania farmers.

"Disaster cash assistance is still an open question," Santorum said as a light
rain fell on the withered cornfield where he stood. "I think that we will have a
disaster-assistance bill coming out of Congress that will include money for
low-interest loans, but the last thing Pennsylvania farmers need is more loans."

FOR MORE INFORMATION To qualify for federal assistance, farmers should contact
their regional office of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency.
In Burlington, Camden and Ocean Counties, call 609-267-1639. In Cumberland,
Atlantic and Cape May Counties, call 609-205-1225. In Salem and Gloucester
Counties, call 609-769-1126.

* Inquirer staff writer Lacy McCrary and suburban staff writer Melody McDonald
contributed to this article. It also contains information from the Associated
Press.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                       AUGUST 5, 1999 Thursday SF EDITION

WITH CROP PRICES AND WATER LEVELS LOW, SENATE OKS FARM AID TALKS WITH THE HOUSE
ARE NEXT. SOME LAWMAKERS WANT MORE HELP FOR GROWERS HURT BY A GRAIN GLUT AND
DROUGHT.

BYLINE: Gail Gibson, INQUIRER WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 478 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Senate approved more than $7 billion in emergency relief yesterday for
farmers suffering through a season of low prices and dry weather.

But producers will have to wait for the political dust to settle before they see
the money.

The House has yet to craft its own relief package for the slumping U.S.
agriculture economy. And despite an 89-8 vote on the Senate Republican plan,
Democrats and the White House say it does not do enough to help farmers.

Most notably, the Senate plan does not include specific disaster relief for
farmers in Eastern states who are feeling the effects of the summer's long
drought. Sen. Thad Cochran (R., Miss.), who crafted the package, said that issue
would be worked out in the fall between House and Senate negotiators.

"We think we have created here a fair program for all farmers," said Cochran,
who called the package a "strong commitment."

Speaker J. Dennis Hastert (R., Ill.) has said the House was committed to taking
action as well, putting Congress on track to pass what would be a record farm
aid package. Last year, the President signed a farm relief bill worth nearly $6
billion.

The Senate's aid package includes roughly $5.5 billion in direct payments to
growers of major grain crops such as corn and wheat. It also includes $475
million for soybean growers and $400 million in subsidies for crop insurance.

The plan aims primarily to boost farm incomes, suffering this year from low
prices brought on by a glut in grain stocks at the same time that global demand
has decreased.

Democrats began the debate Tuesday arguing that nearly $11 billion was needed to
help growers. But Senate Republicans, who offered an original package worth $6.7
billion, held firm. They bumped it up Tuesday only to include the $400 million
to help more farmers buy crop insurance.

A Democratic proposal to include $500 million in disaster aid for farmers hit by
the worst drought the Mid-Atlantic states have faced in decades also was
rejected.

The aid plan is part of a broader, $61 billion agriculture spending bill for the
next fiscal year. The overall bill was approved by voice vote last night. The
relief package had been among the main sticking points.

Sen. Byron Dorgan (D., N.D.) yesterday compared the Republican package to
throwing a short rope to a drowning person. It is a "nice gesture," Dorgan said,
"but it's not a lifesaving gesture."

Several farm groups also had sought more money. The National Farmers Union
called the Senate plan a "good first step" but said more help was needed.

At the White House yesterday, spokesman Joe Lockhart called the farm bailout
plan "clearly inadequate." He said Congress should find a fix for the 1996
"Freedom to Farm" act, blaming that legislation for providing few protections
for farmers when prices are low.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1999 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved


                              267 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                July 5, 1986, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

FARMERS PLAN A NATIONAL MEETING TO OPPOSE NEW REAGAN POLICIES

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 32, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 597 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4


Representatives of several leading farm organizations said today that they had
received a $250,000 grant from Farm Aid Inc., organizers of last year's farm
benefit concert, to finance a national farm policy convention in September in
St. Louis.

The announcement of the three-day United Farmer and Rancher Congress, to be held
Sept. 11-13, was made Thursday at a news conference in Austin, Tex., near where
another Farm Aid concert was performed today.

Representatives of the National Farmers Union, the American Agriculture
Movement, the North American Farm Alliance, the National Farmers Organization
and the National Save the Family Farm Coalition said their groups supported the
congress and hoped it would lead to proposals to change current Federal farm
policy.

The American Farm Bureau Federation, the nation's largest farm group, which
strongly supports current farm policy, has declined to participate in the
congress.

Reagan Policies Spur Meeting

Leaders said the meeting was being organized to express growing discontent with
the Reagan Administration's new farm program.

Economists say the program, based on lowering domestic commodity prices for
better competition on the world market, has not reversed the farm depression,
which has been primarily caused by failing export sales.

Last May, the United States imported more food than it exported, the first
monthly farm trade deficit since 1971.

''Obviously things are falling apart,'' said Doug Zabel, a spokesman for the
congress. ''People are going broke. Banks are folding. Foreclosures are
increasing. And this law, the most expensive in history, hasn't done anything to
help family farmers. If this farm law lasts five years, there won't be anybody
left in the countryside.''

The September congress will not be the first time farmers have held national
meetings in periods of crisis.

Influential 1892 Farm Meeting

Perhaps the most famous farm congress was held in 1892 in St. Louis and resulted
in the founding of the Populist Party was founded. Four years later, the party's
candidate for President, William Jennings Bryan, nearly defeated the Republican
candidate, William McKinley.

Most congresses, however, have not been nearly as celebrated or as influential,
according to Dr. Wayne Rasmussen, chief historian at the Department of
Agriculture. ''These kinds of conventions crop up every three or four years,''
he said, ''and they have some effect because they draw attention to a problem.
But after they end, ordinarily there is no follow-up and the whole political
movement falls to pieces.''

Farm Aid leaders asserted today that the St. Louis congress might play more of a
role in influencing policy than any in recent memory. It will come less than two
months before elections, and many Republicans are afraid that the farm crisis
could determine whether the party maintains control of the Senate. ----Concert
Draws 45,000 MANOR, Tex., July 4 (UPI) - About 45,000 music fans and supporters
of the American family farm crowded a race track today for the second Farm Aid
concert, organized by the country singer Willie Nelson.

Don Johnson, star of the television show ''Miami Vice'' was one of the guest
hosts for the 18-hour show.

''Contrary to what you all might think, I wasn't born in the back seat of a
Ferrari in a white suit down in Miami,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''I was born on a
little farm right up the road here in Missouri. My family were all farmers. I
was raised on a farm. My dad and I -we made out O.K. but there are a lot of
farmers out there not having that luck.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Willie Nelson and Steve Fromholtz performing (AP)

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 11, 2007 Thursday

FEMA expands list for federal aid

BYLINE: Margie Wood, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 339 words


Jan. 11--The Federal Emergency Management Agency has expanded the list of
Southern Colorado counties qualifying for snow emergency assistance because of
the second blizzard that struck the area the week after Christmas, Sen. Wayne
Allard's office announced Wednesday.

Emergency declarations issued last weekend by President Bush included 13
counties qualifying for aid following a pre-Christmas blizzard, but only Otero
County qualified for aid after the second blizzard. Sean Conway, chief of staff
for Allard, R-Colo., said the senator has been working with FEMA to expand the
declaration and learned late Wednesday that Pueblo, Bent, Prowers and Baca
counties now have been qualified for aid for the second blizzard, and Crowley
County likely will qualify as well.

Conway explained the process: "Once a county provides information to the state
(about expenses for snow removal and sheltering of people), the governor can
just write to FEMA to add those counties to the original declaration."

He added that FEMA "has just bent over backwards to help these people."

Last week, Allard introduced legislation to allow the U.S. Department of
Agriculture's commodities program to reimburse ranchers for livestock lost in
the back-to-back blizzards.

FEMA aid at this point is limited to reimbursing local governments for their
expenses in blizzard recovery. FEMA is excluded from offering aid to
agricultural producers for their losses, because that is the purview of the
USDA.

"We're also working with USDA to determine what programs are available to help,"
Conway said. "The biggest challenge is getting people directed to the right
programs. We know this is going to be a long-term issue for those cow-calf
operations out on the plains."

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                              May 23, 2010 Sunday
                                  ALL EDITION

Program starts food fight;
Senators complain about aid to small, local growers

BYLINE: McClatchy Newspapers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 386 words


WASHINGTON - There's a food fight under way between Congress and the Agriculture
Department, and it's about small potatoes - organic small potatoes.

Big ones, too - and peas, beans, beef, poultry and melons. Just about anything
that's farm-raised and edible.

Three Republican senators have complained that a USDA effort to educate the
public about where food comes from slights "conventional farmers who produce the
vast majority of our nation's food supply."

Sens. Pat Roberts of Kansas, John McCain of Arizona and Saxby Chambliss of
Georgia complained in a recent letter to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack that
his agency spent $65 million last year on a program "aimed at small, hobbyist
and organic producers whose customers generally consist of affluent patrons at
urban farmers markets."

The USDA calls the program "Know Your Farmer, Know Your Food." It has no money
of its own, but the agency has spent other federal agricultural dollars to
further its goals, including farm bill funds to aid locally grown food projects.
These include grants to support farmers markets in Kansas and California, crop
productivity and management efforts in Missouri and Alaska, and organic
agriculture research in North Carolina and Washington state.

Bruce Babcock, an economist and the director of the Cen-ter for Agricultural and
Rural Development at Iowa State University, said it was "ironic" that the
senators and others objected to the USDA spending $65 million on "Know Your
Farmer" when commodity producers received $5 billion during the past twoyears,
and the crop insurance industry got $7 billion. "We should welcome alternative
producers if we want to see entrepreneurship grow in rural America," Babcock
said.

Dan Nagengast, the executive director of the Kansas Rural Center, said critics
have ignored the program's larger goals: To spread the word about the economic
value of local food production and thereby preserve America's rural heritage.

"Cultivating these new markets - not replacing old ones - is critical to
revitalizing rural America," Vilsack wrote to Roberts, McCain and Chambliss.

About 40,000 midsize farms disappeared between 2002 and 2007, according to the
U.S. Census. For many, it's too costly to compete. They're too big to market
their own goods directly, but often not big enough to use wholesale.

                              272 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            August 4, 1999 Wednesday

Heat wave withers prospects for record U.S. grain harvest  Large crops still
expected, but some retail food prices starting to rise

BYLINE: SCOTT KILMAN The Wall Street Journal; WSJ

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL; Pg. B12

LENGTH: 586 words

DATELINE: Chicago


Prospects for record U.S. grain harvests are evaporating in the wake of a
Midwest heat wave and a stubborn drought across the East.

Midwest farmers are still expected to harvest such large crops this autumn that
food inflation is expected to remain mild, but some retail food prices are
beginning to rise.

Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting centre at Georgia State
University, said the drought prompted him to raise his outlook for food
inflation this year to 2.5 per cent from the 2.2-per-cent rise he predicted in
early July.

Still, crop prices remain at unprofitable levels for many Midwest farmers, and
few economists see a big improvement soon. Foreign demand for U.S. crops remains
weak, and Midwest grain elevators are stuffed with the remnants of a three-year
string of bumper harvests. Midwest grain handlers are already preparing to store
the autumn harvests outdoors on the ground.

Without the massive farm aid already slated for growers this year, net farm
income would quickly sink to half of what it was in 1996, when the farm economy
was riding high on an export boom.

The U.S. Agriculture Department expects net farm income of $43.8-billion (U.S.)
this year, of which $16.6-billion is government payments that have already been
earmarked. Even more aid is coming. The Senate is debating multibillion-dollar
bailout packages that could push annual farm aid toward the record levels spent
during the mid-1980s farm debt crisis.

Meanwhile, the Northeast drought is slashing the supply of vegetables for
canning companies. Retail milk prices will probably rise later this year,
because the drought is scorching key dairy states from Pennsylvania to Vermont.

Some dairy officials say milk production will probably climb only 2 per cent
this year, instead of the 4 per cent they originally had forecast. Northeastern
cows are producing less milk, because the drought is making them physically
uncomfortable as well as turning their pastures brown.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange's milk futures contract for September delivery
settled at $16.81 per hundred pounds of milk, up 6 cents on the day for a
33-per-cent rise since late April.

Grain analysts cut their harvest forecasts by hundreds of millions of bushels
for the nation's two biggest crops -- corn and soybeans -- after an Agriculture
Department survey showed that last week's triple-digit temperatures across the
Farm Belt caused greater-than-expected damage to Midwest fields.

The government's weekly survey showed that on Sunday, 57 per cent of soybean
fields in the 19 biggest-producing states were in good to excellent condition,
down from 65 per cent the previous week. The per cent of the corn crop in
good-to-excellent condition in the 17 biggest-producing states sank to 63 per
cent from 70 per cent the previous week.

Before the late July heat wave, which lasted for 12 days in some Plains states,
some analysts had expected corn farmers to harvest as many as 9.9 billion
bushels. That would be the second-largest crop on record.

Although cooler temperatures have returned to the Midwest, the damage done to
the corn crop is almost impossible to reverse. The heat wave hit during the
crop's pollination stage, when weather can have the biggest influence on yield.
At the same time, analysts said prospects for the corn crop aren't likely to
worsen much more.

Analysts didn't cut their soybean harvest estimates as steeply because the
soybean plant continues to flower through August, which gives it a chance to
replace damaged pods.

LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The New York Times

                              May 13, 2013 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

Food Aid Reforms

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; LETTER; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 216 words


To the Editor:

Re ''Proposal for Changes in Food Aid Sets Off Infighting in Congress'' (news
article, May 3): American taxpayers' food aid dollars should go to help starving
people, not line the pockets of special interests. That's why the reform
proposal for allowing the local purchase of food for aid represents the best
policy.

More than half the money for foreign food aid in the form of grain goes to
shipping and procurement. Local purchase of food will cut out middlemen and
deliver food to the hungry weeks faster. Four million more hungry people can be
fed if the rules are reformed.

Representative Robert B. Aderholt, chairman of the House Appropriations
subcommittee on agriculture, worries that reform would hurt American farmers.
But food aid currently accounts for less than 1 percent of American agricultural
exports.

''Exports via food aid are a small drop in the market,'' Veronica Nigh of the
American Farm Bureau Federation told Reuters. ''Our concern is less about
decreasing an important revenue stream for U.S. agriculture. It's more about the
loss of a sense of pride.''

Surely Congress can shore up American agriculture's sense of pride without
letting four million people starve.

JONATHAN ZASLOFF Los Angeles, May 7, 2013

The writer is a professor at the U.C.L.A. School of Law.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/13/opinion/food-aid-reforms.html

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              274 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                     JANUARY 21, 2000 Friday CWEST EDITION

HELP LIKELY FOR FRUIT FARMS AFFLICTED BY PLUM POX VIRUS PEACH AND NECTARINE
FARMS NEAR GETTYSBURG WERE INFESTED LAST YEAR. FEDERAL AID MAY BE FORTHCOMING.

BYLINE: Walter F. Naedele, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEIGHBORS; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 313 words


U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman has authorized federal compensation
for peach and nectarine farms near Gettysburg, Pa., hit by the devastating plum
pox virus, Sen. Rick Santorum (R., Pa.) said yesterday.

Glickman signed an emergency declaration Wednesday and intends to announce it
soon, Santorum said in an interview from his Washington office.

The declaration does not provide funding or a timetable for funding, said
Santorum, a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee. Instead, he said, it
makes Pennsylvania fruit growers eligible for federal assistance.

The Agriculture Department will work with the Office of Management and Budget to
determine whether money is available in the current USDA budget or whether
emergency congressional legislation is needed, he said.

The proposal provides money for several years, Santorum said, because after
infested orchards are cleared, it will take time for newly planted trees, free
of the plum pox, to mature and bear fruit.

Susan McAvoy, the Agriculture Department's deputy press secretary,did not
confirm Santorum's statements. But she said in a telephone interview that the
USDA would soon make an announcement involving plum pox.

In a November interview, John M. Halbrendt, a Pennsylvania State University
pathologist investigating the infestation, said: "It's going to be devastating
to the fruit industry [in the state]. They're going to lose a huge chunk of
their income."

The pox, discovered on a fruit-sorting line in Adams County in September, makes
fruit trees barren but does not harm consumers.

The infestation has been found so far on the farms of four growers in the
Gettysburg area.

The loss - the value of which has not been estimated - could be significant
because Pennsylvania is the nation's fourth-largest peach producer, after
California, South Carolina and Georgia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                           August 30, 2006 Wednesday
                                 THIRD EDITION

DIGEST

BYLINE: FROM NEWS SERVICES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 231 words


WASHINGTON

Nearly $800 million in drought aid promised

The government promised nearly $800 million in aid Tuesday to ranchers and
farmers stricken by a near-record drought.

Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced the aid while visiting a ranch in
South Dakota, one of the states hardest hit by drought and heat. Farmers are
struggling in the Plains, the South and, to a lesser degree, the Upper Midwest.

The secretary said 64 percent of the nation's beef cows and breeding stock are
in drought-stricken areas and many ranchers are being forced to cull their
herds. Drought is also stressing fields of cotton, wheat, sorghum, peanuts and
other crops.

Last month was the hottest July since the Dust Bowl in 1936. Drought has
approached records in many parts of the country, where conditions have been
driest from May through June since 1988.

DETROIT

Man is charged with killing seven prostitutes

A man suspected of killing seven prostitutes over the past five years was
charged with murder Tuesday. Police said he is a suspect in as many as 14 deaths
in the city since 1999.

Shelly Andre Brooks, 37, is charged with seven counts of premeditated murder and
seven counts of felony murder.

The seven victims ranged in age from 30 to 53 and were drug users, police said.
All were raped, beaten to death, and their bodies were left on the city's east
side, some in buildings, others in vacant lots.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                              276 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                    Appeal-Democrat (Marysville, California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 7, 2008 Wednesday

Counties seeking farm aid: April freeze squeezes profits for Yuba-Sutter growers

BYLINE: Howard Yune, Appeal-Democrat, Marysville, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 392 words


May 7--Sutter County farmers lost at least $35.7 million in peaches, prunes and
nuts killed by an April frost -- the leading edge of crop losses that could lead
to federal aid for Mid-Valley growers.

Damage from the freeze wiped out $15.6 million worth of English walnuts, $9.7
million in dried plums and $9.4 million of cling peaches, according to figures
released by the Sutter County Department of Agriculture.

The agency has applied to the state Office of Emergency Services for disaster
declarations for the crops. That step would lead the U.S. Department of
Agriculture to decide whether to provide aid for local farmers, such as
low-interest loans to replace some of the lost crop sales.

Unseasonable cold settled over the North State early on April 21, plunging
temperatures into the 20s in much of Yuba-Sutter -- nearly 20 degrees below the
30-year average for that date. Frost destroyed numerous nuts and fruits, most of
them early in their development, and farmers said the full extent of their
losses may only become known during summer harvests.

In Yuba County, agriculture officials are seeking federal aid for a wide range
of local growers. The county has applied for state disaster status on at least
nine local crops, according to Kevin Roush, assistant agriculture director.

Frost damage in Yuba County struck not only the mainstay tree fruits and nuts
but numerous other crops, including persimmons, kiwi fruit and even wine grapes
in the eastern foothills. County farming officials are still checking on smaller
farms and may apply for disaster status on more crops, Roush said Tuesday.

How many businesses will lose revenue and have to cut jobs due to the freeze
remains unknown. Sutter County's reported loss covers only direct damage to
plants and not to farm-linked employers, such as trucking firms and banks.

hyune@appealdemocrat.com

                               The New York Times

                June 6, 1985, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Agriculture vs. the Merchant Marine

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 292 words


To the Editor:

Though less than 5 percent of our exports and imports are carried in U.S. ships,
special interests in Washington, notably the agriculture lobby, are urging
repeal of the cargo-preference law requiring 50 percent of U.S. foreign-aid
cargoes to be carried in U.S. ships. Lobbyists for agriculture complain that the
higher freight rates on U.S. ships are unfair to farmers.

Only on some foreign ships, mostly Liberian and Panamanian, are rates
significantly cheaper. British, French, West German and Scandinavian freight
rates - and even the Soviet Union's when it suits the Russians' purposes -
usually approximate those of U.S. shippers. A Liberian or Panamanian shipper
will undercut a competitor on a foreign-aid cargo if there is a chance of
obtaining another cargo, a profitable one, at the port of destination. U.S.
vessels, with their higher costs, cannot afford to do this.

It is ironic that agriculture, the recipient of billions in Government
subsidies, should seek repeal of a law without which U.S. ships would all but
disappear from the sea lanes. The industry now carries less than 5 percent of
our foreign commerce. It has lost the entire passenger and cruise trade
operating in the Caribbean from U.S. ports and has dwindled from more than 2,000
ships at the end of World War II to fewer than 300 today.

Representative Helen Delich Bentley of Maryland, a former member of the Maritime
Commission, has stated: ''Destruction or serious reduction of the
cargo-preference law would be a fatal blow to the U.S. merchant marine. Our
agricultural industry is not threatened with extinction, but most assuredly, our
U.S. merchant marine is.'' JAMES R. BOLAND Philadelphia, May 28, 1985 The writer
is a retired ship captain.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: LETTER

                   Copyright 1985 The New York Times Company

                              278 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              January 27, 1983, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

BYLINE: By Robin Herman and Laurie Johnston

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 178 words


The Cost of Free Food

I t's not cheap to give away free food, as Operation Lifeline found when it
distributed 2.8 million pounds of cheese last year under the Department of
Agriculture's dairy surplus program.

With an 11 million-pound allotment this year, the coalition of nonprofit
charities says a three-month distribution effort starting next week may cost
$26,000. Some politicians have called for a halt to the program unless the
Federal Government finances the whole operation. Distribution expenses are now
left to the states and charities.

But Ollie Bee Boddie, executive director of Operation Lifeline and the United
Food Bank in the South Bronx, says a $100 contribution from each of perhaps 300
member organizations in the five boroughs would cover the cost.

The demand for the processed American cheese (one pound to a person) is
unabated. ''As a food bank, we serve people all year round,'' Mr. Boddie said.
''There's a lot of people out there who are hungry. I could have a million
pounds of food here and it would go. I can't have too much.''

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                              279 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                     May 27, 1999, Thursday, Final Edition

NATION IN BRIEF;
 Disaster aid checks to go out to farmers

BYLINE: From our news services

SOURCE: Journal

SECTION: News; Pg. 22a

LENGTH: 477 words

Farmers waiting for $ 2.3 billion in emergency disaster aid will begin to see
checks next week, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman told a Senate Agriculture
hearing in Washington today.

Payments to about 260,000 farmers will begin on Tuesday. Glickman and his agency
have been widely criticized for the delay in distributing the money, which was
included in a $ 6 billion farm bailout passed in October.

Glickman has maintained that the massive aid package, which included provisions
for everyone from dairy to grain farmers, was ''complex'' to administer.

The agency distributed $ 2.8 billion in payments to compensate for low prices
shortly after the package was passed. But distributing the $ 2.3 billion in
disaster payments, which cover disasters and disease, was burdensome, officials
have said.

FTC investigating dietary supplement
The Federal Trade Commission is investigating a dietary supplement recently
introduced in the United States as a way to reduce cellulite. The FTC is looking
into whether the makers of Cellasene have enough evidence to substantiate their
claims that an eight-week course of three pills daily can help rid users of
cellulite, the irregular pockets of fat that cause the area around women's hips
and thighs to appear dimpled. The investigation comes even as the Italian
manufacturers of the product, Medestea Internazionale, launched a media campaign
this week to dispel skepticism about their product. Vitamin maker Rexall Sundown
Inc., based in Boca Raton, Fla., has the U.S. distribution rights to Cellasene,
which entered the U.S. market in March and has been promoted in fashion
magazines and newspapers.

GAO: More find work after leaving welfare
Nearly three years after the enactment of federal welfare reform, between 61
percent and 87 percent of adults leaving public assistance have gotten jobs, a
far higher number than previously reported, according to a comprehensive review
of welfare research being released in Washington today. " This is an
unprecedented increase in labor force participation by low-income, especially
never-married mothers," House Republican leaders said in a statement that
accompanies the General Accounting Office's summary.

Man who hit black teens to face trial
A white man accused of driving onto a sidewalk to hit two black teenagers on
bikes has been charged with attempted murder and ordered to stand trial. James
Langenbach, 27, of Kenosha, Wis., intentionally swerved his car and sped toward
the 14-year-old boys as they rode their bicycles May 16, police allege. Dino
Gigliotti, who was riding a motorcycle behind Langenbach's car, testified at a
preliminary hearing Wednesday that he saw the car swerve up the curb and on the
sidewalk about 30 feet behind the boys. ''In my opinion, it was floored,''
Gigliotti said. ''He accelerated all the way.''

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                               February 28, 2001

Fresh aid plea by US farmers

BYLINE: By Jwatson

SECTION: Agency:Agency:Agency, Pg.18

LENGTH: 231 words


Joe Watson

FARM leaders in the US have renewed their claims for billions of dollars in new
federal aid to bolster farm income.

Low grain prices made a new farm bail-out imperative, they claimed.

The US Congress has enacted more than GBP 16billion in rescue packages since
late 1998 as an antidote to keep farmers afloat during a price-depressing global
grain glut.

Roger Johnson, North Dakota agriculture commissioner, said: "We know the hurt is
out there."

US Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman has meanwhile admitted there is likely

to be some cuts to her

budget in the coming

year.

Approved

The cuts are likely to be in discretionary spending, includ$-ing staffing. Most
farm support and conservation programmes are so-called mandatory spend$ -ing.

The National Association of State Departments of Agricul$-ture (Nasda) in the US
has approved a letter that asks Congress to pay out GBP 6.6billion to farmers.

Nasda said: "The sad reality remains that government pay$-ments will once again
mean the difference between remaining in business and going out of busi$-ness."

Last week, 20 mainline farm groups wrote leaders of the House and Senate Budget
com$-mittees in the States to ask for about GBP 6.6billion in emergency aid to
farmers as soon as pos$-sible.

The farm groups said more aid would be required if the new US farm act is not
put in place quickly.

                             Farmington Daily Times

                              June 27, 2004 Sunday

Counties may get drought relief

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 2A

LENGTH: 316 words


- The Daily Times -

WASHINGTON - Some New Mexico livestock producers may qualify for drought aid
under a U.S. Department of Agriculture initiative to open Conservation Reserve
Program acreage to grazing, Sen Pete Domenici announced in a news release.

Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman authorized use of CRP acres by cattle
producers who are having difficulty feeding their livestock due to the
multi-year drought. To be eligible, a county must have suffered at least a
40-percent deviation from normal precipitation, or be at a D3 or D4 level for
drought as rated by the U.S. Drought Monitor.

"I am glad the USDA is offering relief to livestock producers by opening access
to CRP lands.  New Mexico has faced many hardships with the droughts these past
years, and I expect that some of our counties will qualify for this aid," said
Domenici, who continues to press the Senate to act on his bill to create a
national drought policy which will improve preparedness and relief for those
affected by droughts.

County eligibility for emergency grazing will be determined after consultations
between the Farm Service Agency state committees and the NRCS state technical
committees.  The authorization for grazing extends through Sept. 30.

CRP producers place their land in retirement in order to improve environmental
conditions.  The program aids in erosion prevention, wildlife protection, and
water quality improvement.  New Mexico currently has 487,000 acres under CRP.
Last year, there were 15 counties in the CRP (Bernalillo, Cibola, Colfax, Curry,
DeBaca, Harding, Lea, Mora, Quay, Roosevelt, San Juan, San Miguel, Santa Fe,
Torrance and Union).

[cut]

Last November, all New Mexico counties with the exception of Los Alamos were
declared natural disaster areas due to drought losses.  Further drought disaster
designations were issued to Lea and Eddy counties in April.

                              All Rights Reserved

                              282 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                     September 14, 1999, Tuesday, Edition 1

ONTARIO LAGS U.S.

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 862 words



in farm subsidies


Stuart Laidlaw

American farmers get twice the government support Ontario farmers enjoy, and are
expected to get even more, a study by the University of Guelph says.

''That playing field is not level,'' said Brian Doidge, the economist behind the
study. ''We in Canada are at a disadvantage to our neighbours south of the
border.''

The study compares two imaginary and identical 500-acre farms in Ontario and the
United States. Each was assumed to have 200 acres of corn, 100 acres of wheat
and 200 acres of soybeans.

It found that while the Ontario farmer would get $48.50 an acre in support this
year, the U.S. farmer would get $90.51 an acre, with more expected down the
road.

The U.S. House committee on agriculture begins two days of hearings today into
another $7.4 billion (U.S.) in emergency aid for American farmers.

Last year, Congress approved $5.9 billion in emergency aid to farmers because of
depressed prices, declining export markets and bad weather. U.S. farm incomes
are forecast to be 8.2 per cent lower this year than they were three years ago.

If this year's aid is approved as expected, the study's American farmer would
get the equivalent of $130 (Canadian) an acre, or 2 1/2 times that available to
the Ontario farmer.

Last year, the study's U.S. farmer received $103.61 an acre, compared with
$28.52 in Ontario.

That's a big change since 1996, when the U.S. farmer received $21.44, compared
with $18.37 on the Ontario farm.

Farm groups in Ontario have long complained that their counterparts in other
countries are getting more help from the government. Subsides will be a major
topic at World Trade Organization talks in Seattle this fall.

Doidge said farm aid in both countries has been going up the past few years as
market prices for crops dropped and compensating aid increased.

But the huge jump in American aid is a result of disaster relief in the United
States, such as the $7.4 billion being debated today, that has not been matched
in Ontario.

Doidge is a grain-pricing specialist at the University of Guelph's Ridgetown
College and head of continuing education there. He advises Ontario farmers on
factors affecting grain prices and their incomes.

His study appeared in the August edition of a newsletter he and colleagues at
the Ontario Ministry of Agriculture put out for farmers, called The Grain
Letter.

Colin Reesor, a ministry representative in Walkerton who puts out the newsletter
with Doidge, said much of the difference in aid between Ontario and the United
States can be attributed to the way programs in the two countries are set up.

The American program tends to encourage farmers to grow certain crops, such as
soybeans, that pay more in subsidies. As well, the setup of the program makes it
easy for farmers who don't need help to get money anyway.

The U.S. aid program works by setting benchmark prices at the beginning of each
year for each county in the country. If prices fall below that price, farmers
are paid the full difference when they take their crops to market.

But there's a wrinkle under which U.S. farmers get money they don't need, Reesor
said. The government pay- outs are based on the previous day's prices, while
farmers can sell their crops at today's prices.

Farmers have learned to take advantage of that by selling their crops on days
when the price spikes up, Reesor said.

Here's how: The current benchmark price for soybeans is about $5.40 (U.S.) a
bushel, depending on the county. If the price of soybeans jumps from, say, $5.
10 one day to $5.40 the next, there will be a rush of farmers to the grain
elevator selling their crops, Reesor said.

They will then be paid the full price for their soybeans, plus 30 cents in
government aid, based on the previous day's prices.

''They are basically harvesting the program,'' Reesor said.

Ontario farmers don't have it so well. The province's market revenue program, by
contrast, is much slower to pay and hands out less money when it does. It sets a
benchmark price based on a 15-year average.

If farmers sell their crops for less than the benchmark, which is set at the end
of the harvest, they get two-thirds of the difference in aid. But calculating
the benchmark and how much each farmer will get takes about a year, so farmers
are usually harvesting one year's crop when the cheques arrive for last year's.

''We still haven't been paid for last year,'' Reesor said.

Doidge expects the U.S. aid program to continue setting high benchmark prices
for soybeans, so he expects a big U.S. soybean crop next year, which he said
will boost supplies and drive down already low prices.

Because of that, he is recommending that Ontario farmers plant corn next year,
since its price won't be under as much downward pressure.

Forecasts for a fourth year of bumper U.S. harvests, combined with three years
of weak export demand, have left grain piling up in U.S. bins. U.S. corn prices
are forecast to be the lowest in 12 years and soybean prices are likely to be
the lowest in 13 years, the U.S. agriculture department said Friday.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      SEPTEMBER 1, 2000 Friday SF EDITION

METROPOLITAN AREA NEWS IN BRIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 770 words


Two events to be added

to annual 12K AIDS Walk

Organizers of the annual AIDS Walk announced yesterday that they would add two
events - a 12-kilometer run and a one-mile stroller walk for families with small
children - to the traditional 12K walk at this year's event on Oct 15.

Also for the first time, participants will be able to register or obtain a
sponsor form online at www.aidswalkphilly.org Anyone interested can also
register by calling the AIDS Fund at 215-731-9255. There is no registration fee
and no minimum pledge requirement.

"This year's goal is to increase overall participation to help raise more funds
for essential AIDS-related services in the region," said Susan Higginbotham,
executive director of the AIDS Fund. Last year, more than 30,000 people
participated, raising nearly $1 million for 44 area organizations that provide
care, education and other services for people with HIV and AIDS and others
affected by the disease.

Cheese franks are recalled

over possible metal shards

READING - The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection
Service has announced the recall of 6,588 pounds of cheese franks that could be
contaminated with metal fragments.

Berks Packaging Co. of Reading recalled Weis Quality Our Deluxe Cheese Franks
after a consumer from Pennsylvania reported finding two metal fragments in the
product, company officials said. The recalled package has "EST. 8782" in the
USDA seal, and a sell-by date of Oct. 17. The contaminated product is believed
to have been sold in Pennsylvania, Maryland, New York and New Jersey grocery
stores within two weeks of production.

Anyone with food-safety questions may call the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline at
1-800-535-4555.

N.J. judge dismisses challenge of welfare cap for mothers

NEWARK, N.J. - A Superior Court judge in Essex County has dismissed a lawsuit
challenging the state law that caps welfare benefits for mothers who have more
children.

Judge Anthony J. Iuliani on Wednesday granted the state's motion for a summary
judgment in a lawsuit filed on behalf of mothers on welfare who gave birth to
children after 1992. He rejected arguments that the "family cap," or child
exclusion provision, keeps poor children from getting enough food and other
benefits and interferes with a women's right to have children.

The American Civil Liberties Union, the National Organization of Women, and
other groups that filed the suit are expected to appeal.

Man awaiting murder charge

died of a heart attack in cell

A Shamong man charged with the 1999 murder of his father died of a heart attack
in his state prison cell, a Mercer County coroner has ruled.

Michael S. Mazzola, 34, was found dead Monday morning in his cell at the state
Central Reception and Assignment Facility in Trenton, where he was serving a
separate three-year sentence, officials said. His attorney said Mazzola was a
diabetic.

A grand jury in February issued an 11-count indictment against Mazzola on
charges that he shot his father, Richard J. Mazzola, 61, twice in the head on
March 28, 1999, in the trailer home they shared. He then stole his father's car,
a .22-caliber rifle, credit cards and cash, authorities said.

State to begin mailing

property-tax rebate checks

TRENTON - New Jersey property owners should receive their NJ Saver property-tax
rebates starting next week.

The first checks are to be mailed tomorrow. More than $280 million in checks
will be mailed to 1.2 million property-tax payers in the coming days. This is
the second year for the program, designed to partially reimburse residents for
school taxes.

The average rebate is $240. Checks will go out tomorrow for Burlington and
Cumberland Counties, Tuesday for Gloucester and Mercer Counties, Thursday for
Atlantic and Cape May Counties, and next Friday for Camden and Salem Counties.

Nurse's assistant arrested

in Del. patient-rape case

Police in New Castle County, Del., yesterday arrested a 38-year-old former
employee of the Mary Campbell Center in Wilmington on charges he repeatedly
raped a 24-year-old patient while he worked there.

Investigators said the patient, who has cerebral palsy, told them that Demetrius
Joyner, a certified nurse's assistant, raped her at least twice in October and
November while she was his patient. The victim told police she did not come
forward until Wednesday because Joyner had threatened to kill her parents if she
said anything, investigators said.

Joyner, of the 1300 block of Chestnut Street, Wilmington, was taken to Gander
Hill Prison in Wilmington to await arraignment.

                               The New York Times

                August 5, 1986, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

DROUGHT AREA WAITS FOR AID AND MORE THAN A LITTLE RAIN

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4


Moderate rainfall in much of the South and Middle Atlantic region over the
weekend provided the first substantial break in the scorching, dry conditions
that have plagued the 10-state area for months.

Meteorologists and coordinators of the Agriculture Department's drought-relief
program said today that they were encouraged by the precipitation, which also
brought lower temperatures that are expected to last two or three more days.

But it would take weeks of such weather to end the South's costliest drought,
and one of its deadliest heat waves, weather experts said. And August is usually
the hottest and driest month of the year in the drought region, which extends
from Mississippi to southern Pennsylvania and now includes northern Florida and
much of eastern Tennessee.

''The heat has taken a vacation - the rain helps,'' said Larry Heitkemper, a
meteorologist with the Earth Satellite Corporation in Chevy Chase, Md. ''Eastern
North Carolina received moderate rainfalls. But the problem with this kind of
rain is that it falls so heavy it runs off that hard soil. They still need
general, good soaking rains.''

House to Act on Aid Plan

In other developments, the House of Representatives is preparing to act,
possibly as early as Tuesday, on drought-relief measures that are similar to a
proposal passed on Friday by the Senate. The measures are designed to complement
the Administration's relief program, which was put into action on Friday.

The House bill is sponsored by Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of
Texas, who is chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, and Edward R.
Madigan, Republican of Illinois. The House bill and the Agriculture Department's
program, for instance, would enable farmers to split the costs of feed with the
Government.

In addition, the House proposal would require the Agriculture Department to
monitor areas where livestock feed became scarce. In any area where there was
less than a three-day supply of feed, the Secretary of Agriculture would be
required to move surplus stocks of Government feed grains into that region to be
donated to farmers until the shortage was alleviated.

The House relief measure also calls on the Government to pay 80 percent of the
cost of transporting hay into areas where feed is in short supply. Last week,
the Congressional Budget Office estimated that these and other measures in the
House proposal could cost $300 million to $600 million. Estimates of the cost of
the Senate's package range up to $1.5 billion.

The Administration program will cost well over $1 billion, according to budget
analysts, including more than $50 million in income-subsidy payments to be
mailed this month, instead of after the harvest.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                          November 26, 1992, Thursday

NEWS BRIEFS Food giveaway will help truly hungry

BYLINE: Compiled by Dana Dratchfood; holidays; aid; sales; arts; children;
entertainment; charities

SECTION: EXTRA; Section G; Page 2

LENGTH: 527 words


Workers at Cobb Emergency Aid experienced a chilling kind of first during their
September food distribution. Six of the men coming in for food were so hungry
that they sat down and ate their groceries right there in the Civic Center
parking lot.

"You could tell they were really hungry," said Laura Mauldin, the U.S.
Department of Agriculture food coordinator for Cobb County Emergency Aid. "There
was a real need in the crowd. They were really hungry. Several people who worked
with us have noticed the difference. [The clients] were very gracious and very
polite, but it was a different level [of want]. And the need continues to grow."

Emergency Aid will feed 2,300 families with its distribution Dec. 9. The winter
disbursement consists of 5 pounds of flour, 2 pounds of peanut butter, 2 pounds
of rice, 2 pounds of butter, two 29-ounce cans of pork, a pound of canned corn
and a pound of raisins.

Shut-ins can authorize someone to pick up their food by signing a paper with
their name, address, Social Security number, number of people in the family and
total household income.

Emergency Aid will also provide free blood pressure screenings.

The distribution will be held at the Cobb Civic Center between 9 a.m. and 6
p.m., though Ms. Mauldin says that this time they expect to run out of food
before they run out of customers.

For more information, call 428-2601.

Powder Springs to auction goods: The city of Powder Springs will hold an auction
Dec. 4, at 9 a.m. at the city's public works facility at 3006 Spring Industrial
Drive. Twelve items, including cars, trucks, bikes and a generator, will go on
the block. Prospective buyers can examine the goods from 8 to 9 a.m., when
sealed bids will be taken.

Sculptors' works on display at Galleria: Gallery 300 is displaying the work of
four Atlanta artists through November.

Gordon Chandler, Carl Andre Davidt, Michael Gilmartin and Timothy Sutherland are
nationally recognized sculptors who create unique furniture. Mr. Chandler and
Mr. Davidt work in metal and Mr. Gilmartin and Mr. Sutherland use wood.

Gallery 300 is on the lobby level of the Atlanta Galleria, 300 Galleria Parkway.
Guests should enter from the parking lot side.

For more information, call the Jubilee Cultural Alliance at 988- 9641.

Ticket Tree will send 100 kids to see "Nutcracker": Proceeds from a Nutcracker
Ticket Tree at the Stouffer Waverly Hotel will send 100 underprivileged children
to see a performance of the Atlanta Ballet's "The Nutcracker."

For a $ 10 donation to fund one child's ticket, patrons receive 12 nutcracker
cookies. They also receive a gift tag with the child's name, and donors may
write in their name and hang the tag on the tree.

The hotel bakes and donates the cookies and the Atlanta Ballet donates $ 500 by
discounting its tickets from $ 15 to $ 10.

A kickoff ceremony Sunday in the atrium lobby featured two six-foot
ice-sculpture nutcrackers and the giant mouse from "The Nutcracker." The Atlanta
Ballet performed a short piece and storyteller Sarah Dubignon will tell a
10-minute story.

The hotel is in the Galleria shopping center across U.S. 41 from Cumberland
Mall.

                      Arizona Range News (Wilcox, Arizona)

                                  May 8, 2013

Local educators advocate for CTE on Capitol Hill

BYLINE: Arizona Range News staff

LENGTH: 583  words


WASHINGTON, DC Mike Zamudio, agriculture educator from San Simon High School,
and Davida Molina, agriculture teacher from Valley Union High School, attended
the Association for Career and Technical Education's (ACTE) National Policy
Seminar (NPS) March 4-6 in Arlington, Va., and met with Members of Congress on
Capitol Hill to educate them about the value of career and technical education
(CTE). Career and technical education delivers realworld training and skills
development to over 94 percent of America's high schools. Now, more than ever,
the nation is turning to CTE to prepare the skilled workforce needed to keep
America competitive and grow our economy. With CTE programs expanding and
changing across the country to meet the needs of employers, students and
communities, educators and administrators are challenged to effectively advocate
for resources and support on local, state and federal levels.

While attending ACTE's three day briefing on federal policies, Zamudio and
Molina consulted with Representative Barber's aid, Jeremy Wilson-Simerman,
Congressman Matt Salmon's aid, Jonathan Sarager, and Senator Jeff Flake's aid,
Sarah Towles to encourage more support for CTE and other education and work
force development programs. All three aids were very receptive to learning about
career and technical education programs and the benefits these programs provide
to today's youth. The legislative aids agreed to inform their congressman about
the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act Reauthorization, the
federal government funding source for CTE programs, that should be presented
soon.

At the opening session of the NPS, attendees heard from Dr. Anthony Carnevale,
director and research professor of the Georgetown University Center of Education
and the Workforce, who spoke on his research findings in career outcomes for
students engaging in CTE programs of study in secondary and postsecondary
settings. "Nearly 30 percent of associate-degree holders make more than those
with bachelor's degrees and 44 percent of graduates from four year colleges have
higher earnings that those with graduate degrees," said Carnevale on Monday
morning.

Carnevale applauded the efforts of ACTE, noting that career-tech programs were
efficient and a proven approach that helps students gain real-world experience
and provides skilled workers for the economy.

Other speakers at NPS included James R. Stone III, professor and director of the
National Research Center for Career and Technical Education (NRCCTE), Mark
Edwards, Executive Director of Opportunity Nation, and leaders from the
Congressional House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

Jane Oates, Assistant Secretary of Labor, Employment and Training Administration
delivered remarks during the closing general session and emphasized the
importance of education that trains individuals in the skill areas needed by the
workforce today and moving forward into the future. She stressed the importance
of the partnerships between CTE and business and industry leaders to ensure
economic vitality and strong job growth for the country. More than 400 teachers
and administrators attended the conference and participated in the Hill visits.
The National Policy Seminar is an annual event that takes place in early spring
as policymakers are beginning work on the federal budget and appropriations
process as well as reauthorizations such as the Elementary and Secondary
Education Act (ESEA) and the Workforce Investment Act (WIA).

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                           October 27, 2004 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

State Gets $222 Million To Aid Growers, Forests

BYLINE: JEROME R. STOCKFISCH, jstockfisch@tampatrib.com

SECTION: METRO; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 385 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE


FEDERAL FUNDING IS FOR STORM RECOVERY

By JEROME R. STOCKFISCH

jstockfisch@tampatrib.com

TALLAHASSEE -- More than $222 million in federal aid is headed to Florida to
help clean up hurricane damage in rural, agricultural and forest areas.

The money is part of the $13 billion disaster aid package passed by Congress
this month. Mark Rey, an undersecretary at the U.S. Department of Agriculture in
Washington, visited the Capitol on Tuesday to present the funds to Gov. Jeb Bush
and Agriculture Commissioner Charles Bronson.

"The people of Florida have our sympathy for their suffering and our admiration
for their courage," Rey said. "Over the past month they have been in our
prayers, and today, we're offering additional assistance."

Damage to homes in the state's urban and coastal areas has received the lion's
share of attention after Florida was battered by four hurricanes since Aug. 13.

The money presented Tuesday includes $120 million to remove vegetation and
debris that is impeding drainage, contributing to flooding and posing fire
hazards in rural areas. An additional $61 million will help farmers restore
fences and grade or reshape damaged farmland. The rest of the money goes to
reforestation of state and national forests.

"This money will be very helpful for farmworkers, for ranchers, for our rural
communities, for farmers as they rebuild," Bush said. "Agriculture is really our
heritage as a state, and it continues to be such an essential part of our
livelihood and who we are."

Rey pointed out that federal help has been on the ground in Florida since the
hurricane barrage began. More than 1,000 members of the U.S. Forest Service, who
typically fight Western wildfires, are involved in the recovery effort in
Florida's forests.

"We're used to moving fast to extinguish rapidly spreading wildfires, and I
pledge to you we will move with equal alacrity to help this state recover from
the 2004 hurricane season," Rey told the governor.

Bronson estimated that there are 50 million tons of tree debris scattered in
state forests. His accounts of tree damage prompted Bush to quip, "We're going
to be the mulch capital of the world."

Reporter Jerome R. Stockfisch can be reached at (850) 222-8382.

Copyright © 2004, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com
