                          The Times (Munster, Indiana)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            August 13, 2015 Thursday

BRIEF: Region farmers eligible for flood aid

BYLINE: Dan Carden, The Times, Munster, Ind.

SECTION: NATIONAL POLITICAL NEWS

LENGTH: 143 words


Aug. 13--INDIANAPOLIS -- Five rain-sodden Northwest Indiana counties were among
53 statewide declared disaster areas Wednesday by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture.

"Our hearts go out to those Indiana farmers affected by recent natural
disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "(The) USDA stands with you
and your communities when severe weather and natural disasters threaten to
disrupt your livelihood."

The declaration permits farmers operating in Lake, Porter, LaPorte, Newton and
Jasper counties to apply for low-interest emergency loans through the federal
Farm Service Agency.

Farmers in Illinois' Cook and Will counties also are eligible for assistance
because they are contiguous to declared disaster areas.

                              289 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 30, 1991, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grains and Soybeans Rally On Talk of Help for Soviets

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 18; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 356 words


Grain and soybean futures prices rallied strongly late yesterday on the Chicago
Board of Trade amid indications that the Bush Administration was about to offer
new food aid to the Soviet Union.

Wheat for delivery in December settled 4 3/4 cents higher, at $3.62 1/4 a
bushel; December corn was 2 3/4 cents higher, at $2.53 1/4 a bushel; December
oats rose 2 1/4 cents, to $1.32 3/4 a bushel; November soybeans rose 7 3/4
cents, to $5.56 3/4 a bushel.

Grain futures surged in the last half hour after Agriculture Secretary Edward
Madigan said in Washington that President Bush and President Mikhail S.
Gorbachev would make an announcement about food aid "in the very, very near
future."

Mr. Madigan said the President had agreed with the Agriculture Department's
recommendations about the level of assistance, but he did not disclose that
amount.

Mr. Bush met with Mr. Gorbachev in Madrid earlier yesterday and said afterwards
they had reached no agreement on how much food aid the Soviets would get.

It has been widely reported that Mr. Gorbachev has asked the United States for
$2.5 billion in loan guarantees and $1 billion in direct humanitarian assistance
in addition to the $2.5 billion in credits already allocated and used this year.

The grain markets have already discounted a $1.5 billion package, said Steve
Freed, a grain analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.

"If the announcement comes soon and is over $1.6 billion, that's friendly," he
said, meaning prices would rise.

Livestock and meat futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as weak
cash livestock markets prompted selling. Near-term hog futures dropped to a
two-year low as hog marketings continued to run above expectations.

Live cattle for December delivery fell 0.72 cent, to 73.85 cents; December live
hogs fell 0.72 cent, to 41.70 cents a pound; February frozen pork bellies
tumbled 1.42 cents, to 42.50 cents a pound.

Near-term crude-oil futures fell slightly but prices for refined products rose
on the New York Mercantile Exchange in thin trading ahead of the American
Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  June 29, 1989, THURSDAY, THREE STAR Edition

HOUSE PASSES AID FOR WHEAT FARMERS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9A

LENGTH: 147 words


WASHINGTON (AP) - The House ignored a veto threat and passed legislation on
Tuesday to pay more than $900 million to farmers suffering losses in winter
wheat and other crops this year from drought and weather-related disasters. The
legislation was approved on a voice vote and was sent to the Senate.  The bill
is aimed primarily at winter wheat growers in Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, Nebraska
and other states where dry weather is expected to sharply reduce this summer's
harvests.  Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday that he would
recommend a veto of the bill because it was too broad.

                               The New York Times

                             April 29, 2008 Tuesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Senate Democrats Calling For More Food Assistance

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; National Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 585 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Citing hunger riots in developing countries and soaring grain prices around the
world, Senate Democrats called on Monday for a swift increase of $200 million in
foreign food aid, on top of an additional $350 million that President Bush has
requested in a supplemental spending measure.

In response, the administration urged Congress to give it more flexibility to
buy food for donation from local and regional providers, a method that
antihunger experts say is cheaper and more efficient than buying and shipping
American commodities, as well as encouraging agricultural development.

This month, Mr. Bush directed the Agriculture Department to release $200 million
in commodities to address the crisis, and on Monday the United States Agency for
International Development said that it was coordinating that program in addition
to $40 million in emergency food aid.

A.I.D. said the United NationsWorld Food Program and private organizations would
deliver those resources to Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Haiti, Kenya,
Mauritania, Somalia, Sudan, Uganda and Zimbabwe.

At a news conference, Senators Richard J. Durbin of Illinois and Robert P. Casey
Jr. of Pennsylvania, both Democrats, called for adding $200 million in food aid
to the supplemental spending measure that will provide additional financing for
military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.

''This is the worst global food crisis in more than 30 years,'' Mr. Durbin said.
''It threatens not only the health and survival of millions of people around the
world, many of them children, but it also is a threat to global security.

''As many as 36 countries, almost one-fifth of the world's nations, are now
facing food crises requiring help from abroad.''

A spokesman for the White House, Scott Stanzel, said the administration was
monitoring the crisis and moving swiftly to respond.

''We appreciate the shared concerns of members of Congress,'' Mr. Stanzel said.

He urged greater flexibility in running the programs.

''The president has continually asked Congress to support an innovative proposal
to provide food assistance by purchasing crops directly from farmers in the
developing world,'' he said. ''This flexibility would not only get food to
people in emergency situations faster, it would also build up local agriculture
and help break the cycle of famine. Unfortunately, Congress has repeatedly
failed to act on this proposal.''

The administration has urged Congress to use the farm bill, which is in
House-Senate talks, to allow up to 25 percent of United States food aid to be
bought from local or regional providers. In 2007, the United States donated more
than 1.5 million metric tons of food, valued at $1.2 billion.

The Senate proposed a much more modest pilot program to buy up to $25 million in
food for donation from producers overseas. Farm bill negotiators continued to
debate that on Monday. Separately on Monday, three Democrats, Senators Tom
Harkin of Iowa, Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Bill Nelson of Florida, and a
Republican, Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, sent a letter to Mr. Bush urging at
least $60 million in added emergency food aid, specifically for Haiti, which has
had food riots.

''The United States must now demonstrate leadership and resolve and help one of
its closest neighbors,'' the senators wrote. ''We must come to the aid of the
Haitian people.''

A spokeswoman for A.I.D., Gina Jackson, said she could not specify how much of
the $240 million emergency aid was for Haiti.

                              293 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                                January 8, 2000

US farm aid of $1bn in pipeline

BYLINE: By Joe Watson

SECTION: Business:Farm/Food:News, Pg.17

LENGTH: 528 words


AMERICA looks set to pay its farmers another $1billion in emergency aid to take
increasing areas of farmland out of production in a bid to end its meat and
grain mountains and stabilise prices.

In a direct appeal for the farm vote, US vice-president Al Gore said yesterday
that President Clinton would be seeking money from the American Congress to take
land out of production.

Mr Gore, on the presidential campaign trail in Iowa, said more than $1billion
(GBP 625million) would be sought in the next financial year to expand American
conservation programmes, including those that pay farmers to set-aside land.

Peter Stewart, the Scottish NFU vice-president, last night said the likely deal
was another climbdown for the American administration's allegedly flagship
Freedom to Farm Act, introduced in 1996 and which decoupled production-based
subsidies.

Decline

Mr Stewart added: "It again shows that other countries are prepared to put money
into their agricultural industries to help farmers through. We have got to make
it very clear to our ministers that they have got to do the same.

"We have got to put money into the industry to keep people on the land and to
allow a natural change to take place. The American situation shows it is
prepared to help manage change."

US Department of Agriculture officials declined to discuss what President
Clinton will propose in his 2001 Farm Safety Net Proposal to boost the American
farm economy, which has been in spiralling decline for two years.

But one official said the farm budget - due to be announced on February 7 and be
implemented on October 1 - will deal with more than conservation.

"I think there will be more to come," said an Usda source.

Over the past two years, the US Congress has approved $15billion in emergency
farm aid after huge crops and sinking exports forced. Included in the figure is
last autumn's $9.2billion (GBP 5.6billion) compensation deal.

With US farm income forecast to drop 16% this year because of continued low
prices, both the administration and Congress will be under tremendous pressure -
heightened by election year politics - to provide additional aid.

Assistance

Mr Gore said the President was looking to expand America's conservation reserve
programme by 3.6million acres to 40million next year.

This scheme allows farmers to idle environmentally sensitive land for 10 years
in exchange for cash payments. Some farm groups have advocated expansion of the
programme as a way to cut back on production and boost prices.

Mr Gore said: "The administration believes a crucial part of the farm safety net
that will yield benefits to all Americans is providing assistance to farmers and
ranchers who practice environmentally sound land management."

Separately, US pig producers tried to take advantage of Mr Gore's campaign in
Iowa to urge the vice -president to wield his influence to once again have pork
included in US food aid to Russia. Iowa is the nation's biggest pig-producing
state.

In 1998, Usda agreed to donate 50,000tonnes of pork to Russia as part of a
$1billion aid package. The department is considering a second Russian food aid
request.

LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

                   Copyright 2000 Aberdeen Press and Journal

                              294 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            January 17, 1997 Friday

BYLINE: Don Davis

LENGTH: 704 words


North Dakota's harsh winter weather puts up to 100,000 head of cattle at risk of
dying, a Stockmen's Association official says, but federal aid is on the way.
State and federal officials Thursday announced money and feed will be available
to ranchers who cannot get feed to their cattle or sheep, or do not have feed
for their livestock. Ranchers whose livestock are threatened with dying should
contact their local U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency offices,
state Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson said. Stockmen's Association Vice
President Wade Moser said 50,000 to 100,000 cattle could be at risk in North
Dakota.

Federal agriculture officials estimate 20,000 cattle are in immediate danger,
with 100,000 head of cattle and sheep in danger in the entire Northern Plains.
Agriculture Department officials estimate $1.4 million is needed to feed those
animals through Jan. 25. Farmers and ranchers who spent extra money to feed
endangered livestock since Jan. 10 may be eligible for federal aid. Rep. Earl
Pomeroy, D-N.D., emphasized the aid is for the short term only; state and
federal officials are looking at ways to help livestock producers beyond Jan.
25. ""There will not be assistance that makes the pain go away for the ranchers
of North Dakota,'' Pomeroy said. Early next week, a state agriculture weather
emergency state task force meets to discuss the severity of the problem. State
officials will share that information with federal ag officials to draw up a
plan to help livestock producers the rest of the winter. Now, three kinds of
help are available to livestock producers with animals in danger of dying: þ
Money to get feed to cattle on farms and ranches where snow prevents moving
feed. Paying for snow plowing is among the ways the federal government will
help. þ Money to buy feed when needed. Up to 100 percent of feed costs may be
provided for feed purchased Jan. 10 to 25. þ The use of up to 600,000 bushels of
grain under federal government control.""In North Dakota, producers will be
exhausting available supplies of hay for their 1.9 million head of cattle
soon,'' an Agriculture Department news release said. ""Cattle stranded away from
feed sources are expected to be a problem for the next several months.''
Department rules say: ""Assistance is computed for the actual number of days the
livestock are determined to be in danger of perishing and no not have access to
their normal feed supply, not to exceed 15 days.'' But Moser said the threat of
death is not the only problem cattle face. The extreme cold and deep snow mean
many cattle are losing weight, needing more calories just to keep warm. ""It is
one of the biggest problems we have had in a long time,'' Moser added. Pomeroy
said 1978 was the last time an agricultural snow emergency was declared in North
Dakota. Thirteen counties were declared a disaster area then; all 53 counties
are eligible for disaster relief this year. Problems are just beginning for
cattle producers, Moser said. Many cows will begin having calves soon, but the
winter weather is weakening them so much that both the cows and calves are in
danger. Also, Moser added, cows may be so weakened this spring that they will
not be able to breed. Some ranchers kept their cattle until prices went up. Now,
the cattle are losing weight and worth less, Pomeroy said. Other ranchers are
selling off calves at low prices to cut their losses. Southern and western North
Dakota counties have the most cattle at risk.

CUTLINEByline: TOM STROMME of the Tribune Opening roads is a priority in the
cities but in the country it's imperative for farmers and ranchers to have
access to feed for livestock. Above, a farmer operating a rotary blower opens a
road to a supply of big round hay bales. The town of Venturia in McIntosh County
has drifts blocking its Main Street and as tall as some buildings. "I stood on
top of the snow bank on the north end of Main Street and a snowplow drove by and
my feet were higher than the top of the truck,' said Randall Tschetter, who
estimates the drifts to be "at least 12 to 15 feet high. It's almost worth a
drive down here to see them from the ground,' added Tschetter who is the Baptist
minister in Venturia.

                              295 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             June 5, 2008 Thursday
                                  City Edition

Wilting Panhandle thirsts for rainfall ;
Agriculture secretary seeks state aid for region.

BYLINE: John David Sutter, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20A

LENGTH: 348 words


The state secretary of agriculture asked the governor Wednesday afternoon to
start the process of classifying the Oklahoma Panhandle as a disaster area
because of an extreme drought, said Jack Carson, spokesman for the state
Department of Agriculture.

Carson said state Agriculture Secretary Terry Peach took a letter to Gov. Brad
Henry making the request. Carson declined to release the letter on Wednesday.

How it's affecting farmers

Crops are failing in the western Panhandle, and farmers are running out of grass
to feed their cattle, residents said. One resident said the area is starting to
look like the Sahara Desert.

A disaster declaration would have to come from the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, Carson said, and the governor would need to recommend the
declaration to that agency.

The designation could bring help in the form of low-interest loans and tax
relief, which would help farmers and ranchers buy feed, replace failed crops and
buy back livestock they have to sell, Carson said. Even if approved, the aid may
not come soon.

"It's a slow process, let's just be honest," he said. "We're talking in terms of
months."

A conservation official in Cimarron County, at the western edge of the
Panhandle, said he wants state officials to visit the area so they can get an
idea of how intense the drought is. Hal Clark, chairman of the conservation
district, said some farmers in Cimarron County are selling off all of their
livestock because they can't afford to feed them.

What's the chance of rain?

Derek Arndt, assistant state climatologist, said the coming weeks will be "make
or break" for farmers and ranchers in the western Panhandle.

To date, this is the third-driest year on record for the Panhandle, he said.

Recent triple-digit temperatures have increasing soil evaporation and added to
the dire situation, he said.

The U.S. Drought Monitor has labeled the drought "extreme" - the second most
severe designation.

There's no chance of rain in the Panhandle for at least a week, said J.J. Brost,
a meteorologist at the National Weather Service office in Amarillo, Texas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              296 of 999 DOCUMENTS


            The Fayetteville Observer (Fayetteville, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 12, 2012 Thursday

BRIEF: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture issues disaster declaration for 35 N.C.
counties to aid with tornado recovery

BYLINE: The Fayetteville Observer, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 185 words


Jan. 12--The U.S. Department of Agriculture this week issued a disaster
declaration for 35 North Carolina counties to help farmers recover from the
tornadoes and hurricanes of 2011.

This will allow farmers to apply for federal financial assistance through
low-interest Farm Service Assistance loans and the Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Payments (SURE) disaster assistance program.

Farmers in designated counties have until Sept. 10 to apply for disaster
assistance to cover crop losses.

In the Cape Fear region, Columbus, Cumberland and Sampson counties are in the
disaster declaration and farmers there are eligible for assistance. Also,
agricultural entities in Bladen, Harnett, Robeson and Sampson counties in the
Cape Fear region may be eligible for Farm Service Assistance loans.

Farmers can apply for assistance through the USDA-Farm Service Agency office for
North Carolina. The phone number for the USDA-FSA office is 919-875-4800.

Jan. 11--The U.S. Department of Agriculture this week issued a disaster
declaration for 35 North Carolina counties to help farmers recover from the
devastating tornadoes and hurricanes of 2011.

This will allow farmers to apply for federal financial assistance through
low-interest Farm Service Assistance loans and the Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Payments (SURE) disaster assistance program.

Farmers in designated counties have until Sept. 10 to apply for disaster
assistance to cover crop losses.

In the Cape Fear region, Columbus, Cumberland and Sampson counties are in the
disaster declaration and farmers there are eligible for assistance.

Also, agricultural entities in Bladen, Harnett, Robeson and Sampson counties in
the Cape Fear region may be eligible for Farm Service Assistance loans.

Farmers can apply for assistance through the USDA-Farm Service Agency office for
North Carolina. The phone number for the USDA-FSA office is 919-875-4800.

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

                     July 17, 1993, Saturday, FINAL EDITION

Seaway handles U.S. aid grain

SECTION: BUSINESS; IN BRIEF; Pg. C1/BREAK

LENGTH: 156 words


A Montreal shipper scored a coup for the St. Lawrence Seaway by convincing
American authorities to allow some aid grain to Russia to be shipped through the
seaway.

It is the first time American aid grain has gone through the seaway, Fred Pitre,
president of Global Self-Unloaders, said yesterday. He's hoping to attract a lot
more U.S. grain to help the declining seaway. Normally the grain goes down the
Mississippi River to be reloaded on ocean-going ships, or else by train to U.S.
east coast ports.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture awarded the business to Global Self-Unloaders
and its U.S. affiliate, Mormac Marine Transport Inc. of Stamford, Conn., because
they offered a lower rate.

Yesterday, the American Mariner (above) squeezed through the final locks of the
seaway in Montreal carrying grain bound for Russia. Its width of 78 feet makes
it the widest ship to navigate the locks which are 80 feet wide.

                              299 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                  September 23, 2004, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Farmers deserve aid, too

BYLINE: Max Baucus

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 19A

LENGTH: 390 words

Today's debate: Spending priorities

Opposing view: Like other natural disasters, droughts have devastating effects.

Whether it's offering a ride to the hospital or providing a warm place to sleep,
when disaster strikes in this country, we rush to help our friends and
neighbors. That's just what we do as Americans.


And when a hurricane, tornado or flood ravages an entire community, the federal
government is quick to lend its hand. At every turn, we're there to help, but
for one exception: severe, unrelenting drought.

I recently sponsored an emergency-disaster-assistance amendment that would
provide aid to farmers and ranchers who've been hit by natural disasters,
including drought.

I'm leading this effort because drought is every bit as much a disaster; it just
doesn't make for big headlines or provide 24-hour cable-news shows with dramatic
live interviews as some other disasters do.

Drought is the quiet killer that slowly squeezes the life out of Main Street
America. For the past several years, we've watched crops silently wither away,
herds be sold, storefronts be boarded up, and dustbowl-like conditions drive
generations off the land. That's why I pushed in the recently passed $33.1
billion homeland-security-spending bill to set aside $3 billion in
emergency-disaster aid for farmers and ranchers who qualify.

Some may call this move an act of "home-state opportunism." But I call the
amendment -- supported by more than 60 senators of both parties -- a show of
support for our farmers and ranchers, who, day in and day out, provide us with a
safe and affordable food supply.

My provision will help agriculture producers who've suffered "losses from
hurricanes, drought, freezes, floods and other natural disasters." That includes
producers in Florida and other areas hit recently by hurricanes. More than half
the states in the union will benefit from this amendment, which is supported by
more than 20 leading agriculture groups.

Just as our friends, family and neighbors who've recently been hit hard by
hurricanes, the nation's farmers and ranchers deserve a helping hand.

Some may suggest we can't afford to help agriculture producers right now. I say
we can't afford not to.

***

Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., is a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

.

LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: DEBATE

                      Copyright 2004 Gannett Company, Inc.

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 14, 2011 Thursday

BRIEF: More disaster aid sought for 8 counties

BYLINE: Patrick Malone, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 254 words


July 14--DENVER -- Gov. John Hickenlooper is seeking additional disaster
assistance from the federal government for eight weather-battered Colorado
counties whose economies are reliant on agriculture, including five in the San
Luis Valley.

In a letter to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack this week, Hickenlooper
sought disaster relief for Alamosa, Conejos, Costilla, Rio Grande and Saguache
counties.

"Drought impacts are resulting in the loss of native grass, mixed forage, cool
season grasses and alfalfa throughout the San Luis Valley in south-central
Colorado," Hickenlooper wrote in the letter. "Losses are greatest to cool season
grasses reaching 75 percent. The availability of surface water has resulted in
many producers having to abandon alfalfa irrigation completely."

A second letter sought disaster assistance for Delta, Montrose and Mesa counties
on the Western Slope, where fruit producers were stung by a freeze in late April
and early May. Some producers there suffered losses of 95 percent of their
apples and other fruits.

If the declaration is approved it would allow farmers and ranchers to apply for
emergency loans if they are unable to get credit elsewhere.

http://www.chieftain.com. Copyright (c) 2011, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services

                              The Washington Post

                   January 22, 1992, Wednesday, Final Edition

Ex-Soviet Republics Make Loan Payment

Guy Gugliotta, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A26

LENGTH: 406 words


The former Soviet republics have made a $ 1.7 million principal payment on $
3.75 billion in agricultural loans guaranteed by the U.S. government, sources
said yesterday, clearing a modest hurdle on the eve of a multinational
conference to coordinate humanitarian aid to the republics.

The payments, due Jan. 17, were made promptly along with $ 700,000 in interest,
Agriculture Department sources said. Before Jan. 17, the Soviet Union had paid a
bit less than $ 10 million in interest. The republics, said one source, "are
current" on their debt.

The loans, contracted with U.S.-based banks to purchase American agricultural
products, are guaranteed by the department's Commodity Credit Corp. The credits
total $ 3.75 billion and constitute the only significant debt owed by the former
Soviet republics to the United States.

Doubt about the republics' creditworthiness has increased steadily since the
loan program began one year ago, fueling an ongoing debate between Congress and
the Bush administration about the wisdom of extending further loans.

Making the first payment, no matter how small, was likely to win some goodwill
from the United States during the two-day conference, which brings
representatives of more than 50 nations and international organizations to
Washington today to discuss aid coordination for the republics.

It was unlikely, however, either to inspire lasting confidence in the United
States or dispel the misgivings of other creditor governments. The acid test for
the United States will begin in February, when more than $ 120 million in loan
principal is due, and in March, when the figure rises to more than $ 140
million.

The former republics have already notified Western banks that they were
suspending principal payments on debts contracted before 1991.

The $ 3.75 billion loan program has allowed the Soviet Union to buy U.S.
agricultural products -- chiefly wheat, corn, soybeans and soybean meal -- with
loans from U.S.-based banks. Under terms of the program, the Soviets must retire
the loans in three yearly payments, the first payment due one year after the
loan was obtained.

If the Soviets default, the Commodity Credit Corp. is liable for either 97
percent or 100 percent of principal and a significant percentage of interest.
Critics have charged the program is little more than foreign aid by another
name, given the political and economic disorder in the republics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: FOREIGN NEWS

                       Copyright 1992 The Washington Post

                              302 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                  Morning Star

                            August 2, 2012 Thursday

US farmers get aid as drought puts counties on natural disaster list

BYLINE: Our Foreign Desk

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 224 words


The Department of Agriculture's addition of the 218 counties means that more
than half of all US counties, 1,584 in 32 states, have been designated as
primary disaster areas, the vast majority of them mired in the worst drought in
decades. Counties in Arkansas, Georgia, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas,
Mississippi, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Tennessee and Wyoming were
included in the announcement. Deeming drought-stricken counties as disaster
areas makes farmers and ranchers eligible for federal aid including low-interest
emergency loans. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack opened up 3.8 million acres
of conservation land for ranchers to use for haying and grazing yesterday. "The
assistance announced today will help US livestock producers dealing with
climbing feed prices, critical shortages of hay and deteriorating pasturelands,"
Mr Vilsack said. Under the previous conservation programme, farmers were paid to
take land out of production to ward against erosion and to help create wildlife
habitats. As of this week, nearly half of the US corn crop was rated poor to
very poor, according to the National Agricultural Statistics Service. About 37
per cent of the US soybean crops has also been included in that category, while
nearly three-quarters of US cattle acreage is in drought-affected areas.

                       The Natchez Democrat (Mississippi)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              March 3, 2017 Friday

Area farmers eligible for drought assistance

BYLINE: Lindsey Shelton, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 417 words


March 03--NATCHEZ -- Farmers and ranchers in Adams, Franklin, Jefferson and
Wilkinson counties as well as Concordia Parish are currently eligible to apply
for drought disaster aid from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Drought disaster aid is available in 79 of Mississippi's 82 counties -- and in
22 counties and parishes in adjacent states.

Farmers and ranchers in those areas have eight months from Feb. 23 to apply for
low-interest loans from the Farm Service Agency to help cover part of their
losses from the drought.

Sixty-nine Mississippi counties are considered primary disaster areas, and the
other 10 are adjacent to them. That status also qualifies farmers in four other
states: 10 counties in western Alabama, three in south Arkansas, five in
southwest Tennessee and four northeast Louisiana parishes.

The only Mississippi counties not on either list are Amite, Pike and Walthall.

The Mississippi counties declared primary disaster areas are: Adams, Alcorn,
Attala, Benton, Bolivar, Calhoun, Carroll, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Claiborne,
Clarke, Clay, Coahoma, Copiah, Covington, Forrest, George, Greene, Grenada,
Harrison, Hinds, Holmes, Humphreys Issaquena, Itawamba, Jackson, Jasper,
Jefferson, Jones, Kemper, Lafayette, Lamar, Lauderdale, Leake, Lee, Leflore,
Lowndes, Madison, Marshall, Monroe, Montgomery, Neshoba, Newton, Noxubee,
Oktibbeha, Panola Perry, Pontotoc, Prentiss, Quitman, Rankin, Scott, Sharkey,
Simpson, Smith, Stone, Sunflower, Tallahatchie, Tate, Tippah, Tishomingo, Union,
Warren, Washington, Wayne, Webster, Winston, Yalobusha, and Yazoo counties.

The adjacent counties where farmers and ranchers also can qualify for
low-interest disaster loans are in Mississippi are DeSoto, Franklin, Hancock,
Jefferson Davis, Lawrence, Lincoln, Marion, Pearl River, Tunica and Wilkinson.

In Louisiana, adjacent parishes available for loans are Concordia, East Carroll,
Madison and Tensas.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

(Natchez, Miss.) at www.natchezdemocrat.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                June 09, 2000, Friday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Governor asked to seek U.S. aid for drought damage

SOURCE: Compiled from Staff and Wire Reports

SECTION: CITY & STATE; Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 467 words



The estimated crop loss is $ 188-million. Wildfires continue to take a toll.

Faced with increasing numbers of wildfires and no end in sight to a drought,
Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford on Thursday asked Gov. Jeb Bush to
persuade federal authorities to declare an agricultural disaster for Florida.

The estimated crop loss from the drought is $ 188-million, primarily cotton,
soybeans, corn, watermelons and hay, Crawford said.

Many ranchers are selling parts of their herds  because they  lack  food and
water as farm ponds and wells dry up. The heat and stress on cows has resulted
in lower milk production. Bodies of water have recorded the lowest oxygen levels
ever , damaging aquaculture crops, Crawford said.

No decision has been made on Crawford's plea, said Bush spokesman Justin Sayfie,
but "there appears to be a legitimate need for such a request."

Though wildfires continued to burn in Florida on Thursday, there were fewer and
smaller outbreaks than at any time in recent weeks.

Scattered  showers, especially the brief torrents that hit the Tampa Bay area
Wednesday, provided some firefighters a respite - albeit brief -  Thursday.

Sarasota County, where one of the first big blazes raged last month, received
its first serious rain dose Thursday.

Still, much of the state's landscape remained brown, its wells tapped dry and
sinkholes appearing hither and yon - the latest, a 20-foot-deep maw in Lake
County on Wednesday.

Hot spots Thursday were a fire that has burned 3,000 acres in Alachua County and
a smoldering burn near Hudson in Pasco County, as well as fires near Naples and
Waldo, according to the state Division of Emergency Management.

Robert and Chris Gonzalez used to treasure their pond stocked with fish and
waterfowl at their home near Tampa. All they see these days are buzzards
circling.

"They come for the dead fish," Robert Gonzalez said. "There isn't enough water
to keep the fish alive."

The drought index in some Florida Gulf Coast counties  rivals that of Arizona's
deserts, and tourists are being asked to use their towels twice so hotel laundry
rooms can save water.

Agricultural officials in Florida plan to ask the federal government to declare
a disaster, allowing farmers to receive relief money.

Even if the summer rains begin to fall soon, most of the crops already are
destroyed, said Whit Chase of the Florida Agriculture Department.

Northern Florida's hay crop is badly damaged, and that will force ranchers to
buy hay from other states at much higher prices.

Bush issued a memorandum Thursday to state and local law enforcement and fire
agencies reiterating the need to monitor and enforce the outdoor burning ban of
May 17.

- Staff writer Robin Mitchell and the Associated Press contributed to this
report.

drought.

                                   USA TODAY

                    November 1, 1994, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Bosnian Serb threatens strikes against Muslims

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 419 words



Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, responding to one of the worst defeats of
his troops in the 2 1/2-year conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina, threatened a
counteroffensive against the Muslim-led Bosnian government army. U.S. officials
Monday ruled out joining NATO air strikes that might be called by U.N. officials
against Muslim forces. A State Department official said Muslim military gains
could be what is needed to persuade Serbs to accept a peace plan by the United
States, France, Britain, Germany and Russia.

AID TO SOUTH AFRICA: Department of Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy signed an
agreement in South Africa to provide U.S. technical and financial aid. Espy,
under investigation for accepting gifts from food companies regulated by his
department, has resigned effective Dec. 31. "We don't want to impose our system
or process on anyone, but we would like to offer our experience, especially in
school feeding programs," Espy said.

OAS ON CUBA: Cesar Gaviria, new chief of the Organization of American States,
chided the United States for its continued embargo of Cuba. At a USA TODAY
Newsmaker breakfast, Gaviria said decisions to isolate Fidel Castro were
"relics" of the Cold War.

AIDS IN RUSSIA: A proposed bill forcing all visitors to get AIDS tests Monday
sailed through the Duma, Russia's lower house of parliament. The bill led to an
outcry from foreigners who say it would violate their rights, hurt tourism and
is virtually impossible to enforce.

HILLARY'S FAN: An Israeli woman is seeking a divorce because her husband is so
infatuated with U.S. first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, a newspaper reports. The
woman says she even was ordered to color her hair and copy the first lady's
hairstyle. When her husband heard the Clintons were coming to Israel, "he lost
all control," the woman said in divorce papers, the newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth
reported. The couple's names were withheld.

ALSO: Algerian President Liamine Zeroual said presidential elections would be
held before the end of next year. . . . Mario Aburto Martinez, 23, the man who
assassinated Luis Donaldo Colosio, presidential candidate of Mexico's ruling
party, was convicted of murder and sentenced to 42 years in prison. . . . Three
British hostages held by Kashmiri separatists in India were freed after a
shootout, police said. Two police officers and a militant were killed. U.S.
hostage Bela Josef Nuss of Walnut Creek, Calif., who was held in a separate
location, was freed earlier by police.

WASHINGTON AND THE WORLD

                      Copyright 1994 Gannett Company, Inc.

                              306 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                 NEW YORK TIMES

                           November 17, 1974, Sunday

SECTION: Page 1, Column 8

LENGTH: 499 words

World Food Conf approves formation of World Food Council, new UN agency to
supervise antihunger programs.  New orgn will have secretariat in Rome,
associated with FAO, but will rept to UN hq in NYC.  Council requires
endorsement from parent orgn, but action is expected to be formality.  Council,
representing key accomplishment of conf, is result of intricate compromise
between underdeveloped and developed nations that was reached in final session
of 11-day conf.  Compromise ended deadlock over what sort of follow-up mechanism
should be created to supervise and coordinate food-aid and development programs.
US and other developed countries wanted ECOSOC to control new council, while
underdeveloped nations sought establishment and control by Gen Assembly.  Under
compromise, council will be established by Gen Assembly as UN body reptg to
Assembly through ECOSOC.  Council members will be officials of ministerial or
other high-level positions who will meet from time to time, but everyday work
will be done in secretariat.  Secretariat's staff and budget will be drawn from
FAO, but secretariat will be independent of agency.  US delegation deputy chief
Edwin M Martin says new body will not have power to order action but will have
coordinating role and responsibility for reptg to UN on needed actions.  Before
end of session, conf assigns number of new programs to projected council,
including fertilizer aid program to help increase supplies for developing
nations and for new and improved plants.  Council is also assigned to supervise
or coordinate pesticide aid program.  Will conduct research on residual effects
and other environmental questions, irrigation, drainage and flood-control
program to aid developing countries, expansion of agr research and training and
methods of disseminating findings among growers, nutritional aid program,
including special feeding for malnourished children and studies on fortification
of staple foods with vitamins, recognition of women's role in agr and food and
call for 'achievement of desirable balance' between population and food supply.
Conf also completes work on 10-million-ton-a-yr food aid program for developing
nations, on internationally coordinated system of natl grain reserves and on
early-warning system of data-sharing to help alert world to any threats to food
supplies or sudden surges in demand.  In another action, developed nations
effectively resist demand by underdeveloped nations for trade references, saying
that conf is not forum for trade negotiations.  Instead conf adopts resolution
that requests improved treatment of exports from poorer countries.  Conf also
recommends creation of world food security council and food aid com to take over
responsibility for present World Food Program and coordinate bilateral and
multilateral aid operations.  Adopts carefully worded declaration calling on all
govts to accept removal of 'scourge of hunger and malnutrition' as objective of
internatl community (L).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

JOURNAL-CODE:  NYT

TYPE: 321-2

                              307 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Herald-Sun (Durham, NC)

                           October 14, 1999 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Senate aids N.C. with $8.7B farm-aid bill;
Leaf farmers get $98.4 million and state gets $200 million for disaster-relief
efforts

BYLINE: By AMY ETTINGER The Herald-Sun Washington bureau

SECTION: INSIDE FRONT; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 417 words


WASHINGTON - The Senate passed an $8.7 billion emergency farm-aid bill Wednesday
that includes $98.4 million for North Carolina tobacco farmers and $200 million
for the state's disaster-relief efforts.

The Senate adopted the agriculture appropriations bill with a vote of 74-26. The
lion's share of the money will go to help farmers hurt by this year's low prices
on crops such as soybeans, cotton and peanuts.

The legislation includes $1.2 billion for flood and drought relief nationwide.
Although the $200 million estimated for North Carolina is $101 million more than
the House approved earlier this month, Sen. John Edwards, D-N.C., said the
figure was "short of what we're going to need."

Sens. Edward and Jesse Helms, R-N.C., both supported the bill.

The $200 million, though not written into the bill, was agreed upon by Edwards
and Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman. It could be reduced if other disasters
occur and require relief funding.

Preliminary estimates of crop, livestock and farm-structure losses from
Hurricane Floyd total $717 million, according to Kurt Pickering, a spokesman at
the disaster field office in Raleigh.

Gov. Jim Hunt has already asked Congress and President Clinton for $2.1 billion
to help in the recovery from Floyd, and bills that would provide additional aid
are being worked on. Hunt has said he would ask for a total of $5.3 billion.

"The governor is certainly pleased that Congress is turning its attention to the
plight in North Carolina," said Tad Boggs, spokesman for Hunt. "We're obviously
going to need a lot more for agricultural losses ..."

Edwards said during the Senate debate that he recognized North Carolina farmers
need help immediately. "The reality is that this is a loss that's going to take
years to recover from," he said.

The appropriations bill was drafted before Hurricane Floyd hit North Carolina,
which is why the disaster relief amount isn't higher, said David Rouzer,
spokesman for Helms. "The losses are so much throughout country that [the $1.2
billion] is not enough money to go around."

But the $328 million nationwide for tobacco farmers who have suffered from low
crop prices was an important factor in pushing the bill through, Rouzer said.

About 30 percent of the tobacco money has been earmarked for North Carolina
farmers, Rouzer said. That money is separate from any money the farmers will get
as part of the recent government settlement with tobacco companies.

The bill will be sent to President Clinton, who is expected to approve it.

                              308 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The Times (London)

                             June 18 1988, Saturday

Aid pledged for drought-hit US farms

BYLINE: From MOHSIN ALI, Washington

SECTION: Issue 63111.

LENGTH: 499 words


With weather forecasts offering little hope of relief, worried senators and
congressmen yesterday called for quick action to aid the nation's farmers in
what may become the most devastating drought since the 1930s.

The legislators warned that action was needed now to save farmers threatened
with economic ruin.


President Reagan, deeply concerned about the drought, has set up a policy group
of senior officials from various government agencies and ordered it to report to
him in two weeks on how to ease the plight of farmers.

Senator Patrick Leahy (Dem, Vermont), chairman of the Senate agriculture
committee, said that some farmers needed aid immediately. 'We know that we need
rain, we know that in two weeks a lot of people are going to be bankrupt.'
Overall, a third of the US spring wheat crop could be destroyed. 'If that's the
case, you've got a virtually unprecedented disaster.' Senator John Melcher (Dem,
Montana) said that 60 per cent of his state's wheat crop was already gone and
'nothing can help it'. Mr Richard Lyng, Agriculture Secretary, told a
congressional hearing that to get the full economic impact of the drought in any
part of the country 'you almost have to go to the harvest period'. He added :
'We will be prepared to consider at that time what sort of economic assistance
might be needed.' He and Vice-President George Bush plan to tour the worst-hit
areas of the drought this weekend.

Mr Lyng said that until his department got a full assessment of the crop damage,
it would focus on helping livestock producers find feed for their animals and
help Congress prepare an economic assistance package.

He said that 'in another 10 days or two weeks the drought will become almost a
catastrophe if we don't get some relief'.

The Mississippi and Ohio rivers, main transportation routes for US grain, have
fallen to historic low levels.

Hot, dry weather is searing crops in the northern plains, parts of the corn
belt, Texas, California and the South. Corn leaves are curling and twisting, a
sign of stress, in Kentucky. North Dakota had record heat in the past week and
soil moisture is the lowest since records began 30 years ago.

The new inter-agency drought policy committee comprises the Secretaries of
Agriculture and the Interior, and officials from the Pentagon, the Energy
Department, the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Federal Emergency Management
Agency, the Vice-President's office and the Office of Management and Budget.

President Reagan wants to make certain that everything that the federal
government can do to assist the farmers will be done, Mr Marlin Fitzwater, the
White House spokesman, said.

Paris Violent thunderstorms and high winds have struck some of the Bordeaux
wine-growing areas of France just as the vines have begun to flower (Philip
Jacobson writes). But prospects for the 1988 harvest are said to remain fairly
encouraging provided there is not another miserable summer like that of 1987.

              September 13, 1981, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

Block Says Development Aid Will Go to 'Truly Rural Areas'

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 68, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 104 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11


Federal aid for rural development programs will be concentrated in ''truly rural
areas'' rather than in those that are becoming more urban, Agriculture Secretary
John R.  Block said today.

''For several years now, the Federal Government has used rural development
programs and funds to encourage a wide range of community projects in urbanizing
areas,'' Mr. Block said. ''Grants of Federal money have even been used to
sponsor studies and plans aimed at teaching communities how to ask for Federal
funding for various projects.''

                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                          September 26, 2012 Wednesday

25 certified in CPR, first aid

BYLINE: RHONDA WARDLAW, For The Capital

SECTION: A; Pg.6

LENGTH: 851  words


On Sept. 8, the Annapolis Fire Department, in conjunction with Iglesia Hispana
Emmanuel, offered a class with a specific focus on the Spanish-speaking
community. A total of 25 people were certified in the life-saving techniques of
CPR and first aid.

The Annapolis Fire Department has a long history of providing citizen CPR and
first aid courses. Chief David L. Stokes recognizes the life-saving benefits of
CPR and the Annapolis Fire Department is committed to making the saving
educational opportunity available to this significant part of our community.

For more information about future CPR classes, contact the Annapolis Fire
Department's CPR coordinator by email: CPR@annapolis.gov or by phone:
410-263-7975.

Nov. 6 presidential election upcoming

The City of Annapolis wants residents to remember that the next United States
presidential election will be held on Tuesday, Nov. 6. The Anne Arundel County
Board of Election Office is open from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through
Friday.

The county has a website with valuable information regarding how to register,
how to get an absentee ballot, where the polling places are, and how to take
advantage of early voting. You can also view the general election sample ballot
on this site. To find more information on the November elections, go to
http://www.aacounty.org/elections or call 410-222-6600. You can also email your
questions to elections@aacounty.org

Mosquito spraying in Eastport Monday

The Maryland Department of Agriculture (MDA), in cooperation with the City of
Annapolis and the Anne Arundel County Health Department, will conduct a second
round of mosquito spraying to reduce the risk of West Nile virus in Eastport on
Monday. Weather permitting, spraying will take place beginning at 7:30 p.m. and
go into the early morning hours.

To view the areas being sprayed, go to http://bit.ly/RIYw60. The Maryland
Department of Agriculture recommends that residents in the affected area stay
indoors during spraying.

Spraying will be conducted using MDA spray trucks. The spray material, Biomist
30-30, contains the active ingredient permethrin, and is approved by the U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency. For the product label and Material Safety Data
Sheet, visit the MDA web site. For information on health and environmental
effects of permethrin, refer to the National Pesticide Information Center
Technical Sheet found at http://bit.ly/P66kPI

For more information or questions on locations affected, call Mosquito Control
at 410-841-5870.

Volunteers needed to assist students

Volunteer tutors are needed to assist After School Homework Club for elementary
and middle school students. Volunteers will assist students with reading,
language-arts, math, science, and social studies homework assignments. The After
School Homework Club takes place Monday through Thursday, from 3-6 p.m. at the
Stanton Community Center. If interested, please contact Sharon McElfish at
sharonmcelfish@aol.com or call 410-990-0294.

City email notifications

MyAnnapolis is an email-based news service, designed to help anyone with an
interest in the City of Annapolis find out quickly about city government news
and events, employment opportunities and more. It is a "custom" service that
lets you select areas of interest that you want to receive information about.

To subscribe, go to http://bit.ly/w3DmHk and select the appropriate list(s) by
entering a check mark into a box next to the subject of interest. Then, enter
your email address and click the "subscribe" button. It's that simple! When you
will receive a verification email, just follow the instructions.

Annapolis Neighborhood Watch Program

Neighborhood Watch works when citizens take an active role in making their
community safer. The Annapolis Police Department, in cooperation with the
communities it serves, has a Neighborhood Watch Program that is more than 5,000
citizens strong.

Neighborhood Watch is crime prevention program that:

1. Teaches citizens techniques to reduce the risk of being victimized at home
and in public

2. Trains citizens on the importance of recognizing suspicious activities and
how to report them

3. Teaches participants how to make their homes more secure and properly
identify their property

4. Allows neighbors to get to know each other and their routines so that any out
of place activity can be reported and investigated

5. Mostly, Neighborhood Watch ia a cohesive body of concerned citizens
addressing issues that concern the entire community

Neighborhood Watch IS NOT a vigilante force working outside of law enforcement
or a program designed for participants to take personal risks to prevent crime.

Monthly meetings are designed to give members maximum exposure to the latest
trends in personal and community safety through crime updates, multi-community
networking and speakers on related topics. Meetings allow for an exchange of
ideas on how APD can make communities safer and enhance the quality of life in
Annapolis. Meetings held on the second Tuesday of every month. For additional
information contact Sgt. Jessica Kirchner at 410-268-9000 ext 7233 or
jkirchner@annapolis.gov

                              312 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                    March 16, 1995, Thursday, FIRST EDITION

PHONY HIV TESTS

BYLINE: Paul Leavitt

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 244 words


Prosecutors in Jacksonville, Fla., filed 14 charges against Tammy Lynn
Esckilsen, 13, who is accused of calling six University Medical Center emergency
room patients and falsely telling them they had tested positive for the HIV
virus. One 16-year-old victim, who also was falsely told she was pregnant, tried
to kill herself. Felony charges include taking confidential information --
patient names -- from a computer at the hospital, where her mother worked. A
caller ID system led to her arrest.

BEAGLE BRIGADE: At a Washington ceremony, a pioneering pooch in the Agriculture
Department's Beagle Brigade was singled out for honors marking the 10th
anniversary of the dog squad. The dogs are trained to sniff out forbidden
fruits, plants and meat that air travelers illegally try to import. Sam, a
12-year-old beagle, who is retiring, and 10 canine co-workers, including Clueso
from Seattle and Abbott from Miami, took part in the celebration, in which
speakers were greeted with yelps and applause. Sam's big busts were 60 pounds of
sausage from a Polish passenger and 40 pounds of plantains from a Ghanaian.

CHEMICAL WEAPONS: The EPA fined the Army $ 122,300 for releasing a "small amount
of nerve agent" at the Johnston Atoll chemical weapons disposal site in the
Pacific, the Army said. It said there was no health hazard from the release, or
from two other violations covered by the fine. Corrective measures have been
taken, the Army said.

                              313 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                              June 27, 2014 Friday

Texas: South Korean Network Features TAMU Center on Conflict and Development

LENGTH: 340  words

DATELINE: Austin


Texas A&M University, The State of Texas has issued the following news release:

In the last thirty years, South Korea has transformed itself from a country
receiving international aid to a donor country for international aid. Their
improvements continue to be a model example of international aid and its
success.

Dr. Ed Price, Director of the Center on Conflict and Development at Texas A&M
University and Professor of Agricultural Economics, recently visited South Korea
to speak with development agencies and conduct lectures on agriculture
development and its influence on conflict. Dr. Price was featured on the Korean
television show, Heart to Heart, for an engaging interview on the work of
ConDev, Texas A&M University, and international development.

Heart to Heart journalist, Seung-yun Rah, and Dr. Price discussed topics from
his origins in agriculture to successes and struggles of international
development and agriculture.
Dr. Price credits his service as a Peace Corps Volunteer in Borneo as his
motivation to become involved in agriculture and the international development
of it. Through that experience, Price emphasized the importance of involving
youth in development and the vitality of agriculture. As Dr. Price pointed out,
youth activities, such as 4-H, help to involve and educate future
agriculturalists and leaders.

Highlights from their conversation educated the audience on the positive impacts
agriculture can have on developing countries, especially during conflict
situations. Hunger is often a root cause of conflict; therefore, Price stressed
that improved science and technology, especially with advancements in
agriculture, can have a positive impact in conflict zones.

The Center on Conflict and Development focuses on four main areas, youth, local
institutions, natural resource management, and food security. Dr. Price
highlighted ConDev's work in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Botswana, and
a joint study in Senegal, Liberia, and Ghana.

For further information please visit: http://tamutimes.tamu.edu/

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                June 22, 1988, Wednesday, North Suncoast Edition

Senator urges relief for drought victims

SOURCE: Associated Press; Reuters

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 427 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON



WASHINGTON - The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee said    Tuesday
that farmers were facing disaster from a devastating drought    and urged quick
action by Congress and the administration to forge a    relief plan.

     "I would hope that we would have a consensus tomorrow on some
legislation," Sen. Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, said at a news
conference. "You've got to give something to give some hope to some of    these
people."

     Leahy, who led a group of farm state senators to drought areas in    the
Dakotas and Montana last weekend, said in a speech to the Senate    that "a
drought of this magnitude is a national crisis."

     "We saw brown and brittle and sad land," he said. "What I saw    there was
not a disaster in the making. I saw a disaster."

     Weather forecasters continued their pessimistic forecasts Tuesday.

 Norton Strommen, the Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist, said    dry,
hot weather was expected to continue through Thursday, with    temperatures
above 100 degrees in much of the Great Plains.

     Not only are thousands of farmers threatened with bankruptcy, Leahy
said, but American consumers could be hit with significant increases in    food
prices.

     "I think when we see the effect of these prices will be in the    winter
and the spring," he said.

     Administration officials have said, however, that a rise in crop    prices
should not have a major impact on food costs.

     As lawmakers grappled with the problem in Washington, temperatures    hit
record highs Tuesday in more than 40 cities from the Dakotas to the    East
Coast, the National Weather Service said.

     The official highest reading in the lower 48 states was 107 degrees    at
Tucson, Ariz., and Hill City, Kan. The high of 98 at Dickinson,    N.D., was the
10th record there this month. It was only the third time    that Milwaukee has
reached 100 degrees during the past 33 years, the    weather service said.

     Meanwhile, U.S. officials said that movement of grain, oil, metals    and a
host of essential products will continue to be interrupted on the    Mississippi
River as long as the drought persists.

     "Our anticipation is that we are going to have periodic stoppages    of
operation, and our aim is to keep them at a minimum," said Gary    Campbell of
the Army Corps of Engineers.

US Contract Award: Department of Agriculture grants Federal contract to Farm
Service Agency (Missouri) Contract worth $442,196.37 for "Purchase of Empty Bags
for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 141  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has granted federal
contract (No. AG-INAE-S-15-0023) on May 8, 2015 for "Purchase of Empty Bags for
U.S. Food Aid Programs" to Farm Service Agency (Missouri), The total value of
the contract is  $442,196.37 .


Contractor Award Details:  USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity
Office (KCCO) intends to issue solicitation AG-INAE-S-15-0023 (2000003306) for
50kg empty woven polypropylene bags to be used in U.S. international food aid
programs. Delivery basis is FAS Vessel at U.S. Gulf.

Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Agricultural Marketing Specialist

                             Daily News (New York)

                          February 15, 1997, Saturday

FEDS OK 500G TO REPLACE BUGGED-OUT TREES

BYLINE: By Kimberly Schaye

SECTION: News; Pg.  14

LENGTH: 121 words


ALBANY Uncle Sam has come up with $ 500,000 in seed money to replace trees
devoured by the Asian long-horned beetle.

The money pledged by the U.S. Department of Agriculture will be enough to
replace some 900 trees in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and Amityville, L.I., that were
infested with the destructive insects.

The state is chopping down and burning the trees this winter in a battle to keep
the beetles from spreading.

"I know how important trees are to the residents of Greenpoint and Amityville,"
said Gov. Pataki, who announced the federal aid. "I am committed to working with
the local communities to develop a responsible tree replacement plan to preserve
and enhance the character of these communities."

LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Monterey County Herald (California)

                            April 18, 2009 Saturday

Briefs: Grants to aid specialty crops

BYLINE: The Monterey County Herald

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 372 words


SACRAMENTO
Grants to aid specialty crops

The California Department of Food and Agriculture is seeking proposals for a
grant program designed to enhance the competitiveness of the state's specialty
crops.

Up to $15 million will be awarded in grant amounts from $75,000 to $500,000 per
project. The department receives funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
through its Agricultural Marketing Service.

To apply, eligible nonprofit organizations, local, state and federal government
entities, for-profit organizations, and universities can see
www.cdfa.ca.gov/grants for detailed solicitation and application instructions,
or access the California State Water Resources Control Board's online
application site at http://faast.waterboards.ca.gov .

Prospective applicants may contact the Department of Food and Agriculture's
Federal Funds Management Office at 916-657-3231 or grants@cdfa.ca.gov

MARINA
Workshop covers solar power

The Association of Monterey Bay Area Governments' Energy Watch and Pacific Gas &
Electric Co. will host a free workshop on "Solar Power Basics for Residential
Use" from 9 to 11 a.m. Friday at the Marina Public Library, 190 Seaside Circle.

Preregistration is required. For information or to register, send your name,
organization (if applicable), phone number and e-mail address to
eschell@ambag.org or call the AMBAG office at 883-3750.

PEBBLE BEACH
Lula's Chocolates owner to address Rotary

Scott Lund, founder and owner of Lula's Chocolates in Monterey, will speak at
the Pacific Grove Rotary Club's next weekly lunch meeting, noon to 1:30 p.m.
Tuesday at Peppoli's at the Inn at Spanish Bay.

Cost is $20 for lunch. For reservations, call 649-0657.

DEL REY OAKS
Tax service hosts seminar on mortgages

Bay Tax Service will hold a free seminar on "Mortgage Options in the New
Economy" with Eric Solve from 10:30 a.m. to noon Tuesday at 203 Calle del Oaks.

For information or to register, see www.baytaxservice.com . or call 392-0584.

CARMEL
Chamber luncheon includes wine tasting

The Carmel Chamber of Commerce will hold its fourth annual members luncheon
Thursday at Rancho Cañada Golf Club, 4860 Carmel Valley Road. Wine tasting
starts at 11:30 p.m., with the luncheon at noon.

Cost is $30. For information, call 624-2522.

                              321 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                June 23, 1988, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Drought Disaster Covers 40% of Nation's Counties

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1101 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22


The Agriculture Department today added 102 counties to the list of drought
disaster areas and declared that the drought emergency exists in more than 40
percent of the nation's counties.

Secretary of Agriculture Richard E. Lyng has so far designated 1,231 counties in
30 states as disaster areas, making them eligible for a variety of aid and
relief programs. Five days ago, about 1,000 counties in 20 states had been
designated.

The Secretary's statements today were the strongest response yet by the Reagan
Administration in the face of dry conditions stretching from New Mexico to
Pennsylvania and from Idaho to South Carolina.

''This could be, if the weather continues, such a catastrophic thing,'' said Mr.
Lyng. ''Rural communities could suffer devastating damage.''

As Mr. Lyng spoke, temperature records were broken in many areas across the
continent for the fourth straight day, with no relief in sight.

Forecast Is Bleak

Mr. Lyng's statement came at a hearing held by an 18-member Congressional panel
that is monitoring the drought and the Agriculture Department's responses. At
the hearing, the panel and the Administration approved general proposals that
the Agriculture Department and the Congress could pursue. They are intended to
alleviate drought-related hardships.

Some of the most influential members of both houses are on the 18-member panel,
and the sense of urgency coupled with agreement on the need for assistance cut
across party lines.

Panel members include Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat and chairman
of the Senate Agriculture Committee; Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority
leader; Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Representative E.
(Kika) de la Garza, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Agriculture
Committee.

Lawmakers were concerned about statements by the Administration that the drought
might cause food prices to rise. Representative Charlie Rose, Democrat of North
Carolina, said he feared that some companies might take advantage of such
statements to profiteer from the droughts. ''The department must be careful not
to give food manufacturers unnecessary opportunity to raise prices,'' he said.

More and more, said lawmakers, the damage to crops looks like it could be of
historic proportions. The Agriculture Department's chief meteorologist, Norton
T. Strommen, said today that the forecast over the next 10 days, a critical
period in the growing season for corn, calls for continued hot, rainless weather
throughout most of the drought-stricken region.

Soybean Crop Is Threatened

Mr. Strommen also told the Congressional panel that, if the Middle West and
South do not receive at least two inches of rain in early July, a substantial
portion of the soybean crop also could be in danger.It had earlier been reported
that half of the wheat, barley and oat crops in the northern Great Plains may be
lost.

Mr. Lyng said President Reagan has expressed keen interest in the drought.
Today, the task force Mr. Reagan established last week to assess the damage and
decide how to deal with it through existing programs convened for its second
meeting at the Agriculture Department.

The task force is made up of top officials from the Department of Agriculture,
the Office of the Vice President, and leading officials of the Energy
Department, the Department of the Interior, the Army Corps of Engineers, the
Federal Emergency Management Administration and the Department of Commerce. The
meeting was not public.

More Remedies Considered

On Capitol Hill, the Congressional panel members agreed to seek administrative
remedies and possibly new legislation to protect consumers, farmers, and rural
communities.

In a broad policy framework that was approved today, the lawmakers said they
wanted the Agriculture Department to expand emergency programs recently put into
effect that would enable livestock farmers to gain corn and other feed from
Government stocks at reduced or subsidized prices.

Mr. Lyng said ranchers and dairy farmers have been the first to suffer. Feed is
scarce in many regions of the country.

Mr. Lyng agreed to use all of his authority to restructure loans, especially
those from the Agriculture Department's chief lending agency, the Farmers Home
Administration, if farmers affected by the drought would benefit from lower
interest rates or deferred payments.

In addition, Mr. Lyng said the Agriculture Department is prepared to extend
emergency loans, as happened in 1986, when emergency loans were extended in a
severe drought in the Deep South. Loans for less than $100,000 carried a 5
percent interest charge over seven years. Larger loans carried an 8 percent
interest charge, said Mr. Lyng.

Some Proposals Rejected

Mr. Lyng, however, rejected a proposal that would allow farmers to havest grain
on land that had been left idle this year. Oats and other grains had been
planted on some of that land as a cover crop, said Mr. Lyng. But it would be
unfair and even unwise, he said, to ''change the rules in the middle of the
game.''

Mr. Lyng also rejected a proposal that would enable farmers to recover 92
percent of their income support payments even if they did not plant a grain
crop. This proposal, said its supporters, recognized that farmers have chosen
simply not to plant a crop where they know seeds will not germinate and where
they fear erosion from the wind.

Mr. Lyng said he had no plans to slow export sales of American grain, and corn
has been selling especially well in recent weeks.

Other Ideas Put Forth

Several lawmakers today suggested other ideas to aid farmers that clearly
sparked the Agriculture Secretary's interest. Senator David H. Pryor, a Democrat
from Arkansas, suggested that farmers ought to be allowed to cut grass alongside
interstate highways and use it as a source of forage.

In many states, the only green grass is found along the superhighway system. Mr.
Lyng said he thought the idea was sound, and said he would pass it along to nine
governors he is meeting in Chicago on Thursday.

Another lawmaker, Representative E. Thomas Coleman, a Republican of Missouri,
suggested allowing cattle to drink from watering holes located on eroded land
that is to be left idle, under a Federal program enacted in 1985, for 10 years
to recover.

Last week, Mr. Lyng approved a change in the law and allowed farmers to harvest
forage from such land. Grazing cattle on this fragile land is prohibited,
though. Mr. Coleman said that ''cattle would only drink, not graze.'' Mr. Lyng
said he would consider the suggestion.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Richard E. Lyng (pg. A18) (Reuters)

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company

                              322 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                August 11, 1991, SUNDAY, LATE FIVE STAR Edition

DROUGHT WITHERS CROPS YIELDS, PRICES BOTH LOW FOR SOME FARMERS

BYLINE: Jerri Stroud Of the Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1G

LENGTH: 806 words


Drought is creeping across parts of Missouri, Illinois and other Midwestern
states, withering crops and leading politicians to seek federal disaster aid for
farmers.  So far, the drought is far less widespread than in the sizzling summer
of 1988. But that makes it all the more insidious, officials and analysts said.
In 1988, searing heat scorched a wide swath across the Corn Belt, prompting
grain traders to bid up corn and soybean prices on the Chicago Board of Trade,
said Becky Doyle, director of the Illinois Agriculture department.  ''This
(drought is so spotty that prices aren't going up because some farmers are
having good crops,'' Doyle said. ''The ones who have the drought not only face
reduced yields but also low prices.  ''It's going to be a tough income problem
for farmers this year,'' said Doyle, who farms with her husband near Gillespie,
about 40 miles northeast of St. Louis.  The experience of farmers around St.
Louis shows the erratic effects of this year's weather.  The gully-washing rain
of July 11 brought relief to many bi-state grain farmers, providing the only
moisture in a month of plant-shriveling heat.  ''We were among the lucky ones,''
said Don Luking of Hoffman, Ill., about 50 miles east of St. Louis in Clinton
County. His farm got an inch of rain early last week and 4 inches in mid-July.
Luking called the rains ''a godsend.'' This year's harvest ''may be the best
crop we ever had,'' he said. Barely 15 miles south of Luking's farm, Clarence
Harre of Nashville has watched his corn deteriorate steadily since he planted it
in mid-May.  ''We haven't had much moisture since the first part of June,''
Harre said.  His farm got only 1.7 inches on July 11, when parts of St. Louis
County got more than 5 inches of rain. His farm netted little from last week's
storm clouds.  Harre says ears on his corn plants are small, and they may not be
filled to the tips. He was hoping to reap 100 or more bushels an acre, but now
will feel lucky to get 90.  The mid-July storm created a disaster for Mike
Bockhorst of Troy, Mo., who farms along the Cuivre River in Lincoln County. The
flooding river killed about a fourth of Bockhorst's corn, damaged another fourth
and left the rest in questionable condition.  The flood dashed Bockhorst's hopes
that his corn crop would make up for the poor-quality wheat he harvested in late
June. His wheat yields were a little better than half of normal, and prices were
worse.  Bockhorst expects to harvest only half of his soybeans, which were
planted just before the flood.  ''When you add them together it comes up
hurting,'' Bockhorst said with a wry laugh.  Better to laugh than cry, Bockhorst
said. ''You can't do anything else about it.'' Weekly crop reports have shown a
gradual worsening of the corn crop in Missouri and Illinois over the last two
months. Soybeans are showing signs of stress, too.  As of last Monday, the
Missouri Agricultural Statistics Service reported that none of the Missouri corn
crop was in excellent shape and that only 18 percent was in good condition. The
service said 27 percent was in poor or very poor condition.  In Illinois, only
27 percent of the corn crop was in good or excellent condition, down from 33
percent the week before. The Illinois Agricultural Statistics service said 35
percent was in poor or very poor condition.  Scattered rains last week may
revive the soybeans, observers said. But rain can do little for the corn crop
now. Many corn plants are beginning to turn brown at the bottom, a sign that
they have reached maturity and are beginning to dry out for harvest.  Gov. Jim
Edgar toured farms last week in northern and eastern Illinois. He is expected to
ask U.S. Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan for disaster aid there and in
Southern Illinois, where diseases decimated winter wheat.  Madigan, a former
congressman from Illinois, says farmers have been calling his home in Virginia,
pleading for aid because their crops are dying.  Madigan pledged to work with
Congress on disaster relief. But the White House has threatened to veto any aid
bills.  Madigan said any aid would have to wait until after harvest, when
officials can gauge the extent of damage.  Doyle, the Illinois agriculture
secretary, said the prospects for aid are iffy at best. The House passed a
disaster aid bill before going home for the August recess, but the Senate hasn't
acted. ''Even if they pass it, (President George Bush will have to sign it''
before farmers can get anything, she said.  Doyle and Edgar have been lobbying
Illinois senators and members of Congress at the Illinois State Fair in
Springfield, Doyle said. Many have promised to work for aid when they return to
Washington in September.  ''The awareness level is rising,'' Doyle said.  This
story contains some information from wire services.

LOAD-DATE: October 14, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Photo; PHOTO By L.T. Spence/Post-Dispatch...Lincoln County farmer Mike
Bockhorst standing in a cornfield damaged by July flooding.

                  Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.
