                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                             March 28, 2005 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Stetson to host lecture series on 20 years in Russia

SECTION: SECTION C; Pg. 4C

LENGTH: 546  words


A lecture tonight at Stetson University the second in a series of five examining
Russia 20 years after Mikhail Gorbachevs rise to power is titled Remaking
Russias Second Capital: St. Petersburg in a Time of Change. Alexander Sungurov
of St.

Petersburg State University and the Kennan Institute will speak at 7 p.m. in
Room 123 of the Lynn Business Center, 345 N. Woodland Blvd., on the DeLand
campus. Other upcoming speeches in the series, all in Room 122 of the Lynn
Business Center, include:*Stefan Hedlund, Economic Meltdown in Russia: Is
Gorbachev to Blame? 7 p.m., April 7.*Harley Balzer, Russian Politics and Society
Since 1985, 7 p.m., April 13.*Lawrence Uzzell, Church- State Relations: Shaking
off the Past? 7 p.m., April 20. MONSTER MASH Two more lectures connected to the
national traveling exhibit Frankenstein: Penetrating the Secrets of Nature, are
planned for this week at Stetson: Stuart Curran, a professor of English at the
University of Pennsylvania, will discuss Frankenstein and Science, at 4 p.m.
today in the Rinker Auditorium at Lynn Business Center. Curran will explore
developments in chemistry in the early 19th century and how they relate to
themes in Mary Shelleys novel. Also, Patricia Matthew, professor of English at
Montclair State University in New Jersey, will discuss Shelley the novelist at 7
p.m. Thursday in Room 25 of Stetsons Instructional Media Center on the north
side of the duPont Ball Library, 134 E. Minnesota Ave. Her lecture is titled:
Beyond Victors Monster: Mary Shelleys Corpus and the Romantic Novel. AIDS IN
AFRICA Devi Sarinjeive, a professor of English at the University of South
Africa, will discuss HIV/AIDS, literature and health issues in her homeland
during a lecture Wednesday at Daytona Beach Community College. The talk, slated
for 2 to 4 p.m., in Room 112 of Building 110 on the Daytona Beach campus. ERAU
DEAN HONORED Tim Brady, dean of the College of Aviation at Embry-Riddle
Aeronautical University, was named winner of the 2005 Excellence in Pilot
Training Award by the National Air Transportation Association. Brady was
specifically cited for distinction in both the civilian and military sectors of
the aviation industry as a highly knowledgeable and experienced aviator,
teacher, administrator and writer. GUATEMALAN HONOR The Guatemalan government
recently cited Stetsons Alliance for International Reforestation for its work to
improve forests and agriculture in the Central American country. Since 1993, AIR
has helped plant millions of trees, install several hundred fuel- efficient
stoves, establish more than 50 tree nurseries, publish environmental childrens
books, train teachers at more than 150 schools and instruct hundreds of farmers
in sustainable agriculture. The Guatemalan National Institute of Forests named
AIR as its 2004 best nongovernmental organization. AID WORKSHOPS A financial aid
workshop for students and parents at Seminole Community College is designed to
demystify the process. The free session starts at 7 p.m. Wednesday in the
Sanford/Lake Mary Campus Fine Arts Concert Hall (Building G). Application
deadlines, how to avoid costly errors when filing for federal aid and tips for
student transfers will be among the topics discussed. Compiled by Education
Writer Mark Harper

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                            November 28, 2005 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Florida's Agriculture Industry Needs Federal Help After Storms

SECTION: NATION/WORLD; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 455 words


Sen. Mel Martinez is asking the federal government for $2 billion in emergency
aid for Florida farmers and citrus growers whose livelihoods were wrecked by
this year's hurricanes.

Unlike most farm subsidies, this is a good bill because it would make growers of
specialty crops eligible for emergency aid and not create long-term dependency.

Martinez's proposed recovery package, backed by Sen. Bill Nelson and the rest of
Florida's congressional delegation, is sure to face a fight in a Congress that
faces competing interests and an escalating national debt. Still, our senators
are right: Florida's besieged farmers cannot be forgotten in appropriations for
hurricane relief.

Producers of nursery crops grown in greenhouses suffered half of Florida's
agriculture losses from hurricanes Dennis, Katrina, Rita and Wilma. All told,
Florida farmers lost roughly $1.2 billion in crops and structures.

Other segments of Florida agriculture also got hit hard. The citrus industry
predicts $180 million in crop losses. Vegetable growers lost $311 million.
Cotton and peanut farmers in the Panhandle say they've lost $18 million. And the
tropical aquaculture industry lost $7.6 million.

The bill also would help offset losses in livestock, fisheries and sugar, and
provide $40 million to help replace lost housing for farm laborers.

Critics will object that Congress already subsidizes American agriculture to the
tune of $30 billion each year, but most of the money goes to large agribusiness
rather than family farms. In Florida, for example, Big Sugar already receives
substantial assistance from the federal government in the form of tariff
protections, which is why offering more federal aid to that segment should be
carefully reviewed.

At any rate, the Martinez bill is not a bailout of agribusinesses wrecked by
poor management or overproduction. This is true disaster aid.

Sure, farming is a risky venture, but Florida's agriculture industry stands more
on its own than most of the large conglomerates in the Midwest. Only 4 percent
of Florida's crops draw federal assistance through commodity support programs.
The only safety net when catastrophe strikes is federal relief.

Congress has already spent more than $72 billion in Katrina relief, but as
Martinez points out, not much has been done to address agriculture and nothing
has been designated for Hurricane Wilma relief.

Agriculture is the second-largest industry in Florida with a $62 billion impact
on our state's economy. It is a hugely important industry that needs short-term
help. The appropriation sought by Martinez, which has its match in the House,
would help.

Copyright © 2005, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: OUR OPINION

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              325 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                   September 10, 2003 Wednesday CITY EDITION

FARMERS TURN UP THE HEAT
DURING A VISIT TO EXAMINE DROUGHT DAMAGE IN SHRIVELED CORNFIELDS, GOV. PAWLENTY
IS TOLD MORE FARM DEBT ISN'T THE ANSWER.

BYLINE: Bill Salisbury, Pioneer Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 418 words


MAZEPPA, Minn. -- While getting a firsthand look at Carl and Joyce Larson's
drought-stricken farm here Tuesday, Gov. Tim Pawlenty also found a decided lack
of enthusiasm for the low-interest disaster-aid loans he is seeking from the
federal government.

"I don't feel a low-interest loan is the answer. A loan is just going to put you
deeper in debt," Carl Larson told Pawlenty as they examined shriveled ears of
corn.

"Farmers need some kind of program that puts money in their pocket," Larson
said. Without cash, they won't be able to buy the seed, fertilizer, feed and
fuel they will need next year.

About 25 of Larson's southeastern Minnesota farm neighbors came to his farm to
tell the governor about their plight, and many agreed they couldn't afford more
debt.

Pawlenty couldn't offer much help. For now, he said, farmers will have to rely
on crop insurance and most likely federal loans to offset their losses. State
Agriculture Commissioner Gene Hugoson told the farmers that at a time of rising
federal budget deficits, it is unlikely Congress will provide more farm aid.

But Pawlenty said that if crop insurance and federal loans fail to meet farmers'
needs, "I'm sure the Legislature would be willing to provide emergency
assistance" next year.

In his 65 years of farming here, Larson said he has never seen a drought as
severe as this one. It hasn't rained on his farm in more than two months.

He estimated he has already lost about half of his corn crop and probably will
have to buy silage to feed his 100-plus beef cattle and sell his feeder calves
instead of fattening them for slaughter. But the drought won't put him out of
business, he said.

The farmers told Pawlenty the drought is spotty. While some farmers, like
Larson, already have lost much of their crops, others just a few miles away are
expecting good yields.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has projected Minnesota's crop loss at $1.1
billion, Hugoson said. A preliminary survey indicated 49 or 50 of the state's 87
counties are eligible for federal aid, and that number is likely to grow. He
said state officials plan to submit their initial damage assessment to the USDA
by the end of the week, and the department will respond in 30 to 60 days.

Pawlenty said the one-hour visit to Larson's farm reinforced his view that the
drought is a "major crisis. It is a very significant challenge to Minnesota
farmers."

Bill Salisbury can be reached at bsalisbury@pioneerpress.com or 651-228-5538.

LOAD-DATE: August 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: JODI OSHAUGHNESSY OLSON, ROCHESTER POST-BULLETIN

Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, right, opened an ear of drought-dried corn on the
farm of Carl Larson, left, in Mazeppa on Tuesday. About 25 of Larson's neighbors
came to tell the governor that farmers need cash for seed, feed, fuel and
fertilizer.

                              The Washington Post

                     March 20, 1992, Friday, Final Edition

F.E. Pinder II Dies;
State Dept. Official

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C9; OBITUARIES

LENGTH: 681 words


Frank E. Pinder II, 84, a retired agricultural official with the Agency for
International Development who had extensive experience in Africa, died of cancer
March 15 at his home in Chevy Chase.

Mr. Pinder joined the State Department in 1940. In 1944, he went to Liberia as
an agricultural consultant, and he remained in Africa almost continuously until
he retired about 1968.

He worked for the successive foreign assistance programs of the U.S. government
over the years and joined AID when it was formed in 1961. In addition to
Liberia, his assignments included Ghana and Ethiopia.

Mr. Pinder twice received the State Department's Meritorious Service Award.

A native of Key West, Fla., Mr. Pinder graduated from what is now Florida A&M
University. He received a master's degree in agriculture at Cornell University.
He was a farm agent with the U.S. Department of Agriculture in Florida until he
joined the State Department.

In retirement, he was a consultant to AID. He also wrote an autobiography,
"Pinder, From Little Acorns."

Mr. Pinder received the Mary McLeod Bethune Medallion from Bethune-Cookman
College in Daytona Beach, Fla., and honorary doctoral degrees from Morris Brown
College in Atlanta and Monrovia College in Liberia. He donated his collection of
African art to Florida A&M University, and he was a member of the school's Hall
of Fame and a recipient of its Outstanding Alumnus Award.

Mr. Pinder also was a member of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, the Cornell
University Alumni Association and St. Stephen & the Incarnation Episcopal Church
in Washington.

His marriage to Terrecita E. Pinder ended in divorce.

Survivors include three children, Terrecita E. Pinder-Watkis of Hempstead, N.Y.,
Frank E. Pinder III of Los Angeles and Dorothea I. Pinder of San Francisco; a
brother, Alexander Pinder of Camden, N.J.; and five grandchildren.

ARTHUR J. BROERING

Medical Library Official


Arthur J. Broering, 59, an architect who was an official of the National Library
of Medicine, died of cancer March 15 at Georgetown University Hospital. An area
resident and employee of the National Institutes of Health for 30 years, he
lived in Reston.

Mr. Broering retired in January as deputy director of the library's extramural
programs, which provide grants to outside activities related to the medical
library.

He previously was an architect in the NIH health research facilities branch and
a construction officer at the library and chief of its resource division. He was
named deputy director in 1974.

Mr. Broering was born in Covington, Ky. He attended Vanderbilt University and
received a bachelor's degree in architecture from the University of Cincinnati.

He served in the Marine Corps in the early 1950s.

Mr. Broering received the Superior Service Award of the former Department of
Health, Education and Welfare.

He was a member of the American Institute of Architects, the Medical Library
Association and St. John Neumann Catholic Church in Reston.

Survivors include his wife, Naomi C. Broering of Reston; a sister, Hilda
Landwehr of Indianapolis; and three brothers, Robert Broering of Indianapolis,
Leo Broering of Fort Wright, Ky., and William Broering of Fort Thomas, Ky.

MARGARET MARIE MIDKIFF

Pharmacy Assistant


Margaret Marie Midkiff, 67, a retired pharmacy assistant in a Washington
drugstore and a member of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church, died of cancer March
18 at Florida Hospital in Altamont Springs, Fla.

Miss Midkiff was a resident of Adelphi, and she was visiting family when she was
stricken.

A native West Virginia, she grew up there and in Takoma Park. She graduated from
Takoma Academy and attended the old Alexander Hospital nursing school.

She worked at a pharmacy at Connecticut Avenue and McKinley Street NW from 1943
until she retired in 1970 for health reasons.

Survivors include three brothers, John Reuben Midkiff and Raleigh F. Midkiff,
both of Orlando, and Alotha B. Midkiff of Adelphi, and three sisters, L. Isabel
Starcher of Adelphi, Esther Maas of Greenbelt and Patricia Ann Mosheim of
Richmond.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: OBITUARY

                              327 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     March 25, 1993, Thursday, City Edition

Chiles supports reporting HIV carriers

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; CAPITAL DIGEST; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 475 words



Gov. Lawton Chiles said Wednesday he supports reporting the names of people  who
carry the AIDS virus, but not until there is public confidence the names  would
be kept private. Many opponents to reporting, including AIDS activists  and
nurses, argue that people will not get tested for acquired immune  deficiency
syndrome if doctors are required to report names of patients  carrying the
virus. Florida is one of 15 states that don't require the  reporting of people
who have tested positive for HIV, the virus that causes  AIDS. Under current
law, the names of people with full-blown AIDS are reported  to public health
clinics but private doctors are banned from reporting the  names of patients who
carry HIV but haven't developed the disease.

Governor on TV call-in show tonight

If you want to ask Gov. Lawton Chiles a question, you have a chance tonight.
The governor will participate in a "televised dialogue" with viewers across  the
state during a one-hour edition of Florida Face to Face. The broadcast,
produced by the public television station in Tallahassee, will be carried from
8 to 9 p.m. in the Tampa Bay area on WUSF-Ch. 16. Viewers can call in their
questions to the governor at (800) 322-9378, or (904) 487-3200.

Chiles calls for lobbyist, vote reforms

In a letter to legislative leaders Wednesday, Gov. Lawton Chiles urged passage
of election reforms and lobbyist disclosure issues that are pending in the
House and Senate. Chiles commended the Senate for including a requirement that
lobbyists disclose their fees in a bill that won committee approval last week,
and he urged the House to force more disclosure so that Floridians will know
more about the special interests that seek to influence the passage and
rejection of laws that affect their lives. Citizens will only have a fair
chance to be heard when no one interest group has an unbridled opportunity to
dominate the legislative process and override the public good, Chiles said.

Senate orders access to migrant camps

Social workers, doctors and lawyers would have rights of access to migrant
farmworker camps under a bill passed 38-0 Wednesday by the Senate. The
legislation, which now moves to the House, also provides a way for workers to
bring complaints about housing conditions to the Department of Health and
Rehabilitative Services without fear of retribution. The measure is an
outgrowth from problems that lawyers, physicians and social workers had in
getting access to some of the 452 Florida camps, which house about 41,770
migrant workers. The Senate voted unanimously for an amendment by Sen. Rick
Dantzler, D-Winter Haven, reducing the potential fine for violations of
sanitary conditions from $ 10,000 per violation to the current level of $ 500.

LOAD-DATE: March 30, 1993

                            China Daily - US Edition

                           October 16, 2014 Thursday

China goes from hungry nation to farm giant that feeds the world

LENGTH: 411  words


While China feeds the world's largest population, it is also feeding starving
people across the world, playing an important role in helping tackle global
hunger, experts said.

While China feeds the world's largest population, it is also feeding starving
people across the world, playing an important role in helping tackle global
hunger, experts said.

"As a major responsible country, China is making full efforts to eliminate
famine across the world," said Wang Sangui, a professor of economics and rural
development at Renmin University of China.

Wang said increasing investment in, and support for, agriculture is guaranteeing
the country's food production growth and making China a major supplier of food
aid in the world.

He said 2005 was an important year, when the United Nations World Food Program
officially ended aid to China, and the country has since emerged as one of the
world's major food aid donors.

The latest WFP report, released in 2013, showed that China provided 243,000
metric tons of food aid in 2012, a more than 100 percent year-on-year increase
that made the country the fifth-largest donor, after the United States, Japan,
Brazil and Canada.

China continues contributing aid to the world, most recently in early October,
when it provided $6 million in food aid to the WFP to help Sierra Leone, Liberia
and Guinea, all hit by the Ebola virus, according to the Ministry of Commerce.

The WFP estimated that 1 million people in the three countries will suffer from
food shortages in the coming months because of the disease.

Wang conceded that China has its own resource limitations, but he was optimistic
about conquering them.

"Even though China itself has a huge population, shrinking arable land and water
scarcity, authorities are increasing investment in and strengthening support to
agriculture through technological innovation to maintain steady growth in food
production," Wang said.

In the past four years, China planted hybrid rice, with an expected yield of 15
metric tons per hectare, in 8.7 million hectares of farmland in 17 provinces and
regions, said Tang Ke, an official of Ministry of Agriculture.

Agriculture Minister Han Changfu noted in a news conference last year that China
feeds 20 percent of the world population with 9 percent of the world's arable
land.

"We are transforming from food aid receiver to major food donor, showing our
achievements in agriculture," Han said.

wangqian@chinadaily.com.cn

(China Daily USA 10/16/2014 page6)

                          Australian Financial Review

                            September 9, 1991 Monday
                                  Late Edition

HUNGRY SOVIET UNION WORRIES WASHINGTON

BYLINE: Source: The New York Times

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 597 words


Predicting a poor Soviet harvest and concerned that financing problems may delay
Western food aid, US Administration and private experts on agriculture are
increasingly worried about how the Soviet Union will feed itself this winter.

The consensus of agriculture experts in and outside government is that the
Soviet harvest will be as much as 25 per cent smaller than last year's.
Political turmoil after the failed coup against the Soviet President, Mr
Gorbachev, has delayed the gathering of crops, experts say, adding that the
harvest may be even smaller if the work is delayed any further.

In response to an urgent request from Soviet authorities soon after the coup
plot was foiled, the US President, Mr Bush, announced two weeks ago that he
would make $US315 million of $US500 million in agricultural loan guarantees for
the Soviets that had been planned for October 1 available immediately.

The Soviets wanted to begin moving grain in September to ensure that their
antiquated distribution system did not become overloaded in October.

But a senior Department of Agriculture official said at the weekend that no US
or foreign bank had yet come forward to claim any of the guarantees, so no grain
was being prepared for shipment.

"The President's purpose will not be served if that $US315 million is not
touched," the official said, adding that Soviet officials had asked the US for
help in financing the deal.

Mr Bush authorised $US1.5 billion in loan guarantees for the Soviet Union on
June 11. The first instalment of $US600 million was given then to the Soviet
authorities, who needed a month to find banks willing to lend.

The final instalment of $US400 million is scheduled for February.

A broad consensus in favour of large-scale food aid to the Soviet Union emerged
in London on August 29 at a meeting of the heads of State of the Group of Seven
countries.

The US and Japan have been concerned that food aid may be wasted if it rots on
arrival for lack of transport, as reportedly happened to some grain last year.
But they nonetheless support aid this year as a way to stave off possible civil
disorder.

Even with last year's record harvest, the transport and distribution problems
endemic to the Soviet system created local shortages as grain, fruit and
vegetables never made it from regions of surplus to areas that grow little of
their own food. And officials of two large grain-producing republics, Russia and
the Ukraine, have said they will ensure their own populations are fed before
allowing food to go to other republics.

Soviet State farms have become less willing to sell their crops privately for
fear of being accused of speculation in the current turmoil, although their
alternatives are to sell to an inefficient State system or allow grain to rot in
the fields.

"It is our expectation that the Soviet harvest will be considerably less than it
was last year, and you will recall that even with the dimensions of last year's
harvest there were still some problems within the Soviet Union,"the US
Agriculture Secretary, Mr Edward Madigan, said.

"So we would anticipate that with a diminished harvest, those problems would be
exacerbated even if the relationships between the republics were clearly
understood today."

Private experts disagree about whether time may be running out for large-scale
shipments.

Ms Carol Brookins, the president of World Perspectives Inc, a Washington
agriculture consulting firm, said: "If they don't get it moved in the
September-November period, it's going to be even harder to move in December,
January and February, during the Soviet winter."

LOAD-DATE: March 15, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Evening St Petersburg. The newspaper had previously been called the Evening
Leningrad

Description: Agriculture is a buyer of domestic origin food commodities for use
in various U.S. Government international food aid programs and, from time to

for commodity purchases are generally published in Commodity Requirements
Documents (CRD) available on the Kansas City Commodity Office's (KCCO) website.

identify the requirements document applicable in accordance with FAR 11.201(b)

                               The New York Times

                 August 14, 1998, Friday, Late Edition - Final

METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
$172 Million in U.S. Aid Along Upstate Canals

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 134 words

DATELINE: OSWEGO


The Federal Government will provide $172 million in assistance to help
revitalize small communities along the state's canal system, officials announced
yesterday.

The money will be used to help economic growth, job creation, tourism, housing
construction and structural improvements in more than two dozen counties along
the state's 524-mile canal network. Andrew Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and
Urban Development, and Dan Glickman, Secretary of Agriculture, announced the aid
package in Oswego and in Lockport.

The assistance is an outgrowth of the New York Recreationway Plan, developed by
the state in 1995. The plan is meant to turn the historic Erie Canal and
connecting waterways into a major tourism destination that will generate
economic development in adjacent communities.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Representative John M. McHugh of northern New York, at the Barge Canal in
Oswego, N.Y. (Associated Press)

                              333 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)

                           January 30, 2008 Wednesday

Bush presses to allow food aid from farmers abroad

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 515 words


DESMOND BUTLER

WASHINGTON -- President Bush is making a renewed push to allow the government to
spend food aid money to buy crops in poor countries. Congress is unlikely to go
along.

Bush has asked Congress to change a law that requires food supplies for foreign
aid to be bought in the United States.

Lawmakers from states with large agricultural industries are opposing the
proposal on grounds that American farmers should continue to benefit from the
aid program. Congress members, nearing completion of a bill that would govern
how the administration spends about $1.2 billion in aid, so far have not
included loosened restrictions on food aid sourcing.

Bush mentioned the issue in Monday's State of the Union address. He urged
Congress to make the changes that he argued would "help break the cycle of
famine" in countries that receive U.S. food aid.

The administration and aid groups have argued that the current policy slows
efforts to deliver food to disaster areas, sometimes by months. Critics also say
it harms farmers in developing countries by denying them markets that could help
them and the people who would work with them out of grinding poverty.

"In some cases, food aid coming from the United States puts local farmers at a
disadvantage," said Laura Rusu, a spokeswoman for Oxfam America.

Bush's latest request for the change comes less than three weeks before he is to
go to Africa, where he is likely to highlight his administration's efforts to
fight HIV-AIDS, malaria and other diseases and poverty.

Keith Williams, a spokesman for the Agriculture Department, says the
administration is continuing to push Congress to approve the sourcing changes,
and mentioning the issue Monday was an attempt to press the case.

With less than a year in his presidency and his popularity at low levels, Bush
lacks the political muscle to push unpopular proposals through Congress.
Traditionally, agricultural interests are quite strong politically.

Anti-poverty groups who have been critical of the current policy are skeptical
that the administration is determined enough or even politically capable of
winning over Congress.

"I don't see that this is going to happen," said Marianne Leach, director of
government affairs for the anti-poverty group CARE. "We have not heard about
anything that the administration is doing to make this happen."

Some U.S. lawmakers, who oppose Bush's proposal, argue that massive agricultural
purchases in developing countries could disrupt local economies and drive up
prices for important staples beyond the crisis areas targeted by aid.

"I agree with the president that we should strengthen the emergency response
capability of U.S. food assistance," said Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin of Iowa,
chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee in a statement. "Allowing some
local purchase of food in poor countries seems to have promise, but let's be
careful about wholesale change."

The Senate version of the bill would include $25 million -- a small fraction of
the overall food aid budget-- for a four-year experimental program to test the
idea of buying crops abroad.

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                           February 8, 2007 Thursday
                                 Metro Edition

Minnesota senators grill U.S. agriculture chief over farm-bill plans;
Coleman and Klobuchar are worried about providing adequate aid during bad crop
years and times of disaster.

BYLINE: Brady Averill, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7A

LENGTH: 302 words

DATELINE: Washington, D.C.


Minnesota's senators told Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns Wednesday that
they're worried there isn't enough aid for farmers in President Bush's farm-bill
proposal.

It was their first chance to question the secretary since Bush presented his
budget this week, calling for a reduction in farm spending of $18 billion over
five years.

Members of the Senate Agriculture Committee, including Republican Norm Coleman
and Democrat Amy Klobuchar, offered a mixed bag of criticisms. But Johanns
called the proposed farm bill equitable and market-based. He also said the
administration's proposal would provide a more stable safety net .

Some senators argued that the proposal doesn't provide enough help for farmers
during bad crop years and times of disaster.

"My major concern is that it just doesn't provide a good enough safety net for
our farmers in Minnesota," Klobuchar said after the hearing.

During the hearing, she asked Johanns why there isn't permanent disaster relief
for farmers. Referring to flooding in 2005 and drought in 2006, she said,
"Minnesota farmers have been hit with heavy losses for two consecutive years,"
totaling $700 million.

Klobuchar and Coleman are sponsors of the 2007 Emergency Farm Relief Act. It
would provide $4.4 billion in emergency money for "farmers and ranchers who have
suffered weather-related crop production shortfalls, quality losses and damage
to livestock feed supplies."

Coleman said he is concerned with a proposed change to a commodity program that
would base some payments to farmers on U.S. crop yields instead of prices. He
wants to make sure that Congress protects farmers who have low yields.

He also said he thinks federal research programs should examine ways to turn
sugar beets into ethanol.

Brady Averill is a correspondent in the  Star Tribune Washington Bureau.

                  The Register-Herald (Beckley, West Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 24, 2008 Tuesday

Federal bill to help new farmers won't aid them in clearing land

BYLINE: Mannix Porterfield, The Register-Herald, Beckley, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 469 words


Jun. 24--CHARLESTON -- Farmer-legislator Bill Proudfoot thinks the federal
government needs to help budding food growers in West Virginia with clearing
land to help meet the needs of a hungry planet.

Yet, as the Randolph County delegate learned Monday, the new federal Farm Bill
enacted recently contains no specific help in that arena.

That doesn't mean, however, that such help in clearing off lands and making
other preparations cannot be provided, Bill O'Donnell, an assistant state
conservationist for the U.S. Department of Agriculture, indicated before the
Agriculture and Agri-business Committee.

Using a slide presentation, O'Donnell outlined features of the federal
legislation, when Proudfoot inquired about help in preparing land for
agriculture.

"We do have some pretty good land ... and that could be turned to agriculture,"
the Democratic lawmaker said.

O'Donnell acknowledged a need to produce locally grown foods, but advised
Proudfoot that the local offices working directly with a landowner must
determine if such uses are viable.

While the farm bill doesn't contain language for specific assistance in clearing
land, he emphasized afterward, "It doesn't mean it's excluded."

"You have to look at it from the ground," the federal official said.

"What are the resources? Is that soil good for what that producer, that
landowner, wants to do with it? It's just not something we're going to go in and
do willy-nilly because somebody wants to do it. There has to be a really good
reason, and then, can we support the program?"

O'Donnell advised Proudfoot that top soil is the top priority of his agency.

At construction sites, the delegate said valuable top soil that was formed over
millions of years is cast indifferently over hillsides and no effort is made to
reclaim it.

"In Asian countries, you have a respect for the top soil you don't have here,"
he said.

On another matter, the federal official said his agency doesn't deal with deer
since there is no difficulty in raising them in West Virginia, although the
agency does have a wildlife habitat program.

Speaking for other farmers, Proudfoot suggested deer are a constant nuisance for
those in agriculture because the state lets them run rampant to satisfy its
multimillion-dollar hunting industry.

"The game plan is to get the deer herds as high as they can for the hunt-ers,"
he added.

-- E-mail: mannix@register-herald.com

                       EVENING CHRONICLE (Newcastle, UK)

                      December 22, 1997, Monday Edition 1

Row looms as agriculture lobby says help is not enough - £80m aid plan for beef
farms

SECTION: BRITAIN TONIGHT, Pg. 6

LENGTH: 396 words


   Agriculture Secretary, Jack Cunningham, is today expected to announce in the
Commons a compensation package for Britain's crisis-hit beef farmers.

The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, has been beating down demands for compensation
from the farmers, according to reports, arguing the Government must limit
payouts when it was under fire for reducing payments to lone parents.

Mr Cunningham's aid could be worth as little as £80 million - falling far short
of demands by the National Farmers' Union for nearly £1 billion to support the
beef industry.

There was also speculation today that Dr Cunningham is considering methods of
reducing the industry by ordering big cutbacks in beef production, including a
voluntary decommissioning scheme to take farmers off the land.

Concern

The idea is to lure farmers, principally in the beef sector, away from the land
with retirement packages partly funded by the European Union.

There is growing concern about the massive cost of keeping the beef industry
afloat following the BSE crisis - £1.5 billion this year alone.

Even the £80 million handout will qualify for only 29pc support from Brussels -
with the remainder coming from the British taxpayer.

Those opposed to the plan claim the support is hard to justify when the
Government is poised to cut benefit for lone parents.

The decommissioning plan would follow a relatively successful - but costly -
scheme in the fishing industry where vessels have been scrapped to conserve fish
stocks.

Although Dr Cunningham is set to offer hill-farmers emergency aid to compensate
for falling incomes, he is understood to be determined to make any handout
conditional on talks with the NFU to restructure the industry.

Shadow Agriculture Secretary, Michael Jack, accused Labour of trying to divert
attention from the paucity of its aid for farmers by delaying until today the
announcement of a public inquiry into past handling of the BSE crisis.

Two patients given cornea transplants from a donor with CJD face having the
grafts removed. The patients were warned that otherwise they risked developing
the human form of BSE from the corneas of Marion Hamilton.

A Liverpool woman in her 80s has received one cornea and a 29-year-old man from
Wolverhampton the other. A third patient, a man in his 30s from Manchester,
received the white of the eye.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            July 12, 2000 Wednesday

Vanclief slams U.S. farm aid policies;
Says rhetoric belies reality of subsidies

BYLINE: BARRIE McKENNA, Washington Bureau

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 347 words

DATELINE: Washington


The United States continues to boost aid to its own farmers even as it vows to
get rid of agricultural subsidies elsewhere in the world, Canadian Agriculture
Minister Lyle Vanclief complained yesterday.

As efforts continue to revive stalled global trade talks at the World Trade
Organization, the U.S. has quietly restored its own farm subsidies to the record
levels hit more than a decade ago, Mr. Vanclief said as he emerged from a
meeting with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman in Washington.

"When the United States continues to increase [its] support to producers and at
the same time say[s] to the world 'you shouldn't be doing that,' it raises a lot
of questions in people's minds," Mr. Vanclief told reporters. "Where's the
rhetoric and where's the reality?"

Canadian officials said the United States will transfer $25-billion (U.S.) to
farmers this year, based on spending already approved by Congress. Much of that
aid is destined for wheat farmers, who have been hit hard by depressed world
commodity prices.

U.S. wheat subsidies have now reached $50 per ton, compared with $15 a ton in
Canada, a top Canadian official noted.

But Mr. Vanclief said one of the most divisive issues in Canada-U.S. farm trade
- the operations of the Canadian Wheat Board - didn't come up during an annual
bilateral meeting between the countries' top farm officials.

Nonetheless, the U.S. has repeatedly vowed to target the CWB's practices in any
new round of trade talks - most recently in a submission late last month to the
WTO in Geneva.

Mr. Vanclief also warned the U.S. that proposed new health regulations in North
Dakota for imported cattle and hogs may violate WTO pacts and the North American
Free Trade Agreement.

"If we feel that whatever is done is not in accordance with the WTO and the
NAFTA, we'll take the challenge to the next step" he said.

Mr. Vanclief complained that the proposed North Dakota measures, now out for
comment, are aimed directly at hindering imports from Canada.

He is slated to meet with U.S. trade representative Charlene Barshefsky today.

                               The Ottawa Citizen

                      July 19, 1992, Sunday, FINAL EDITION

FRONTIERS

BYLINE: CITIZEN NEWS SERVICES; CITIZEN

SECTION: OUR PLANET; FRONTIERS; Pg. E4


Star moss study could lead to greener pastures

Imagine a brown, sun-baked lawn springing to life almost instantly with the
first few drops of rain.

Or lush crops blanketing vast areas that now sustain only the most meagre of
plant and animal life.

It may seem like Star Trek fantasy right now. But some down-to-Earth work
already has some scientists boldly going where no drought researchers have gone
before.

One of them, Mel Oliver, a molecular biologist with the U.S. Department of
Agriculture's research service in Lubbock, Tex., is trying to identify the genes
that give a simple plant called star moss the almost magical ability to survive
drought.

Another, Derek Bewley, a professor in the botany department at the University of
Guelph first began looking at the star moss more than a decade ago.

The power of star moss to quickly recover from drought is easily demonstrated .
Pour water on some dry moss and in less than a minute what looks like a brown
Brillo pad becomes a lush green mass of individual branches with star-like
needles.

Bewley, whom Oliver called his mentor from their days at the University of
Calgary in the late 1970s, earlier investigated the star moss to find what
happens as the plant is dried out and then rehydrated.

"What we found was that when the moss dries out, everything is conserved," said
Bewley, who still collaborates with Oliver.

Oliver hopes to identify the genes responsible and insert them into crops such
as cotton, corn and the like.

How soon will scientists be able to beam up that instantly-green lawn?

"Not in the foreseeable future" and maybe never, said Oliver.

Scientists haven't yet developed techniques for inserting genes in grass "and
the plant is so complex that that may never be possible."

New hybrid AIDS virus

Researchers have constructed a hybrid AIDS virus from the human immunodeficie
ncy virus and the AIDS virus that infects monkeys. The purpose is to test
vaccines against the human virus in monkeys. The new hybrid has most of the
monkey virus geneswrapped in a coat from the human virus.

The researchers call their virus SHIV, standing for simian human immunodefici
ency virus. Dr. William Haseltine of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston
said he hoped it would serve as "a sharp little knife to pry apart the problem."

Japanese scientists created a similar virus about a year ago, but it failed to
grow in monkeys.

Researchers trying to assess potential AIDS vaccines have run into a fundamental
problem: It is hard to find ethically acceptable ways of testing the vaccine in
volunteers, yet there is no suitable animal species that is susceptible to HIV.

Macaques are infected only by SIV, not HIV. Chimpanzees can be infected with
HIV, but they are an endangered species and so it is not feasible to use them in
vaccine tests.

Recently investigators showed that the pigtailed macaque can be infected with
HIV, but some researchers question whether there are enough of them available
for large-scale studies of vaccines.

Bone breakthrough

WASHINGTON -- Indianapolis researchers believe they have found the reason women
after menopause often develop weak bones -- a condition called osteoporosis.

The finding may lead to new drugs to combat the disorder.

Dr. Stavros Manolagas of the Veterans Medical Centre and Indiana University
School of Medicine in Indianapolis said laboratory studies show lack of the
hormone estrogen leads to an overproduction of bone-scavenger cells that carve
pits and cratersthroughout the skeleton.jThe result is pain, fragile bones that
break easily and a spinal slumping.

Manolagas said studies with mice show the lack of estrogen stimulates production
of interleukin-6, one of the host of chemicals in the immune system.

Interleukin-6, or IL6, then stimulates the growth of cells called osteoclasts,
he said. And the osteoclasts are the culprits in bone-degenerati on.

A bone-formation cell, called an osteoblast, usually follows the bone scavenging
cells and fills in the pits and craters with new bone.

The problem comes when a woman goes into menopause and stops the normal
production of estrogen.

After that, said Manolagas, the balance between bone-scavengers and
bone-builders is lost.

Estrogen apparently plays a role in suppressing the effect of IL6 and, thus,
helps keep the bone-destroying cells from dominating.

Many women take estrogen pills to prevent osteoprosis but, until now, it was not
known exactly what role the hormone played in the loss of bone mass.

Now that the mechanism is understood, Manolagas said researchers will be able to
design drugs that block the overproduction of IL6. This will be more efficient
than the current estrogen pills, he said, because the action will be limited
specificallyto protecting the bones.

(By Citizen staff and news services)

Next Week in Our Planet

Thirty years ago, the Aral Sea was the size of West Virginia. But for 30 years,
the Soviet Union diverted it's water to grow cotton in the desert has shriveled
the lake into a lifeless lagoon. The move has polluted and salinated Central
Asia'srivers and farmlands and impoverished and sickened millions of its
inhabitants.

                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                              June 27, 2008 Friday
                                8:32 AM EDITION

MORE FOOD AID FOR FLOOD VICTIMS

BYLINE: THE CAPITAL TIMES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 241 words


Victims in all 28 counties included in the federal disaster declaration for
recent floods and storms are now eligible for federal emergency food assistance.

The six counties added to the disaster declaration June 24 were approved for
food aid Thursday, so victims in Adams, Calumet, Green Lake, Jefferson, La
Crosse and Walworth Counties can apply for food assistance from Friday to July
8.

The one-time emergency food benefit is from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
Food and Nutrition Service, distributed through the Wisconsin Department of
Health and Family Services as a Wisconsin QUEST debit card, used at grocery
stores accepting the program.

Food aid could be as much as $426 for a family of three.

While victims in the six counties have until July 8 to apply for food aid,
victims in the first seven counties declared disaster areas must apply by today
(Friday) for assistance. Those counties include Columbia, Crawford, Milwaukee,
Racine, Richland, Sauk and Vernon Counties.

The second group of counties added to the disaster list have a July 1 deadline
to apply for food aid. Those counties are Dodge, Fond du Lac, Green, Iowa,
Marquette, Washington, Waukesha and Winnebago Counties.

The third group of counties added have a July 3 deadline, including Dane, Grant,
Juneau, Kenosha, Ozaukee, Rock and Sheboygan Counties.

For more information, go to the Wisconsin Department of Health and Family
Services Web site at http://dhfs.wisconsin.gov.

                              340 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                December 24, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Ideas & Trends;
Charity Begins at the Rule Book

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1020 words


CHARITY is kind, the Bible says. And in this season of coat drives and food
baskets, who would disagree? Not President-elect George W. Bush, who has vowed
to "rally the armies of compassion," and met with black ministers last week to
promote faith-based charity as the kinder, more cost-effective alternative to
government-run help for needy people.

But as charities attempt to take up the slack in the safety net caused by a $7
billion decline in government food aid for the poor, they have taken on some of
the worst aspects of the government bureaucracy they try to replace. Seemingly
arbitrary eligibility rules, inflexible limits on aid and impersonal
requirements are now common features at many food pantries and religious social
service organizations as they struggle with overwhelming demands.

To meet a new scale of need, many nonprofit agencies became more professional
and so rule-bound. Public money to expand, or access to supplies from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, brought greater accountability and state rules so
detailed they can specify the number of cans of green beans allowed one family
in a year. Even small, church-based volunteers are adding rules that can make it
harder to get help.

In New York City, a recent survey of 216 food pantries by the Coalition Against
Hunger found 63 percent now set rules to limit use, though such rules were too
rare to measure just a few years ago, and only reached half the pantries in
1999, said Judith Walker, director of the coalition. At United Bronx Parents,
hungry families are barred from getting groceries from the food bank more than
three times a year; before the coordinator hands out cans of chili beans and
meat balls, he consults a ledger cross-referenced with names, dates and
photocopies of such required documents as a referral from a church or social
service agency.

The more programs are forced to turn people away for lack of supplies or money,
researchers say, the more intent they become on adding rules that tighten their
service boundaries, trying to slow demand and ensure help goes to those who need
it most. The unintended result is that people unable to make ends meet because
of low wages or serious health problems trudge from one food pantry to the next.

"What's most worrisome is that some of the people who are in most need are
simply not able to play by all these rules," said Amy Brown, a researcher with
the Community Food Resource Center in New York.

One goal of the welfare overhaul was to replace a sense of entitlement from
government with a sense of personal responsibility for self-sufficiency. Private
charity was expected by many to do a better job than government at deciding who
deserved help. And agencies generally consider rules, even arbitrary ones, a
fairer way to ration inadequate resources than unbridled discretion.

More rules can also be a healthy development in a growing organization, contends
Noel Tichy, a professor of business at the University of Michigan and a
management expert who advises corporations and nonprofits alike. In fast-growth
software companies, he said, "we try to create some rules and bureaucracy to
guide decision-making so it's not all anarchy." In lean social service
organizations, "they're trying to be fair, and rules are one way to play
triage."

But the result can seem like the worst of both worlds, said Doug O'Brien,
director of policy for America's Second Harvest, which distributes $2.4 billion
worth of donated food annually, compared to $18 billion-worth of food stamps
delivered by the government, down from $25 billion five years ago.

In its survey of 12,000 food programs two years ago, 77 percent of pantries said
they limit who can be served, and 70 percent screen clients, often to prevent
use by those outside a certain geographic area. Some consider that applicants
who make the rounds abuse the system, but 53 percent say the practice is fair,
in part because clients cannot get enough food from one program.

At one food bank in Austin, Tex., for example, many young mothers who arrive
with hungry toddlers in tow have been referred straight from the food stamp
office for emergency supplies to bridge a 30-day delay before their first
allotment. But Debora Duncan, the center director, said it cannot supply food
for a whole month and bars a client's return for three months. If they go
elsewhere, she added, "They are labeled as using the system, when all they're
trying to do is survive."

Not surprisingly, a recent survey at the Community Food Resource Center's West
Harlem food programs, which has no geographical restrictions, found 21 percent
of clients travel there from other boroughs.

SUCH demand pushes charities to ratchet up eligibility requirements, said David
Reingold, an assistant professor at the Indiana University School of
Philanthropy, who studied the impact of welfare reform on faith-based charities
in Indiana. Surveying 295 social service agency directors, he found 23 percent
of the faith-based organizations had tightened eligibility criteria for their
services -- far more than the 8.7 percent of their secular counterparts. In
Green county, Indiana, some churches are limiting help to members of their own
congregation, he said.

These trends have a familiar sound to American social welfare historians. In the
late 19th century, after public relief was drastically cut in an effort to end
"pauperism," private charity organization societies with the motto "not alms but
a friend" promoted investigations to curb the "unworthy" poor from seeking
multiple handouts and slipping back into dependency.

Then, as severe recessions hit, "scientific charity" came under attack. By the
early 20th century, many charity leaders agreed that more government help was
needed to relieve poverty rooted in ill health, low wages and economic
dislocation.

"In any business solution is embedded the next problem," Mr. Tichy said. "You
run a risk of creating a bureaucracy which becomes less human, less in touch
with what the vision of these agencies was. On the other hand, you have little
alternative."


http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: December 24, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

a Navajo reservation in New Mexico. (Associated Press)

                              341 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                The Toronto Star

                          December 14, 2005 Wednesday

WTO struggles for deal to help poorest countries

BYLINE: Richard Waddington, ; REUTERS NEWS AGENCY

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E08

LENGTH: 512 words

DATELINE: HONG KONG


Members of the World Trade Organization strove for a face-saving deal on special
help for poorest members today as tensions flared again in global talks to
reform world trade and lift millions out of poverty.

Negotiators worked through last night on details of a possible deal on duty and
quota-free access for goods from poor nations and other benefits, touted as
possibly the only realistic target of the WTO ministerial conference, being held
in Hong Kong until Sunday.

The ministerial meeting was initially intended to approve a draft free-trade
treaty, freeing up business in farm and industrial goods and services.

But the plan was postponed because differences between rich and developing
countries were too wide, particularly over agriculture, leaving a pact for the
poor the focus of attention.

But even as the conference began yesterday, transatlantic tensions between the
European Union and the United States over food aid, a contentious part of farm
exports, threatened to sour the mood.

"Last time it was development issues that caused the trouble when we were
looking for a deal on agriculture," said one Latin American diplomat. "I hope
that this time when we are trying something on development, it will not be
agriculture that causes the trouble."

The diplomat was referring to the last WTO ministerial meeting two years ago in
Cancun, Mexico, when developing countries brought talks to a halt before
negotiations on agriculture could begin in earnest.

The EU, under intense pressure at the WTO talks to open up its farm markets,
accuses the U.S. of using the food it buys from farmers to give away as aid as a
form of agricultural subsidy.

Brussels was incensed at a United Nations newspaper advertisement that said that
restrictions on donations of food to the UN could deprive hungry children.

"I find it shocking that UN agencies should be financing an advert ... designed
to support U.S. trade-distorting policies on food aid," said EU trade
commissioner Peter Mandelson.

U.S. trade representative Rob Portman said he did not understand the EU
"obsession" with food aid. His spokeswoman, Christin Baker, said Washington had
put forward a proposal to tighten food aid to ensure it does not skew local
commerce.

Hong Kong has mobilized thousands of police to contain any violence by
anti-global protestors and to prevent a repeat of the bloody clashes that marked
both the Cancun conference and its predecessor in Seattle two years earlier.

Nine people, including two police officers, were slightly hurt yesterday as
police used a skin-irritant spray to force back protestors.

Inside, dozens of protestors forced WTO director-general Pascal Lamy to raise
his voice as they chanted: "Development yes, Doha no.'"

Although the 149-state WTO has given up hope of a draft treaty in Hong Kong, it
still needs to agree enough to make a trade pact possible early next year.

The final deadline for the WTO's Doha round, launched in late 2001 with the
world still reeling from the Sept. 11 attacks, is 2006 or early 2007, but a
detailed blueprint must be ready well before then.

LOAD-DATE: December 14, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                      July 16, 1993, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Floods may wipe out US$2B in crops

BYLINE: Reuter

SECTION: SECTION 1, NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 303 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


The disastrous summer flood covering much of the Midwest will cause some US$2
billion in corn and soybean losses and ruin up to three million hectares of
crops, U.S. officials and economists said yesterday.

''Six to eight million acres of crops are under water, and we expect that most
of that will be a total loss,'' said Randy Weber, chief of the Agriculture
Department's Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service.

Norwest Corp. economist Sung Won Sohn estimated total crop damage in the five
states hardest hit by the wet weather at US$1.94 billion.

Sohn said Iowa would lose 20% of its soybeans and 10% of its corn for a total of
US$785 million.

Total damage and losses caused by the flood could approach US$5 billion, White
House budget director Leon Panetta said.

Weber said the lost acreage would be divided fairly evenly between corn and
soybeans.

''That area is essentially 50-50 corn and soybeans,'' he said after a briefing
with President Bill Clinton on the flood. ''With that amount of time it's been
under water you would have to believe that it would be lost.''

Farm state lawmakers have estimated that affected farmers could get disaster
relief worth less than US25 cents for each dollar of losses.

U.S. Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., said disaster aid would not be a windfall for
farmers because of provisions built into the aid program.

Losses are covered only if they exceed a threshold - a 35% or 40% loss - and
payments are calculated at two-thirds of a set price.

Under Clinton's disaster-relief plan, payments would be reduced further to
maintain parity with 1992 flood payment rates and to spread out the available
money to a larger coverage group.

As a result, Roberts said, farmers will get 21% to 24% of losses - ''a quarter
on the dollar.''

                               The New York Times

                           September 20, 2002 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

$752 Million In Aid Is Due For Farmers Hit by Drought

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 606 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19


The Bush administration said today that it would provide $752 million in
emergency aid for livestock producers in the West and elsewhere. The move could
aid a Republican Senate candidate as well as drought-stricken ranchers.

Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman announced the new relief program in a
teleconference with Representative John Thune, a South Dakota Republican who is
in one of the closest Senate races in the country with control of the chamber at
stake in November.

"This program will provide immediate assistance to producers who need it the
most," Ms. Veneman said.

The high-profile help from the White House underscored how the drought has
emerged as a political issue not only in South Dakota, but in other farm states
like Minnesota, Iowa and Missouri -- all sites of Senate races. But it has been
particularly prominent in South Dakota, where some ranchers have been selling
their herds because of the severe drought.

Mr. Thune has been somewhat on the defensive on the issue since President Bush
traveled to South Dakota last month and said he could not endorse new drought
help if it drove up the deficit.

Mr. Thune's opponent, Senator Tim Johnson, the Democratic incumbent, is seeking
$6 billion in relief that is tied up in the Senate. Mr. Johnson's campaign had
said Mr. Bush's position showed that Mr. Thune could not get the White House to
deliver and challenged Mr. Thune to back the Senate measure.

Mr. Thune said today that the new approach would bring help faster. "With
drought relief so uncertain in the Senate, I worked with the administration to
deliver critically needed cash assistance to livestock producers," he said.

Mr. Johnson and the majority leader Tom Daschle, the senior senator from South
Dakota, welcomed the new help, but they said it was not enough. "I hope the
administration understands that this assistance is merely a drop in the bucket,"
Mr. Daschle said. "Farmers and ranchers deserve more than a million-dollar
solution to a $6 billion problem."

Mr. Johnson noted that he had pressed for the release of the very money the
administration is using and said "every little bit helps."

"However, let me be clear, this money does not serve as a replacement for
emergency disaster assistance," he said.

The $752 million will come from unspent portions of a fund generated through
customs fees. Using those proceeds will allow Mr. Bush to say he provided some
help without new spending.

Ranchers can begin applying for the cash assistance on Oct. 1 and it will be
portioned out on a per-head basis, with $18 per beef cattle as a baseline.
Ranchers statewide in Arizona, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Dakota and
South Carolina will be eligible, as well as those in disaster-designated
counties of South Dakota and 29 other states.

The Senate last week added the $6 billion in emergency aid to the spending
measure for the Interior Department but it has stalled as both parties, in the
run-up to the November elections, have sought to deny each other any political
victories through the bill.

Much of this week has been devoted to a stalemate over $825 million in emergency
firefighting money and efforts by Republicans to attach a plan to thin national
forests to reduce the threat of fires. Environmental groups and some lawmakers
say the plan is tantamount to a broad change in policy that will expand
commercial logging on 10 million acres of national forest. Neither side has been
able to make headway.

The White House opposes the $6 billion in emergency drought aid but supporters
say its cost would be offset by savings in other farm spending, so it would not
drive up the deficit.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

(Associated Press)

                               The New York Times

               August 23, 1984, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

THE REGION;
Counties Eligible For Drought Aid

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section B; Page 2, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 126 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22


The Federal Agriculture Secretary, John Block, today named 32 counties in New
York and eight counties in three adjacent states eligible for emergency loans to
help farmers recover from last year's drought.

Secretary Block designated seven New York counties as core counties. They are
Broome, Chenango, Orange, Saratoga, Seneca, Washington and Yates. Because of
legislation enacted this year, 33 contiguous counties were added to the list,
stretching from the Adirondacks to nothern New Jersey and from central New York
and northern Pennsylvania to Vermont.

Eligible farmers may apply for loans with 5 percent interest on the first
$100,000 and 8 percent interest on additional amounts to cover losses between
June 1 through Nov. 1, 1983.

                                US Official News

                            December 9, 2016 Friday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S.
International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 277  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: 12-1NMP-17-S-0006

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: December 8, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation 12-1NMP-17-S-0006 (2000004456) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after December 8, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near December 20, 2016.

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

jessica.howlett@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 8169261109

                              348 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                   September 15, 1989, Friday, DAILY EDITION

Poland pork-aid news sends futures higher

BYLINE: Farm Market News

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20, FARM COMMODITIES

LENGTH: 268 words

DATELINE: Winnipeg,Man.


  News reports that the U.S. government is considering sending pork bellies to
Poland as part of an economic aid package sent hog and cattle futures prices
higher yesterday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

During the trading session, U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee Democratic
Chairman Patrick Leahy introduced a US$2.25-billion aid package to Poland that
included 20 million to 30 million pounds of U.S. pork bellies.

That news sent CME pork belly futures up as much as their US$2.00 daily limit
with the actively traded February contract up S2.00 at US$48.25 a hundredweight.

The daily limit is the maximum amount a futures contract can rise or fall in one
trading session and is set by the exchange.

The strength in pork belly futures spilled over to support CME live hog futures,
which ended the trading session US23 cents to US85 cents higher.

The most active contract was October, which gained US82 cents at US$42.12 a
hundredweight.

Higher prices being paid for hogs in U.S. cash markets also encouraged the
gains.

Traders expect deliveries of hogs to slaughterhouses to drop as the U.S. corn
harvest gets under way and farmers have no time to deliver.

Spillover enthusiasm from the pork pit caused CME live cattle futures to rally
as much as US50 cents per hundredweight. The benchmark October contract rose
US50 cents to US$72.52 a hundredweight.

Active buying by packing houses also led to the rally.

Traders indicated the recent drop in slaughter cattle and wholesale beef prices
caused aggressive buying by supermarkets across the U.S.

                              350 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           August 15, 2001 Wednesday

Farmers welcome federal relief; Emergency aid: The timing of the checks - during
fall harvest - is seen as being vital

BYLINE: JOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Pg. a1

LENGTH: 404 words


Area farmers are relieved to know they will receive some economic help this
fall.

For the fourth year in a row, the U.S. government will come to the rescue of
struggling farmers. President Bush signed a $$ @5.5 billion emergency farm aid
bill on Monday.

"That money is a welcome sight," said Belmont, Wis., farmer Art McNett.
"Whatever we can do to help agriculture helps the economy."

The measure Bush signed should boost net farm income to $$ @47.9 billion, the
highest level since 1997. Grain and cotton farmers, who receive the bulk of the
special assistance, will get smaller government checks than they saw under last
year's bailout. A farmer who got $$ @40,000 in 2000 should receive less than $$
@34,000 this year.

The president threatened to veto a more generous Senate bill that provided $$
@7.5 billion in farm assistance. That plan was championed by Senate Agriculture
Committee Chairman Tom Harkin, D-Iowa.

Dubuque County Farm Bureau President Steve Koch preferred to look at the final
outcome positively. Koch said that with farming's tight operating margins "every
little bit helps."

"I think any payment we get will be a help," Koch said. "If we did not take the
$$ @5.5 billion, we would get nothing. Really, this was the only way we were
going to get a payment by the end of September."

Timing of the aid was important, farmers said.

"As we go harvest, it would be money to buy fuel and inputs for next year's
crops," McNett said.

Still, some tri-state farmers might see only limited benefits from the aid
package because they grow crops, such as hay, not covered by the legislation.
Many local livestock producers will not directly benefit from the aid because
the subsidies do not cover livestock.

Low crop prices have persisted for four years, prompting the government aid.
Soybean prices are expected to remain low as farmers harvest a record large
crop.

"It would be nice to see higher prices in the market," said McNett, who
represents Wisconsin on the United Soybean Board, the farmer organization that
promotes soybean use. McNett is hopeful the group can increase industrial use of
corn and soybeans. Increased use of alternative fuels, such as ethanol and
biodiesel, could raise commodity prices while reducing government farm
subsidies, he said.

"That's one avenue where we maybe can increase demand for corn and soybeans," he
said.

LOAD-DATE: August 15, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2001 Woodward Communications, Inc.

                              351 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 21, 1983, Friday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. CORN SOUGHT IN DROUGHT RELIEF

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 801 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 20


Devastated by a drought, ranchers and poultrymen across the South and West are
bringing increasing pressure on the Reagan Administration to release stored
grains that they contend are needed to save livestock from starvation or early
slaughter.

So far, the Government has refused, saying there is no way to provide surplus
grain selectively to severely drought-plagued areas without providing the same
aid to all ranchers.

Texas agriculture officials maintain that 22.6 million bushels of surplus corn,
enough to feed starving Texas cattle for 300 days, lies molding in a Government
warehouse at a cost to taxpayers of $500,000 a month.

''That corn is going to hell when it ought to be going to West Texas,'' the
state Agriculture Commissioner, Jim Hightower, said,

Although the sharpest criticism of the Government's refusal to release stored
grain comes from Texas, other drought-ridden states have also lodged pleas for
release of the grain.

States Pressing for Grain

Among them are Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, South
Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia. New Mexico has offered to join Texas in
pressing for release of the grain.

In Washington, meanwhile, both the House Agriculture Committee and the full
Senate have approved legislation that would force emergency feed measures.

By a vote of 28 to 9 on Wednesday, the House committee approved a measure that
would require Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block to provide $500 million in
feed assistance. The assistance would come either in the form of sales of grain
from Government granaries like that at Plainview, Tex., where the 22.6 million
bushels are stored, or in direct assistance to ranchers and poultrymen to
maintain their herds and flocks.

The action followed a similar emergency feed provision approved earlier by the
Senate. That measure, an amendment to dairy and tobacco legislation offered by
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, would compel the sale of 80 million bushels of
poorer grade corn, not used for human consumption, at reduced prices to ranchers
and poultry raisers in drought disaster areas.

Fear Voiced on Problem

Despite some sincere efforts, said Representative Ed Jones, Democrat of
Tennessee who is chairman of the subcommittee that first considered the House
feed bill, ''not nearly enough has been done or is going to be done.''

The Administration has also been prodded by the Southern Governors Conference,
which met last month in Austin and adopted a resolution calling for release of
the feed grain and greatly expanded Federal aid.

However, the sharpest assault on the Government's refusal to release disaster
relief feed corn came in the form of the assertion by Texas agriculture
officials that it had misrepresented the quality of corn stored at Plainview.

Texas officials said they had been told that the stored corn at Plainview was of
good quality and therefore too valuable to release as livestock food.

However, both Commissioner Hightower and Gov. Mark White maintained that corn
growers themselves had said the corn was poor quality and should be released.

According to its own analysis of 86 samples drawn from the storage bins,
performed by an outside laboratory, Mr. Hightower reported that ''the corn not
only is of low quality, but actually is in much worse shape that we had
suspected.''

Analysis of Corn Cited

He said the laboratory analysis had shown that, of the 22,660,215 bushels stored
in one large warehouse, 77 percent had ''seriously deteriorated'' and that 53
percent was now below the quality deemed adequate for human consumption.

''A lot of it is much worse off than that,'' Mr. Hightower said in a statement.
''It's moldy, its musty, it's weevilly. A great deal of it is no longer even fit
to feed to sheep or goats - the only thing it can still be used for is cattle
feed, and some of it won't be fit to use as anything but filler by the time the
winter's over.''

In a telephone interview from Washington, Richard Goldberg, the the Deputy Under
Secretary of Agriculture responsible for the commodity program, said that the
results of the state sampling conflicted with a similar one conducted by the
storage warehouse operator, who stores the grain under Government contract. That
sampling, also based on 86 batches, showed the stored corn to be of good
quality, he said.

''But as far as we are concerned,'' he said, ''neither inspection was
official.'' He said the Agriculture Department's own records indicated that the
stored corn had not deteriorated.

Mr. Goldberg also noted that when the corn was first stored in January 1981, as
excess commodity, 732,000 of the bushels were shown as ''sample grade,'' the
lowest quality grade, broken kernels, dust and foreign materials.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
