                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                November 20, 1993, SATURDAY, THREE STAR Edition

MIDWEST GETS BOOST IN LEVEE AID

BYLINE: Robert L. Koenig Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1307 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Flood-gouged levees in the Midwest got an extra $ 18 million in repair aid
Friday, while a separate federal action pumped up efforts to expand wetlands in
flood-prone areas.

Those responses to the Flood of '93 came as Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, who
heads the flood-recovery effort, planned a trip Monday to meet with farmers in
Missouri and Illinois and to tour flood-stricken Valmeyer, lll. The city plans
to move to higher ground.

Meanwhile, Congress appeared poised to approve na bill this weekend to quadruple
buyout money for flooded communities. The Federal Emergency Management Agency
planned a "major announcement" next week on new guidelines for flood relocations
in the Midwest.

"We are taking a look at the entire flood-plain management system in the
Midwest," said FEMA's chief spokesman, Morrie Goodman.

As part of that analysis, the federal interagency group on Midwest flood
recovery decided Friday to earmark an extra $ 18 million to help repair levees
that are ineligible for aid from the Army Corps of Engineers but protect key
roads or buildings and have a public sponsor.

The extra money for levee repair will be taken from emergency flood aid that had
been allotted to the Economic Development Administration for jobs programs. The
new money comes in addition to $ 180 million appropriated last summer for the
corps' levee-aid program.

The new levee money - a compromise between previous plans for no aid for
ineligible levees and the demands of some Missouri officials for $ 100 million
in extra aid - managed to anger both sides in the debate: environmentalists and
pro-levee politicians.

Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., said through a spokeswoman that the extra $ 18
million is "woefully inadequate" to help rebuild the 355 ineligible levees along
the lower Missouri River "in time to prevent spring flooding from causing great
damage in Missouri."

Meanwhile, the American Rivers conservation group, which opposed federal aid for
ineligible rural levees, denounced the new levee rules as a "flip-flop" by
President Bill Clinton's administration, which also is promoting alternatives to
repairing some levees.

"We are repeating the mistakes of the past," said Scott Faber, who directs the
group's flood-plain management programs. He argued that helping to repair
ineligible levees is unfair and "removes incentives to properly construct and
maintain levees in the future."

Goodman, the FEMA spokesman, argued that the new levee rules "are absolutely not
a reversal. This would only help levees that protect significant public property
in the Midwest."

On the same day it moved to rebuild many levees, the administration also
released new rules that aim to make it simpler for farmers to convert
flood-damaged land to wetlands.

Espy's top flood aide, Oleta Fitzgerald, said the new regulations for the
Emergency Wetlands Reserve Programs b "will make it easier for some farmers who
want to get out of the flood plain, and to recover losses."

This week, the Agriculture Department confirmed plans to use $ 15 million in
emergency flood-aid money to buy flooded land suitable for conversion of
wetlands from farmers wwilling to sell.

But Rep. Richard J. Durbin, D-Ill., chairman of the House farm appropriations
subcommittee, urged Espy on Friday to allow Midwestern farmers to enroll flooded
cropland in the wetlands program. Under the current system, most cropland is
ineligible fbecause it is deemed unsuitable for conversion.  Durbin said the
flood destroyed about 10 percent of the million acres of wetlands in Illinois.
He argued that adding some flooded farmland to the wetands program "will help
farmers who are trying to get back on their feet, and will also help protect the
environment."

The flurry of federal actions Friday came as agriculture officials from
Missouri, Illinois and Iowa appealed to a House committee for more help.

"The nation's agricultural heartland experienced its worst flooding in history"
this year, said Kyle Vickers, deputy director of the Missouri Department of
Agriculture.

"Delayed planting, poor seasonal growing conditions, cropland erosion, flooded
fields and an early fall freeze have . . . tleft farmers facing economic and
natural hardships previously unimagined."

Vickers called for a major expansion of the emergency wetlands program in a way
that would make it easier for farmers to convert flooded cropland. He also urged
a big increase in federal aid to repair farm levees and clear massive amounts of
silt and debris.

Missouri officials said the state's farmers already have applied for more than $
38 million in aid under the Emergency Conservation Reserve program to repair
flood damage. They have received only $ 9 million in aid, they said.

Even so, federal officials said Missouri farmers rank first in flood aid among
the nine affected Midwestern states. Iowa farmers have got $ 7 million, Illinois
farmers $ 3.7 million.

LANGUAGE: English

Valentine. The man took in the elk, which was in ill health last year, and now
it hangs around the ranch. The elk plays fetch with the man's hat and follows

                                The Toronto Star

                            July 5, 1993, Monday, PM

Clinton promises Mississippi states more flood aid

BYLINE: (Special)(CHICAGO TRIBUNE )

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 471 words

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill.


   MOLINE, Ill. (Special) - U.S. President Bill Clinton inspected flood-damaged
areas of Illinois and Iowa yesterday, pledging to release nearly $300 million in
additional disaster funds.

He also promised to ask Congress to approve even more aid to flood victims.

As the National Guard and others continued efforts to contain the swollen
Mississippi River, Clinton stopped here to view firsthand the results of the
worst flood in more than 100 years.

Seated on bales of hay in a farm yard, Clinton and Agriculture Secretary Mike
Espy met with about 150 farmers and business owners at a farm owned by Don and
Elaine Schneckloth in Eldridge, Iowa, near Davenport, where flood damage has
been particularly severe.

"I know what you're going through," Clinton told them, recalling the time floods
ravaged property in his home state of Arkansas.

Clinton, who signed legislation Friday releasing $100 million in federal
disaster aid funds, said he would soon sign a bill freeing an additional $297
million.

Even that won't be enough to offset flood-induced losses, said Clinton, in
calling for a bill appropriating additional disaster aid funds. He estimated
flood-induced damage in Iow, Illinois, Missouri, Minnesota and Wisconsin at $1
billion, but didn't specify how much additional aid he would seek from Congress.

However, he said farmers and others hit by flooding would be eligible for the
same level of federal assistance extended to victims of Hurricane Andrew in
Florida last year.

Espy, in response to a question, said he expected the administration would have
to ask for at least an additional $850 million in relief.

Clinton said the aid would not add to the deficit and would not mean new taxes.

The president also said he would direct Espy to come up with a bill to reform
the federal crop insurance program to make it simpler and more fair. Currently,
farmers who can't plant their fields because of flooding or other natural
disasters don't qualify for compensation.

Clinton got a birds-eye view of flooded fields, homes and businesses as he flew
over the area in Air Force One.

"I've seen a lot of it in my life, but it is about as bad as it gets," Clinton
told reporters.

In the worst areas, farm houses looked like soggy islands dotting the river.
Flooded-out roads disappeared into the muddy river like boat launching ramps.
Dozens of idled barges were tied up along the way, unable to carry their loads
downstream.

Flooding brought on by heavy rains has affected 800 kilometres (500 miles) of
the Mississippi stretching from Minnesota to Missouri. In Davenport alone, where
city officials refused to build the type of flood control facilities other river
towns have constructed, Mayor Pat Gibbs estimated damage at $100 million.

CHICAGO TRIBUNE

LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999

                          The Modesto Bee (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune News Service

                            August 3, 2006 Thursday

Governor requesting federal aid for farmers: Letter asks USDA to help as farmers
try to cope with $1B in losses from heat

BYLINE: John Holland, The Modesto Bee, Calif.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 691 words


Aug. 3--The state has primed the pump for possible federal aid to heat-ravaged
farms, but how much money could flow is unknown.

Gov. Schwarzenegger has sent a letter asking for a disaster declaration by the
U.S. Department of Agriculture, said A.G. Kawamura, the governor's food and
agriculture secretary.

Kawamura has heard reports that as much as $1 billion in farm production was
lost to the extreme temperatures of middle and late July, he said. The state's
farmers had an estimated $32 billion in gross income in 2004.

In a conference call with reporters Wednesday, Kawamura said dairies, poultry
farms and growers of tomatoes, walnuts, peaches and a few other crops were
especially hard hit.

"The damage across the whole array of agriculture is significant," he said.

The letter went to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns, who could make aid
available to affected farmers by declaring a disaster. The amounts would be
based on damage assessments being done by agricultural commissioners in affected
areas, including the Northern San Joaquin Valley.

While no final figures have been determined for Stanislaus, San Joaquin and
Merced counties, officials expect them to be staggering, with dairy production
lagging for up to nine months as herds struggle to regain output.

Western United Dairymen, based in Modesto, is urging its members to report
losses so that federal aid can start.

"The economic repercussions of the heat experienced in the past few weeks are
widespread and will be felt by California's dairy farm families for many months
to come," said Michael Marsh, the group's chief executive officer, in a letter
to Schwarzenegger.

"In certain areas, you may see price spikes (for consumers) because of
shortages," he said.

Schwarzenegger paid a visit to Fresno County on Wednesday, touring a Selma dairy
to see firsthand how farmers are coping.

He told them he has asked the USDA to start processing the request disaster
assistance before a final damage report is compiled.

Only now are agricultural officials coming up with statistics. Losses in Fresno
County for beef, turkeys, chickens and dairy animals, as well as milk
production, was calculated at nearly $85 million.

Dennis Plann, deputy agricultural commissioner for Fresno County, said $73
million of that figure is from lost milk production. Some 58,000 turkeys and
270,000 chickens are believed to have died as a result of the heat wave.

Plann, who has been with the agriculture department for 34 years, said it was
the greatest loss for dairy operators that he has seen.

Documenting losses proved challenging. Many farmers buried or composted cows --
a practice allowed by temporary emergency action -- and the industry is relying
on ranchers and dairy operators to disclose details on those deaths.

As for crop loss, in the words of Tulare County Assistant Agricultural
Commissioner Bill Appleby, "it's not like hail damage, where you can go out and
see it. Some you might not see until harvest, because there may be internal
damage."

Perhaps hardest hit were processing tomatoes. Industry leaders say those losses
could run into the millions. One West Side grower, Matt Diener of Five Points,
put his loss on one field at more than $450,000.

Some walnuts may have been sunburned, but industry leaders are saying it is not
as severe as initially thought.

"We can't see the nuts that are on the top from the ground," said Doug Verboon,
a Hanford grower. "Won't know about those until the harvest."

Some growers took the precaution of applying a white-colored compound called
Surround that may keep the trees and nuts cooler.

"It's acts like a sun screen," said Doug Wisecarver, a Hanford grower who used
the material. "I don't have any damage at all," he said.

Bee staff writer John Holland can be reached at 578-2385 or jholland@modbee.com.

The Fresno Bee contributed to this report.

Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                            Healthy Future Group LLC

                        9950 W Boonville New Harmony Rd

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      MAY 22, 2003 Thursday CITY-D EDITION

Bush slams Europe's policies on AIDS and famine in Africa

BYLINE: Ron Hutcheson INQUIRER WASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A18

LENGTH: 755 words

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn.


President Bush took the offensive against America's prickliest foreign allies
yesterday, accusing European nations of hindering the fight against famine and
not doing enough to combat AIDS.

The tough talk, a week before Bush meets with European leaders in France at a
summit of major industrialized nations, signaled he was not ready to soothe hard
feelings over his handling of the war with Iraq. Relations with France and
Germany are still rocky, and polls indicate that anti-American sentiment is
strong in Europe.

Without mentioning any specific countries, Bush challenged European leaders to
follow his lead in spending more to fight AIDS in Africa. The House of
Representatives gave final approval yesterday to Bush's $15 billion, five-year
plan for AIDS research and treatment in Africa and the Caribbean.

In a commencement speech at the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, Bush said he intended
to remind European leaders that "the clock is ticking" on AIDS and urge them to
"match their good intentions with real resources." The annual Group of Eight
summit brings together leaders from the United States, Canada, France, Germany,
Britain, Italy, Russia and Japan.

In Washington, one European Union official, who asked not to be identified
because he was not authorized to quarrel publicly with Bush, expressed dismay.
"We've been involved in development in Africa for a long time, and I think we
are probably the major donor of all forms of aid to Africa," the official said.

Bush used harsher language in criticizing European agriculture policies,
asserting that European opposition to genetically engineered crops could prolong
famine in Africa.

The European Union has banned the importation of genetically altered crops -
soybeans, corn and other plants that have been altered to thwart pests and
disease - because of health and environmental concerns that Washington contends
are groundless.

U.S. agriculture companies have taken the lead in biotechnology, and the United
States filed papers last week asking the World Trade Organization to declare the
ban illegal.

Advocates of genetic engineering say it can help end famine by dramatically
increasing crop yields, but many developing nations are reluctant to accept
genetically modified grain or to plant it themselves for fear that they would be
unable to export their agricultural products.

"We have the ability to confront this suffering. . . . Yet our partners in
Europe are hindering this effort," Bush said, adding that Europe's concerns
stemmed from "unfounded, unscientific fears."

The EU official said European governments did not counsel African nations about
importing genetically modified food: "As far as GM food imports, it's up to the
countries in Africa to decide what they want. Mixing up the issue with the GM
stuff is not really honest."

As for Bush's combative tone, the EU official said: "My personal reaction is
that it's not uncommon, even in this age of television, for people to speak to
one audience and think another audience is not listening. It wouldn't surprise
me if he takes a much more diplomatic line next week. Still, there is a tendency
for Europe-bashing, and it's annoying."

Bush also criticized European agricultural subsidies, a long-standing source of
friction between the United States and France, in particular.

"When wealthy nations subsidize their agricultural exports, it prevents poor
countries from developing their own agricultural sectors," Bush said, calling on
"our partners in Europe" to "immediately eliminate subsidies" on agricultural
exports to developing nations.

His tone signaled to European leaders that if there were fences to mend, it was
up to them to make the first move. Focusing on AIDS and agriculture also might
help the President head off attempts by his critics to turn next week's summit
into a debate over dealing with postwar Iraq.

But Bush's remarks were almost sure to offend Europeans who consider him a
swaggering bully and resent Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's dismissal of
some of them as "old Europe."

Later yesterday, Bush headlined a $22 million fund-raising gala in Washington
for GOP Senate and House candidates.

The Washington Convention Center event was the closest any political party has
come to matching the record $30 million-plus that Bush helped raise at each of
two galas last spring.

Contact reporter Ron Hutcheson at 202-383-6101 or rhutcheson@krwashington.com.

The Associated Press also contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: July 28, 2005

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 2, 2010 Saturday

BRIEF: Federal disaster aid OK'd for area farmers

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 163 words


Oct. 02--Farmers in 16 northwest Ohio counties are eligible for federal disaster
aid, Gov. Ted Strickland's office said.

The counties are Lucas, Wood, Ottawa, Fulton, Hancock, Defiance, Erie, Henry,
Hardin, Paulding, Putnam, Sandusky, Seneca, Van Wert, Williams, and Wyandot.

The disaster aid, from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, is in the form of
emergency loans and assistance payments. It is intended to help offset losses
from rain, flooding, high winds, hail, tornadoes, drought, freeze, and frost
incurred from April 1 through Aug. 3.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   April 9, 2001, Monday, THREE STAR EDITION

NATION BRIEFS

BYLINE: From News ServicesNATIONAL NEWS; CURRENT AFFAIRS

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A4

LENGTH: 623 words



EAST

WASHINGTON

White House plans new AIDS office, official says

President George W. Bush will soon announce a reorganized White House AIDS
office that will tie efforts to combat the disease to a key domestic policy team
and two Cabinet agencies, an administration official said Sunday.

The Office of National AIDS Policy will be led by a director who is a member of
the White House Domestic Policy Council, said the official, who insisted on
anonymity. It will also include one staff member from the State Department and
another from the Department of Health and Human Services.

Adding a State Department staff member would mark an expansion of the AIDS
office's structure under President Bill Clinton, the official said. That person
would work to address AIDS-related issues overseas, particularly in Africa.

In addition, Secretary of State Colin Powell and Health and Human Services
Secretary Tommy Thompson will head an AIDS task force that Clinton created, the
official said.

Bush was to announce the AIDS efforts, and who will head the Office of National
AIDS policy, in the near future, the official said.

WEST

LOS ANGELES

Mayoral candidates set campaign spending record

The six leading candidates in the race to be mayor of the nation's
second-largest city have broken a spending record in hopes of winning Tuesday's
election.

Led by the apparent front-runners - City Attorney James Hahn, businessman Steve
Soboroff and former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa - the six major
candidates had collected more than $ 17 million as of Wednesday. The old record
for the mayor's race was $ 12.9 million, set in 1993.

The lavish spending illustrates the challenge of running for citywide office in
Los Angeles. If no candidate gets more than 50 percent of Tuesday's vote, the
top two will meet in a June 5 runoff.

Mayor Richard Riordan, a Republican, is being forced out by term limits after
eight years in office.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo.

Widely banned poison kills animals in town

A poison so deadly that it is banned in all but four states has killed 30 dogs
and cats and 35 birds in a small neighborhood in Orchard Mesa outside Grand
Junction, police say. The poison even sickened a police officer who handled a
stricken dog; he was ill for 10 days.

Police said Thursday that veterinary experts at Texas A&M University identified
the poison as sodium monofluoroacetate, also known as Compound 1080. The
compound was used in the West for predator control until it was banned in 1972.

The poison was banned because it continued through the food chain, killing
birds, coyotes, eagles, bears and others that came in contact with the targeted
animal.

The substance is allowed in diluted use only in Idaho, Montana, Nevada and
Wyoming, where it is tightly controlled by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

CAMARILLO, Calif.

Gasoline prices are up nationwide, survey says

Gasoline prices at the pump shot up 7 cents in the past two weeks, the first
such rise since early January, an oil industry analyst said Sunday.

The price increase was due mainly to seasonal demand, said analyst Trilby
Lundberg.

The average price of gasoline was about $ 1.54 a gallon, up 7.1 cents from March
23, according to the Lundberg Survey of 8,000 stations nationwide.

Prices had fallen more than 5 cents a gallon since Jan. 15 as the winter season
reduced driving, which in turn reduced the demand for gasoline.

Refineries are also beginning to shift production to special environmentally
friendly formulas required in some states. That, plus a routine decrease in
refining capacity because of scheduled maintenance, also contributed to the
price rise.

LOAD-DATE: April 10, 2001

LANGUAGE: English

TYPE: Nation Briefs Column

                                The Irish Times

                               November 12, 2001

Walsh prepared to veto WTO deal
Minister says EU must not give way to US demands to drop export subsidies and
direct income support

BYLINE: By DENIS STAUNTON

SECTION: CITY EDITION; BUSINESS AND FINANCE; WTO SUMMIT IN DOHA; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 515 words

DATELINE: DOHA


The Minister for Agriculture, Mr Walsh, has warned that he will block the launch
of any new trade round that commits the EU to eliminating or phasing out
subsidies to farmers.

In Doha, where he is attending a Ministerial Conference of the World Trade
Organisation (WTO), Mr Walsh said the EU must not budge in its opposition to
demands from the US and other countries that export subsidies and direct income
support should be phased out.

He said: "It is no more acceptable today than it was two years ago in Seattle.
It is unacceptable."

Failure to agree on farm subsidies was among the reasons the last attempt to
launch a trade round failed in Seattle in 1999.

The European Commission has a mandate to negotiate on behalf of the EU on the
basis of positions agreed between the 15 member-states. The mandate includes a
commitment to reject an agreement that obliges the EU to reduce subsidies with a
view to phasing out or eliminating them.

But some member-states, including the Nordic countries and Britain, have
indicated that they are willing to compromise on agriculture to secure a deal on
other issues.

Only Ireland and France have stated that there is no room for compromise on
subsidies to farmers, an issue that the French trade minister, Mr Francois
Huwart, said could prevent a trade round being launched. "It is a breaking point
with great consequences," he said.

According to sources close to the talks, Mr Huwart made clear to other EU
ministers that he has instructions from both President Jacques Chirac and the
Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Jospin, not to compromise on agriculture.

The EU cannot accept a deal in Doha unless all 15 member-states agree to it.

Mr Walsh pointed out that direct payments account for 60 per cent of the average
Irish farmers' income. As a state that exports one third of its agricultural
produce outside the EU, Ireland has an important interest in retaining export
refunds, he said.

He insisted that agreement was possible in Doha without changing the EU's
position on agriculture, which has taken the member-states two years to agree.

"There is no reason why agriculture should be made a sacrificial lamb for a new
trade round."

There were signs yesterday that the WTO meeting was nearing agreement on the
issue of access to medicines for poorer countries. The 142 countries are
expected to agree to a declaration asserting that WTO patent protection rules
should not prevent countries from protecting public health.

Poorer countries want to be allowed to produce and import cheap, generic
versions of expensive drugs, particularly treatments for HIV and Aids. Other
contentious issues include an EU demand that environmental standards should play
a role in any new trade round.

The EU has already signalled that it is prepared to abandon a call for
investment and competition to play a role in the trade round.

But Mr Walsh was adamant that there would be no deviation from the agreed EU
line on agriculture. "I'm here to ensure that the European Commission's mandate
is strictly adhered to," he said.

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2001 The Irish Times

                              363 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  May 1, 1983, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE RELIEF MAY BE BRIEF FOR SMALL FARMS

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1048 words

DATELINE: JEFFERSON, Iowa


As the Reagan Administration's new payment in kind and acreage reduction
programs are edging into place in the rain-sodden South and Middle West, a
wide-ranging debate is getting under way. It involves questions about which
types of farmers will ultimately be helped the most, how much the farm supply
merchants will be hurt, and what, if anything, the nonplanting of so much grain
and cotton land will do to retail food supplies.

Here in central Iowa, in one of the greatest grain producing areas in the world,
nearly 70 percent of the farmers are committed to not planting some portion of
the acres on which they usually grow corn.  In the rich winter-planted wheat
areas of Kansas, 29 percent of the land that is normally devoted to this crop
will not be harvested. In the cotton belts of Texas and the South, 44 percent of
the cotton land won't be planted this spring.

In return, at harvest time, these farmers will be given grains and cotton now
controlled by the Agriculture Department, which they may sell or store while
they wait for better prices. In addition, they will get cash payments early next
year for what they would have grown on 10 percent of their land usually planted
in these crops.

Most authorities agree that the principal cause of the current farm recession,
the worst since the 1930's, is the huge surplus of grains and cotton that has
piled up during the past two record breaking crop years. By paying farmers in
cash and in kind to leave idle 36 percent of their wheat, corn, rice and cotton
land, the Administration hopes the 1983 crops will be smaller and 1984 farm
prices will be be higher. Meanwhile, the Government will be transferring to the
farmers the commodities it now holds as collateral for three years of price
support loans.

There are no doubts that the new payment in kind and acreage reduction plans
will provide some help, in the long run, for the larger family farmers. They
will be of even more assistance to the tiny number of large corporately owned
farms, because the $50,000 limit on Government aid has been removed from the
p.i.k. program.

But there seems to be more doubt about what all this will do for the smaller
family farm operators, who have been in bigger money trouble than their larger,
better financed competitors.

William Lesher, the Agriculture Department's chief economist, says his agency
believes the new programs will keep many small farmers in business another year
or two ''until things turn around.''

''It's going to give them some badly needed credit,'' he said.  ''It's also
going to assure them a little cash after harvest, no matter what the weather
does. And some will not have to borrow as much this year because they aren't
going to plant as much.''

John Schnittker, a former Assistant Agriculture Secretary and now a private farm
consultant in Washington, was not so sure. ''There is not much change in all
this from past commodity aid programs,'' he said. ''The old ones have always
helped the big family farmers the most, even though the Congressional rhetoric
says they are designed to bail out the small ones. There is a strong tide in all
these plans against the small farmer. Since the benefits in these new ones, like
the old ones, are based on the volume of production, the big family farmers,
once again, will benefit the most.''

Rarely do members of the House or Senate miss a chance to warn that family farms
are facing extinction or to demand that new steps be taken immediately to
preserve these hallowed examples of American enterprise and probity. Actually,
family-owned farms constitute more than 99 percent of the 2.4 American farms now
being tilled. Most of the less than 1 percent that are corporately owned are
included among the large citrus and vegetable farms in Florida and California
and the large cotton and rice farms in California.

Certainly the number of family farms has been declining steadily since the
1950's. But as their owners sold out and took jobs in town, their neighbors,
family farmers too, have bought up their land. As these operations have been
expanded, a smaller number of family farmers have been producing ever larger
portions of the country's food and fibre. Last year, 12 percent of this
country's farmers produced 68 percent of all farm commodities and profited
proportionately.

While few of them believed the new farm programs would do much in the next two
years to reduce the surpluses, many family farmers, large and small, and their
suppliers, seem certain that the rural economy is already getting a lift from
the knowledge that there will be cash, or its in-kind equivalent, coming in this
fall, regardless of what the weather or markets do to them. There's also the
money they're saving by not planting.

''At the moment, this is all more psychological than real,'' said Max Naylor,
one of this area's more skilled grain growers. ''But the prospect of guaranteed
cash later is improving farmers' credit ratings already and it could help bail
out some of the 5 percent or so of the farmers around here who are in bad money
trouble right now.''

The improved outlook, said Cecil Alvis, vice president of the Moultrie National
Bank, ''won't be near as much as the bigger farmers will get. But we're sort of
riding a little optimism here on the perception that Reagan is finally trying to
do something for the farmers.'' In southern Georgia, where the family-operated
cotton, corn, tobacco and peanut farms are a third the size of the grain farms
in the Middle West, the drought has ended and many of the small farmers are
participating in the new programs.

The abnormally wet spring, in general, has helped corn and cotton growers. The
winter-planted wheat is said to be in excellent condition and, despite the
reduction in harvested acres, the forecasters are expecting, at the least, a
crop of more than 2 billion bushels. This would be smaller than the 2.7 billion
grown last year but still the fourth largest on record.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: graph showing statistical variations in farm size, no.,
& total acreage

                              364 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            February 23, 2004 Monday

Hefty farm-aid package planned;
Signalling return to governing agenda, Martin to move on help for mad-cow crisis

BYLINE: DREW FAGAN, OTTAWA BUREAU CHIEF

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 592 words


Ottawa is expected to soon announce additional assistance worth hundreds of
millions of dollars for farmers hurt by the mad-cow crisis, in another sign that
the Martin government is intent on getting back to a governing agenda after
being immersed for two weeks in controversy over the sponsorship scandal.

Government sources said yesterday that the aid package - worth well over
$300-million - likely will be approved by the federal cabinet this week and
announced within 10 days. In a swing through Manitoba and Saskatchewan last
Friday, Prime Minister Paul Martin hinted that Ottawa is intent on doing more
for beef farmers, who have been suffering since last spring when the critical
U.S. market was closed to them because of a single case of bovine spongiform
encephalopathy, or BSE, found on an Alberta farm.

"Governments are going to have to help our beef producers," Mr. Martin said.

At a cabinet meeting last Thursday, officials say, Mr. Martin called on
ministers to bring forward policy initiatives that might have lagged lately
because of the focus on the sponsorship scandal.

The Prime Minister's appeal came one day after Liberal MPs had suggested as much
to him.

"Everything is geared on getting back to an agenda," a senior federal official
said. "I think you are seeing everything moved up."

Agriculture Minister Bob Speller has been pressing for new federal aid for
farmers, although it remains unclear whether the provinces will be willing to
provide funding of their own.

The previous Chrétien government spent more than $400-million on aid programs
nationwide, an amount roughly equal to what the Alberta government says it spent
on its own.

Alberta now wants Ottawa to be more generous as the crisis drags on, and
suggests it is tapped out.

The aid package provided by former agriculture minister Lyle Vanclief last year
was meant to provide farmers with short-term "transitional" payments to get them
over a hump caused by the border closing last May.

The border was reopened to beef exports last fall, and it appeared late last
year as if the U.S. government was about to allow most Canadian cattle exports
to recommence in early 2004.

But the discovery in early January that a cow in Washington state that had
tested positive for BSE originated in Alberta put an indefinite delay on
cross-border cattle shipments.

The chief veterinarian for the U.S. Agriculture Department said earlier this
month that the border likely would not reopen to Canadian cattle until at least
the summer.

A Canadian official said yesterday that, before the discovery of the cow in
Washington state, Ottawa had expected the border to reopen to most cattle by
late February or early March.

The original aid package had been aimed at helping farmers until as late as
August, since it was designed to ensure that all farmers didn't rush to sell
their cattle in the United States as soon as the border reopened - and possibly
cause a sudden drop in prices received at home.

The first package is no longer adequate, the official suggested, since there is
now no sign that the border will open soon.

The U.S. Agriculture Department is expected to take a small step in this
direction later this week when it asks for comments from interested U.S. parties
about whether it should reverse the trade ban.

But few Canadian officials expect that the commentary process will significantly
bolster their case that the industries on both sides of the border are
intimately linked and that it makes little sense to artificially divide the
marketplace.

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Aid, First Aid Kits, Garages, Grasses, Sheds, and 8 other Product & Service
categories tracked by NetWise Data. Salem Housing Community Development
Corporation does business in the Agriculture, Architecture, and Automotive
Industries, as well as 12 other major Manufacturing Industries. Salem Housing
Community Development Corporation has at least 2 business locations. The company
describes itself via it's website thusly: "Salem Housing - Building Stronger
Communities Through Homeownership - Flint, Michigan"

                                     Agweek

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune News Service

                             August 1, 2006 Tuesday

Johnson, Gabriel team up for resolution

BYLINE: Kelly Stone, Agweek Magazine

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 416 words


Aug. 1--North Dakota's agriculture commissioner had a hand in creating two
resolutions that were approved last week by the Midwest Association of State
Departments of Agriculture.

The first resolution urges Congress, the president and the U.S. Agriculture
Department to "move rapidly to implement disaster legislation to provide
financial assistance to producers affected by drought and other adverse weather
conditions covering the 2005 and 2006 crop years."

Roger Johnson introduced the bill jointly with South Dakota Agriculture
Commissioner Larry Gabriel.

"Larry and I are really good friends," Johnson says. "He's a Republican and I'm
a Democrat, and we have philosophical differences, but not on disaster relief."

Johnson says he's pleased that the resolution not only had bipartisan support
from MASDA, but passed unanimously.

Ironically, neither Johnson nor Gabriel were at the meeting in Madison, Wis.,
when the disaster resolution was introduced and brought to vote.

Both were back in their home states monitoring wildfires made worse by extremely
dry conditions.

As for the impact that resolution actually will have on Congress and the White
House, Johnson says, "it's hard to say, but I know if we're going to get it
passed, we're going to have to put enormous pressure on from every direction we
can.

"If you want something to move through the Legislature, especially at the
national level, you've got to come at it from as many directions as possible."

MASDA members also approved Johnson's resolution supporting a "25x25" energy
initiative. It calls for America's working lands to provide 25 percent of all
the energy consumed in the United States by the year 2025.

"I'm big on setting goals because you make more progress when you say this is
what you want to do, rather than just stumbling along," Johnson says.

"Renewable energy has enormous profit potential for agriculture, and North
Dakota is as well positioned as any other state in the country to take advantage
of that."

The MASDA meeting concluded July 25. The National Association of State
Departments of Agriculture meets Sept. 15 to 20 in Norfolk, Va.

To see more of Agweek, or to subscribe to the magazine, go to
http://www.agweek.com. Copyright (c) 2006, Agweek Magazine Distributed by

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                               The New York Times

              February 26, 1985, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

SENATE DEMOCRATS PROPOSE FARM CREDIT PLAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN V. ROBERTS

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 808 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25


Senate Democrats pressed forward today with their courting of farm state voters
as they proposed two amendments that would make it easier for farmers to obtain
loans in time for spring planting.

The Democrats are trying to attach their amendments to legislation providing
$175 million in nonfood aid for African countries stricken by famine. If their
proposals are accepted, the Democrats reason, they would likely become law
because President Reagan would have trouble vetoing the popular African relief
bill.

The amendments advanced today were part of a deal struck Saturday between
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and farm state Democrats who
were filibustering against the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General.
The Democrats dropped their filibuster when the Administration promised to make
existing loan programs easier to use; in addition, the Republican leadership
agreed to allow Democrats to offer additional credit measures as amendments to
the African aid bill.

The amendments include proposals to subsidize interest rates on farm loans and
to pay farmers this spring money they would normally not receive until fall.

Opposition From Dole

Senator Dole strongly opposed the Democratic amendments today, on the ground
that current efforts by the Administration to alleviate the credit crunch were
adequate.

''We don't see the need for any additional amendments,'' Mr. Dole said.

He also argued that any additional spending for farmers by Congress would
undermine Republican efforts to forge a deficit-reduction package. ''The best
thing we can do for farmers is reduce the deficit,'' he said.

But Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, disagreed. ''We still feel
more needs to be done,'' he told reporters,

He was supported by Senator Mark Andrews, Republican of North Dakota, who said
he would co-sponsor one of the Democratic amendments. Mr. Andrews, a sugar beet
farmer, called the proposals for extra aid ''highly necessary.''

Mr. Andrews is one of 22 incumbent Republicans facing re-election next year, and
legislators from agricultural states will face a tough choice on the Democratic
amendments. Senator Boren predicted that if the Republican leadership did not
make the issue one of party discipline, the Democrats could get a number of
Republican votes for their proposals.

''Sure it will be an issue in the next election,'' Mr. Boren said. Any
Republican who opposes the amendments, he added, will ''have to do a lot of
accounting back to their constituents, and they know that.''

Testimony from State Lawmakers

The politically potent nature of the farm credit issue was underscored today
when state legislators from the Farm Belt testified at several hearings around
Capitol Hill. ''These people wouldn't be here if they felt they were getting
adequate help,'' Senator Andrews said.

Susan Roenbaugh, a state legislator from Kansas, told a hearing of the Senate
Agriculture Committee, ''American agriculture is in the worst shape its been in
for many, many years.''

Mrs. Roenbaugh, a Republican, lives on a farm. She added, ''It's sort of like
the farmers are hanging by their hands from a cliff and the Government is
stepping on their fingers.''

The farm credit issue was also raised in a discussion that John R. Block, the
Secretary of Agriculture, had today with members of the National Governors'
Association. Many were openly skeptical of the Administration's farm programs,
and Gov. Mark White of Texas expressed the hope that the Administration's
''safety net'' for farmers ''is not painted on the concrete.''

One of the amendments advanced by Senate Democrats would revise many of the
procedures governing existing loan programs and make them easier to use. One key
change would provide $100 million in Federal funds to subsidize interest rates
charged to farmers by commercial banks for loans guaranteed by Washington.

Paying for Subsidy

Under current rules, Senator Andrews argues, the cost of the subsidy is unfairly
born by other borrowers, such as local merchants, and that as a result, many
small banks have refrained from participating in the program.

The second proposed amendment would allow farmers to receive payments this
spring for crops to be harvested in the fall. Normally these payments are only
available after the harvest, but sponsors of the amendment argue that farmers
need the cash now to finance spring planting.

Senator Dole and the Reagan Administration argue that the proposal could cost $9
billion or $10 billion, the amount that would be made available for advance
payments.

Senator Boren and other supporters argue that any funds advanced to farmers
ahead of schedule would have been paid out anyway. ''We're just getting the
money out there sooner,'' the Oklahoma Democrat said.

                        Clovis News Journal (New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          February 19, 2014 Wednesday

Apps growing aid to farmers

BYLINE: Lillian Bowe, Clovis News Journal, N.M.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 320 words


Feb. 19--lbowe@pntonline.com

Even on the farm, there's an app for that.

Tuesday at the New Mexico Ag Expo, David Yates, a management specialist at Texas
A&M AgriLife Extension showed his audience how to bridge large-scale farming and
handeld technologies with a seminar on agriculture application of tablets and
smart phones.

Yates said there is an app for everything, but it is more difficult to find apps
that pertain to agriculture. So he decided to write his own apps that can be
used in managing agricultural based operations.

"I learned that designing an app is much harder than it sounds.," Yates said.
"It can be expensive and time consuming."

Yates said apps simplify many tasks for farmers and ranchers, and taught the
audience how to search for apps while also providing a list of apps he uses and
a recommendation to ask friends what they use.

Yates had several categories of apps including markets, livestock, agriculture
news, weather, agronomy and precision agriculture.

"The apps I showed, I have used myself and they really help around the farm,"
Yates said.

One of the apps he highlighted was an app called ID Weed, which was created by
the University of Missouri and helps identify weeds and what pesticides to use.

Another app for livestock, CVP Vet, has more than 5,600 pharmaceutical,
biological, feed medication and parasiticide products listed. It can be used
when a person needs to know the dosage of medication for their animals or needs
to know what medication to use when an animal is showing specific symptoms.

Yates said there are apps that can help in management and bookkeeping which make
life easier.

"Everyone nowadays has a smartphone," Yates said. "Why not use it on the farm to
help mix pesticides or measure the acreage of a piece of land?"

                        The Legal Ledger (St. Paul, MN)

                              July 19, 2004 Monday

Three counties await decision on disaster aid

BYLINE: David Knutson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 393 words


Heavy rains washed out crops in three Minnesota counties this spring, prompting
Gov. Tim Pawlenty to call for disaster aid.

Lake of the Woods, Roseau and Marshall counties all sustained crop damage of
more than 30 percent due to soaked fields.

The matter is now in the hands of U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Ann Veneman, who
will decide whether to designate the counties as federal disaster areas. That
designation would allow eligible farmers to receive low-interest loans to aid
their recovery.

Warren Pommier, state program specialist with the USDA's Farm Service Agency in
St. Paul, said Roseau received the most damage - losing up to 90 percent of
crops in some cases. Marshall suffered 50 percent loss, while Lake of the Woods
had about 60 percent loss. The figures are still rough estimates, he said.

"Most of it was because land didn't even get planted," Pommier said. "It stayed
wet too long from the heavy rains."

The governor's request to the USDA came after the Minnesota State Emergency
Board determined the counties to be eligible for disaster declaration.

The board is made up of representatives of federal farm agencies as well as the
state Department of Agriculture and Minnesota Extension Service.

The USDA is expected to respond to the request from Pawlenty in four to six
weeks.

To be eligible for the low-interest loans, producers must present evidence of
their need, Pommier said.

"They have to show they need the money to keep their farm operation going," he
said. "They still have to meet the criteria."

Farmers also have crop insurance that they can access before turning to the
federal low-interest low programs, Pommier noted.

"In those counties, they probably have between 90 and 95 percent participation
in crop insurance," he said.

Tom Decock, a loan specialist with the Farm Service Agency, said during the last
fiscal year Minnesota farmers received 695 direct low-interest loans amounting
to $42 million from the USDA and another 784 guaranteed loans amounting to $146
million.

Those figures are roughly average for recent years, he said.

The numbers were much higher during the farm crisis years such as those of the
mid-1980s or in 1994 following the massive flooding of the Mississippi River the
year before.

"Our loan activity often follows a poor situation (for farmers)," Decock said.

                              Journal of Commerce

                          September 21, 1989, Thursday

PORK BELLIES RISE ON NEWS OF AID TO POLAND, HUNGARY

BYLINE: From Wire and Staff Reports

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 325 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Pork belly futures turned sharply higher Wednesday in response to news the
Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted in favor of endorsing aid for Poland
and Hungry.

Prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange closed up the daily permissible limit
of 200 points or 2 cents a pound. The nearby February delivery closed at 49.50
cents while the March contract was 49.62 cents. October live hog futures ere up
to 41.82 cents.

The Senate action revived bullish sentiment about pork exports to Poland, which
helped the market in recent weeks, dealers said.

Meanwhile, CME live cattle futures closed mostly lower but were lifted from
their lows on spillover buying created by the late reversal in the pork complex.
The spot September delivery was the sole gainer, up 1.20 cents to 70 cents a
pound.

Belly prices were down earlier in the day on long liquidation that reflected the
lack of definitive news about pork belly sales to Poland. Early weakness,
however, was tempered by news of higher cash hog prices.

A high-level U.S. Department of Agriculture official Tuesday night told a group
of pork industry executives that the outlook is bright for U.S. shipments of
pork to Poland.

Richard Crowder, undersecretary for international affairs and commodity
programs, told members of the National Pork Producers Council: "We are looking
at a number of options, of which bellies are one.

"We want to put together immediate assistance, but we don't want to disrupt
their (Poland's) marketing or supply system," he said.

However, the Bush administration already has pledged to send $ 100 worth of food
aid to Poland. The administration had said that meat would be included in a $ 50
million shipment that is part of that total. But no specifics were given on what
types of meat.

Mr. Crowder told reporters the European Community has pledged beef shipments to
Poland, indicating the United States may want to emphasize pork shipments.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    April 29, 1989, Saturday, Tampa Edition

Farmers hit by freeze may get federal loans

SOURCE: Compiled from Staff and Wire Reports

BYLINE: JENNIFER ORSI

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 288 words

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE



TALLAHASSEE - Gov. Bob Martinez requested Friday that federal    disaster loans
be made available to farmers in Hillsborough and four    other Florida counties
hardest hit with crop damage from February's    freeze.

     In a letter to U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter,    Martinez
wrote that the Feb. 23-26 freeze severely damaged young    vegetable and
ornamental crops in Hillsborough, Charlotte, Flagler,    Putnam and St. Johns
counties.

     Demetrio Arredondo, a farmer and foreman at Bioterra Corp. farms in
Wimauma, said the loans could help him and many other farmers.

     "I guess anything would be helpful," he said. "We really don't    have the
yield (of tomatoes) that we're supposed to have, not even half    of it."

     Arredondo said the tomato crop is planted in three groups, and the
freeze wiped out the first of them. "We didn't have any backup plans    for it,"
he said.

     Farmers were taken by surprise because the freeze came so late in    the
season, he said. He couldn't estimate the farm's loss in dollars    but said he
would apply for a loan if they are made available.

     If federal officials agree to classify the five counties as    disaster
areas, local businesses and individuals can qualify for    low-interest
emergency loans from the Farmers Home Administration.

     In the five counties where damage was most severe, more than    660,000
acres experienced "severe damage and losses, causing economic    disaster for
nearly 3,500 farms," according to the governor's    statement.

 - Information from staff writer Jennifer Orsi was used in this report.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            November 3, 2013 Sunday

A fan of farmers: New MOFGA executive director brings diverse experiences to
Maine

BYLINE: Abigail Curtis BDN Staff

LENGTH: 608 words


UNITY, Maine -- The new executive director of the country's oldest and largest
state organic organization has some big gardening shoes to fill, but brings with
him decades of experience helping small farmers all over the country.


Ted Quaday took the helm at the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners Association
at the beginning of October. He succeeds longtime organic advocate Russell
Libby, who led the organization from 1995 until his death last year and who was
called a " powerful voice for and leader of small family farmers" at his passing
by the deputy secretary of the United States Department of Agriculture.


Quaday, who originally is from North Dakota, has spent the last 15 years
advocating for family farms and sustainable agriculture, first with Farm Aid and
then as a communications director at the Organic Farming Research Foundation of
Santa Cruz, Calif.


"The work that MOFGA's doing is so critically important," he said Friday. "The
opportunity to come to Maine and head an organization with the track record that
MOFGA has -- well, I was totally glad to accept it."


The Maine organization, which was formed in 1971, now has 11,000 members, and
its annual Common Ground Country Fair brings tens of thousands of people to
Unity every September to learn, teach, sample food, look at animals and
otherwise enjoy rural living.


The new director described his first days on the job as "exciting and active,"
and have allowed him the chance to sample heirloom apples and meet some of the
organization's many involved board members.


"It's great. I'm getting a chance to get out and meet people all the time. It's
fun," he said.


Quaday said that he grew up as a hockey-playing kid who has been involved with
gardening and soil building his entire life. His family always had a garden, and
even though he didn't come from a farming family, in North Dakota, agriculture
is hard to avoid. After college, he worked as a reporter and anchor for a local
TV station in Fargo.


"If you're covering politics in North Dakota, you're always bumping up against
farming. It's part of the framework," he said.


He grew so interested in that framework, he went on to study public
administration in Boston, and was hired by Farm Aid, the organization that
Willie Nelson found in 1985. There, he focused on farm and food issues between
1998 and 2008, during a decade when the food movement was "growing by leaps and
bounds." In that period, the USDA finally implemented organic standards and
interest in organic agriculture took off. In Santa Cruz, he was involved in
advocating organic farming at the national level.


"Organic is really about paying attention to nature and to what nature is
telling you about the health of your soil," he said. "It's the difference
between people who are building soil and nurturing soil, and those who are
mining soil."


In Maine, MOFGA's work is important both locally and beyond, he said, especially
as the changing climate poses new challenges for crops and farmers. Increased
interest in organic farming has led many people without agriculture backgrounds
to the vegetable fields, and in Maine MOFGA has helped provide them training and
support.


"In 60 years of industrialization, people have lost their memory of how to think
about a diversified farm structure," Quaday said. "The folks that have come back
to farming now have to relearn the system."


He said that Libby was a visionary of the food movement, who helped shape it
both in Maine and regionally.


"My objective is to follow that vision," Quaday said. "It's a democratic
approach. We need to ensure that those voices will always have an opportunity to
be heard and heralded."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              373 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             March 23, 2003 Sunday

Revisiions in inccentives program cause controversy; Environmental quality:
Should large operations receive federal funding to control pollution?

BYLINE: mailto:jeverly@wcinet.comJOHN EVERLY

SECTION: Pg. d4

LENGTH: 888 words


Just about everyone agrees that protecting our soil and water from degradation
is important. Farmers, landowners, environmentalists and conservationists
frequently work together to improve water quality.

But the means to reach those ends have become controversial, following a
revision in the federal Environmental Quality Incentives Program.

The program was modified in the 2002 Farm Bill, with funding boosted from $$
@400 million in fiscal 2002 to $$ @1.3 billion by 2007. Sixty percent of the
funds are to assist livestock producers in controlling feedlot runoff and waste
handling.

Under the program, landowners and farmers receive technical assistance from
county offices of the Natural Resources Conservation Service, an agency of the
U.S. Department of Agriculture.

A point of contention centers on whether those additional livestock funds should
be allocated to small- and medium-sized farms only, or if large livestock
operations also should receive funding to control pollution.

The nonprofit Land Stewardship Project, a Minnesota-based group, argues that the
2002 Farm Bill made the program into a subsidy program for large-scale livestock
expansion, in part by increasing the limit for program payments from $$ @50,000
per farm to $$ @450,000 per farm.

The program is heavily utilized by family farms in the tri-state area for
soil-erosion control and manure management. With the tri-state area's
livestock-intensive agriculture, the Environmental Quality Incentives Program
has been a useful tool for cleaning up local rivers and streams.

"That's probably our main program," said Mike Lieurance, district
conservationist with the Grant County (Wis.) Natural Resources Conservation
Service. The program could pump up to $$ @453,000 into Grant County this year,
and almost $$ @1 million over the next five years.

Other area counties also have used program funds to help farmers install
conservation practices on their land.

The program could be more useful, though, if more resources came our way, says
an Iowa farm group. The Environmental Quality Incentives Program must be
structured to assist farmers in meeting new state and federal regulations, the
Iowa Farm Bureau said in a recent letter to the U.S. Natural Resources
Conservation Service. This includes revising the formula to allocate program
funds, the group said.

Rick Robinson, Iowa Farm Bureau environmental affairs director, said crop and
livestock producers face, or will soon face, environmental regulations targeting
air and water quality.

"Implementation costs for these regulations are significant," he said. "A
comprehensive nutrient-management plan could cost $$ @5,000, installation of a
swine-manure-management system $$ @50,000 to $$ @100,000, and a
crop-nutrient-management plan up to $$ @3,000 per year."

The Farm Bureau worries that Iowa might be left holding the bag when it comes to
Environmental Quality Incentives Program funding.

"Midwestern states, such as Iowa, receive inadequate funding - 21 cents per acre
in 2002 compared to $$ @1.18 to $$ @5.75 per acre for Western states," Robinson
said. "For Iowa farmers to be successful in meeting regulatory challenges and
for the program to retain credibility, this disparity must be addressed."

The Natural Resources Conservation Service needs to consider several factors,
such as soil erosion, nutrient loadings and impaired streams in allocating funds
to states, he said.

Robinson said financial assistance to states should be based upon resource
concerns and available to all livestock producers regardless of size.

The Farm First Aid Kits are again available in the Dubuque area. The kits,
designed specifically for treating farm-related injuries, were sold out in their
initial run a few years ago.

Starting Monday, the Farm First Aid Kits can be purchased at county Farm Bureau
offices in Iowa for $$ @30.

The Farm First Aid Kits contain supplies to respond to serious injuries until
help arrives. Each kit contains shears capable of cutting through seams and
zippers on heavy jackets and coveralls, large tweezers, gauze pads and wide
adhesive tape. Eyewash, a large plastic bag for transporting an amputated toe or
finger, a cold pack and a thermal blanket also are included.

A short video about proper use of the kit and a packet about first aid on the
farm are available for review through Farm Bureau offices.

"Access to a Farm First Aid Kit could mean the difference between life and
death," said Iowa Farm Bureau Leadership Director Barb Lykins.

The need is certainly there. According to the Iowa Department of Public Health
and Iowa State University Extension, there were 1,195 farm-related injuries and
38 fatalities in Iowa in 2000.

The kits are jointly sponsored by the Iowa Farm Bureau Foundation; the Iowa Farm
Bureau Federation; Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc.; Key West True Value
Hardware; the National Education Center for Agricultural Safety; the National
Association of Farm Broadcasters; and Mercy Health Network and its member
hospitals in Dubuque, Clinton, Des Moines, North Iowa and Sioux City.

Everly, a Telegraph Herald reporter, was farm director of Dubuque radio station
KDTH for nearly 10 years. His e-mail address is jeverly@wcinet.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

                 July 31, 1983, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

AID IS SOUGHT FOR JOBLESS FARM WORKERS IN ARIZONA

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 655 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., July 30


An organization that assists migrant laborers says one-third of the state's farm
workers have lost their jobs or will soon be laid off and has asked Gov. Bruce
Babbitt to declare a state of economic emergency.

The layoffs, which could eventually affect more than 18,000 workers statewide,
is attributed to several factors, including recent flooding of farmland along
the Colorado River and a new Federal program that has prodded farmers to take a
record number of acres out of production, the organization says.

Also, a large number of Arizona copper workers, many of whom have been laid off
in the past year, are now competing for farm jobs.  Another factor is the recent
large influx of aliens coming illegally from Mexico because of the devaluations
of the peso.

The request for emergency aid came from the board of Portable Practical
Education Preparation Inc., a private, nonprofit agency based here that is
financed in part by the Department of Labor to train and assist migrant farm
families.

Rising unemployment in agricultural states like Arizona was confirmed by
Representative Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, a member of the House
Agriculture Committee. Mr. Penny recently told the National Association of
Farmworker Organizations at its annual meeting here that the new Federal farm
program would help put farmers back on their feet, but would reduce farm
employment.

The new farm program, in which farmers who agree to idle up to half their normal
grain and cotton acreage are paid with surplus Government crops, is called
payment in kind, often referred to by its acronym, PIK. According to the Arizona
Farm Bureau, which represents agricultural producers and ranchers, the program
has had little impact on the state, even though cotton is the state's largest
crop.  The organization said the claims of soaring unemployment were
exaggerated.

However, John Arnold, director of the Tucson educational project, called the
rise in unemployment the worst he had seen in 25 years.  Mr. Arnold, noting that
farm workers were not covered by unemployment benefits or health plans, said,
''When they become victimized by programs like PIK there are no resources to
fall back on.''

He said that among those recently laid off was a 43-year-old man who had worked
at the same cotton farm north of Tucson for 26 years.  Last week the man and his
family were asked to leave the farm, he said.

There are 1.6 million farm workers nationwide, including 55,000 in Arizona. The
Arizona workers include migrants, who move from region to region, and seasonal
workers, who stay in one state, but who help plant or harvest crops on a
seasonal basis. At least as many workers lacking immigration documents, most
from Mexico, call Arizona home, Mr. Arnold said.

Under the farm payment program, 40 to 50 percent of the nation's farmers will
need fewer workers, Mr. Arnold said in the statement sent to the Governor. In
Arizona, the Federal Government is expected to pay farmers $76 million for not
planting on 303,700 acres. Cotton acreage will be cut by two-thirds, according
to Federal figures.

In response to the appeal for emergency aid, Andrew Hurwitz, a spokesman for
Governor Babbitt, said: ''We don't have the technical power to declare an
emergency because of economic factors. We are limited to emergencies resulting
from natural disasters.''

He said a Babbitt aide would meet here next week with members of the migrant
training agency and the Arizona Department of Economic Security. If the Governor
decides to appeal for Federal aid, Arizona could be eligible under the $4.6
billion emergency job bill passed by Congress in March. The money would be used
to provide education, retraining and subsistence

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                    October 23, 1997, Thursday, ALL EDITIONS

School Watch;
BRIEFS;
Committee to be formed to study attendance zones

SECTION: EXTRA; Pg. 04M

LENGTH: 394 words


To prepare for the opening of Peeples Elementary next fall, the Fayette school
system will begin the process of redrawing elementary school attendance zones
sometime in December. The first step will be to appoint a committee of parents
and school personnel to look at how the lines are drawn now and try to move as
few children as possible, said Superintendent Dave Brotherton. The schools
affected most by the opening of the new school are Braelinn and Spring Hill, he
said. But Brotherton said a "ripple effect" will spread to the system's other
elementary schools. However, he promised to solicit public input and to develop
a plan to redraw lines in the "least disruptive manner" possible. A final plan
will be finished in the spring so information can go home to parents prior to
the end of this school year.

MORE FRUITS AND VEGGIES: The Fayette County school nutrition program received
the United States Department of Agriculture Best Practices Award for increasing
the daily consumption of fruits and vegetables by students and improving the
quality and quantity of fresh produce served at the schools.

FRIDAY

Burch Elementary in Tyrone is holding a Western Day celebration from 5 to 9 p.m.

There will be games with names such as Texas Tornado and Bronco Bustin', food
and a hayride. The schools is on Jenkins Road in Tyrone. Information:
770-969-2820.

SATURDAY

White Oak Elementary will hold its fall festival from 1 to 4 p.m. The school is
at 770 Lora Smith Road, Newnan.

The Heritage School in Newnan will hold a fall festival from 5:30 to 8:30 p.m..
There will be games, a Moonwalk, a hayride and a fortune teller. The school is
at 2093 U.S. 29 North, Newnan. Information: 770-253-9898.

OCT. 30

A financial aid meeting will be held at 7 p.m. at McIntosh High School in the
media center.

A representative from the Georgia Student Finance Commission will be there to
offer tips on completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid form and
to answer questions about college financing.

Sandy Creek High will hold a meeting Dec. 15 at 7 p.m. Fayette County High's
will be Feb. 2.

ONGOING:

Brooks Elementary School is holding a can drive to collect food for the Atlanta
Community Food Bank through Oct. 31. The school is on Price Road. The Lane Co.
and the Atlanta Apartments Associations are sponsors.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   July 17, 1993, SATURDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

GOVERNORS WILL HAVE HANDS OUT; MONEY WILL BE FOCUS OF TALKS WITH CLINTON

BYLINE: Kathleen Best Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7A

LENGTH: 684 words


The language used by the governors of flood-ravaged states may differ, but their
message to President Bill Clinton at today's meeting here will be the same: Send
more cash.  "There is no getting around that the dominant issue is going to be
money," said Al Grosboll, flood coordinator for Illinois Gov. Jim Edgar.  "In
many, many of the areas that people are going to address, they're going to say
that the amount the president has talked about isn't enough." Clinton, Vice
President Al Gore, Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy and other Cabinet members
will meet this morning with the leaders of nine states, plus dozens of local
officials and members of Congress. They will meet at Fox High School in Arnold
in what is being billed as a national "flood summit." Clinton proposed a $2.5
billion flood aid package at a stop earlier this week in Des Moines, Iowa, to
tour flood damage. But he acknowledged at the time that while that total was
likely to grow, the federal government could not cover all of the economic
losses caused by the floods.  The governors of Missouri, Illinois, Iowa,
Nebraska, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Kansas, South Dakota and North Dakota will lobby
to up the ante in their first face-to-face encounter with Clinton since rivers
across the Midwest started swelling beyond their banks.  Marc Farinella, chief
of staff for Missouri Gov. Mel Carnahan, said the governors want to make sure
Clinton "understands the magnitude of the problem" the states face. But some
state officials privately questioned whether the meeting in Missouri would
provide the right forum to deliver that message.  "They've invited the world,"
said one state official, who requested anonymity. "This thing is going to be a
big dog-and-pony show, and there is some cynicism among some of the other states
I've talked to.  "But," the official added, "it's our best shot. And we'll make
the most of it." Lisa Green, spokeswoman for Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, said
Branstad would ask Clinton to waive the usual requirement that states and local
governments put up their own money to qualify for federal aid.  Branstad also
will seek additional assistance for farmers whose crops were swept away or
drowned by the floods. Green said federal aid to farmers is capped at an
unreasonably low level that, in effect, will allow farmers to collect only a
quarter of every dollar they lose.  "The governor can't expect to make everyone
in Iowa whole," Green said.  "But I think he's hoping to do what he can to
increase aid." Joe Pendal, deputy press secretary for Minnesota Gov. Arne
Carlson, said Carlson wants the federal government to recognize that losses from
the flood will ripple throughout the economies of affected states.  Pendal said
tourism in Minnesota is off 30 to 50 percent because people have been scared
away by flood scenes. Moreover, he said, the losses Minnesota farmers sustained
soon will start showing up in shops on main street and agriculture-related
businesses as farmers cut back their spending.  "Even though the federal
emergency officials are on the scene, it's important for the governors to tell
their stories firsthand," Pendal said.  Grosboll, the Illinois official, said
Edgar would come armed with specific budget concerns. For example, he said, the
$100 million set aside for transportation aid in Clinton's flood package may not
even be enough to cover Illinois, much less the other eight states affected by
floods.  Illinois has 28 bridges that cross the Mississippi River, only five of
which remained open Friday. All of those bridges will have to be inspected when
the water goes down, many will require repairs and some may have to be replaced.
House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt, D-St. Louis County, said Clinton is
likely to discuss the appointment of a White House coordinator to the Midwest.
"I think he'll want to talk about having someone on the ground here . . .  to be
a field commander," Gephardt said. "You have to look at this as kind of a war.
You wouldn't prosecute a war having a lead general in Washington.  You'd want
him out where the war is."

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 1993

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                          September 14, 2006 Thursday

Good crop year may dampen Utah counties' chances for drought aid

BYLINE: Tribune Staff and Wire Services

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 502 words


Although dry parts of Utah are asking for emergency help, the outlook is
improving for the nation's corn and soybean farmers - and that may dampen the
effort in Congress to spend billions of dollars in drought aid.

Despite withering heat and dryness in some parts of the country, this year's
harvest should be the second-best on record, the Agriculture Department said in
its monthly crop report Tuesday. Anticipating higher yields, analysts boosted
the production forecast by 6 percent for soybeans and 1 percent for corn.

In Utah, Daggett and San Juan are requesting a disaster declaration because of
drought conditions and both Grand and Uintah counties are abnormally dry, said
state agricultural spokesman Larry Lewis. The majority of the state is
experiencing normal conditions.

Higher yields nationwide might sound incredible to farmers and ranchers
suffering from prolonged drought, but significant rains last month helped
relieve drought that has lingered in soybean fields and pastures in the western
Corn Belt and across much of the Plains.

''The effects of the drought seem to have stabilized,'' said Keith Collins,
chief economist for the department.

Nationwide, yields look promising: Soybean yields should average 41.8 bushels an
acre, up 2.2 bushels from last month's forecast, and corn yields should be 154.7
bushels an acre, up 2.5 bushels from the forecast last month.

''Which is a pretty good yield, considering the very difficult weather season
we've had in so many of the western states,'' Collins said.

The rosier outlook should bolster the Bush administration's resistance to a
massive, $6.5 billion drought relief plan in Congress. The White House opposes
the plan because the money would be unfairly distributed, Agriculture Secretary
Mike Johanns said.

''You do not have to suffer any kind of loss to be the beneficiary of the bills
that are being debated,'' Johanns told members of the National Farmers Union
Monday in Washington.

So far, Bush is providing much more modest aid, including $50 million for
livestock producers. In all, the administration has promised nearly $780 million
to drought-stricken farmers; the amount includes $700 million in already-planned
payments that farmers will be getting sooner.

Johanns wants to see how the fall harvest goes before committing to more aid
dollars. But critics argue more aid is needed now.

U.S. crop forecasts

ä SOYBEANS: 3.1 billion bushels, up 165 million bushels from last month's
forecast. Price estimates dropped 10 cents to $4.90 to $5.90 a bushel; last
year's average was $5.68.

ä CORN: 11.1 billion bushels, up 138 million from last month's forecast. Prices
were unchanged at $2.15 to $2.55 a bushel, compared with $1.99 last year.

ä WHEAT: Unchanged, with production at 1.8 billion bushels.

ä TOBACCO: About 15 percent bigger crop this year.

ä PEANUTS: 34 percent smaller crop than last year, the smallest crop in 26
years.

ä COTTON: Down 15 percent from last year's record.

ä RICE: Down 13 percent from last year.

Source: The Associated Press
