                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 27, 2007 Tuesday

Salazar says budget bill could help cattlemen

BYLINE: Peter Roper, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 436 words


Feb. 27--Trying to find a way to finance disaster aid for Eastern Plains
ranchers, Rep. John Salazar said lawmakers may try to attach funding to a
supplemental budget bill in Congress to provide funding to the USDA's livestock
compensation program.

Salazar spoke with Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns on Monday and said the
USDA created a disaster program for ranchers in 2002 to help pay for losses
caused by the severe drought that summer. The only problem is the program is
empty of funding, said Salazar, a Democrat who represents Pueblo and the 3rd
Congressional District.

"I asked Secretary Johanns whether he could shift funding into the Livestock
Compensation Program and he said that wasn't likely, given his tight budget,"
Salazar said.

Salazar added that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has indicated the Democratic
leadership will allow lawmakers to attach disaster funds to a Defense Department
supplemental bill that is coming to the House this month.

Whether there are enough votes to support an aid plan for farmers and ranchers
damaged by this winter's blizzards is still unknown, Salazar acknowledged.

New House rules requiring lawmakers to "pay as you go" by finding budget cuts to
pay for extra spending could also pose a challenge.

"I don't want to get anyone's hopes up, but that supplemental bill may be the
fastest route to providing help to the agriculture community that has really
been hit hard by these storms," Salazar said. "I talked to ranchers last week
who said they are losing 30 percent or more of their new calves because the
cattle are so weak."

When the USDA ruled that Eastern Plains counties did not qualify for disaster
aid from the Christmas and New Year's blizzards, it cited a requirement that
farmers and ranchers must demonstrate a 30 percent loss in production.

Livestock has not been part of that estimate in the past, but Johanns told
Salazar he would review the regulations.

"If livestock is included, I don't think there is any question these growers
have suffered more than a 30 percent loss in production," said Salazar, who sits
on the House Agriculture Committee.

One factor in the ranchers' favor is the storms hit several states hard,
including Kansas and Nebraska. There is a bipartisan group of lawmakers who are
pushing for disaster-aid legislation, Salazar said.

800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The

                               The New York Times

               September 29, 1998, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Additional Aid for Farmers Is Rejected in Conference on the Agriculture Bill

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 536 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28


Setting up a confrontation with President Clinton, Congressional Republicans
tonight rejected a Democratic request for $3.5 billion in additional emergency
aid to farmers. But they approved millions of dollars for individual
agricultural projects.

Congress had already agreed to provide $4 billion in emergency farm aid for the
next fiscal year. But Mr. Clinton recently joined Democrats in Congress, led by
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, in seeking $7.5 billion in response to emergencies
like droughts, floods, disease and the disappearance of foreign markets, all of
which have forced crop prices down and created what Democrats say is a crisis on
the nation's farms.

"We have a terrible emergency out there, and we have to address it, and $4
billion is just woefully inadequate," Mr. Harkin said tonight as House and
Senate negotiators thrashed out their different versions of the agriculture
spending bill.

But Republicans said they could not spend the additional $3.5 billion without
making cuts elsewhere in the Federal budget.

They said the Democrats' move would be an irresponsible busting of a budget
agreement and was an obvious political ploy, coming five weeks before the
Congressional elections.

"This is an interesting exercise in political posturing," said Senator Thad
Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, who said the Administration was suffering
from a "breakdown in leadership."

Even as House and Senate negotiators rejected the additional farm relief, they
quickly added $77 million in special-interest projects sought by individual
members.

Most of that money, $50 million, had been requested by Senator Ted Stevens, the
Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, to
bolster the salmon industry. The remaining $27 million was added for items like
subsidies for mohair, honey and apple growers.

The Administration has threatened to veto the entire agriculture spending bill
if it does not include the extra relief money.

The Administration is also unhappy with a Republican-backed measure attached to
the bill that would bar the Food and Drug Administration from approving
abortion-inducing drugs, like the French abortion pill RU-486.

The negotiators agreed to have this issue settled on the floor later, rather
than in conference.


                             --------------------


House Clears Two Spending Bills

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Underlining the haste with which Congress is
beginning to consider spending bills for the 1999 fiscal year, the House acted
with startling speed and a lack of contentiousness today in approving military
spending legislation and a separate energy and water measure.

The $250.5 billion military spending bill has money for anti-missile defenses
and a pay rise for military personnel.

The energy and water legislation would finance projects from coast to coast.

It took lawmakers less than half an hour to debate both bills. The military
measure was approved by a vote of 369 to 43, and the energy bill passed by 389
to 25.

The Senate is expected to approve both measures in coming days, as Congress
races to complete 11 spending measures that it has yet to send President
Clinton.

                              381 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                           November 15, 2011 Tuesday

new england in brief

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1169 words


Tuesday November 15, 2011

Funding caps lifted on federal disaster aid

MONTPELIER (AP) -- The big question about post-Irene federal disaster aid for
Vermont has been answered in the state's favor.

Sen. Patrick Leahy on Monday announced that a House-Senate conference committee
on Capitol Hill had agreed to a new federal highway funding package that lifts
funding caps for disaster relief that had had Vermont officials very worried.

Gov. Peter Shumlin says he's elated, and is heaping praise on Leahy, Sen. Bernie
Sanders and Rep. Peter Welch for their work in securing the funding.

The state has been estimating up to $250 million in repair costs for federal-aid
-eligible roads and bridges. Officials were worried about a $100 million-per-
state cap on disaster funding from the federal highway administration. The
provision approved Monday lifts that cap.

Vt. AG looking at open meeting law complaint

BENNINGTON (AP) -- The state Attorney General's office is investigating a
complaint against six southwest Vermont school boards regarding their compliance
with the state's Open Meeting Law.

The boards and Southwest Vermont Supervisory Union Superintendent Catherine
McClure denied wrongdoing at the Oct 28 meeting at Mount Anthony Union Middle
School.

The only item for discussion was updating the boards on teacher negotiations.
The complaint alleges the boards did not allow the public into the meeting room
prior to the executive session, didn't give time for the public to speak, and
the location of the meeting was moved without advanced warning.

The letter does not state who made the complaint.

Teachers who went on strike for nine days overwhelmingly ratified a new
three-year labor contract last week.

Parts of Vt., N.H., Maine designated disaster areas

CONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- Farms parts of New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine are
eligible for low-interest loans to cover losses from flooding, hail and heavy
rains, including Tropical Storm, that started on May 1.

The United States Department of Agriculture designated eight counties in New
Hampshire, five in Vermont and two in Maine as natural disaster areas on Nov. 9.

The designation means the qualified farmers in those counties are eligible for
low emergency loans from United State Department of Agriculture's Farm Service
Agency.

The areas covered are Belknap, Coos, Hillsborough, Strafford, Carroll, Grafton,
Rockingham and Sullivan counties in New Hampshire and Caledonia, Essex, Orange,
Windham and Windsor counties in Vermont. Qualified farmers in Oxford and York
counties also are eligible.

Economists to discuss New England forecasts

MANCHESTER, N.H. (AP) -- Economists from around New England will present their
forecasts for the region at a conference in Manchester, N.H.

The New England Economic Partnership is sponsoring the Fall Economic Outlook
Conference on Friday. University of New Hampshire Professor Ross Gittell and
economist Dennis Delay of the New Hampshire Center for Public Policy Studies are
among the presenters.

Mark Zandi, the chief economist for Moody's Analytics, will discuss the outlook
for the nation.

Seabrook plant to conduct siren test

SEABROOK, N.H. (AP) -- The Seabrook Station nuclear power plant and the states
of New Hampshire and Massachusetts will be conducting a test of 121 public alert
sirens within a 10-mile area around the plant known as the Emergency Planning
Zone.

The siren demonstration scheduled for Wednesday is intended to increase public
awareness of what the sirens sound like and what to do if they should be used in
a real emergency. The sirens will be sounded at 12:30 p.m. with a steady tone
for three to five minutes.

No public action is needed.

50 laid off by N.H.'s Dartmouth-Hitchcock

LEBANON, N.H. (AP) -- About 50 Dartmouth-Hitchcock employees have lost their
jobs as the health system works to close a $100 million budget deficit.

Dartmouth-Hitchcock CEO James Weinstein said earlier this month that up to 100
positions would be eliminated over the next two months. The layoffs started
Monday, with about 50 workers, none of whom are directly connected to patient
care.

Dartmouth-Hitchcock has 8,500 employees. More than three-quarters of them work
at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, and the rest are located
primarily at larger clinics in Manchester, Concord, Nashua and Keene.

Weinstein says some of the terminated workers might be eligible to fill other
vacant positions.

Several other hospitals also have announced layoffs since the state budget took
effect July 1, and at least one has cut services to needy patients.

Aids Memorial Quilt squares coming to Keene

CONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- Portions of the mammoth Aids Memorial Quilt will be
arriving in Keene to commemorate World Aids Day Dec. 1.

AIDS Services for the Monadnock Region will bring 10 12-foot-square panels of
the quilt to the city.

Making of the quilt began in San Francisco in 1987 to serve as a memorial to
those who had died of AIDS.

When first displayed on the National Mall in Washington, D.C. later that year,
it was larger than a football field and drew half a million visitors. By 1996 it
had grown to cover the entire National Mall.

If assembled today as one quilt, it would weigh 56 tons and measure 56 miles if
all panels were laid end-to-end.

N.H.governor will veto video slots bills

CONCORD, N.H. (AP) -- Hoping to squelch efforts to expand gambling, Gov. John
Lynch is promising to veto bills that would legalize video slots in New
Hampshire.

Lynch told Republican legislative leaders Monday that the state does not have an
adequate regulatory structure in place. He also reiterated past concerns about
New Hampshire's qualify of life being affected and of the potential for
proliferation.

The House appears ready to abandon its longstanding opposition to casinos. A
committee is recommending legalizing two casinos equipped with video slots and
using some of the state's profits to reduce business taxes.

A Senate committee last week indicated it wants to keep its options open on
legalizing four casinos with a maximum of 10,000 video slot machines. The Senate
bill does not earmark profits to cut taxes.

Warren unveils 1st ad for senate campaign

BOSTON (AP) -- Massachusetts U.S. Senate candidate Elizabeth Warren is launching
her first television ad of the campaign.

The 60-second ad describes how she got married when she was 19, had two kids and
worked her way through college before attending law school.

The ad, set to begin airing Tuesday, describes Warren's efforts to create the
federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

In the ad, Warren also says she's worked to expose how Wall Street and big banks
are crushing middle class families.

Last week a political action committee associated with former President George
W. Bush's longtime political director Karl Rove began running a 30-second
television ad targeting Warren by linking her to Occupy Wall Street protesters.

Warren's campaign said it's already raised $300,000 to counter the $600,000
estimated to be spent by the Rove-affiliated group on the anti-Warren ad.

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                    September 18, 2003 Thursday CITY EDITION

MINNESOTA STORM MAY BOOST LOCAL DROUGHT AID

BYLINE: TOM WEBBWashington Correspondent

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A7

LENGTH: 559 words


WASHINGTON -- Strange as it sounds, Hurricane Isabel may be the disaster that
helps rural Minnesota.

Minnesota lawmakers have been urging Congress to send drought aid to Minnesota
farmers. So far, they haven't gotten very far, mostly because the drought hasn't
affected enough of America to stir the full U.S. Congress into action.

But a hurricane-size calamity is likely to change all that. Once East Coast
lawmakers start seeking emergency help, watch for farm-state interests to offer
to help -- provided that Congress remembers drought victims, too.

"With the size of the hurricane they're predicting out there, the damage is
going to be substantial," said Tom Buis of the National Farmers Union.

"And usually, when you have disasters around the country, sometimes they all get
lumped together. You don't want other people to have to suffer. But it might
make it easier to get the attention of Congress."

That's a common pattern for congressional disaster aid. An aid package may
include money for drought-stricken farmers, hurricane victims and flooded
residents. For legislators, the trick is to assemble a big enough coalition to
convince the full Congress to spend the billions of dollars sought.

Until this week, Barry Flinchbaugh, a farm policy specialist at Kansas State
University, thought it would be "extremely tough" for Midwestern farmers to win
disaster aid from Congress this year, simply because "the drought's not as
widespread as last year, and it's primarily (hurting) Minnesota, northern Iowa
and the Plains states."

But then came Hurricane Isabel, which threatens a large chunk of the East Coast
with serious damage.

"The hurricane, assuming it's as devastating as some are predicting, will bring
widespread support for disaster relief across the board," Flinchbaugh said.
"You're not going to give disaster relief to the South for the hurricane, and
ignore the farmers in the Plains."

Minnesota farmers have so far suffered $1.1 billion in crop losses due to the
summer drought, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service
Agency. Both U.S. Sen. Norm Coleman, R-Minn., and U.S. Sen. Mark Dayton,
D-Minn., have endorsed drought-aid packages, although they vary somewhat.

Dayton's plan, introduced Wednesday, would provide somewhat more generous
assistance, covering crop losses greater than 20 percent rather than the typical
35 percent. On Wednesday Dayton was seeking a Republican co-sponsor from outside
of Minnesota, mindful that a disaster has to be of sufficient size to stir
Congress.

"It's not going to be sufficient to have Minnesota by itself," Dayton said.
"We'll have to develop broad enough support in other states."

Last week, Coleman signed on to a drought-aid package sponsored by two Democrats
from Arkansas. He said he hoped the rain would return and crop insurance would
cover the losses. But if not, "if this falls short, the bipartisan bill I am
cosponsoring today would help," Coleman said.

In Minnesota, 62 of the state's 87 counties have been certified by the USDA as
having drought-related crop losses of at least 30 percent. That may not have
been enough to win congressional action, Flinchbaugh said. But, he added, "That
hurricane could be the big push for us in disaster relief."

Tom Webb can be reached at twebb@krwashington.com or 202-383-6049.

LOAD-DATE: August 16, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                              May 20, 2013, Monday

Business briefs

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P6A

LENGTH: 718 words


Frontier expands Kanawha broadband

Frontier Communications announced it has expanded broadband access to hundreds
of homes and businesses in the Kanawha Valley.

The company said landline broadband service is now available in the Amma Road,
Charleston Road and Cottontree Road areas of Clendenin; the Fisher Ridge Road,
Washington Drive, Sugar Creek Drive, and along Kanawha County 21 from Sugar
Creek to Falcon Drive in Sissonville; the Eskdale and Gallagher areas of East
Bank; in St. Albans along Riverbend Boulevard; and in the Liberty area along the
Kanawha-Putnam county line.

"Frontier has invested in expanding and strengthening its network across West
Virginia, and additional residents and businesses in the Kanawha Valley now have
access to our leading-edge broadband service," said Frontier general manager
Ryan Bailey.

Since the company took over Verizon's landline operations in July 2010, Frontier
has added broadband service to more than 158,000 West Virginia households.

The company said its investments in broadband have increased high-speed internet
access from 62 percent in 2010 to more than 86 percent of its service area in
the state.

Farmers to get $700,000 in Sandy aid

West Virginia farmers in 11 counties stand to receive up to $700,000 in federal
aid for lingering cleanup from Superstorm Sandy.

State Agriculture Commissioner Walt Helmick announced that West Virginia was
among 12 states eligible for up to $209 million in federal funding to help
farmers, landowners and communities recover from the storm.

"The general public doesn't always see the damage that natural disasters do to
rural agriculture and forestry operations in West Virginia," Helmick said.

"But these industries are vital to our state, and I'm pleased that the U.S.
Department of Agriculture is providing funding to help our farmers recover from
this historic disaster."

The state aid will be administered through the federal Farm Service Agency
Emergency Conservation Program.

State FSA director Alfred Lewis said agency officials have been collecting data
from counties to determine the type and extent of damage. Most of the funding
will be used to remove tree debris from farmland and fence lines.

Eligible for assistance are landowners in Preston, Randolph, Tucker, Barbour,
Braxton, Clay, Nicholas, Webster, Lewis, Upshur and Boone counties.

The agency already has received more than 100 applications for individual
assistance. The deadline to apply is May 31.

For more information, visit www.lrftool.sc.egov.usda.gov.

Federal employees meet in Barboursville

National Active and Retired Federal Employees Association will have its 48th
annual Convention today through Thursday at the Holiday Inn Hotel & Suites in
Barboursville.

William F. Martin, Region X vice president of the association, will share what
is being done to protect rights and benefits of its members. He also will speak
on how the association is implementing its 2013 Membership Marketing Strategy
Plan.

Federal employees and retirees from chapters throughout the state will be in
attendance.

For more information, visit www.narfe.org or contact Wayne Mitchell at
304-487-9335 or wmitchel2002@yahoo.com

Frontier plans ceremony for fallen soldiers

Frontier Communications plans to hold a special ceremony Wednesday morning to
honor veterans and those who lost their lives in service to the nation.

The company is inviting the public to attend the ceremony, which begins at 11
a.m. in front of its offices at 1500 MacCorkle Avenue in Charleston.

Frontier employees, including those who served in the military, will join local
and company officials to honor veterans during the event. During the ceremony,
Frontier will install an Honor and Remember Flag as a lasting acknowledgement of
the price that military veterans have paid to secure the nation's freedom.

"Frontier has a strong commitment to members of the military," said Dana Waldo,
Frontier senior vice president and West Virginia general manager. "Our military
men and women were there for us. It's our turn to be here for them."

In 2006, Frontier chief executive Maggie Wilderotter established a veteran
hiring program at the company to provide employment opportunities to returning
members of the armed services.

Military veterans now make up 11 percent of Frontier's total work force.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                              July 13, 2012 Friday

Parts of 26 states disaster areas;
Ag Department declaration doesn't include Ohio.;
WEATHER

BYLINE: ByAlan Bjerga and Elizabeth Campbell

SECTION: WEATHER; Pg. C6

LENGTH: 409 words


WASHINGTON - State leaders welcomed a pledge of U.S. aid for the worst drought
in decades, even as the assistance paled in comparison to potential losses and a
forecaster said weather conditions may not improve in some areas until
September.

The Agriculture Department on Wednesday named 1,016 counties in 26 states
natural-disaster areas, the agency's biggest such declaration ever. Substantial
rains that would relieve the worst-hit areas may not arrive for months, said
Mike Pigott, meteorologist at Accuweather Inc.

The declaration covers counties in the following states: California, Oregon,
Nevada, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming, Kansas,
Oklahoma, Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Illinois,
Indiana, Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, Delaware and
Hawaii.

Central Illinois, Indiana and Ohio are expected to remain under severe drought,
which may worsen as July continues. Parts of Arkansas, Missouri and southern
Illinois have been "substantially affected," he said.

The drought, which may be the worst since a 1988 dry spell that caused $78
billion in damage, is "beginning to have an impact on the corn crop in parts of
the Midwest," Pigott, whose company is based in State College, Penn., said. "The
building heat and humidity could affect maturity and eventual production." Corn
and soybeans are the two biggest U.S. crops.

"When you are one of the biggest agricultural-producing states in the nation, a
monumental drought causes enormous losses," said Bryan Black, a spokesman for
the Texas Agriculture Department. "The disaster-relief assistance from USDA will
help Texas farmers and ranchers recover from devastating losses."

The federal action makes farmers and ranchers eligible for low-interest loans to
help weather the drought, wildfires and other disasters. The projected cost to
the federal government is about $4 million as loans are ultimately repaid,
according to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. Still, with a budget-cutting
farm-policy bill going through Congress and prospects for other disaster aid
slim, officials say the low-cost loans and reduced penalties for grazing
livestock on land set aside for conservation announced Wednesday are better than
nothing.

Moderate to extreme drought now covers about 53 percent of the Mid-west, fueling
price gains that are the biggest this year among the 24 commodities tracked by
the Standard & Poor's GSCI Spot Index.

intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-16-0051 (2000004155)  for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.

expected to be available on or after July 6, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a

solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near July 13, 2016.

qualification requirements established in accordance with FAR Subpart 9.2.
Details of these requirements and contact information are available online at:

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            December 5, 2006 Tuesday

Senator to block farm aid bill

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 2B

LENGTH: 437 words


OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - A bill that would help drought-stricken farmers in Oklahoma
and other states may not get a chance to be considered if Sen. Tom Coburn is
successful in blocking it.

Coburn has said he plans to stop an attempt to approve $4.5 billion in
agriculture disaster aid because he believes it is too large and would cover too
many producers.

Supporters of the aid package haven't show how it will be paid for and they
should have targeted those who weren't able to plant a crop, not for crop losses
that could have been covered by federally subsidized insurance, Coburn, R-Okla.
said.

"If we're going to do relief for the farmers, we can't say, 'We'll take care of
you and give the bill to your grandkids,'" Coburn told the Oklahoman's
Washington bureau.

Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., pared his aid request to about $4.5 billion. Conrad is
expected to offer his proposal as an amendment to the annual agriculture
appropriations bill.

Coburn said he will try to block Conrad's package on a procedural move. If that
doesn't work, he'll try to cut other parts of the bill.

Conrad has said his bill is intended to cover two years of flooding, drought and
fires that ravaged crops in several states.

"This is not some outsized disaster assistance legislation; it is bare bones.
... We are down to $4.5 billion, as we have taken out things the White House
said they would object to," he said. "We took out the energy provisions, for a
savings of $1.8 billion. We stripped out some of the support for small
businesses for a savings of $215 million."

Conrad said bankers in his state have warned that if farmers and ranchers aren't
helped, 5 to 10 percent of them could go out of business.

In the House, Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Okla., is supporting a $3.3 billion aid
package, which he said could mean the difference for producers who lost crops in
2005 and this year.

"In my home county (Roger Mills), the wheat crop was a total failure," Lucas
said. Though the aid could be months after the losses were incurred, Lucas said
that's not necessarily unusual for federal disaster aid and still could
determine whether some producers survive.

"It never becomes irrelevant" whether they get the aid, he said, since the
losses can affect their long-term viability.

Coburn said he didn't know how much of a disaster package he would support, and
he is having staff members analyze losses and various factors involved,
including crop insurance coverage.

"Why have a crop insurance program if you're not going to require them to buy
it?" he asked. "Those that couldn't plant, we ought to help them, and we can
help them. But we have to pay for it."

                          Sunday Times (South Africa)

                               September 7, 2003

World's poor the losers as Cancun talks head for deadlock on farm subsidies

BYLINE: Lukanyo Mnyanda

SECTION: Economy, Business & Finance; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 730 words


SPREADING THE WORD: Filipino anti-globalisation demonstrators stage a torch
parade rally in Manila this week ahead of

the World Trade Organisation summit in Cancun, Mexico, beginning on Wednesday

World's poor the losers as Cancun talks head for deadlock on farm subsidies

New World Bank report makes the case for doing away with agricultural
protection, writes

Negotiations should revive the global economy and reduce poverty

THE widely anticipated failure of this week's global trade talks in Cancun,
Mexico, would represent a tragic lost opportunity for the world's poor.

In a new report, the World Bank says that liberalisation in agriculture alone
could benefit the global economy to the tune of $ 350-billion. Further, it says
that an appropriate deal addressing the concerns of developing nations could
spur global growth and reduce poverty for as many as

144-million people by 2015.

The report, Global Economic Prospects 2004: Realizing the Development Promise of
the Doha Agenda, comes on the eve of the meeting of world trade ministers in
Cancun, Mexico, which begins on Wednesday.

The meeting was supposed to review the progress being made following World Trade
Organisation (WTO) negotiations on the Doha Development Agenda. But the talks
have stalled on issues important to developing countries, including agricultural
reform, tariff reduction on manufactured products and special treatment for
developing countries.

Uri Dadush, the bank's trade department director, said successful negotiations
in Cancun were crucial to reviving the global economy and reducing poverty.

"If ministers can reach an agreement to reduce trade barriers affecting the
products that poor people produce - especially farm products and
labour-intensive manufacturing - it would help raise their standard of living.
If not, an opportunity will be lost. "

But the talks are expected to end in failure like the previous round in Seattle
in 1999, which was disrupted by violent

anti-globalisation protests.

Agriculture is expected to be the most divisive issue and developed countries
are expected to refuse to reform

and open up their agricultural markets to developing country farmers.

President Thabo Mbeki said this week he feared the Cancun talks would end in
failure, mainly due to the lack of a beneficial agreement on agriculture. Trade
and Industry Minister Alec Erwin will lead the SA delegation to the talks.

Disagreements over agriculture overshadowed a key agreement on legal changes to
make it easier for poorer countries to import cheaper generics to deal with
public health crises such as HIV/Aids.

The World Bank report said the global trading system was characterised by
inequities that drag down export growth in developing countries. "In agriculture
, for example, Japanese support to rice producers amounts to 700% of production
cost, which effectively shuts out exports from Thailand and other producers."

It said the European Union was spending around

$ 100-billion a year on direct budget subsidies to producers, depressing world
market prices in sugar, dairy and wheat.

One of the biggest culprits was the US, which spent

$ 50-billion annually on direct support to its agriculture sector alone. Its
annual cotton

subsidy expenditure of

$ 3-billion was three times its foreign aid to Africa.

The Bank said liberalisation would shift agricultural production from the
so-called North to developing countries, and boost world prices for many
commodities. For example, the price of rice in world markets would rise by as
much as 90%, while those for cotton, dairy products, groundnuts and sugar would
rise by 10%-40%.

Cutting protection and agricultural subsidies, which go mostly to large farmers,
would also benefit consumers in the developed world.

The Bank estimates that measures to protect large farmers cost the average
family in Japan, US and the EU about $ 1 000 a year.

The report concluded that a "good" WTO agreement could produce between $
290-billion and $ 520-billion in income gains for both rich and poor countries.

World Bank Chief Economist Nicholas Stern called on the rich countries to take
the lead in negotiating a fair outcome to the Cancun negotiations.

"They are the dominant players and account for

two-thirds of the global market," he says.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           December 7, 2006 Thursday
                                  City Edition

LEGISLATURE ;
Farm aid proposed

BYLINE: Michael McNutt, Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; CAPITOL BRIEFS; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 234 words


State leaders should prepare a relief package for farmers and ranchers because
Congress failed to pass a nearly $4.5 billion agriculture disaster relief
package, three state legislators said Wednesday.

"Oklahoma livestock producers and farmers are currently facing dire conditions
brought on by one of the worst drought periods in state history," said Sen. Jeff
Rabon, D-Hugo.

In September, the state got word of about $6.5 million from the U.S. Agriculture
Department to be distributed to livestock producers. Oklahoma farmers, however,
could be left with nothing if no federal aid is approved, he said.

With Oklahoma farmers in the second year of a devastating drought cycle, quick
action is necessary, he said.

State Sen. Earl Garrison, D-Muskogee, and state Rep. Terry Hyman, D-Leon, agreed
with Rabon.

Hyman said even if aid is eventually approved, it could take more than a year
before farmers receive funds.

GOVERNOR

School to get 500 books

Oklahoma first lady Kim Henry is giving 500 books to an Oklahoma City elementary
school participating in a reading event Friday.

Southern Hills Elementary, 7800 S Kentucky Ave., is one of more than 150 state
schools in the eighth annual read-a-thon.

Scholastic, a children's publishing, education and media company, provided the
books and created the read-a-thon. The event encourages students to read Friday
for at least 2,007 seconds, or about 33 minutes.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             March 27, 2016 Sunday

ON CAMPUS

SECTION: E; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 406 words


Two on dean's list

Kelsey Kramer, Bismarck, and

Erin Rector, Mandan, have been named to the Mayville State University fall
semester 2015 dean's list.

To be on the dean's list, a student must attain a grade-point average of 3.5 or
higher and successfully complete a minimum of 12 graded credit hours.

Gereszek 'shadows'

Six seniors from Minnesota State University Moorhead are working with Forum
Communications Co. professionals in a semester-long apprenticeship program. The
students shadow professionals as well as produce digital content and blogs for
the Forum.

Area student and her major is

Josie Gereszek, Bismarck, multimedia journalism.

The Marcil Center nurtures and develops future journalists as they study media
and innovative communication strategies.

Two on Creighton list

Catherine Bopp and

Mary Roller, both of Bismarck, were named to the fall dean's list for the
2015-16 academic year at Creighton University in Omaha, Neb.

Full-time students who earn a 3.5 grade-point average or better on a 4.0 scale
are eligible for the dean's list.

Miles scholarships

Miles Community College, Miles City, Mont., recently received an $8,000 donation
from Northwest Farm Credit Services/CoBank to be used toward scholarships for
freshmen and sophomore students enrolled in any of MCC's agriculture programs.
The scholarships will be awarded as four $2,000 scholarships for the 2016-17
academic year.

Incoming, full-time freshmen or sophomores who have a minimum 3.0 grade-point
average and are majoring in one of MCC's agriculture degrees are eligible to
apply for the scholarships. Interested students should complete the MCC
Scholarship Application form found at
www.milescc.edu/CampusServices/FinancialAid/scholarships.htm and submit it to
the Financial Aid Office by April 15. For questions about the scholarship,
contact the Financial Aid Office at 406-874-6208.

Coleman achieves

Bismarck resident

Charles Coleman made the academic dean's list at Azusa Pacific University in
Azusa, Calif. Coleman, an applied health major, is honored for a fall semester
2015 academic standing of a 3.5 or better grade-point average.

Wolfe earns award

Abby Wolfe, a sociology undeclared major in the Colgate University class of
2019, has earned the dean's award for academic excellence for the fall 2015
semester. The dean's award for academic excellence is awarded to students with a
3.30 or higher term average.

Wolfe, of Bismarck, is a graduate of Century High School.

                               The New York Times

                January 21, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final
                              Correction Appended

AID TO EX-SOVIETS IS BEING HINDERED

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 621 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20


Two months after Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan announced a $165
million program to send free American food to what was then the Soviet Union, no
food has been delivered and only one contract, worth $15 million, has been
awarded.

And that contract, providing for deliveries of mostly butter to Armenia, will
not be carried out until Feb. 20 because shipping companies refused to lease
refrigerated air-freight containers for fear they would be stolen, said the Rev.
Yeznig Balian, who is supervising the delivery for the Diocese of the Armenian
Church of America, which is based in New York.

As diplomats from four dozen nations and seven multilateral institutions prepare
for meetings in Washington on Wednesday and Thursday to coordinate assistance to
the former Soviet republics, aid programs remain bogged down by Western red tape
and Soviet corruption.

Theft There, Ultracaution Here

The disappearance of German food parcels from St. Petersburg docks, the
availability of Dutch ground meat on the Russian black market and the rejection
of free British beef by Moscow authorities with possible links to hoarders have
made headlines in the West.

The invisible twin of the problem there is caution verging on paralysis among
Western aid officials, who lack the staff to supervise large-scale deliveries
and find private voluntary organizations overwhelmed by the task.

The result is that while many Western and Russian experts warn that shortages
could provoke the overthrow of the democratic governments in the former Soviet
republics, any major Western assistance organized at the conference is unlikely
to arrive soon.

Frustration is also causing American and German officials to speak seriously of
sending humanitarian supplies with forces from the North Atlantic Treaty
Organization, which will be represented at the conference.

Pace Is Slowing, Not Quickening

The European Community has delivered barely half of the $300 million in food
grants it pledged 13 months ago, said a senior community official who insisted
on anonymity. None of the $600 million in food credits announced then has been
disbursed and almost none of a recent $250 million package of grants, he added.

Japan has pledged $600 million in aid and credits but has only just begun
deliveries after several months of worrying about who would repay the loans.

When Mr. Madigan announced the $165 million in food grants along with $1.25
billion in food credits on Nov. 18, the Agriculture Department had already been
negotiating for a month or more with nonprofit groups.

But the need to insure that these groups have realistic distribution plans,
guarding against spoilage and corruption, has kept a half-dozen contracts from
receiving final approval, said Roger D. Runningen, a spokesman for the
department.

A Warning from the Embassy

The delays have produced irritation at the highest levels of the American
Embassy in Moscow, Administration officials said.

The embassy has repeatedly warned the State Department that food must be shipped
more quickly, and is considering a plan to begin selling some food to Russian
officials to reduce the embarrassment of giving food away and then having it
show up in markets anyway, the officials said.

The food delivery issues will be taken up by a special committee at the
conference this week, led by Canada, Britain and Germany.

And for those who want to flee the uncertainties of the new economics in the new
republics, Foreign Minister Guido di Tella of Argentina said in an interview
published today that his country would be willing to accept up to 100,000
immigrants from the Russian minorities in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, Reuters
reported.


LOAD-DATE: January 21, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: January 23, 1992, Thursday

CORRECTION:

An article on Tuesday about food aid to the former Soviet republics omitted an
American contract, because of incorrect information provided by the Agriculture
Department. The department awarded a $1.2 million contract last week to the
Brother's Brother Foundation in Pittsburgh.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             August 23, 1996 Friday

LENGTH: 153 words


Applications for financial aid for the 1996-97 school term are being taken by
the North Dakota Grain Dealers Educational Foundation. Ten awards of at least
$500 per person are planned. Students must be enrolled in one of a number of
higher education curriculums. These include agribusiness sales and service,
agribusiness management or agriculture transfer at Bismarck State College,
University of North Dakota-Lake Region in Devils Lake, North Dakota State
College of Science in Whapeton, Dickinson State University, UND-Williston or
Minot State-Bottineau. It also includes agriculture economics, agriculural
systems management, crop and weed science, soil science and food science at the
College of Agriculture, North Dakota State University in Fargo. Scholarship
deadline is Sept. 30. Applications can be obtained by writing the Foundation
office at 212 Black Building, Fargo, N.D. 58102 or by calling 701-235-4184.

                         Morning Star (Wilmington, NC)

                           January 15, 2002, Tuesday

COMMON SENSE / Hampstead native ready to brave heat of diplomacy

BYLINE: Cantwell

SECTION: Local/State; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 586 words


A Hampstead native has become the new ambassador to the Central African
Republic.

Mattie Sharpless says it's not too hot there now, but she figures it will be in
a couple of months.

Since 1965, Ms. Sharpless has been working in foreign agricultural trade
relations. She plans to tap that expertise in helping the landlocked nation
develop its economy and battle the spread of AIDS.

Ms. Sharpless was appointed by the Bush administration and sworn in by
Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman in Washington on Oct. 23. She presented her
credentials in Bangui, the capital city, on Dec. 14, and has settled into the
ambassador's residence.

She is the daughter of Lecola Sharpless and the late James Sharpless of
Hampstead. She graduated from Pender County Training High School in Rocky Point
and received a master's degree in business administration and economics from
N.C. Central University in Durham.

She has participated in trade talks in Switzerland and worked in U.S. offices in
Paris, Rome and Brussels, Belgium. Before the ambassadorial appointment, she was
acting administrator of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Foreign
Agricultural Service.

I spoke with her last week. She's comfortable and feels safe in Bangui.

But it's a tough assignment.

The Central African Republic has seen factional fighting since mutinies in the
1990s. This month, the Security Council of the United Nations expressed concern
over the situation there.

"The United States is calling for reconciliation of various political entities,"
Ms. Sharpless said.

The violence has discouraged American companies from investing in the CAR.

"Because of those mutinies and continued political unrest, companies have
decided to sit back and see what the situation is going to be," she said. But
one U.S. company is exploring the possibility of drilling for oil there.

The World Wildlife Fund and other organizations are looking at the issues of
reforestation, replanting areas that have been denuded of trees. But it's not
easy to even examine the problem.

"The difficulty is getting to those areas," Ms. Sharpless said. "The roads are
not the best, and we don't always have airports to go where we want to go.

"It takes time to get to outlying areas."

The Central African Republic is slightly smaller than Texas, and it lies in
almost the exact center of Africa.

As in much of Africa, AIDS poses a serious threat. In 1999, nearly 14 percent of
the adults had HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.

"What's even more devastating is that the educated population - the teachers and
professors - are the hardest hit," Ms. Sharpless said. She speculates that's
because they are more prosperous and thus more mobile.

Life expectancy at birth is 44 years, according to the CIA's World Fact Book,
compared with 77 years in the United States.

She said government officials are hoping for U.S. help on educating the
children.

The U.S. Embassy is home to the Martin Luther King Cultural Center, which
teaches English and computer skills to people living in the capital.

I asked her how she's getting along.

"It's a very nice residence," she said. "I'm surprised to have electricity
almost everywhere I go."

"I find the weather much cooler than I had anticipated," she said. "I thought it
would be stifling and humid. I'm told in the next month or two I will see that."

"Common Sense" appears Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays and Sundays. Contact Si
Cantwell at 343-2364 or si.cantwellwilmingtonstar.com


LOAD-DATE: January 15, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Sharpless (mug shot)

                   Copyright 2002 Wilmington Star-News, Inc.

                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                              July 31, 1998 Friday
                                 Early Edition

US wheat gift a ploy, Fischer warns

BYLINE: BRENDAN NICHOLSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 608 words


CANBERRA

The United States was using a massive donation of wheat to Indonesia to move in
on one of Australia's major wheat customers, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim
Fischer, said yesterday.

Mr Fischer, who is also Trade Minister, said he accepted the need for
humanitarian aid, but questioned the motives behind the huge US donation.

He said he felt concern about the size of the donation and the fact it was going
to a traditional Australian market.

On the eve of today's AUSMIN (Australian-US Ministerial) talks, Mr Fischer said
the US move was as much about market penetration as it was about humanitarian
aid.

He quoted from a briefing given on 18 July by the US Secretary of Agriculture,
Mr Dan Glickman, about President Bill Clinton's donation of 2.5 million tonnes
of wheat to the world.

Mr Glickman said the new program was a bold initiative to respond directly to
one of the primary weaknesses in the farm economy of the US.

"Starting next week, USDA (US Department of Agriculture) will begin buying wheat
that will then be used for foreign food donations, opening new export channels
for American farmers."

Mr Fischer said he accepted the need for granting humanitarian aid.

"But it is the quantum, the massive size, the direction towards an Australian
traditional market and, on top of that, the objective of opening new export
channels which causes me great concern as Australia's Minister for Trade. I will
stand up for Australian farmers in respect of this," he said.

Mr Fischer's anger over the wheat export issue ensures the matter will be a
major issue at the AUSMIN talks.

But the US Secretary of State, Dr Madeleine Albright, referred only in passing
to the row when she addressed the Asia Society in Sydney yesterday.

"Obviously, we don't always see eye to eye," she told an audience that included
the Foreign Minister, Mr Alexander Downer, and many senior politicians,
diplomats and business leaders.

"In some economic sectors we are competitors as well as partners," Dr Albright
said.

Mr Fischer said Indonesia was an important and growing market involving about
three million tonnes of wheat a year.

As Australia's second-biggest wheat export destination, Indonesia bought about
$600 million worth of Australian wheat last year.

"It is a very significant market for Australia," Mr Fischer said.

He suggested that half a million tonnes of the free US wheat might go to
Indonesia, which "will distort our market".

Australia wanted the US to stick to President Clinton's commitment not to
"ambush" Australia's traditional export markets. The donation to Indonesia was a
clear breach of the spirit of that undertaking.

"Let's hope that further dialogue will help turn this around," Mr Fischer said.

He said the US move was as much about market penetration as it was about
humanitarian aid, and despite record Australian exports of $114 billion in the
past financial year, "these latest moves by the USA are a sharp reminder we
cannot be complacent."

But Mr Fischer hoped a concerted government campaign - including complaints by
the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, to Dr Albright - would help resolve the
problem.

Welcoming Mr Howard's involvement, the president of the National Farmers
Federation, Mr Ian Donges, said the US donation appeared to be a subtle form of
export subsidy or support to US wheat farmers.

The National Party's Senate Leader, Senator Ron Boswell, also accused the US of
breaching its undertaking to Australia not to subsidise agricultural exports.

The US must be told that Australia "will always be here whenever the US needs
it", he told ABC radio yesterday. He said the US was favored in terms of trade
between it and Australia.

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                            December 7, 1999 Tuesday

Farming challenge ;
 Another tough year likely for producers

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. 31

LENGTH: 581 words


CHICAGO - For many Illinois farmers, 1999 was the most challenging year they've
ever faced. And 2000 will likely bring more of the same, said Ron Warfield,
president of the Illinois Farm Bureau.

"I still believe in the future of farming, but you're going to see agriculture
change and change rapidly," said Warfield at the IFB's 85th annual meeting.

Despite $8 billion in federal aid this year, Warfield said farmers need more
than a temporary Band-Aid.

"As I talk to farmers across the state, there is a certain number saying, 'I
don't see a future. I'm going to get out while I still have equity,'" he said.
"I think things are better than the '80s, when we saw wholesale bankruptcies.
But we are going to lose a significant number of producers, even with the
federal aid."

Illinois Department of Agriculture Director Joe Hampton said he's hoping for a
strong turnaround.

" I'm very concerned about farmers. A lot of them had extraordinarily good
yields, which compensated for the low prices," said Hampton. "Some farmers are
doing OK and will hang on for a while. Some won't."

Generous help from the government, such as the $8 billion farmers received this
year, may not continue, said U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin.

"I don't believe it's politically sustainable to be putting in an emergency farm
aid bill year after year," said Durbin, a Springfield Democrat. "I voted for the
Freedom to Farm bill, but maybe it's time to amend it. If it continues to cost
$8 billion every year, then farmers need to readdress it."

Both Durbin and U.S. Sen. Peter Fitzgerald, R-Ill., said crop insurance reform
will be forthcoming.

The 2, 180 farmers attending the IFB convention, which runs through Wednesday,
also are concerned about mergers among major agribusinesses. Already this year,
Cargill has acquired Continental, DuPont purchased Pioneer, and Smithfield is
buying Carroll Foods and Murphy Family Farms.

"Now there are talks between Monsanto and Novartis," said Warfield. "Farm Bureau
was very vocal about the potential impact of these mergers on farmers and
agriculture."

Other issues that will be addressed in the group's resolution process, which
directs the IFB throughout the year, include biotechnology, a new farm bill,
risk management, the conservation reserve, alternative fuels, flood plain
regulation and contract production.

Farmer John Beatty of Auburn helped draft a resolution that will direct the IFB
to launch a campaign to inform consumers of the benefits of genetically modified
products, or GMOs.

Last year, he planted 50 percent of his crop in GMO corn and 50 percent in
traditional hybrids.

"I'm not going to do that this year," said Beatty. "I didn't have trouble
selling it because I'm a guy who sells out of the field. But there's too much
uncertainty.

"We need a unique method of distributing information about the safety of GMOs -
an infomercial or Jane Pauley or something. I'd like to see the big chemical
companies putting up billboards that say GMOs are wholesome foods."

On a brighter note, Rich Brauer of Oakford, president of the Illinois Pork
Producers, said things have begun to turn around for hog producers.

"People are seeing a light at the end of the tunnel," said Brauer. "This will
still be a tough year, as farmers have to talk to their bankers and get ready
for next year, but it looks a lot better than it did last year. Once we get past
the point of having too many hogs, demand will go up."

LOAD-DATE: June 29, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1999 The State Journal-Register

                              397 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                           September 23, 2005 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

Senate Rejects Bush Bid to Ease Delivery of Food To Poor Nations

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 435 words


A Bush administration proposal that sought to get food to starving people more
rapidly and efficiently was rejected by Senate leaders yesterday, but the
Canadian government announced that it was increasing the use of the same
technique.

Up to half of Canada's food aid budget may now be used to buy food in developing
countries near a hunger crisis, with the rest bought from Canadian producers.
Before, only 10 percent could be bought abroad.

Canada's minister of international cooperation, Aileen Carroll, said in an
interview that the new policy would permit Canada to spend more than $100
million in aid ''to get more food to more people more quickly.''

In contrast, under the food aid program run by the United States Agency for
International Development, with a budget of more than $1 billion, all food must
be bought in United States markets and most must be shipped on United States
-flagged vessels. Shipping costs consume 40 percent to 50 percent of the food
aid budget, and delivering the food typically takes four months.

The Bush administration asked that the aid agency be allowed to spend up to a
quarter of its food aid budget in or near the poor countries afflicted by hunger
crises. The Senate leadership declined to include such a provision in the
agricultural appropriations bill passed yesterday. The House did the same in
June.

Keith Williams, a spokesman for Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia
and chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said yesterday that there were
concerns that food aid bought abroad might not be delivered as reliably as aid
bought in the United States, and that such purchases might drive up food prices
and worsen scarcity in drought-stricken areas.

The American proposal appears all but dead, but Senator Mike DeWine, Republican
of Ohio and a member of the Appropriations Committee, said through his spokesman
that he would try to revive a scaled-down version when the bill goes to a
House-Senate conference committee.

He sought unsuccessfully yesterday to persuade Republican leaders of the Senate
Appropriations and Agriculture Committees to allow 10 percent of the food aid
budget to be spent in poor countries.

''There will be a time lag in how quickly we can get food in to help, and in
that lag there are children dying,'' his spokesman, Jeff Sadosky, said.

In the looming hunger crisis in southern Africa, Canada already buys corn in the
region. The World Food Program estimates that more than 10 million people will
need food in Malawi, Mozambique and Zambia, among other nations. At the same
time, South Africa has had a bumper corn crop.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company

                                US Official News

                             July 15, 2014 Tuesday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for
"Maintenance and Repair of Navigational Aids"

LENGTH: 228  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Forest Service Officer has issued requirement for
"Maintenance and Repair of Navigational Aids."

Solicitation no. AG-94TZ-S-12-0077                Posted on: July 15, 2014

Notice Type: Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 811

Description: The contractor shall provide any and all labor, equipment,
supervision, transportation, services, supply's/parts necessary to maintain a
system of navigational aids on six reservoirs within Tonto National Forest and
one reservoir on Coconino National Forest . Maintenance includes maintaining all
existing components of navigational aids, including all components of buoy
lines. And making all needed repairs, monitoring lake-level fluctuations and
making needed adjustments to buoy locations. Navigational aids include hazard
and controlled use buoys and buoy lines. Also included is on two mile beacon
light.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Feb 01, 2014 2:00 pm Mountain

Contact Details: 2324 E McDowell Road
Phoenix, Arizona 85006
United States

Point of Contact(s):
Elbert H. Hunt
ehunt@fs.fed.us
Phone: 602-225-5341
Fax: 602-225-5204

             Journal Record Legislative Report (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           September 7, 2006 Thursday

Livestock aid unlikely to help much, Oklahoma ag secretary says

BYLINE: Brian Brus

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 411  words


State Agriculture Department officials and industry leaders met Wednesday to
discuss a federal drought relief program for livestock producers that some say
they expect will help few Oklahomans.

The $6.04 million gift has mixed value, Secretary of Agriculture Terry Peach
said: On one hand, any funding is better than nothing. But the number of cattle
in Oklahoma reduces that funding per head to a negligible amount.

"Every little bit will help, but it's such a small amount," he said.

At the end of August, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced $780
million in federal aid to help farmers and ranchers "manage drought and
weather-related production challenges. '" That package includes a new program
earmarked with $50 million for livestock producers.

After that money is dispersed across the nation, Oklahoma will get the
second-largest portion out of 20 states directly affected by drought; Texas will
receive the most, at $14.51 million.

However, Peach said the maximum $10,000 a producer could receive, as described
in the USDA program outline, will be out of reach for all but the largest
commercial cattle operations. The actual aid to any particular producer will be
worth only a few hundred dollars.

"In the cattle industry alone, Oklahoma has over 2 million head. By the time we
add our sheep and goat and buffalo industries to that, and other livestock in
the state which have all suffered losses, it won't be a significant impact
hardly at all. "

Based only on 2 million cattle, the distribution of $6 million means about $3
per head. Peach said the actual aid needed is about 100 times that amount, a
figure in the billions of dollars.

The funding was unexpected and not requested by the states, Peach said, "So it's
a good gesture on Mr. Johanns' part. We're thankful for that.

"And actually, the U.S. Senate does have a $5 billion disaster program in their
'07 appropriations bill that they'll be looking at when they meet this fall," he
said. "So that would be enough to see a significant benefit. ... But this $6
million will be a hard program to administer. "

Moving the money will take time as well. Peach got feedback from industry
representatives Wednesday on how to best administer the program.

Because all the funds must be committed to the program's original purpose, "we
won't be able to issue any payments until all the sign-ups are completed," he
said. "It won't be a quick, easy fix. You won't sign up one day and get your
check the next. "

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           September 7, 2006 Thursday

Livestock aid unlikely to help much, OK ag secretary says

BYLINE: Brian Brus

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 413  words


State Agriculture Department officials and industry leaders met Wednesday to
discuss a federal drought relief program for livestock producers that some say
they expect will help few Oklahomans. The $6.04 million gift has mixed value,
Secretary of Agriculture Terry Peach said: On one hand, any funding is better
than nothing. But the number of cattle in Oklahoma reduces that funding per head
to a negligible amount.

"Every little bit will help, but it's such a small amount," he said. At the end
of August, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced $780 million in
federal aid to help farmers and ranchers "manage drought and weather-related
production challenges. '" That package includes a new program earmarked with $50
million for livestock producers. After that money is dispersed across the
nation, Oklahoma will get the second-largest portion out of 20 states directly
affected by drought; Texas will receive the most, at $14.51 million. However,
Peach said the maximum $10,000 a producer could receive, as described in the
USDA program outline, will be out of reach for all but the largest commercial
cattle operations. The actual aid to any particular producer will be worth only
a few hundred dollars. "In the cattle industry alone, Oklahoma has over 2
million head. By the time we add our sheep and goat and buffalo industries to
that, and other livestock in the state which have all suffered losses, it won't
be a significant impact hardly at all. " Based only on 2 million cattle, the

and get your check the next. "

                              403 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     April 30, 1991, Tuesday, Final Edition

Moscow Not Creditworthy For Grain Aid, Bush Says

David Hoffman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1

LENGTH: 711 words


President Bush said yesterday the Soviet Union "regrettably" is not creditworthy
enough to qualify for a requested $ 1.5 billion in additional guarantees to
purchase U.S. grain. Administration officials said the president's remarks were
based on an internal administration review that has recommended the Soviet
request be rejected.

But Bush has not yet notified Moscow of a decision, the officials said, adding
that the president also has been urged by advisers to tell Soviet President
Mikhail Gorbachev that the United States will look for other ways to offer aid
to the Soviet Union.

"I'd like to be helpful," Bush told a group of agricultural broadcasters at the
White House in answer to a question. The Soviet request, he said, is "still up
in the air."

Gorbachev wrote Bush last month seeking another $ 1.5 billion in credit
guarantees in addition to the $ 1 billion the United States offered in December.
If granted, the credits would allow the Soviets to buy U.S. wheat, corn and
soybeans or soybean meal, paying for the purchases with loans from U.S. banks
backed by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corp.

Under current law, the Soviet Union's creditworthiness is a major consideration
in deciding whether to award the guarantees, and officials said this is the
reason Bush is expected to reject the Soviet request. The Organization for
Economic Cooperation and Development, an international economic research group,
said recently that Soviet creditworthiness had deteriorated after many years of
being good.

The Soviet Union had large currency deposits in Western banks and huge gold
reserves at home that made it a good credit risk throughout most of the 1980s,
according to the research group. But, the group said, the Soviet Union's foreign
debt rose rapidly in the past few years as the Kremlin departed from what had
been extremely conservative borrowing practices.

The group said there was a "virtual collapse of central control over
international payments," which slipped badly in the last two years. The Soviet
Union's internal economic chaos contributed to its declining creditworthiness
abroad, the group said in a Feb. 27 survey.

Under the U.S. farm credit program, if the borrowing country fails to repay the
loans, the U.S. government, which guaranteed the loans, suffers a loss. The
United States, for instance, is expected to bear a loss on loans that were
guaranteed to Iraq, previously the largest recipient in the program.

Rejection of Gorbachev's appeal for more aid would come as a setback for the
Soviets, who have lobbied hard for the grain credits. Congressional and
administration officials have said the Soviets are primarily interested in
buying corn for use as animal feed.

"The legislation is fairly specific in terms of creditworthiness," Bush said
yesterday. "Regrettably," he added, "the Soviet Union has not entered into the
market reforms that I think Gorbachev aspires to, and that I know the president
of the [Russian] republic, Mr. [Boris] Yeltsin, aspires to.

"So they've got to move forward to be creditworthy if we're going to do this,"
Bush said. "Now, there may be -- and we're thinking about this -- there may be
some way to extend credits, but it would -- I'll tell you another problem, is we
want to be sure how it's distributed, that no area is precluded from getting
this kind of -- being the beneficiaries of this kind of credit."

The president was reflecting a widespread concern that the Soviet food
distribution system has broken down as the command economy has collapsed. U.S.
officials have said they also are increasingly sensitive to the struggle between
the republics and authorities in Moscow, and they want any aid to be balanced
between these rival power centers.

Officials said they did not know what other kinds of aid Bush may offer in lieu
of the grain credits.

"I don't want to say that I won't go forward with this," Bush said, adding that
it would benefit U.S. farmers, but "I've got to abide by the law.

"And if we can find ways to encourage forward movement on these credits, or find
ways to make it creditworthy any other way. . . . Market reform is a good way to
do it. There are other ways that perhaps they would make the credit more
secure."


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, PRESIDENT BUSH; PHOTO

TYPE: FOREIGN NEWS, NATIONAL NEWS

                               The New York Post

                             May 22, 2003, Thursday

W. RIPS FRANCE ON AIDS EFFORT$

BYLINE: DEBORAH ORIN Bureau Chief

SECTION: Sport+Late City Final; Pg. 006

LENGTH: 516 words


WASHINGTON - President Bush popped the weasels yesterday with swipes at Europe
that hit home in France as he challenged allies to do more to fight AIDS and
famine in Africa.

His tough talk came as Secretary of State Colin Powell headed to France last
night for the highest-level meetings since Paris led the "Axis of Weasel" in a
futile bid to block the U.S.-led war that toppled Saddam Hussein.

Bush's remarks also made it clear that he intends to speak from a post-Iraq
position of strength when he travels to Evian, France, in a little over a week
for an international G-8 huddle hosted by French President Jacques Chirac.

Bush challenged "our European partners" as well as Japan and Canada to
contribute more money to fight AIDS in order "to match their good intentions
with real resources."

"I will remind them that the clock is ticking," he added.

Bush said they must do more because "AIDS can be prevented, and AIDS can be
treated."

He pointed to his own $15 billion anti-AIDS plan, which Congress just passed, as
"the largest single up-front commitment in history" to fight a disease
worldwide.

The president also accused Europe of "impeding" efforts to fight starvation in
Africa by opposing genetically modified crops "because of unfounded,
unscientific fears" as he addressed Coast Guard Academy graduates in New London,
Conn.

In a final slap, he challenged "our partners in Europe" to immediately end
agricultural export subsidies that block farmers in Africa and Latin American
from "a fair chance to compete."

France is a prime beneficiary of the European Union's agricultural subsidies,
while Britain - America's closest ally in Iraq - feels it is hurt by EU
agricultural policy.

The White House yesterday officially announced Bush's Europe trip, which
features stops in Poland, Russia and France and may be capped by a visit to U.S.
troops in Kuwait or Qatar.

The brief White House announcement singled out "the warm ties between the Polish
and American people." Poland backed the Iraq war and even sent commandos.

By stressing America's leading role in helping Africa - and challenging Europe
to do a lot more - Bush could upstage what Chirac hoped to accomplish at the G-8
summit, where he's invited many developing countries and sought to bill himself
as their protector.

Today, the U.N. Security Council votes on a resolution to lift Iraq economic
sanctions. France and Russia had balked at the plan because it confirms
U.S.-British control of Iraq, but yesterday both said they'd vote yes.

"This is France's opportunity to recognize that they played a role in the last
debate [on the Iraq war] that was completely self-centered, in terms of looking
out for their own oil contracts," said a U.S. official.

Powell is slated to meet in Paris with other foreign ministers, including
France's Dominique de Villepin, who led the anti-war contingent at the United
Nations.


LOAD-DATE: May 22, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

while chatting with a cadet at the Coast Guard Academy graduation in New London,
Conn.  AP

                              406 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 March 9, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

THE STANDARD SCENARIO FOR AFRICAN FAMINE

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 873 words

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz.


The news report was familiar. More than 150 million Africans faced famine, the
United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said last September. What could
prevent such a disaster? Wealthy Western nations must provide ''massive
emergency shipments of cereal by the end of the year,'' the F.A.O. was quoted as
having said.

Thus, another of the periodic crises of starvation threatening some sizable
segment of impoverished humanity grabbed for international attention, and the
first step was taken in a three-step scenario for famine relief - a scenario
that by now is familiar.

Following the proclaimed threat comes the mobilization of assistance, through
the agencies of the United Nations and various bilateral arrangements. Reports
appear on breakdowns in the reliefdelivery system that emphasize the
incompetence or corruption of the receiving governments. The problem is made
personal by horror stories that feature descriptions of children with swollen
bellies and spindly legs.

Finally, after some months, it will be acknowledged that the crisis has passed.
The success of the relief program will be shouted by stressing how many people
have been saved from death.

However, these comments will hint at an inevitable ''next time'' when
international charity will be called upon to check the threat of enormous human
disaster.

The argument that relief programs are successful depends on the absence of piles
of stacked bodies of the starved dead. It is a false conclusion. Large-scale
famine may be avoided, not because of the organized relief effort but simply
because Africa's impoverished millions are, as yet, unready to submit to
starvation.

The fact is that such efforts, monumental exercises that they are, provide food
in piddling amounts when compared to the proclaimed need.

Such was the case in the threatened famine in the wake of drought in the Sahel
region of West Africa in 1973-1974. Six million to 10 million of the 24 million
people in the seven countries of the region were said to face imminent death
from hunger. The reaction by food donors was impressive. According to a Federal
Government report in August 1973, 625,000 metric tons of cereal were pledged by
the whole world for the two years of the crisis. United States aid was 256,000
metric tons (most of it from earlier ongoing programs), nearly 41 percent of the
world total.

However, even under the wildly optimistic assumption that all the food reached
its destinations, and at starvation rations of 1,000 calories per day, fewer
than 3.5 million people could have been fed in that crisis. Further, for 1973,
America's emergency assistance was less than 40 percent of its total food aid to
the region. The balance came from the previous commitments.

What happened to the millions whose deaths were predicted in the absence of food
aid? They survived. Traditional arrangements for food supply were enough to
outlast this crisis.

The Sahel was wounded by its encounter with drought. Significant environmental
deterioration was experienced, diminishing the region's capacity to rebound to
face the inevitable next time. There was a sharpening of hardship in a harsh
setting. And, yes, the sickly old and young died in greater numbers than normal
because of undernutrition-related disease. However, the needs of the Sahel and
places like it are not advanced by false cries of famine, however
well-intentioned they may be.

This highlights the awful irony of famine relief. The fire-brigade approach
focuses on the immediate problem, each time stated in more outrageous terms, as
a tactic to generate maximum food aid. The unfortunate result is to miss the
opportunity to address the underlying causes, contributing to what may be the
making of a false famine into a true one in the Sahel and elsewhere in Africa.

The remedy lies in building on, rather than draining, the great strengths of
Africa's village civilization. The effort to build stable nation-states and
prosperous industrial economies on the narrow base of raw materials produced for
export, introduced in the colonial period for a no more exalted purpose than
deriving a profit for empire, has proved beneficial to some Africans and
non-Africans alike. But obliging Africa's villages to produce first for the
consumption of others has undermined the very village selfsufficiency on which
the exploitive status quo depends.

Let there be no mistake about the risk. In Africa's future, there may indeed be
a failure of food production for local consumption. The consequences would be
horrific. Any relief program would be overwhelmed. Millions would die in weeks.
My guess is that they would go silently to their graves. Then, at least, the
problem of hunger in Africa would be solved.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
James M. Harkin, assistant professor of public administration at The University
of Arizona, did development work in Africa's Sahel region during the 1973-74
drought.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                              407 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                             The Gazette (Montreal)

                            August 28, 2004 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Minister cautious about mad cow relief: Meets American counterpart to discuss
costly crisis; warns producers not to be overly optimistic

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A10

LENGTH: 344  words

DATELINE: OTTAWA


Manhattan and mad cow may seem an unlikely combination, but Agriculture Minister
Andy Mitchell will be mixing the two today when he travels to New York City to
meet his American counterpart to lobby for an end to the costly mad cow crisis.

Before leaving, Mitchell tried to dampen expectations among desperate producers
that the U.S. border might swing open quickly following his first face-to-face
meeting with U.S. Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman.

"I think I'll measure the results (of the session) in terms of establishing a
relationship," Mitchell said in an interview shortly before meeting Veneman, who
is in New York for next week's Republican Party convention.

"But I am going to take the opportunity to state the Canadian position because I
think it cannot be stated enough," added Mitchell, who took over the agriculture
portfolio after the June 28 federal election.

The meeting comes as Ottawa has started to drop broad hints that as the crisis
drags on, more emergency aid could be coming for the cash-strapped industry.

Ralph Goodale, the federal finance minister from southern Saskatchewan, has been
suggesting recently that he might shake open Ottawa's piggy bank.

In March, just before the last federal budget, Ottawa announced a $1-billion
farm aid package that included $680 million in relief for cattle producers. That
also included a pledge from Goodale of more help if the border remained closed
"for a protracted period."

Goodale is now repeating that pledge to help cope with mad cow - "a serious
issue not just for producers but a serious issue for the country."

However, he isn't saying yet just how much aid might be made available.

That's good news for the Canadian Cattlemen's Association, which has developed a
long-term plan including emergency cash aid as well as initiatives for boosting
slaughter capacity, loan guarantees and market expansion.

New data shows the Canadian cattle industry is being crushed under the weight of
the 15-month long crisis that dates back to the discovery of single case of mad
cow on a ranch in northern Alberta.
