                              408 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                  November 16, 1988, Wednesday, Final Edition

U.S. Bishops Spell Out Food Policy;
Catholic Document Stresses Linkages

BYLINE: Marjorie Hyer, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A14

LENGTH: 458 words


The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, continuing their four-day meeting here
yesterday, adopted a comprehensive policy paper on food and agriculture and
established a permanent committee to implement it.

The wide-ranging document stresses interrelationships involving food production
and distribution: linkage between last summer's drought in Iowa and the higher
cost of bread in New York, between farm foreclosures in Illinois and increased
numbers of homeless in St. Louis, between poverty and hunger.

The document, adopted by a voice vote with no apparent opposition, applies to
agriculture the principles of the bishops' two-year-old pastoral letter on
economic justice.

"It is central to the church's teaching on human dignity that everyone has a
legitimate claim to the goods and services required to live a truly human life,"
the document says.

The statement expresses a strong preference for family farms over corporate
ownership, warns of the danger to consumers and agricultural workers of
pesticide use and urges farmers to "create or join cooperatives as a means of
self-development."

The committee will have educational and advocacy functions, Archbishop James
Roach of Minneapolis said. "Urban people need to understand that food and
agriculture are not just rural issues, they are global issues," he said.

Roach, a former president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops (NCCB),
said the Washington-based conference staff would work with agriculture
specialists of state bishops' conferences and the grass-roots staff of the
National Catholic Rural Life Conference to address issues raised by the
document.

In other business, Archbishop Roger Mahoney of Los Angeles reported that the
committee he heads to draft a new conference statement on AIDS plans to hold "a
series of interviews" here this week and hopes to have the project completed by
June.

In a closed session earlier this year, the bishops agreed to produce the new
statement. A previous document released on the subject last December was
criticized by the Vatican because it gave qualified approval of public-education
programs advocating condom use to prevent spread of the disease.

The more than 300 bishops adopted a $ 30.6 million budget for the NCCB. The
largest item, $ 8.2 million, is earmarked for migration and refugee services.

In his annual report, the Rev. William Byron, president of Catholic University,
cited the civil suit that was brought against the university by the Rev. Charles
Curran and is scheduled to be heard in D.C. Superior Court next month.

Curran, whom the Vatican declared ineligible to teach as a Catholic theologian
because of his dissent from church teaching on sexual ethics, is suing for
breach of contract.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, CONFERRING HERE WERE, FROM LEFT, AUXILIARY BISHOP OF RICHMOND
DAVID E. FOLEY, WASHINGTON CARDINAL JAMES A. HICKEY AND RICHMOND BISHOP WALTER
F. SULLIVAN. AP

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1988 The Washington Post

                              409 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                             October 1, 2006 Sunday

ACRES APART

BYLINE: Harold Brubaker, Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E01

LENGTH: 1000 words


The thousands of music fans who partied this weekend at the Farm Aid concert in
Camden raised as much as $1 million to promote the preservation of family farms.

When Farm Aid officials talk about "keeping family farmers on the land," they
imply that they are trying to save an endangered species. Yet, the reality is
that 95 percent of U.S. farms - excluding retirement and residential farms - are
owned and operated by families.

In recent years, Farm Aid organizers have added a twist to their mission: a
vision of family farms producing food for local consumers - which advocates call
the "good food movement."

"It began to dawn on us that food and farming were so closely linked that we
couldn't really separate them," Ted Quaday, Farm Aid program director said.

Farm Aid's evolution into an advocate for a direct connection between farmers
and consumers occurred over the last decade as a segment of the American public
became intensely interested in food: how it tastes and how it was produced -
especially with regard to farm animals.

What Farm Aid is reacting to is the 20th century's massive consolidation in
agriculture - which happened in step with other key sectors, such as banking and
energy. That consolidation eliminated more than two-thirds of American farms
since the 1930s as slaughterhouses, food processors and supermarkets grew and
gained economic leverage.

On the consumer side, demand for easier-to-prepare processed foods grew as women
entered the workforce, reducing the amount of time available to prepare meals.

The number of farms in the United States peaked at 6.8 million in the 1930s,
when 21 percent of the workforce was engaged in agriculture and Americans spent
about the same percentage of their disposable income on food.

Now, the United States Department of Agriculture counts 2.1 million farms -
though 10 percent account for 75 percent of production, and less than 2 percent
of Americans work in agriculture. Huge productivity gains that accompanied the
rise of industrial agriculture reduced the portion of income Americans spend on
food to 11.5 percent last year.

Seventy years of consolidation have created huge family-owned and
family-operated farms, such as Sheppard Farms Inc. in Cumberland County, N.J.,
owned by three brothers who employ 250 and raise 1,500 acres of peppers,
cucumbers, tomatoes and other fresh-market vegetables that are sold in
supermarkets locally and all over the country.

Despite the size of Sheppard Farms Inc., which has $8 million in annual sales,
Tom Sheppard does not hesitate when describing the operation. "We are a family
farm," with roots that go back more than 300 years, he said.

At the other end of the farming spectrum, George and Melanie DeVault cultivate
three acres of their 20-acre Pheasant Hill Farm in Lehigh County.

"We try to sell everything we grow as close to where it's grown as possible,"
George DeVault said. The DeVaults used to haul their fruits, vegetables and cut
flowers more than 50 miles to a market in Philadelphia. When a market opened in
Telford, 30 miles closer, they moved there. Now, they sell at a Sunday market in
Emmaus, which is only three miles away.

The DeVaults, who have other income, represent the kind of locally based farming
Farm Aid promotes, in DeVault's words: "producing food for people and selling it
directly so the farmer gets all the income from it."

Mainstream agricultural economists scoff at the idea that such a regional food
system can meet Americans' food needs.

"There's a good reason why we don't produce most of our own food," Jim Dunn of
Pennsylvania State University said. "Part of it is specialization, part of it
has to do with the seasons we have," which impose serious limits on production.

"We do what we're good at, and we let other people do what they are good at," he
said.

Brian Snyder, executive director of the Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable
Agriculture, said local or regional food systems might be the only way to feed
the world in the long run because heavily subsidized conventional agriculture is
input-intensive and damages the environment.

Besides, he said, industrial-farming advocates "ignore the technological
advances that allow for season extension, better utilization of marginal lands,
and intensive farming on a smaller scale."

Snyder's nonprofit in Milheim, Pa., which runs educational programs for farmers
and works to build markets, has received $17,500 in grants from Farm Aid since
2004.

Since 1985, Farm Aid has granted $93,500 in Pennsylvania, Quaday, the program
director, said. Almost half the money went to the nonprofit group FoodRoutes
Network, which promotes local food systems. The group has not made any grants in
New Jersey.

Farm Aid said it had raised more than $29 million since 1985 and had spent 84
percent of it on programs "to build and strengthen family-farm food production."

A big reason for the widespread perception that corporations dominate American
agriculture is the proliferation of production contracts in poultry and pork
production.

Under such contracts - which account for almost all poultry production and 60
percent of hog production - the farmers own the buildings and equipment, but not
the animals. The contractor owns the animals, supplies the feed, decides when
the animals go to market, and pays the farmer to raise them.

Some critics of industrial agriculture said this system took too much control
out of the hands of farmers.

Jim Brubaker, a Union County, Pa., farmer disagreed.

Brubaker and his two sons - with no hired help - farm 600 acres of corn and
soybeans, fatten 6,300 hogs at a time for a contractor that supplies Hatfield
Quality Meats, and produce a million kosher broilers a year.

"I don't consider myself to be a serf or a slave to the integrator," said
Brubaker, who had an independent hog operation until 1993, but switched because
of declining profit. "They can't exist without us. We can't exist without them."

Contact staff writer Harold Brubaker at 215-854-4651 or
hbrubaker@phillynews.com.

LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2006 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved

                              The Washington Post

                           October 10, 2002 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

IN BRIEF

SECTION: ANNE ARUNDEL EXTRA; Pg. T06

LENGTH: 823 words


The Anne Arundel County Department of Health will conduct vision and hearing
screenings for preschool, kindergarten and third- and eighth-grade public school
students, private school students, and children in day-care centers and
nurseries.

Children are screened in order to detect vision or hearing problems that may
hinder their ability to perform successfully in school. If a potential
deficiency is detected, a letter will be sent to the child's parents or
guardians.

Children who wear glasses should bring them on the day of the screening.

The following schools will hold screenings in October:

Oct. 17 Aleph-Bet Jewish Day School

Kneseth Israel Nursery School

Severn School

Oct. 18 Kneseth Israel Nursery School

Oct. 21 and 22 Marley Elementary

Solley Elementary

Oct. 23 and 24 Meade Heights Elementary

Pasadena Elementary

Oct. 25 Creative Gardens Learning Center of Annapolis

Oct. 28 and 29 Bodkin Elementary

Crofton Woods Elementary

Oct. 30 and 31 Corkran Middle

Crofton Middle

For more information about the health department's school vision and hearing
program, call Anna M. Edwards at 410-222-0071.

In October, the Maryland Higher Education Commission will hold financial aid
workshops geared toward high school seniors preparing for college. October is
also a good time, according to the commission, for students to tour college
campuses, meet with college faculty and staff, and contact college financial aid
offices.

The following is a list of Maryland Higher Education Commission financial aid
workshops:

Oct. 17 7 p.m., Frederick Douglass High School, Prince George's County

Oct. 18 7 p.m., Chapelgate Christian Academy, Howard County

Oct. 22 7 p.m., Hereford High School, Baltimore County

Oct. 23 6 p.m., University of Maryland, College Park

7 p.m., Howard High School, Howard County

Oct. 24 6:30 p.m., Center of Applied Technology North, Anne Arundel County

Oct. 26 11 a.m., Largo High School, Prince George's County

For more information about state financial aid programs, call the commission's
office of student financial assistance at 410-260-4565, or visit its Web site at
www.mhec.state.md.us.

The Anne Arundel County Department of Parks and Recreation is slated to receive
a $ 118,250 grant for land preservation from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The county department will receive the grant next month, and the money will be
used in conjunction with the Maryland Agriculture Preservation Program, which
helps owners of farms, woodlands and other qualified properties preserve their
land.

During the past 20 years, the county's Department of Parks and Recreation has
preserved more than 10,000 acres of farm and woodland.

For more information call Barbara Polito, parks and recreation preservation
program manager, at 410-222-7317.

World Heritage, a nonprofit student exchange program, is seeking a local
representative to screen potential host families; plan annual family and student
orientations; meet with local high schools; provide support counseling; and
visit exchange students and their host families.

Representatives would also help students -- who come from Germany, France,
Spain, Japan, Thailand, Mexico, Great Britain and Brazil -- and their host
families to organize social and recreational activities.

The ideal candidate should enjoy fostering international friendships, be
community-minded and enjoy working with teenagers. Community representatives
will spend an average of two to four hours a month with each student and his or
her host family.

For more information call Eileen Coen at 800-888-9040, or visit the World
Heritage Web site at www.world-heritage.org.

The Pasadena Senior Center, at 4103 Mountain Rd. in Pasadena, will host a
"Girls' Night Out" from 4 to 6 p.m. Wednesday.

The evening, billed as a fun and informative night for women, includes a dinner,
door prizes and a discussion about breast cancer treatment and prevention.

The program is free, but reservations are required. For more information or to
reserve a slot, call the Anne Arundel County Department of Health at
410-222-7979.

The Severna Park branch of the American Association of University Women (AAUW)
will hold a book drive from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Oct. 19 in the parking lot of the
Arnold Safeway on Ritchie Highway, and the Severna Park Safeway on Benfield
Road. Members of the AAUW will be on hand at both sites to accept book donations
and provide receipts.

The organization will hold a book sale in November to raise money for their
scholarship fund, which assists Anne Arundel Community College graduates who
want to attend four-year institutions.

In addition to Saturday's collection drive, people can drop books in AAUW
collection bins, which are in front of the Safeways in Arnold and Severna Park;
the Severna Park Giant on Ritchie Highway; and the Annapolis Safeway on Forest
Drive.

For more information call 410-647-6232.

-- Compiled by Eileen Rivers

                              411 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                            August 16, 2011 Tuesday
                                  Main Edition

GREGOIRE SEEKS FEDERAL DISASTER AID FOR FARMERS;

BYLINE: Jim Camden<P>jimc@spokesman.com, (509) 879-7461<P>

SECTION: A; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 362 words

DATELINE: OLYMPIA


Here's one more thing to consider when complaining about this year's weather:
All 39 counties in Washington may be "disaster areas" and eligible for farm
disaster aid because of several hard freezes last winter and the cool, wet
spring.

Chris Gregoire asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to begin the process for
determining disaster relief across the state, which would make farmers who
sustained significant crop losses eligible for emergency loans and other aid.

It's an unusual request on several counts. For one, it's not tied to any single
event, like a hailstorm, tornado or flood, where the damage is immediately
apparent. For another, some of the crops are actually looking good as harvest
gets under way.

In a letter to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, Gregoire listed weather
problems for each of the state's counties, ranging from "excessive rain and cool
spring" throughout Eastern Washington's wheat counties and the Puget Sound area
to "freeze, frost and excessive rain" in Benton and Yakima counties.

"It is unusual that this happened throughout the state," Chris Bieker, of the
U.S Farm Service Agency. "All 39 counties may not get a primary disaster
designation."

Farmers are being asked to report their losses to the FSA. If there's a 30
percent loss to a particular crop in a county, farmers with losses in that
county and the adjoining counties could be eligible for emergency loans and
supplemental payments to make up for lost revenue, Bieker said. There's also a
tree assistance program that could help orchardists who lost trees to the frosts
in November and February.

The losses won't be known until after harvest, she said, and the cool weather
has delayed harvest in many parts of the state.

While the overall apple crop looks good right now, some orchards, vineyards and
berry farms were hit hard by deep freezes.

"This is turning out to be a really good crop for winter wheat, but not spring
wheat," Bieker said. The wet spring made it difficult to plant spring wheat. It
also caused rust, a fungus, in the winter wheat that farmers had to spray in
time to save their crops. She added, however, "It's not a good crop until it's
in."

                                Replate Edition

                              413 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     July 22, 1995, Saturday, City Edition

What happened in Congress

SECTION: NATIONAL; WASHINGTON; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 475 words



Abortion: The House Appropriations Committee continued to vote to limit
abortion rights, approving amendments Friday that would permit states to deny
Medicaid abortions to victims of rape or incest and to prohibit the federal
government from penalizing medical residency programs that choose not to
provide training in abortions. On Thursday, the committee approved amendments
restricting federal embryo research and abolishing the government's family
planning program.

Big business: The House voted to continue spending tax dollars to promote  U.S.
agricultural exports, a program widely criticized as a leading example of
corporate welfare. Instead of killing the program, House members increased
funding for the Department of Agriculture's Market Promotion by 30 percent  from
last year - for a total of $ 110-million. The program provides grants to  such
corporate giants as McDonald's, Pillsbury, Campbell Soup, Welch's Foods,
Sunkist Growers, Gallo Wines, and Tyson's Foods to help finance overseas trade
shows and advertising. House members also easily defeated attempts to limit
grants to corporations with revenues of more than $ 20-million and to prohibit
grants to promote the sale of U.S. wines, whiskies and other alcohol.

Military: The Senate approved an $ 11-billion defense construction bill that
includes $ 4.2-billion for military family housing and homeowners' aid. Defense

 Secretary William Perry has called family housing a top priority.

Packwood: The clubby atmosphere of the U.S. Senate wilted Friday amid
Republican threats to revisit Chappaquiddick if Democrats press for public
hearings on the sexual misconduct charges against Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore.
Despite the hints about an investigation of Sen. Ted Kennedy's involvement in
the 1969 Chappaquiddick tragedy, Sen. Barbara Boxer of California renewed her
demand for public hearings on the Packwood case. Boxer plans to introduce
legislation next week requiring senators to vote on whether they favor public
hearings on Packwood's conduct.

Whitewater: The White House announced that it had reached a preliminary
agreement with a special Senate Whitewater committee to provide a more  complete
disclosure of the files removed from the office of the deputy counsel  Vincent
Foster Jr. after he died. Senate Republicans complained that many  pages
submitted from Foster's files were so heavily edited as to be utterly
unhelpful.

Ovation: Rep. Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat, got a standing  ovation
from colleagues Friday. Richardson negotiated for three months with  Iraq's
ambassador to the United Nations to help win release of William Barloon  of Iowa
and David Daliberti of Florida. The men were sentenced to eight years  in Iraqi
prison for crossing the Kuwaiti-Iraq border March 13.

LOAD-DATE: July 24, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1995 Times Publishing Company

                              414 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            December 12, 2010 Sunday

Despicable behavior

LENGTH: 210 words


Colleges and universities -- whose tuition hikes far in excess of inflation are
enabled by government grants and loans to students -- have no business
redefining food stamps as another form of "financial aid" and encouraging
students to apply for them.

Yet many -- including Oregon's Portland State University, Iowa State University
and Ivy-League Cornell University -- are doing just that, The Daily Caller
reports. Thus, they're teaching a pernicious entitlement mentality.

Part of the problem is the U.S. Department of Agriculture's 2008 rebranding of
food stamps as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, which has lessened
the stigma associated with receiving them. With more than 42 million Americans
receiving government food assistance this year -- six million more than last
year -- it's all too easy to view it as just one's "fair share."

But, again, government "aid" only gives higher education cover to stick it to
students. And then places like Portland State, Iowa State and Cornell have the
audacity to encourage food-stamp use to ease the financial pain they have
inflicted?

That's despicable behavior. And it should force government at the federal and
state levels to critically question the practice and sanction those who employ
it.

LOAD-DATE: December 12, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           October 31, 2015 Saturday

Head Line: US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri) Issues
Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 277  words

DATELINE: Lahore


   WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAG-S-16-0007

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: October 30, 2015

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-16-0007 (2000003704)  for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after October 30, 2015, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near November 4, 2015.



   Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Janet Cleveland, Grain Marketing Specialist
janet.cleveland@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 816-926-2540

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            August 28, 2001 Tuesday

Wisconsin Briefs

BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Pg. a10

LENGTH: 435 words

DATELINE: GREEN BAY


Beef recalled over potential for E. coli

American Foods Group is voluntarily recalling more than 530,000 pounds of ground
beef in 17 states because the food might be contaminated with a strain of the
deadly E. coli bacteria.

No illnesses have been associated with the beef, the Green Bay-based company
said in a statement Sunday night.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture found a sample of the E. coli strain known as
0157:H7 while testing the meat produced Aug. 2.

The ground beef was distributed to Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana,
Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South
Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia and Wisconsin.

It has a sell-by date of Aug. 19, 2001, and a label with the USDA establishment
number 410. The 530,118.62 pounds of ground beef was shipped to retailers in
three-, five- and 10-pound packages, but might have been repackaged at the
retail level.

Anyone with the recalled meat can return it to the store where they purchased it
for a full refund.

McCallum intends to veto kindergarten-aid reduction

MADISON - Gov. Scott McCallum said he will veto a budget measure that would
reduce state aid for 4-year-olds' kindergarten classes.

McCallum says he believes in early education, but one legislator says children
are better served in the care of their family and not the government.

President Bush will visit Green Bay on Labor Day

DETROIT - President Bush will return to Wisconsin just two weeks after his last
visit.

Bush is planning to visit Detroit and Green Bay, Wis., on Sept. 3 "to celebrate
the values of hard work and responsibility with working Americans," White House
officials told the Detroit Free Press in Monday's editions.

Suspect steals police car

NEW GLARUS - An 18-year-old man stole a police car and used its police radio to
try to elude authorities, police said.

Police came to a New Glarus residence Sunday to respond to a report that the man
was sleeping in a parked vehicle in the garage of a private residence, said
Police Chief Steen Allbaugh.

They apprehended the man, put him in the back seat of the police car and
interviewed people at the residence. While they were talking, Allbaugh said the
man "entered the front seat of the squad by going through the partitioned cage
and stole the police vehicle."

The man drove off, and while Green County law enforcement tried to find him, he
"utilized the police radio, giving false locations where he was traveling,"
Allbaugh said.

The squad car was found abandoned a couple of hours later.

LOAD-DATE: September 4, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2001 Woodward Communications, Inc.

                              420 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             June 13, 2013 Thursday

Washington: U.S. Aid Experts Back Proposed Changes in Food Delivery

LENGTH: 779 words

DATELINE: Washington


US Embassy in London, The Government of USA has issued the following news
release:

Two former senior U.S. officials have urged Congress to reform the country's
system of delivering food aid to include local and regional procurements.

"The costs of procuring in the U.S. and transporting the commodity [are] higher
than purchasing the commodity locally," Andrew Natsios said referring to a 2012
U.S. Department of Agriculture assessment of the current food aid delivery
system. A former administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development
(USAID), Natsios is a professor of government and public service at Texas A & M
University.

"The lower costs and greater efficiency are not the only benefits of the
reforms," Natsios testified June 12 before the House Committee on Foreign
Affairs. Reforms, he said, "will allow our food aid to reach more people at the
same cost."

The current U.S. food aid program requires that 50 percent of donated food aid
be U.S.-produced and shipped on U.S.-flagged vessels to locations around the
world. It requires that 15 percent of the aid be monetized -- or donated to aid
organizations that then sell the food in local markets and use the proceeds to
finance a variety of development projects.

Advocates for change say the current system is both outdated and inefficient, as
it can take weeks for food to arrive at its destination. In addition, they say,
food aid that is monetized damages local economies.

Former Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman said change is needed for other
reasons as well. "While great progress has been made over the past several years
to enhance the prepositioning of U.S. commodities to increase response time and
strengthen early warning systems to better prepare for weather-related shocks,
much more can be done to improve the flexibility of our food aid system," he
said. Glickman is the executive director of the Aspen Institute Congressional
Program.

"This new model pairs the continued purchase of the best of American agriculture
with the flexibility of increased local and regional purchase, cash transfers
and electronic vouchers," USAID states on its website.

Natsios said that USAID estimates that under the proposal as many as 4 million
more people could receive food aid. He said there is "considerable evidence"
that purchasing food locally boosts local economies, supports farmers with more
knowledge of local markets, improves housing and cash incomes and reduces the
need for middle men.

U.S. agribusiness, shippers and labor unions support keeping the current system.
"Shipping a cargo load of food rather than the money to buy food if it is
available is the best and most secure way to ensure that taxpayer-funded
international food assistance actually makes it to hungry people overseas,"
American Farm Bureau President Bob Stallman argued in a May 15 statement posted
on the organization's website.

However, the mood among some in the food business is changing, with the National
Farmers Union and agribusiness giant Cargill recently expressing support for
food aid reform, Glickman said.

The proposed change would retain U.S. purchases of food aid when it is "the most
appropriate response such as when buying food locally might increase food
prices," Natsios said. In addition, many so called ready-to-use therapeutic
foods and processed foods will continue to be purchased in the United States,
USAID says.

In April, Representative Ed Royce, a Republican from California and the
committee's chairman, and subcommittee ranking minority member Karen Bass, a
Democrat for California, introduced legislation to reform the food aid program
to feed more people, more quickly, at lower cost.

"Modernizing U.S. international food aid to help more people facing starvation,
more quickly, at a lower cost is common sense, especially given our national
debt. By reforming food aid, we can reach more people in need, while at the same
time saving hundreds of millions of dollars", Royce said.

Since 1954, U.S. international food aid programs have helped feed more than 3
billion people and promoted food security in more than 150 countries, according
to USAID.

Earlier in May, the House and Senate agriculture committees reauthorized the
food aid program but left it largely intact in the agriculture budget.

The Senate then voted to make modest changes to the food aid delivery system,
but in a scaled-back version of Obama's proposed overhaul.

House and Senate negotiators next must agree on a compromise before sending it
for final congressional action and then, if approved by both chambers again, to
the president for signature or veto.

For more information please visit: http://london.usembassy.gov

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                               February 26, 2000

New policy urged to replace 'damage-control'

BYLINE: By

SECTION: Agriculture: USA, Pg.21

LENGTH: 348 words


DETAILS of America's new farm regime have emerged, with one Government official
saying that the country cannot simply keep lurching from one expensive bailout
to another.

Gus Schumacher, under secretary at the US Department of Agriculture, said: "It's
expensive, it's inefficient, it's hard on our farmers, it's hard on our
overworked USDA staff and it's hard on the taxpayers.

"It is time to move beyond annual damage-control to a stable policy that helps
farmers prepare for disasters and price downturns, invest in long-term market
development and export-promotion programmes and gives them the tools they need
to thrive - not just survive."

Mr Schumacher said America's Freedom to Farm Act - hailed in 1996 as a
revolutionary approach to agricultural support - had caused considerable
uncertainty in the countryside, forcing the administration to plough in more
than GBP 15billion in emergency aid in the last two years.  There was little
support for its continuation.

Now under consideration, and the package most likely to emerge, is the injection
of about GBP 6billion to provide an improved safety net for US farmers until the
Act's end in 2002.

It would help farmers through their current difficulties, said Mr Schumacher.

He added: "We need a firmer kitchen chair with a stronger back for America's
farmers. In essence, our proposal moves US farm policy in a new direction from
ad hoc emergency aid to reliable, counter-cyclical assistance that makes
planning easier for farmers.

"It also takes aid, unrelated to need, to assistance that is targeted to small
and medium-size producers during times of greatest need and from a fragmented
system to a more holistic and national approach that covers more commodities,
more producers and more regions of the country - and includes additional
conservation efforts and expanded crop insurance.

"This plan would help prevent costly, ad hoc emergency assistance bills like the
ones we've passed for the past two years. Instead, a plan for assistance would
already be in place, ready to kick in when farmers need help."

                            December 20, 2013 Friday

BRIEF: USDA: Counties in Grand Forks region qualify for aid

BYLINE: Grand Forks Herald

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 134 words


Dec. 20--Several counties in the Grand Forks region have been designated primary
natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Since the start of the year, farmers have suffered losses caused by multiple
disasters that ranged from spring snowstorms and flooding to hail damage and
weather-related insect infestations, the department said.

Counties included in the disaster listing include Benson, Cavalier, Grand Forks,
Nelson, Pembina, Ramsey, Traill and Walsh.

Counties adjacent to these are also eligible for federal aid, including Griggs
and Steele in North Dakota and Kittson, Marshall, Norman and Polk in Minnesota.

            Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                            December 14, 2012 Friday

Lancaster Farmland Trust Gets$10,000 From Farm Aid Concert

SECTION: B; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 207  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


The Lancaster Farmland Trust will benefit from Farm Aid's 2012 concert
profits---- to the tune of $10,000.

The award, announced Wednesday by Farm Aid in Cambridge, Mass., will support the
trust's Next Generation Farming Initiative.

LFT was one of 67 family farm and rural service organizations nationwide given
$532,300 in all.

A total of $49,000 is being handed over to farmers and organizations pursuing
sustainable farming and ag education and local food systems in Pennsylvania,
where the 27th annual Farm Aid concert was held Sept. 22 at Hersheypark Stadium.

Legendary musicians and founding Farm Aid board members Willie Nelson, Neil
Young and John Mellencamp were featured at the sold-out, all-day event. The bill
also included artists Kenny Chesney and Dave Matthews, a board member who began
playing Farm Aid concerts in 1995.

The trust received its grant under Farm Aid's "Helping Farmers Thrive" category.

Other Pennsylvania grant recipients included the Pennsylvania Association for
Sustainable Agriculture in Millheim, which received a total of $20,500; Rodale
Institute, Kutztown, "$10,000; and The Seed Farm, Allentown, $7,500.

In addition, according to Farm Aid, three Pennsylvania farm families in crisis
received grants of $500 each.

USDA SCHOLARSHIPS

BYLINE: David Landis

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. 1D

LENGTH: 166 words


The Agriculture Department announced Monday a $ 2.8 million scholarship fund for
students at 17 historically black land-grant colleges and universities. The
four-year National Scholars Program, offering at least 34 scholarships a year,
is open to students studying agriculture or related subjects at the 17 mostly
Southern schools. Participating students must agree to work one year for USDA
for each year of scholarship.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            December 4, 2006 Monday
                                  City Edition

Coburn plans to block ag disaster aid bill

BYLINE: Chris Casteel, Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 785 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON - Though he favors helping some farmers hit hard by the drought and
other weather problems, U.S. Sen. Tom Coburn plans to block an attempt this week
to approve nearly $4.5 billion in agriculture disaster aid.

Coburn, R-Muskogee, said the aid package pushed by some Midwestern senators is
too large and would cover too many producers.

He said aid should be targeted at those who weren't able to plant a crop, not
for crop losses that could have been covered by federally subsidized insurance.

And he said any aid should be paid for by cutting spending in other areas.

"If we're going to do relief for the farmers, we can't say, 'We'll take care of
you and give the bill to your grandkids,'" Coburn said.

A Senate vote could come Tuesday on an aid package proposed by Sen. Kent Conrad,
D-N.D., who pared his request from nearly $5 billion to about $4.5 billion.

Conrad is expected to offer his proposal as an amendment to the annual
agriculture appropriations bill.

Coburn said he will try to block Conrad's package on a procedural move, raising
the point that its cost is not offset by cuts elsewhere.

If that fails, he said, he'll try to cut other parts of the agriculture spending
bill.

In debate on the Senate floor two weeks ago, Conrad defended his package, saying
it is intended to cover two years of flooding, drought and fires that ravaged
crops in several states.

Conrad said, "This is not some outsized disaster assistance legislation; it is
bare bones. ... We are down to $4.5 billion, as we have taken out things the
White House said they would object to. We took out the energy provisions, for a
savings of $1.8 billion. We stripped out some of the support for small
businesses for a savings of $215 million."

He said the package would cover anybody who had a loss of at least 35 percent
and that it still only would cover a percentage of the loss.

"The bankers of my state have told me if this kind of assistance is not
forthcoming, 5 to 10 percent of the farmers and ranchers in our state will go
out of business, not because of any fault of theirs, but because of the most
incredible swing in weather that we have ever seen," Conrad said.

In the House, Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Cheyenne, has been pushing for a $3.3 billion
aid package.

In an interview last week, Lucas said parts of Oklahoma still are "desperately
short of moisture," and the aid could mean the difference for producers who lost
crops in 2005 and this year.

"In my home county (Roger Mills), the wheat crop was a total failure," he said.

Though the aid could be months - or even more than a year - after the losses
were incurred, Lucas said that's not necessarily unusual for federal disaster
aid and still could determine whether some producers survive.

"It never becomes irrelevant" whether they get the aid, he said, since the
losses can affect their long-term viability.

Coburn said he didn't know how much of a disaster package he would support, and
he is having staff members analyze losses and various factors involved,
including crop insurance coverage.

"Why have a crop insurance program if you're not going to require them to buy
it?" Coburn asked.

"Those that couldn't plant, we ought to help them, and we can help them. But we
have to pay for it."

Spending bills in limbo

The debate over the aid package could be academic if congressional leaders
determine that no more spending bills can be finished and sent to the White
House before Congress adjourns for the year.

Lawmakers again failed to get most of their spending bills completed this year,
and there was speculation that the remaining ones would be combined into one
bill, as has been done in previous years.

However, after the elections swept Republicans from power in both houses, the
talk turned to pushing off the tough work until January, when the Democrats
officially take over.

Coburn and other conservative senators didn't want a single spending bill
because of the tendency for such bills to get loaded with so-called pork barrel
projects.

"I don't want an omnibus bill," Coburn said. "There are way too many earmarks in
there."

He said it would be "much better" to approve a resolution that will continue
federal spending at current levels until February.

Then, he said, lawmakers could do the necessary work on the individual spending
bills.

And he said an agricultural assistance plan could be developed.

Lucas isn't optimistic an agriculture disaster package could be approved in the
remaining few days that Congress will meet this year. All the signals coming out
of the Senate, he said, indicate that real spending decisions would be delayed
until next year.

"It means the new majority will have to finish up the budget process," he said.

LOAD-DATE: October 19, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Photo 2: Rep. Frank Lucas
The Republican from Cheyenne has been pushing for a $3.3 billion aid package.

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 6, 1993, Thursday

US OFFICIALS: RUSSIAN PORTS ADD TO COST OF GRAIN AID

BYLINE: WILLIAM DiBENEDETTO; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 634 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Clinton administration officials and House members, discussing high U.S. carrier
costs to transport grain to Russia, attributed much of the blame Wednesday to
discriminatory delays and congestion at former Soviet ports, unfair or
unanticipated delivery requirements and pressures from the "Russian mafia."

U.S. carrier representatives said Russian chaos and U.S. government practices
push up freight rates, but added that the difference between U.S. and foreign
transportation rates to Russia are not as great as has been portrayed. Sources
have reported bids as high as $ 138 a ton, compared to foreign rates of 25 a
ton.

Still others crowding into a House appropriations panel's review of the
transportation costs surrounding the $ 700 million aid package to Russia
Wednesday were critical of the cargo preference law, which reserves the bulk of
the aid for U.S. bottoms.

Sen. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, said it involved "nothing less than legalized
piracy" for the "welfare queens of the sea."

Members of two House Appropriations Committee subcommittees - Agriculture, Rural
Development Food and Drug Administration, and Commerce, Justice, State and
Judiciary - tried to sort through a blur of explanations and rate quotations in
an attempt to understand why some $ 200 million of the Russian aid package will
go to pay for the cost of transporting it.

After a full morning of testimony it was unclear whether they had made much
progress.

Members said port conditions probably do not fully explain the cost
differential, but that they will instruct the Department of Agriculture to
negotiate for better port conditions in Russia.

"I'm going to recommend that there be a direct communication from Congress to
the Russian officials" about our port concerns. "This might help move them to
follow some our recommendations," said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., chairman of
the agriculture subcommittee.

Christopher Goldthwait, acting general sales manager and assistant administrator
for export credits at the Agriculture Department, said the final package is not
yet signed and that fine-tuning on port conditions will be negotiated.

"I'm trying to discern how a foreign carrier can charge $ 25 a ton and the U.S.
carrier can charge $ 80," Rep. Durbin said.

"We've been concerned about getting the costs down," said Richard E. Bowman,
acting administrator of the Maritime Administration, "but there is a difference
and there will continue to be a difference" between U.S. and foreign costs.

High rates "represent risks inherent in the current market. They do not
represent rate-gouging," Mr. Bowman said.

He said there "clearly are problems in the Russian trade that have caused
freight rates to rise." The increases "are caused by a combination of port
congestion, costly contracting firms and vessel discrimination" at three ports,
Novo Tallinn (in Estonia), St. Petersburg and Novarassysk, he said.

"Arbitrary port restrictions force larger, efficient vessels to lighter cargo or
to pay 'fees' to get into larger berths," Mr. Bowman said. Those costs add
significantly - from $ 35 a ton to $ 40 a ton - to U.S. carrier costs but are
generally not included in a foreign operator's tender.

That prompted a series of questions about whether carriers must resort to paying
bribes in Russian ports so they can be first on line to unload cargo or get a
preferred berth. "I'm not sure but we sense they are," said Mr. Bowman.

Asked if there is a pattern of discrimination against U.S. vessels, Mr. Bowman
replied, "I believe it's possible." But Mr. Goldthwait said, "No, I do not;
there's no evidence of it."

"There is a mafia in Russia, and the fees are indeed bribes," said Rep. Pete
Peterson, D-Fla. "The Russian government won't be surprised when you talk about
it."

LOAD-DATE: December 12, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1993 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.

                              The Washington Post

                           December 28, 2002 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Disease Hits California Poultry

SECTION: FINANCIAL; Pg. E02

LENGTH: 640 words


California destroyed 100,000 chickens and quarantined poultry in three southern
counties because of an outbreak of exotic Newcastle disease, which is deadly to
poultry but cannot be contracted by humans. The state Department of Food and
Agriculture and the U.S. Department of Agriculture prohibited the movement of
all poultry, poultry products and nesting materials from Los Angeles County and
parts of Riverside and San Bernardino counties. A statewide outbreak of the
disease in the early 1970s threatened the entire U.S. poultry and egg supply and
led authorities to destroy nearly 12 million chickens.

China plans to start mass-producing anti-AIDS drugs next month, the state-run
New China News Agency said. It did not disclose which drugs will be made but
said the price will be about a tenth that of imported drugs, which cost $ 3,600
per person each year. The per capita annual income in China is $ 700. Health
officials said 1 million people in China are infected with the AIDS virus. China
has already begun treating patients with a domestically produced version of the
anti-AIDS drug AZT, for which patents recently expired. Ten Chinese firms have
applied for permission to make generic versions of anti-AIDS drugs with expired
patents.

J.P. Morgan Chase cut stock options for most employees by more than half.
Full-time workers at the second-biggest U.S. bank each will get 150 stock
options when bonuses are handed out in February, employees were told in a memo.
This year, full-time employees each received 375 options. The reduced options
award reflects J.P. Morgan's declining stock price and the fact that earnings
have fallen seven of the past eight quarters because of rising loan defaults,
investment losses and the bankruptcies of loan customers.

Help-wanted advertising in major U.S. newspapers was at its lowest level in
almost 40 years in November, the Conference Board said. The volume of job ads is
one indication of demand for labor, although many employers also now advertise
for help through online services.

Bidding for a decrepit Northern California town closed at nearly $ 1.8 million
on eBay. If the deal goes through, 82 acres of Bridgeville will go to the
unidentified buyer who bid just seconds before the Internet auction closed.
Almost 250 bids were placed during the month the town was up for bids. The town
includes a mile and a half of riverbank, a cemetery, more than a dozen cabins
and houses and a post office with Zip code 95526.

Argentina's Senate approved a 2003 budget and ratified former J.P. Morgan
economist Alfonso Prat-Gay as chief of the nation's central bank. The government
said the national unemployment rate fell to 17.8 percent, down nearly 7
percentage points from its highest rate ever, in May. President Eduardo
Duhalde's government is seeking an aid agreement that would roll over some of
the $ 141 billion in foreign debt that Argentina defaulted on last December
after the International Monetary Fund stopped lending it money.

Ethan Allen Interiors opened its first store in Asia -- a showroom in Tianjin,
China. Ethan Allen, the largest U.S. furniture retailer, has an agreement with
the Chinese company Markor Furniture International to develop a chain of stores
in China. Ethan Allen has more than 300 stores, 23 of which are outside the
United States.

WorldCom's losses nearly doubled in October from the previous month, according
to a bankruptcy court filing. The phone company lost $ 234 million in October,
compared with a loss of $ 108 million in September. Revenue stabilized at $ 2.3
billion. WorldCom got permission in October to borrow up to $ 1.1 billion to run
its business while planning its emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

Compiled from reports by the Associated Press, Bloomberg News, Dow Jones News
Service and Washington Post staff writers

                          Sacramento Bee (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune News Service

                            August 3, 2006 Thursday

Governor asks for federal aid: Heat help sought for farmers and poor

BYLINE: Jim Downing, The Sacramento Bee, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 505 words


Aug. 3--Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who toured a Fresno County dairy farm
Wednesday to see the impact of a July heat wave, has already requested federal
disaster relief for producers who sustained losses, state officials said.

California Secretary of Food and Agriculture A.G. Kawamura declined to speculate
about monetary losses to the state's crop and dairy operations, saying that a
meaningful estimate may not be possible for months.

Dairy cows can take months to recover from heat stress, and the damage to many
crops can't be assessed until harvest time, Kawamura said. But Western United
Dairymen, which represents 60 percent of the state dairy industry, has pegged
losses at more than $1 billion.

Separately, the governor on Wednesday requested additional federal funding for a
state-administered program that helps low-income residents to insulate their
homes and pay electricity bills associated with running air conditioners.

In past years in which California has requested these home emergency funds, it
has received between $5 million and $12 million, according to Lloyd Throne,
director of the state Department of Community Services and Development.

If approved, the emergency funds would add to the $91 million already granted to
the state this year for the program, which is known as the Low Income Home
Energy Assistance Program.

Earlier this week, Schwarzenegger sent letters to Mike Johanns, secretary of the
U.S. Department of Agriculture, seeking the disaster aid and wrote Sen. Barbara
Boxer, D-Calif., to request that she continue to work on the state's behalf,
according to Food and Agriculture spokesman Jay Van Rein.

The first letter amounts to an official report that the state has sustained
significant agricultural damage and is in need of an unspecified amount of
federal assistance. The governor is also dispatching Kawamura to Washington to
lobby for aid.

Eight county boards of supervisors declared states of emergency during the hot
spell in July, but Schwarzenegger did not declare a statewide emergency. Van
Rein said that the counties did not request additional state assistance beyond
what was already being offered.

Fresno County released a livestock and milk damage estimate of $84 million on
Wednesday afternoon. Officials cited the loss of 100 head of beef cattle, 2,252
dairy cows, 2,464 dairy calves, 63 million gallons worth of long-term milk
production, 58,000 turkeys and 270,000 chickens.

No other counties have provided a detailed accounting of losses, Van Rein said.

Heat's toll on dairies

16,500: Estimated number of dairy cows that died during the heat wave.

$1 billion: Expected monetary losses.

10%: The percentage of milk production that was cut by the heat wave.

Source: Fresno Bee

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          November 16, 2011 Wednesday

BRIEF: Erie disaster designation to aid Crawford, Warren counties

BYLINE: Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 228 words


Nov. 16--The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated Erie County as a
natural disaster area due to excessive rain from May 1 through June 28.

That qualifies Crawford and Warren counties for federal natural disaster
assistance, according to U.S. Rep. Glenn Thompson, R-5th Dist.

Producers in both primary and contiguous counties are eligible to be considered
for Farm Service Agency, emergency loans, and the Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Program.

The Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program was approved as part of the Food,
Conservation and Energy Act of 2008, and was implemented on Jan. 4, 2010.

Food, Conservation and Energy Act officials will consider each emergency loan
application by evaluating the extent of losses, security available and repayment
ability.

Applicants in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the
declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. Local
Food, Conservation and Energy Act offices can provide affected individuals with
additional information.

For information, contact the Crawford Farm Service Agency, 14699 N. Main St., in
Meadville, at (814) 336-2127, Ext. 2, or the Warren Farm Service Agency, 265
Holiday Inn Road, in Clarion, at (814) 226-8160.

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            October 12, 2004 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Drought aid goes to Bush

BYLINE: ART HOVEY, Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: A; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 639 words


$2.9 billion package offset by cuts in conservation funds.

The Senate completed a torturous trip toward drought relief Monday by attaching
$2.9 billion in federal aid to a military construction bill. The House took
similar action over the weekend.

Senate concurrence clears the way for President Bush's signature on legislation
that could provide $150 million or more to Nebraska farmers and ranchers for
weather losses in 2003 and 2004.

A voice vote in the Senate ended arguments with House Republicans who held firm
on demands that the latest emergency aid for agriculture be offset with cuts in
future spending on soil and water conservation.

Most of the drought punishment inflicted in Nebraska in 2004 is in the western
third of the state. Brad Hansen of Hemingford said he wouldn't know how much his
corn crop had been hurt by a moisture deficit and an unseasonably cool summer
until it was harvested.

"Every little bit will help, of course," Hansen said of the final course set by
Congress on Monday. "I guess the bad thing about it is this $3 billion comes out
of agriculture. It's being offset out of agriculture itself."

Allowing crop and livestock producers to choose either 2003 or 2004 for their
aid applications is significant in Nebraska because all of the state's 93
counties carried federal drought disaster declarations last year.

The area of impact is much smaller this year.  The Nebraska Agricultural
Statistics Service will provide an October update today on earlier predictions
of a record corn crop.

John Hansen, president of the Nebraska Farmers Union, defended the efforts of
Nebraska Sen. Ben Nelson, Rep. Tom Osborne and others to add drought relief to a
larger package that routes about $11.6 billion to victims of a series of Florida
hurricanes.

But Hansen also conceded some possible political overtones. "I suppose the fact
that this is an election year certainly had something to do with why we were
able to make this thing work," he said.

No matter what the motivation, "we're extremely pleased that folks that need
help are going to be getting some, and we hope it's in a timely fashion. And the
reason we fought so hard for it is this amount of disaster assistance may well
decide if people stay in business and stay in production agriculture or not."

Both Hansen and Rob Robertson of the Nebraska Farm Bureau Federation voiced
displeasure with cutting conservation funding to pay for the aid.

Still, "some money is better than no money," Robertson said. "It's a true
disaster out there in western Nebraska because of the drought."

He cited "all kinds of problems with alfalfa and corn being frozen." Also, "the
wheat had been frozen earlier this year."

Traci Bruckner of the Nebraska Center for Rural Affairs also objected to offsets
and spending cuts in the Conservation Security Program.

"Why don't they look at cutting payments to mega-farmers, who use unlimited
commodity payments to drive their neighbors off the farm?" Bruckner said.

Cutting conservation funding undermines some of the gains made for agriculture
in the 2002 farm bill, she said.

"They're not following through on the agreement they passed and the president
signed."

Reach Art Hovey at 523-4949 or ahovey@alltel.net

OTHER ACTION

The Senate gave final approval and sent to President Bush a bill to close
egregious tax loopholes, reduce taxes for domestic producers and dole out scores
of breaks for interests from tackle box makers to Native Alaskan whaling
captains.

The most significant corporate tax legislation is more than two decades includes
$143 billion in tax breaks over 10 years, offset by loophole closures and other
revenue raisers. The House also has approved the bill, and President Bush is
expected to sign it.

The Senate also approved funding for homeland security and military building for
the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.

Story, 3A

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            December 4, 2006 Monday
                                  City Edition

Coburn plans to block ag disaster aid bill

BYLINE: Chris Casteel, Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 785 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON -- Though he favors helping some farmers hit hard by the drought and
other weather problems, U.S. Sen. Tom Coburn plans to block an attempt this week
to approve nearly $4.5 billion in agriculture disaster aid.

Coburn, R-Muskogee, said the aid package pushed by some Midwestern senators is
too large and would cover too many producers.

He said aid should be targeted at those who weren't able to plant a crop, not
for crop losses that could have been covered by federally subsidized insurance.

And he said any aid should be paid for by cutting spending in other areas.

"If we're going to do relief for the farmers, we can't say, 'We'll take care of
you and give the bill to your grandkids,'" Coburn said.

A Senate vote could come Tuesday on an aid package proposed by Sen. Kent Conrad,
D-N.D., who pared his request from nearly $5 billion to about $4.5 billion.

Conrad is expected to offer his proposal as an amendment to the annual
agriculture appropriations bill.

Coburn said he will try to block Conrad's package on a procedural move, raising
the point that its cost is not offset by cuts elsewhere.

If that fails, he said, he'll try to cut other parts of the agriculture spending
bill.

In debate on the Senate floor two weeks ago, Conrad defended his package, saying
it is intended to cover two years of flooding, drought and fires that ravaged
crops in several states.

Conrad said, "This is not some outsized disaster assistance legislation; it is
bare bones. ... We are down to $4.5 billion, as we have taken out things the
White House said they would object to. We took out the energy provisions, for a
savings of $1.8 billion. We stripped out some of the support for small
businesses for a savings of $215 million."

He said the package would cover anybody who had a loss of at least 35 percent
and that it still only would cover a percentage of the loss.

"The bankers of my state have told me if this kind of assistance is not
forthcoming, 5 to 10 percent of the farmers and ranchers in our state will go
out of business, not because of any fault of theirs, but because of the most
incredible swing in weather that we have ever seen," Conrad said.

In the House, Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Cheyenne, has been pushing for a $3.3 billion
aid package.

In an interview last week, Lucas said parts of Oklahoma still are "desperately
short of moisture," and the aid could mean the difference for producers who lost
crops in 2005 and this year.

"In my home county (Roger Mills), the wheat crop was a total failure," he said.

Though the aid could be months -- or even more than a year -- after the losses
were incurred, Lucas said that's not necessarily unusual for federal disaster
aid and still could determine whether some producers survive.

"It never becomes irrelevant" whether they get the aid, he said, since the
losses can affect their long-term viability.

Coburn said he didn't know how much of a disaster package he would support, and
he is having staff members analyze losses and various factors involved,
including crop insurance coverage.

"Why have a crop insurance program if you're not going to require them to buy
it?" Coburn asked.

"Those that couldn't plant, we ought to help them, and we can help them. But we
have to pay for it."

Spending bills in limbo

The debate over the aid package could be academic if congressional leaders
determine that no more spending bills can be finished and sent to the White
House before Congress adjourns for the year.

Lawmakers again failed to get most of their spending bills completed this year,
and there was speculation that the remaining ones would be combined into one
bill, as has been done in previous years.

However, after the elections swept Republicans from power in both houses, the
talk turned to pushing off the tough work until January, when the Democrats
officially take over.

Coburn and other conservative senators didn't want a single spending bill
because of the tendency for such bills to get loaded with so-called pork barrel
projects.

"I don't want an omnibus bill," Coburn said. "There are way too many earmarks in
there."

He said it would be "much better" to approve a resolution that will continue
federal spending at current levels until February.

Then, he said, lawmakers could do the necessary work on the individual spending
bills.

And he said an agricultural assistance plan could be developed.

Lucas isn't optimistic an agriculture disaster package could be approved in the
remaining few days that Congress will meet this year. All the signals coming out
of the Senate, he said, indicate that real spending decisions would be delayed
until next year.

"It means the new majority will have to finish up the budget process," he said.

LOAD-DATE: December 5, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Photo 2: Rep. Frank Lucas
The Republican from Cheyenne has been pushing for a $3.3 billion aid package.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     June 17, 1993, Thursday, City Edition

WIC seeks more mothers, children

BYLINE: ROGER CLENDENING II

SECTION: PASCO TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 412 words



County health officials want more people to take advantage of a federally
financed nutrition program for mothers and children.

The Women, Infants and Children program is operated by the Pasco County  Health
Department and financed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. It  provides
pregnant women, new mothers, infants and children ages 5 and younger  with
nutrition education, access to medical care and food supplements.

Officials want to increase WIC enrollment from 8,500 to 10,000 clients by
September, said Clara Law-head, WIC director for Pasco County.

"Historically, Florida has way underserved its potential caseload," she  said.
"We're going to rise to the challenge."

The push for more clients stems from a recent increase in funding, Lawhead
said.

"Florida has been identified as one of the target states based on the  increase
in new residents. Because of this population increase, (the USDA) has  earmarked
WIC funds for those growth states," which also include Texas and  California,
she said.

Food supplements are purchased with WIC checks. Eligibility is based on  income
and medical need. Walk-in clients might be evaluated the same day they  come in.
"In WIC, we get them in real quick," Lawhead said.

Several obstacles have prevented the program from reaching its potential,  she
said.

"Barriers to the WIC program . . . include lack of public transportation,  time
delays in making appointments and lack of awareness," she said, adding  that she
hopes the increase in funds will help solve some of these problems.

"The biggest barrier is the lack of understanding," she said. "I suspect  that
many people think of us as a welfare program, which is not the case. . .  . We
are charged with the responsibility of ensuring that WIC clients get  necessary
medical help somewhere."

WIC has six offices in Pasco County. Their locations, phone numbers and  times
of operation:

Dade City, 602 S 17th St., (904) 521-1453, weekdays, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Hudson, 11511 Denton Ave., (813) 863-8034, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday,  8:15
to 11:45 a.m. and 1 to 3:45 p.m.

Land O'Lakes, 9930 Land O'Lakes Blvd., (813) 996-3703, Thursday and  Friday, 8
a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

New Port Richey, 10841 Little Road, (813) 862-0782, weekdays, 8 a.m. to  4:30
p.m.; and 610 Forest Ave., (813) 849-0237, Tuesday-Friday, 8 a.m. to 4  p.m.

Zephyrhills, 39048 Alston Ave., (813) 788-6274, Tuesday-Friday, 8:45 a.m.  to 4
p.m.

LOAD-DATE: June 17, 1993

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           October 18, 2007 Thursday

Veto seals N.D. as a pioneer for hemp

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 651 words


In the hemp-growing world, hip, countercultural California is eating North
Dakota's dust.

For the second year in a row, California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has vetoed a
bill that would have created state guidelines for farmers wishing to grow hemp.
North Dakota passed a similar hemp guidelines law during the 2007 session with
bipartisan support from lawmakers, Republican Gov. John Hoeven and Democratic
Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson.

The law outlines a state permitting process for hemp, which is extensively
regulated by the federal government because of its relation to marijuana. Hemp,
a coarse fibrous plant with much lower THC levels than its intoxicating cousin,
is used to make everything from soap to clothes.

North Dakota has gained the spotlight from hemp advocacy groups such as Vote
Hemp as the national leader on pushing to let U.S. farmers grow the crop. David
Monson, a farmer and Republican state legislator from Osnabrock who's suing the
federal government for not letting him grow hemp under North Dakota's new law,
was recently profiled in the New York Times.

The spotlight could have shone on California.

In 2006, California legislators approved a similar law but could not get it past
Schwarzenegger. In his veto message this year - which was issued last week
-Schwarzenegger said he's worried that the bill would tax law enforcement
resources and create murkiness in the face of the federal government's
disapproval.

"Unfortunately, I am very concerned that this bill would give legitimate growers
a false sense of security and a belief that production of 'industrial hemp' is
somehow a legal activity under federal law," he wrote to legislators.

Conrad touts deal

Fresh off behind-the-scenes negotiations on the farm bill, Sen. Kent Conrad,
D-N.D., touted a deal Wednesday that he said will secure permanent disaster aid
and more favorable price supports for Midwestern crops.

Conrad, as Senate budget chairman, was part of a small circle of negotiators
that also included Agriculture Committee Chairman Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa and
the committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Saxby Chambliss of Georgia.

"I believe (the deal) will get an overwhelming bipartisan majority," Conrad said
in an interview Wednesday. "I think we're well positioned to get the farm bill
done this year."

The farm bill, which is up for renewal every five years, is the nation's main
statement of agriculture policy. It deals with everything from crop subsidies to
land conservation, nutrition programs and the promotion of biofuels.

This year's bill must still officially pass though the Senate committee process,
be voted on by the full Senate, and be reconciled with a House version that
passed this summer. Conrad said he expects the process to go smoothly because
the Democratic majority included Republicans in the negotiation process that
concluded this week.

The inclusion of permanent disaster aid in that process can be viewed as a
victory for states such as North Dakota and Montana. The aid would pre-empt the
need for a separate bill when there's a drought or other disaster.

Harkin and other senators from less drought-prone parts of the Midwest had
initially opposed the idea, calling it too expensive and too geographically
concentrated in its benefits. Conrad said he and colleagues made "a powerful
case" that earthquakes, hurricanes and tornadoes have an effect on crop outcomes
even in areas without many droughts.

The deal also unwinds some of the crop subsidy favoritism toward cotton and rice
enacted in past congressional sessions that were controlled by Southern
lawmakers. It improves the support payment levels for crops like wheat, barley,
oats and soybeans.

It proposes to spend $2.8 billion on energy development, $4.5 billion for
conservation and $4.2 billion on nutrition programs such as food stamps.

(Reach reporter Jonathan Rivoli at 223-8482 or
jonathan.rivoli@bismarcktribune.com.)

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              437 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                           September 16, 2012 Sunday

Farm Aid: Hershey

BYLINE: By John Duffy

SECTION: E; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 1174  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Continued from 1

For just over a quarter-century, Farm Aid has used pop music to try to help fix
some of the problems in American agriculture: the disappearance of family farms,
the corporatization of food, and the widening gap between producers and
consumers.

The nonprofit organization will bring its annual fundraising concert to
Hersheypark Stadium on Saturday, Sept. 22, to once again share its message in a
very public way. Performers will include founders Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp
and Neil Young, as well as Dave Matthews, Animal Liberation Orchestra, Kenny
Chesney, Jack Johnson, Pegi Young & the Survivors, and Lukas Nelson & Promise of
the Real.

The show came to Pittsburgh in 2002, and organizers say they are excited to be
bringing it back to Pennsylvania.

"We looked at Hershey before," said Carolyn Mugar, Farm Aid's executive
director. "It's right in the middle of some the best farm country in the region,
and the size is perfect. We're going to change out all the concessions to be
homegrown and regional, and it is really going to feel like the venue is ours
that day."

Originally conceived in the summer of 1985 in an attempt to focus national
attention on an alarming rash of foreclosures devastating rural communities in
America's heartland, Farm Aid transformed itself into a permanent advocacy
group.

While Farm Aid staff spends most of the year in the trenches aiding farmers and
rural service organizations, the annual fall benefit is the only time most
Americans see the organization's public face.

By holding benefit concerts every year in the early fall, the nonprofit through
last year has been able to give $37 million to grass-roots organizations - urban
and rural - that help family farms stay competitive, develop sustainable growing
practices, reach new markets, fight off the pressures of corporate farming and
ride out the boom and bust cycles of weather, prices and global demand. A little
more than $192,000 of those funds have gone to seven Pennsylvania organizations.

According to Farm Aid program director and Pennsylvania native Alicia Harvie,
one of the reasons the group chose Hershey was because of just how strong
small-scale family farming remains in the commonwealth.

"Pennsylvania has a lot going for it," Harvie said. "Agriculture employs one in
seven in the state, and that has a noticeable ripple effect. Pennsylvania is,
for all intents and purposes, the home of Buy Fresh, Buy Local."

Also known as "slow food," the Buy Fresh, Buy Local movement grew in large part
out of Farm Aid's decades-long push to close the gap between those who grow and
those who eat.

Sales of organic food grew from $1 billion in 1990 to $26.7 billion in 2010,
according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

"Farm Aid was deeply involved in helping to develop the federal organic
standard," Harvie said.

And there's more. "Pennsylvania is third in the nation in direct farm sales,
sixth in the number of certified organic farms, and has permanently preserved
more than 450,000 acres of farmland - one of the best programs in the country,"
Harvie said.

Innovation in farming has also had a home in the state.

Farmer Steve Groff has been pioneering modern no-till and cover-crop farming at
Cedar Meadow Farm in Holtwood for decades. Today, as much as 35 percent of crops
planted in the United States are planted this way.

The Rodale Institute in Kutztown has been researching organic farming since the
1940s, laying the groundwork for today's federally certified organic programs;
and the Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable Agriculture is one of the most
active organic programs in the nation.

"This gives Pennsylvania a solid base on which to grow," Harvie said.

According to the USDA, more than 90 percent of the farms in Pennsylvania are
family owned. While growers here face the same uncertainties of weather, global
commodities markets, speculation and price pressures as any other ag operation
in the country, the large-scale corporate operations common along the Great
Plains and in the Midwest and deep South practically don't exist here.

That's one of the reasons the commonwealth remains so competitive, said Mark
O'Neill, a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Farm Bureau.

"Here, a large dairy farm is 2,000 cows," O'Neill said. "In other parts of the
country, that is pretty small." In the flat states of the West, operations can
approach 10,000 cows. Yet Pennsylvania is the fifth-largest dairy producing
state, he said.

Despite the farmers' strength, the margins for dairy farmers here have been
getting tighter, as feed and fuel prices put a serious strain on small-herd
producers. While Pennsylvania has been spared the summer drought that has left
large swaths of the country denuded of harvestable crops this summer, it will
still face higher costs as a result.

To give farmers in the state some added support, the Pennsylvania Legislature
earlier this year passed laws aimed at helping farms stay in the family. Act 85
exempts from inheritance taxes qualifying farmland transferred by the death of
the owner to members of the same family. The tax had previously been as high as
12 percent. The law also waives real estate transfer taxes when land is conveyed
from one family partnership to another in the course of a farm reorganization.

The changes help keep farms in the family, and help farmers avoid having to sell
off assets to pay a tax bill, O'Neill said.

"Five years ago there was lots of money to be made," O'Neill said. "The market
was high; land value was incredibly high. ... You could get wealthy overnight.

"But it's not just about making money," he said. "Farmers need to make money to
support a family, to keep their farm going so their kids can go to college and
have something to come back to."

On the federal level, competing versions of Senate and House omnibus farm bills
saw no resolution before the August recess, and may not get a final vote before
the Sept. 30 deadline.

While back in Pennsylvania, hydraulic fracturing in the state's farm communities
continues even as discussions over further regulations and the specter of
accidents loom large. Farm Aid issued a statement earlier this year opposing the
practice without further protections for farmers against the risk of
catastrophic loss.

Despite the many political footballs being tossed about the farm fields of
America, Mugar said Farm Aid tries to remain nonpartisan, instead tackling
problems at the grass-roots level.

"We would almost like to go to every state," Mugar said. "I think the state of
affairs in every state has an illustration of probably some good, some bad and
some contradictions.

"I don't think there's ever going to be a final moment on many of these issues,"
she admitted. "But Farm Aid has never been made up of people who can easily
abandon an issue. None of us are people who sit on the sidelines. And in
Pennsylvania, we can highlight many successes."

Gates at the Farm Aid fundraising concert at Hersheypark Stadium open at noon,
Saturday, Sept. 22. For ticket information, call 534-3911 or visit
hersheypa.com.

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
