                              438 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                           September 21, 2008 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Mainer blooms at Farm Aid;
The marathon concert plays up the future of small family farming.

BYLINE: BOB KEYES Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 727 words


On a day when all eyes focused on Willie Nelson, Neil Young and their Farm Aid
brethren, a shy farmer from Brunswick reluctantly stole a small sliver of
spotlight.

At a press briefing prior to the first Farm Aid concert in New England on
Saturday, Brenna Chase found herself seated somewhat uncomfortably alongside
Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick and just a few chairs down from some of the
biggest music stars in the world.

Not that she wasn't thrilled to be there, but Chase, 29, is far more comfortable
digging in the dirt, raising animals and selling flowers at farmers' markets in
Brunswick.

''I'm a little out of my element,'' she told an assembled group of media
representatives and Farm Aid friends. ''I was just feeding hogs this morning.
Thank you for making me feel like the work I do is important.''

Farm Aid put her on stage to address the media because she and her farming
partner, Susan Meredith, run Little Creek Farm in Brunswick and represent both
the success of Farm Aid and the hopeful future of small family farming in
America.

Through grants provided by Farm Aid to the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners
Association, Chase has received training to become a farmer.

She and Meredith lease about 30 acres and raise hogs, chickens, hens, turkeys
and ducks, and grow flowers. They sell everything locally. They've had their
farm for a year, after working for other farmers from California to Connecticut
for the past decade.

In addition to Nelson and Young, Saturday's concert included performances by
John Mellencamp, Dave Matthews, Kenny Chesney, Steve Earle, moe., the
Pretenders, Arlo Guthrie and many others.

Among the highlights early in the day was a performance by rock pioneer Jerry
Lee Lewis, who received a sustained standing ovation after a performance that
included ''Whole Lotta Shakin' Going On'' and ''Great Balls of Fire.''

At Farm Aid, the cause is never far from the music.

The 11-hour marathon event at the Comcast Center included testimonials, displays
and recognition for model farmers. It also featured organic and locally grown
food in its concession stands, which organizers said was a major accomplishment
given the volume of food needed to serve the 20,000 or so people who showed up.

One of the concessionaires was Peak Organic Brewing Co., a Portland-based
brewery that specializes in hand-crafted ales.

Peak Organic founder and president Jon Cadoux spent much of his day keeping the
taps flowing. He accepted the invitation to sell beer at Farm Aid because he
shares Farm Aid's belief in family farming.

''We have a passion for sustainable agriculture and supporting family farmers,
and that's what Farm Aid is all about,'' he said. ''This is a mind-boggling
event in terms of its size and scope, and it's great to be a part of it.
Whenever possible, we try to partner with organizations that are like-minded,
and this is a perfect example of it.''

Farm Aid has shifted its focus over the years from saving family farmers to
helping those who survived the farm crisis thrive. Since 1999, the organization
has issued $29,500 in grants to the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners
Association.

Regionally, Farm Aid has granted more than $418,000 to New England farm groups
since 1985.

Mellencamp, a Farm Aid co-founder, said it was ''disheartening'' that people
continue to ask him why Farm Aid is still in business. ''Isn't that problem
solved?'' they ask him.

Not even close, he tells them.

Corporate farming still dominates U.S. agriculture, and small family farmers are
still in crisis, he said. The issues affecting farmers have changed since Farm
Aid began in 1985, but the bottom line remains that farmers are still in peril,
he said.

''That's why we're still doing Farm Aid,'' he said.

At the press briefing, Nelson made the case that a healthy farm economy is good
for the overall economy, calling it the bottom rung of the country's economic
ladder. When it fails, he said, the rest of the ladder comes crumbling down.

Young struck a hopeful tone. Noting the growth and popularity of farmers'
markets across America, he said Farm Aid can help by promoting awareness of
local-food campaigns.

He suggested that instead of Farm Aid, in the future the group might consider
calling itself Farm Made.

''What we're trying to do now is just help,'' he said.


Staff Writer Bob Keyes can be contacted at 791-6457 or at:

bkeyes@pressherald.com

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Willie Nelson

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2008 Blethen Maine Newspapers, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              439 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                    OCTOBER 27, 1999 Wednesday CWEST EDITION

PA. LEGISLATURE PASSES FARM-AID BILLS / THE HOUSE AND SENATE SEEK TO AID FARMERS
IN THE RED AFTER THE DROUGHT. GOV. RIDGE'S POSITION IS UNKNOWN.

BYLINE: Ken Dilanian and Walter F. Naedele, INQUIRER STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: NEIGHBORS; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 939 words

DATELINE: HARRISBURG


Responding to a drought that experts are calling the worst agricultural disaster
in Pennsylvania history, the state House and Senate passed two competing
farm-relief proposals yesterday that lawmakers say could result in one of the
biggest such bailouts ever provided by state government.

The big question was where Gov. Ridge stands on the issue. He was in Los Angeles
speaking to Hollywood movie executives yesterday, and his spokesman declined to
say whether he could support either version - or any state drought relief at
all, beyond a $5 million, hay-assistance program already under way.

"He's really the big gorilla in the room, and he has yet to say 'boo,' on this,"
said Steven Crawford, the top agricultural staffer for House Democrats.

The House unanimously passed a $192 million, three-bill package that would
provide direct grants to farmers to offset crop, hay and feed losses. The Senate
unanimously passed a smaller, $50 million bill. Now the two will have to be
reconciled with Ridge's input, something lawmakers say they hope will happen by
year's end.

"A drought like this comes along only once in a lifetime," said Rep. Raymond
Bunt (R., Montgomery), who is chairman of the House Agriculture and Rural
Affairs Committee and has visited 55 counties to assess the damage.

"It'll make you cry," he said of what he saw. "I don't know how these people can
recover."

Bunt said pointedly that the two unanimous votes by lawmakers should "send a
strong message to this governor."

When the two bills are merged into a final product, Bunt said, he expects a
package of around $100 million, which he said would be the biggest farm-relief
bill Harrisburg has passed in recent memory. Others said the only comparable
farm-aid effort followed the infamous 1972 Hurricane Agnes floods.

Across the Philadelphia region yesterday, county extension agents said farmers
devastated by the drought were likely to overcome their conservative tendencies
and reach out for the public assistance. Some farmers praised the aid bills.

"I'm surprised. It sounds decent," said Travis Lee Moser, a Montgomery County
farmer who this summer lost about 60 percent of the corn he planted to feed his
dairy herd.

The most recent U.S. Census of Agriculture in 1997 found farming to be a $4
billion industry in Pennsylvania, the state's largest.

Although Republicans control the House and Senate, they are not always on the
same page as their GOP governor. And Ridge often does not weigh in on issues
brought forward by the legislature until he absolutely must.

"We haven't taken a formal position on it," Ridge spokesman Tom Charles said of
drought relief. "Gov. Ridge is glad for all farmers that the process is moving
forward."

Ridge aides and Harrisburg farm officials yesterday were more interested in
talking about federal, not state, drought relief. They said they wanted to see
what the state's federal share would be before discussing state aid.

"We're waiting to see how this all sorts itself out," said Bob Bunty, spokesman
for the state Agriculture Department, which would administer any state drought
relief.

Congress recently passed a national farm-aid bill that includes a $1.4 billion
national drought-assistance package, but Ridge and Pennsylvania's congressional
delegation joined other Northeastern officials in denouncing that effort as
inadequate and too focused on the Midwest.

Pennsylvania farm losses due to the drought are estimated at $700 million, state
officials said.

The main element of the three-bill House package, House Bill 1888, provides $160
million in assistance for grants to farmers and other agricultural producers.
The grants can provide partial compensation for crop losses; repay 100 percent
of a farmer's rental for state-owned land that a farmer leases for crop
production; help buy hay and feed for dairy farmers; defray up to 20 percent of
the cost of seed, fertilizer and pest control for the 1999 crop year.

The other parts of the package provide $12 million for full refunds to farmers
for their 1999 crop insurance premiums and a 50 percent refund for 2000.

The House proposal also includes $10 million in grants and low-interest loans to
assist farmers in the development of irrigation and water conservation systems.
And on the House floor yesterday, an amendment was inserted providing $10
million for flood relief for farmers whose crops were damaged by Hurricane
Floyd.

Under the Senate plan, farmers who suffered 30 percent or more in crop losses in
the drought would be eligible for reimbursement of seeds, plants, fertilizers
and lime.

Moser farms 325 acres near Gilbertsville in northwestern Montgomery County, the
seventh generation in his family to do so.

"We will basically be feeling the effects of the drought for the next year," he
said.

At first, he said, he was hoping to avoid taking state grants, but then he
called a reporter back to say that he probably would.

"I talked it over with my father," he said.

In Chester County, the relief is needed especially on farms north of Route 30,
said Tim Fritz, farm management agent for the Chester County office of the Penn
State Cooperative Extension.

"It's very bad," he said. "You're talking about 75 percent loss or more on a lot
of the crops."

As of early August, said Penn State extension agent Mike Fournier, Bucks County
had suffered an estimated 95 percent loss on corn and 90 percent loss on
soybeans, both of which are used to feed livestock. Seventy percent of
vegetables and half the hay and fruit also were said to be lost.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO;
PHOTO
A Montgomery County farmer who in this summer's drought lost about 60 percent of
the corn he planted to feed his dairy herd, Travis Lee Moser applauds the state
House and Senate action. He is a seventh-generation farmer and works 325 acres
near Gilbertsville. (SCOTT S. HAMRICK, Inquirer Suburban Staff)
Moser drives a tractor out to the fields near Gilbertsville in northwestern
Montgomery County that he farms. He said that his operation would feel the
effects of the drought for the next year and that he and his family would take
advantage of the state grants. (SCOTT S. HAMRICK, Inquirer Suburban Staff)

                              440 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             March 1, 2008 Saturday

Farm bill touted as at 'critical stage'

BYLINE: JONATHAN RIVOLI Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 595 words


Negotiations on the farm bill have reached a critical juncture in Washington as
Congress and the White House haggle over the bill's funding, Rep. Earl Pomeroy
said Friday.

"The next few days will be absolutely critical in whether the farm bill gets
done or not," he said.

In a roundtable discussion in Bismarck with state agriculture leaders, Pomeroy
said this critical sticking point has been reached because of a major sticking
point over whether some programs get funded and where that funding comes from.

At issue in the more than $280 billion package is whether to include $10 billion
for programs including a permanent disaster aid title. Congress is looking to
find a way to pay that pleases the White House, but has thus far been out of
luck.

In the works since last summer, the farm bill sets the country's agriculture
policy on everything from crop subsidies, to food stamps and government payments
for conservation land. A farm bill passed both the House and Senate last year,
but is stuck in negotiations between a Democratic Congress and Republican White
House.

Pomeroy, a Democrat, said one of his top priorities is protecting parts of the
bill that pay for crop insurance. In today's environment of both high input
costs and high commodity prices, insurance payments can offer better protection
than price targets because the targets will undershoot the need, he said.

Permanent disaster aid also is important, he said. The idea for around $5
billion of a permanent disaster aid fund was included in the Senate's version of
the farm bill to simplify and speed up the process by which such aid is
delivered.

Over the last few years, lawmakers from upper Plains states like North Dakota
have successfully fought for disaster aid packages separate from the farm bill,
but this often occurred years after the actual disaster.

The Senate is insisting on this provision, but the Democrats' idea to pay for it
with various tax law changes have met the ire of the White House. Democrats say
they're simply closing loopholes -such as the use of offshore bank accounts or
tighter tax reporting requirements on credit card companies - while the White
House said they're relying on tax increases instead of spending cuts to make the
math work.

Smaller controversies are brewing within the farm bill as well. On Friday, for
example, a Washington public relations outfit blasted a provision of the farm
bill that requires government aid to be distributed only by government
employees. The group said this would critically harm states' abilities to
administer their Medicaid and food stamp programs by contracting out the work to
companies and nonprofits.

Pomeroy said this provision was inserted to prevent companies from handling a
lot of the private personal data they are given in such contract arrangements
and won't harm the administration of programs.

If a farm bill is not passed by March 15, the last bill, passed in 2002 would
expire, leaving farmers with an outdated permanent law passed in 1949. The 2002
farm bill was originally set to expire last October, but the deadline was
extended as negotiations dragged on.

North Dakota Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson said the major goal is just
to have a farm bill signed into law soon.

"That's maybe a simplistic approach, but I think it's the approach of most
people in the agriculture community," he said.

Planting season is coming up, and farmers need to know the rules they'll be
playing by as they make their investments, Johnson said.

(Reach reporter Jonathan Rivoli at 223-8482 or
jonathan.rivoli@bismarcktribune.com.)

LOAD-DATE: April 25, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 2008 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             March 1, 2008 Saturday

BYLINE: JONATHAN RIVOLI Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE

LENGTH: 595 words

Congress and the White House haggle over the bill's funding, Rep. Earl Pomeroy
said Friday.

done or not," he said.

                                Tampa Bay Times

                              March 3, 2017 Friday
                             Politifact.com Edition

THE FUZZY MATH OF FOREIGN AID AND TRADE

BYLINE: JON GREENBERG

SECTION: POLITIFACT: GLOBAL NEWS SERVICE; Pg. 0

LENGTH: 1140 words


Every dollar of foreign aid for agricultural research "will bring $4 in trade
with the countries and the United States ... generating employment back in the
U.S."

- Shenggen Fan on Thursday, March 2nd, 2017 in a panel discussion in Washington,
D.C.

* * *

The ruling: MOSTLY FALSE

While the details are vague, foreign aid is on the chopping block in President
Donald Trump's pending budget. Non-military assistance accounts for less than 1
percent of federal spending and defenders of aid would like to argue that it
actually pays dividends to America.

Shenggen Fan, the head of the International Food Policy Research Institute, a
widely respected organization, said his group had a study showing very specific
paybacks tied to aid.

"If we help the countries developing to invest in agriculture research, every $1
invested will bring $4 (in) trade with the countries and the United States," Fan
said Feb. 2 at a meeting in Washington. "So if you're investing in foreign aid,
you're generating employment back in the U.S. It helps economic growth here in
this country."

Fan's office said he was referring to a 1996 article that described a sort of
domino effect. Agricultural research leads to higher production, which in turn
delivers economic growth and the extra income generates demand for more imports.

"When the flow of additional imports over time is taken into account, the $1
investment in agricultural research generates $4.39 of additional imports," the
article said.

That seems to back up Fan's point, but it terms of what it means for sales by
American companies, he pushed the findings a little too far. The article
specifically noted that there's no guarantee "that a particular donor country
captures the gains from the increase in exports."

Put another way, an investment of $1 might spur $4 in trade, but there's no
guarantee the original investor will be the one to benefit. Fan posted an item
later that dialed back on the trade gains, writing that they would help
"economies like the United States or Germany."

In addition, that study is 20 years old, and we could find no other study that
reached the same conclusion.

Fan's office cited a 2006 analysis from the Australian Centre for International
Agricultural Research. The center wanted to gauge the economic impact of the
work it funded. It did find that research boosted trade, but for a number of
reasons, that result didn't do much to bolster Fan's case.

In the first case, the Australians defined trade gains broadly to include
increased sales by Aussie firms to developed countries such as Japan. On top of
that, they didn't find a 4-to-1 payback on trade. When we crunched their
numbers, it was more like 1-to-1.

The authors also warned that their dollar amounts were based on projected rather
than actual benefits. "It is possible that these benefits never actually emerged
or that the benefits that did emerge were considerably greater," they wrote.

We asked a number of researchers if they knew of any study that linked foreign
aid for agricultural research to greater exports for American firms. Not one
could think of such work.

"We are not aware of other quantitative estimates of a relationship between
investment in agriculture in foreign countries and trade," Cheryl Christensen of
the USDA's Economic Research Service told us.

The consensus that emerged was that the domino effect Fan had in mind might take
place in some countries, but no analysis had pulled all the pieces together.

"I believe that our foreign aid to agriculture is effective and can boost
agricultural production and rural income in developing countries," Phillip
Abbott, professor of agricultural economics at Purdue University, told us. "As
countries grow, they may well -- many do -- need more food than they can produce
themselves, and this leads to greater imports, including agriculture imports
from U.S. agriculture. Turning this into a causal chain with a fixed multiplier,
as claimed by Fan, is a stretch."

Robert Paarlberg at Harvard University's Kennedy School said plenty of research
ties aid to greater productivity and rising incomes.

"But it starts to become difficult when you look for links back to foreign aid,
especially agricultural development aid," Paarlberg said. "There the links
remain plausible, at least in countries capable of using aid well, but they
become too remote to estimate with any confidence."

- - -

Our ruling

Fan said every dollar of foreign aid for agricultural research "will bring $4 in
trade with the countries and the United States ... generating employment back in
the U.S." A 1996 article supports most of that assertion except for the part
about all the trade being with the United States. However, that article is 20
years old and we could find no other study that mirrored its findings.

The leading agricultural researchers we reached told us that in some countries,
that general result might come about, but it varies from place to place and it
is difficult to show the connection to foreign aid in the agricultural research
sector.

So Fan went too far on three points: the 4-to-1 payback, the amount of trade
with the United States and the idea that this general rule applies to most
countries when it is actually less predictable.

We rate this claim Mostly False.

* * *

Sources:

Food Tank, How to Cultivate Food Security, Feb. 2, 2017

World Hunger, Foreign Assistance to Agriculture: A Win-Win Proposition, Fall
1996

Medium, Aid to end hunger is a win-win investment, Feb. 13, 2017

U.S. Department of Agriculture, Income Growth in Developing Countries Can
Increase U.S. Agricultural Exports, March 14, 2011

Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, Benefits to Australia
from ACIAR-funded research, September 2006

University of Georgia, The Impact of Agricultural Aid on Agricultural Sector
Growth, February 2008

University of Nottingham Centre for Research in Economic Development and
International Trade, New Evidence on the Impact of Foreign Aid on Economic
Growth, accessed Feb. 27, 2017

Email interview, Julian Alston, professor, Department of Agricultural and
Resource Economics, University of California Davis, Feb. 28, 2017

Email interview, C. Parr Rosson, professor of agricultural economics, Texas A&M
University, Feb. 28, 2017

Email interview, Adugna Lemi, PhD, department Chair and associate professor of
economics, University of Massachusetts Boston

Email interview, Phillip Abbott, Professor, Department of Agricultural
Economics, Purdue University, Feb. 27, 2017

Email interview, Cheryl Christensen, Chief, Food Security and Development
Branch, Economic Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, March 1, 2017

Email interview, Robert Paarlberg, adjunct professor in global food policy,
Kennedy School, Harvard University, Feb. 28, 2017

Interview, Drew Sample, head of media, International Food Policy Research
Institute, Feb. 27, 2017

LOAD-DATE: March 6, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO (3)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              443 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                           August 29, 2007 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

On the Road to Farm Aid, The Long, Sweet Way

BYLINE: By KIM SEVERSON

SECTION: Section F; Column 0; Dining, Dining Out/Cultural Desk; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 769 words


FOR most of August, Diane Hatz has been on a national quest for pie. She has
eaten walnut pie in northern California; lemonade peach pie in Laramie, Wyo.;
and a pie of goat cheese, onion and tomato in Kansas City, Mo.

Yesterday,  she and other members of the food-centered educational group
Sustainable Table wheeled their bio-fueled rock-star tour bus into Chicago to
eat pizza pie.

The pie adventure is part of a 25-city road trip, called the Eat Well Guided
Tour of America, that will bring the group to New York just in time for the Farm
Aid concert and Homegrown Festival, Sept. 9 on Randall's Island.

''I was looking for something to tie together Farm Aid and the people in towns
around the country who are part of the sustainable agriculture movement,'' she
said. ''To me, pies are a metaphor for something bigger. They represent the
connection to local, wholesome food.'' (Pie recipes and blogs from the road are
at sustainabletable.org.)

A cross-country trip in the name of sustainable food is not something that would
have come to mind when Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young started
Farm Aid 22 years ago.

In the 1980s, the focus was on saving mostly corn and bean farmers who were
awash in debt and losing their land. In the 1990s, Farm Aid began to fight the
proliferation of large agricultural operations that were driving smaller farms
out of business.

Since the new millennium, Farm Aid has taken on the cause of family farmers. In
its third act, Farm Aid has become a rallying point for the local-food movement,
said Mark Smith, Farm Aid's campaign director.

The concerts themselves, which have raised almost $30 million over the years,
are a jumping off point for local-food loyalists to organize events, meals,
forums and parties.

''Every time we go into a city, it's a good excuse to pull together all the
food-based organizations,'' Mr. Smith said.

Mr. Smith will be running a caravan from Syracuse to New York City, talking
politics with state and local agricultural officials, showing off innovative New
York farms and picking up food to feed concert crews backstage.

From Sept. 4 to Sept. 10, dozens of New York restaurants will add special dishes
with ingredients that are either grown locally, produced by a family farm or
certified organic, with some of the price going to Farm Aid. Whole Foods will
donate 5 percent of total sales at tristate stores to Farm Aid on Sept. 12.

Organizers have also created an interactive map featuring New York farmers'
markets, urban gardens, school cafeterias and other places where local food
stars. Contributions are encouraged, even if it's your own kitchen.

The concert has inspired local and state policy makers to meet in New York next
Wednesday with local-food and farm advocates to discuss food policy.

And then there are the parties, including a harvest barbecue in the Hudson
Valley at Gigi Market at Greig Farm in Red Hook on Sept. 7, the Eat Well tour's
last stop before Manhattan, and a Homegrown Fair in Union Square on Sept. 8 with
plays, testimonials from family farmers, a young person's Iron Chef-style
competition and horseshoes. (Information on the events, and the map, are at
farmaid.org/homegrownnewyork.)

The concessions at the concert itself will go way beyond nachos and beer. As far
as anyone can tell, Farm Aid's New York show will be the first major rock
concert to serve only food that is either organic, local or from a family farm.

Organic food will come from sponsors including Chipotle, Horizon Organic and
Niman Ranch. The local part is trickier. In New York, you might think a cart
full of Sabrett hot dogs would be a perfect example of local food. But you would
be wrong.

''That's not going to happen,'' said Sonya Dagovitz Kugler, the Farm Aid
organizer charged with approving vendors based on whether their food meets the
spirit of the group. Specialty coffee drinks from Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn
made the cut, along with sausages and soy dogs from Sparky's in the East Village
and pork chop sandwiches from Missouri.

Missouri?

They're not local, but they are from a family farm, said Ms. Dagovitz Kugler,
who has spent months trying to explain why funnel cakes from a mix don't qualify
while making sure there is enough food to feed 30,000 concertgoers.

''You have concessionaires who know how to vend but who don't understand this
food because no one taught them what is local and what is sustainable,'' she
said. ''On the other side are the younger people who have beautiful small
businesses and who get the whole thing about sustainability but they don't know
how to vend.''

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: August 29, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              444 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                      October 2, 2001 Tuesday 1ST EDITION

63 elk exposed to disease were sold Officials track shipments to Colo. ranches,
5 states

BYLINE: By Theo Stein, Denver Post Environment Writer,

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 797 words


Sixty-three elk exposed to chronic wasting disease at a Del  Norte ranch were
exported to at least five states and three other  Colorado ranches before their
herd was quarantined, agriculture  officials disclosed Monday.

In an emergency move, officials banned the transport of  domestic elk for 30
days as they shifted their focus to the search  for elk shipped from seven
licensed ranches now under quarantine.

More Colorado ranches are likely to be investigated as a  review of records
documenting the flow of animals across the state  and the country continues.

On Monday, a herd of 200 elk on a shooting park in the North  Park community of
Cowdrey was quarantined after a bull shot by a  hunter tested positive two weeks
ago for the fatal brain wasting  disease. With the addition of that herd, 1,300
elk now likely will  be destroyed, officials said.

The Cowdrey bull and 24 other hunting bulls on the North Park  ranch came from
Elk Echo Ranch, a Stoneham operation that  investigators believe is a potential
center of infection, said Dr.  Wayne Cunningham, the Colorado Department of
Agriculture's  veterinarian.

'We want to get a handle on this as soon as possible and we  want to put a stop
to it,' said Jim Rubingh, the Agriculture  Department's director of marketing
and the chairman of the Captive  Wildlife and Alternative Livestock Board.

The transport ban applies to all animals except those going  to slaughter.

Elk ranchers on the board asked the Agriculture Commission to  double the
monitoring period for elk brought into the state to 36  months, and require a
similar surveillance period for any elk  moved out of the northeastern counties,
where the disease has  existed in wild herds for close to four decades.

The board also asked the agriculture commission to ban the  construction of new
elk ranches when it meets Thursday.

Other animals diseased

In addition to the Cowdrey bulls, Elk Echo Ranch also  produced the cow elk
diagnosed with CWD on Rancho Anta Grande in  Del Norte, along with animals on
the All American Antler Ranch,  All American Antler Ranch Two and Country Care
Ranch - all under  quarantine. A call to the ranch was not returned.

Rancho Anta Grande in turn sold elk to ranches in Texas,  Utah, Idaho, Nebraska
and Pennsylvania, Cunningham said.  Veterinary officials in Texas and Utah each
said ranches in their  state had bought single elk, now under quarantine.
Neither animal  has shown signs of the disease.

'We won't let that animal or her offspring be sold and we'll  be keeping track
of her for five years,' said Dr. Mike Marshall,  Utah's state veterinarian.
Other members of the herd can be moved  only with his office's permission.

Cunningham said the Idaho herd was also quarantined.

Rich Forrest, who runs the 520-acre Rancho Anta Grande in the  San Luis Valley,
knows his 400 elk soon will be destroyed, even  though only one has tested
positive for CWD. Forrest said every  elk processed for meat is tested for the
disease.

'The industry has been testing these animals for several  years,' he said. 'The
system works, and we caught the problem.  That's the good news. The bad news is
it's mine.'

The bewildering turn of events has left him uncertain about  his ranch's future.

'Having an elk ranch was a dream that I managed to  accomplish,' he said. 'I
certainly love the animals, and I'd like  to remain in the business, but that
may not be possible. A lot of  unknowns need to be sorted out first.'

Ranchers skeptical of aid

State agriculture officials hope a $ 2.6 million federal aid  program will help
ranchers such as Forrest, who remains skeptical.

'The fairness of the indemnity program remains to be  demonstrated,' he said
Monday.

On Friday, the alternative livestock board will meet for the  third time in two
weeks to decide whether to ask the state to  supplement the federal aid. 'We may
want to allocate some funds  for depopulation,' Rubingh said.

Chronic wasting disease is a transmissible spongiform  encephalopathy related to
mad cow disease. Unlike that disease, it  has not been shown to infect humans.

Symptoms of chronic wasting disease were first recognized in  wild mule deer and
elk in adjacent parts of Colorado and Wyoming  in the late 1960s, though it
wasn't diagnosed until 10 years  later. The degenerative disorder attacks the
brains of deer and  elk, causing unsteadiness, excessive slobbering, confusion
and  death.

Although researchers don't know how the disease is  transmitted, they do know
the infectious agent persists in the  environment and can sicken deer or elk
that move onto contaminated  ground.


LOAD-DATE: October 02, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  The Denver Post Elk investigation (map)

                              445 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            Buffalo News (New York)

                             October 2, 2009 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Bill brings aid to WNY dairy farmers

BYLINE: By Jerry Zremski - NEWS WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 430 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Struggling Western New York dairy farmers are likely to win relief from Congress
next week with the passage of legislation that could bring them nearly $10
million in financial aid, lawmakers on both sides of Capitol Hill said Thursday.

House and Senate negotiators this week agreed to include $350 million in aid to
the struggling dairy industry -- including $290 million in direct payments to
farmers -- in the final version of a fiscal 2010 agriculture spending bill.

If the Department of Agriculture uses the formula that now guides the existing
federal Milk Income Loss Contract Program, known as "MILC," Wyoming County
farmers would get $3.9 million -- the most in the state, said Sen. Charles E.
Schumer, D-N.Y. Genesee County farmers would get $1.8 million, and their
Chautauqua County counterparts would receive $1.5 million. Erie County would get
$922,000, Cattaraugus County $860,000 and Niagara County $690,000.

The bill does not specify how the Agriculture Department should allocate the
payments because opening that issue would have sparked a regional battle in
Congress that could have slowed the legislation's progress, said Schumer.

"Rarely in history have dairy farmers been saddled with such low prices for such
a long period of time," Schumer said. "If it's distributed right, this $350
million will make a big difference for our dairy farmers."

Meanwhile, Rep. Chris Lee, R-Clarence, Rep. Eric Massa, D-Corning, and other
lawmakers met with Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack to discuss a more permanent
fix for the current system that makes dairy prices highly volatile.

"I was also able to discuss one of the greatest concerns to my dairy farmers --
the process used for establishing these prices, specifically the Federal Milk
Marketing Order," Lee said. "As we have seen time and time again, the Federal
Order system must be more responsive to changes in cost of production and market
forces."

Other local lawmakers agreed that a permanent fix is needed.

"While this [funding boost] is great for New York's dairy farmers, this is only
a temporary solution to the fundamental problems with the dairy pricing system,"
said Sen. Kirsten E. Gillibrand, D-N.Y., an Agriculture Committee member who,
with Schumer and Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., proposed funding.

Massa vowed to do the same.

"It's important to point out that this aid will not be the silver bullet to fix
all of the long-term issues facing our dairy farmers, but it is another
essential piece to help keep them in business until we can deliver long-term
solutions," Massa said.

e-mail: jzremski@buffnews.com

LOAD-DATE: October 7, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2009 The Buffalo News
                              All Rights Reserved

                                 FINAL EDITION

Bill brings aid to WNY dairy farmers

BYLINE: By Jerry Zremski - NEWS WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 430 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

                    The Portales, News-Tribune (New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 19, 2009 Wednesday

BRIEF: Area farmers eligible for disaster aid

BYLINE: The Portales News-Tribune, N.M.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 252 words


Aug. 19--U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom J. Vilsack has declared Roosevelt
County a disaster area in a move that also affects Curry and Quay counties.

Roosevelt is among seven New Mexico counties listed as disaster areas because of
production losses from high winds and drought, according to the U.S. Department
of Agriculture.

Curry and Quay counties are among those listed as contiguous, or neighboring,
disaster counties.

Vilsack made the designations Friday, according to information the agency
release late Tuesday.

The declaration makes farm operators in primary and contiguous counties eligible
for federal assistance, including emergency loans and supplemental revenue
payments from the Farm Service Agency.

Chaves, De Baca, Eddy, Lea, Lincoln and Otero counties are also designated
primary disaster areas.

Dona Ana, Guadalupe, Sierra, Socorro and Torrance counties in New Mexico, and
Andrews, Bailey, Cochran, Culberson, El Paso, Gaines, Hudspeth, Loving, Reeves,
Winkler and Yoakum counties in Texas are contiguous disaster counties.

Information: Farm Service Agency at 356-6629.

To see more of The Portales News-Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.pntonline.com/. Copyright (c) 2009, The Portales News-Tribune, N.M.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 July 19, 1998, Sunday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION
                              Correction Appended

CLINTON ORDERS PURCHASE OF WHEAT TO HELP FARMERS;
80 MILLION BUSHELS WILL BE DISTRIBUTED OVERSEAS TO COUNTRIES NEEDING AID

BYLINE: From News Services

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A3

LENGTH: 344 words

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, ARK.


President Clinton announced Saturday that he is ordering the Agriculture
Department to buy 80 million bushels of wheat from U.S. farmers and distribute
them to several countries that desperately need food aid.

The new program, he said from Arkansas in his weekly radio address, would both
ease farm troubles at home and alleviate mass starvation overseas.

He said: "With the economic crisis in Asia weakening some of our best customers
for farm products, and with strong world crop production bringing prices down,
and with farmers facing flood and fires and drought and crop disease, our
farmers face a difficult and dangerous moment."

The wheat purchase would reduce surpluses in the United States and lift prices
by as much as 13 cents a bushel, or about 5 percent, Clinton said. At the same
time, it would provide about $ 250 million worth of wheat for hungry people in
Ethiopia, Sudan, Indonesia, North Korea, Eritrea and other countries to be
determined.

Clinton also engaged in a pep talk for his home state Democrats, assailing the
Republican-controlled Congress for opposing "our whole agenda."

Referring to GOP efforts to stop his program for putting 100,000 more police
officers on the streets even as the national crime rates fall, Clinton said,
"It's unbelievable."

"We have proved what works in education, and yet they're still saying 'no' to
smaller classes, 'no' to better school buildings, 'no' to so many of our efforts
to improve the education of our children," he said.

The president ticked off a list of other issues that have drawn partisan
opposition, including his administration's environmental priorities and its
proposal for a health care patient's bill of rights.

He told the Arkansas State Democratic Committee that Democrats needed to find
not just good candidates but candidates with good ideas.

Among those in the president's audience were Bill Bristow, Democratic candidate
for governor, and Blanche Lincoln, the former congresswoman who is running for
the Senate seat of retiring Democrat Dale Bumpers.

LOAD-DATE: July 23, 1998

LANGUAGE: English

CORRECTION-DATE: July 22, 1998

State Treasurer Jimmie Lou Fisher as U.S. Senate candidate Blanche Lincoln.
Fisher is shown sitting next to President Bill Clinton.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

              October 10, 1995 Tuesday SANTA CRUZ/MONTEREY EDITION

FEDERAL AID AVAILABLE FOR FLOODED FARMS USDA TEAM VISITS SALINAS TO PROCESS
CLAIMS FOR NEW NON-INSURED PROGRAM

BYLINE: LEE QUARNSTROM, Mercury News Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 428 words


Farmers who lost crops during the March floods that devastated the fertile
fields of the Salinas and Pajaro valleys, causing an estimated $600 million in
damage, may qualify for federal aid under a new program.

Rep. Sam Farr, D-Monterey, said a team from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
will be in Salinas for at least two weeks, beginning today, to process claims
from growers who lost crops when the Salinas and Pajaro rivers jumped their
levees and flooded vast portions of the two valleys. The team will be working
out of the Farm Service Agency building at 635 S. Sanborn Road, Salinas.

According to Farr, the new federal Non-insured Assistance Program may provide
money "for affected crops that are not otherwise covered" by other federal farm
insurance programs. In order to qualify, said Farr, "a grower must lose more
than 50 percent of his crop and be in an area that suffered an overall loss of
more than 35 percent" in one crop or groups of similar fruits and vegetables.
"To qualify, an affected grower cannot gross more than $2 million."

The March floodwaters caused an estimated $600 million damage in the
congressman's district, a Farr aide said Monday. That figure includes damaged
roads, levees, homes, bridges, vehicles and equipment as well as ruined fields
and crops. In Monterey County alone, according to Agricultural Commissioner
Richard Nutter, the floods caused $240 million damage to crops, wells and
irrigation equipment.

Farr aide Alec Arago said he expected the program could provide farmers in
Farr's district whose losses meet the federal guidelines with as much as $25
million total.

Farr said the government has been processing claims under provisions of
"numerous federal accounts, each with separate regulations," since the March
floods. He described potential beneficiaries of the new program as
"specialty-crop growers."

Among produce the program covers, according to Farr, are strawberries - which
were destroyed in great quantities in north Monterey County when the Pajaro
River spilled through and over its levee - as well as raspberries, blackberries,
carrots, celery, head lettuce, leaf lettuces, onions and garlic, peppers,
broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower and various other row crops.

"I would have hoped we could get the money to the farmers faster," Farr said in
a prepared statement. "Unfortunately, to get a new federal program in place . .
. was a challenge" for the federal government.

He said the new program is to assist growers in California's central coastal
region.

LOAD-DATE: October 24, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: IF YOU'RE INTERESTED
For more information about the Non-insured Assistance Program, call (408)
424-7377.

                              451 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Irish Times

                               November 10, 2001

Irish anti-poverty campaign calls on ministers to favour the poor at WTO

BYLINE: By DENIS STAUNTON

SECTION: CITY EDITION; BUSINESS & FINANCE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 587 words

DATELINE: DOHA


Irish anti-poverty campaigners have called on Irish ministers to take a strong
stand in favour of poorer countries at the WTO conference in Doha. They want the
Minister for Agriculture, Mr Walsh, to agree to the abolition of farm subsidies,
which developing countries claim create an unfair advantage for rich countries.

Tr caire's policy analyst, Ms Maura Leen, praised the commitment of the Minister
for State for Trade and Enterprise, Mr Tom Kitt, to giving developing countries
better terms and conditions.

But she said he should put pressure on other EU member-states to take a more
sympathetic approach to poor countries' concerns over how the WTO "TRIPS"
agreement, which protects patent rights, affects their ability to deal with
illnesses such as HIV/Aids, malaria and tuberculosis.

"We would hope that Ireland will listen sympathetically to the views of
developing countries and push hard for the public health consequences of TRIPS
to be addressed," she said.

Although fewer representatives of non-governmental organisations (NGOs) are in
Doha than were present when the WTO met in Seattle two years ago, a small group
of campaigners travelled as observers with the Irish delegation.

Mr Conall O'Caoimh of Comhl mh and Ms Leen are representing Dochas, an umbrella
group of Irish NGOs. Mr David Joyce, development officer at the Irish Congress
of Trade Unions (ICTU), is also attending the conference.

Mr Joyce said the issue of agricultural subsidies was likely to be key to
achieving agreement for the launch of a new trade round.

"Some of the stronger developing countries are here with a strong mandate to
achieve real progress on agricultural subsidies. I think it is very significant
that Joe Walsh has decided to come here. I think he knows the writing is on the
wall. The EU can't get a new round without giving something on agricultural
subsidies," he said.

Developing countries complain that EU farm aid, especially export subsidies and
the US system of export credits, create unfair obstacles to farmers from poorer
countries. A draft declaration calls for the phasing out of such subsidies, but
some EU member-states face enormous political pressure to avoid taking any step
that could damage the interests of their own farmers.

Ms Leen believes agriculture ministers should accept that change is inevitable.
"The Common Agricultural Policy is being reformed in any case and the
liberalisation of agriculture is happening over time," she said. Mr Joyce backs
a demand by the EU that labour rights should be incorporated into trade talks
and that the WTO should consult formally with the International Labour
Organisation (ILO). But he acknowledges that opposition from poorer countries
such as India, which fear that the imposition of minimum labour standards would
favour developed countries, is so great that the move has little chance of being
accepted.

"It's not surprising that developing countries are suspicious. But if they look
closely at the proposal, they will see that it is very modest and is not
protectionist in any way," he said.

Ms Leen argues that it is more important to ensure that existing trade rules are
applied fairly than to launch a new round of talks. But Mr Joyce, who favours a
new round, believes that, if the EU and the US are willing to compromise, the
chances of success are good.

"The EU and the US want a new round more than the developing countries do. So
the developing countries are in a relatively strong position," he said.

LOAD-DATE: November 10, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2001 The Irish Times

                      Post-Bulletin (Rochester, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 19, 2014 Friday

BRIEF: State aids in investigation of DuPont's role in tree destruction

BYLINE: Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 212 words


Sept. 19--ST. PAUL -- The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced Monday
that DuPont has been fined nearly $2 billion for its role in the widespread
death and damage of trees across the Midwest.

The company has been penalized for failing to submit reports to the EPA about
the potential adverse effects of Imprelis, a turf herbicide. The Minnesota
Department of Agriculture aided in the investigation.

The EPA says DuPont also sold Imprelis with labeling that didn't ensure its safe
use. When customers applied the misbranded product, it led to widespread death
and damage to trees.

The MDA first learned of problems in Minnesota in 2011, then gathered
information through investigations and surveys to help assess the scope of the
damage. Cases of tree damage and death from Imprelis hit especially hard in
Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Ohio.

The herbicide was registered with the EPA in 2010, and was sold primarily to
commercial pesticide control services for controlling weeds in lawns, parks,
golf courses and athletic fields.

The product registration for Imprelis expired Sept. 8, and DuPont is no longer
selling the product.

Distributed by MCT Information Services

-in-investigation-of-DuPont-s-role-in-tree-destruction-0919-20140919

                              453 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                           January 18, 2001, Thursday

USDA: Another farm bailout needed; Low commodity prices: Without aid, farm
income will dip 10%, officials estimate

BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Pg. a10

LENGTH: 382 words

DATELINE: TRENTON, N.J. (AP)


WASHINGTON (AP) - Farm income will decrease 10 percent this year without another
multibillion-dollar bailout from Congress to compensate producers for low
commodity prices, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.

The department estimated net farm income will dip to $ 41.3 billion this year, $
4.1 billion less than last year, without a special aid program. In 2000, farmers
received $8 billion in emergency assistance from Congress, boosting net farm
income to $ 45.4 billion.

Average farm income for the 1990s was $ 45.3 billion per year.

Last year was the third year in a row that Congress has approved a
multibillion-dollar aid package to supplement the government's permanent farm
assistance. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said this week that another aid
package will be needed this year.

Farm groups already are developing a request. "We're working on a plan with the
rest of the commodity groups ... even as we speak to see if we can come up with
a consensus," said Mary Kay Thatcher, a lobbyist for the American Farm Bureau
Federation.

Crop prices plummeted in the late 1990s because of lagging exports and heavy
worldwide production.

"By historical standards, the last five years have been an unusually favorable
period for crop production," according to a report issued by the USDA's Economic
Research Service. "Not only has there been little adverse weather, but rainfall
has also been generally abundant and timely, not only in the United States but
also in the world's major agricultural producing countries."

Farmers received a record $ 22.1 billion in direct government payments last
year, including the emergency aid, $6.4 billion in crop subsidies and other
assistance.

Commodity prices are expected to rise enough to provide some help to farmers and
taxpayers. Federal crop subsidies, known to farmers as loan-deficiency payments,
are expected to drop $ 2 billion this year.

The USDA expects improvement for both crop and livestock farmers.

Total crop production for 2001 is projected to rise $ 4.7 billion to $ 101
billion. Total livestock production is estimated at $ 100.2 billion for 2001, up
$ 1 billion from last year, with the gains coming in higher prices for milk and
hogs. Income from cattle are expected to decline slightly.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Clinton pledges flood aid for Midwest

BYLINE: (Special)(CHICAGO TRIBUNE)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A13

LENGTH: 191 words

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill.


   MOLINE, Ill. (Special) - U.S. President Bill Clinton inspected flood-damaged
areas of Illinois and Iowa yesterday, pledging to release nearly $300 million in
additional disaster funds.

He also promised to ask Congress to approve even more aid to flood victims.

As the National Guard and others continued efforts to contain the swollen
Mississippi River, Clinton stopped here to view firsthand the results of the
worst flood in more than 100 years.

Clinton and Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy met with about 150 farmers and
business owners at a farm in Eldridge, Iowa, near Davenport, where flood damage
has been particularly severe.

In Manitoba, hundreds of people evacuated from a flooded town were allowed to
return to their homes today, but a state of emergency remained in effect as rain
continued to pour on the northern part of the province, Canadian Press reports.

An evacuation order for Minitonas, about 400 kilometres (252 miles) northwest of
Winnipeg, was lifted early this morning by the town's mayor, said Diana Soroka,
a spokesperson for Manitoba's Emergency Measures Organization.

                                The Denver Post

                    February 14, 2001 Wednesday 1ST EDITION

Farmers group sees seeds of disaster Rising costs for energy hit profits hard

BYLINE: By Steve Raabe, Denver Post Business Writer,

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-01

LENGTH: 616 words


Colorado's farmers and others across the nation face a  catastrophic drop in
income because of soaring energy and  fertilizer prices, an agriculture group
said Tuesday.

Already beset with low crop prices, farmers could face an  additional decline of
20 percent in net farm income over the next  two years without an emergency
infusion of federal aid, according  to the Food and Agricultural Policy Research
Institute at the  University of Missouri.

The policy group said in a report to Congress that farmers  may be hit with an
income loss of $ 9 billion by 2003 before  commodity prices are expected to
rise, helping turn around the  farm sector.

'I'm very concerned,' said vegetable grower Bob Sakata,  president of
Brighton-based Sakata Farms. 'Our cash flow was way  off last year because of
energy costs, and this year we'll be hit  with a double whammy because of higher
fertilizer costs.'

Natural gas is used in the manufacture of nitrogen-based  fertilizer. Many
Colorado farmers also use natural gas to fuel  irrigation pumps that supply
center-pivot sprinklers.

'There's no question that given the higher input costs and  lower commodity
prices, I will lose money this year,' said Steve  Scott of Scott Farm
Enterprises in Burlington, a grower of wheat,  corn and beans.

Scott said his cost for anhydrous ammonia, a common farm  fertilizer, has risen
to $ 425 a ton this year from $ 255 a ton last  year.

Speakers at the Colorado Agricultural Outlook Forum held  Tuesday in Denver said
it is probable that Congress will include  more emergency aid in a current farm
bill.

'Congress will address the issue,' said Barry Flinchbaugh,  chairman of the
Commission on 21st Century Production Agriculture  and a farm economist at
Kansas State University.

'Clearly the cloud on the horizon is energy costs,' said  Flinchbaugh, a keynote
speaker at the agriculture forum. 'The  average farmer cannot absorb these
higher costs.'

Colorado Agriculture Commissioner Don Ament said his  discussions with the
state's farmers show that energy and  fertilizer costs are a big concern.

'Nobody anticipated the types of increases we've seen in  natural gas prices on
top of low crop prices,' Ament said. 'You  don't have to be too much of a
dreamer to put all this together  and see that it spells trouble.'

Farmers received $ 8 billion in emergency aid last year.  Congress will begin
hearings this month on a long-term overhaul of  farm policy that includes
proposals for a new system for  subsidizing growers when crop income is down.

The report released Tuesday estimates that net farm income  will drop from $
45.4 billion last year to $ 39.6 billion in 2001  and $ 36.3 billion in 2002
before starting to turn around in the  following years as commodity prices rise.

Farm income peaked at $ 55 billion in 1996.

Government payments have been soaring since then, topping $ 22  billion last
year - triple what they were in 1996.

The cost of fuel that farmers need for tractors, combines and  irrigation
equipment jumped 31 percent last year, according to the  report.

Prices may drop slightly in coming months, but growers are  expected to be hit
this year with a 33 percent cost increase for  fertilizer, the congressionally
funded institute reported.

Meanwhile, the price of corn has averaged less than $ 2 a  bushel without a
significant increase for several years.

Cattle producers are in the best shape, in part because of  rising beef
consumption and the low grain prices, which result in  lower feed costs.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.


LOAD-DATE: February 14, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

farmers in many ways. Natural gas is used to fuel irrigation pumps that supply
center-pivot sprinklers like this one. The cost of fuel for tractors, combines
and irrigation equipment jumped 31 percent in 2000.

                               The New York Times

                             April 22, 2007 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Bush Administration Gains Support for New Approach on Global Food Aid

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 1289 words

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19


Waiters in white aprons maneuvered through a noisy cocktail party here Tuesday
evening, offering heaping platters of jumbo shrimp, lamb chops and crab-stuffed
mushrooms to a crowd of people in town for an annual food aid conference
dedicated to ending world hunger.

As shipping and agribusiness executives, charitable workers, lobbyists and
federal employees mingled at Morton's steakhouse, Charles Worledge, who works
for the Long Island-based Sealift Inc., a major shipper of American food to the
hungry, offered an insight essential to understanding the politics of food aid.

''I thought this was a charity,'' he explained during the party, for which
another shipping company played host. ''It's not. It's a business.''

It was here in Kansas City, at the 2005 food aid conference, that the Bush
administration pushed for a fundamental change in food aid that would have
diminished profits to domestic agribusiness and shipping companies. It proposed
allowing a quarter of the Food for Peace budget to be used to buy food in poor
countries near hunger crises, rather than buying only American-grown food that
had to be shipped across oceans.

And Secretary of Agriculture Mike Johanns spoke at the conference on Wednesday
to again make the administration's case for the same idea, contending that such
a policy would speed delivery, improve efficiency and save many lives.

Congress in each of the past two years killed the proposal, which was opposed by
agribusiness and shipping interests who stood to lose business, even as it won
support from liberal Democrats like Representatives Barney Frank of
Massachusetts and Earl Blumenauer of Oregon -- generally not a subset of
lawmakers found in the president's corner.

But there are signs that the frozen politics of the issue are beginning to thaw,
especially as evidence of flaws in the current aid system mounts.

A Government Accountability Office report released on the eve of this conference
described in stark detail a system rife with inefficiencies: the amount of food
shipped over the past five years has fallen by half as shipping and other
logistical costs have soared. Only a little more than a third of federal food
aid spending actually buys food. The United States feeds about 70 million people
a year now instead of the more than 100 million it fed five years ago.

And experts worry that the food aid budget will feed even fewer of the world's
850 million hungry people as soaring demand for corn to make ethanol drives up
the cost of that staple, a mainstay of food aid programs.

This year, some farm state lawmakers are for the first time considering backing
a pilot program to test buying food overseas. Representative Jo Ann Emerson, a
Missouri Republican on the Agricultural Subcommittee of the House Appropriations
Committee, opposes major changes in food aid, but, she said, ''doing a small
demonstration is fine with me.''

''If it turns out to work better in some places than others,'' she said, ''I
don't have a big problem with that.''

And some influential supporters of the administration's more ambitious proposal,
contained in the farm bill, are speaking out. Former President Bill Clinton
recently said at a fund-raiser for Bread for the World, a Christian group that
lobbies on hunger issues, that it was to Mr. Bush's ''everlasting credit'' that
he had proposed buying food aid in poor countries. Such a policy had never
crossed his mind when he was president, Mr. Clinton said, but he thought it was
a great way to help farmers in Africa and buy food more efficiently.

And while an alliance of 15 nonprofit groups involved in food aid has endorsed
only a pilot program for local purchase, Catholic Relief Services, which has a
million donors and links with 13,000 parishes, has embraced the administration's
proposal. Addressing hundreds of people assembled at the conference, Ken
Hackett, president of the agency, which is a major player in food aid, declared,
''C.R.S. supports the administration's request for greater flexibility through
local purchase.''

At perhaps no time since the government's food aid program was created during
the Eisenhower administration over a half century ago has there been more
ferment about its future among scholars, politicians and advocates for the poor.

The curious mix of altruistic and self-interested motivations that animate
American food aid spring from its origins. Early in the 1950s, the government
was the farmer's buyer of last resort when commodity prices fell, and as a
result it sat on mountains of grain. Public Law 480 and the Food for Peace
program, adopted in 1954, provided a way to dispose of the surplus grain, which
was costly to store, and at the same time feed the world's hungry people. The
law mandated that food for the program be grown domestically.

Over the years, the farm programs evolved, and the government shifted to buying
virtually all food on the open market, but the requirement that it be grown in
the United States never changed. In recent years, the United States has bought
more than half the food for its aid programs from just four agribusinesses and
their subsidiaries: Archer Daniels Midland, Cargill, Bunge and Cal Western
Packaging, according to the Agriculture Department.

Some researchers and advocates say it is time to rethink the American approach
to fighting world hunger.

''Are we committed to eradicating hunger because it's feasible, not terribly
expensive and our moral obligation as the richest society in human history?''
asked Christopher B. Barrett, a Cornell University economist and the co-author
of ''Food Aid After Fifty Years.'' ''Or are we just trying to placate a few
agribusiness, shipping and NGO constituencies with a handout?'' referring to
nongovernmental organizations.

But some in Congress, as well as lobbyists for interest groups that benefit from
food aid, warn that untying aid from requirements that the food be grown in
America and mostly shipped on American-flagged vessels would shatter the
political coalition that has sustained the program for decades and made the
United States the world's largest food aid donor. They also warn that cash sent
to poor countries can be misused or stolen, and that a mismanaged program to buy
food in poor countries could drive up food prices.

Still, even here at the food aid conference organized by the Department of
Agriculture and the Agency for International Development, some participants were
talking up approaches that would sound heretical to old-line champions of food
aid.

Marv Baldwin, president of the Foods Resource Bank, a Christian nonprofit group
dedicated to fighting hunger, described how more than a thousand farmers have
turned American-style food aid on its head.

They are raising farm animals and growing crops on some 7,000 acres across
America. They donate their land, labor and the use of their equipment, and
church groups help raise cash for fuel and fertilizer. But instead of shipping
the crops and animals to poor lands to feed the hungry, the farmers sell them in
the United States. The Foods Resource Bank then spends the money from those
sales in developing countries to buy seeds, fertilizer, tools and other goods
poor farmers say they need to grow food for their families.

Vernon Sloan, 81, used to donate and ship corn he grew on his 200- acre farm in
Ohio to Haiti, Liberia and Angola to feed the hungry. But after years of working
with the Foods Resource Bank, he said in an interview, he concluded that it was
more practical to sell the crops here, avoid the huge shipping expense and use
the proceeds to help farmers in Africa support themselves. ''It's what's needed
there,'' he said, ''rather than what we think they need.''

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 5, 1999, Wednesday

Analysts: beef tenders to Russia may be too late

BYLINE: BY JOHN HELMER

SECTION: COMMODITIES/CHEMICALS/ENERGY; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 665 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW


Russian government officials and American meatpackers have been asking,
""Where's the beef?''

The answer from the U.S. Department of Agriculture: Tenders for shipments to
Russia will be issued this week.

But analysts say that Russia's meat shortage has passed, courtesy of assistance
from the European Union, thus making any U.S. assistance effort a questionable
exercise.

The American and European aid programs were first devised last year, following
the mid-August collapse of the Russian financial system and a fourfold
devaluation of the ruble. Meat, grain, and milk-powder donations were planned to
meet expected shortfalls in domestic supplies.

But Russian officials said months of delay in negotiating the preliminaries
means the food aid is arriving during the spring and summer seasons, when
domestic Russian supplies, and low-cost food from neighboring Ukraine and
Belarus, are plentiful in the marketplace.

The U.S. food aid program to Russia, formally agreed to last December, includes
120,000 tons of beef and 50,000 tons of pork. More than a month ago, USDA
officials met in Washington with representatives of the meat-packing companies,
such as Monfort and Iowa Beef Processors, to tell them that purchase tenders
were on the way.

On April 9, USDA formally authorized funds for the purchases. And this week
USDA, with assistance from a working group of U.S. and Russian officials in
Moscow, have finalized the tender offer process.

But the delay in releasing the bids has some critics asking: Why bother?

""There are mutually conflicting claims about what is going on,'' said one
trader. ""The whole thing is so politicized, I don't want to get caught between
those people.''

Another trade source said he believed USDA had slowed the tender process fearing
a backlash of reaction in the United States, in response to vocal opposition by
the Russian government to the U.S. bombing campaign in Yugoslavia.

U.S. officials emphatically deny the charge. They attribute the delays to
technical details that had to be negotiated before the purchase specifications
could be fixed.

According to one source, it has taken longer than expected for U.S. and Russian
officials to agree on exactly what cuts of meat should be included in the
delivery program. The Russians reportedly have favored higher-quality cuts for
direct consumption, while the Americans preferred to offer lower- quality cuts
for processing into sausage.

That issue has been resolved, a U.S. source said Friday, noting that the tenders
will ""probably'' go out this week.

At the same time, EU officials say the delivery schedule for their beef and pork
aid to Russia has slipped, but that sea and truck shipments are ""mostly on
schedule.''

The EU agreed in February to deliver 150,000 tons of beef and 100,000 tons of
pork to Russia. EU officials acknowledge that until very recently, they were
unable to agree with their Russian counterparts on the price at which their food
products should be sold.

According to one source in Moscow, there were disagreements over what the
prevailing market price payable for the goods should be. Also in dispute were
the costs of transport and processing meat deliveries that can be deducted from
the gross sales price, before the receipts must be deposited in the special bank
accounts the EU has established.

According to the EU pact with Russia, the money from these accounts will be
spent to clear arrears in payment of pensions and other government welfare
obligations. The U.S. food aid agreement with Russia makes similar arrangements.

To check that these are being faithfully implemented, the United States has
appointed special monitors. For its part, the EU is spending several million
dollars on a special auditing contract.

European officials claim they have been able to start deliveries, and activate
the logistic chain, as they negotiated a solution to technical and financial
details of their beef and pork programs.

                              Journal of Commerce

                           December 21, 1990, Friday

PORT OF LAKE CHARLES BENEFITS FROM FOOD FOR PEACE SHIPMENTS

BYLINE: Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 300 words

DATELINE: LAKE CHARLES, La.


The Port of Lake Charles is reaping the benefits of a change in U.S. law
governing the allocation of food aid cargoes among ports.

Lake Charles officials say their port won the lion's share of shipments that
will be exported in December under the U.S. Department of Agriculture Public aw
480 program, also known as Food for Peace.

The Louisiana port received 39 percent of the nationwide total of 142,000 short
tons of milled rice and beans, peas and lentils available for shipment this
month, the port said.

With the USDA no longer required to route a fixed portion of food aid shipments
through Great Lakes ports this year, more of those shipments have been moving
through Gulf ports such as Lake Charles.

As a result, Lake Charles is handling record volumes of breakbulk cargoes, the
Lake Charles Harbor & Terminal District said in announcing the port's cargo
volume figures for the third quarter of 1990.

A compromise measure enacted by Congress earlier this year will restore the
so-called Great Lakes set-aside, but at a much lower level than existed before
the program was allowed to expire at the end of 1989.

Breakbulk cargoes include foodstuffs such as flour, beans, rice, peas and
lentils, as well as forest products.

Breakbulk volume at the Louisiana port climbed 4 percent to 131,639 short tons
in the recent quarter, from 126,000 short tons during the same period of 1989.
Flour shipments surged 317 percent, to 8,262 short tons, while forest products
jumped 329 percent to 33,293 shorttons. Port figures show similar volume gains
for the first nine months of 1990, compared with the same period of 1989.

Foodstuffs account for 65 percent of the port's general cargo volume.

Lake Charles handled 417,208 tons of containerized carg o during the third
quarter.

                              The Washington Post

                            September 3, 2001 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Education by the Numbers

SECTION: ; Pg. A19

LENGTH: 347 words


While education mostly is a state and local responsibility, the federal
government contributes to schools through Title I grants to disadvantaged
students, the Agriculture Department's school lunch program and college
financial aid, among other programs. Here is a numerical look at the
government's role in education and facts about the nation's schools.

* Percentage of national education spending that comes from the federal
government: 9 percent

* Amount of money the federal government spent on elementary and secondary
education in 2000: $ 40 billion.

* Portion of federal budget that goes to the Department of Education: 2 percent.

* Approximate number of Education Department employees: 4,700.

* Year original Education Department was created: 1867.

* Year Education Department became a Cabinet-level agency: 1980.

* Percentage of undergraduate college students who received financial aid in the
1999-2000 school year: 39 percent.

* Average amount of federal student aid received by undergraduate college
students in 1999-2000 school year: $ 5,230.

* Amount of Title I money allocated to the District of Columbia in the 2000-2001
school year: $ 25.6 million.

* Amount of Title I money allocated to Maryland in the 2000-2001 school year: $
104.4 million.

* Amount of Title I money allocated to Virginia in the 2000-2001 school year: $
120.5 million.

* Number of students who receive low-cost free lunches through the Agriculture
Department's school lunch program: 27 million.

* Cost of national school lunch program in fiscal 2000: $ 5.6 billion.

* Amount a school is reimbursed for each free lunch it serves: $ 2.09.

* Number of children enrolled in public elementary and secondary schools: 47
million.

* Percentage of people 16 to 24 years old who have dropped out of high school:
11 percent.

* Number of computers available for use in elementary and secondary classrooms:
10.5 million.

* Percentage of public schools with Internet access in fall 1999: 95 percent.

SOURCES: Census Bureau, National Center for Educational Statistics, Agriculture
Department.
