                              The Washington Post

                             March 10, 2014 Monday
                                Suburban Edition

States find ways to skirt food-stamp cuts, thwarting congressional spending
goals

BYLINE: Derek Wallbank;Alan Bjerga;- Bloomberg News

SECTION: A-SECTION; Pg. A13

LENGTH: 814 words


Congress last month passed a revamp of agriculture and food policy that was
supposed to save the U.S. government $8.6 billion in food-stamp costs over a
decade.

That may not happen, though, now that some states are finding a way to avoid the
cuts.

New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania are triggering extra nutrition spending
by adding money to a home-heating subsidy tied to increased food-stamp aid. The
move feeds needy families while thwarting spending-reduction goals.

Deficit watchers say they are disappointed, while anti-hunger activists are
lobbying other states to do the same. If more follow, the federal government
would have to spend much of the $8.6 billion it planned to save, as states
reduce spending on other programs to meet the new mandate.

"Some states will be able to do it, some states will not be able to. No one
knows for how long they'll be able to do it," Rep. Rosa DeLauro (D-Conn.) said.
"They have jumped into the breach where the federal government abdicated its
responsibility."

Federal spending on food stamps - formally called the Supplemental Nutrition
Assistance Program - has more than doubled in the past five years, with most of
the money spent at retailers. The program cost a record $79.9 billion in fiscal
2013, almost one-eighth of the roughly $650 billion a year that Americans spend
on groceries.

Some of that food aid is tied to the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program,
also known by its acronym, LIHEAP.

Under the previous farm law, states that gave residents as little as $1 a year
in home-heating assistance -  a move nicknamed "heat-and-eat" - could qualify
that person's household for an average of $1,080 in additional food stamps
annually from the U.S. government.

About 15 states and the District of Columbia did just that, catching the
attention of lawmakers who sought savings through the farm bill. "States were
gaming the system," Sen. Pat Roberts (R-Kan.) said last month.

The new law raises to $20 a year the home-heating aid needed for a household to
get extra food-stamp money. The idea is that most of those 15 states will stop
qualifying residents for the food aid and save the U.S. government money.

That's not happening in New York. The state said it raised home-heating spending
by $6 million, triggering an additional $457 million a year in federal
food-stamp spending.

Lawmakers who supported even deeper cuts to food stamps than those eventually
included in the farm law have criticized states for using the rules to erode
savings.

"We didn't expect that, or we would've written it in the language to prohibit
it," said Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa), chairman of the House Agriculture
subcommittee that oversees food stamps and nutrition aid. The move, though
legal, is "perverse, just perverse," he said.

States pushing to maintain the aid call it necessary.

"These federal cuts have made it harder for our state's most vulnerable
residents to put food on the table. The state has intervened on behalf of these
low-income New Yorkers," Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo (D) said in a statement Feb 25.
"New York is stepping up to help families in need."

Connecticut is spending an extra $1.4 million to preserve federal food-stamp
money for about 50,000 households, Gov. Dan Malloy (D) said the day before
Cuomo's announcement. Pennsylvania said Wednesday that it will spend $8 million
to preserve $300 million in food-stamp funding for up to 400,000 families.

The moves are encouraging in their commitment to helping the hungry, said Ellen
Vollinger, a food-stamp lobbyist with the Food Research and Action Center in
Washington.

At the same time, it's frustrating that states may have to divert resources from
other necessary programs to counteract congressional budget cuts, she said.

"This was always budget-driven," Vollinger said. "Discussions in Washington can
be academic, but $90 a month for needy families is a real number. It's shifting
a burden to the states, and it's doubtful how many of them will be able to do
it."

Vollinger said anti-hunger activists are lobbying states affected by mandates in
the new law to increase their home-heating assistance.

Recently, 16 senators and 81 House members wrote to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture seeking a delay in the food-stamp cuts. The agency, in a memo to
states on Wednesday, said it cannot put off the reductions.

Meanwhile, budget watchdogs who supported the cuts are not pleased, either.

"True reform would have included stringent work requirements for food-stamp
eligibility," said Andy Roth, government affairs vice president with Club for
Growth, a Washington small-government advocacy group. "Even better, devolve the
program back to the states" as block grants, which would end the temptation to
exploit quirks in federal law, he said.

About 47 million Americans got food stamps in November, the latest month for
which data were available, the USDA said Friday.

- Bloomberg News

                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             April 5, 2008 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

KIND, RYAN ARE WRONG

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 260 words


Rep. Ron Kind, who has worked with East Coast think tanks to undermine the
safety net for working farmers in Wisconsin throughout the current farm bill
fight, is playing a dangerous game when he seeks to pit supporters of
conservation programs against supporters of permanent agricultural disaster
assistance.

Both conservation and disaster assistance funding needs to be in the farm bill.

Kind, a La Crosse Democrat, and Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Janesville, are trying to
suggest that disaster aid will be "monopolized" by farmers in a few states while
voluntary conservation programs can help farmers everywhere. But what Kind is
not saying is that availability of disaster aid determines whether farm families
that have been hit by storms, floods or other natural catastrophes can stay on
the land.

Funding a permanent disaster assistance program would provide working farmers
with protections they currently lack.

Instead of playing games with the farm bill, Kind, Ryan and their allies should
be working with the House Agriculture Committee to ensure that the legislation
includes adequate funding for conservation and disaster relief programs.

Unfortunately, Kind is more interested in eliminating protections for working
farmers, as part of an initiative that would ultimately give corporate
agribusiness the upper hand in American agriculture, than in doing right by
them.

Kind has consistently taken stands that, while popular with think tanks in New
York and Washington, have been opposed by all the major groups representing
working farmers. He is doing so again.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            August 15, 1993, Sunday

SOUTH IN BRIEF Women literally build better lives in rural Mississippi

BYLINE: Compiled by Mike Smith

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 4

LENGTH: 464 words


A tiny spot near Sumner, Miss., has been transformed from Dirty Corners to New
Hope, thanks to two women who were determined that their families and three
others would lead better lives.

The women wrote to Mike Espy, who was their congressman at the time and now is
U.S. secretary of agriculture. He turned for help to the United Parcel Service
Foundation and a federal housing program. The UPS group gave $ 100,000 for
building materials, and Delta Housing Development Corp. obtained other funds and
taught the families building skills.

The five families now are living in new homes instead of shacks. "We got
everything," says Marie Woodson, 10, whose mother, Susan, helped get the ball
rolling. "In the old house, we didn't have a bathroom. It was outside. When I
had to go to the bathroom, I would put my shoes on."

BATTLE OF THE BOOKS: The Bradley County (Tenn.) Commission, siding with library
officials and staff, voted overwhelmingly last week to keep 18 library books
about AIDS, sex education and the supernatural. The Concerned Women of America
chapter in Cleveland was demanding that the commission fire the head librarian
and the library's oversight board as well as remove the books, which included
such titles as "A Young Man's Guide to Sex" and "What's Happening to My Body." A
couple of hundred people attended the special commission meeting, and most
applauded after the 11-2 vote in favor of the books.

HIGH AND DRY: A posh Palm Beach, Fla., yacht club lost its state docks recently
over allegations that its members regularly blackball minorities who wish to
join. By unanimous vote, Gov. Lawton Chiles and his Cabinet stripped the
Sailfish Club of use of the docks and said the state would tear them down in six
months if the club hasn't done so before then. The club says it has some Jewish
members but acknowledges having no black ones. The state officials threatened
similar action against any other yacht club found to discriminate.

SAY WHAT?

"I knew there were good people in this world, and I know where they are. They're
down South." - Joyce Lane of Brooklyn, N.Y., after learning that a South
Carolina man whom she has never met has been raising funds to ship home the body
of her son Cameron, who was killed in a drug dispute in Charleston. Doug
Gilmore, a drug abuse counselor, said he started the fund because he thinks the
dead man, "regardless of his lifestyle, deserves a decent burial." HED ELSEWHERE

A Greeneville, Tenn., lawyer was sentenced to 10 days in jail and fined $ 50 for
punching another lawyer in the eye during a court hearing involving a hotly
contested child custody case. . . . Broward County, Fla., police arrested a
71-year-old woman on crack cocaine charges - as a granddaughter and two
great-grandchildren watched.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

              August 05, 1999, Thursday, 0 South Pinellas Edition

Senate okays $ 7.4-billion in farm assistance

SOURCE: Compiled from Times Wires

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 405 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON



The Senate on Wednesday approved $ 7.4-billion in emergency aid for farmers hurt
by depressed crop prices and brutal droughts, setting the stage for negotiations
with the House.

The money was added by voice vote to the Agriculture Department spending bill
for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

Fiscal conservatives warned that Congress is sending the message that its
generosity to farmers knows almost no bounds. The Senate measure would take more
than half of next year's projected $ 14-billion budget surplus.

A House-Senate committee will negotiate the final bill.

Holbrooke moves closer

to Senate confirmation

WASHINGTON - After 14 months, the last remaining obstacle to Senate confirmation
of Richard Holbrooke as U.N. ambassador fell Wednesday as Iowa Republican
Charles Grassley dropped his hold on the nomination and switched it to three
other diplomatic appointments.

With other senators abandoning efforts to hold Holbrooke hostage for unrelated
concessions by the Clinton administration, Grassley's action appeared to clear
the way for Holbrooke's confirmation before Congress leaves this week.

Grassley said he had no more objection to these three than he did to Holbrooke.

He said he was using them to force the State Department to protect whistle
blowers and reach a deal with Linda Shenwick, an employee who complained to
Congress about mismanagement at the United Nations and was reassigned.

Liberians in U.S. may

lose protected status

The State Department said Wednesday that while Liberia continues to struggle
from the effects of civil war, the West African nation is stable and it is
recommending that the 1,000 to 1,500 Liberians granted special status return
home by Sept. 28.

After civil war erupted in 1989, Liberians were granted temporary permission to
live and work in the United States. The special immigration status was extended
year after year, and many Liberians were able to begin new lives.

While the country is largely at peace, much of it is still without electricity
and passable roads, and supplies remain short.

The Temporary Protected Status allows foreigners to stay in the United States if
their home countries suffer political violence or natural disasters.

Liberians whose temporary protected status expires have the right to apply for
political asylum.

Liberia's civil war ravaged the country from 1989 to 1996, leaving an estimated
200,000 people dead.

TYPE: DIGEST

                              464 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 October 16, 1998, Friday, Late Edition - Final

THE BUDGET DEAL: AGRICULTURE;
Proposed Farm Aid Signals A Shift in Economic Winds

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, By The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 693 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 15


The agreement to spend $6 billion on the nation's farmers marks a departure, at
least in spirit, from a landmark 1996 measure intended to move agriculture into
a free market economy.

The aid, which comes in addition to the more than $5 billion that has already
been appropriated for farmers this year, is intended to salve an agricultural
economy that has been hurt by weather disasters, crop diseases and falling
commodity prices.

The bid to rescue farmers is a contrast to the 1996 law, under which subsidies
will be phased out by 2002.

"Congress is demonstrating an unwillingness to let the free market control the
agricultural economy -- at least in an election year," said Neil Harl, an
agricultural economist at Iowa State University. "There is a big upside to the
market approach. And there's a big downside. And that downside causes pain."

The bill earmarks about $3 billion for farmers hurt by disaster, especially in
the Southwest and the upper Great Plains. Farmers in Oklahoma and Texas endured
severe drought, while those in the Dakotas saw crops devastated by disease.

The bill also includes about $2.5 billion to help farmers hurt by falling crop
prices, a result of stronger foreign competition, especially in South America,
as well as weaker import demands, particularly in Asia. Prices have also been
driven down by the good weather that brought abundant harvests in the central
Midwestern states, which produce most of the nation's corn and soybeans.

"This is definitely going to help," said Brent Kleinsasser, a grain farmer in
Huron, S.D. "But is it going to make or break many farmers? I don't think so."

The measure also gives $200 million in subsidies to dairy farmers, although milk
prices have strongly rebounded lately, and $200 million for stockmen, especially
in the Southwest, where forage for grazing cattle burned in the intense heat.

The bill was a compromise between a Republican measure that would have spent
about $4.2 billion and a Democratic version that would have spent about $7
billion. President Clinton vetoed the Republican measure last week.

Farm groups generally praised the bill. Mary Kay Thatcher, a spokeswoman for the
American Farm Bureau, which usually supports the Republican view on agriculture,
said the measure kept the Federal Government out of farming decisions, a tenet
of the 1996 measure.

Democrats in the Upper Great Plains, sometimes known as the "prairie populists"
-- a group that includes Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota -- had hoped to
restore some Government control over planting decisions that were eliminated by
the 1996 law. In the view of some critics of the 1996 measure, including the
more liberal National Farmers Union, the free market approach has led to
overproduction of some crops, causing prices to fall.

"We've seen what happens when the market takes over -- prices drop through the
floor," said Marilyn Wentz, a spokeswoman for the National Farmers Union. Ms.
Wentz said the new money would help many farmers avoid foreclosure. Nearly a
quarter of farmers in some parts of the Southwest had been facing financial
failure, she said.

The bill also underscores the powerful influence of agriculture on the nation's
political debate. Only about 600,000 commercial farmers remain, but millions of
Americans can trace their ancestry to the farm and see the way of life as a
symbol of American virtue.

Support for the subsidies started last summer, when politicians in the Dakotas
urged President Clinton to help farmers with a payment of $500 million. Farmers
and politicians in other states then called for relief, as crop prices fell.

Critics of subsidies have long complained that farmers have no special right to
a safety net. Unsuccessful farms should fail, just like unsuccessful drug stores
and auto repair shops, critics say.

But Mr. Kleinsasser, the South Dakota farmer, said farmers were not the only
ones who gained from aid to agriculture.

"The more farms there are, the longer food will stay cheap," he said. "When you
get a handful of big corporations that control food production, the prices would
go way up."
   DIRK JOHNSON

LOAD-DATE: October 16, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             October 2, 1998 Friday
                                  City Edition

Bereuter path on farm aid best approach

SECTION: B; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 442 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, NE


First District Rep. Doug Bereuter has a sound, responsible approach to helping
farmers at a time when commodity prices have plunged to lows not seen since the
1980s. Breaking with his GOP cohorts, Bereuter said this week the Republican
plan "is not sufficiently generous" to meet the needs of agriculture under
current economic conditions.

House and Senate conferees Wednesday chose the Republican plan, which would
provide $4 billion in aid, over a Democratic plan which would have provided $7.1
billion in tax subsidies to farmers.

Agriculture was one of the first sectors of the economy to be buffeted by the
Asian financial crisis. Export markets in some Asian nations have virtually
evaporated. Now markets in Latin America also are being affected.

In addition to providing a cushion against low prices, the aid package under
consideration in Congress is intended to help farmers who have been hit by
drought and other adverse weather conditions.

Debate over the size of an aid package for farmers unfortunately has bogged down
in partisan rhetoric and a running debate over the five-year Freedom to Farm act
approved by Congress in 1996.

The Republican aid package unfortunately also rejects other measures that would
provide substantial benefit to agriculture. For example, it does not require
mandatory price reporting, which would allow cattle producers to know what
packing plants are paying for beef.

It also does not include a provision to require labeling showing the national
origin of meat. The measure would allow consumers to select beef produced in the
U.S. rather than other countries.While pushing for more financial help for
farmers, Bereuter rightly resists a return to previous ag policies that are part
of the Democratic approach, which would base subsidies for grain farmers on the
so-called loan rate.

Previous farm policy was based on a heavily bureaucratic approach with strict
government dictates. Proponents of the Freedom to Farm act left more
decision-making to farmers, at the same time leaving them more subject to market
pressures.

In the long run, the market-oriented approach under Freedom to Farm will benefit
agriculture, although it certainly should be open for modification and
improvement.

But now, while farmers are facing a double whammy of record harvests and low
prices, is not the time to get bogged down in partisan debate over basic
philosophy.

Providing aid under the payment system of the existing farm bill makes sense.
But, as Bereuter suggested, the amount should be more generous than Republicans
have agreed to so far to preserve the stability and capability of the sector of
the economy that feeds the nation.

LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              Journal of Commerce

                            June 14, 1990, Thursday

HOUSE PANEL AMENDS FOOD AID PROVISIONS

BYLINE: ROSE A. HOROWITZ; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 8B

LENGTH: 262 words


The House Agriculture Committee moved Wednesday to modify provisions of the farm
bill that incorporate the Bush administration's position on changing the system
for transporting food aid shipments.

Even with the new amendments, the House agriculture bill calls for less changes
in the current system than the Senate farm bill. The Senate version eliminates
foreign agents representing foreign countries and requires the U.S. epartment of
Agriculture to take over their role.

House Agriculture Chairman E. de la Garza, D-Texas, introduced three amendments
to the committee on Wednesday, said a staff aide. The committee was expected to
adopt the amendments, said an aide, who asked not to be identified.

The revamping of the transportation system for the $ 1.4 billion food aid
program is designed to make the program more efficient and to resolve questions
of possible fraud and abuse raised by government investigators.

The amendments incorporate three of four proposals made by the Bush
administration. The changes would:

* Prohibit shipping agents from representing suppliers of ocean transportation
or related services during the course of the fiscal year. The House Agriculture
original bill precludes agents from representing suppliers ''at the same time."

* Require full and open competition in connection with all food aid shipments.

* Provide authority for the U.S. government to regulate commissions paid to
country agents or other representatives of importers on foreign-flag shipments.
Current regulations apply to U.S.-flag shipments.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 July 21, 1998, Tuesday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

NEBRASKA OFFERS FREE COUNSELING TO FARMERS

BYLINE: Barry Bedlan; The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A4

LENGTH: 233 words

DATELINE: OMAHA, NEB.


Low grain prices and a damaging drought are making life so difficult for farmers
in southwest Nebraska that the state is offering them free counseling.

"We're going to see a lot of clients later in the year when the banks have to
foreclose on some farmers and the situation hits home even harder," said Joyce
Boyd of Counseling Professionals in McCook, Neb. "It is going to be bad."

The Nebraska Department of Agriculture is offering farm families unlimited
telephone consultations on a 24-hour hot line and up to three face-to-face
meetings with professional counselors. Everything is confidential.

"There is a lot of talk about depression, a lot of stress and hidden emotions at
this time in the area," said Larry Sitzman, state agriculture director. "People
may become reclusive after not meeting bills and not know where to turn to or
what to do. We want to help."

Last year in South Dakota, at least six farmers committed suicide because of
lost crops and other difficult conditions, Sitzman said. He sai d he hopes the
free counseling may help save the lives of farmers in the same situation in
Nebraska.

"Free counseling is a great idea because farmers don't have the support of a
company or a human resources department to turn to like many other jobs do,"
said Jean Faber, account services supervisor for the Methodist Employee
Assistance Program, based in Omaha.

LANGUAGE: English

                          The Herald-Sun (Durham, NC)

                            August 4, 2001 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Veto threat prompts Senate to pass smaller farm aid bill;
Bush praises $5.5 billion agriculture bailout, but Democrats say it won't make
up for low prices

BYLINE: By PHILIP BRASHER Associated Press

SECTION: INSIDE FRONT; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 576 words


WASHINGTON - The Senate gave final congressional approval to a $5.5 billion farm
assistance package Friday after Democrats bowed to a White House threat to veto
a fatter measure.

"This vote is a victory for our nation's farmers at a time when they need it
most," President Bush said, promising to sign the measure.

Democrats saw it a bit differently. The Senate abruptly approved the legislation
on a voice vote after the Democrats failed to break a Republican filibuster of a
$7.5 billion measure that had been approved by the Agriculture Committee.

"The gun was held to our heads, and the White House refused to compromise," said
the committee chairman, Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa.

It's the fourth straight year that Congress has provided a multibillion-dollar
bailout of the farm economy to compensate for low crop prices. The latest
measure should boost net farm income to $47.9 billion, $2.7 billion above last
year and the highest level since 1997.

Grain and cotton farmers, who receive the bulk of the special assistance, will
get smaller checks than under last year's bailout. A farmer who got $40,000 in
2000 should receive less than $34,000 this year.

After meeting with the president Friday, Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman said
the farm crisis is ebbing, particularly when it comes to milk, livestock and
even grains, where prices are improving. Overall for farmers, she said, "There
is some easing in the downturn of pricing we've seen in recent years."

With Congress breaking for a monthlong recess this weekend, senators were in a
rush to finish work on the bill. The congressional budget agreement provided
$5.5 billion in farm aid for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30, so the cash had
to be distributed to farmers by that date or it could have been used for other
purposes.

Senate Republican leaders got four major farm groups representing soybean, corn,
cotton and wheat growers to sign a letter urging passage of the smaller aid
package. Had the Senate passed the Democratic bill, lawmakers would have had to
negotiate a compromise in September.

But the nation's largest farm group, the American Farm Bureau Federation,
doesn't think $5.5 billion is enough and declined to sign the GOP letter.

A state-by-state look

Grants that would be provided to each state to assist farmers who grow crops
other than grain, cotton, oilseeds and peanuts:

California, $63.3 million

Florida, $16.9 million

Washington, $9.6 million

Idaho, $3.7 million

Arizona, $3.4 million

Michigan, $3.3 million

Oregon, $3.2 million

Georgia, $2.7 million

Texas, $2.7 million

New York, $2.7 million

Wisconsin, $2.6 million

North Carolina, $1.5 million

Colorado, $1.5 million

North Dakota, $1.4 million

Minnesota, $1.3 million

Hawaii, $1.2 million

New Jersey, $1.1 million

Pennsylvania, $980,000

New Mexico, $900,000

Maine, $880,000

Ohio, $800,000

Indiana, $660,000

Nebraska, $640,000

Massachusetts,$640,000

Virginia, $620,000

Maryland, $500,000

Louisiana, $460,000

South Carolina, $440,000

Tennessee, $400,000

Illinois, $400,000

Oklahoma, $390,000

Alabama, $300,000

Delaware, $290,000

Mississippi, $250,000

Kansas, $210,000

Arkansas, $210,000

Missouri, $210,000

Connecticut, $180,000

Utah, $140,000

Montana, $140,000

New Hampshire, $120,000

Nevada, $120,000

Vermont, $120,000

Iowa, $100,000

West Virginia, $90,000

Wyoming, $70,000

Kentucky, $60,000

South Dakota, $40,000

Rhode Island, $40,000

Alaska, $20,000

Each state would also receive $500,000 to "support activities that promote
agriculture." Puerto Rico would get $1 million.

                              471 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                              May 16, 2008 Friday

BYLINE: JONATHAN RIVOLI Bismarck Tribune Permanent disaster aid a k

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 432 words


North Dakota government and agriculture officials agree that the farm bill
passed Thursday should benefit farmers across the state, especially through the
implementation of a $3.8 billion permanent disaster aid fund.

The bill passed by a veto-proof margin, meaning that it is almost assured to
become law despite longstanding White House opposition.

It provides federal funding for five years worth of food stamp and related
nutrition programs, crop subsidies, payments to farmers who put their land in a
conservation program, and renewable energy development incentives.

Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson said he thinks the permanent disaster aid
title will be of the greatest immediate benefit to North Dakota farmers. He said
the old system of having to pass a separate bill each time there was a
crop-killing disaster took too long, while the new system will guarantee these
payments and get them there in a timely manner.

While important, the crop supports will likely play less of a factor in the near
future because the market prices are all much higher than the support prices.

"I'm pleased with the bill overall," Johnson said.

Dan Wogsland, executive director of the North Dakota Grain Growers Association,
said North Dakota farmers will benefit greatly from the permanent disaster aid
because they operate in an environment with more weather risk than colleagues in
other states. Wogsland also said it's a good bill for a state that grows a wide
diversity of crops because it provides some protection for them all.

"I think everyone's breathing a sigh of relief that we got a farm bill," he
said.

That sigh extended from here in North Dakota to the D.C. offices of the state's
Democratic congressional delegation. Sens. Kent Conrad and Byron Dorgan, and
Rep. Earl Pomeroy have all been leading advocates for the bill as it wound its
way through the process.

"These votes in the House and Senate illustrate the bipartisan consensus we were
able to build for this farm bill," Pomeroy said in a statement

From back home, Republican Gov. John Hoeven was pushing the bill with the White
House and other involved players on his side of the aisle.

One area of disappointment was payment limits to the wealthiest of farmers and
agricultural operations. Even though the bill included a $40,000 per year
payment cap, Johnson said he would have liked to see tighter income restrictions
on who receives them.

Dorgan spearheaded an attempt to do just that in the initial Senate debate, but
was shot down by his colleagues.

(Reach reporter Jonathan Rivoli at 223-8482 or
jonathan.rivoli@bismarcktribune.com.)

LOAD-DATE: May 16, 2008

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 3, 1990, Thursday

SHIP AGENT ATTACKS FOOD AID OVERSIGHT

BYLINE: ALLEN R. WASTLER; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 591 words


A foreign country shipping agent has launched an attack on the U.S. Department
of Agriculture and its administration of the federal Food for Peace program.

The agent, New York-based Trans-Orient Marine Corp., is telling other brokers
that the department has an informal policy of allowing "kickbacks" from brokers
to their client countries. The agent is backing its claim with letters from the
department sent in response to Trans-Orient's complaints about the ractices of a
competitor.

Trans-Orient hopes its actions will force the agency to take a public stand on
how commissions are handled among the shipowners, brokers and foreign countries
participating in the Food for Peace program.

Such a declaration could help Trans-Orient win back business it lost to Star
Trading and Marine Inc., Washington, D.C.

"It is going to put USDA between all the agents and the embassies," said Alison
Dobra, president of Trans-Orient.

Under the Food for Peace program, the federal government arranges special loans
for impoverished countries to buy U.S. agricultural goods.

The countries receiving the food aid select an agent to secure transportation
for their purchases. The country agent receives commissions from the shipowners
it selects to handle Food for Peace cargo.

Last fall, the General Accounting Office, a watchdog congressional agency,
warned Congress about the "vulnerability of the program" to fraud and abuse by
foreign country agents.

"What they (Trans-Orient) are saying is a confirmation of what we've suggested,"
said Phil Thomas, assistant director of international trade for the GAO.

For several years Trans-Orient has been trying to get the USDA to levy sanctions
against Star. Star shares the commissions it receives from foreign flag ship
owners with its country client, Sri Lanka.

Trans-Orient claims that this is essentially a "kickback" from Star to Sri Lanka
for allowing Star to serve as its agent, an apparent violation of USDA
regulations on kickbacks. Both Star and the USDA state the practice is not a
violation of regulations and is proper.

In several pieces of correspondence, most recently a letter from the USDA
inspector general's office, the department has maintained that the Star
arrangement is not a violation of USDA rules. Trans-Orient wants the rest of the
Food for Peace industry to take that as a blanket endorsement by the USDA of
shared commissions in the industry.

Whether Trans-Orient's admonitions will carry any weight with other agents is
debatable.

"I don't think too many people take Trans-Orient that seriously," said one agent
executive, who asked not to be named.

Others, however, agree with Trans-Orient that the USDA has to publicly explain
why a "shared commission" doesn't amount to a kickback.

"In this case he (Trans-Orient) has a point," said another agent, who also asked
not to be identified.

The USDA admits that there is a problem with the application of its anti-
kickback rule.

"We are conceding that people read the regulation and come to different
interpretations of what it means," said Glen Whiteman, deputy assistant
administrator in the USDA's Foreign Agricultural Service. "We need to clarify
it."

The USDA is currently trying to rewrite the regulations, Mr. Whiteman said. The
effort is running behind schedule because of bureaucratic problems, he said.

The USDA, in conjunction with the U.S. attorney's office in Washington, has been
investigating Star for more than three years. Star officials were unavailable
for comment.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                            March 25, 1993 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

CRAWFORD ASKS TO DECLARE STATE A DISASTER AREA

BYLINE: By LISA SHUCHMAN, Palm Beach Post Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 181 words


Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford asked Gov. Lawton Chiles on Wednesday to
request that federal authorities declare the entire state a disaster area

-- a move that would trigger federal aid for Florida's farmers.

Certain types of disaster aid cannot be provided until a declaration is

requested by the governor and issued by either the U.S. Secretary of

Agriculture or the president, said Crawford spokeswoman Michelle McLawhorn.

The governor had not yet seen the request Wednesday, said Jo Miglino,

spokeswoman for the governor's office.

Crawford said federal assistance could make the difference in salvaging

the spring growing season, which was reaching its peak when the March 13 storm
hit.

Twenty-one counties already qualify for aid because they are included in

the previous disaster declaration. Most others qualify because they are next

to one of the covered counties or because they suffered crop damage in excess of
30 percent.

But declaring the entire state a disaster area would simplify the process for
farmers, McLawhorn said.

A dollar estimate of storm damage is not yet available.

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                           December 4, 2004 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

REFORMING FARM SUBSIDIES IS TOUGH ROW TO HOE

BYLINE: By Sara F. Cooper Guest Columnist

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Sara F. Cooper guest column; Pg. A05

LENGTH: 795 words


When Nebraska Gov. Mike Johanns, whom President Bush has just nominated to be
the next secretary of agriculture, takes office, his first order of business
should be pushing for an end to America's drastically distorted farm subsidy
programs.

Eliminating U.S. farm subsidies would dramatically reduce government spending,
end a program that mostly benefits corporate interests and the wealthy,
strengthen U.S. agriculture, give us needed leverage in international trade
negotiations, and allow the United States to extricate itself from the
embarrassing practice of undermining its own foreign-aid program.

The United States made $17 billion in direct government payments to farmers and
ranchers in 2003 - amounting to 32 percent of net farm income. On top of this
were additional billions in indirect assistance, delivered via subsidized loans
and insurance, loan guarantees and tax breaks.

IF THE FARM lobby's argument that such largesse is necessary to preserve the
family farm ever applied, it doesn't now. According to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, about 40 percent of all farms receive government payments of some
kind. The bulk of these payments, however, go to larger farms. In fact, while
just 7 percent of all U.S. farms have sales of $250,000 or more, this 7 percent
receive almost half of all government payments.

How could a domestic aid program become so distorted?

The reason is simple: Eligibility for farm subsidies is determined by crop, not
by income or poverty standards. Growers of corn, wheat, cotton, soybeans and
rice receive more than 90 percent of our farm subsidies. Growers of the other
400 domestic crops grown receive nothing.

Because crop rather than need determines eligibility, billionaires such as Ted
Turner and corporate behemoths such as Georgia Pacific and Cargill are
subsidized. The struggling little guy, as often as not, receives nothing.

The U.S. cotton industry is a stark example of this distortion. Growers in the
Mississippi Delta are among the highest-cost cotton producers worldwide.
According to a recent report by the international aid agency Oxfam, the United
States spends nearly $4 billion yearly on subsidies for cotton producers, making
us the world's largest cotton subsidizer. Reflecting the farm industry overall,
the largest 10 percent of cotton farms receives 79 percent of all payments, and
the top 1 percent receives 25 percent. The average payment to cotton growers was
$331,000 in 2002; 25 growers received more than $1 million each.

FARM SUBSIDIES are a barrier to trade, putting the United States at a
disadvantage in negotiations for increased market access in other countries.
Countries are less than eager to remove trade barriers when the United States
won't remove its own.

Subsidies also undermine U.S. efforts to help developing economies. On the one
hand, the United States annually provides billions of dollars in foreign aid to
developing countries. At the same time, U.S. farm subsidies prevent farmers in
those countries from effectively competing in, or with, the U.S. market.

U.S. farmers claim that since their European counterparts receive subsidies,
they need them to compete. Yet New Zealand's prosperous agricultural sector -
which at one time was also addicted to subsidies - shows this is untrue. New
Zealand farm subsidies today are the lowest in the world. Meanwhile, the
country's agricultural sector is growing at a faster pace than the overall
economy.

In 1984, the New Zealand government did away with most farm subsidies. Without
subsidies, New Zealand's farmers don't make decisions based on government
handouts. They regrouped and reorganized. They cut spending. They found ways to
increase the market value of their crops or switched crops altogether.

Expectations to the contrary, New Zealand lost less than 1 percent of its
farming businesses. Family farming, not corporate farming, expanded. New Zealand
agriculture was not destroyed. Rather, it changed to meet the demands of the
market and thrived.

WHAT HAPPENED in New Zealand could be duplicated in the United States. In fact,
the United States has less at stake than New Zealand did. Agriculture in New
Zealand accounts for more than 13 percent of its gross domestic product. Here,
agriculture accounts for around 2 percent of GDP.

Simply put, there are too many reasons not to eliminate farm subsidies. Such a
reform - which the farm lobby would fight tooth and nail - would force U.S.
agriculture to make decisions based on market conditions, rather than the
availability of government subsidies. New Zealand has proved it's possible; it
is time for the United States to prove it again.

(Editor's note: The writer is a visiting fellow at the American Institute for
Economic Research.)

Knight Ridder/Tribune Information Services

LOAD-DATE: December 7, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

on a lawn outside the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Dairy Store in Lincoln,
Neb., June 1. President Bush on Thursday chose Johanns to be the new secretary
of agriculture. If he takes office, he might want to look at farm-subsidy
reform.

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                            January 25, 2009 Sunday
                                   L2 Edition

Buying food locally in crisis saves lives, USDA says

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 285 words


Buying food near famine-stricken areas overseas may be more efficient and save
more lives during crises than shipping U.S. products over long distances,
according to a Department of Agriculture report.

"Food that is procured locally and regionally" is likely to reach those in need
"more quickly than in-kind food aid" that is bought and shipped from the U.S. or
other developed countries, the report said. Still, U.S.-produced aid is
sometimes needed because there often isn't enough food available near where a
disaster occurs, according to the study.

The report, which is being circulated among congressional committees, was
required under last year's $289 billion farm bill to help set up a four-year
local-purchase pilot program involving no more than $25 million annually. The
U.S. accounts for almost half of the world's total food-aid spending, at about
$2.5 billion a year.

The speed and efficiency of the country's food-assistance programs, which
require most aid to be purchased from U.S. farmers and delivered by U.S. ships,
has been criticized by humanitarian groups including Oxfam International and
CARE. About 47 percent of government spending on commodities for aid went to
Cargill Inc., Archer Daniels Midland Co. and Bunge Ltd., according to the USDA.

A U.S. move toward buying food near areas experiencing famine would be a step in
the right direction, said Laura Rusu, a spokeswoman in Washington for Oxfam
America, the Boston-based affiliate of the international aid group.

"By shifting some food-aid resources into cash for local purchase, the new
administration would not only help make food aid more efficient and flexible,
but would also invest in developing-country agriculture," Rusu said.

LOAD-DATE: January 25, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    The Floyd County Times, Prestonburg, Ky.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 11, 2011 Friday

New truck aids God's Pantry in food delivery

BYLINE: Sheldon Compton, The Floyd County Times, Prestonburg, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 269 words


Feb. 11--PRESTONSBURG --God's Pantry Food Bank has for years provided food
donations, totaling some 21 million pounds last year alone to more than 200,000
Kentucky residents, but has done so with the use of smaller trucks.

Tuesday and Wednesday, the use of several trucks and also the occasional hiring
of other trucking companies ended, as the organization put to use its first
18-wheeler semi-truck to drop off food donations at the Prestonsburg
distribution center.

The food dropped at the center will be given out to the county's food pantries
over the next several weeks, organizers said, and totaled at about 30,000 pounds
for the single load.

The purchase of the 18-wheeler was made possible through a grant of $250,000
from the United States Department of Agriculture Food and Nutrition Service,
money which also helped fund a portion of driver's salary.

The food bank changed its ordering procedures in late 2009. Before, agencies
served by the Prestonsburg facility had access to a limited amount of the full
inventory of the food bank. The change allowed the nonprofits access to all the
available inventory by having their order pulled in Lexington and brought to the
county to be picked up.

The new truck has a total capacity of 45,000 pounds.

http://www.floydcountytimes.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, The Floyd County Times,
Prestonburg, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                            December 12, 2008 Friday
                                  City Edition

State farmers get disaster relief for summer losses

SECTION: News; pg. 3

LENGTH: 133 words


Massachusetts farmers in a dozen counties will be able to apply for federal
disaster loans to recover from severe summer weather.

The state announced Wednesday that the U.S. Department of Agriculture approved
the aid for counties that had damage to crops, livestock and farm buildings.

Gov. Deval Patrick had asked for the federal aid for farmers who had reduced
crop production of more than 30 percent. Heat, heavy rain, hail and high winds
hurt crops including alfalfa, pumpkins and apples last summer. Lightning from
thunderstorms injured livestock and damaged buildings.

Farmers have eight months from Nov. 20 to apply for low-interest federal loans.

Eligible counties include Barnstable, Berkshire, Bristol, Essex, Franklin,
Hampden, Hampshire, Middlesex, Norfolk, Plymouth, Suffolk and Worcester.

Almond Growers to Get Aid

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 55, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 90 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29


Twenty-five percent of this year's record California almond crop will be set
aside in hopes of relieving depressed prices for growers, Secretary of
Agriculture John R. Block said this week. The almonds in the pool, which was
requested by producers, are to be sold gradually into ''noncompetitive outlets
at salvage prices,'' he said. Noncompetitive outlets could include nuts sold to
make almond oil, for export to new foreign markets or for livestock feed.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            September 4, 1989 Monday

Willie Nelson plans Farm Aid IV

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 196 words

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.


Reuter
  KANSAS CITY, Mo.

Country singer Willie Nelson said Saturday night that his organization,
Farm Aid , will present a concert next year and will exist until U.S.
farmers are guaranteed specific protection.

'I'm in for the duration,' said Nelson, flanked by representatives of  Missouri
and Kansas farmers groups.

The fourth Farm Aid fundraising concert will be in the spring, he said,
'early enough to get the money out before spring planting.'
   Another concert will be held in Washington in March, about two weeks
before Farm Aid IV, Nelson said, 'to invite our political friends,' he
said.

Nelson and the farmers with him said they want the 1990 Farm Bill to
provide farmers with more money and more flexibility in deciding what
crops to plant.

Besides seeking changes in farm policy, Nelson said the United States
should change its stance in international agricultural trade talks under
the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

The GATT negotiations, intended to liberalize farm trade and eliminate
subsidies, 'is the worst thing that can happen to the family farmer,'
Nelson said, because the effect would be to shift decision-making on farm
policy outside the United States.

                              481 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                                December 4, 2009

Final crop loss estimate awaited in Mississippi

BYLINE: Wally Northway

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 656  words


Today, Dr. John Michael Riley, an agriculture economist at Mississippi State
University, was pulling together figures for a final update on the crop losses
suffered in the state from flooding fall rains. Riley had been waiting for
farmers to get out of the fields to determine if the nearly $485-million,
30.3-percent crop loss estimate released in November would be too low or too
high.

If that number holds or grows, it would be the worst year for the state's
agriculture community since the 1950s. To gauge the widespread destruction
caused by torrential rains in September and October, the U.S. Department of
Agriculture declared 79 of Mississippi's 82 counties a disaster area in
November.

Lawmakers in Washington are working to get legislation passed that would offer
relief to the state's farmers, and time is an issue. The Farm Bill provides
disaster assistance to producers, but does not pay off until the end of the crop
marketing year, which is Oct. 2010. State and national leaders say that would be
too late for farmers. They must have immediate relief or many producers will be
forced to park their tractors for good.

On Dec. 2, H.R.4177, co-sponsored by Rep. Travis Childers (D-Miss.), was
introduced, which aims to provide timely disaster assistance to producers. It
would also offer aid to livestock producers.

"In North Mississippi, both farmers and local economies have suffered from this
season's unprecedented rainfall," said Childers. "Significant assistance
currently available through the USDA is still not enough to make up for the
incredible crop losses local producers have experienced. While we await the full
implementation of Farm Bill assistance provisions, this important legislation
will help local economies stay afloat by providing farmers with the resources
they need to get back on their feet. "

The House bill is the second piece of disaster relief legislation introduced in
Congress by Mississippi lawmakers. On Nov. 20, Sen. Thad Cochran (R-Miss.) and
Roger Wicker (R-Miss.) introduced S.2810, a bill similar to the House's proposed
legislation.

"Sweet potatoes, grain sorghum, soybeans and cotton harvests have been
compromised to an extent that the financial survival of many producers is
uncertain," said Cochran, a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee.
"Existing Department of Agriculture disaster aid programs cannot provide the
near-term help needed by growers. The Direct Payment mechanism, which has been
used to provide assistance numerous times, is the only way for the Department of
Agriculture to provide timely assistance. "

Both H.R.4177 and S.2810 include $650 million to assist specialty crop
producers, $150 million in assistance for livestock producers and $42 million to
aid first handlers of cottonseed. This aid would be in addition to the
aforementioned direct payments provided by the Farm Bill's Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Program (SURE).

Mississippi Agriculture told the Mississippi Business Journal that the disaster
was the worst he had seen. "Staggering losses," he said, "If something isn't
done, I'm afraid the state stands to lose some mighty good farmers. "

David Cochran is one of those at risk. An Avon cotton producer, he said the
30-plus inches of rain he received in September and October "cost us anywhere
from 50-60 percent of our anticipated yield. We felt like we had one of the
better cotton crops than we've had in recent years, but a lot of the cotton
either hardlocked and fell out or just rotted. "

He said this year has been unusually devastating, and that immediate disaster
assistance such as introduced in the Senate and House would help him meet his
financial obligations.

Cochran said his ginning operation also was hurt because of the lost seed. "We
gin for the seed, and where we normally get 700-800 pounds of seed per bale,
we're only seeing 550-600 pounds. "

Riley said he should have the final crop loss figures available for release
Monday.

LOAD-DATE: April 14, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2009 Dolan Media Newswires
                              All Rights Reserved

                              482 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           September 15, 1989, Friday

LEAHY PROPOSES $ 2.25 BILLION POLAND PACKAGE

BYLINE: KEITH M. ROCKWELL; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 682 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., turned up the heat
on President Bush Thursday by proposing a $ 2.25 billion food-aid package for
Poland that would boost commodity exports.

The six-point Leahy plan far exceeds the $ 125 million in aid promised by the
president, although it contains little in the way of new money for the new
overnment in Warsaw.

"Everybody realizes that (the $ 125 million) was a nice airport gesture, but I'm
challenging the president now to do something substantial, to do something that
would make a difference," the senator told reporters.

In Chicago, pork belly futures rose sharply on the news of the Leahy proposal,
which includes 20 million to 30 million pounds of bellies. Following the
president's trip to Poland in early July - he made his aid offer at the airport
- solidarity leader Lech Walesa and other Polish officials characterized the $
125 million as insufficient.

The Leahy proposal includes:

* $ 2 billion in agricultural debt forgiveness.

* A donation of $ 150 million in corn, grain sorghum, wheat, butter and pork
products.

* $ 100 million in aid through special foreign assistance.

* Granting Poland special trade status under the generalized system of
preferences.

* Technical assistance from U.S. Department of Agriculture

* $ 10 million in donations from the private sector.

Administration officials say that budgetary pressures make additional lending
difficult. The administration has urged surplus nations to contribute additional
aid and West Germany and Japan have responded with proposals of their own.

The European Community Commission has been charged with coordinating relief
efforts.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has warned in the past that sending
huge shipments of food to Poland would be a major disincentive to Polish farmers
and may exacerbate the food shortages there.

There was no immediate comment from the Bush administration or the Agriculture
Department on the Leahy proposal.

But the Vermont Democrat rejected these arguments.

"That's a nice free market idea that very well might work in a country that
already had a booming agriculture market with a solid infrastructure. That's not
the case with Poland," he told reporters.

Sen. Leahy said the plan would have no impact on the already staggering U.S.
federal budget deficit since the food stocks are already in hand and because
there is no realistic chance of being reimbursed for the $ 2 billion in farm
loans and credits extended to Poland.

Moreover, he said the plan requires no legislation and can be implemented
immediately. Lengthy delays in disbursing aid to Poland could undermine the new
Solidarity government, he said.

"We want to take the pressure off that government. Give them a chance to
implement the reforms that are necessary. We want to show the people of Poland
that they are better off than under the communists and one of the ways we can do
that . . . is to put food in the homes of Poles," he said.

The senator said that failure to shore up the new government in Warsaw would
send a negative signal to other communist countries considering democratic
reforms.

"We are not going to be able to use Poland as an example to other countries
seeking democracy if when (Poland) sought democracy we only gave them $ 125
million in aid," he said. According to Knight-Ridder Financial News, the Leahy
plan's forgiveness of $ 2 billion in agriculture-relate d debts would likely
revive Poland's eligibility to participate in certain credit programs run by the
U.S. Agriculture Department.

Though Sen. Leahy's plan calls for shipping pork products, a Senate Agriculture
Committee aide indicated that most of the pork sent would be in pork bellies. As
of Aug. 23, there were 96.42 million pounds of bellies in cold storage,
according to the USDA.

Lech Dzikiewicz, economic attache at the Polish embassy, said that the food aid
package will be discussed in Poland with high-level officials when U.S. Commerce
Secretary Robert Mosbacher visits Warsaw on Sept. 19-21.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                    October 13, 1996, Sunday, Final Edition

Snow Drought Is Disaster for Alaska; Agriculture Secretary Certifies Areas for
Federal Relief

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A09

LENGTH: 229 words

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE


Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has declared regions of Alaska disaster areas
because of an extended drought, state officials said.

In a letter sent to Gov. Tony Knowles (D) last week, Glickman named the
Fairbanks-North Star Borough, southeast Fairbanks-Delta area, Matanuska-Susitna
Borough and Kenai Peninsula as areas where farmers will be eligible to recover
disaster aid.

"I requested the disaster designation in July and instructed my administration
to work closely with federal officials to ensure a disaster declaration for the
farmers in Alaska," Knowles said Friday.

The areas were affected by a snow drought last year that was compounded with
especially cold temperatures. Without an insulating layer of snow, the ground
froze to deep levels and subsequently dried out, officials said.

Only a few farm operations will be eligible for the aid, said Alaska Division of
Agriculture Director Jay Kerttula. They must have both livestock and produce,
and must have sustained a production loss of 30 percent or more during the past
year, Kerttula said.

Alaska farmers with irrigation systems fared well despite the drought, and were
able to produce bumper crops, he said.

Dry conditions in the Matanuska-Susitna Borough were blamed for the spread of a
devastating June wildfire that destroyed more property than any wildfire in
Alaska history.

                               The New York Times

                               May 3, 2013 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

Proposal for Changes in Food Aid Sets Off Infighting in Congress

BYLINE: By RON NIXON

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; National Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 890 words


WASHINGTON -- A proposal by the Obama administration to overhaul the
international food aid program has set off a jurisdictional fight among members
of several House and Senate committees, threatening to derail the most
significant change to the program since it was created nearly 60 years ago.

The $1.4 billion annual program provides emergency food supplies to
disaster-stricken regions across the globe. The United States provides over half
of the world's food aid.

The food aid money is currently part of the Agriculture Department's budget, but
President Obama's proposal would transfer it to the foreign affairs budget,
where it would be overseen by the Agency for International Development. The
reorganization would also mean that Congressional oversight of the program would
shift from the House and Senate appropriations subcommittees on agriculture to
the appropriations subcommittees on foreign operations.

Administration officials say the current program is costly and inefficient, and
does not get food quickly enough to the people who need it. By law, the food
must be bought from American farmers and shipped on vessels flying American
flags, which can sometimes take weeks, with food arriving after a crisis is
over, administration officials and development experts say.

Also, because of rising shipping costs, the amount of food the United States
sends abroad has fallen, to 1.8 million cubic tons annually from 5 million cubic
tons, according to figures from the development agency.

Under the new proposal the agency, or charities working in partnership with it,
would use money to buy some food locally, closer to the disaster areas.
Fifty-five percent of the food would still be purchased from American farmers.

''This new reform would give us the flexible tools we need to get food to people
who need it now, not weeks later,'' said Rajiv Shah, the agency's administrator.
''We would still buy from U.S. farmers.''

He added, ''But this way we can help feed two to four million more people
without additional costs.''

But members of the House and Senate agriculture subcommittees are skeptical.

During hearings last week, Representative Robert B. Aderholt, Republican of
Alabama, the chairman of the House agriculture subcommittee, said he was
concerned that removing food aid from the agriculture budget would hurt American
farmers.

Representative Sam Farr of California, the committee's ranking Democrat, also
questioned the transfer, raising concerns about the subcommittee losing
oversight of the program.

''I'm not endorsing the transfer -- the realignment -- until there are
assurances that the program will remain intact and not be raided by other
foreign ops interest,'' Mr. Farr said at the hearing.

Mr. Farr expressed doubts about the proposal's chances of success. ''I don't
think it will happen this year,'' he said. ''That's the politics.''

There has been a similar response from members of the Senate agriculture
subcommittee. Senator Mark Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, the chairman of the
subcommittee, along with Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri, the ranking Republican,
both said that they were opposed to transferring food aid dollars out of the
agriculture budget.

In February, they joined 19 other senators in sending a letter to the president
opposing the measure.

Representative Kay Granger, Republican of Texas, the chairwoman of the House
foreign operations subcommittee, which oversees the foreign aid budget, has not
said if she will support the Obama administration's proposal.

But Nita M. Lowey of New York, the subcommittee's ranking Democrat, has endorsed
the plan to move food aid, as have members of the House and Senate Foreign
Affairs Committees.

Representative Ed Royce, Republican of California, the chairman of the House
Foreign Affairs Committee, has criticized the administration's overall budget
proposal, but he supports the food aid change.

''The president's budget proposal to reform the international food program --
helping more at less cost -- is a bright spot in the budget request,'' Mr. Royce
said.

Budget experts say Mr. Obama's proposal will be a tough sell in Congress, where
committee members can be parochial and rarely want to give up control of
programs.

While it is common for committees to allow agencies to move money from one
account to another, experts said it was rare for Congressional appropriators to
move money and oversight of a program from one agency to another.

''This is a classic jurisdictional battle among committees,'' said Edward A.
Brigham, a consultant and former staff member at the White House Office of
Management and Budget and at the House Budget Committee. ''No one wants to give
up their area of control.''

Mr. Brigham said lawmakers could vote to move the money through the
appropriations process or just to authorize the change in the next farm bill,
which falls under the jurisdiction of the House and Senate Agriculture
Committees. Members of those committees have already voiced their opposition to
the proposal.

''Food aid is in need of reform for all the hungry people in the world who
depend on it,'' said David Beckmann, president of Bread for the World, a
Christian antihunger group that supports the Obama administration's proposal.
''But it's going to be difficult to get anything through Congress, particularly
because of the jurisdictional issues.''

URL: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/03/us/food-aid
-proposal-sets-off-infighting-in-congress.html

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 18, 2009 Monday

State loans will aid area farmers

BYLINE: Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 339 words


May 18--HARRISBURG -- Despite the national recession, Gov. Ed Rendell stressed
the importance of investing in key industries Friday as he announced nearly $5
million in loans and guarantees for 17 agriculture and tourism projects in 13
counties.

Rendell said investing in these two industries, which support about 1.4 million
jobs in the state, is essential to better position each sector. The budget
Rendell proposed in February institutes cuts, but still provides crucial
investments that will help each industry to expand.

The following projects were among those approved:

--$1.3 million machinery and equipment loan to Penn England LLC for the $2.8
million purchase of dairy cows and farm equipment in Williamsburg, Blair County.

--$35,000 agriculture loan to Kelly Hite and Gena Hite toward the $70,000
purchase of a Massey Ferguson Sunflower No-Till Grain Drill in Ebensburg.

--$307,040 machinery and equipment loan to Fabin Brothers Farms toward the
$615,040 purchase of machinery and equipment for the farm's new soybean
processing plant in Indiana.

"We must continue to invest in these industries in a prudent manner so that when
the economy turns around, we're in a position where we can emerge stronger than
ever,'' the governor said.

"This $4.9 million investment, which will leverage an additional $14.7 million
in private funding, does that. Investing in these projects will help to
encourage job growth and expansion in Pennsylvania's rural communities."

For more information on programs available through the Department of Community
and Economic Development, call (866) 466-3972 or visit newpa.com.

To see more of The Tribune-Democrat or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribune-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Tribune-Democrat,
Johnstown, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                       May 25, 2004 Tuesday Home Edition

Q & A

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Metro News; Pg. 2B

LENGTH: 539 words


Q: An article said billions of "Brood X" cicadas are emerging from New York to
Illinois to Georgia, and in Georgia will be confined mostly to the northernmost
counties. Has the Georgia Department of Agriculture released a specific "cicada
line," comparable to the "gnat line" in South Georgia?

--- John Deeds, Flowery Branch

A: No. There's no specific line, or even a generalized one.

The best information available so far, according to the Georgia Department of
Agriculture, is a series of distribution maps developed by the University of
Michigan.

The maps depict the expected sites of the different broods of the 17-year and
13-year cicadas, said Tommy Irvin, Georgia commissioner of agriculture.

The maps are on a Web site:
www.ummz.lsa.umich.edu/magicicada/Periodical/Index.html.

Data are insufficient for many areas, so the maps are likely to be updated as
more information becomes available, Irvin said.

It might be difficult to draw any conclusions from the maps, because they're
vaguely defined. Also, some stragglers in each brood don't emerge on schedule,
and annual cicadas are present each summer throughout Georgia, Irvin said.

Q: Is there a telephone number to report people who have children riding in cars
without being restrained, either by a seat belt or in a car seat?

--- Ann Saad, Lawrenceville

A: You can call star (*) GSP or 911 on a cellphone, said Gordy Wright of the
Georgia Department of Public Safety.

Q: Q&A recently listed the drinks associated with the Triple Crown horse races.
The White Carnation was shown as an early drink for the Belmont Stakes. Can you
give us the recipe?

--- Bonnie Jackson, Buford

A: Ingredients: 2 ounces vodka; 1/2 ounce peach schnapps; 2 ounces orange juice;
soda water; 1 splash cream; crushed ice.

Stir liquors, juice and soda together and pour over ice in a highball glass.
Garnish with an orange slice.

Q: A recent item in Nation in Brief said Vermont will become the ninth state to
let very sick patients use marijuana to alleviate pain, nausea and other
symptoms without fear of state prosecution. What are the other eight states?

--- Mike Gardner, Powder Springs

A: As reported by The Associated Press, Alaska, California, Colorado, Hawaii,
Maine, Nevada, Oregon and Washington state already have laws allowing marijuana
for medical needs.

Arizona passed an initiative to allow marijuana by prescription, a largely
symbolic law because federal law prohibits doctors from writing such
prescriptions.

Vermont Gov. James Douglas said last week that he would let a bill become law
without his signature. He said the bill covers "symptom relief for a small
percentage of individuals with only the most debilitating conditions," such as
cancer and AIDS.

Vermont patients may keep up to three marijuana plants in a locked room
accessible only by the sick person and caregiver, both of whom must register
with state police.

Douglas, a first-term Republican, said he hoped advocates for legalization of
marijuana for recreational use would not take cheer from the new Vermont law.
"To ease suffering is commendable, but to crusade for legalization of an
addictive, destructive and dangerous drug is contemptible," he said.

LOAD-DATE: May 25, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                             July 12, 2008 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

ACROSS THE NATION

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A10

LENGTH: 515 words


Senate votes to expand Bush's global AIDS plan

WASHINGTON - The Senate voted Friday with a strong show of bipartisanship to
take up a stalled global AIDS bill that would vastly expand a President
Bush-backed program that has had marked success in combating AIDS in Africa and
other affected areas of the world.

The vote was 65-3 to begin debate next week on the legislation approving $50
billion over the next five years to prevent and treat AIDS, malaria and
tuberculosis. Sixty votes were needed to advance the bill.

The current five-year bill, which expires at the end of September, approved $15
billion. It has been widely lauded for supporting anti-retroviral treatment for
nearly 2 million people suffering from HIV/AIDS and putting the United States at
the forefront of world efforts to fight the pandemic.

Consumers to be told where bad meat is sold

WASHINGTON - Consumers may be told if their local grocery store got tainted meat
during a recall under a new policy announced Friday by the Agriculture
Department.

The planned rule change comes in the wake of the nation's biggest-ever beef
recall - 143 million pounds from a slaughterhouse in Southern California.

Under the new rule, which is expected to be published next week and take effect
30 days later, retailers' names will be posted on the Agriculture Department Web
site during so-called "Class I" meat and poultry recalls - those deemed to pose
a definite public health risk.

Currently when there is a meat recall, the Agriculture Department makes public
the name of the establishment recalling the meat, a description of the recalled
product, and any identifying brand names or product codes. But the public is not
told where it is being sold.

FAA changes protocol after near-collisions

WASHINGTON - Two airborne planes - one landing and the other taking off - came
within a half-mile of colliding at John F. Kennedy International Airport on
Friday in the second such incident at the airport in a week, the Federal
Aviation Administration said.

The FAA moved quickly to change takeoff and landing procedures at JFK on
perpendicular runways - the kind of runways involved in both incidents.

FAA spokeswoman Laura Brown said Delta Flight 123 was arriving at the airport
Friday when the pilot decided to abort his landing and execute a "go-around" - a
routine procedure used during congestion. That caused the Delta flight to
intersect with the path of Comair Flight 1520, a regional jet that was taking
off on another runway.

The FAA ordered new procedures Friday afternoon that are designed to ensure
"that aircraft of one runway clear out of the path of the other runway before
the second flight comes down on the other runway," Ms. Brown said.

Last Saturday, a Cayman Airways flight was coming into JFK when the pilot
decided to abort the landing and fly around the airport again as a LAN Chile jet
was taking off. Their flight paths crossed, bringing the planes within about 200
feet of each other vertically and a half mile horizontally. The National
Transportation Safety Board is investigating that incident.

- Edited from wire reports

                          Australian Financial Review

                           September 23, 1991 Monday
                                  Late Edition

TOP-LEVEL TALKS INDICATE SOFTER US APPROACH TO SOVIET AID REQUESTS

BYLINE: From JOHN HELMER in Moscow

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 712 words


Soviet officials who held meetings last week with the US Secretary of the
Treasury, Mr Nicholas Brady, say that US-Soviet financial talks are progressing
with "a softer appearance", suggesting greater sympathy for Soviet needs.

"But these are still words, not deeds," the officials add.

Mr Brady, together with the chairman of the US Federal Reserve Board, Dr Alan
Greenspan, met the Soviet President, Mr Gorbachev, the Russian President, Mr
Boris Yeltsin, and senior figures in the new union economic policy body, the
Inter-Republican Economic Committee.

Mr Brady's visit followed that of the US Secretary of State, Mr James Baker, and
an agricultural policy mission led by officials from the US Department of
Agriculture. The US Secretary of Agriculture, Mr Edward Madigan, is expected in
Moscow in a few days.

Mr Madigan's department summed up current satellite picture and site visits in
the Soviet Union with the prediction this month that this year's Soviet grain
harvest would be between 20 per cent and 30 per cent below last year's total.

The US figure was adopted last Thursday by Mr Yuriy Luzhkov, a senior member of
the Union government, who told the European Commission in Brussels that Moscow
was doubling its emergency food aid request from about $US7 billion to more than
$US14 billion.

Mr Brady's delegation disputed the need for this level of food supply.

Soviet officials have responded to what they view as a sluggish response on the
food aid issue by the EC and the US, with the suggestion that the West should
consider establishing commodity stocks, including food and feedgrains, that
would be stored on Soviet territory and used, in conjunction with domestic
production, to ease food price inflation and relieve regional distribution
problems.

Most Western and Soviet experts regard these factors, and hoarding by food
producers in the Soviet Union, as the main reasons for the expected winter
shortages.

Creation of a "commodity stabilisation fund" is being considered by Soviet
government experts, instead of the annual autumn requests for once-off emergency
food shipments to prevent winter-time starvation.

Mr Brady and Dr Greenspan were in Moscow to follow up commitments they gave at
the Group of Seven summit meeting in London in June. The US policymakers are
preparing for next month's meeting in Bangkok of all G-7 finance ministers to
finalise a decision on both Soviet credit and food aid requests.

Soviet representatives are likely to attend the Bangkok meeting and to include
the Deputy Foreign Minister for International Economic Relations, Mr Ernest
Obminsky.

Mr Obminsky has retained his post at the Soviet Foreign Ministry through the
upheavals of recent weeks, and is one of the most widely respected and
influential economic policy advisers in Moscow.

Soviet officials appreciate the public tone of optimism and support for
financial assistance which Mr Brady, and Mr Baker before him, have expressed to
the media.

They observe, however, that President Bush remained as cautious and
non-committal as ever in remarks last week after meeting with the German
Chancellor, Dr Kohl, in Washington.

Soviet officials say that Mr Bush's decision to grant Most Favoured Nation
status to the Soviet Union as a whole, including the Baltic republics, has been
welcomed as the strongest American signal to date that US policy favours
preservation of the

union.

But the view in Moscow is also that there is much Mr Bush could do to create "a
smooth path" for future Soviet-American economic relations that he has so far
delayed.

The major form of assistance would be US support in the Soviet quest to gain
membership of world financial institutions.

The Soviets want accelerated negotiations on their application to become full
members of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

They also want to raise the loan limits for lending by the European Bank for
Reconstruction and Development to the Soviet Union.

Despite the creation of funds for technical assistance from the World Bank and
an "emergency" loan programme of the EBRD, Soviet officials believe the US is
continuing to block large-scale lending and veto membership of the IMF, as well
as any increase in EBRD loans beyond 36 million Ecu, the value of the Soviet
Union's paid-in capital to date.

LOAD-DATE: March 15, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
