                              492 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 28, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

JUDGE CRITICIZES ADMINISTRATION ON FOOD FOR POOR

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 958 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27


A Federal judge ordered the Reagan Administration today to take immediate steps
to distribute food aid to 47,000 poor women and children in New York and
Georgia.

Before issuing the order in response to a lawsuit that was filed on Tuesday,
Judge Charles R. Richey of the United States District Court here severely
criticized Agriculture Secretary John R. Block for ''inaction.''

The lawsuit was filed by two nonprofit organizations, the Food Research and
Action Center of Washington and the Georgia Legal Services Program, on behalf of
six indigent women from New York and five from Georgia. The New York State
Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, and three Democratic Congressmen joined
the suit as plaintiffs. They were Representatives Theodore Weiss of Manhattan,
Matthew F. McHugh of Ithaca, N.Y., and Wyche Fowler Jr. of Atlanta.

$7 Million Believed Available

The suit said that needy families in New York and Georgia had been denied
benefits because Mr. Block refused to reallocate the money unspent by other
states. After checking with the states, a Justice Department lawyer, Alphonse M.
Alfano, said the Agriculture Department had estimated that $7 million was
unspent and available for redistribution to 23 states that needed additional
money.

Judge Richey ordered Mr. Block to ''reallocate such funds immediately.'' Mr.
Alfano told the judge that the Federal Government would be willing to start
distributing the unspent money after the current fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.
But Judge Richey said that by that time some of the children might be dead or
retarded.

''Meanwhile,'' he asked, ''what's going to happen to these poor infants who are
the beneficiaries of this program? What's going to happen to these poor innocent
children - women, infants and children?''

Mr. Alfano said that no harm would be done by waiting for five or six weeks.
But the judge interrupted him to say: ''I don't think a Secretary of Agriculture
ought to have any excuse. Let him wash the blood off his own hands and get it
done. This is a very heart-rending allegation here.''

The money in question comes from a special supplemental food program for women
and children up to the age of 5. Nationwide, the program serves 2.2 million
women and youngsters at a total cost of $960 million this year. State health
agencies use the money to provide packages of high-protein, high-vitamin foods
such as milk, infant formula, cereal, eggs and orange juice.

Federal law says that the Secretary of Agriculture must ''reallocate funds
periodically'' if he finds that a state agency cannot spend all the money it
receives.

Nancy Amidei, director of the Food Research and Action Center, said that the
judge's ruling was ''a victory for mothers and children.'' She added, ''The only
tragedy is that this should not have happened in the first place.''

Daniel D. Kaplan, an assistant attorney general of New York State, said the
ruling was ''obviously very positive'' for the state.  ''It may mean that New
York will be able to recover a great part of the money needed to maintain the
present caseload,'' he said.

Called 'Unconscionable'

When Congress approved money for the program in October 1981, Senator Thomas F.
Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, said that ''removing women, infants and children
from the program and allowing funds to remain unspent is unconscionable.'' Judge
Richey said he fully endorsed that sentiment.

Mr. Alfano said that if money were reallocated to New York and Georgia now,
funds might be unavailable for other states at the start of the next fiscal
year, beginning Oct. 1.

Judge Richey said he considered that a ''threat,'' and he told the lawyer, ''You
are not going to get away with it.'' John W. Bode, a deputy assistant secretary
of agriculture, said this evening that the department was taking steps necessary
to comply with the judge's order.

Mr. Bode said there would be no immediate response to the criticism of Mr. Block
because department officials had not had an opportunity to review a transcript
of Judge Richey's remarks.

Judge Richey said in court: ''I don't understand why the Secretary of
Agriculture can't pick up the ball and get this unspent money distributed to the
states right now, without a long delay. When somebody is hungry and needs food,
it becomes quite a different matter from what we are talking about when you
build a highway. These are little human beings who have no constituency but
their parents.  They live in impoverished, disadvantaged neighborhoods.''

In their complaint, the indigent women and their lawyers said that Mr. Block had
ignored clear requirements of the law in the fiscal year 1981 by having failed
to redistribute unspent money. As a result, they said, the ''caseload declined
by 200,000 persons during the last half of the year, despite the existence of
ample funding.'' In fact, they said, more than $51 million went unspent last
year.

The judge referred caustically to projections by the Agriculture Department that
$11 million might be unspent at the end of the current fiscal year.

The budgetary arithmetic to support the lawsuit was done by Robert Greenstein of
the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a nonprofit research group. Mr.
Greenstein served as head of the Federal Food and Nutrition Service in the last
two years of the Carter Administration.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: photo of Judge Charles R. Richey

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company

                              493 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                    July 9, 1993, FRIDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

CLINTON VOWS SWIFTNESS ON FLOOD-AID PACKAGE; GEPHARDT SAYS HE WILL LEAD EFFORT
IN CONGRESS

BYLINE: Charlotte Grimes and Jo Mannies Of the Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 962 words


President Bill Clinton promised on Thursday a coordinated relief effort "without
delay" for the flood-stricken Midwest, and House Majority Leader Richard A.
Gephardt said he would use his political muscle to bring aid to Missouri.
Clinton, at the economic summit in Tokyo, said in a radio address that his
administration would forward a flood-assistance package to Congress by next
week. Gephardt, slushing through mud at flood sites in his district, promised to
lead the effort to get the aid approved.  Vice President Al Gore is scheduled to
speak today via conference call with governors in eight flood-stricken
Midwestern states, including Missouri and Illinois.  Gore is scheduled to fly to
the Midwest on Monday to view the flood damage.  Gephardt said he was lobbying
to have Gore come to Missouri.  "Up and down the Mississippi River, it's the
same story - Americans and Missourians fighting to save their property," said
Gephardt, after viewing flood-fighting crews in Lemay, Festus-Crystal City, and
Ste. Genevieve.  In each town, local officials and flood victims met Gephardt,
D-St. Louis County. They hope that Gephardt can use his clout to help them.
Gephardt and the officials were encouraged by Clinton's radio message.  The
president said: "Let me ask each of you to take heart and have faith.  As hard
as these times are, you know that the waters will soon recede and the work of
recovery will begin." Gephardt faxed a letter Thursday to the White House,
asking Clinton to declare Missouri a federal disaster area. Such a declaration
would make Missouri flood victims eligible for federal loan and grant programs.
Gov. Mel Carnahan must formally ask for the federal declaration; state officials
said he would do so today.  Gephardt said a federal declaration could take
several weeks after Carnahan's request. But Gephardt is hoping for swifter
action.  As soon as Carnahan files Missouri's request, the Federal Emergency
Management Agency will be working "on a 24-hour basis" to get its paperwork to
the White House and clear the way for federal aid, said Richard Krimm, deputy
associate director of the agency.  Krimm's agency coordinates relief efforts of
federal agencies. Under relief programs, flood victims could get money to rent
temporary housing and repair their homes. Flood victims who don't qualify for
loans from the Small Business Administration or the Agriculture Department for
help with their businesses or farms could get grants of up to $11,900 for
emergency needs, Krimm said.  Gephardt also cautioned that flood victims may
have to settle for less help than they would like. The budget deficit may
restrict the amount of flood help the federal government can offer, he said.
Agriculture Secretary Michael Espy already has said he will need $850 million to
help Midwestern farmers survive crop losses and other flood damage, Gephardt
said. That is in addition to $100 million for farm aid released by Clinton last
week, Gephardt said.  About $100 million is available to help stricken
businesses and homeowners - an amount Gephardt called inadequate. He declined to
speculate on how much money Congress would approve to help flood victims.  While
warning of budget restraints on flood aid, Gephardt called for more money for
flood control. He said that would be money well spent because it would prevent
future damage.  In particular, he is lobbying for more federal help to build a
higher levee for the historic community of Ste. Genevieve, in Gephardt's
district.  Much of Gephardt's letter to Clinton focused on Ste. Genevieve.
Gephardt wrote that the town "contains one-fourth of all original colonial
French homes in North America." Federal law requires communities to pay 25
percent of the cost to construct levees. Gephardt is trying to get that local
tab down to 5 percent for Ste.  Genevieve and other historic towns.  The cost of
a new levee for Ste. Genevieve is estimated at $40 million.  City officials say
they can't afford $10 million.  In his radio address, Clinton said Gore will
oversee the coordination among the federal agencies that will provide relief.
Budget director Leon Panetta will put together the emergency aid bill to be sent
to Congress.  "We'll be working with Congress early next week to get this
process under way," Clinton said. "We'll ask for federal funds on an emergency
basis to help pay for crop losses and damage to homes, businesses and public
property.  "Just as we depend upon you for the harvest, you can depend upon us
for support at this critical moment in your lives," Clinton added.  A spokesman
for the Office of Management and Budget, Barry Toiv, said any aid would be
portioned out to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the Department of
Agriculture, the Small Business Administration, the Department of Transportation
and other agencies.  He declined to speculate on how much money the
administration would ask from Congress.  As Gephardt toured flooded areas, other
members of the bi-state congressional delegation also pledged their help. While
Sen. John C.  Danforth, R-Mo., was vacationing with his family, he was briefed
on the state's efforts to get emergency relief, spokesman Steve Hilton said.
Other members of the Missouri delegation also were briefed on the flooding.
Danforth returns to Washington this weekend. "He obviously will be very
concerned to do anything he can to help the state," Hilton said.  Illinois has
already submitted a preliminary request to have parts of the state declared a
disaster area, the first step in qualifying for federal aid.  Its two senators,
Paul Simon and Carol Moseley-Braun, both Democrats, have also written the
president asking for "expeditious" handling of the request, Simon spokesman
David Carle said.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            July 23, 2008 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

14 western Oklahoma counties eligible for federal drought aid

BYLINE: Michael McNutt, Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 174 words


Low-interest loans and other federal assistance will be available to eligible
farmers and ranchers in 14 northwest Oklahoma counties, including the three
Panhandle counties, the governor's office announced Tuesday.

The U.S. Agriculture Department has issued an agricultural disaster declaration,
which will make farm operators in those counties eligible for low-interest
loans, according to the governor's office.

The designation also will let farmers and ranchers postpone for one year paying
taxes on any grain or livestock sold early due to the drought.

Extreme heat, dry weather, high winds and lack of rain have damaged hay forages,
livestock grazing lands, alfalfa and other crops.

Farmers and ranchers in  the counties are eligible to be considered for aid.
Local Farm Service Agency offices can provide further information.

AT A GLANCE

Drought-aid eligible counties

Primary natural disaster areas:

Beaver, Cimarron, Dewey, Ellis,

Harper, Roger Mills, Texas, Woods,

Woodward

Contiguous disaster counties:

Alfalfa, Beckham, Blaine, Custer, Major

                              495 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               June 22, 1988, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

Senator Says Drought Area Tour Showed Urgent Need for Farm Aid

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 612 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21


The drought has turned the nation's major crop-producing region into ''a brown
and brittle land,'' creating an urgent need for Federal aid to farmers, the
Senate Agriculture Committee chairman said today.

''This drought comes at a time when many farmers are just climbing out of the
hole after five years of farm depression,'' said the chairman, Senator Patrick
J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. ''But now, with their crops burned and their
livestock hungry, they are once again threatened with bankruptcy.''

Mr. Leahy, who made a weekend inspection tour of Montana and the Dakotas with
six other senators, told of crop damage amounting to billions of dollars.

Study Group to Meet

''These three states, along with Minnesota, are suffering through the worst
drought this early in the season that has occurred in my lifetime,'' Mr. Leahy
said. ''Estimated crop losses in these states alone are running in excess of
$1.8 billion, and that's a conservative estimate that goes higher every day.''

He said a group of lawmakers and Reagan Administration officials that is
studying the drought are scheduled to meet Wednesday and should stay in session
until a consensus is reached on what kind of aid package to recommend.

Any hope of winning approval of drought relief depends on keeping the issue
bipartisan and avoiding friction with the Administration, Mr. Leahy said. He
praised Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng for opening conservation lands for
cutting hay and cattle-grazing.

The senator's comments came as a Government report said that crops and livestock
were continuing to suffer from drought in much of the nation, but that the
effects were varying widely.

Precipitation last week ''across the northern Great Plains did very little to
ease the drought and improve crop condition,'' the Ariculture Department report
said. ''The lack of moisture, combined with high temperatures, stressed crops
and slowed growth throughout most of the eastern half of the nation.''

'No Signs of Resurgence'

Livestock pastures ''showed no signs of resurgence'' in the eastern half of the
nation, and producers began culling herds as forage supplies declined, the
report added.

Other areas of commerce in the Middle West and the South were being affected by
the drought as the Coast Guard planned to close the Mississippi river at
Memphis, Tenn., to river traffic so a 1,000-foot section could be widened and
deepened. That section of the river had shrunk from 500 feet wide and 15 feet
deep to 170 feet wide and 9 feet deep.

Comdr. Michael Donohue of the Coast Guard said the river would stay closed
starting tonight for up to three days for the dredging, tieing up as many as
1,800 barges.

Heavy rain was reported today on part of the northern Plains, but the intense
heat gave it little chance of soaking in deeply.

Records Tumble Early

Temperatures hit record highs Monday across the central and eastern United
States, the National Weather Service said. And records for high temperatures
started toppling today, well before the sun was directly overhead. Milwaukee
tied its record for the date with a 93-degree reading at 10:34 A.M., then the
mercury continued upward until it reached 101.

Other three-digit readings included 105 in Lincoln, Neb.; 103 in Aberdeen, S.D.
and Bismarck, N.D.; 102 in Grand Island, Norfolk and North Platte, Neb.; 102 in
Waterloo, Iowa; 101 in Fort Wayne, Ind., and La Crosse, Wis., and 100 in
Rockford, Ill., and Toledo, Ohio. Twenty-three states reported at least one city
in triple-digit heat.

Agricultural experts said high temperatures worsen the drought by evaporating
what little moisture remains in the soil.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company

                              496 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    October 7, 1999, Thursday, Final Edition

WASHINGTON IN BRIEF

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A05

LENGTH: 539 words



U.S. Opposing Deportation Appeal

The Justice Department urged two federal appellate courts not to block the
deportation of a Saudi dissident suspected of involvement in the 1996 attack on
U.S. airmen in Saudi Arabia.

Hani Abdel Rahim Sayegh was scheduled to be deported to Saudi Arabia yesterday,
but his lawyer filed last-minute appeals in the federal circuit courts here and
in Atlanta to try to block the move. Sayegh had sought asylum in the United
States, saying he would be subjected to torture in Saudi Arabia.


For the Record

* Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman sought to assure lawmakers that U.S. food
aid to Russia will be used as intended, even as investigators disclosed the
first evidence that some proceeds from earlier sales may have been stolen. The
United States is giving Russia 3 million metric tons of wheat, corn, pork and
other commodities this year, worth an estimated $ 1 billion, and Russia has
asked for 5 million more tons in 2000, Glickman told the House Agriculture
Committee.


* By a narrow margin, the Senate sent the White House a $ 12.6 billion foreign
aid bill that President Clinton has threatened to veto. The legislation cuts
nearly $ 2 billion from Clinton's request. The Senate passed the bill 51 to 49
after Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) changed his no vote to yes. The House approved
the same bill on Tuesday, 214 to 211.


* The Clinton administration will ask Congress for a huge increase in U.S.
military aid to Colombia to fight drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas
financed by the cocaine trade. White House drug control policy director Barry R.
McCaffrey said Congress will soon be asked to provide between $ 1 billion and $
2 billion in military equipment--similar to a $ 1.5 billion proposal last month
by two Republican senators--and other economic assistance to Colombia over three
years. U.S. aid to Colombia jumped from $ 85.7 million in 1997 to $ 289 million
this year, making it the third-largest recipient after Israel and Egypt.


* House and Senate negotiators reached a final agreement to postpone production
of the F-22 fighter plane until 2001 as part of a $ 267 billion defense spending
bill. House Republicans led by Rep. Jerry Lewis (Calif.) prevailed in their
efforts to block production until the Air Force completed more extensive tests
of the jet fighter to determine if it meets performance expectations and is
affordable, but Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Ted Stevens (R-Alaska)
won funding concessions that would allow for substantial production the
following year, provided the plane passes muster.


* The House Committee on Education and the Workforce rejected a move to permit
school vouchers--a goal of congressional Republicans--under the $ 8 billion
Title 1 program of remedial education for disadvantaged students. Nine
Republicans, including Chairman William F. Goodling (Pa.), joined with committee
Democrats to defeat an amendment proposed by Rep. Thomas E. Petri (R-Wis.), 28
to 13. Petri's plan to allow poor parents to use a per-pupil share of the money
to help pay for private school tuition or tutoring resembles a proposal made by
GOP presidential front-runner George W. Bush.

                              498 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Oklahoman

                             April 24, 2006 Monday
                                  City Edition

OKLAHOMA CITY ;
Coalition names top restaurants

BYLINE: Staff and Wire Reports

SECTION: NEWS; STATE BRIEFS; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 351 words


Two Oklahoma eateries were named 2006 Made In Oklahoma Restaurants of the Year
by the Made In Oklahoma coalition in Oklahoma City.

Molly's Landing of Catoosa and Big Belly's BBQ and Steakhouse in Slaughterville
received the award and $500 each for their efforts to promote Oklahoma products.

Julie Fitzgerald, marketing coordinator for the Oklahoma Department of
Agriculture, Food and Forestry, said the coalition named two restaurants this
year because judges felt both deserved the award.

There are about 60 restaurants in the state participating in the program.

A complete list is available on the Web at www.miocoalition.com.

STILLWATER Grants to aid small towns

The U.S. Agriculture Department's rural development initiative will provide more
than $517,000 in grant funds through the Rural Business Enterprise Grant program
to aid in the growth and development of small towns throughout Oklahoma.

Officials in Stillwater said the primary purpose of the program is to finance
and facilitate development of private business enterprises in rural Oklahoma
towns.

Six ideas were funded, ranging from incubator projects in the Panhandle to water
and sewer infrastructure in southeastern Oklahoma.

The program is eligible to public bodies, nonprofit organizations and federally
recognized Indian tribes.

The grant winners and amounts were: High Plains RC&D, Buffalo, $99,000; Guymon
Utilities Authority, $99,500; Cross Timbers RC&D, Okemah, $99,000; Frederick
Economic Development Authority, $20,000; Clayton, $100,000; and Ardmore
Development Authority, $99,900.

TULSA Annual walk set next month

The second annual "Bridging the Gap" walk will be May 6 at LaFortune Park in
Tulsa to benefit The Bridges Foundation.

Registration begins at 8 a.m. The walk starts at 9:30 a.m.

In 2005, the foundation served 165 clients with developmental disabilities, such
as cerebral palsy, Down syndrome and Asperger syndrome.

Various sponsorship levels are available for those who want to help.

For more information, contact The Bridges Foundation at 1345 N Lewis Ave.,
Tulsa, OK 74110.

The phone number is (918) 592-3333.

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *
Sitepen Inc. is a manufacturer focussed on Encapsulation, First Aid, First Aid
Kits, Loaders, Platforms, and 11 other Product & Service categories tracked by
NetWise Data. Sitepen Inc. does business in the Aerospace, Agriculture, and
Architecture Industries, as well as 17 other major Manufacturing Industries.
Sitepen Inc. has at least 2 business locations. The company describes itself via
it's website thusly: "Talk with SitePen about your custom software application
development project in complete confidence."
INDUSTRY TYPE: manufacturer; Custom Computer Programming Services
